title: From Nothing to Something (M Zurkow and Z Marsh)
description:
THIS WORKSHOP IS CLOSED AT 27 PARTICIPANTS!!!!
(Matt Miller is the last sign-up)

How do you go from a wayward spark of an idea to a fully realized
project concept? What's the path from hunch to proposal? Revamp your
creative practice with new skills and strategies for brainstorming,
ultra-rapid prototyping, and play-testing to fully explore, develop,
and direct your ideas. This session aims to change your predisposition
to sitting around and just thinking. Bring a sketchbook (paper or
otherwise) and a hunch.

title: Spatial Media
description:
Computer screens are nothing new. But what happens to the screen when
it becomes a table or a mirror or a sidewalk? How does one design for
such a screen? This course explores how interactive media can be
integrated into physical spaces and furniture through the creative use
of projectors and embedded displays. The course also examines the
multitude of questions that arise when when designing for this type of
media. Emphasis is placed on the role of spatial and social context
and the importance of relevant content within each of these
environments.  The course also provides a brief overview of the types
of technologies utilized to make this kind of project happen.

title: The Social Body
description: Interactive systems designed to live on the body can be intimate, upfront, and sometimes literally in your face. This session will focus on clothing that communicates, either through form or function, and the challenges and opportunities that the social body presents. Themes of connection, protection, extension, memory, longing, closeness and distance will be addressed through examples of work being developed in the realm of design, fashion, art, and technology.

title: Design For UNICEF
description:
In 2008, UNICEF approached ITP with an idea for a lightweight collaboration, so that ITPers could get an inside view on the issues a global NGO takes on, and so that UNICEF could see how innovators would approach such problems outside typical NGO constraints. The result was a course called Design for UNICEF.

Design for UNICEF has generated numerous ideas for new tools (a low-cost water sensor, better data gathering for family reunification after disasters, editable visual instructions for cross-cultural communications about tools) that have gone on to prototype construction and testing. Clay Shirky, who taught the first two semesters of the class, will talk about what we've learned about both development within developing-world constraints, and about collaboration with large bureaucratic organizations.

title: Pop Up Books
description: Learn paper engineering techniques and designs that can be incorporated into your work.  This workshop will be very hands-on.

title: Portfolio Review Workshop (slash n burn!) (MZ and Zannah Marsh, hosting)
description:
Get feedback on your work (re)presentation.
This is particularly for artists and designers who want fresh eyes on their portfolio and how you represent your work.

Imagine you are sending a "package" out to a prospective gallery or employer. You have been recommended to do so by a mutual friend or employer or artist, so it's not *quite * a cold call. Or it is a cold call.

Come to the session with a cover letter (ready for email or mail), an elevator pitch about your work, and a URL or physical portfolio.

We'll also look at various work samples of other artists and designers and assess.
Please bring some links to portfolios/artist web sites you admire.

The first 9 people who sign up will be active participants; after the first 9 people, you can listen but not have your work looked at :(

title: It Never Hurts to Ask
description:
This will be an informal Q & A session on developing skills and finding opportunities in the wonderful worlds of fine art: grants, commercial galleries, fundraising, marketing, ingenious workarounds...

Come with questions or discussion points.

title: Follow Your Pez Dispenser:Talk & Quick Sketching
description: Legend has it that Pierre Omidyar's wife collects Pez Dispensers and was looking for a better way to trade them...eh, voila! EBay!In this session there will be some other quirky invention stories, but most of the time will be a quick sketch/product development/brainstorming/pictionary workshop. Do you have a pet peeve ( why can't they make bandaids you could put on with one hand? a phone app that would hold the elevator door open even if you were 10 feet away?) or a pet passion you'd like to spend more time on. Bring your ideas, a sense of play. I'll bring markers and big post-it notes (Post-it notes are also a quirky invention story)

title: Augmented Reality
description:
Imagine being able to rotate around the solar system, navigate through a data set in 3D, and interact with a simulated ecosystem - all from within the palm of your hand. With Augmented Reality, it's possible! Augmented reality is a technique through which 3D virtual objects can be overlaid onto the "real world" in real-time, using nothing more than a home computer, a webcam and a printed symbol. In this 2-hour session, participants will explore Augmented Reality (AR) and how it is beginning to impact ways in which we live, work, learn and play.  We will discuss and demo a wide range of AR applications including augmented gaming, dynamic advertising, immersive learning tools and 3D data visualization.  In addition, we will spend some time building our own basic Augmented Reality experiences that can easily be deployed on any website or blog using the Adobe Flash plug-in. No prior experience with AR or Flash is necessary for the session.  However, for the hands-on portion of the session it will be necessary for participants to bring the following:
  • Laptop with a webcam (built-in or external - you can check one out of the ER if necessary)
  • A copy of Flash CS4/CS5.  You can download a free 30 day trial version of Flash at https://www.adobe.com/cfusion/tdrc/index.cfm?product=flash if you don't have your own copy.
[caption id="attachment_1936" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Augmented Reality Pop-Up Books"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_1938" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Mobile Augmented Reality"][/caption] Hey campers -
Following up on last evening's grerat AR presentation (thanks Craig!), this is a book that I think a lot of you would be very intrigued by.  Its by an author and mathematician  named Vernor Vinge, who, among other things, is credited with coining the phrase 'technological singularity', which many of you are familiar with.  He is an extremely interesting thinker (if maybe not the world's greatest writer), and he posits some very compelling possibilities for what might be done in the future with Augmented Reality in particular, and networked personal communications technology in general.
http://www.amazon.com/Rainbows-End-Vernor-Vinge/dp/0812536363/
If anyone has read it, or reads it, would love to know your thoughts.
Couldn't make the Augmented Reality session (had to check out Motion Capture), but I just wanted to plug a coupla vids I made that are very closely related to AR... Parts I & II:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jyAqrjIMmUo
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q6z8HDSIXSU
: )
_______________
Albert Hwang 253.347.9253 http://phedhex.com/

title: Making Things Talk
description:
How many electronic devices do you have that don't connect with some other device?  Your mobile phone talks to other mobile phones, your laptop, and the internet. Your camera talks to your laptop.  Your Nike+ talks to your phone and your computer. Every device talks to some other device.

Industrial designers, with some help from interaction designers, have gotten pretty good at designing interfaces for people to talk to their devices. But not enough designers understand ho things talk to each other. When you have a general understanding of how things talk, you can design them better. In this session, I'll use a laptop, an Arduino microcontroller, and a few other devices to show different communications methods.

You should have some programming experience to get the most out of this workshop.  Familiarity with microcontrollers is helpful, but not absolutely necessary.  The "Hello Arduino!" workshop will be a good intro to this one.

title: Location, Location, Location
description: Dennis Crowley of Foursquare will talk about opportunities for location based services and life in start up land.

title: Design Frontiers in Biology and Materiality
description: Biological organisms and systems are essentially living machines. Digital technologies allow us to create a control structure with computational predictability and precision. What happens, however, when designers begin to incorporate the self-determined internal control structure of a biological system as part of a design strategy? This course offers a new approach to materiality, positing that all matter is dynamic but exists within a continuum of control ranging from passively temporal (wood, water) to electronically active (photovoltaics, thermochromics) to biologically alive (plants, tissue). This course presents alternative design strategies for creating computational interfacing with living matter and state change of natural materials. Students are introduced to the world of the bio lab from a designer’s perspective, both conceptually and practically. We examine the state-of-the-art in artistic experimentation with biological systems such as the genetic manipulation projects of Eduardo Kac, or the carbon nanotubes grown into architectural structures of Ryan Wartena. We also examine more DIY approaches to living systems integration and interactivity with biological systems. Students use a hands-on approach in their design process, with biological sensing as input and indicators or material state change as an alternative method of information display, for example. This course is designed to further our computational relationship with the natural world pushing forward ideas in sustainability, interactivity, energy production and the emerging relationship between the designer/artist and the bio lab, approaching biology as an open frontier for digital design.

title: Web Tech 101
description:
How do HTML, Javascript, CSS, Ajax, PHP, Ruby, MySQL, Flash, etc. all fit together in your web applications? Come to this session to learn about a variety of technologies and how they all relate to each other.
  • Big picture overview
  • Front-end toolbox: HTML, CSS, Javascript and Flash
  • Server-side toolbox: PHP, Ruby on Rails, MySQL
  • Ajax and Comet
  • Registering a domain name (yourwebsite.com)
  • Advice and practical considerations

title: Cognitive Surplus Talk and Book Party
description: Talk and party for Clay Shirky's new book.

title: Getting Started with Wearables
description:
This session provides an introduction to tools and possibilities for working with wearables. Considering the body as both interface and display, we'll review tools and techniques for incorporating technology into clothing including working with soft circuitry and building custom sensors. Included will be an explanation and demonstration of the Lilypad hardware and an overview of conductive materials. Sensors and actuators will also be discussed. NOTES FROM THE SESSION The whiteboard: interests of the group & simple sensor/actuator circuit with Lilypad: Possible shopping lists... Basic soft circuits
  • CR2032 battery holder
  • CR2032 battery
  • conductive thread (2-ply or 4-ply large spools, or a bobbin to get you started) (also available at NYU computer store)
  • LEDs (through-hole or Lilypad)
  • Alligator clips! (available at Radio Shack)
Lilypad Arduino kit
  • Lilypad Arduino (also available at NYU computer store)
  • FTDI board
  • USB miniB cable (you probably have one of these)
  • Alligator clips! (available at Radio Shack)
  • sensor/input (photocell, accelerometer, etc.)
  • actuator/output (LEDs, vibrating motor, buzzer, speakers)
  • conductive thread (if you want to make soft circuits) (2-ply or 4-ply large spools, or a bobbin to get you started) (also available at NYU computer store)
  • power! A 2xAAA battery pack is a good option to start with.
Lilypad Resources
  • Arduino site
  • Leah Buechley's tutorials

title: Hello Android
description: Getting Started with Android Programming As promised, here is the Eclipse project that we were building last night in the Hello Android workshop: http://itp.nyu.edu/~sve204/helloandroid/HelloWorldAndroid.zip Here are the download and installation notes for Eclipse and the Android SDK: http://itp.nyu.edu/~sve204/helloandroid/download_install.html and last here is the PDF that we were working off of: http://itp.nyu.edu/~sve204/helloandroid/helloandroid.pdf

title: Hello CMS using Wordpress
description: In most cases it is crazy to make a dynamic web site from scratch.  This sessions talks about cobbling together a fully featured web site using Wordpress as a content management system (CMS) customized with  themes and plugins.

title: Hello Javascript
description: Getting started with JavaScript.  Make your web pages come alive! JavaScript 101 Notes Dynamic Example from Class (the javascript) Ajax Example from Class

title: Hello Arduino: A Physical Computing Studio
description:
Microcontrollers are cheap little chips that allow you to sense and control the physical world. In this session, I'll introduce the Arduino microcontroller as a tool for physical computing. I'll show you how to get started with Arduino, and the ins and outs of input and output.  I'll also introduce basic serial communications. If you've got experience with physical computing on other microcontrollers, this will be an easy session for you to learn a new tool.  If you're a rank beginner at this. Arduino's an easy enough platform that you'll be able to get going with it quickly. Some experience with programming would be helpful, as I'll talk about programming concepts like variables, if statements, and loops as if you know them. A few useful links:
  • The Arduino website
    • Arduino language reference page
    • Arduino examples pages
  • ITP intro to physical computing labs and tutorials
  • Tom's intro to physical computing and electronics lecture notes

title: So, You Don't Hate Flash?
description: Getting started with ActionScript 3.0. We'll take a look at working with ActionScript in Flash Professional and Flex / Flash Builder. Procedural and Object-Oriented techniques will be explored. It's okay to like Flash.

title: Maker Faire Prep
description: Meeting of people thinking of presenting at Maker Fair New York. If you've got an idea for Maker Faire in New York in September (it's Sept. 25 and 26), then come along and let's talk about it.  Get advice on how to make it, how to submit for Maker Faire, how to prep, and so forth.  Many folks at ITP have been to a number of Maker Faires, so we can give you an idea of what to expect.  Also, we'd like to see ITP represent at MF:NYC!

title: Smartphone Studio
description: Working on an application for a smartphone (iPhone, Android, Nokia)?  Come to this studio for hands on help.

title: Physical Computing Studio
description: This is an ongoing studio session for people who have physical computing projects in mind.  There's no set agenda to it, just an open workshop for makers.  Someone from staff will be on hand each session to answer questions, offer advice, and suggest resources.  But mostly it's a chance to build stuff in a convivial setting. Think of it as a knitting circle for physical computing.

title: A Giant Group Project
description: Let's make something together - a giant collaboration that creates a collage of images input from campers phones projected on all the walls of the lounge.  It should have may gratuitous features using cell phones, heart beats, motors.  It also should use dry ice.   This does not exist and needs to be invented by campers.  Please leave comments about what you think it should be.

title: Total Eclipse
description:
Learn how Eclipse can make your coding life easier. This tutorial
will focus on developing Processing in Eclipse using the Proclipsing
plugin and give some introductions to some Java basics. However,
Eclipse can be a valuable tool for PHP, C++, Action Script, etc.
Eclipse Plugins allow you to have access to version control, build
tools, and DB development. Chances are, if you want to do some sort of
programming,

title: Processing Physics
description: An overview of physics simulation in Processing. The Nature of Code site Vectors Tutorial Forces Tutorial Box2D tutorial Toxiclibs tutorial Craig Reynolds Steering Behaviors Books: The Computational Beauty of Nature: Computer Explorations of Fractals, Chaos, Complex Systems, and Adaptation Mathematics and Physics for Programmers (Game Development Series) Head First Physics: A learner's companion to mechanics and practical physics (AP Physics B - Advanced Placement)

title: Evolutionary Computing
description: An overview of Genetic Algorithms and applications in Processing. Tutorial / handout: http://www.shiffman.net/teaching/nature/ga (also more on the ecosystem example: http://www.shiffman.net/2007/03/27/single-parent-ecosystem/) Sims Evolved Virual Creatures: http://www.karlsims.com/evolved-virtual-creatures.html http://www.karlsims.com/papers/siggraph94.pdf http://www.karlsims.com/papers/alife94.pdf Sims Galápagos: http://www.karlsims.com/galapagos/index.html Sims Paper on "Interactive Selection" technique: http://karlsims.com/papers/siggraph91.html Mona Lisa Project: http://rogeralsing.com/2008/12/07/genetic-programming-evolution-of-mona-lisa/ A ton of links/resources (many probably outdated): http://www.red3d.com/cwr/evolve.html Books with material on genetic algorithms: Computational Beauty of Nature Mathematics and Physics for Programmers Evolutionary Design by Computers session video

title: Physical Computing for Kids
description:
Teach your kids physical computing.  We will be learning a little bit about sound, then making contact mics and amplifying various objects. We will also make battery operated mini LED lamps.

Parents: Materials will be provided, but if you can bring your own pliers and wire strippers that would be helpful. Otherwise - we can share.

title: Urban Interventions
description:
This session is about getting you excited about the city as a platform  for your work.  The city offers inspiration, interaction, networks,  connections, strangers, an audience, narrative, vitality.  From  highlighting the unseen to making something completely outlandish seem  perfectly normal, urban public space offers room to play, to subvert, to  express your creativity in new ways.  The session will be  less about  presenting existing work (although some may be covered), and more about  getting  out there and getting comfortable and inspired.  We will do several  activities that will involve interacting with strangers, noticing, and  leaving our mark on urban public space. It will be an adventure!

Participants: please please bring a digital camera with you to this session.  One of the activities will involve a camera for each participant.  There may be a few in the ER, but definitely not enough for everyone.

title: Building a Large Multi-touch
description: How to build a large multi-touch screen?  Why we need a larger multi-touch screen, since most of us have smart devices that uses touch as an input? This session includes information about different techniques to build the physical part, camera based tracking for multi-touch screens, some libraries that you can use for multi-touch programming. Also, I want to have a group discussion on innovative/ergonomic ways to interact with this devices and some possible software applications.

title: Foursquare API
description: Walk through making a Foursquare app from scratch.

title: Ready, FIRE!, Aim.
description:
Learn the correct order of things you need to do to take your idea and create a technology business.  We will review the key elements that you need to address to be successful: Pain (that your customer/potential customer is feeling doing things the way they do them now), Friction (the pain caused by changing or doing something new) and Grease (the benefit you provide your customer/user).  Other topics include:

·         Chickens and Eggs – what comes first?
·         Ideas vs Execution
·         Developing a product
·         Toll booths in the desert –how can you charge for your project.

title: Motion Capture for Animation
description: Meet next door south 715 Broadway, 12th Floor for a demo and discussion with a state of the art motion capture studio.  We are hoping to have you walk away with data of body motions that you can use in your animations or visualizations.

title: Extreme [Programmable] Environments
description:
Integrating technology in the very make up of furniture, walls, ceilings, and building engineering systems reveals vast implications for how we design our future habitats.
Today, the speed of adoption of technology is far greater than what our current environments can absorb. But what if our physical environments could be reprogrammed and dynamically change after construction ends? What if information became a design material or our work environments transform, and do so while reducing the environmental impact of change? And, what if the inhabitants of a space could be its co-designers, in real space and real time?
My presentation will be framed around my work in Programmable Environments and advanced R&D projects at Herman Miller. I will share learning in built project sites and prototype spaces while testing “extreme” conditions and lead users.

title: Office Hours
description:
Sign up here:

http://www.doodle.com/inqz3wmaxbdte62m

title: Social Television - Enjoying broadcasts together in realtime
description:
In this session we will talk about TV as a broadcast medium, some history of the use of social behaviors, technologies (digital and analog), and take a look at the various apps that are working on connecting social behavior to TV.

We will examine the reality of online Video distribution, the effect of the internet and video on demand on real time TV watching, and the growing usage of real time connectivity between  fans, shows and broadcasters to create excitement and deliver value to both passive and active viewers.

title: Laser Cutting for Graphic Designers
description:
This class will begin with a tour of the Advanced Media Studios and then head back to ITP to learn how to use Adobe Illustrator CS4 to create precise design files to be used with the AMS laser cutter. Direction will focus on tool set, best practices, and how to work with the AMS template. The Advanced Media Studios is located at 35 West 4th Street. Enter the building, show the guard your ID and walk up the steps to the second floor. AMS is located through the second set of double doors. You do not need to swipe your card. ATTENTION: CLASS WILL BEGIN AT 35 WEST 4th STREET. We will then return to ITP for the second half of the class. Here are a few resources that relate to AMS:
  • AMS website
  • Laser Service Guide
  • Laser Service Template for CS2/CS3
  • Laser Service Template for CS4
You will need to set up an appointment to have your file approved and priced before it can be cut. To set up an appointment, send an email to its.rp@nyu.edu. In the email include your name and your availability for the following week. I find it is always best to be gracious when dealing with AMS, they tend to receive a lot of pushy customers and will be more than willing to work with you if you are nice. Files for demo: Final Jig CS4 Working Jig CS4

title: Taking Wearable Technologies to Market
description:
In the past few years a storm of wearable electronic projects has
appeared along with countless DYI blogs and books. At the same time
the successful commercial products in the same area can be counted in
one hand. Why this disconnect? The answer is multi-fold and touches
every aspect of a product development-to-store lifecycle.

This 2-hour session will start with a brief history of wearable
technologies and then examine in detail all the barriers to entry,
challenges and opportunities in the area.

title: Object Oriented Programming
description:
For people with basic Java programming knowledge, I will present more
advanced principles of code organization and Object Oriented design
that might be useful in their projects, particularly as their software
grows in size and abstraction.

I'll present topics on OO topics such as encapsulation, inheritance,
interfaces, generics, polymorphism, abstract types, and others in the
context of building a large (multiple-object) Processing sketch in Java.

I can also present Design Patterns used in software architecture,
such as Command, Strategy, Chain of Command, etc.

title: Email Apnea
description: Let me know if you have any further questions. Description below! We probably have 3 hours of content for you — 4 pm to 7 pm, on June 17. Hope to see you there! mail Apnea: http://oreil.ly/aBFE1t This will be an informal session, with Linda and friends, Fred Muench and Steven Dean, in 3 parts: Part One (Linda Stone) What is email apnea? What are the cognitive, attentional, emotional and physiological implications? What can be done (what technologies are applicable, what’s out there, what might be developed)? How does email apnea foreshadow a new post-productivity era in our relationship with computers, one where human performance and embodied computing contribute to a healthier co-creative relationship between humans and technology. Some show and tell, most likely toward the end of the session (HeartMath emWave and Desktop software, StressEraser, Autonomic Biometer) Check out http://www.LindaStone.net or articles by me on the Huffington Post on email apnea, are we at war with technology, etc. Part Two (Frederick Muench, Ph.D.) Fred is a clinical psychologist and a Senior Research Associate at the National Center for Addictions and Substance Abuse at Columbia University.  He is the founder of Mobile Health Interventions, a mobile messaging and health company.  Previously, he served as the Director of Clinical Research and Development at an ambulatory biofeedback company.  He has held faculty positions at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and NYU.  He recently founded the new Special Interest Group, Technology and Behavior Change, within the Association for Behavioral and Cognitive Therapies. (ABCT) The presentation will primarily focus on the following: What happens when we breathe—what are the effects throughout the body? What is the research on impaired breathing?  What is the research on therapeutic breathing?  How can biofeedback and simple phone apps help? Keeping it up- maintaining motivation to stay healthy through mobile. Part Three (Steven Dean) Steven offered a QS (Quantified Self) course on June 6 (see that description) For our session, Steven will review some of the material from the QS session, and will discuss QS and email apnea. Other special guests who may be hanging out with us include Christina Cacioppo, USV analyst, and Tomas Sander, HP Researcher and Chair of the Working Group on Positive Computing.

title: Representing Earth
description: (and why camera cars are here to stay) Representing Earth, actual places at actual moments, presents unique opportunities and challenges. Unlike fantasy places, Earth has a "ground truth" frame of reference, indexed by latitude, longitude, altitude, and time. Hence all potential Earth models can cross correlate into a singular unimaginably giant Earth model, containing as much detail as is chosen to add. The big players know it and the field is lively. Advances and new features spring up weekly - based on novel camera rigs, automated image morphing, crowd-sourced 3D modeling, live webcams and other sensors, and immersive displays. So have critical concerns - around access, control, privacy, and authenticity. The artist and activist communities know this as well. This presentation is based on a recent visiting faculty seminar at ITP, which attempted to make sense out of this fast-moving and uncharted domain. http://itp.nyu.edu/RepresentingEarth/

title: Native smartphone apps via PhoneGap
description:
Wanna make a native application for the iPhone, Android, WebOS, or even WindowsMobile and Blackberry?  Sounds like a lot of work, right?  What if I told you you could use nearly the exact same code for each platform to create NATIVE applications (i.e. access the accelerometer, GPS, play audio, etc.)...using your knowledge of HTML and javascript?  This is PhoneGap!

In this session, I'll show you how to use the opensource PhoneGap project (http://phonegap.com) to generate native applications.  PhoneGap apps are great for quickly prototyping, but the applications are also high-performance and fully compliant with each platform's distribution requirements (yes, even Apple will approve your app).

title: The Seeing Hand
description:
Get closer to your seeing experiences by learning/enjoying blind drawing technique.

Live model(s).

Hands on session :)

3 hours, join any time.

No previous drawing experience necessary.

Enjoy!

title: The Listening & Seeing Hand: Field Trip
description:
Drawing field trip to Bang on a Can Marathon at World Financial Center Winter Garden, NYC

Join us any time: the marathon is from noon till midnight. It's a beautiful spacey place and usually a lot of people come in. If you are planning to stay for 12 hours, bring yoga mat -- you can listen to live music meditating ;)

Regroup/recharge before the show!

title: Cross Pollination: Field Trip
description:
Mix dance/movement with drawing.  Participate to creative process (or just watch) and share the energy.

Bring your art supplies and musical instruments and wear comfortable clothes. No shoes. $5 fee for the space.

title: Taking Care of Parents
description: Discussion of ideas for using technology to help take care of aging parents. (Bring your lunch if you want). Electronics for Taking Care of Mom Mom has demetia, old, dc, Jitterbug A/V Support Medicine Food--Online Grocery Delivery Emailing my sisters Tracking Scheduling Activities Reminders Kindle - shared reading Remote Desktop Social Television

title: Physical Interaction Crit
description: Working on a project involving physical interaction?  This session is a chance to get feedback on how it turned out or how it's coming along.

title: Makers: Make with Better Stuff
description: Secret tricks for learning about how stuff is made. Be a responsible maker: know where your stuff comes from, who makes it, how it affects the earth and the people that make and use it, how to use it best, and where it should go when it's time for it to no longer be usable stuff. You'll never look at making the same way again.

title: Electronics for PComp
description: UPDATE A small slide deck from the session is here.  Topics include tools, suppliers, and resources. We'll cover basic electricity and electronics, focusing on their application to physical computing. Topics to include electronic principles, components, debugging, and tools and techniques. The session will be pretty freeform - add a comment below if there's anything in particular you'd like to see covered.

title: Pre-show physical computing help session
description: Bring your broken or never-working physical computing projects for a little debugging TLC.  We'll have tools and parts on hand to diagnose, debug, and (hopefully!) fix any projects that need help.

title: Gardening With Gadgets
description: Practical information for garden hackers including basics of drip irrigation, super-lightweight soil mixtures for rooftop growing, and growing indoors hydroponically. I'll also talk about my current research into using Arduino and Processing to gather data from and control water and fertilizer systems for my rooftop chile garden. Check out http://brooklynchiles.com/gardengadgets/gardengadgets.html for photos and links to sources.

title: Zen Proposals
description:
This work follows on from Marina Zurkow's 'It Never Hurts to Ask,' which is an informal Q&A about funding for the arts.

This session will help you develop better project proposals. It will begin with a presentation covering basic principles and pitfalls, including tips for better copywriting and for understanding the psychology of the funder. This will be followed by a hothaus-style proposal development workshop. If you have project ideas and proposals in progress, please bring them, but this is by no means a requirement.

title: The Art of the Scrape
description:
You have no data.  The internet has lots of data.  This does not seem fair! Art of the Scrape is a quick and dirty intro to getting data off the web and into your application where it belongs!  We'll talk about data scraping, grabbing, parsing, juggling, and plain all out messing with websites and rss feeds.   We may even tackle the mosquito-ridden swamp of api's. Coding is going to be in PHP, but all that students will need is some basic knowledge of any coding language.  Show the internet who's boss!  Scrape it! 
http://www.binaryspark.com/Scrape/examples.zip
http://www.binaryspark.com/Scrape/Art-of-the-scrape.pdf

title: Don't be a jerk, share your code.
description: An introduction to the philosophy of free and open-source software development and hands on skills in how to collaborate on code using GIT. Hour 1: Answers to the questions: What is Free Software? Why should I care? I'm selfish, how is this going to help me? Hour 2: Answers to the questions: What is GIT? Why should I care? Ok, I'm impressed, now how do I use it? That's interesting, can I try? Hour 3: Answers to the questions: Ok, this is a lot to take in, can I just have some time to actually try this out on a sample project while everyone is in the room? Your Workshop Leader is artist and Eyebeam Senior Fellow, Steve Lambert. I have developed several free open source projects like add-art, wpfolio, and self-control. Since 2006 I have released all of my work with open licenses. Despite all this I am neither poor or unsuccessful. Do not be afraid. Various tutorials: http://learn.github.com/ http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/tools-and-tips/terminal-git-and-github-for-the-rest-of-us-screencast/ http://a.parsons.edu/~zeravivm/s10/osd/joanrho/05/07/git-for-designers/ We got Git here: http://code.google.com/p/git-osx-installer/ and gitx here: http://gitx.frim.nl/

title: Kick Off
description:
This is a gathering to kick off the camp.
  • See the other campers
  • Learn about the idea of an UnConference
  • Look around ITP and hear how it works.
  • Have a Drink.
  • Make a Lanyard(not really).
This orientation, like all the events, is completely optional.

title: A Year in Afghanistan: Design & Development
description: I came back to NY this January after having spent a year in Kabul working as the Business Development Director at Turquoise Mountain,  an NGO founded at the request of  The Prince of Wales and Hamid Karzai with the "aim is to revive Afghanistan's traditional crafts, and to regenerate Murad Khane, a historic area of Kabul's old city known for its rich cultural heritage." The experience keeps informing my thinking and part of it is still unfinished: what would I have done different, which parts of the "designer" in me kicked in, what does it mean to develop products and work with craftspeople and aspiring entrepreneurs in one of the most conflicted and conflict ridden parts of the world? What systems can easily (what is "easily") be put in place? What is the role of design and of emerging technologies in reconstruction efforts and "capacity building"?

title: Game Design in Social Media
description: A topic of special interest to me for the past couple of years has been how many creators of social media applications have been looking to the world of game design for ideas. Badges and points are becoming quite common, but there are a bunch of much more interesting ideas being explored along these lines right now -- and as apps need to differentiate themselves further and reach into newer social spaces, I expect this subject will flourish in the coming years. I'd like to go over a few of my thoughts on the matter and share some interesting examples and have an open discussion. I gave a talk at SXSW on a similar subject, which you're welcomed to check out here, as well: http://auscillate.com/writing/xbox_ux

title: Advice For Tech Novices
description: There is a lot of acronyms and jargon in the schedule for this camp.  This may be a little off-putting for novices to tech.  The good news is that you can pick up the lingo pretty quickly and you only have to learn the bits that serve your project.  The bad news is that learning how to use the technology behind these names can take a long time.  In this session we will try to figure out where you need to focus your learning efforts.

title: Intro to Making Things Move
description: In this 1.5 hour session we'll talk about motors, torque, and how things move.  Then we'll open in up into a studio/discussion so we can talk about the ideas of the participants and how we can turn them into reality.  You can come just for the how-to and discussion, but you'll get more out of it you have a real project idea in mind that could benefit from what you'll learn. Here's a link to my blog post for the class that contains notes and more links

title: Doing cool stuff with MTA Data
description: Sarah Kaufman (Intelligent Transportation Systems Coordinator  at MTA New York City Transit) and Corey Menscher (Resident Researcher at ITP) will be discussing the multitude of data being provided by the MTA, and explore some of the cool applications that have been created using open public transporation data in other cities.

title: The Future of Music Entrepreneurship
description: A discussion of the past, present and future of entrepreneurship in the music business, led by Jason King, the artistic director of NYU's innovative Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music.

title: Communicating Business Ethnography
description:
Business ethnography combines intense observation with analysis and communication. In this workshop, we’ll spend about a half hour talking about how to do business ethnography, using digital cameras and/or note pads. Participants will choose from a list of cooperating stores/restaurants/etc in the ITP vicinity, and spend about 45 minutes gathering notes and photos. When everyone returns to ITP, we’ll process the findings and then post them to a digital web site – maybe a ning site, or a site that ITP already uses. What are we looking for? Our goal is to prepare a type of digital business map of the area, focusing particularly on how these businesses achieve their goals or promises to consumers.

<input id="gwProxy" type="hidden" /><input id="jsProxy" onclick="jsCall();" type="hidden" />

title: The Role of Media in Exhibition Design at the American Museum of Natural History
description: David Harvey is the head of exhibitions at the American Museum of Natural History. In this discussion he will talk about the role of media in creating environments. He will talk about the history of media at the AMNH and show some examples from recent exhibitions. He will also show plans for the upcoming exhibit on The Brain.

title: An Introduction to Usability Testing
description:
An opportunity for anyone who has a product whether it is a software application, website, or even a physical device to learn about usability testing.

This session will cover basic concepts in usability testing. Why should you do it? How often should you do it? What resources do you need to conduct a usability test?

If you would like to use this session as an opportunity to perform a live test with participants, please feel free to bring your product, whatever it is, and use the class as your own testing ground.

The session is meant to be informal and fun.

title: A Magazine at the Electronic Threshold
description:
strategy+business is a quarterly management magazine with 115,000
print and 340,000 web audience members - and we're trying to build our
influence online. In the process we're coming up against many of the
issues facing publications online, including the evolution of
advertising, the dynamics (and ethics) of lead generation, the
expectations of readers online (vs. offline) and the evolution of
circulation numbers. In this seminar-style workshop, editor-in-chief
Art Kleiner and publisher Jonathan Gage lay out the issues facing us,
and lead the group in talking through the implications and options.
We'll explore the decisions we've made and the reasons for them, and
open the floor to talking about what we could do going forward, and
why. How should a leading-edge magazine (in terms of content) think
about the formats and business models of the next few years?

title: One-on-One: Proposal Review & Editing Help
description: I will be available from 3-6 to review, crit and help edit any written document....proposal business plan, grant, story, poem.... email me at: nancy.hechinger@nyu.edu to sign up for a specific time.

title: Open Government Data: How To
description: Government agencies, from NYC to Data.gov to the World Bank are releasing reams and reams of statistical data in a mish mash of formats, with mixed results. How do you work with this stuff? How good is it really for visualizations or decision systems? What are common development issues? How should an technology-facilitated government work? Most data is about results, sometimes years late. What else do we need to make good judgments about these institutions which are ours? This session will be half a How-To for a few data sources, and open discussion with you. Bring ideas and questions, examples. Links: http://www.begoodnow.com/itpcamp/ http://delicious.com/goodness/itpcamp

title: Co-creative Art in the Digital Age
description: Mass customization, production on demand, open innovation, co-creative design, tele-fabrication, robotics and other computer-driven technologies are re-defining how things are made in nearly every sector of the global marketplace. It's inevitable that they will affect how art is produced as well. This session will review the various production techniques available to creatives; show work by contemporary artists using these techniques; and generate discussion about the implications of what can be called the New Industrialism on the creative disciplines. Topics for additional discussion can include the potential democratization of the art marketplace; the dissolution of conventional notions and myths about what art is; and the rise of new venues for creating, collecting and thinking about contemporary art.

title: Digital Democracy, Hand-Held Human Rights
description: Mark Belinsky, co-founder of Digital Democracy, will talk about the efforts of this young non-profit that has done extraordinary work in some of the most repressive societies in the world, focusing on how the access to technologies like cellphones, is a powerful human rights tool. He will also talk about how mapping & media can help save lives under repression or during a crisis..

title: Numerical Narratives
description: Self-tracking methods, Feltron Annual Reporting techniques and discussion.

title: Quantified Self
description:
In September, 2008 a small group of folks gathered at Kevin Kelly's house in Pacifica, CA to share about different ways they use data and measurement for self-knowledge. People using science upon themselves. I'll take you through the short history of Quantified Self, with some highlights from the meetups on the West and East Coast, and then we'll do an interactive session where we each get to share and explore our own interests in self-tracking. Some stuff people are interested in:
  • actionable measurements
  • mood and emotions
  • health and biometric data
  • devices and gadgets
  • lifelogging, lifestreaming
  • using geocoding for self-analysis
  • visualizing data
  • and lots more
How have you incorporated tracking and measurements in your life? Where do you do your research and get your ideas? How do you extract meaning from all the data you have or might capture? What data would you be willing to share with others? Can we learn too much about ourselves? Are these self-absorbed pursuits? Thanks for coming out ya'll! Great discussion. Let's pick up and continue the discussion on what "awareness" we lose as we move away from self-tracking to more ambient tracking. What do we lose? What do we gain? Linda Stone, Fred Muench and I will be there on the 17th. Linda will lead off with email apnea and we'll talk more about self-tracking & ambient tracking and we'll test out some bio-feedback devices. Bring some of your works-in-progress in and we'll incorporate your projects into the session. See you on the 17th! Quantified Self Resources & Links Quantified Self (QS) NYC QS Meetup http://www.meetup.com/NYQuantifiedSelf/ Bay Area Quantified Self Show & Tell Meetup http://www.meetup.com/quantifiedself QS blog http://quantifiedself.com QS group on Vimeo (77 videos) http://vimeo.com/groups/17842 Gary's article in the NY Times http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/02/magazine/02self-measurement-t.html Stuff that came up… Toggle time tracking http://www.toggl.com/ Nicholas Felton & Ryan Case's project Daytum.com Maira Kalman's piece on Ben Franklin http://kalman.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/30/can-do/ Sam Huleatt, Mike Singleton & Eric Friedman, tracking meals with http://eat.ly Jake's http://WeHaveStandards.com Jamie Pennebaker and linguistic analysis http://www.liwc.net/liwcresearch07.php http://analyzewords.com/ SenseCam http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/um/cambridge/projects/sensecam/ 24 Hours of Lemons http://www.24hoursoflemons.com/ Finally, here is the link to the Microsoft SenseCam reborn as the ViconRevue: https://www.viconrevue.com/home.html

title: Observing/Interacting with African Diaspora Communities
description:
UPDATE:

I am leaving my initial description below, and providing a little bit more context on my talk today. There will be snacks if anyone needs enticement besides the topic and the guests.

My sister, Dr. Sekai Chideya holds a MPH. She's worked for the Centers for Disease Control's Epidemic Intelligence Service and the New York City Department of Health, focused on AIDS and TB studies domestically and internationally. I have worked for companies including ABC, CNN, Newsweek, NPR; I'm now getting ready to pilot a new public radio/digial program. Together she and I will talk about the different ways in which we have brokered honest discussions and gotten the best data given issues/tensions of race and  diasporic identity between investigators/interviewers and subjects. Working as a journalist (me, Farai) and as a public health researcher (Sekai) has brought us into contact with people who may be suspicious of us; overly deferential; or any number of emotional/social relations that have to be worked through in order for us to do good work.

We look forward to having a conversation that deals not only with the African Diaspora communities, but also with the entire construct of the observer and the observed, and of data gathering in the field...

Best,
F

======= former description ============

Various parts of the African diaspora, from urban American communities to vast stretches of rural areas throughout the Continent, are being used as spaces to experiment. That includes everything from crowdsourcing content; building new revenue-sharing models for assets from oil to wind; and performing public health interventions.

Innovation is good, but/and if there's a disconnect between innovators and community, you can have big problems. I'd like to give a personal and professional perspective on things I've learned from interacting with African diaspora communities; and things I've learned from being part of two different ones.

I'm black American by birth and upbringing; my father was also Zimbabwean and I have a lot of ties in Southern Africa and go back every 3 years. I have shot some documentary footage in Zimbabwe and almost had it confiscated by the secret police. When I go into a low-income black community in the U.S., or an African-American celebrity event, or a gay black male social space, I am an insider in some ways, an outsider in others.

I suspect some of you are exploring not only technology but the power relationship between "observer" and "observed." (We are all observed, but not all document their observations publicly.) I think people who want to work either with Africanas or Afro-diasporic communities in the US (from black American to Haitian-American and even Cuban- and Puerto Rican-American) might want to have a conversation.

More on me at faraichideya.com

title: Sensors and Interface Board--Easy!
description:
Workshop Web Page:

www.elasticmind.com/itp

Hagstrom Electronics makes a wonderful interface board for about $70. that makes it really easy to plug input from almost any sensor into an existing or custom computer program.  http://www.hagstromelectronics.com/products/kead6.html This session will demonstrate how to use sensors and this board to input sensor data into a program you create, or an existing one.  The board takes up to 6 sensors simultaneously, and outputs dynamic sensor values as keystrokes into the USB port.  So, for example, your simple photocell is wired into channel 1, and you program the board to return keystrokes "a","b","c "and "d" depending on how much light the photocell "sees".  Once programmed, the board monitors the photocell and sends back the corresponding keystroke when the light level changes.  If you program the board to return keystrokes like the arrow keys (UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT) then the board can feed these keystrokes into any program that is expecting the user to hit these keys for control of an object.  So it's really easy to retrofit an existing program or game to accept user input from sensors.  Typical sensors that work include photocells, switches, Sharp IR distance ranging sensor, force sensors, pots, etc.  I will bring a variety of sensors and some boards and we will program them.  The board will function autonomously on either PC or Mac, but must be programmed on a PC.  Once programmed with a configuration of keystrokes matching sensor values, the board can hold that program permanently (until you want to reprogram it for another project).  This is a really easy and fun way to integrate sensors into your project without coding a more complex microcontroller.

title: UX: Rapid Application Prototyping for Mobile and Web
description: So you have a fantastic idea for a mobile or web application. First, congratulations for coming up with your wonderful idea. Second…please oh please, do not first launch into Photoshop to create a beautiful interface that may or may not work or even worse, start coding before your idea has been fully incubated. Take it back to a higher level. Sketch it out. Test it. Make mistakes, correct them and then do it all over again but go into more detail. This is rapid prototyping. It will help you illustrate proof of concept, sell your ideas, save time and provide you with a better product in the end. This workshop will provide you with tips, tricks and solid process recommendations on how to do this effectively using pencils, paper, software and simple communication to help you get there. I'll mix in personal war stories of horrible interfaces, disaster projects, designers, coders and clients gone wild. I promise this will be collaborative, informative and fun. UPDATE: I would like to thank everyone who came Wednesday to hear my overview of an aspect of the User Experience process of rapid application prototyping.  As promised, here are some additional links that I may have made reference to during my session. If you have any more questions or need help refining your ideas during camp, I'll be happy to help out. My Contact Information: Dan Kawasaki dkawasaki@gmail.com/dan.kawasaki@ogilvy.com Partner, Associate Director of Information Architecture Ogilvy & Mather GOOD READS Boxes and Arrows A good source of article and discussion about documentation, presentation, prototypes and wireframing http://boxesandarrows.com/ Konigi Good Blog for UX news and resources. http://konigi.com/ A List Apart Another good resource of articles and information http://www.alistapart.com/ COMMUNITY Interaction Design Association (IxDA) Meetups (good parties), UX community and jobs http://www.ixda.org/ ACM's SIGCHI Old-school HCI group (requires paid membership) http://www.sigchi.org/ For more links and resources not highlighted here: http://wiki.fluidproject.org/display/fluid/UX+Resources COMMERCIAL WIREFRAMING TOOLS OmniGraffle Mac equivalent to Visio that produces nice diagrams. $99-199 - 14 day free trial http://www.omnigroup.com/products/omnigraffle/ Mac OS X and iPad Visio More technical too from Microsoft that IAs use commonly. $259-559.00/60-day free trial http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/visio/default.aspx PC Only Adobe InDesign Some user swear by this.  I have not played with it. http://www.adobe.com/products/indesign/ Mac and PC PROTOTYPING TOOLS Mockingbird (in beta) Free! http://gomockingbird.com/ Balsamiq Mockups $79.00 http://www.balsamiq.com/ Mac and PC Axure RP Pro My tool de jour. It is growing in popularity. $589.00 - 30 day free trial http://www.axure.com Mac and PC iMockUps for iPad $9.95 http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/imockups/id364885913?mt=8

title: Design something that solves a problem
description: The James Dyson Award applications are due July 1st, and the general requirement is just to "design something that solves a problem."  For example, the 2008 winner made a jacket that communicated a bicycle rider's intention to turn by embedding flashing lights in the sleeves of a jacket. In this section I'll  introduce the award and lead a brainstorming session to identify opportunities for innovation.  Then we can discuss the steps needed to solve the problems we identify, and you can attend or suggest other sessions for the camp based on the skills you need to learn to implement your ideas. Here are the notes for the section, and here is the list I made of everyone's ideas on how to solve the problem of forgetting to buy toilet paper.

title: Social Design: Transforming Storytelling into Storysharing
description:
Social Design: Transforming Storytelling into Storysharing Social media, Obama, and the recession have shifted our focus from me to we, from publishing to participation. Where we once told stories to shape values and propel action, this presentation explores how to effectively share stories, build communities & offer incentives to participate. Questions Considered. 1. What is Social Design? 2. What are the implications of the shift from publishing to participation? 3. What are the best practices of social design? 4. What are some examples/case studies? 5. How do you build engaging communities and incentives to participate? What tools might help? 6. What role does transparency and social capital play? 7. What happens to stories, and their value, in the transformation of storytelling into storysharing? 8. Is this all idle manipulation?
  1. How We Decide, Jonah Lehrer http://amzn.to/9Kjdv7
  2. Why We Buy by Paco Underhill  http://amzn.to/bQo88C
  3. Predictably Irrational by Dan Ariely http://amzn.to/bkXru3
  4. the Upside of Irrationality by Dan Ariely http://bit.ly/aOQZ5e
  5. Storytelling for User Experience  www.rosenfeldmedia.com/books/storytelling <http://rosenfeldmedia.com/books/storytelling> You can get a discount on the book if you use the discount code:  WHITNEYKEVIN
  6. Your Brain is Almost Perfect, Read Montague, http://amzn.to/aIWBmr (out of print, but in stock now...or also on half.com...) (Dan, I bought you a copy last week...:)
  7. Why People Work, Aaron Levenstein  http://amzn.to/do9Pjm ( out of print...and not sure you need to buy it, but if you want too its avail used here and on half.com) (will also be discussed at greater length in my session tomorrow)
I also mentioned the LIveScribe (www.livescribe.com) and the Brinno GardenWatch Camera http://amzn.to/9cf7Fi I'll have both with me at Camp this week and next.  Let me know if you'd like to check 'em out:) Thank you all; this experience has been a privilege and delight to share with you all!  May it never end!!!

title: Why People Work
description:
Today, as transparency changes the economy and our understanding of value, we are re-thinking how and why we work, and whether work is a reflection of passion, or something you must be paid to do. Can business systems, processes and structures offer greater incentives for participation, efficiency and maybe happiness?

Questions Discussed:

1. Why do people work? What is work?

2. How is this changing?

3. Why is the value and meaning of work changing?

4. How does social media impact work?

5. How does transparency impact how we work and how it is valued?

6. What new processes and structures hold most promise?

7. How can we change and build incentives to work and participate?

8. Can work be kept as a separate identity?

9. What can I do to prepare myself for the future?

title: Smartphone Studio
description: Developing an app for a smartphone?  Come to this studio session for hands on help.

title: Hello Android
description: Get started programming for Android mobile phones.

title: Shop Safety for Campers
description: Learn how to keep the shop clean... and how not to cut off fingers! Every person who plans to use the shop is required by law to attend a safety session. We can accommodate up to 12 people per session

title: Sustainable Artist 101
description:
Want to be make your way as an artist? Entrepreneur? Activist? Inventor? Then you will need a good plan, some money, committed partners, and a communications strategy. We can't get you all that in one session but this this 2 hour workshop will help you develop language, skills, and materials to use in proposals and pitches. And, we'll talk about how to develop relationships with individuals and organizations that will help sustain your work...and you.
First of all, a recent NYTimes article with resources for artists gives artists props for increasing the cultural value (and tax revenue) of the city:
http://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/19/arts/design/19profit.html?hp
The book I referenced in class is The Artist’s Guide: How to Make a Living Doing What You Love by Jackie Battenfield.
http://www.artistcareerguide.com/
This book covers everything from planning and budgeting to documenting your work and written communications.
Creative Capital runs professional development workshops and internet/communications workshops.
Their schedule is here: http://creative-capital.org/events/index/category:3
And they have created a wiki called Internet for Artists
http://ifa.wikispot.org/
Other resources for NYC-based artists:
New York City Economic Development Corporation (www.nycedc.com)
New York Foundation for the Arts (http://www.nyfa.org)

title: HTML5 101
description:
HTML5 has received a lot of press lately as the technology that will
transform the web from a document-based model into an app-based one.
This session will show examples of how using HTML5 will enable users
to interact with web-apps in ways never before possible.

title: Measuring Biological Signals for Art and Business (and anything in between)
description: We'll discuss what types of biological signals you can measure from the body using simple circuitry, what information they can tell you about mental and physical states, and how bio-signals can be integrated into art, fashion, games, toys, social media, medical devices, sports equipment and various types of other applications. See http://produceconsumerobot.com/ITPcamp2010/ for more information.

title: Heart Happy: How to monitor your EKG
description:
The heart is a powerful symbol that has inspired mythology in civilizations throughout history. The beating of your heart -- your overall pulse rate as well as changes in rate and inter-beat variability -- carries intimate information about your mental and physical state that can be used in art, fashion and industry.
In this workshop, we'll cover the conceptual and practical considerations for monitoring your pulse using simple electronics. As an example of an easy method for pulse detection, we'll use an off-the-shelf chip (Polar RMCM01) for measuring heart beat information sent from various Polar heart straps and transmitters.
No knowledge of biology or engineering will be assumed. Some basic level of comfort implementing circuits on a breadboard is optimal, but all are welcome.
For more information, see http://produceconsumerobot.com/ITPcamp2010/
UPDATE: I will have 12 kits available for $10 each offered to the first 12 people that show up to the session. Once the kits are "sold out", folks may buddy-up with someone who has a kit. IN ADDITION to the things in the kit, YOU MUST BRING the following to participate: 1) breadboard + wire jumpers 2) 2 AA batteries 3) 2x AA battery holder with wire leads (don't bring a 4x holder... it will fry the chip) These can be purchased at Radioshack or the NYU computer store on Mercer and Greene St. The following will also be helpful if you can bring them: 1) soldering iron 2) tweezers 3) wire cutters

title: Exposing Emotional Arousal: How to measure GSR
description:
The galvanic skin response (GSR) is a measure of increased emotional arousal that is commonly used in lie detector tests. Generated by fast acting sweat glands that are tied into the arousal systems of your body (like adrenaline), the GSR reveals a powerful view of ongoing changes in your psyche that is otherwise invisible to the naked eye.
In this workshop, we'll cover the conceptual and practical considerations of monitoring your GSR using simple electronics and create an easy-to-assemble breadboard circuit that may be used to display GSR on an LED or as input to a microcontroller.
No knowledge of biology or engineering will be assumed. Some basic level of comfort implementing circuits on a breadboard is optimal, but all are welcome.
For more information, see http://produceconsumerobot.com/ITPcamp2010/
UPDATE: I will have 12 kits available for $10 each offered to the first 12 people that show up to the session. Once the kits are "sold out", folks may buddy-up with someone who has a kit. IN ADDITION to the things in the kit, YOU MUST BRING the following to participate: 1) breadboard 2) 2 AA batteries + wire jumpers 3) 2x AA battery holder with wire leads These can be purchased at Radioshack or the NYU computer store on Mercer and Greene St. The following will also be helpful if you can bring them: 1) soldering iron 2) tweezers 3) wire cutters ALTERNATIVE OPTION: I will also have a few Truth Wristband kits available for purchase (discounted to $40) if you would prefer to make some wearable art instead of or possibly in addition to the breadboard circuit. The Truth Wristband makes a prettier display but is conceptually similar in the treatment of the GSR signal. Required tools for the Truth Wristband kit: Soldering iron, solder, pliers, wire cutter/stripper, flat head screwdriver, scissors, rubbing alcohol and a toothbrush (for cleaning circuit board after soldering), clear tape (e.g. scotch tape).

title: Pick Your Brain Activity: How to analyze EEG
description:
In you brain, oscillations at various frequencies synchronize billions of neurons and enable you to generate a diverse repertoire of behaviors. By recording brain-generated microvolt potentials from different locations on the scalp (EEG), the frequency and location of these oscillations can reveal numerous aspects of cognition and can be utilized for mind-controlled user interfaces.
In this workshop, we'll discuss some of the off-the-shelf options for monitoring brain activity and we'll cover the conceptual and practical considerations of how to analyze EEG activity with a fast Fourier transform (FFT) embedded on a microcontroller. We discuss how the FFT breaks down the EEG signal into different behaviorally relevant oscillation frequencies and we'll wire up a microcontroller programmed to separate Alpha, Beta, and Gamma waves onto 3 RGB LEDs.
No knowledge of biology, mathematics, or microcontrollers will be assumed. Some basic level of comfort implementing circuits on a breadboard is optimal, but all are welcome. I will provide you with a pic pre-programmed to run an FFT, but if you program dspics, feel free to bring your programmer.
For more information, see http://produceconsumerobot.com/ITPcamp2010/
UPDATE: I will have 12 kits available for $10 each offered to the first 12 people that show up to the session. Once the kits are "sold out", folks may buddy-up with someone who has a kit. IN ADDITION to the things in the kit, YOU MUST BRING the following to participate: 1) breadboard + wire jumpers 2) 2 AA batteries 3) 2x AA battery holder with wire leads These can be purchased at Radioshack or the NYU computer store on Mercer and Greene St. The following will also be helpful if you can bring them: 1) soldering iron 2) tweezers 3) wire cutters

title: Theatrical Control for Programmers and Artists
description:
The control systems used to run Broadway shows and theme parks can be confusing and intimidating from a user's point of view, but to a programmer, these systems are almost shockingly simple.  Using low-cost hardware, it is possible to control equipment such as theatrical lighting, special effects equipment, fountains, and animated props through Processing, Max, or numerous other programming languages.  In this session, we will look at ways to control the entertainment industry standard protocol of DMX in some very non-standard ways.  We will also cover subjects such as how to configure DMX equipment and systems, what can be done with DMX, the future of DMX, and possible applications through code.

Links to some of the material covered:

http://briankim.tumblr.com/post/681179724/some-links-for-the-theatrical-control-for-programmers

Thanks for showing up to the Theatrical Control for Programmers and Artists session. Since I had so many links, here's a link to all those links:

http://briankim.tumblr.com/post/681179724/some-links-for-the-theatrical-control-for-programmers

The hardware options I mentioned (Arduino DMX shield, Enttec, Lanbox, Anyma,) and programming options for them (Processing, OF, Max, PureData, vvvv, Isadora,) are also (mostly) linked.

One thing I forgot to mention was that if you don't feel like writing code, the links to the Enttec devices have some freeware DMX controller programs you can download and use with those devices.

title: What Happened to the Music Industry?
description: The Chair of Tisch's Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music talks about the huge changes in the Music Industry. What Happened to the Music Industry? Over the past decade recorded music sales has dropped by over 50% yet music is more important in people's lives than ever before. How can this be? No one seems to have the answer--is it piracy to blame? the ipod? is it the major record companies? perhaps the quality of music is to blame. In this discussion, we will examine the current state of the industry from a historical context and look at the decisions the industry has made to create a situation where they no longer control their own destiny. Some of the reasons for the current matrix may surprise you.

title: Everything You Always Wanted To Know About The Internet (But Were Afraid To Ask)
description:
Years of experience teaching students of all shapes and sizes at NYU's School of Continuing And Professional Studies have taught me that the majority of perfectly intelligent sophisticated computer-using professionals have little understanding of what the internet is, let alone how a computer or network actually operates. This will be a hybrid discussion  / workshop to get the concepts of the web, the Internet, and networking clear and maybe do some hands-on live coding, should the situation call for it (no coding experience necessary).  We will stay away from theory, and try to focus on actual practices.  Bringing a computer is recommended.  Suggested topics include, but are by no means limited to:
  • What is the Internet?  How does it work?
  • How do you put something on the web, and where does it go once you do?
  • What is a web browser, and why has it barely changed since 1993?
  • I have this thing I want to do, how do I do it?
  • Can I make a living from ad revenue on my blog?
  • What's the difference between the web and the Internet?
  • How did that Nigerian hacker get my credit card info?
  • Can the government control the Internet?
  • What does Peer-to-Peer mean, and how does my cable company always find out that I've been downloading illegal copies of Curb Your Enthusiasm?
  • Is Facebook too big to fail?
  • How can I learn to build a Facebook app in 15 minutes?
  • Will my grandkids be able to find photos of me passed out online?
Come with questions, discussion points, and problems, and we'll do our best to get to the bottom of them.

--

Update 6/13/2010: here are some of the links we looked at during our discussion:
  • How Does the Internet Work - a very straightforward introduction to the main internet concepts
  • Internet Protocol Suite - Wikipedia's entry on TCP/IP and the "protocol stack" model of internet communications
  • Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) - Wikipedia's entry about the primary "application level" protocol responsible for what we call the web.
  • WhatsMyIp.org - a simple site that shows you what IP address you have, meaning what IP address the "internet layer" of your protocol stack is attaching to every packet of information your computer sends out to the wilds of the Internet.
  • The Internet Engineering Taskforce - the open community standards body responsible for defining and maintaining most of the protocols that define what it is we call the Internet.
  • Visual Traceroute - a visualization of the route taken by packets as a simple message traverses the internet to its destination IP address.  (Based on the UNIX traceroute command... also see Ping, which we used to get a domain's IP address manually by conjuring up the DNS)
  • Tor - uses BitTorrent-like "peer-to-peer" technology to allow users to browse without being tracked as easily.  All requests from your computer to servers on the Internet are distributed among other Tor users' computers, which make parts of the request on your behalf..  So the server can never tell the true IP address of the client asking for the information.
  • Anonymouse.org - a web application that makes requests for other websites on your behalf as a sort of proxy, so the other web servers can not track your IP address, but rather see the Anonymouse.org's IP address instead with each request.
  • Web Internet Usage Statistics - some numbers about Internet usage worldwide
  • The Electronic Frontier Foundation - one of the most vocal groups advocating for privacy rights online.
  • Venmo.com - sending/receiving payments via SMS
  • Some random thoughts on Privacy and Security online
  • WebDAV - an extension to regular HTTP that can be used to host a shared calendar on your own site with Google's free Calendar or Apple's paid MobileMe service.  Some web hosting companies have this installed by default.

--

title: Hello Processing
description: This is a brief and quick introduction to Processing.  I'm used to using Processing as an environment to teach programming, but this session will be different and will assume basic programming knowledge (but no knowledge is ok too), focusing on Processing itself.  We'll look at the very basics (coordinate system, shapes, colors, pixels) and then demonstrate a few typical applications of Processing (image processing, data visualization, physics simulation).  I'll do all this in a brief 30-45 minutes and then take time to answer questions, as well as talk to people individually about what Processing can and cannot do.

title: Systematic Creativity
description:
Conventional wisdom holds that creativity is something extraordinary, even mystical, and best realized without constraints (brainstorming, thinking "outside the box," etc.) Then there's the myth of creative genius:  some have it, some don't.

In this session, we're going to explore a different way of thinking about creativity. Specifically, I want to present a methodology called "systematic creativity" from business professors Jacob Goldenberg and David Mazursky's 2002 book, Creativity in Product Innovation. Despite their emphasis on *product* development, this methodology offers a powerful way to generate creative ideas in many domains. Then, depending on the group's appetite, we'll workshop some ideas together or independently.

Links and Notes

The miserable, ugly little book I discussed, called Creativity in Product Innovation

My blog post summary of the book (with downloadable cheat sheet) entitled "Systematic Creativity: Four Templates for New Product Ideation, Innovation and Invention"

Twyla Tharp's The Creative Habit: Learn It and Use It for Life (thanks, Joe!)

Brian Eno and Peter Schmidt's Oblique Strategies (thanks, Luisa!)

Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi's Creativity: Flow and the Psychology of Discovery and Invention (thanks, Shawn!)

title: Brainstorm: Freshkills Park–a Platform for Art and Interaction
description: NYC's newest and largest park is built on the site of the old Fresh Kills Landfill. It's about the size of 3 Central Parks and has the same kind of potential to revitalize the city as Central Park did 150 years ago. There are plans underway related to wildlife conservation,sustainable energy (methane, windmills, solar), recreational uses, scientific research etc. And there are challenges too: it's located in the far-reaches of Staten Island, not all of it will be open for several years. Come hear a presentation by the team that's developing the park, and then join  a brainstorming session to  help them figure out how best to engage the public in this project and this site (through digital media, events, arts, programming) and craft the message about sustainability that this site can represent.  This is a terrific opportunity to help envision a greener NYC and a great new resource for the city that's still in the design stage. To learn more about the park before the session, go to: http://www.nycgovparks.org/sub_your_park/fresh_kills_park/html/fresh_kills_park.html

title: Shop Safety for Campers
description: Learn how to keep the shop clean… and how not to cut off fingers! Every person who plans to use the shop is required by law to attend a safety session. We can accommodate up to 12 people per session

title: Software that sees (OF / Computer Vision)
description: This session will cover the basic of computer vision using openframeworks, a cross platform, open source toolkit for creative coding in c++.  We'll look at recent projects I've worked on, such as: eyewriter,  iq font,  night lights and go over some basic code examples that illustrate the principles at play.    See more at:  http://openframeworks.cc For people that are curious about pixels, gesture, code and building interactive experiences that leave the screen and move into physical space.

title: Understanding Aesthetics: what does the brain 'like'?
description: If we already know that how the brain functions is the basis for complex cognitive and social appreciate of art – now what? Session led by Michael Barnwell (mostly, with some help by) Laurie Frick What makes a person consider something aesthetic? There must be a quantifiable point (the prediction) at which some collection of material becomes aesthetic. The material could be shapes, colors, images of people, things, places, musical notes, sticks, stones, bones—doesn't matter. If we think of art as a composition, either static or moving, then that composition comes into being through a process and at some point in the process takes the form of something people might call arresting, inspiring, moving, challenging, cool—in other words an aesthetic artifact. After a short initial discussion of aesthetics, and a few perceptual principles (V.S. Ramahandran’s 10 rules, Gestalt psychology, and brain fluency theory), we'll do an exercise and brainstorm together. As a group we’ll decompose known artworks  from Malevich to Mehretu and try to predict at what point in the recomposition the assemblage of material tips over into the aesthetic. The scientist would want to ask is this judgment universal or highly subjective? Can we make some assumptions about when composition lifts out of the non-aesthetic and become part of this other realm, that people more or less agree to call art. Also, what are the axes that aesthetics moves on? Can these be predictably manipulated to produce different qualities of art? ___________________________________ Some links from session discussion below (2-3MB files)-- ppt is available if anyone wants, just email me. -- Laurie ITP_Camp_6_15_2010_part1 ITP_Camp_6_15_2010 part2_images ﻿V.S. Ramachandran and William Hirstein’s original article on art and the brain.  The Science of Art 1999 -- http://www.imprint.co.uk/rama/art.pdf Power point slide-show with simple visuals on Gestalt psychology and how the brain visually processes and interprets images -- http://www.slideshare.net/chelsc/gestalt-laws-and-design-presentation Why’s of aesthetic experience – model on p 4 --- http://www.moz.ac.at/user/billm/seminare/2007/Leder_British_Journal_of_Psychology_2004.pdf Processing fluency and an explanation for why the brain prefers certain visual imagery -- http://psy2.ucsd.edu/~pwinkiel/reber-schwarz-winkielman-beauty-PSPR-2004.pdf

title: Musical Conducting
description: Musical conducting involves a language of abstract gesture that has evolved over hundreds of years for a very specific purpose: it helps musicians communicate an efficient but complex set of signals in real-time.  As such, it provides an interesting and useful model for other interactive gestural communication methods.  This session will highlight relevant aspects of conducting and present quantitative techniques for tracking and analyzing conducting gestures.
