title: Conversation Starters for Disparate Lovers
description: Because Flash lacks support for accessing serial ports (for good reason), getting it and an Arduino talking isn't as easy as it could be. I'll show some examples and help you through this process. Once Flash and Arduino meet, you'll see why they can't stop talking.

title: Interactive Video for Artsy Times
description: Come with me on a journey into the bizarre yet intriguing world of interactive video software. This 3 hour course is a basic intro to Jitter for those who want to make videos that move, emote and react to our presence.  No previous programming, video or artsy experience is necessary.  Gabe Barcia-Colombo is a new media artist who teaches several courses at ITP.

title: Touchables: Making Sensors with Textiles
description:
In this session we'll review common approaches for creating sensors of varying sizes, shapes, and sensitivities using conductive thread, fabrics, and other materials. *Bring your physical computing gear if you have it. We'll incorporate our sensors into circuits to see their effect!

Materials

  • Conductive fabric
  • Conductive thread
  • Copper/silver/aluminum mesh or foil
  • Conductive paint or ink
  • Steel wool
Simple switches
  • Broken switch
  • Sandwich switch
  • Pinch switch
  • SNAP!
  • Velcro & other fasteners
Textile Sensors
  • Semi-resistive sandwich for pressure or flex sensor (example: Velostat & conductive fabric)
  • Combined materials (example: sheep's wool felted with steel wool)
  • Modding contacts for existing sensors (example: heart rate, GSR, etc.)
  • Resistor ladder
Projects
  • How to Get What You Want
  • Zipper sensor
  • Tom Gerhardt's Felt Resistor
  • Felted Signal Processing - Sara & Lara
  • Capacitive wall sensors at MIT

title: Very Small Video
description: What is it like to tell a story on video in 25 seconds? What about 10 seconds? What about 4? For several years, documentary filmmakers like me have been turning to smaller and smaller cameras and making smaller and smaller films.  What was once a necessity that grew out of technological barrier (e.g. a cell phone that would record a maximum of 30 seconds of video) has since become a growing genre. In this workshop we will: - watch some of the work coming out of this sphere (including my own). - discuss how stories are constructed and how new ideas might be broken down into very small parts. - discuss distribution and display options for this kind of work. - make some very small videos! Though this isn't a documentary workshop specifically, the approach to this work is very much rooted in the documentary tradition. If possible, bring a cell phone or digital camera that shoots video so you can make your very own before the end of the workshop. title: Fun with iPhones and iPads
description:
I'll structure this around your needs and fall back to a general intro to coding for the iPhone.  If you want to code along, make sure you bring a macbook with xcode installed.  We can cover most any area of the SDK.  If you have special needs or interests, feel free to call them to my attention in your "I will be there" comments. Tools
  • Intel-based Mac with Snow Leopard
  • XCode
  • iPhone SDK for XCode
To download XCode with the iPhone SDK, you'll need to create an Apple Developer Account which you can do using the link below.  If you don't pay $100 to join the developer program, you won't be able to install on your phone. http://developer.apple.com/programs/iphone/

title: Wearables Workshop & Lilypad 101
description: So you've got your gear and now you want to use it. This hands-on session is an opportunity to ask questions and get help as you move through the Lilypad, Arduino, and/or soft circuit tutorials.

title: Plays Well with Others
description:
If we toss out the heirarchical org chart and start throwing around terms like "open" and "collaborate," how can we work together without a lot of coordinating costs? Who does what? Is everybody happy?

What does good collaboration look like?

How do YOU navigate the social space of democratic working conditions and what are you finding?

I will moderate this but I'd like it to be a more typical unconference session with all of us contributing-- a true discussion.

Let's come out of the discussion both with some big ideas about where we are as a culture, some shared language about types of collaboration, and some very immediate suggestions on how to be a good collaborator at ITP Camp.

title: MOBILE APPS: Meet up, partner up, collaborate, sketch
description: I've been hearing that a lot of campers really want to build mobile apps.  I want to build one but I don't know exactly what form it will take.  If I hear a good idea, I may want to see if I could help collaborate and flesh it out some more.  I think a lot of others are in the same situation or have an idea and need help. Let's gather together and present our ideas and maybe you'll find complementary projects or meet someone to partner with to help realize the idea.  This is a mixer of sorts to get people together, talking and starting to sketch the interfaces. First - I may talk briefly for about 10-15 minutes, then we are going to go around the room to present our ideas. Second - Let people mingle and hopefully form groups around an idea/concept that appeals to them Third - Get those groups sketching on whiteboards/paper/whatever. Think of it as a sort of speed dating for project partners. This is how great things begin.

title: Basics of Felting
description: I am an avid felter  and would love to share some basic techniques of felt making using wet felt and mold forming and also demonstrate needle felting and a dye process using basic acid dyes.  I am interested in integrating wearable technology with felt that would be flexible as a two or three dimensional form.[gallery link="file"] Link to my Power point presentatation https://docs.google.com/present/edit?id=0AUTUfcCLRaQVZGM5dDRoNnhfMTU2Z3BnODliZHQ&hl=en

title: MAX/MSP - Computer Vision, Wireless Communication
description: I will show how I use MAX/MSP in my projects, talk a little about computer vision and the cv.jit.library.  I can demonstrate an example of integration of MAX/MSP, Wireless communication using XBEEs and Max for Live (M4L) as I use it with my musical glove.

title: Brainstorming: The Future of Documentary Photography:How to Witness the World in the Internet Age
description:
You've read a lot about the not-so-bright future of newspapers and traditional media. This session focuses on an aspect of journalism that has been less covered: photojournalism and documentary photography. We are probably not in danger of missing out on events as they happen--but where are the models to support in-depth investigative reporting? Think of the images that brought home the realities of war, human rights abuses--who will take them, where will they be published?

This is a brainstorming session with one of the great documentary photographers of our age, Susan Meiselas (http://www.susanmeiselas.com/). She's leading the Magnum Foundation to support documentary photographers. Magnum Photos (http://www.magnumphotos.com/)has been in the forefront of documentary photography for more than sixty years. It is a member-owned cooperative whose existing models rely on quickly vanishing economics.

The challenge is to reinvent the form, the dissemination, and the financial models as we move into the next decade. How can we harness new technologies and social structures to give presence to critical issues of documentary work?

Come with an open mind, questions, and your brightest visions for how photography can be sustained in this new environment.

title: Office Hours
description: One-on-one project consultation - 15 minute slots. Sign up with your desired time: 4:00, 4:15, 4:30, 4:45.

title: Cheap boxes and lines. Low cost real-time video and audio synthesis.
description:
When you think of video and audio synthesis the tool that comes to mind is Max/MSP.  However Max is expensive, there are cheaper (as in free) alternatives that can run on cheaper hardware.

This brief introduction aims to show two of such alternatives,  PureData and vvvv.

I will introduce the environments, show how to get started and where to go on.

vvvv offers a very simple way to distribute images to networked computers and screens, we will demonstrate that as well as explore networking in general as networking can be a cheap solution to complex problems

title: MOBILE APPS: Partner up and sketch
description:
Many of us are interested in more than one idea and more than one technology.  This can be a chance to connect our projects, ideas and technologies.  Collaborations with pcomp projects are welcome.

We will finalize our ideas, partnerships,  and get to work if not already.

title: Sensors, interface board, easy, hands-on
description: Many people attended my workshop on sensors and the Hagstrom Board, but we couldn't play.  This session will be hands-on (for six to eight people).  I'll bring 3 Hagstrom boards, sensors and two pcs.  Perhaps someone can bring an additional windows pc.  PS:  this is about the Hagstrom interface board NOT the Arduino.

Session 2 Introduction to Casting and Mold Making in Two Tuesday Hands–On Sessions Session Two (Tuesday June 22  7:00-9:30 pm) will build on Session One and introduce the latest two-part rubber and plastic compounds as well as fiberglas reinforced plaster. We’ll make a silicone rubber mold and cast with polyurethane plastic and foam. Meet in the shop area at the big tables. http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/casting.html http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/wiki/index.php/Classes/Class5CastingAndMoldmakingI http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/wiki/index.php/Classes/Class6CastingAndMoldmakingII

title: Winslow's TelePresence Workshop!
description:
This workshop will explore the many uses of Cisco's HD Teleconferencing technology known as TelePresence. Using the two units at NYU we will play games like charades and pictionary and also brainstorm future uses for this impressive device.

We will meet at ITP and half of the group will walk with me to the ITS computer lab in the Education building.

See you then!

title: Public Art Overview
description:
In this session we will look at some public art projects using both "old" and "new" media. Also, we will look at some of the organizations in NY that sponsor public art projects and review their submission policies.

Here's a few links.

title: Visual programming & Max/MSP
description: Learn about the paradigm and power of visual programming languages (specifically Max/MSP) for creating interactive performance and installation projects.  Learn about visual programming styles and how to organize your projects and creative approach so that your ideas can transcend your software tools. -- Dafna Naphtali

title: Get Your Hands Dirty! Intro to Casting and Mold Making – Part 1
description: Introduction to Casting and Mold Making in Two Tuesday Hands – On Sessions Session One (Tuesday June 15  7:00-9:30 pm) will introduce the basics, with a description of tools and techniques, how to design a mold, and how to choose the appropriate casting material. We’ll work with clay, plaster, and alginate, and make a plaster cast of a hand. Meet in the shop area at the big tables. Session Two (Tuesday June 22  7:00-9:30 pm) will build on session one and introduce the latest two-part rubber and plastic compounds as well as fiberglas reinforced plaster. We’ll make a silicone rubber mold and cast with polyurethane plastic and foam. http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/casting.html http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/wiki/index.php/Classes/Class5CastingAndMoldmakingI http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/wiki/index.php/Classes/Class6CastingAndMoldmakingII

title: Mobile App Meet Up - Everyone Welcome!
description:
This is part of a regular gathering of Campers who want to discuss and develop mobile applications.  Everyone is welcome.  Share your idea, get valuable feedback, put ideas to faces.  This is not technical.  It will allow campers to solidify their ideas and goals for their camp project.

No knowledge of prior sessions is necessary. Come in at any time.

Part study group, part support group, all collaboration.

This will start after the FourSquare API session.

title: Wireframing & Prototyping Workshop - Intro to Axure
description: People have expressed interest in creating dynamic prototypes to refine their ideas before going deep into final project development.  This hands-on session will give an tutorial of a powerful but simple to use wireframing/prototyping/documenting tool called Axure. Please bring your laptop and install the 30-day trial version of the software (PC and Mac) before the class so we can get started as quickly as possible. http://www.Axure.com UPDATE: I'd like to thank everyone who came  to the workshop.  I hope you saw enough to load Axure on your computers, play with it and explore the possibility of using it on your future projects. Again, feel free to email me (dkawasaki@gmail.com) or stop me in the hall if you want to talk more about this subject. The following are some links to some of the content I referred to during my discussion. Video tutorials: Really good, online training videos that you can use to get up to speed fast. http://axure.com/online-training.aspx Active Community: http://axure.com/CS/forums/4/ShowForum.aspx Widgets and Libraries http://www.axure.com/widgetLibraries.aspx http://www.axure.com/communityLibraries.aspx http://www.acleandesign.com/m/ACDAxureTemplate/Home.html http://wireframes.linowski.ca/2009/09/axure-libraries-widgets-compilation/

title: Columbo: Starring Jacques Derrida
description: This session is designed to entertain and inform anyone hoping to bring a little more theory into their practice.  It will show you that everything you need to know about Jacques Derrida and Deconstruction can be learned from a single episode of Columbo.  Deconstruction is a powerful tool for thought - one that shouldn't simply be employed by theorists and critics - but Derrida's texts are cryptic, and often intimidating for most readers.  So taking on one of Derrida's most famous, but misunderstood essays "Signature, Event, Context" we'll come to a nuanced understanding of the methods used by Mr. Columbo as well as Mr. Derrida in solving mysteries.  After a short introduction on how Derrida/Columbo tackle problems, we'll alternate between the text and clips from a single Columbo episode, engaging in a lively, guided discussion.  In the process we will come to understand a way of approaching paradoxes and mysteries that can be put to use in daily life, and illuminate some of Derrida's most powerful insights on communication, performance, presence, writing and mediated action.   Attendees need no prior knowledge of media theory, philosophy or TV-crime-mysteries, but some genuine interest in one or more of them will help.

title: The World Cup Informational
description:
Special Event / Drive-by hosted by Ian Cleary:
The event is a  "driveby-like" talk on the WorldCup. The idea is to use the international scope of the ITP student body and Camp to share what the World Cup means to people in different countries. I have a panel of 8 current students lined up to describe a) what the World Cup is and how it works, and b) what it's like to be a soccer fan in their countries during the world cup. So far I've got people ready to talk about Mexico, Germany, Chile, Brazil, Denmark, England, Spain, and the USA.
Open to all Campers and Students in the lounge tonight at 6:30PM
Once the World Cup begins, we will have matches on in the lounge whenever possible during the tournament.

title: Come with me if you want to know how to make a database
description:
Because there seems to be a lot of interest in understanding databases I'm going to lead this session to get people up to speed.

The intended audience is people with little or no experience in any database environment.

The bedrock of any serious discussion on databases is invariably going to involve SQL so in addition to introducing the database concepts that you need to be aware of, I will also show you how to use SQL to accomplish what you're trying to do.

I am not a front end developer, but I'll try to provide some clarity on how you can incorporate SQL into your own projects.

title: Private Event - Rob Ryan
description: This area is reserved

title: ITP SNAPSHOTS (open hours - come anytime between these hours for taping)
description:
Come anytime between video taping hours.  About 10 minutes per person This is an open session where I will ask ITP camp participants a series of 5 randomly selected questions to capture their thoughts, views opinions on a variety of topics via video, and  photography. Potential outcomes include:
  • Starting and continuing a conversation/partnership past the completion of ITP camp
  • Meeting and learning about interesting people you didn’t have a chance to meet
  • Learning about each other past my name is....
  • Opportunity to develop future projects to work on
  • New business or social ideas and platforms for future development
  • Opportunity to hear and share in each other stories and narrative in a very up close way
Sample questions include: 1. If you could invite anyone to dinner living or dead, What would you  serve and why? 2. Who are you and what would you want your legacy to be? 3. What problem in the world has the easiest solution 4. What song represents your life and why? 5.  If you can have one business partner who would it be? 6.  What is your favorite word?

title: Wordpress Studio
description:
This is a follow up to the session from 3-5.  We will move rooms and individually set up your own blog.  It would help to to have access to web hosting.  You can set up a trial account with dreamhost at:
https://signup.dreamhost.com/

title: Hands on Felting for 6-8 campers
description:
I will be in the Physical Computing Lab giving a quick demo on various types of simple wet felting.

There will be a simple dye demonstration.

People can begin or finish existing projects as needed.

There will be wool available for people to use.

If you are participating please pay $5 or more to help the cost of the wool fiber. Thanks

title: A Call for Collaboration...and Drinks
description:
An invitation to my fellow campers to congregate at a TBD neighboring bar for casual conversation about how our varied skill sets may be used for collaboration.

I'll take any and all recommendations for a neighboring bar.

title: Nothing to Something 2
description:
By popular demand, a second session of the Nothing to Something
workshop... How do you go from a wayward spark of an idea to a fully
realized project concept? What’s the path from hunch to proposal?
Revamp your creative practice with new skills and strategies for
brainstorming, ultra-rapid prototyping, and play-testing to fully
explore, develop, and direct your ideas. This session aims to change
your predisposition to sitting around and just thinking. Bring a
sketchbook (paper or otherwise) and a hunch. This will take about 2.5
hours. Limit: 10 sign-ups.

title: Biofeedback with Arduino
description: In this session I am planning to focus on GSR and heart rate sensors and how to use them with Ardiuno and Processing. Also, I will show some projects that came out from ITP and some projects on the field to show for what reasons people are using biofeedback. I am planning this session as a hands on session that will help to start playing with sensors and Processing sketches. Please let me know if you want to explore different bio sensing techniques with Arduino. Please don't forget to bring your physical computing tools, and an Arduino. Also,  you can bring Polar heart rate sensor, bluesmirf and HRMI (http://danjuliodesigns.com/sparkfun/sparkfun.html) First we will make a GSR setup, and get all the data to a Processing sketch. Then we will try to do the same with bluetooth connection (via bluesmirf). Then I will show how polar heart rate sensors works and their circuit setup. If you have a polar hear rate monitor you can also bring it to the session. I have started to create a blog for this session. You can check it out at biofeedback.mustafabagdatli.com. I will be adding more sketches ASAP

title: The Exhibitionists
description: This is an end-of-camp show where campers can display and share their projects.  Other campers and their guests will mill around try your stuff out.  Please sign up here with a link to your project and talk to rob.ryan@nyu.edu for space and equipment requests.

title: Five Minute of Fame
description: This is your opportunity to take the stage. Campers can give Ignite-style presentations, perform a skit, or give a talk on what conclusions they have come to while at camp.  The five minute limit will be strictly enforced. Please sign up here to get in the line up.

title: Party
description: Closing ceremonies: food, drink, and good conversation.

title: A Call for Collaboration…and Drinks - Part Two
description: This is a follow up to the previous Drinks and Collaboration session held on 6/16.  Meet at The Stoned Crow (85 Washington Pl. nr 6th Ave.) for casual conversation about how our varied skill sets may be used for collaboration.

title: Open Source Democracy
description:
Social and organizational systems are naturally constrained by their technological context. Today, we are experiencing the advent of a transformational new technology.

While our knowledge-creation and economic production systems are adapting quickly to the new information technologies, our political decisions are still made using a 220-year-old legacy system, and it is straining to keep up. In recent years many Internet-powered groups have spontaneously organized to pressure their governments to action. In this session I'd like to discuss to what degree the Internet can BE the government - a platform through which communities organize and govern themselves directly.

Is direct democracy possible in a complex society? And is it desirable?

title: Pilates for Campers
description: The David Barton Gym at Astor Place has graciously allowed me to host a Pilates mat class for ITP Campers. No previous Pilates experience necessary. Wear comfortable clothing you can move in. A bit of background on Pilates if you have no idea what I teach http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pilates The address for David Barton Gym -Astor Place http://www.davidbartongym.com/gyms/astor.html

title: Symptoms and Strategies: Documentary Photography
description: Please join me on a (free) field trip to the International Center of Photography on 43rd and 6th to see the Exhibition FOR ALL THE WORLD TO SEE: VISUAL CULTURE AND THE  STRUGGLE FOR CIVIL RIGHTS. We will then go across the street to the School (where I am an instructor) and walk through the Final Exhibition of the full time students in the Fine Art and Documentary Photography Programs, and examine the developing After the exhibition we will adjourn to a class room at ICP to  discuss the exhibitions and have a brainstorming session regarding the issues and challenges facing Documentary practice today.

title: Sensormania
description: Curious about sensors about different applications? In this session Tom & Kate will talk about any & all sensors they know about.

title: This to That (Going Wireless)
description:
Got a project that you think needs wireless but don't know how to do it? Kate & Tom will review a number of technologies including bluetooth, XBees, serial RF, and IR and give to pointers on where to start with them. Resources:
  • ITP XBee Resources (from Phys Comp wiki)
    • xbeeBasics - Introduction to Xbees
    • xbeeFirmware - How to upgrade the Firmware on XBee
    • Xbee Radios - Rob Faludi explains everything you wanted to know about Xbee radios, and then some. See also the ITP ZigBee Wiki page, in which you can (and should) reserve a PAN ID.
    • Rob and Luke Dubois' Max/MSP patch to read XBee API code
    • Tymm Twillman's XBee library for Arduino
    • Tymm's Google repository for Arduino-Xbee development
    • hc Gilje's example of using Xbee series 2 radios standalone
  • Demystifying 802.15.4 and ZigBee (white paper)
  • Making Things Talk (Chapter 6: Wireless Communication)
  • Building Wireless Sensor Networks
  • Stone's Throw - Steve Daniels

title: Shop Safety Session - Last One of Camp
description: Learn how to work with tools, keep a safe shop clean and neat… and how not to cut off fingers! Every person who plans to use the shop is required by law to attend a safety session. We can accommodate up to 12 people per session If you want to work on a final project for Camp that might require you to work in the tools shop, you should take this session! Email us if you can't make this last session and need a one on one.

title: Programming Help Session: Java, Eclipse, Processing, and Android
description:
Need last minute help with your project?  ITP Resident Researcher Matt Parker, has experience with Java, Processing, and Android and can help you with your last minute development issues.

So come by and get your projects working at the last minute.  It's the ITP way!

title: Hacking Kinects and other Cameras
description:
Survey some of the interesting possibilities for projects at the intersections of cameras and computers. This is a practical session full of demos of tools that you can get your hands on. Topics will include, network cameras, face tracking, augmented reality, kinect cameras, cameras on smart phones and cameras attached to microcontrollers. When you sign up for this session it would be great if you could add some links of interesting things around computers and networks attached to cameras. Computational Cameras Class

Ubiquity

  • Citizens Survaiance of their Government
  • Networked Cameras my code
  • Web -- Flash
  • Cellphone
    • Android Processing Sensor Library, my code
    • Junaio
     

Visual Literacy

  • Visual Intelligence
  • Descreet vs Blended
  • Reading in the Brain
  • Greenscreen
  • IR
    • WiMote
  • OpenCV my code
  • Markers mycode patterns
  • Kinect
    • Easiest for Depth Information Shiffman
    • Easiest for Depth and Skeleton Simple OpenNI
  • Pixel by Pixel Programming
  • Skeleton

title: Intro to PCB design in EagleCAD
description: Intro to Printed Circuit Board (PCB) Design with EagleCAD from schematic to board layout to manufacturing.

title: Intro to 3D modeling in Rhinoceros
description: Introduction to precision 3D modeling in Rhino (mac or windows) .  We'll start with the very basics and work up to modeling an existing object from scratch.  Learn how to draw stuff in 2D, extrude curves, generate surfaces, generate solids, combine solids, output to the lasercutter, output to a CNC mill, output to a 3D printer.  Leave a comment on any specific tools in Rhino you'd like to see covered.

title: Making Pop-Up Books
description:
This workshop covers the basics of paper engineering techniques (including folds (symmetrical, asymmetrical, parallel and angle), generations, floating layers, V cuts, dials, and pull tabs) to make designs that pop that can be incorporated into your other work.

Campers should bring the following to the workshop: scissors, x-acto knife, paper, cutting mat, tape, glue stick.

title: So, You Don't Hate Flash?
description: We'll build something together in Flash. This session will provide a gentle introduction to the Flash platform as well as ActionScript 3. It's okay to like Flash. Check out the session syllabus and download some samples.

title: Basics of Physical Computing using Arduino: session 1
description:
In this four-session series, I'll introduce the basics of physical computing using the Arduino microcontroller.  We'll cover what a microcontroller is, the basics of input and output from sensors, communication between microcontrollers and computers, and control of other devices. Bring your own laptop, Arduino, and components.

In the first session, I'll cover the basics of electricity.  Many people find that even after they've been introduced to physical computing, they're still unsure of how electricity works, and how it relates to the projects they build. In particular, how mechanical energy becomes electrical energy remains a mystery for many people. We'll go from a basic circuit to reading a sensor in this session, and attempt to clear up the mystery.

These sessions may be videotaped, so if you're camera-shy, please speak up.

title: Basics of Physical computing using arduino: Session 2
description: In this four-session series, I'll introduce the basics of physical computing using the Arduino microcontroller.  We'll cover what a microcontroller is, the basics of input and output from sensors, communication between microcontrollers and computers, and control of other devices. Bring your own laptop, Arduino, and components. In this second session, I'll cover the basics of digital and analog input and output. I'll focus on low-current outputs, but we'll talk a little about using transistors and relays to control high current loads as well.  We'll focus on converting the energy from sensors into electrical signals that the microcontroller can read, and then sending signals from the microcontroller to switch on and off devices that convert electrical energy into sound and light. These sessions may be videotaped, so if you're camera-shy, please speak up.

title: Basics of physical computing using arduino: Session 3
description: In this four-session series, I'll introduce the basics of physical computing using the Arduino microcontroller.  We'll cover what a microcontroller is, the basics of input and output from sensors, communication between microcontrollers and computers, and control of other devices. Bring your own laptop, Arduino, and components. In the third session of this series, I'll introduce motors and the electrical principle of induction. You'll learn a bit about how motors work, and will control a basic DC motor, a servo motor and a stepper motor, and learn what kinds of application each is good for.  We'll also review electrical power calculations because motors need a lot of power. These sessions may be videotaped, so if you're camera-shy, please speak up.

title: Basics of physical computing using Arduino: session 4
description: In this four-session series, I'll introduce the basics of physical computing using the Arduino microcontroller.  We'll cover what a microcontroller is, the basics of input and output from sensors, communication between microcontrollers and computers, and control of other devices. Bring your own laptop, Arduino, and components. In this fourth and final session I'll concentrate on communication between microcontrollers and other devices. We'll talk about various ways that electronic devices talk to each other. These sessions may be videotaped, so if you're camera-shy, please speak up.

title: Hello ITP Camp!
description:
Let's get it started! This is a gathering to kick off the camp.
  • Meet other campers
  • Learn about the idea of an UnConference
  • Look around ITP and hear how it works.
  • Have a Drink.
  • Make a Lanyard(not really).
This orientation, like all the events, is completely optional.

title: Closing Party
description: Closing ceremonies: food, drink, and good conversation.

title: 1-in-1
description:
[gallery columns="7"] Is your excited brain overflowing with great ideas? That's why we're all here! Today you're going to take one of those ideas - and make it. 1-in-1 is bold scheme to do one creative project in one day. The event is an extension of a popular ITP tradition started by the Resident researchers in 2008 with an ambitious 7-in-7 event. Since then the event has been repeated many times in multiple configurations, drawing in ITP faculty, students and alumni in a huge rush of creative output. We'll gather in the morning - and embark on a full day marathon of sketching, building, and documenting a single stellar project, celebrating the satisfaction of doing without fuss and the great camaraderie of the ITP floor. Bring: enthusiasm, resourcefulness, and determination. This is an opportunity for ITP Campers to hit the ground running. You'll have a project done by the end of your first week!

The mandate in short:

  • Do a one creative project in one day.
  • Projects must be completed in a single day, so the results need to be as compact as they are creative.
  • Each project needs a name and documentation posted by the end of the day. It should be a stand-alone accomplishment.
Check out Rob Faludi's Advice for Participants.   Schedule! 10 am : coffee + bagels, casual chit chat, setup your workspace gather your materials. 10:30 : I'll answer any questions, bless any materials, and off we go! 12 pm: standing check in, everyone says "Hello! I am making X". (this is a good moment for quick feedback and brainstorming) 1 - 2 pm: Your blog post should begin - a picture, maybe two, and a couple of sentences, like a teaser of what's comin'. The counselors on staff and I will roam around from person to person to prompt you with some curious questions in this direction.  At around 3 I'll send the link to the mailing list to show the rest of the campers what they're missing. you're on your own for lunch so that you can set your own pace. remember: snack often and hydrate. talk, play, help others, tweet out some overheards #itpcamp, and push through the bulk of the work. 7 pm: dinner! ( good sandwiches with solid veggie options ) You are done when you're documented. if you've made a great blog post with a bunch of pictures, your project has a name and you're readily imagining version 2.0, you are welcome to call it a day. Campers can stay as late as they 'd like if they're in a creative groove, and want to get the blog post just right.

title: Smart Materials for DIY Projects
description: Overview of a selection of smart materials which are simple enough to be used on DIY projects, such as: quantum tunneling composite; conductive adhesives; electrotextiles; thermosensitive pigments; photochromic pigments, polymers and textiles, amongst others. The first part of the session will be an overview (description and demo) of a range of smart materials appropriate for DIY projects. On the second part, everyone will describe an idea or project they are working on and I'll help select the appropriate materials, demonstrate how to use them, where to source them, etc. Session slides: http://www.slideshare.net/catlx/weird-and-wonderful-materials-7449801

title: Intro to Surface Mount Electronics
description: Through hole components are arguably going the way of the dinosaur.  We'll look at SMD component packages, how to work with them and learn various soldering techniques so you can build things like it's the 21st century.

title: Intro to Laser Cutting
description: Using ITP's Epilog Laser cutter, this session will go through the steps of creating a design in Illustrator and cutting it from the material of your choosing.

title: Graphic Design 101
description: If you think you need to have been born with a special gene to produce good graphic design work, this 2 hour session will set you straight and keep you out of trouble.

title: Two Approaches to Behavior Re-Set (with Fred Muench)
description:
1.  Lean Behavior Design  (Steven Dean) Break big behaviors into smaller ones. Find out what's preventing the behavior from occurring. Choose the right technology. Imitate and improve successes. Design, test and measure solutions that target the behavior. 2.  Self-Modeling  (Fred Muench) Technology allows us to capture the moments when we are most motivated to change and replay those moments during times of waning motivation using text based (SMS), audio (IVR) and video feedback of our "motivated self". [Linda Stone regrets she's not able to be in town. We'll do our best to speak to her topic on how breathing and simple biomechanical exercises that effect the autonomic nervous system (ANS) can support behavior change.  This information also supports a healthier relationship with technology. Technology can also help support the ANS shifts.] From Steve Dean sgdean@gmail.com http://twitter.com/sgdean Steve's slides: On Behavior Change [PDF: 22 MB]
Quantified Self
Quantified Self Blog: http://www.quantifiedself.com
Join NY Quantified Self Meetup: http://meetup.com/NYQuantifiedSelf/
BJ Fogg
http://www.behaviorgrid.org
http://www.behaviorwizard.org
http://captology.stanford.edu
http://www.behaviormodel.org
Reinforcers
Karen Pryor Don’t Shoot the Dog
Alfie Kahn: Punished by Reward (Book: Amazon)
From Fred Muench fredmuench@gmail.com Motivational Self-Modeling Procedure Motivation is fleeting. What should you do when you are motivated to change a behavior in the moment? Before you begin – remember:
  1. 1. Only record positive – motivating statements and pictures (Positive Self-Review)
  2. 2. Never highlight negative or degrading aspects of the self – record who you think you can be!
  3. 3. You CAN record process as long as you end up in the place where you want to be.
Take out your phone and audio or video record the following during those critical moments when you make the decision to change: 1- WHAT DO YOU RECORD – (no more than 3-5 minutes)
  1. a. What is your specific plan – be very specific – only include things in your plan that you will be able to achieve
  2. b. Why you want to change – this is the one area where you could discuss the consequences of not changing.
  3. c. Show your self-performing behavior or being motivated (audio).
  4. d. What would you say to yourself if you were considering not changing
  5. e. What are the barriers and how will you deal with them when you are confronted by them (implementation intentions)
  6. f. Who you want to be and that if you are not feeling it today does not mean it is not real.
  7. g. Who is your motivator?
2- UPLOAD: Keep on phone or upload to closed youtube site and link via text message or email 3- PLAYBACK – WHEN IS PLAYBACK
  1. a. Schedule in calendar or SMS/email to alert every two days for a week
  2. b. Schedule in calendar or SMS/email to alert 2 days in next week
  3. c. Then once a week for 90 days.
  4. d. Send to friend and ask them to put in their calendar
4- Re-record your message as necessary (at least every 90 days) with new information Maintaining motivation using audio review Articles by Fred Technology supports self modeling Maintaining motivation using audio review

title: Open Hardware Round Table
description: [caption id="attachment_1003" align="alignnone" width="688" caption="Makerbot, Arduino, Little Bits"][/caption] Round table with Alicia Gibb (Bug Labs, NYC Resistor & Open Hardware Summit), Ayah Bdeir (Little Bits & Open Hardware Summit), Bre Pettis (Makerbot), Tom Igoe (Arduino & ITP), Catarina Mota (openMaterials). Free and open source software has been around for several decades during which it evolved from an informal practice of academic and corporate researchers into a multi-billion dollar industry. In recent years, the open source philosophy and approach started to penetrate other areas of human endeavor, now promising to transform not just the world of bytes but also the world of atoms. What are the implications of adopting these practices of knowledge sharing and distributed development to product design and hardware? What happens when everyone has access to digital fabricators and 3D scanners and parametrized models for nearly everything circulate freely on the web? While open source software has already proven itself, how can we create successful businesses for open source hardware and consumer products? Join us on this Q&A session to discuss these and other open source hardware related questions.

title: Integrating Rhino 3D Modeling with Processing
description: 3D modeling allows us to virtually examine work-in-progress from a rotational, 360-degree view, and provides crucial perspectives into identifying design flaws, visualizing aesthetic choices and drafting multiple iterations before construction or fabrication. This workshop focuses on translating data from Processing into the NURBS based 3D modeling software Rhino – a virtual space to explore, create and manipulate designs. Emphasis is placed on developing an individual workflow to transition from an original concept to a final form. Learning Objectives -    Introduction to Rhino as a modeling tool -    Translating data between Processing and Rhino -    Understanding the uses and limitations of Rhino and other 3D modeling software Processing References  http://www.processing.org/learning/  http://www.processing.org/reference/  http://www.openprocessing.org/ Rhino References  http://www.rhino3d.com/tutorials.htm  http://www.rhino3dhelp.com/ Libraries and Commands for Importing/Exporting from Rhino to Processing *Fluidforms http://fluidforms.eu/processing/fluid-forms-libs/ objimp http://www.pixelnerve.com/processing/libraries/objimport/ OBJloader http://code.google.com/p/saitoobjloader/ loadStrings (command for txt, PC only) http://processing.org/reference/loadStrings_.html Libraries and Commands for Importing Exporting from Processing to Rhino *DXFexport (command) http://processing.org/reference/libraries/dxf/index.html Fluidforms http://fluidforms.eu/processing/fluid-forms-libs/ superCAD http://labelle.spacekit.ca/supercad/ PrintWriter (command for txt, PC only) http://processing.org/reference/PrintWriter.html *this is the library we used in class – it is the easiest to use but doesn’t have as many features at the other libraries Most links to  the libraries listed above can be found under the heading Import/Export at http://www.processing.org/reference/libraries/

title: Interactive Video for Artists
description:
This session will introduce non programmers to the world of interactive video programming for art installations.

In this course we will make video scream, shake, stumble and speak using Max/Msp + Jitter

title: Measuring Biological Signals for Art and Business (and anything in between)
description:
We'll discuss what types of biological signals you can measure with simple circuitry, what information they can tell you about mental and physical states, and how bio-signals can be integrated into art, fashion, games, toys, social media, medical devices, sports equipment and various types of other applications.
See http://produceconsumerobot.com/ITPcamp2011/ for more information.

title: Heart Happy: How to measure your EKG
description:
The heart is a powerful symbol that has inspired mythology in civilizations throughout history. The beating of your heart -- your overall pulse rate as well as changes in rate and inter-beat variability -- carries intimate information about your mental and physical state that can be used in art, fashion and industry (e.g. this installation I recently made with some ITP folks - http://produceconsumerobot.com/emergence/).
In this workshop, we'll cover the conceptual and practical considerations for monitoring your pulse using simple electronics. As an example of an easy method for pulse detection, we'll use an off-the-shelf chip (Polar RMCM01) for measuring heart beat information sent from various Polar heart straps and transmitters.
This is a hands-on workshop in which we'll put a circuit together with a breadboard and a small amount of soldering. I will supply all the parts you need for the circuits for $20/kit. Please sign up for the session as early as possible so that I can order enough parts to cover everybody.
No knowledge of biology, or engineering will be assumed. Some basic level of comfort implementing circuits on a breadboard is optimal, but all are welcome. If you have a Polar heart rate strap, bring it along!
For more information, see http://produceconsumerobot.com/ITPcamp2011/

title: Exposing Emotional Arousal: How to measure GSR
description:
The galvanic skin response (GSR) is a measure of increased emotional arousal that is commonly used in lie detector tests. Generated by fast acting sweat glands that are tied into the arousal systems of your body (like adrenaline), the GSR reveals a powerful view of ongoing changes in your psyche that is otherwise invisible to the naked eye.
In this workshop, we'll cover the conceptual and practical considerations of monitoring your GSR using simple
electronics and create an easy-to-assemble breadboard circuit that may be used to display GSR on an LED or as input to a microcontroller (e.g. Arduino).
This is a hands-on workshop in which we'll put a circuit together with a breadboard and a small amount of soldering. I will supply all the parts you need for the circuits for $20/kit (as described in my recent Make Magazine article - http://cdn.makezine.com/make/2011/04/MAKEVol26TruthMeter.pdf).
Please sign up for the session as early as possible so that I can order enough parts to cover everybody.
No knowledge of biology, or engineering will be assumed. Some basic level of comfort implementing circuits on a breadboard is optimal, but all are welcome.
For more information, see http://produceconsumerobot.com/ITPcamp2011/

title: Pick Your Brain Activity: How to analyze EEG
description:
In you brain, oscillations at various frequencies synchronize billions of neurons and enable you to generate a diverse repertoire of behaviors. By recording brain-generated microvolt potentials from different locations on the scalp (EEG), the frequency and location of these oscillations can reveal numerous aspects of cognition and can be utilized for mind-controlled user interfaces.
In this session I'll demo a couple different off-the-shelf options to measure EEG activity and discuss the benefits and drawbacks of these and other options. We'll discuss the conceptual and practical considerations of measuring EEG, what types of information can be extracted from brain activity with different analytical tools, the inherent difficulties and pitfalls and how you might think about overcoming these difficulties.
For more information, see http://produceconsumerobot.com/ITPcamp2011/

title: Intro to DIY Bio
description: Biological organisms and systems are essentially living machines. Digital technologies allow us to create a control structure with computational predictability and precision. What happens, however, when designers begin to incorporate the self-determined internal control structure of a biological system as part of a design strategy? This course offers an introduction to world of the bio lab through the designers perspective including the ideas and processes of bio tech, the works of bio artists and the future thinking of synthetic biology.  Lecture discussion with a hands-on DNA extraction from strawberries.

title: The User Experience of Media
description: As all media becomes digital media, we're being confronted with re-thinking long held paradigms for how to create, consume, distribute, and sell our cultural output. We'll discuss the software-ization of everything from books to television, examine the complete stack of experiences a user may encounter to get to their media, and identify strategies for designing the whole widget of modern media.

title: Creating and Controlling Motion
description: This session will be a whirlwind tour of Chapter 6 in my book  Making Things Move: DIY Mechanisms for Inventors, Hobbyists, and Artists.  We'll talk about three different kinds of motors (DC, servo, and stepper) and solenoids, how to choose, and how to stick things that spin on all of them.  I'll also point out quick and easy ways to control them and share sample code used to run simple demos.  I'll plan for about an hour of talking about this stuff, then an hour of open workshop/questions.

title: Making electricity
description:
You use it - now make it. In this crash course we'll turn small motors into generators, explore solar panels, and dissect batteries and capacitors (for storing electricity). Along the way you'll gain precision in thinking about energy and power, and perspective on energy technologies at larger scales. Basic parts provided for use in-session; feel free to BYO small motors or solar panels. Some resources from my Energy class:
  • Kinetic energy slides, kinetic electrical one-sheet
  • Basic crank circuit, Advanced crank circuit, circuit 2
  • Power conditioning flowchart
  • Energy Storage overview, Capacitors, Batteries
  • Solar overview
Also:
  • Updated US electricity generation numbers (source)
  • LNL Energy Flowcharts

title: Telematic Dinner Party
description:
WOW! That was quick! We have our 4 RSVP Dinner Guests:
  • Michael Morgenstern - Starter Course
  • Alicia Eggert - Main Course
  • Becky Stewart - Main Course
  • Adina Levin - Dessert Course
Thank you to all who expressed interest in the Telematic Dinner Party. There is space for spectators during the dinner party, please come hang out with us during the dinner starting @ 12:30pm. If you want to share in the spirit of Latitudinal Cuisine, we will be eating from longitude of 168, Russia and/or New Zealand. So bring you own variation lunch to eat along with us. Because it is important that we have 4 people to collaborate on each side this isn't a drop in session for active participants. The Telematic Dinner Party is a shared meal with Londoners connected by mobile technology. The two host sites are London based Furtherfield, art & technology organization and ITP Camp. The goal is to create a co-presence experience where two remote groups will share a meal mediated sonified objects embedded with smartphones. We aim to create a satisfying remote experience through a dinner party. As food is the greatest mediator.  

The Schedule:

11am - 12pm  - "Get you know you" Workshop - you will be creating sonified object using smartphones with Skype to connect with your London counterpart. 12:00 pm - 12:30pm - Preparation - heat up food and prepare for the dinner 12:30 pm - 1:30pm -  Collaborative Dining - you will be sharing a meal and hosting your remote guest through the object your built for them conversely you will be hosted by your London counterpart. 1:30pm - 2:00pm - After dinner drinks and interviews - Marco and Giana will interview you about your experience during the workshop and the dinner. - Limited to 4 active participants.

Full Details of the Workshop/Dinner Party

NYC Facilitators: Marco Castro and Giana Gonzalez London Facilitators: Pollie Barden and Brittany Lind

Workshop Supplies

Provided Supplies Technology 4 Android phones with Skype installed will be provided by ITP for the session Craft Supplies Basic craft supplies and building supplies. Supplies for you to bring: Technology Bring your laptop with Skype installed. You will need it to communicate with your London partner during the workshop part of the session. (Let me know if need a webcam for your laptop.) Craft Supplies While we will have basic supplies and building materials on hand, here are somethings to consider bringing.
  • a container that will hold the phone to be the foundation for your object. The container can be plastic, cardboard, etc...
  • your favorite x-acto knife, or cutting device
  • any fun items you have laying around that you haven't found a use for yet, might be used: feathers, beads, decorative paper, cardboard, magazines, etc...
[caption id="attachment_1159" align="aligncenter" width="342" caption="Rough prototype of object holding phone. "][/caption]

The Dinner Party

The dinner party will be formatted in the style of Latitudinal Cuisine (LatiCui). LatiCui cooks food from the longitude corresponding to the day of the year. For June 18th the longitude is 169th day of the year and therefore the 169 longitude. We will be eating from Russia or New Zealand. There will be three courses: Start, Main, Dessert:
  • 1 guest brings a Starter
  • 2 guests brings a Main
  • 1 guest brings Dessert.
Each participant will choose which type of dish they will bring. Make (or buy) enough for the four people you with whom you will be dining. At the start of each course, the dinner guest presents their dish and tells why they choose to make/buy it and any other stories.

Research and  Documentation

This session is one of a series of telematic dinners that I am running as part of PhD research project. The session will be video documented for data analysis of how the interactions happens among the diners in the co-present and remote spaces. I am looking forward to meeting all the diners and spectators remotely. You can follow the other dinners and research process on The Telematic Dinner Party Blog.

title: Ready, FIRE!, Aim.
description:
Learn the correct order of things you need to do to take your idea and create a technology business. We will review the key elements that you need to address to be successful: Pain (that your customer/potential customer is feeling doing things the way they do them now), Friction (the pain caused by changing or doing something new) and Grease (the benefit you provide your customer/user). Other topics include:

· Chickens and Eggs – what comes first?
· Ideas vs Execution
· Developing a product
· Toll booths in the desert –how can you charge for your project.

title: Entrepreneurship for Creatives - Make it doing what you love.
description:
Few things are as rewarding as making a living doing what you love. But ask any seasoned vet - it ain't always easy! Many designers have been forced to learn the fundamentals of business by groping in the dark with no playbook.

This class will introduce designers to key concepts to thinking entrepreneurially. It will cover essential skills for any designer/photographer/writer/freelancer interested in starting his/her own practice using real world lessons in cash flow, billing, negotiating and contracts. It will conclude with an overview of the state of the design landscape and new opportunities in NYC's current tech scene. Awesome news! The class will be joined by a fantastic attorney, Doug Barnes(Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher). Doug will decode how contracts work - a must attend section for any creative professional! EntrepreneurshipAndContracts.ppt EntrepreneurshipForCreatives-ITP.key

title: Recording a Song - Tips, Tricks, and Strategies
description:
This session will focus on strategies for recording and mastering a song from scratch using free to cheap audio software. I will be demonstrating with GarageBand on a Mac, anyone wishing to follow along with their own copy in class can certainly do so. But feel free to use whatever audio software you are comfortable with, the concepts in the session will be applicable across all platforms and operating systems. Some topics to be discussed:
  • Where to get sounds
  • Basic questions on quality
  • How to build your song (which tracks where and when)
  • Authoring and good songwriting tips for editing
  • What to do in post
This will be about half conceptual, half practical, with us building a little (mini) song of our own by the end of class. So if you want to participate in the practical part, bring a computer with your choice of multitrack recording software. There are links below to some that I know/would recommend. If you feel comfortable doing it, install the one you plan to use before coming to class. Also, if you have software you already like, feel free to use it instead of these. Audacity (Mac & Windows) http://audacity.sourceforge.net/   Sonar Free Trial (Windows) http://www.cakewalk.com/products/sonar/web-trial.aspx   Garageband (Mac) Available in the app store.

title: Design for Developers
description:
The truth is, developers aren't as good at design as they'd like to think they are. Ask any designer. But that doesn't mean you can't make the smallest of changes to really make that designer in your life happy. A few very simple steps will get you all kinds of cred and respect from them. And maybe you don't care about that, but it would probably make your life easier at work. (You know it would.) Here's the kind of things we're talking about:
  • UX concepts
  • Grids
  • Color
  • "Details..."
By the end of the session, I'll have you producing work that will have designers saying, "Well, it's not terrible." Which is probably something they're not saying right now. LINKS Here are some links and twitter ids of books, sites, and people you should get familiar with: Don't Make Me Think - Steve Krug http://www.amazon.com/Dont-Make-Me-Think-Usability/dp/0321344758/ Rocket Surgery Made Easy - Steve Krug http://www.amazon.com/Rocket-Surgery-Made-Easy--Yourself/dp/0321657292/ The Design of Everyday Things - Donal Norman http://www.amazon.com/Design-Everyday-Things-Donald-Norman/dp/0385267746 OOCSS https://github.com/stubbornella/oocss/wiki Grid Generator http://www.gridsystemgenerator.com/ Gradient Generator with Color Pallette http://www.colorzilla.com/gradient-editor/ Forrst (Awesome community resource for questions, advice, code snippets) http://forrst.com/ Whitney Hess (Great UX resource) http://whitneyhess.com/blog/ BE A FOLLOWER: @joestump @jasonsantamaria @BrainTraffic @TechCrunch (duh, but too useful to me to omit) @use_this @boagworld @CobraCommander (Nothing to do with design, just funny)

title: Introduction to processing.py
description: Python is a great language---easy to learn, and easy to use. Processing is a great framework for making interactive applications. processing.py combines the best of both: write your program in Python, but use all the features you know and love from Processing. This workshop will cover the basics of getting processing.py up and running, writing your first processing.py programs, and using existing Processing libraries (like the serial and video capture libraries) in your processing.py code. Prerequisites: basic knowledge of Python and Processing.

title: Wordpress Workshop
description: In most cases you don't want to start from scratch in putting together a website.  Cobbling together plugins and themes and with a touch of your own php and css will get you off and running really fast.  This session is for wordpress experts to help people who need to make a highly dynamic website.  I am looking for people to talk about their needs and I (hopefully with help) will try to see if Wordpress can be twisted to meet them.

title: Communications for Insurgents: Synchronize, Coordinate, Document
description: The idea that the internet would be a useful tool for insurgents in autocratic regimes has been around for 20 years, but the first actual overthrow of a autocratic state by revolutionaries using these tools happened only 20 weeks ago. Seeing insurgencies through the Middle East and North Africa, and full revolutions in Tunisia, Egypt, what can we learn about where insurgents can use these tools and where they can't, and what does that mean for the design and use of future social tools?

title: Design of Conversational Spaces
description:
Conversation is everywhere online, but that its quality ranges from terrific to terrible. The negative end of that scale is astonishingly bad – moronic rants, off-topic rambles, vitriolic attacks. (“dude just stfu nobody watches ur videos just gtfo out of you tube oh no were hurting his little feelings i feel soo bad”.)

Yet not all online speech suffers this fate; many sites manage to host productive conversations, from the talk pages on Wikipedia to the
design conversations on github to political debate on Comment is Free. Programmers have contentious but respectful conversations on StackOverflow and #winprog; crafters on Etsy and Ravelry; mathematicians on Polymath; pop artists on DeviantArt.

This session is about the design of environments that support or encourage good conversation: what makes comments on YouTube so bad, and on Ravelry so good? We will end with brainstorming about new possibilities for conversational spaces.

title: Digital Interactive Art with Mirrors
Jeremy Bailey talks about the thought controlled computer you care about more than him.
description:
Jeremy will talk about his work, including new thought controlled performance work for the New Museum.
"Jeremy is a Toronto-based new media artist whose work explores custom software in a performative context. Powered by humor and computer vision, his work wryly critiques the uneasy relationship between technology and the body while playfully engaging the protocols of digital media." (Greg J Smith, Rhizome)

title: The Games People Play -- an exploration of the different types of games
description:
This session will be an exploration of the different types of games, a topic of personal interest. I'll survey what I've found so far, covering the following topics:
  • what is a game? games versus play versus toys
  • can there ever be an organized taxonomy of all games? (cf. my favorite science fiction/fantasy novel)
  • types of game "platforms" (not just the video game platforms!)
  • the traditional video game categories -- and the shortcomings of these categories
  • types of casual game mechanics (cf. game designer Greg Trefry)
  • types of social game mechanics (cf. game designer Raph Koster)
  • types of "fun" that games gives us (cf. game designers Marc LeBlance and Nicole Lazzaro)
  • types of game players (cf. the BrainHex player model)
  • and finally... types of purposes for games, or what's the point of games? (cf. Bernard Suit's The Grasshopper)
I'll cite all kinds of games throughout as examples to hopefully bring the topic alive. And please do come with your own thoughts and game examples for discussion. Here are the slides.

title: Mobilizing Action (aka "Small Change in Our Pockets")
description: Building on Clay's session discussing Communications for Insurgents from last week, this session will focus on the role that mobile communications technology (phones, networks, protocols, etc). have played in movements and marches since the dawn of the telegraph. More than just a broad overview, we'll breakdown specific tech, tactics and tools utilized (either successfully or not), and discuss how they might be applied to the personal causes or campaigns of session attendees, and the apps they might build to empower them.   This session is based on the ITP course "Social Activism using Mobile Technology" taught in the Fall semester.

title: 'Learning by doing: using games in the real world.'
description:
Games and gamification are hot conversation topics these days, but most of these conversations are focused on screen-based games. What happens if you apply game mechanics to different contexts? In this session, we’ll focus on how principles from game design were applied to develop short-form emergency simulations for UNICEF.

In the first half of the session, we'll put you in the shoes of a UNICEF emergency response team and steer you towards making quick decisions about what course of action UNICEF should take in the aftermath of a major flood.

In the second half we’ll discuss the larger implications of simulation-based experiential learning -- as a powerful technique for introducing people to an organization, creating individualized empathy for a cause, or even just getting people to read through extremely dense training manuals.

title: Art of the Gift
description: As humans, our most personal accomplishments and memories are associated with the simple act of giving to others. As a community of makers living in an era of abundance, our ability to create worthy gifts and lasting memories is of growing value. 'Art of the gift' is a lecture and brainstorming session focused on the idea of the gift as a time honored vessel of social cohesion in our daily professional practices. Themes to explore include reciprocity, empathy, charity, forgiveness, the trojan horse, personalization, gift-wrapping, the Zakat and heirlooms.

title: Sneak Peek: A new Processing-based live coding performance application
description:
For the past month I've been working on a visual "live coding" framework that harnesses the power of Processing for visual rendering and Groovy for real-time code manipulation.  The goal here is to be able to change a Processing sketch and have the changes update in real-time to the running sketch without the need for recompiling.  My personal interests are in coding as a performance, but I think it has other uses as well.  I've got it to the point where it works, it's cool, and it needs user feedback.  However, it's very much in development mode.

This session will be the project's public unveiling.  I'm interested to hear your opinions on how it could be used, what features you'd like to see, and anything else you'd like to say.  It's currently called "Per4ming" (a riff on "Processing" and its nickname "P5") but I'm open to better suggestions!

Aside from the demo and feedback we will also talk about other live-coding projects (like fluxus), and how to shape a live coding performance.

This session is for people who are interested in live performance, algorithmic art, and bleeding edge software.

------------------LINKS

Toplap- The source for Live Coding info: http://www.toplap.org/

BBC piece about live coding: http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/8221235.stm

Video collection of live coding performances: http://livecoding.co.uk/doku.php/videos

"Show Us Your Screens" short documentary: http://vimeo.com/20241649

Per4ming Source Code: http://github.com/chris3000/per4ming

title: A+A (Android plus Arduino)
Hello Android
description:
Get started building apps for Android In order for things to go smoothly and not spend the entire time downloading software, it would be a big help if you all downloaded some of the necessities before hand:
You'll need the Android SDK from: http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html
You'll also need Eclipse: http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/eclipse-ide-java-developers/heliossr2 (the download links are on the right)
If you want to look ahead, here are the installation notes that we'll go through: http://itp.nyu.edu/~sve204/helloandroid/download_install.html


Class Notes: http://itp.nyu.edu/~sve204/helloandroid/helloandroid_2011.pdf

title: DIY U: Designing Self-Organized Education
description:
How do we learn, teach, and credential each other outside the expensive and slow-moving traditional educational institution? In this workshop we’ll explore the parameters of an ideal education organized on peer-to-peer principles. We’ll also create a credentialing system and award each other degrees.
  Anya Kamenetz is the author of two books, Generation Debt (Riverhead, 2006), which dealt with generational economics and politics including student loan policy, and DIY U: Edupunks, Edupreneurs, and the Coming Transformation of Higher Education, (Chelsea Green, 2010) which investigated the roots of the cost, access, and quality crises in higher education as well as innovations to address these crises. She has two forthcoming ebooks in the summer of 2011: Learning, Freedom and the Web, funded by the Mozilla Foundation, and The Edupunk's Guide, funded by the Gates Foundation. She's a senior writer at Fast Company, where she writes the column Life In Beta about change. She was named a 2010 Game Changer in Education
by the Huffington Post, received two National Awards for Education Reporting from the Education Writers Association in 2009 and 2010, and was nominated for a Pulitzer Prize in Feature Writing by the Village Voice in 2005. She travels and speaks across the country, blogs at DIYUBook.com, Twitters @anya1anya, and occasionally gives commentary on NPR, CNN and other news networks.
Session description coming soon...

title: Subway as musical instrument and HTML5 Canvas intro
description: I will be walking through the details behind MTA.ME, a project which turned the New York subway map into a string instrument, running on actual subway schedule data. (Watch video capture.) The visuals for MTA.ME were built in HTML5 Canvas and Javascript. I'll show some of the math/geometry behind the string plucking with snippets of code. Besides the hands-on details, I plan to talk about the creative process that led up to the project, and hopefully kick off a bigger discussion of interactive musical experiences. At the beginning of the session, I'll give a page of links where attendees can download the full source code as a take home kit. It will also include some HTML5 Canvas starter code, so that we can spend a bit of time doing some hands-on quick coding. All you need is an Canvas-capable browser (Chrome, Safari, Firefox) and a text editor to edit HTML and Javascript. I'm currently a designer at Google Creative Lab, living in Brooklyn. I also recently created the Les Paul Doodle with a small team here at Google, which reused some of the string plucking code used on MTA.ME. If people want to get a head start, I've put up this page of links. The full source of MTA.ME is there, as well as a few HTML5 Canvas starter templates and other useful links. Feel free to enter any questions or suggestions for specific aspects you might like to have discussed in the comments below. Looking forward to meeting everyone!

title: Workshop on Selling and Producing Innovation
description: The ability to sell an idea from inception through production to   clients, galleries, and peers is becoming increasingly difficult as   budgets are being more closely scrutinized.  The goal of this workshop is   to foster conversations about ways to “hack the system”  - I will ask the group to speak about projects they are having a hard time getting produced either in a corporate environment or on a freelance basis and we will come up with ways to get it done.  Additionally I will reference past projects I have worked on which have been successful (or failed) and how I might do things differently.

description: This is a regular ITP Class, not available to campers.
