title: Tinkering with Google's AppEngine
description:
Do you like making websites but hate server management? Google's AppEngine is an easy to use, no need to understand server management, web server. Learn the basic concepts of Google's AppEngine datastore (like a database), user authentication and other capabilities that let you work on the site and not think about how it will scale when BoingBoing blogs about you.

AppEngine can be built with Python or Java and soon Go. We will be covering AppEngine in Python, don't worry if you don't know Python, its syntax is easy to read and learn.

For more information on Google AppEngine, http://code.google.com/appengine/

title: NodeJS & Internet controlled Arduino with Javascript
description:
There are dozens of ways to have your Arduino connect to the Internet probably the most ridiculous is with Javascript, right? Javascript is great for frontend client web interactions but now with Node.js you can use JavaScript to build a 'chat' server that provides a TCP like connection to the browser. Node.js goes further and people have created serial port and arduino libraries.
In the session we will be covering the basics of javascript, getting to know your browser, the realtime web, NodeJS servers (http, tcp, websocket), Socket.io and basic chat room, and finally Socket.io to Internet connected Arduino - showing a basic input control of the Arduino,  with a button on webpage to turn on/off a LED.
After the session I'll post the slides and sample code online for reference and those folks that cannot attend.
For anyone who wants to get a head start with NodeJS, it could be helpful for you to install it on your own computer.
  • For MacOS X you can download Node and NPM (package manager) in one shot here, https://sites.google.com/site/nodejsmacosx/
  • For windows, http://node-js.prcn.co.cc/
After it is installed, open up the Terminal application and type 'node' and press enter. This will put you into the console and if you type '1+1' then <enter> you should get 2. to exit type '.exit'


Github repo - https://github.com/johnschimmel/node-session


Slides - https://docs.google.com/present/view?id=aftvwjrdxms_285gppfzghj

title: Quantified who? Designing self-monitoring for insight
Dying Hungry: Lede construction as a path to narrative enlightenment
description:
"Kazbek Misikov stared at the bomb hanging above his family. It was a simple device, a plastic bucket packed with explosive paste, nails, and small metal balls. It weighed perhaps eight pounds. The existence of this bomb had become a central focus of his life. If it exploded, Kazbek knew, it would blast shrapnel into the heads of his wife and two sons, and into him as well, killing them all."
If you can get this part down, the rest is easy. The lede is the first sentence or two of your narrative. It's where writing comes together if it manages to come together at all. But it's also there in how we tell stories to ourselves and others. It's the heart of the matter, the tl;dr. It's the grave where, when we speak badly, we bury our meanings in misplaced efforts to stay safe. The lede is a place where we boil down and clarify, and once we have it nailed, it protects the rest of the story.
"Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way."
In this class we'll sit there, for hours, and talk about how to build a lede. It won't be anywhere near enough time. You can't do it until you know what you think; that can take years. But once you have it the stories you tell will be more true, even the fake one.
"His followers called him Mahasamatman and said he was a god.  He preferred to drop the Maha- and the -atman, however, and called himself Sam.  He never claimed to be a god.  But then, he never claimed not to be a god."
It's not just about fiction, it's not even just about writing, it's about any idea that takes the form of a narrative, that contains an arc.
"Depression is the flaw in love."
Once you nail the lede, you nail the reader. A good lede makes the reader need to follow the story, to understand it, to the very end. There's more tricks and skills to the story, but without this one the rest of them never get read.
"Frank Sinatra, holding a glass of bourbon in one hand and a cigarette in the other, stood in a dark corner of the bar between two attractive but fading blondes who sat waiting for him to say something."

title: Shop Safety Training
description: Safety first! Learn how to work with tools, keep a safe shop clean and neat… and how not to cut off fingers! This session will a basic orientation to the shop at ITP. Every person who plans to use the shop is required by law to attend a safety session. We can accommodate up to 12 people per session

title: Meet the MakerBots
description: During this session, Adi and Caroline will introduce ITP's two resident MakerBots: the Cupcake CNC and the Thing-O-Matic. We'll talk about the process of assembling the 'bots, discuss some of their potential uses, and demonstrate a few prints.

title: HTML5 - The Cool Stuff
description: Come learn about some of the cooler new features available in HTML5.

title: DIY Flying Robots
description: You may have heard them referred to as UAV's, drones, "Flying Robots". The military has been using these robots for years, but it has been only recently that the technology to create flying robots has become available to hobbyists. There are several open source communities developing autonomous flying platforms. These robots have practical uses such as aerial photography, wildlife tracking, surveillance, cartography and just pure fun to fly. We'll show you how to get started in building a flying robot. We will go over different open source platforms. Find the best approach for building a drone for specific applications. We will discuss the consequences of having this technology available to the public, including regulations from the FAA. For more information visit scoutuav.com | Presentation Slides

title: Hands-on Data Visualization (with S.Dean & M.Frick)
Place Representation and the "One Earth" Model
description:
Much of the history of representation, as both an art and a science, has concentrated on conveying sense of place. Representing actual places presents unique opportunities and challenges because–unlike fantasy places–actual places share common frames of reference as indexed by latitude, longitude, altitude, and time. Thus, all real-world representations can cross-correlate into a singular, unimaginably giant Earth model, containing as much detail as is chosen to add.

The big players know it and the field is lively. Advances and new features spring up weekly. So have critical concerns–around access, control, privacy, and authenticity. The arts community knows this and can play as both bridge-builder and provocateur.

My presentation is based on a seminar taught last year at NYU ITP and touches upon such topics as Google Earth and Streetview, MS PhotoSynth and Streetside, crowdsourcing, camera cars, ortho-stereo display, folksonomy, nodal points, "playbor," webcams, and the visual perception of Mbuti Pygmies.

title: Shop Safety Training
description: Safety first! Learn how to work with tools, keep a safe shop clean and neat… and how not to cut off fingers! This session will a basic orientation to the shop at ITP. Every person who plans to use the shop is required by law to attend a safety session. We can accommodate up to 12 people per session

title: Vlog Roulette
description: Campers have 4 hours to produce the basics of a video blog series, shoot three episodes, edit and post online. History of video blogging and examples will be covered in the first 45 minutes. No previous film/video experience is necessary. Final vlogs will be screened at the vlog roulette festival at 5:00pm.

title: Introduction to the Facebook Platform
description:
You like Facebook, right?  Of course you do — and so do nearly 700 million other people.  That's why it makes so much sense to build applications on and using the Facebook platform, and why so many developers use their toolkits in their work.

Since launching the Facebook Platform in 2007, developers have had access to  an incredible amount of data about users, their friends, and their activities online.  The platform has grown, matured, and changed a lot since then, however, and there's still a lot to take in if you're just diving in.

This session will cover the basics for setting up a Facebook application, gotchas for devlopers, good idea/bad idea points, and more.  Examples will be in JavaScript, but anybody comfortable with REST API's should feel right at home.

title: Real-time 3D graphics in Processing 2
description: My main goal for this session is to describe the new OpenGL-based renderers for Processing 2.0, called OPENGL2 on PC and Mac, and A3D on Android. OPENGL2/A3D make 3D graphics performance closer to that of C++, while keeping the simplicity of the Processing interface, and adding new functions for real-time rendering. I will start with an overview of the functions available in OPENGL2 and A3D, and will continue with examples and simple applications of 3D rendering (camera, lighting, transformations, textures, models). I will also describe a new method for fast rendering of complex geometry (shade recording). The example codes will be demonstrated using OPENGL2 on PC and Mac, but most of them translate over to Android without major modifications. [caption id="attachment_1863" align="aligncenter" width="600" caption="Screen capture from the Planets example included with the OPENGL2 and A3D renderers."][/caption]

title: Image filters and 3D effects with GLSL shaders
description: In this session I will introduce shader programming using the OpenGL Shading Language (GLSL). Shaders make possible to program the Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) in order to run complex image post-processing filters and effects like bump mapping and vertex deformations in real-time. This will be an advanced session (sort of a continuation of my 3D Graphics in Processing session the day before), so it is recommended that people attending this one already have some knowledge of 3D graphics and OpenGL. Online material like the Lighthouse GLSL tutorial, and Learning Modern 3D Graphics Programming are a recommended reading. I will present an overview of the programmable graphics pipeline of modern GPUs, followed by application examples of GLSL shaders in Processing, implemented using JOGL and the GLGraphics library. [caption id="attachment_1866" align="aligncenter" width="512" caption="Screen capture from the ShaderToy example included in GLGraphics. Originally written by Inigo Quilez. "][/caption]

title: Monday Meetup
description: This weekly moment acts as a springboard for the week to come. Camp Counselors will present "This Week at Camp". Campers are invited to make announcements, pitch projects, and call for collaborators. Specially catered edibles selected by this week's Food Captain will be served.

title: 1 to 1  Breathing underwater?
description:
[caption id="attachment_1682" align="alignnone" width="224" caption="Breathing Underwater 2"] 
[/caption]  
Breathing Underwater
I played with magnets yesterday, hanging forks and cookies in baggies from the fridge, iPhone necklace, over the door remote control holder. Yesterday, I had a strong compulsion to control the chaos.  Organizize  my scattered belongings.  The clutter is a result of my clumsy way of trying to get rid of 70% of my  stuff to move into a studio in NYC. I identify with mermaids.  I was conceived on a boat - so I was told, lived on the beach, and always swim, better than I could walk since being hit by a drunk driver. I have been renting a house with a canal in the back.  Beautiful.  Love the ocean.  I was told by my landlord that he was selling my house and I had to move out. I decided to move to NYC.  The past 3 months of my life have been consumed with finding an apartment in Manhattan. Today I took pictures of my new apartment in the city and met with the super. I believe my creation, Breathing underwater is me leaving the summer life of Long Beach and moving in with the masses that NYC hoards. I am a writer and right brained and am dying to fill in the technical gaps missing in my left brain. My magnetic people are clinging to the circuit board in hope of becoming tech minded and fit into ITP camp.

title: Monday Meetup
description: This weekly moment acts as a springboard for the week to come. Camp Counselors will present “This Week at Camp”. Campers are invited to make announcements, pitch projects, and call for collaborators. Specially catered edibles selected by this week’s Food Captain will be served.

description: This weekly moment acts as a springboard for the week to come. Camp Counselors will present “This Week at Camp”. Campers are invited to make announcements, pitch projects, and call for collaborators. Specially catered edibles selected by this week’s Food Captain will be served.

title: Monday Meetup
description: This weekly moment acts as a springboard for the week to come. Camp Counselors will present “This Week at Camp”. Campers are invited to make announcements, pitch projects, and call for collaborators. Specially catered edibles selected by this week’s Food Captain will be served.

title: How to Clone a really, really, tiny part of Yourself
description:
Presented by Oliver Medvedik, Ph.D.
Co-Founder and Director of Scientific Programs Development, Genspace

A hands on workshop in learning to use the most widespread tools of biotechnology (polymerase chain reaction and gel electrophoresis). You'll then use these tools to amplify and analyze your own genomic DNA. We'll specifically be amplifying a region of our DNA that will then enable us to determine whether or not we possess a naturally occurring genetic variation that grants us resistance to HIV-1, the virus that causes AIDS. This genetic variation is currently the focus of intense research towards the development of a cure for HIV infections.

Limit 12 participants. First come, first serve.  Please RSVP by commenting 'I'll be there.'

title: Bio Energy: Build Your Own Microbial Fuel Cell
description:
Explore concepts in alternative energy and decentralized models for energy production. Learn about algae biofuels, bio batteries, and microbial fuel cells. Part lecture/discussion, part hands-on building of your own microbial fuel cell.

Limit 15 participants. First come, first serve.  Please RSVP by  commenting 'I'll be there.'

title: Build Your Own Gel Electrophoresis Box
description:
With cell biologist Dr. Ellen Jorgensen

The ability to separate molecules based on charge is an important tool for synthetic biologists and others. We'll go over the theory and practice of gel electrophoresis, then each participant will build a simple gel box out of plexiglass and platinum wire which can be operated using an external power supply or 9V batteries.  When the boxes are finished we'll use them to separate molecules of dye and DNA. We'll also discuss what cool things you can do with the box at home, and where to buy supplies for your own experiments.

Limit 15 participants. First come, first serve.  Please RSVP by  commenting 'I'll be there.'

title: FIELD TRIP: RYOJI IKEDA the transfinite
description:
Hello all, I'd like to organize an excursion to see RYOJI IKEDA the transfinite, a multimedia interactive installation at the Park Avenue Armory (643 Park Avenue at 66th Street.) The only time I could really do it this week is tomorrow, and I would propose 4pm. If that doesn't work for others then perhaps you could organize a second field trip. Sign up if you want to go. Come around 3:50, and we'll be going inside at 4pm - you can reach me on my cell at 310-595-5330 if you have any questions or can't find us.

A bit more about the installation from the website, or watch this video. ”…spectacular, trippy and fun…the transfinite is definitely something to see and experience.  Sublime spectacle.” –The New York Times “Rocks the senses…the Drill Hall…has lately become the playground for artists with outsized imaginations.” –Financial Times “...a physical manifestation of information in its rawest form.” –Time Out NY ”…an extreme and elaborate visual and sonic environment.” –New York Magazine Following critically acclaimed installations by Ernesto Neto and Christian Boltanski, Ryoji Ikeda has been selected by the Armory for its third annual visual art commission in the Wade Thompson Drill Hall. Ikeda creates a visual and sonic environment where visitors are submerged in an extreme illustration of projected and synchronized data. His work uses scale, light, shade, volume, shadow, electronic sounds, and rhythm to flood the senses. In choreographing vast amounts of digital information, Ikeda conjures up a transformative environment in which visitors confront data on a scale that defies comprehension, experiencing the infinite. This installation includes strobe effects.

title: 1-in-1 Round 2
description:
Because I missed the one on Saturday, I'm calling all campers to help us all get a re-do for the 1-in-1 this weekend.

Anyone who missed the first one or anyone who liked it enough to do it again should come!!!

If no one shows up, I'll just have to do my own sad little project, all by myself. Talking to the wall for inspiration (though solitude can sometimes make for interesting inspiration).

But if you're so inclined to particpate, bring your ideas and let's make something on Sunday!

title: Instructional Comics
description: Comics That Explain Technology From Will Eisner's PS magazine to Scott McCloud's introduction to the Chrome browser, comics have often been used to describe technical material. This session will look at using comics to explain technical information and other uses of comics in education. We'll also look very briefly at the history of comics. [caption id="attachment_2233" align="aligncenter" width="210" caption="Cover Issue One of Preventive Maintenance Monthly"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_2234" align="aligncenter" width="203" caption="Page One of Google Chrome Browser Comic"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_2235" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Howtoons"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_2260" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Intro to Arduino Comic"][/caption] Here's a page of links, more stuff at session. Here's the powerpoint presentation as a pdf. comics-instructional-3

title: Finance 101 to Grad School in 60 minutes
UX Design with Keynote
description:
Build out your UX design in Keynote! Keynote allows rapid prototyping of all of your application's views to quickly illustrate the user flow before getting knee deep in code. We will first build a basic mobile app prototype in Keynote.  Then, we will see how easy it is to insert your own designs without rebuilding all your actions.  Finally, we will export a prototype onto the iPhone for testing.  There are advantages and disadvantages to doing this and we'll explore those, along with any questions you may have along the way. Anyone can attend, but you will get the most out of this class if you have:
  • a Mac
  • Keynote($19.99 in the Mac App Store)
  • an iPhone

title: Intro to Processing
description: What can computation add to human communication? Creating computer  applications, instead of just using them, will give you a deeper  understanding of the essential possibilities of computation. The session focuses on the fundamentals of programming the computer (variables,  conditionals, iteration, and functions). The Java-based  'Processing' programming environment is the primary vehicle for the session.  This session is designed for computer  programming novices.

title: Intro to Processing
description: What can computation add to human communication? Creating computer  applications, instead of just using them, will give you a deeper  understanding of the essential possibilities of computation. The session focuses on the fundamentals of programming the computer (variables,  conditionals, iteration, and functions). The Java-based  'Processing' programming environment is the primary vehicle for the session.  This session is designed for computer  programming novices.

title: Pollie Barden - Telematic Dinner Party
description: Reserved for research project

title: Post Telematic Dinner Party Interviews
description: This is my post.

title: Technology via Inspiration
description:
This session focuses on interactive multimedia technology and how it is used to create projects that are:
  • fun [  ]
  • beautiful [  ]
  • compelling [  ]
  • meaningful [  ]
  • all of the above [  ]
I will show some of the applications I have worked on and demonstrate various techniques to get to the finished product as well as highlight fundamental programming concepts. Projects will include a game, an art project, a mobile/tablet application, an award-winning website, an interactive animation. Programming concepts covered will be:
  • the rendering process (you are staring at it right now)
  • bytes (scary but fun)
  • multitouch technology and gestures (the future is now)
  • using a 3rd party technology (Google maps, requests no introduction unless you have been living under a rock sans wifi)
  • game logic (not as hard as knowing how to walk or tie shoe laces)
  • trigonometry (because not everything moves along a straight line)
  • organizing data and assets (programmers all have OCD, it is not our fault, the computers make us)
Design concepts discussed will be about visualizing ideas and displaying (sometimes massive) information in a manageable and attractive fashion. My goal to make you feel empowered, inspired and joyful. Links for some of the work covered and references Mesocosm by Marina Zurkow: http://www.o-matic.com/blog/?p=1959 American Museum of Nation History - Biodiversity hall: http://www.v-ro.com/work/amnh1.html Local Projects - NY Visitor Center: http://localprojects.net/types/page/7/?type=multi-touch-touchscreen and http://www.v-ro.com/work/nyvisitor.html Make History website: http://localprojects.net/types/page/5/?type=websites Sokoban Game: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sokoban and some Computer Science Reference papers: http://larc.unt.edu/techreports/LARC-2011-01.pdf and http://www.slideshare.net/jamcheca/isia-ia4 Lifetime TV Open House game: http://www.mylifetime.com/games/online-games/open-house.aspx Bit blit technique (also called blitting): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bit_blit ROME (musical video and WebGL): http://www.ro.me/

title: liiive.tv workshop
description: <!-- p.p1 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 12.0px Verdana} -->See Shawn Van Every's one-to-many FaceTime hack and participate in our mobile webcasting experiments!

title: Using Cinder in iPad Apps for Visualization
description: The Apple SDK for the iPad affords developers a lot of control for drawing with OpenGL ES1 and 2 (with many enhancements announced at Apple's WWDC 2011), but Apple is not the only tablet platform and its Objective C-based SDK, although powerful and elegant, is not designed for artists. Cinder, a Processing-like library based in C++ is designed for visualization. When used inside an app built with the Apple SDK, it creates an environment that's slightly friendlier to the Processing/Flash/Silverlight communities. In our session, we'll explain our evolving reasons for using this method for tablet projects plus demonstrate how it can be used inside a standard Objective C project using the Apple SDK's EAGLView. The example will be a very simple visualization of data stored in a JSON file.

title: Intro to Objects w/ Processing
description: Objects can help you write code that is powerful, dynamic, and easier to manage.  This session will focus on how to get started with Object Oriented Programming with Processing.  It will start with simple examples to help reduce the difficulty of understanding the basic concepts, but we'll move into more complex subjects such as inheritance and polymorphism to really show how powerful objects can be.

title: Intro to Objects w/ Processing
description: Objects can help you write code that is powerful, dynamic, and easier to manage.  This session will focus on how to get started with Object Oriented Programming with Processing.  It will start with simple examples to help reduce the difficulty of understanding the basic concepts, but we'll move into more complex subjects such as inheritance and polymorphism to really show how powerful objects can be.

title: Making Electricity II
description:
Note: This is now a separate post from the first session: if you RSVP'd to this date previously, please do so again. Depending on who's attending, this could be a continuation of the first session (starting with solar and covering batteries and capacitors) or an intro starting at energy + electricity basics. - Jeff You use it - now make it. In this crash course we'll turn small motors into generators, explore solar panels, and dissect batteries and capacitors (for storing electricity). Along the way you'll gain precision in thinking about energy and power, and perspective on energy technologies at larger scales. Basic parts provided for use in-session; feel free to BYO small motors or solar panels. Some resources from my Energy class:
  • Kinetic energy slides, kinetic electrical one-sheet
  • Basic crank circuit, Advanced crank circuit, circuit 2
  • Power conditioning flowchart
  • Energy Storage overview, Capacitors, Batteries
  • Solar overview
Also:
  • Updated US electricity generation numbers (source)
  • LNL Energy Flowcharts

title: Creative Show & Tell
description:
This session will give us an opportunity to learn a little bit more about what each of us does for a living, makes on the side, or has always dreamed about doing or making but never had the chance. Each attendee will have 2-5 minutes to show images/video/audio of past work, and talk briefly about their current interests and ideas. It will be a great way to meet potential collaborators and see what skills other people can bring to the table.

Ideally, whatever you would like to show would already be on the internet (on your website, blog, flickr page, etc), so transitioning from one person to the next will be as easy as typing in a new URL. Small files on a Mac-compatible jump drive would also be okay. Presentations don't have to be well-prepared; the format will be very informal in order to encourage an open dialogue.

Please come to show, tell, or if you're shy but curious, just sit and watch other people do the showing and telling. And if this sounds like fun to you but this day/time doesn't work, let's schedule another one for sometime next week.

Alicia Eggert

www.aliciaeggert.com

title: Intro to the Kinect: Gestural Interfaces
description:
This class will provide an overview of the Microsoft Kinect and teach you the basics of using it to make interactive, gesture-controlled, applications in Processing.

We'll install the simple-openni Processing library, learn how to locate the user's joints, and learn how to use these to build some basic gestural interfaces. Additional topics covered will include the basics of drawing and measuring in 3D in Processing.

title: FILMMAKING WORKSHOP (4 sessions, 4 hours)
description:
Four sessions that cover different aspects of filmmaking and video production. They will be interactive, and you will get the most out of them if you come with projects of your own or questions. Feel free to come to whichever hours interest you most. Leave any ideas, requests, or questions in the comments, or reach me at michael@mjmfilms.com. (If you want to see some of my stuff, check out my music video, commerical, some artsy stuff and a documentary.)

Session 1 (5pm): Introduction to Editing with Final Cut Pro

(or any other non-linear editing software!) Before class time, download editing software: Premiere Pro for Mac/PC, the free Lightworks for a PC, or Final Cut Pro, which does not come with a free trial. You may be able to check out a computer with FCP from the equipment room. This class will cover the basics of using and getting around Final Cut Pro, and after an hour any intimidation will become excitement for using this new tool.
  • overview on how editing works
  • how to get video in and out of the software
  • making edits and transitions
  • panning across images
  • adding titles

Session 2 (6pm): Advanced Editing and Color Correction

We will cover more advanced topics, for those who know a bit about editing and want to advance your skillset:
  • blending modes, track mattes, and effects, oh my!
  • color correction with Final Cut Pro and Color
  • sound editing with Soundtrack Pro
  • if we have time, we will begin to cover video formats for the next session

Session 3 (7pm): Constructing a Narrative and Technical Filmmaking

Two more or less unrelated items. Constructing a Narrative should be useful for anybody who is building projects with story associated. I will cover the essential elements of narrative and how to create and sustain interest, using several clips from films as examples. If we have time I will go into a discussion of technical filmmaking.

Session 4 (8pm): Collaborative work, further teaching, and questions

Bring projects to work on together or brainstorm ideas for film and narrative. We can also use this time to go over things that were covered earlier, work one on one, or explore other related topics.

title: Learning Processing by Learning Kinect
Making Soft Sensors
description: We'll go over the basic techniques of soft circuits and then make some sensors (eg. on/off switch, pressure sensor, stroke sensor, etc.) to control the brightness of an LED. I'll provide conductive fabrics, conductive thread, etc., but please do bring the following: - SMT battery holders with flat pads. These work very well: http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Eagle-Plastic-Devices/122-2820-GR/?qs=sGAEpiMZZMupuRtfu7GC%252bUBbujVUAwsWIdu88PLQZEU%3d - 3V lithium battery (CR2025 or CR2032) - 1 or 2 LEDs - sewing supplies (needles, thread, scissors, needle threader) - scrap pieces of fabric (felt is great) - if you'd like to apply your circuit to a pillow, muslin doll or t-shirt, bring them too :) Session Slides: http://www.slideshare.net/catlx/making-soft-sensors Other Resources: http://openmaterials.org/?s=soft+circuits http://www.kobakant.at/DIY/ Tutorial (Becky Stuart wrote a great tutorial on how she made her voodoo doll during the session): http://blog.theleadingzero.com/?p=262

title: Prototyping for Wearables
description:
Our bodies are our primary interface for the world. Interactive systems designed to live on the body can be intimate, upfront, and sometimes literally in your face. But bringing these systems from concept to prototype can be challenging. This session will provide an overview of the following:
  • general concepts of physical computing as applied to wearables
  • factors to consider when choosing parts & materials
  • soft and alternative approaches to circuitry
  • wearables prototyping platforms including the Lilypad: http://www.sparkfun.com/categories/135
  • strategies for incorporating electronics into garments & accessories

title: 3D Printing @ Makerbot's Botfarm
Mobilized Maps: Engaging a Crowd in a Reporting Project (rescheduled)
description: This is a session on mobilizing crowds for mapping projects. That was my job at the public radio station here, WNYC, starting 5 years ago, when we got hundreds of radio listeners to report on the prices of goods at their local groceries to see if they were being gouged. This year, we got listeners to report on the first major snow storm of the winter when the city was slow to clear the streets. And last month, we got people to submit their favorite bird-watching spot in the city (along with what they last saw), which we did with The New York Times. Here are links to the mapping projects: WNYC Snow Map WNYC/New York Times Bird Map Are You Being Gouged: Crowdsourcing Food Prices in NYC

title: Intro to CNC Router: Demystifying Digital Fabrication
description:
5pm - 8pm

In this session I will explain the CNC (Computer Numerical Control) Router and how to design for such a powerful tool.  Individuals who have attended earlier sessions or have previous experience with design software such as Rhino, Illustrator or AutoCAD will be well prepared for the ideas discussed.

Topics:
Modeling and Drawing in brief.
Understanding the Machine
Importing File Types
What is CAM (Computer Aided Machining) and how to create tool paths.
Master CAM, a program used for producing machining instructions from 2D and 3D models.
Software alternatives and tools that use similar workflow.

You should expect to understand what is necessary to create something using this tool and will be able to take advantage of the router for the rest of ITP camp, with assistance from camp staff.

title: 6 Minutes or Less
description:
Wikipedia defines the following:
  • Pecha Kucha (Japanese: ペチャクチャ, IPA: [pet͡ɕa ku͍̥t͡ɕa][1], chit-chat) is a presentation methodology in which 20 slides are shown for 20 seconds each, usually seen in a multiple-speaker event called a Pecha Kucha Night (PKN).
  • Ignite is a global event, organized by volunteers, where participants are given five minutes to speak about their ideas and personal or professional passions, accompanied by 20 slides. Each slide is displayed for 15 seconds, and slides are automatically advanced. The Ignite format is similar to Pecha Kucha, which features 20 slides displayed for 20 seconds each. The presentations are meant to "ignite" the audience on a subject, i.e. to generate awareness and to stimulate thought and action on the subjects presented.
This session will provide an introduction on how to give a talk in 6 minutes or less. It will cover how to pick a topic, prep your slides, practice your speech, own the audience, and scam the system. We'll close with an exercise in which you'll make an entire presentation in 15 minutes. This is great way to get going for those who want to give a talk at the closing party on June 30th! DOWNLOAD SLIDES HERE

title: POSTPONED - The 2011 ITP Camp Games Mega-Tournament
description: >> FUN -- LEARNING ABOUT GAMES -- PRIZES -- GLORY!!! << You are invited to come have fun, socialize, and learn about different types of games in a practical hands-on way this Sunday at 3pm at the 2011 ITP Camp Games Mega-Tournament. (That title is firmly tongue-in-cheek. It's more an un-tournament, being organized as an ad hoc follow-on to my session on games this past Sunday. EVERYONE'S WELCOME and no need to have come to that session to enjoy the tournament.) Please sign up below. It will be very helpful for planning to know how many people are coming. There will be around 10 games of all sorts, some physical, some strategic, some fast-paced, some artistic, some social, some solitary. All games will all be accesible and easy-to-learn on the spot. You can also come a bit early to practice if you want (and only if you want). NO EXPERIENCE WITH ANY OF THE GAMES NEEDED. The better you do in each game, the more tournament point you'll earn. We'll keep a running tally on a wall of how everyone's doing and in the end give our various prizes (e.g. best at strategy games, best at physical games, etc.) and of course a Grand Prize for being the best overall. To make it more competitive, we'll try some handicapping based on player's general level of experience (starting from "none") with the games, and we'll also have a tournament scoring formula that, for instance, ignores the 2 or 3 worst scores on individual games you got. At the end of the tournament, we'll spend some time talking about the experience, referencing the different game platforms, game mechanics, social mechanics, and types of fun discussed at last Sunday's session. Again, no worries if you didn't come to the session; it will all still make sense and be educational. Finally, hopefully we can get someone to take some photos and videos of highlights during the afternoon, and perhaps someone can DJ some music. And we'll see about beer and snacks. Here's the tentative game-plan, subject to revision. As an ice-breaker, we'll start with a group party game called Mafia: 1. Mafia - the classic party game of social persuasion and acting in which everyone plays together. You are either a mafia member or a townsperson. Each "night" someone gets secretly killed by the mafia. The townpeople then debate who to kill in return for being a suspected mafia member. The longer you live, the more tournament points you get. If you've never played, you are in for a psychological treat. Then we'll have a series of small group games: 2. Scrabble - 4 players at a time. The normal word-tile game, except with a chess-style timer to keep things moving along. Play multiple times with different opponents as time allows. The more Scrabble points you get, the more tournament points you get. 3. Stratego (the Barrage of "speed" version) - a face-paced version of Stratego, a classic 1-on-1 board game simulating two armies fighting each other. Easy to learn, hard to master. 4. Harbor Master - a top-selling "casual game" for iPad. You are the harbor master and have to make sure the ships unload their cargo without crashing. It's a at times calm, at times frantic game of "attention management". Use the wonderfully intuitive touch interface to draw routes for ships, shoot the attacking pirates, and kill the giant squid. If time allows, we'll play single player and two people cooperating at a time. Also we'll project the image on a large screen for spectator enjoyment. 5. Bomberman - a classic dead simple but completely engrossing multiplayer game where everyone is trying to blow up everyone else. 4 players at a time. Last person standing wins. Great fun, and great to watch also. We'll also have a few 1 player games: 6. Clock - a mesmerizing, abstractly beautiful game of concentration and hand-eye coordination by game designer Luke O'Conner. Featured at NYU Game Center's recent No Quarter exhibition of indie games, for which it was commissioned. Takes a minute to play but totally addictive and you'll want to keep playing to get it right. 7. Whac-a-Wall - my ITP Camp 1-in-1 project! Like Whac-a-Mole but on a wall, using Kinect for motion detection. See how many critters you can whack in a minute. Involves jumping and waving your arms around and getting maniacally laughed at when you miss (or when my calibration is off...) 8. Passage + reflections on Passage. Passage is a 5-minute "art game" by noted indie game designer Jason Rohrer (see this Esquire magazine profile). Be warned, this surprising little game might make you cry. The contest is this tournament isn't to cry the most, but to express your thoughts and feelings in the most compelling way after you play. We'll put the game in a separate room and give you some time to write or draw some post-play thoughts. Then everyone will vote on the thoughts and you get tournament points based on these votes. For a note of randomness, we'll have:  9. Pass the Pigs. A game of complete chance that you can't stop playing once you get in the mood. Good dumb fun -- or deep philosophical truth? And finally, to end the festivities, we'll play: 10. Ping Pong -- Around the World! We might be able to get a full-sized ping pong table onto the floor so we can play. One idea is to end the tournament with the group game variant of Ping Pong called "Around the World". Everyone runs around and around the table hitting the ball back and forth. You get eliminated from the rotation if you miss. Last person to survive wins. Watch this for an idea of how it works. The exact plan will evolve over the coming week. Please share suggestions, ideas, and requests.  At the end of the tournament, we'll hand out prizes and see what we've learned after an afternoon that will hopefully have been a lot of fun together. Again, please sign up below so I know how many people to plan for, or email me. Also if you want help with video/photos, DJ'ing, keeping score, or whatever, that'd be much appreciated!

title: Proclipsing: Processing + Eclipse
description: The Processing Development Environment is  a great way to get started programming, but there are other Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) that have features that make coding and debugging much easier.  One such IDE is Eclipse, the popular free and open source Java standard.  Though powerful, Eclipse can take some getting used to, as the number of tools, functions, and GUI elements can be confusing.  Proclipsing is a plugin for Eclipse that simplifies the basics of creating a Processing Project in Eclipse and exporting them.  This session will discuss how to install Eclipse, add Proclipsing to it, and start taking advantage of the features of Eclipse to write code better and faster.

title: Proclipsing: Processing + Eclipse
description: The Processing Development Environment is  a great way to get started programming, but there are other Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) that have features that make coding and debugging much easier.  One such IDE is Eclipse, the popular free and open source Java standard.  Though powerful, Eclipse can take some getting used to, as the number of tools, functions, and GUI elements can be confusing.  Proclipsing is a plugin for Eclipse that simplifies the basics of creating a Processing Project in Eclipse and exporting them.  This session will discuss how to install Eclipse, add Proclipsing to it, and start taking advantage of the features of Eclipse to write code better and faster.

title: Get Your Hands Dirty! Intro to Casting and Mold Making – Part 1
description: Get Your Hands Dirty! Session 1 Introduction to Casting and Mold Making in two hands – on sessions Session One (Saturday June 25  2:00-4:30 pm) will introduce the basics, with a description of tools and techniques, how to design a mold, and how to choose the appropriate casting material. We’ll work with clay, plaster, and alginate, and make a plaster cast of a hand. Meet in the shop area at the big tables. Session Two (Tuesday June 28  6:00-8:30 pm) will build on session one and introduce the latest two-part rubber and plastic compounds as well as fiberglass reinforced plaster. We’ll make a silicone rubber mold and cast with polyurethane plastic and foam. http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/casting.html http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/wiki/index.php/Classes/Class5CastingAndMoldmakingI http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/wiki/index.php/Classes/Class6CastingAndMoldmakingII

title: RESCHEDULED Get Your Hands Dirty! Intro to Casting and Mold Making – Part 2
description: RESCHEDULED Get Your Hands Dirty! Session 2 Introduction to Casting and Mold Making in two hands – on sessions During  Session One (Saturday June 25  2:00-4:30 pm) we started with the basics, with a description of tools and techniques, how to design a mold, and how to choose the appropriate casting material. We worked with clay, plaster, and alginate, and made a plaster cast of a hand. If you missed the first session come anyway, and we'll start with a brief review. Session Two (Sunday June 26  12:00-2:30 pm) will build on session one and introduce the latest two-part rubber and plastic compounds as well as fiberglass-reinforced plaster. We’ll make a silicone rubber mold and cast with polyurethane plastic and foam. Meet in the shop area at the big tables. http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/casting.html http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/wiki/index.php/Classes/Class5CastingAndMoldmakingI http://itp.nyu.edu/materials/wiki/index.php/Classes/Class6CastingAndMoldmakingII

title: Wanna be a VJ? Intro to Realtime Visual Performance
description: VJ'ing is the art of realtime visual performance, performing alongside DJ's or live musicians to create a multimedia experience. This session will introduce you to the basics to help get you started. We'll start with a brief history, then cover software (both commercial and open source), hardware (from projectors to mixers), and finally discuss gig preparation, setup, and other real life concerns for visual performance artists in the field. No extra software or hardware needed, but coming to the session with Max/MSP + Jitter installed would help, as I'll be using it for part of the demo and sharing example code. You can find a free 30 day trial here: http://cycling74.com/downloads/

title: Introduction to openFrameworks
description:
openFrameworks is an open source toolkit for creative computing and is very similar to Processing. The major differences are that it uses C++, not Java, as the programming language and it does not have its own software called an IDE (integrated development environment). For a very technical description of the differences between Processing and OF, see the OF wiki. Before the session, go through the setup instructions. Schedule
  • 2:30-3:00 I will be available to help anyone who had problems with installation.
  • 3:00-4:30 We will go over how OF works and have a very basic introduction to essential concepts in C++. We will try to spend most of the time programming and learning by doing, because no one wants to listen to a lecture on a Saturday afternoon.
  • 4:30-5:00 I will quickly go over some more advanced topics in OF such as addons and debugging just to demonstrate the possibilities of what can be done OF
Who should attend this session? If you have programmed in C/C++/C#/Java, feel comfortable with Processing and/or have used an IDE besides Arduino or Processing (perhaps attend the Proclipsing session) then this session may be beneficial. If you've only recently started programming and are still getting familiar with Processing, then this might move a little fast. Of course everyone is welcome! Those that don't want to code but are curious about OF, the last half hour may be of interest. There are some instructional videos on how to setup and use openFrameworks here. Here are the slides:
A Gentle Introduction to openFrameworks

title: Projects, Talks, and Process Work
description:
Because Camp is meant as a spring board, this is an opportunity to collectively consider What Happens Next. An great way to get that conversation going is to share What's Happened So Far. Here are some ways you can share:
  • PROJECTS: Did you create a project at camp? This is a good opportunity to install your work and share it with the group. The large screens in the front hallway are available as well as many spaces in the lounge and classrooms.
  • IGNITE TALKS: 20 slide. 15 seconds each. 5 minutes of auto-advancing fun! Topics can include projects, areas of expertise, emerging ideas, and reflections on things you learned at camp. Please sign up by Tuesday evening and the schedule will be determined accordingly!
  • PROCESS WORK: Most often Camp is about starting rather than finishing so process work can be extremely valuable to share. Got a basic demo? A mock up? A wireframe? A first draft? Think about how you might share that with the group in some form.
  • SESSION RESULTS: What happened in there? Unless you did really really well in Amanda's cloning workshop, you likely didn't get a chance to attend every session. Which sessions had results that are worth reviewing? Should the Microbial Fuel Cells be hooked up in parallel to achieve a yet-to-be-known amperage? Should the 1-in-1 projects be collectively showcased so we can consider what really can be done in a day? What else?
  • BEYOND: If there's anything else you think should be shared before parting ways now is the time! The suggestion box is open.
If you are planning to show a project, give a talk, or seize any other opportunities please leave a comment below!

title: Hacking the Dinner Party: An Introduction to Sous Vide & Meat Glue
description: The dinner party is the original burning platform for social interaction. For the host/cook, it is a chance to not only create a social hub but to express oneself through the food that is prepared and served to guests. Sous Vide and Acvita (Meat Glue) are force multipliers that can dramatically amplify the size, scope, and level of creativity behind the dinner parties that you throw. This session will introduce both techniques and explain how you can use them to throw kick ass dinners for your friends. Sous vide cooking means cooking under vacuum, typically with the help of an immersion circulator, which is a high precision water temperature regulator. Learn the basics of how to use a vacuum sealer and an immersion circulator to create an incredibly wide range of foods. I will introduce the basic methods to cook with sous vide, display a few examples of sous vide recipes, discuss safety, and how you can create/hack your own sous vide setup at home. Also up for discussion is an introduction to Activa, affectionately known in culinary circles as "meat glue." Activa is an enzyme that binds proteins together and can be used to make novel gastronomic delights. It also plays a synergistic role with sous vide techniques and its usage will be integrated into the sous vide tutorial. Bio: Mike Lee is the founder and chef of Studiofeast, an invitation only dining collective based in NYC. Studiofeast plans and executes pop-up style dinners and was recently a part of the supperclub group that cooked and served a 6 course lunch on the L Train. He is an ITP Camp 2010 alum. /// SLIDES POSTED /// Thanks to all those who attended. Here's a link to a recap that includes the slides, some photos, and a video. EMail me at mike@studiofeast.com if you have any questions about what was covered. Thanks! http://studiofeast.com/2011/07/01/hacking-the-dinner-party-itp/

title: ITP Camp games night
description: Rescheduled games night, as a hands-on followup to the session The Games People Play. See original description here.

title: Unity3D Workshop
description: Unity3D is an application that allows you to create (with incredible ease) both 2D and 3D environments. Although Unity is primarily used as a game development tool, there is a growing community of people who are starting to use this platform for purposes outside the realm of gaming - primarily due to the program's ability to create highly immersive environments with little to no programming experience . Personally, as a former ITP student, learning about this program has been invaluable to my work at ITP, and I've grown to see this program as an incredibly useful tool in creating highly immersive pieces.

title: Hello Google App Inventor
description: Within minutes of firing up Google's App Inventor, a totally programming newbie (like me) can create a simple app for their Android phone. One of my apps - a simple sight word app - was featured in the Google research blog. This session will provide an introduction to Google's App Inventor and those with an Android phone will hopefully be able to leave with a program or two of their own. App Inventor is a blocks-based programming platform meant to help new programmers learn the basics of programming, but it also has a fair amount of complex and somewhat deep functionality. For more complicated programming questions, I will defer to the App Inventor forums (and people who know more about me), but I can certainly get you started.

title: Mobile UX - Practice, tips and tools of the trade
description:
User Experience (UX) has gained a solid foothold in the design, development and building of online applications.  Thinking a project through in a high-level visual form is a necessary step towards helping a project become more successful.  The practice is more predominant in the web site space.  As mobile applications continue to grow at an exponential rate, the specialization of mobile User Experience is becoming more important.  This session will be divided into roughly two parts.  The first part is a quick overview and presentation.  The second part is where we get our hands a little dirty as I demonstrate a few tools and techniques. A lot to cover in a short amount of time. Other participants who are in the same field, please feel free to share other tools/techniques. Part I - The Practice of Mobile UX (0:20 min)
  • Introduction
  • Differences between web sites and mobile sites
  • Differences between mobile Apps and mobile sites
  • Different platforms and considerations
  • Current trends (HTML apps)
Part II - Tips and Tools of the Trade (1:00)
  • Wireframing with Omnigraffle
  • Prototyping mobile sites and apps with Axure
  • Prototyping mobile Apps with xCode and PhoneGap
  • Presentation techniques and technologies
Q&A (0:10)   The tools I'll be primarily be demonstrating are Omnigraffle, Axure.  You can download free trial licenses from the following sites.  These are paid applications, but I will also talk about other solutions (free/open source). NOTE: You do not have to download these programs to follow along.  This is more of a demo of the landscape of tools available to help present and realize the vision of the project. http://www.omnigroup.com/products/omnigraffle/ http://axure.com/   I'll briefly demonstrate how to prototype and deploy an HTML App using PhoneGap (free/open source), xCode ($4.99) and Dreamweaver (v5.5). http://www.phonegap.com/ http://www.adobe.com/products/dreamweaver.html http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/xcode/id422352214?mt=12

title: Designing Interactive Museum Experiences
description: Museums, Science Centres and Cultural Institutions around the world are in the midst on renewal. With the traditional static dioramas behind glass and large panels of didactic text being replaced by tactile learning and educational video games, what are the new opportunities and challenges facing experience designers? In this session, Mark Argo from Aesthetec Studio will explore these challenges and opportunities through his recent experiences, discuss technologies and future trends, and outline a couple design processes that can help keep ideas fresh and feasible.

title: Experience Design Workshop
description:
Do you have an idea for a fun interactive experience? Do you have something important to convey, but want to find a clever way to get the message across? Do you want to port your video game into the physical world, but aren't sure where to start?

This workshop will take you through the steps of 'piloting' an exhibit concept in the course of three hours. Beginning with some key elements of exhibit design, participants will brainstorm an exhibit concept, quickly create a prototype using simple materials (technology not required!!) and then test and evaluate the concept based on user feedback. Expect this fun weekend session to help develop your critical thinking and critical making skills, with the paper cuts to prove it.

title: Asterisk in the cloud
description:
Asterisk is an open source telephony/voip server that give us the power to interact and manipulate phone calls.  This session will go over the steps you'll need to get Asterisk running on a Rackspace Cloud server, with a free incoming phone number, along with the tools you'll need to send call information to other programs or devices.

I will go over examples that use Ruby, Sinatra, Node.js, and Processing, but my examples should be easy to port to your programming language of choice.

This session is ideal for people who have some comfort with a terminal command line, but all are welcome to attend.

title: Unity3D for Creating Virtual Installations
Unity3D for Creating Virtual Installations Session 2
description: Hi my name is Matthew Swenson and I will be teaching you Unity3D. What is this dark sorcery you ask? Don’t be afraid. Unity is just a powerful 3D engine that gives you the ability to create virtual environments and interact with them in physical space. In other words, you will be able to manifest your wildest dreams, ever. In this class you will be taught: 1. How to create your first 3D environment 2. How to use the kinect to interact with this environment 3. How to use projection mapping to layer this environment on physical objects 4. How to use augmented reality to tag this environment in the physical world   Requirements: To join us, please download Unity3D here : http://unity3d.com/unity/download/   And, for optimum mental flow, bring snacks. …

title: Counselor/Staff Workshop: Shop Safety
description: Drill press, CNC, chop saws, oh my! Shop safety is required for ANYONE who wants to use the shop facilities at ITP - this includes the CNC and lasercutter. Additional workshops will be offered for more in-depth use of the lasercutter and CNC.

title: Counselor/Staff Workshop: Shop Safety
description: Drill press, CNC, chop saws, oh my! Shop safety is required for ANYONE who wants to use the shop facilities at ITP - this includes the CNC and lasercutter. Additional workshops will be offered for more in-depth use of the lasercutter and CNC.

title: Kinect Hacking
Topics in Programming: Arrays and Objects
Face as Interface
description: In this workshop we will explore the use of advanced face tracking technology as an alternative interface. We'll discuss the history, structure, and limitations of face tracking algorithms. We’ll use our faces to make weird noises, and control our cursor. The workshop will be based on the free, open source FaceOSC application. Participants should bring a laptop with a webcam, with a copy of the following free software: FaceOSC, FaceOSC-templates, Processing, oscp5, and OSCulator.

title: Reading Group
description: Summer's a good time for reading -- it's a good non-sweaty outdoor activity. At the first meeting of the ITP Camp reading group, we'll discuss one article (Getting Creative with Urban Metadata), and then decide what to read next. Check your Amazon wishlist (or whatever), and bring ideas. We might pick a book and do 1-2 chapters each week, or pick a new article each week.

title: Reading Group
Reading Group
description: Third meeting of the reading group. The reading is the introduction and first chapter of Culturematic. Click and read for free using your preferred service: Amazon / Google Books / iBooks.

title: Reading Group
description: Fourth meeting of the reading group. The reading is Modern Medicine by Jonathan Harris.

title: Purpose, Passion and Patience
description:
One of the most appealing things about entrepreneurship and self-employment is the opportunity to immerse ourselves completely into our work. Without such tyrannies as office politics and convoluted approvals processes, we're able to focus on getting things done; on realizing our vision. We're able to "find" our "purpose" and "live" our "passion."

But what do those things mean, really? How far can these ideas take us?

It's been suggested that passion is a form of aggression. Because it's high-urgency, it creates blindness (to alternative perspectives) and exhaustion. Perhaps what we *really* need is patience.

A facilitated discussion about patience, purpose, presence, and the limits of passionate work.

title: Tech, health and happiness
description:
Technology has made our lives easier and more fun -- when is it going to start making us healthier? Typing gives you carpal tunnel syndrome, wifi causes headaches and cancer, cellphones fragment our attention, and through social media we unlearn how to have a conversation. What can we, as makers, do to minimize our contribution to these problems? Or, better, introduce ways of addressing them? Read (or re-read) the articles below, and bring ideas, strategies, cautionary tales and success stories:
  • The Flight From Conversation (Sherry Turkle)
  • Liking Is for Cowards. Go for What Hurts. (Jonathan Franzen)
  • Pinterest: A vast city of beautiful mutes
  • The wired onesie for 'first time moms who are afraid'

title: Making Tangible Futures
description:
What inspires us to make stuff? Do you hope that your creations will help -- in whatever little way -- make the world a better place? That they will, perhaps, direct us towards a more desirable future? If so, you're a tangible futurist.
"Tangible Futures are the output of applying design-fueled disciplines ... to represent futures and strategies." - Victor Lombardi
What if we considered the things that we make to be artifacts from some desirable other reality? Tangible Futures are like the flipside of design fiction. If we're willing to admit that we're trying to make the world a better place, how could we use that to improve our impact?

title: LED fetishism, or the future's so bright we gotta wear shades
description:
LED technology has come a long way from being simple indicators to full blown media facades in a relatively short amount of time. Similarly, it's possible to control these lights with a number of different tools: the humble Arduino can drive multi-million dollar displays.

We'll look at common tools used, from DIY to architecturally complete solutions, and try to figure out why these things are so damn appealing.

title: Projection Mapping v1: Introduction
description: Projection mapping is the technique of projecting video onto three dimensional and non-traditional projection surface. We will show you basic to advanced projection mapping techniques using MadMapper each week. Please download MadMapper Demo before you come to the class. http://www.madmapper.com/shop/. We will set up demo stations you can try projection mapping during the class. Week 1: Introduction - History of Projection Mapping - Showing Examples - Software solutions - Basic mapping technique with MadMapper (basic use/movie playback only) - Discussion about media creation - Practice session Week 2: Dynamic Media - Showing Examples - Content creation for an installation - Intermediate mapping technique with MadMapper - Using MadMapper in conjunction with other visual applications - Practice session Week 3: Large Scale Projection - Showing Examples - Advance mapping technique with MadMapper - Practice session Pre-requisits: - Mac OS X based computer running 10.6 or greater - Download Demo for MadMapper http://www.madmapper.com/shop/ - DVI or MiniDVI adapter that allows you to connect your computer to a projector - Working knowledge of graphics and video creation software - Working knowledge of VJ software

title: Projection Mapping v2: Dynamic Media
description: Projection mapping is the technique of projecting video onto three dimensional and non-traditional projection surface. We will show you basic to advanced projection mapping techniques using MadMapper each week. Please download MadMapper Demo before you come to the class. http://www.madmapper.com/shop/. We will set up demo stations you can try projection mapping during the class. Week 1: Introduction - History of Projection Mapping - Showing Examples - Software solutions - Basic mapping technique with MadMapper (basic use/movie playback only) - Discussion about media creation - Practice session Week 2: Dynamic Media  - Showing Examples - Content creation for an installation - Intermediate mapping technique with MadMapper - Using MadMapper in conjunction with other visual applications - Practice session Week 3: Large Scale Projection - Showing Examples - Advance mapping technique with MadMapper - Practice session Pre-requisits: - Mac OS X based computer running 10.6 or greater - Download Demo for MadMapper http://www.madmapper.com/shop/ - DVI or MiniDVI adapter that allows you to connect your computer to a projector - Working knowledge of graphics and video creation software - Working knowledge of VJ software
