title: Startup Fundraising Basics
description:
Startup fundraising is an opaque, often confusing, and always time consuming process. New founders are at a disadvantage, unfamiliar with but expected to navigate the unwritten rules of pitching to angel investors and venture capitalists.

This session is for anyone considering raising outside capital for their project or company. Fundraising options and the steps in the process will be addressed, with insight into how investors judge pitches. Additional topics could include Kickstarter, 'crowd funding,' AngelList, etc.

title: Make Something That Does Something with littleBits
description:
In this session we will use littleBits electronic modules and various craft and design materials to create interactive objects.  After a brief demo of the modules and system, we'll sketch out ideas and start brainstorming our creations.  Once ideas are solidified, we'll start building our objects with various materials including cardboard, wood, foam, and anything else we can get our hands on.   About littleBits:

littleBits is an opensource library of electronic modules that snap together with tiny magnets for prototyping and play.

We spend more than 7.5 hours with technological devices every day, but most us don't know how they work, or how to make our own. For all the interactivity of these devices, we are bound to passive consumption. At littleBits, we believe we need to create scientific thinkers and problem-solvers, and interventions need to occur early. The time is ripe to create the pipe cleaner and the popsicle stick of the 21st century. littleBits consists of tiny circuit-boards with simple, unique functions engineered to snap together with magnets. No soldering, no wiring, no programming, just snap and play.

title: Telematics - artistic collaborations over high speed networks
description:
Telematics - Real time collaborations over distance networks Part 2

Telematics is artist collaborations over high speed, 1G fiber optic research networks. This session will take individuals through a basic understanding of the telmatic environments and initial audio transmission with Jacktrip and Jackpilot. We will look at one of the few telematic nodes in NYC at the Steinhardt School between NY and San Diego. Next we will examine a number of telematic projects through analysis and video playback that took place using live motion, 3D environments, sound and interactivity. We will look at mapping configurations and routing of complex network topologies. Experiments with sending Jitter based visual coding over the network in response to sonic cues will be looked at. Finally, a complex data mapping project in a 12-camera motion capture studio that send sound and motion over the telematic network to affect visual

title: Intro to Surface Mount Electronics
description: Through hole components are arguably going the way of the dinosaur.  We’ll look at SMD component packages, how to work with them, and learn various soldering techniques so you can build things like it’s the 21st century.

title: Intro to PCB design in EagleCAD
3D Printing with Style
description: 3d printing isn't just for fighter jets and custom lego weaponry anymore. From bikinis to shoes, see how 3D printing can create the next generation of products. We'll have shiny photos, physical models to ogle, and  help you get started with making things with 3D printing on your own. For those of you who'd like to make some 3D print files of your own, please download and install Rhino (OSX, Windows) and Netfabb (OSX, Linux, Windows). We'll help you get started modeling, export your file, check it for print-ability and send it off to be printed.

title: How To Makerspace with Site 3 coLab
description: Makerspaces are fantastic places to dream big, then bigger, then ridiculous. Starting a makerspace is an incredibly rewarding, if expensive hobby - it's a great way to gather the most difficult resource for project development, which is people with awesome ideas. This presentation will take you through how we started Site 3 (http://www.site3.ca), how we run Site 3, the goals that keep a space running, and some of the design patterns of other makerspaces. We will also present the most ludicrous projects and how we come up with them, which may give you the encouragement you need to dream bigger. This talk is about how to make a space for people who will make truly amazing things, without going completely mad, and how to then translate that space into more incredible projects yourself. Hint: Many of our projects involve something being on fire. Like, 30 foot tall jets of it. Also, psychic fire controls. Sometimes there are unicorns that actually do fart rainbows. Makerspaces make awesome ideas actually happen. It's easier than you think.

title: Workshop: Making and Making It Happen with Site 3 coLab
description: This is a workshop wherein you'll develop a completely crazed idea with a few of your peers, then work up the logistics of it, and figure out which of the subscriber mob assembly techniques will work best for your idea. At the end of the workshop, present your pitch and take home your polished notes on how subscription might work for you, along with a detailed idea of how to make your thing, then make your thing much better.

title: Build a Lasersaur!
description: Lasersaur is an open-source laser cutter, currently in beta, and we will be building one at camp this year. Come help! Laser cutters have revolutionized fabrication for makers, designers and artists, but they can be very expensive and it can be difficult to get access to one. The Lasersaur project will provide us with plans, a bill of materials and documentation so we can build our own here at ITP. We will be putting the whole thing together, frame, electronics, software and more- then the cutting begins. Addie Wagenkancht and Stefan Hechenberger started this project with Kickstarter funding, and they will be helping us with the build via skype. We will be contributing to the development of this project and to the open source hardware movement with our experience and documentation. At this initial meeting, we will look at the plans and bill of materials, discuss the phases of the building process and set up a schedule for the build. Here's a time lapse video of a Lasersaur build at CultureLab. Here is a link to a page of resources. And here is intro-lasersaur powerpoint.

title: Genspace: DNA Cocktails
description: Ever wondered what DNA looks like? In this workshop you will learn about DNA, the blueprint for life, and how to extract chromosomal DNA from fruits using Bacardi 151! Extraction and purification of DNA are the first steps in learning biotechnology. You will learn about DNA structure and function from Genspace experts, and see the strands of genetic material that make all living things, while enjoying tasty cocktails with the resulting concoctions.

title: Paper Circuits
description: [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="842" caption="paper synthesizer"][/caption] The intersection of electronics, smart materials and traditional crafts represents a new opportunity for creative and artistic expression. In this session we will cover the basics of electronics-enhanced paper projects, discuss several relevant projects and techniques, and make a circuit on paper with hand-made switches and LEDs. Please bring a CR2025 or CR2032 battery (3V coin cell), a few sheets of card stock, paper scraps of different colors, and scissors (or an x-acto knife if you prefer). All other materials will be provided. Video shown on the session: Electronic Popables by Jie Qi TeleScrapbook by Natalie Freed Electronic Origami Crane by Jie Qi Interactive Light Painting by Jie Qi Paper Speakers by Hannah Perner-Wilson Switches from Conductive Ink by various artists How to Make Conductive Ink by University of Illinois Interactive Wallpaper by MIT Hi-Low Tech Group Piano Box by Catarina Mota More info about materials at openmaterials.org

title: Designing for Behavior Change
description:
When we create a product, a service, or a feature of a product or service, we are essentially trying to get people "to do" something.  I'll teach you practical skills that you can use immediately and also prepare you to teach others what works when it comes to designing for a behavior to occur.

We'll explore different behaviors, how to classify them and how to use design to trigger behaviors. I'll show you the importance of identifying specific target behaviors and how to sequence them as a way to be explicit in figuring out what works and doesn't work.

title: How Cybernetics Helps Us Design
description:
Sorry folks, something came up and I'll have to try and reschedule. Lots of good stuff at 6 otherwise: Dave Miller's session and others.

How do we express the interior workings of our body, our exterior behaviors and the behavior of things? Cybernetics provides a powerful framework to abstract complex systems into diagrammatic structures. We'll cover goal-directed systems, feedback loops and some other surprises. Come learn how to be more purposeful with your design interventions.

title: Embodiment. What can we measure? And should we?
description: Session led by Linda Stone, Fred Muench, and Steve Dean. How can we measure embodiment, sensing and feeling in a way that is reliable? Can self-reporting help us or do we only rely on quantifiable biometrics like EEG, PET, GSR, HRV and others? Can we use collateral reports from friends and family to let us know when we are at our best? We are just beginning - steps will take us to floor 2 and let us know that more exists but what takes us to the top of the building?

title: Smart Materials for DIY Projects
description: Smart materials have one or more properties that can be changed in a significant manner and include: conductive inks, textiles with electrical properties, pigments that change color at a given temperature, conductive acetate, light diffusing acrylics, shape memory alloys, amongst many others. This will be an overview of a selection of smart materials which are simple enough to be used on DIY projects.

title: Open Source to Tackle Real World Challenges
description: An introduction to some of my past, current and future projects and open discussion on the lessons learned and the challenges encountered in building multiple businesses focused on open source platforms to solve real humanitarian, environmental and social challenges worldwide. Some of the projects shown have been tested and deployed in many countries such as Ethiopia, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, United States and more... some were very successful while some totally bombed! :-)

title: GSM Workshop!
description: This will be a workshop that first will cover the basic of how GSM cellphone networks/technology work and how you interact with a GSM network, then will introduce a hands-on session that can allow you to have your hardware project interact with the network by sending SMSs or connecting to the internet via GPRS. Bring your Arduino as this will be a hardware workshop!

title: Taming the Monkey Mind: Yoga and Creative Focus
description: We all know this feeling of being under the gun with a deadline, needing to access our most creative ideas at a moment's notice. The chatter of our minds is going a mile a minute to no avail. When we really need our creative muse to show up, she somehow has the uncanny ability to hide like a needle in a haystack and then show up at 3:00am as we bolt upright out of bed, making our way in the dark to scribble down the ideas she's handed to us. For too long we've accepted that's just the way creativity and imagination work - unpredictably. Yoga - physical postures, breathing techniques, and meditation - helps us tap into our imaginations at will and with ease, exactly when we need them. A regular yoga practice keeps our minds sharp, helps us make connections between seemingly disparate bits of information that may otherwise go unnoticed, and causes us to imagine solutions to complex challenges. By learning to quiet the mind, we give our greatest ideas the chance to rise to the top. Yoga gives us a way forward. This session will provide a sample class geared toward enhancing creativity. It will include a few basic standing postures that can be done in your everyday clothes. The breathing and meditation techniques will all be practiced seated. It is helpful for everyone who needs to tap into their own creativity on a regular basis - from performers to programmers, in all mediums. You will also receive the sequence of postures and techniques after the class so that you can continue to practice on your own. Dress comfortably. You do not need to bring a mat or any props with you.

title: Trackin' Monkeys!
description:
Q: What do monkeys have to do with digital technologies?

A: Monkeys are cool. What else do you need?

In this session I'll talk about the class I co-teach at ITP with primatologist Anthony Di Fiore on interaction design for wildlife researchers. I'll share a bit about Tony's working conditions in the Amazon, show some of the projects students have developed, discuss the latest in wildlife tracking technologies, and talk about work we're hoping to do next, on developing digital fieldbooks for wildlife researchers.

title: Arduino and the (wireless) Internet
description: Microcontrollers are more fun when they can communicate over the internet.  In this session, I'll introduce the Arduino Ethernet and the Arduino Wifi shield, and talk about the Client and Server libraries that now make it possible to use virtually the same code for both wired and wireless internet connections. I'll have some Wifi shields on hand for people to play with and try out. Bring your favorite sensors, and together we'll play a networked game of pong.

title: Counselor Workshop: CNC Basics
description: You took the Shop safety workshop, but now you want to learn the basics of how to use the CNC. This Counselor Workshop will help you out with the basics of file management, laying out your tool paths and running your job.

title: Counselor Workshop: Lasercutting 101
description: You took the Shop safety session, now you want to learn the basics of lasercutting.  This Camp Counselor led workshop will help demystify the arcane arts of cutting stuff with a laser beam!

title: Counselor Workshop: Finishing Touches
description: So you learned how to cut something on the lasercutter or the CNC and you want to put the finishing touches on your work. From material selection to finishing options, this workshop covers those extra techniques and details that can help make your piece show worthy: learn how to properly sand, fit, assemble and finish your work.

title: Staff/Counselor Workshop: SoftLab Basics
description: Learn the basics of sewing, embroidery, paper and vinyl cutting. Whether you want to use these tools to create soft circuits, embroider your favorite hoodie or cut paper or vinyl for making a popup book, this workshop will help you learn how to use ITP's basic tools in all these areas.

title: Staff/Counselor Workshop: DIY PCB Etching
description: You took Paul's session on how to design your own PCBs using EagleCad. Now, learn how to print and etch your own PCBs - DIY-style - using ITP's SoftLab!

title: Designing product interfaces to influence user behavior
description:
Products, services, and systems inevitably influence our behavior, often in ways that are unconsidered by the designers.  Human factors and product design as fields are concerned with how users use products, with regards to performance, satisfaction, safety, and sustainability.  Some products, such as an alarm clock or the FitBit exist to shape behavior, but most products have influence over the user as only a means to an end, such as avoiding improper use (such as using a lawnmower as a hedge-clipper).
In this session we will discuss behavior design as applied to both persuasive technologies and designing persuasion into products.
  1. overview of persuasive technology
  2. products that exist to persuade
  3. 'normal' products and their persuasive influence (perhaps the designers didn't think of that...)
  4. Research on behavior design
  5. exercise: Applications of behavior design to products.

title: How bad are -whatevers-? Lifecycle analysis for products
description:
Mike Berners-Lee (son of Tim) wrote a great book, How Bad are Bananas? which explores the carbon footprint of all kinds of things.  How did he do it?  He conducted a lifecycle analysis of bananas, burgers, and all manner of things that don't start with the letter B. http://howbadarebananas.posterous.com/ A thorough lifecycle analysis takes a long time to do--in Jen van der Meer's course, If Products Could Tell Their Stories, you can spend a whole semester doing a lifecycle analysis.  We don't have that kind of time so instead we'll quickly go over tools to do an LCA, including the stellar software Sustainable Minds and Sourcemap (a tool for tracking supply chains--the bits of a product go some strange places before ending up in your pocket, or on your plate).
  1. product impacts
  2. stages of the life cycle - materials extraction - production - transport - use - end of life - second (or 3rd or 4th...) life
  3. Defining the system/system boundaries
  4. supply chains (where's this been?)
  5. quick run through of a lifecycle analysis
  6. freak out
in all seriousness, this will make you freak out a bit, because everything is a bit more complex than one would think (see Julio Terra's exploration of Dole Iceberg Lettuce http://julioterra.com/journal/2010/03/dole-iceberg-lettuce/) and what would seem to be simple and even healthy may not be so.  The good (if there is a silver, or at least aluminium, lining) news is that by understanding more about the products in our lives we can make better choices, in terms of the things we buy and use, and the things we make, from both the business and product standpoints.

title: Intro to Programming with Processing
Genspace: Bio Engineering Lab 1 - Bacterial Transformation
description: Take a tour to Genspace, community biology laboratory in Brooklyn NY and become a molecular biologist. In this workshop you will learn the basic techniques of bio engineering as used in molecular biological laboratories. You will learn how to transform a plasmid into bacteria, manipulating the organism into accepting foreign DNA into its genetic material. We will use E. coli bacteria and insert a new gene from several plasmids. For directions and how to get to Genspace NYC Inc., please visit: http://genspace.org/page/Contact%5FUs or email nurit@genspace.org In the next lab (Lab 2) you will be able to see how the bacteria strains express green or red fluorescence proteins (GFP, RFP), luciferase or violacien operons, and use these transformed bacteria to create biological paintings.

title: Genspace: Bio Engineering Lab 2 – Bacterial Painting
description: Did you know that Alexander Fleming, discoverer of Penicillin, was also a bio artist who enjoyed painting with bacteria? In this workshop you will create living works of art with a variety of genetically engineered and naturally occurring strains of bacteria. (See Lab 1) After incubation, the strains that you have chosen from your bacterial palette will produce a variety of colors, and express green or red fluorescence proteins, luciferase or violacien operons. As a result, the strains will either glow red, green, yellow or produce a purple pigment.

title: Intro to MakerBotting
description:
This workshop will focus on 3D Printing, one of the most disruptive technologies around. 3D printers allow anyone at any skill level to become producers, inventors and artists, and they are changing the way we create and learn.  Participants will learn how to make and personalize 3D models with free, readily available software like Tinkercad,  123d Catch, Meshmixer, OpenSCAD and Blender. We'll look at Thingiverse, ReplicatorG and print our models on a MakerBot Replicator. No prior modeling, computer or printing experience is necessary. But bring a laptop with a 3 button mouse. Also come to the workshop with the following software installed:
ReplicatorG (replicat.org)
OpenSCAD (openscad.org)
Blender (blender.org)
Meshmixer (http://www.meshmixer.com) NetFabb (http://www.netfabb.com/download.php)
Google Chrome

title: Encoding Space : generative design
description:
Imagine spreading geometry like butter.  Commanding points, lines and fluid surfaces like marionettes that jump at your every wish.  Building cities with a wave of your hand or generating clouds like puffs from a cigarette.  Well, you can.

Rhino, the premier 3D modeling software for many architects and designers, has a new way of interacting with its geometry through the very easy to learn programming language, Python.

In this first session, we'll cover the basics of Python and how it works with Rhino.  Students should have at least a small amount of experience with Rhino and a laptop with Rhino 5 installed would be helpful.

title: Encoding Space : generative design
description:
Imagine spreading geometry like butter.  Commanding points, lines and fluid surfaces like marionettes that jump at your every wish.  Building cities with a wave of your hand or generating clouds like puffs from a cigarette.  Well, you can.

Rhino, the premier 3D modeling software for many architects and designers, has a new way of interacting with its geometry through the very easy to learn programming language, Python.

In this second session, we will explore what RhinoPython is capable of.  If you didn't come to the first session, a wek earlier, you should know Rhino and Python fairly well or at least have a good deal of programming experience.

title: From Unstructured Data to Structured Data Stories
description:
Have you ever wondered how to take data, all the data out there, and turn it into meaning?  I've tried to do that, researched what's out there, came up with my own system to do it, which I'm open to improving.

Basically, we need to find the right structure to overlay unstructured data (what most of social media, for example, is), creating meaning, and ultimately, data stories.

Well look at the filed, not so much from a data scientist or data analyst point of view, but for here, as a data artist or visionary (let's learn to see the patterns in the data, then decide the meaning of the story, how it begins and ends).

Since it's an exploration, and it's also a Friday in late June, I'll come up with something pretty creative and compelling so the camp session will be as full as it can be.   Rather than define the tools (which I have a pretty good idea of right now), I'll leave some of it a mystery.

title: Eeny, Meeny, Miny, Motor?: Creating and Controlling Motion
description: This session will be a walk through and demonstration of Chapter 6 in Making Things Move: DIY Mechanisms for Inventors, Hobbyists, and Artists.  A free pdf of the chapter is available at that link.  This chapter covers the different kinds of motors and how to choose between them. Once you know what power and torque are and how to estimate what you need for a certain project, it becomes less voodoo and more of a process of elimination. We'll also talk about some other ways to create motion, from solenoids and linear motors to emerging technologies like muscle wire.

title: Shit Happens (how to handle online emergencies with aplomb)
Physical Computing 101
description:
From the Physical Computing syllabus : 
"Physical Computing is an approach to learning how humans communicate through computers that starts by considering how humans express themselves physically. In this course, we take the human body as a given, and attempt to design computing applications within the limits of its expression.

To realize this goal, you'll learn how a computer converts the changes in energy given off by our bodies (in the form of sound, light, motion, and other forms) into changing electronic signals that it can read interpret. You'll learn about the sensors that do this, and about very simple computers called microcontrollers that read sensors and convert their output into data. Finally, you'll learn how microcontrollers communicate with other computers."

We'll be using the Arduino as the platform of choice during the camp physComp sessions. In this first one, we'll be going over basic electronics, programming the physical equivalent of "hello world" and looking at digital inputs and outputs.

This session will probably move pretty quickly, and while it may have a little more blah blah blah than the other two intros, the focus will be on building and demoing circuits. You're welcome to bring along an Arduino and some digital inputs and outputs to play along, or just hang out for the duration.

title: Physical Computing 102
description:
From the Physical Computing syllabus : 
"Physical Computing is an approach to learning how humans communicate through computers that starts by considering how humans express themselves physically. In this course, we take the human body as a given, and attempt to design computing applications within the limits of its expression.

To realize this goal, you'll learn how a computer converts the changes in energy given off by our bodies (in the form of sound, light, motion, and other forms) into changing electronic signals that it can read interpret. You'll learn about the sensors that do this, and about very simple computers called microcontrollers that read sensors and convert their output into data. Finally, you'll learn how microcontrollers communicate with other computers."

We'll be using the Arduino as the platform of choice during the camp physComp sessions. In this second session, we'll build on what we covered in the previous week, specifically using analog inputs and outputs. This will covers many different kinds of sensors and a number of outputs like light, sound, and motion. There will be more build, less theory, more fun, more power!

title: Physical Computing 103
description:
From the Physical Computing syllabus : 
"Physical Computing is an approach to learning how humans communicate through computers that starts by considering how humans express themselves physically. In this course, we take the human body as a given, and attempt to design computing applications within the limits of its expression.

To realize this goal, you'll learn how a computer converts the changes in energy given off by our bodies (in the form of sound, light, motion, and other forms) into changing electronic signals that it can read interpret. You'll learn about the sensors that do this, and about very simple computers called microcontrollers that read sensors and convert their output into data. Finally, you'll learn how microcontrollers communicate with other computers."

We'll be using the Arduino as the platform of choice during the camp physComp sessions. In this final session, we'll shift our focus to connecting with mutimedia computers, and sending sensor data to programs like Processing and Max/MSP. If you have a particular application you would like to see covered, drop a note in the comments below!

title: Data:  Art, Product, or Tool
description:
Due to the changing landscape of data availability companies and public organizations are making massive amounts of data to the public.  This panel will look at some examples of data usage in the public and private sector,  discuss why companies and public offices doing this and explore who benefits  most from these new structures.

Moderated by Marc Maleh – Director of Interactive Production, Wieden+Kennedy New York

Panelists include:
Husani Oakley – Tech Director at Wieden+Kennedy NYC
Bob Richardson – Director, Office of Strategic Technology Development, City of New York
Daniel Shaw - Executive Producer, Wieden+Kennedy New York
Nick Barham - Global Director, Wieden+Kennedy Tomorrow

title: Sherry Huss & the Maker Faire team
description: Learn about Maker Fair and Maker culture at a meet, greet, and Q&A with the Maker Faire team: Sherry Huss, Director of Maker Fair Louise Glasgow, Maker Faire Producer Bridgette Vanderlaan, Marketing Director

title: Dennis Crowley
Counselor Workshop: Lasercutting 101
description: You took the Shop safety session, now you want to learn the basics of lasercutting.  This Camp Counselor led workshop will help demystify the arcane arts of cutting stuff with a laser beam!

title: 1 in 1
description:
1-in-1 means 1 project in 1 day. (Because you simply cannot be stopped.)
  • Start and complete a creative project in 24 hours ( you don't need to work on it through the night - but nobody will be surprised if you do.)
  • It can be anything creative - there are no rules here
  • The Counselors will be around to help you out with tutorial and brainstorming
  • Each project needs a name and documentation posted by Monday morning - you can document it in the Campers Blog!
  • You're encouraged to exhibit your completed project at ITP during the week!

title: Hello Arduino
description: Super quick, super casual intro to Arduino for those who just can't wait any longer!

title: Lasersaur!
description: In this session we will review what materials have come in and start planning the first stage of the build, which is building the frame. And materials have started coming in! We have set up in the physical computing area, where we will build the lasersaur. If you have time, try and review the CAD model before we meet in Rhino. If you don't have the link to the file, let Jody know, she will email it to you. Download Rhino for Mac. Download Rhino for Windows It would also be helpful to check out the system overview and the bill of materials Link to the Bill of Materials by subsystem as a google doc spreadsheet. Link to the Bill of Materials by supplier as a google doc.

title: Generative Art in Structure Synth
description: I'm rescheduling my compositing class till later, at a point to be decided.  I'm going to use this slot for a different class: Structure Synth: - Is a generative modeling language. Think Rhino3d + python, except much simpler. - It uses it’s own super tiny language (15-20 commands) that you can learn quickly. - No previous knowledge of 3d, scripting, or programming required! - Recursive! We’ll spend the first 30 minutes of class learning how to use the software, and the remainder to make beautiful generative art. Come, learn, and I guarantee everyone’ll walk away with some beautiful 3d models they can print, use for other projects, or just oggle! I can talk a bit about exporting geometry created in this program into other software like fancy 3d renderers if there’s time. You should come if: - You enjoyed spirograph as a kid / adult - You’d like to learn a new way to create abstract forms - You think these are pretty (each were generated by me in under 50 lines of code): [gallery link="file"]   More images: http://www.flickr.com/groups/structuresynth/ Please install structure synth (available, TOTALLY FREE, for linux, mac os and windows herehttp://structuresynth.sourceforge.net/) before class. Excited! Jesse   OLD CLASS DESCRIPTION:   I'm a freelance VFX compositor...I describe my work as "photoshop over time"...or the manipulation of image sequences.  Some common things compositors do: - removing film crew / equipment from footage / reflections - adding explosions and fire - introducing stationary objects in scenes where the camera is moving (often wildly) - duplicating crowds - keying (replacing green / blue / red screens) with some other footage - seamlessly combining two separate takes - integration of computer generated (CG) elements into photographic footage - Make robots destroy cities In order for an audience to buy your work, the manipulations have to be very precise and seamless. While the software is far from real-time and therefore "interactive" as in the "I" of ITP, I do think there is a lot of overlap between the compositing workflow and common image manipulation tasks in more real-time environments like processing, oF, or game engines.  Concepts like color math / depth / matching, blending modes, Photogrammetry, 3d tracking / projection and rendering, warping, procedural texturing, and managing lens distortion, grain and motion blur seem directly connected, just in a different (and less interactive) context.  The software is controlled with a node based interface that has become popular for the manipulation of complex streams of information. The concepts are widely applicable to more real-time uses.  For example: - In an augmented reality app, while previously you might have just positioned images floating in space, what if you used compositing concepts to make them act more like real objects...casting shadow, interacting with people, being colored appropriately by the surroundings?  Or what about more believably integrating fire or electrical elements with heat haze / distortion or color changes surrounding the region? - 3d projection which is implemented very cleanly in the software has parallels to more real-world projection systems. - Could your interaction with the real world be improved using 2d/3d tracking or keying algorithms?  Also, what do more real time applications like openCV sacrifice in order to deliver real-time output?  As computers / gpus get more powerful, how many of these traditionally offline techniques become achievable in real time? I'll step through a basic or intermediate composite to show off the concepts of blending or tweaking footage, and then dive into the math / artistry that's going on under the hood of the software?  Then I'd talk about how those concepts / algorithms could be applied in more real time applications? Please install either the nuke PLE (Personal Learning Edition, free) prior to class or apply for the fully functional 15 day free trial.  it runs on mac, linux and windows.  Start here: http://www.thefoundry.co.uk/products/nuke/

title: Git and GitHub
description:
As you write code, you'll want to keep track of changes you make, so that you can experiment without losing track of your last working versions, and so that you can collaborate on the same codebase with others without copying and emailing files around. I'll go over the basics of version control with git and how to add your repository to GitHub. If there's time, we can talk about GitHub's role in open source, possible git workflows, etc. Edit: Moved to 5pm so that people can unwind after Intro to Processing. To do:
  1. Set up git
  2. Set user name and email address
  3. Create a repo
  4. Add a commit
  5. Rollback a commit
  6. Create a branch
  7. Merge a branch
  8. Create a GitHub account
  9. Add SSH keys to GitHub
  10. Create a project on GitHub
  11. Clone a repo
  12. Pull changes
  13. Push changes
Links: Git downloads: http://git-scm.com/downloads Setup on Windows: https://help.github.com/articles/set-up-git#platform-windows Generate SSH keys: https://help.github.com/articles/generating-ssh-keys

title: Learn Vim!
Boxes and Lines for fun (not profit): an Intro to Max/MSP/Jitter
description:
Max/MSP is a dataflow programming environment. Instead of writing code, you create (what look like) crazy flowcharts. These flowcharts move and manipulate data, and can be used for many different types of creative expression : sound, video, MIDI, all types of crazy stuff. You can even hook up microcontrollers and physical components to get input and output from the software.

This session will introduce campers to the basics of Max/MSP and Jitter. We'll discuss video and audio playback, and look at how information moves through a patch. It's probably best to download the software from the cycling74 website : http://cycling74.com (Mac and Windows). You get a 30-day unlimited demo after you install it, plenty of time to create a camp masterpiece!

title: Lasersaur: skype with Nortd Labs
description: We skyped with Addie Wagenknecht, who with Stefan Hechenberger of Nortd Labs started the Lasersaur project. We told Addie about our progress so far, sorting materials as they come in to the various sub-systems of the Lasersaur. She had some tips, including the importance of a level surface to build upon (not critical, but will make life easier). She told us that Stefan will send us a link to more "Ikea" like instructions for the various sub-systems and thought that we can divide our team into groups to work on the sub-systems once we have the materials in. She and Stefan are agreeable to using a Google+ hangout instead of skype for communicating. She is also enthusiastic about the tasty snacks from ThorLabs. This will be the first of many skype calls to get tips on how to proceed with the Lasersaur build.

title: Counselor/Staff Workshop: Shop Safety
description: TDrill press, CNC, chop saws, oh my! Shop safety is required for ANYONE who wants to use the shop facilities at ITP – this includes the CNC and lasercutter. Additional workshops will be offered for more in-depth use of the lasercutter and CNC.

title: Learn How to Solder
description: The counselors will be doing a quick session in the shop reviewing the basics of soldering. If you've never soldered before or are looking for a refresher, this session is for you.

title: Happy Hour
description: Happy hour is a great time to chat about stuff you've learned, ideas you have, or projects you're working on. Join us for healthy  drinks and adult beverages in the lounge!

title: The Internet is a physical thing (and why that matters)
description: It's tempting (and common) to think of the Internet as placeless and etherial. But the Internet has a physical reality that's easy to overlook. In many cases, it's intentionally hidden from view. We don't often see internet infrastructure -- the server farms, the colocation centres, the undersea cables -- but those things are there, and their physicality matters. At 5:30, special guest Ben Mendelsohn will be at ITP to present a screening of his short documentary Bundled, Buried & Behind Closed Doors, followed by a talk and Q&A. Then, shortly before 7pm, we'll head a few blocks down to The Architectural League of New York (594 Broadway, Suite 607), where Andrew Blum is giving a talk about his new book Tubes: A Journey to the Center of the Internet.

title: Lasersaur!
description: Many parts arrived, and we logged them in and sorted them to their various sub-systems. We also started sorting out the little parts, screws, nuts, washers, to the various sub-systems so it will be easier when we start to build. Thank you everyone! We will work on Sunday, hopefully starting the actual build. Link to the Bill of Materials by subsystem as a google doc spreadsheet. Link to the Bill of Materials by supplier as a google doc.

title: Turning hand-drawn images into digital files for the laser cutter
description: I figured out how to use a laser cutter for my hand-drawn work and thought I'd give a session and show you all the hard-won tricks for  how to do it. I'll walk you through step-by-step drawings using ink and paper, photoshop, illustrator and how to think like an artist when using the laser cutter. I also now use a Wacom tablet and an Inkling pen (a pen that captures in a vector file). I gather self-tracking data from walking, steps, daily routine, and lots and lots of measurements from gadgets that make self-quantification easy. A Zeo, a fitbit, a withings scale, along with online websites to capture mood (moodjam.com), microjournaling (mercuryapp), and time on your laptop (manictime). If interested checkout the Quantified-Self . Also Steve Dean is giving some sessions during camp! Just imagine the not-so-far-off-future where all the data about you is gathered invisibly and seamlessly produced as wall texture in the spaces you inhabit, using laser and 3D printers. Bring your laptop and follow along live, make a drawing as we go and produce a file ready to cut on the laser in the shop at ITP.... or just sit and watch. BTW, if you don't have the Adobe suite the NYU computer store has the software at an unbelievable price. Totally worth it while you're at Camp. (You'll need photoshop and illustrator...or checkout a machine with the software loaded). I post work and write about it at www.lauriefrick.com If you're experienced with using the laser cutter,bring examples of your work and share images or the actual thing. I've also priced laser cutting at a number of places and can talk about estimating and getting a shop to do the cutting for you. I dream of a day soon when I'll have a laser cutter alongside my miter and table saw in the studio.

title: More Lasersaur! Postponed
description: I am delayed getting back to New York, stuck waiting for a train, so this session will have to be postponed.

title: Kids Day!
description:
I'll invite some of my students. We'll organize a few kid friendly maker activities. Invite any kids you know! Let me know in the comments if you might bring kids and how many...
  • We have a Squishy Circuits researcher who is going to Skype in and do some demonstrations for us. Then we are going to do some Squishy Circuit experimentation on our own. See: http://courseweb.stthomas.edu/apthomas/SquishyCircuits/ for more on Squishy Circuits
  • We will do a quick introduction to the Scratch programming environment. This is a programming language for kids that was developed at MIT. See http://scratch.mit.edu/
  • We will do an introduction to http://www.TinkerCAD.com, a kid-friendly 3D CAD application.

title: Introduction to the command line
description:
This will be a slow paced introduction to the command line, no previous knowledge required.

Mac OS or Linux is strongly recommended. Windows could work too though.

Going through the motions is important here, so to get to most out of this session you should bring a computer.

title: Making things on the Craft Robo
description: As I learned yesterday, ITP has my favorite rapid prototyping machine, the Craft Robo, in the Soft Lab. The Craft Robo is a low cost and versatile machine that can be used to cut a variety of materials and draw with nearly any tool. I'll be going over how to create files in Illustrator and send to the machine to be cut or drawn, as well as showing some examples of work I've done on my own machine. Those interested can also design and cut their own "computational" bowl using a Processing sketch. The Illustrator plugin can be found here: OSX, Windows The Processing sketch can be found here: OSX, Windows 32, Windows 64 I can't seem to get the video of the Processing sketch to embed, but you can see it here.

title: Usability Testing on the Cheap
description:
If you're making a new product, you should be testing it with users as early and often as you can. If you have limited resources, this can seem daunting - but it can be cheap and easy to test enough to learn critical things about how users use your product.

In this session, I'll discuss some of the tactics and strategies I've used at MakerBot and elsewhere to plan and execute software and hardware usability testing. If you've done testing as well, bring your favorite stories and suggestions!

title: Performance Video using Isadora with Mattt!
description: Come learn you some super-quick-nasty-fast-n-dirty video presentation using the live performance software Isadora.  I will cover installation, basic playback, using effects, live camera and sound input, mayyyyyyyybe even some tracking if there's time.  Come!  It will be awesome!!

title: Field trip
description:
Let's go outside! They say there are people there too ...

Meet at 10am at ITP. We've had suggestions for a trip to the galleries in Chelsea, the MoMA and a few other proposals.

title: Game Design
description:
Digital games are a major cultural force for the 21st century. Moving beyond entertainment games are increasingly being used to generate new knowledge and to engage socially-aware collaboration across different sectors. As a design discipline, game form combines game worlds, rule sets and play to actively engage a player in ongoing activity. This session is aimed at introducing core game and play design principles in order to unpack the potential of this form to drive creative innovation. [caption id="attachment_1706" align="alignnone" width="259" caption="Loco Roco as a boardgame"][/caption] A discursive lecture on game design will be followed by group game design exercises that iteratively analyze, visualize, design and develop game concepts for presentation. Attendees will develop skills including paper prototyping, game modelling and level design.
Lecture notes available here:
Game design@itp v3
View more PowerPoint from Emma Westecott

title: Lasersaur: Build Frame Monday night
description: We started building the frame for the Lasersaur, specifically the frame gantry. Instructions to build frame gantry Bill of Materials by sub-system And we continued to sort and label parts, as there are many materials still coming in. We also set up an electronics team, with Jaymes and Karl in charge. We will continue to work tomorrow night.

title: Overview of Embedded Linux with the BeagleBone
description: So you've almost got the Arduino down pat, but what's around the corner? In the maker community, more and more people are turning to embedded Linux platforms like the Raspberry Pi and the BeagleBone to do more complex projects. In this session, we'll review some of the fundamental differences between 8-bit microcontrollers and embedded Linux platforms, learn how to get started coding and prototyping with the BeagleBone, and talk about some of the creative possibilites of using these platforms. No Linux experience is necessary, but it helps to have an understanding digital input and output on a microcontroller like the Arduino.

title: Super Sad True Love Story
description: Reading group bonus round: read *all* of Gary Shteyngart's Super Sad True Love Story. (Highly recommended by Molly.) Amazon | Google Books | iBooks.

title: An Approach to Data Driven PR
description: Startups of all sorts have a treasure trove of valuable, proprietary data. Why not put it to work? We've had a ton of success at SeatGeek in leveraging our database of event ticket price information to craft an interesting storylines that drive real, meaningful PR mentions for our company. We think the general approach of using your own data creatively for PR purposes is broadly applicable to all sorts of startups and enterprises, so we're excited to share our approach with ITP campers this year! SeatGeek is a NYC based sports and concert ticket search aggregator. Here are some examples of Data Driven PR stories that we've secured in major publications. We think startups and young companies of all stripes and and kinds can use a similar approach to win press coverage: Deadspin - The Market for Yankees Tickets Is Worse Than We Thought New York Times - Jeremy Lin Turning Fans Into Scalpers, Too USA Today - Talking Tickets with SeatGeek (video)

title: Build Lasersaur Frame:Tuesday night
description: We built the frame table tonight. Much measuring with calipers. Jaymes has started wiring up the shield. John and Rob have ordered a sheet of plywood to extend the flat surface of the cart. Bill of Materials by sub-system Instructions to build frame table

title: Lasersaur Build continues! Wednesday night
description: We worked on the frame door tonight. Also, Jaymes got sockets for the LasaurShield. There were so many great sessions tonight, we worked for a bit, then we all ran off to other sessions. Our time frame is turning out to be rather informal, we are working when people have the time to stop by. I assume this will continue to some extent, seems to work best so everyone can participate in sessions they are interested in as well as build the Lasersaur. Instructions for building the frame door Bill of Materials by sub-system

title: Lasersaur Build: Thursday night
description: More Lasersaur. We adjusted the frame gantry, then starting laying out the outer frame. This sub-system is the bulk of the frame, it will incorporate everything we have built so far. We will continue on this system over the weekend, Saturday 1-5, Sunday 3-8. Stop by if you are interested, even if you are only available for a short time.

title: Lasersaur Build: Saturday afternoon
description: Lasersaur build continues. We tightened up the bottom part of the frame, then attached the frame table. Progress! Tomorrow we will attach the frame gantry and possibly the frame door.

title: Lasersaur Build: Sunday
description: More Lasersaur build. Today we will attach the frame gantry and possibly the frame door. Stop by if you have a bit of time to check out our progress and tighten a screw.

title: Open CV basics
description: A quick down and dirty introduction to using the Open CV library with Processing. Open CV Website

title: XBee Internet Gateway with Rob Faludi
description:
The XBee Internet Gateway ("XIG") is an open-source application written for Digi's ConnectPort series of XBee-to-IP gateways and soon to be available for any computer. It gives any device the ability to connect seamlessly to the Internet by mirroring the interactions humans have with web browsers. All the tricky technical aspects of web connections are all handled for you behind the scenes. This XIG gives your prototype or device a simple yet completely flexible pathway to any web service that you can imagine, including posting sensor values, scraping Facebook, interacting through iDigi or commanding your robotic kitten army. In one engaging session, Rob Faludi will explain the fundamentals of XIG and why it matters to the people who are building the Internet of Things. Topics to include:
  • short history features
  • iDigi links
  • projects, including videos
  • advantages of open-source
  • how-to, with more videos
  • future directions

title: ITP for K-12
description: The skills that you learn at ITP Camp can be used to teach science, technology, engineering, art, math and design in fun and interesting ways. You don’t need a teacher’s license to get started teaching. Teaching, tutoring, and mentoring can be a great part-time gig for freelancers. We will tell you how we got started teaching and give you some resources that will help you find your own teaching gigs with special focus on K-12. Lyel Resner Lyel is the Founder of Startup Box South Bronx (SB)^2 - a co-learning space that incubates promising technology startups and offers STEM programming to youth in the South Bronx. After a stint on Wall Street, Lyel committed to sampling the social sector. He has managed micro-finance projects in Peru for Kiva, run academic programming for a large non-profit in Spanish Harlem, and consulted for the Rockefeller Foundation about Impact Investing. Lyel holds degrees from NYU, where he was a Reynolds Fellow in Social Entrepreneurship, and in Physics and Political Science from MIT, where he was a Burchard Humanities Scholar. Jaymes Dec (ITP ’07) Jaymes is the Technology Integrator and FabLab Administrator at the Marymount School. Previously, Jaymes was Program Manager at GreenFab, a high school program for students from the South Bronx that taught Science, Technology, Engineering and Math skills through classes on sustainable design and green technologies. Laura Allen Laura is the Founder and President of Vision Education & Media. She has worked with teachers and students and technology for over eighteen years. An early interest in LOGO programming led Laura to the Harvard Graduate School of Education where she collaborated on projects with the MIT Media Laboratory and the mathematician and educator, Dr. Seymour Papert, the founder of LOGO programming and one of the world's foremost expert on instructional technologies. Prior to founding Vision Education, Laura directed the Computer Department at The Buckley School in Manhattan for fourteen years and was Director of the Technology Program at the Little Red School House and Elisabeth Irwin High School for two. In recent news, Enterprising Women has named its 2006 Enterprising Women of the Year and Laura Allen was named one of forty.

title: Experimenting with LEDs, Arduino, TLC5940
Audio & Pro Tools with Phan V.
description: Learn how to use Pro Tools with master sound designer/composer Phan V. Great for people who need to take their audio to the next level. Especially for finalizing video before publishing on the web.

title: From Illustrator to Rhino (and possibly back again)
description: A few people have expressed interest in learning more about how to model in Rhino. This session will go over how to take 2D geometry from Illustrator and create 3D forms from it in Rhino. If there's time at the end, I'll also explain how to transform these 3D shapes back to Illustrator as line drawings. Please bring an Illustrator document with a sketch of the object you'd like to model. Plan/aerial views are encouraged, but sections are also fine.

title: RGBD Filmmaking with Kinect + DSLR
description: Update: Thank you all for attending the workshop! We had a blast with you all. Our film of perpetual introductions was on view almost immediately afterwards in the ITP hallway. It looks great.   As promised here is the data from the workshop and a link to the brand new 003 release of the RGBD toolkit and a new set of tutorial videos. Created for you! RGBD_preRelease_003_osx_lite.zip — RGBD PreRelease v. 003 for Mac OS X ITPCamp.zip –  Your data! https://vimeo.com/album/1977644/ – New tutorials that cover everything we went over in the workshop Thingiverse.com – Instructions & STLs for making asus & kinect mounts. Workshop Description: Imagine a future where the only constraint to filmmaking is your capacity to envision. Where the camera can easily float like a balloon or perform that neurotically complex tracking shot. Where the surfaces of your subjects can undulate or disintegrate into a cloud of unruly dots at whim. The RGBD toolkit is an open source project built in Open Frameworks for making volumetric films with a Kinect and any HD video camera. It supplements the depth-sensing capabilities of the Kinect with lush HD footage to create an immersive cinema. As an RGBD filmmaker, the form, the appearance and the perspective of your film are all within your reach to mold on a basic level. We will do a demonstration and quick workshop covering the whole RGBD workflow. We'll send you off with a folder of matched and calibrated depth and video data of yourselves with a primer on how to create your own immersive  films in the RGBD visualizer timeline tool. With James George & Alexander Porter www.rgbdtoolkit.com rgbd.tumblr.com RGBD github

title: XBee Basics
description: Learn the basics of XBee wireless communication with 802.15.4 (Series 1) radios. We'll demystify the various different types of radios and wireless networks, work through a basic wireless serial connection and talk about direct pin access. I'll provide loaner XBees, but if you'd like to bring your own, we'll be using XBee Series 1 with Sparkfun's XBee explorer. Also, please download Coolterm and FTDI drivers if you haven't already. Presentation

title: Making a Mouse or Keyboard Emulator with the Arduino Leonardo
description: So you've played around with an Arduino before, and you can make an LED blink, but have you ever made a keyboard or mouse emulator?  It's dead simple now, thanks to the new Keyboard and Mouse libraries for the Arduino Leonardo. In this workshop, I'll show you how to use the Keyboard and Mouse libraries, and we'll make our own mouse and keyboard devices. Bring your favorite sensors, components to attach them to an Arduino, and  materials and we'll make some game controllers together to use with laptop and brower-based games. I'll have some Leonardos on hand for people to work with. Since you'll learn the basics of making a keyboard or mouse emulator in the session, we'll have a competition in the second hour:  Make a game controller that can play the Chrome version of Angry Birds better than anyone else in the room, and you get to take home a Leonardo. Top ten scorers win. BYO sensors and anything else you need to go with them. In this session I'll assume everyone knows the basics of working with Arduino, and has enough knowledge to attach an analog sensor to an Arduino and program it to read the sensor. We'll break into groups or individuals in the second half and build working projects. So bring your parts!

title: Economics of Being an Artist
description:
This session is a panel discussion on the economics of being a working artist. I'm completely unfamiliar with how artists fund their work, and what types of opportunities are available to them. I hope this discussion will be not only informative for myself and others unaware of the process, but also constructive for the artists among us. When you RSVP, please indicate if you'd also be willing to be on the panel. Some of the questions that have been proposed (and please add more in the comments):
  • How do you finance your work?
  • If you do commissioned work, where do you find the clients?
  • What types of clients or buyers are their for your pieces?
  • Do you need a dealer, if so in what city, what can they do for you?
  • How do you meet curators, what are their interests and motivations for showing work
  • How do you find opportunities to exhibit your work?
  • Are there ways like self-publishing in literature and music to ‘go direct’?
  • How do you determine the price of a piece?
  • What other ways do you supplement your income (and is that generally necessary)?
    • Talks, visiting artist, stipends from artist-residencies, other sources of $$?
  • Commercial gallery vs. non-profit exhibition spaces vs. museum shows, how are they different?

title: Seeing Sensors: How to visualize and save Arduino-sensed data
description: Sometimes when you're prototyping a project it's nice to see what's going on with your sensors or variables in your code. Sure you can watch analogRead() values scroll at warp speed on your Arduino Serial Monitor, but what if you want to save that data? Or look at a graph you make in real time instead of numbers? Maybe you want to do some self tracking and visualize your Fitbit stats, or compare two different light sensors or force sensing resistors? In this class I'll demonstrate two workflows that help us do this... 1) The Graphing Serial data in Processing Lab 2) Using CoolTerm to view and save data, then Excel (or OpenOffice/Google Docs equivalent) to graph the data. To follow along, you'll just need the parts from the Graphing Serial data in Processing lab: an Arduino, a few wires, a breadboard, and a potentiometer (or other analog sensor). To save time, make sure you come with Arduino, Processing, and CoolTerm installed on your laptop. We'll be talking through my blog post here with plenty of screenshots so if we go a little fast you always have this to refer back to at your own pace.

title: Staff/Counselor Workshop: SoftLab Basics
description: Learn the basics of sewing, embroidery, paper and vinyl cutting. Whether you want to use these tools to create soft circuits, embroider your favorite hoodie or cut paper or vinyl for making a popup book, this workshop will help you learn how to use ITP’s basic tools in all these areas.

title: Staff/Counselor Workshop: DIY PCB Etching
description: Learn how to print and etch your own PCBs – DIY-style – using ITP’s SoftLab! If you have a schematic you want to try out, bring it with you.

title: Lasersaur build Monday June 18
description: We finished the outer frame and incorporated the door. Participation is informal, stop by if you have a bit of time.

title: Lasersaur build continues Wednesday June 20
description: We started working on the gantry system, but ran into a problem when it turned out the the custom acrylic parts that had been cut for us were the wrong size, so evening ended early. We will get them recut- then back to work.

title: Intro to digifab
description: In this session we will learn how to design our projects in Rhino3D. We will go over how to setup our files for the laser cutter, cnc, and maker bot. You will requie to download rhino3d for Mac which is in free beta.

title: An App For That - Intro to Phonegap
description: Phonegap is an open source framework for building cross-platform mobile applications with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. This is a great tool for web developers interested in mobile development as it allows them to leverage existing skills rather than start form scratch with a device-specific compiled language. And for total beginners, Phonegap's web languages are much easier to pick up than Objective-C or Java. In this workshop, you will learn how to setup the PhoneGap development environment, learn some of the fundamental development considerations of the platform, and deploy your very own app to a device. We will be focusing on iOS development, but Phonegap's greatest strength is it's cross-platform compatibility. All smart phone enthusiasts are encouraged to attend. In order to participate in the demo it is recommended that you arrive with a machine running Mac OS Lion with Xcode pre-installed from the Mac App Store

title: PixelPhones
description: Seb is known for large scale installations and events that bring people together using technology, like his interactive digital fireworks, and glowstick voting systems. In this session he talks about his most recent project - PixelPhones, making good use of the audience and stretching the wi-fi network to its limits! The software connects to all the smart phones, turning each member of the audience into a single pixel of a huge pulsating display. He then explores how PixelPhones can create unique events where the audience can truly become part of the performance, and the challenges involved in scaling this system up to 1000s of audience members. Bring your iPhones, and Flash enabled Android devices! Oh and probably worth charging them up beforehand. :-) More information about Seb

title: Mobile Dev Intro
description:
Counselors Sheiva and Genevieve will be running an introductory session to talk about various programs and dev environments to get started programming for mobile devices and tablets. We're going to tackle these questions in our session: (1) what are the best platforms and programs for mobile programming?
(2) what are the pros and cons of these different strategies? (3) what are you interested in learning? We're also putting together more platform specific sessions, which should be on the schedule soon!

title: Build a Communal Musical Instrument with Mark Kleback & Ezer Longinus
description:
Help us build sequencers to create a communal musical instrument. The board, designed by Mark Kleback and Ezer Longinus, can function on its own as a 10-step sequencer, but can also be plugged into a master clock so that many people can play together at the same time. This version can be prototyped and constructed by beginners using through-hole soldering. All participants will leave the workshop with their very own sequencer, which they are welcome to play at the ITP Camp show.
Instructions
https://docs.google.com/presentation/pub?id=1fIxuceksfkaJH5QXso3H2hFJgP8sLh9ZgFSJN5j6Cls&start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000
Build of Materials
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/pub?key=0AreLUBNmIrkAdDNWRTZsd0lVV3lwVXFSbmNGRENJN2c&output=html
Board: Schematics: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hGmhtp6tWbE Capped at 20 participants

title: ITP Camp Jam Session
description: It's a party! Come with musical instruments, laptops, sequencers or other items that make noise for this end of ITP Camp hoorah!

title: Musical Robotics – beyond the basics
description: What happens when you mix music and robotics? Delicious projects that you love building and sharing. But you probably don't love listening to them. That's because it's hard to make music with machinery. Let's fix that right now. In this session we'll explore how to design musically talented robots, instruments, and installations. Which physical phenomena create sound and how can we harness them with actuators? How can new musical machines create new musical possibilities? What makes instruments successful and what do we mean by success? Where do we start? This session will be a mixture of lecture and open discussion. Come prepared to ask questions and share ideas.

title: The Jitters: Intro to Interactive Video Art
description: This session will introduce you to Jitter and interactive video. The session will feature a lecture about the history of video art (including what's going on today in the world of interactive video) as well as a Jitter tutorial for Artsy types who want to get their hands on some easy to use interactive software. By the end of the session you will no longer fear video but video will fear you.

title: Rapid UX Prototyping Applications (mobile and web)
description:
User Experience (UX) has gained a solid foothold in the design, development and building of online applications.  Thinking a project through in a high-level visual form is a necessary step towards helping a project become more successful.  The practice is more predominant in the web site space.  As mobile applications continue to grow at an exponential rate, the specialization of mobile User Experience is becoming more important.  This session will be divided into roughly two parts.  The first part is a quick overview and presentation.  The second part is where we get our hands a little dirty as I demonstrate a few tools and techniques. I set up a followup work session to go into more detail on the prototyping tools demonstrated and to talk. http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2012/?p=2333 A lot to cover in a short amount of time. Other participants who are in the same field, please feel free to share other tools/techniques. Part I – The Practice of Web and Mobile UX (0:20 min)
  • Introduction
  • Differences between web sites and mobile sites
  • Differences between mobile Apps and mobile sites
  • Different platforms and considerations
  • Current trends (HTML apps)
Part II – Tips and Tools of the Trade (1:00)
  • Wireframing with Omnigraffle
  • Prototyping mobile sites and apps with Axure
  • iBooks Author for iPad + Hype
  • Prototyping mobile Apps with xCode and PhoneGap
  • Presentation techniques and technologies
Q&A (0:15) UPDATE (06/25/2012): Here are some of the links to examples and software that was demonstrated last Friday.  If you have any other questions or want to talk some more, you can email me at dkawasaki@gmail.com or Twitter @dansempai.  Thanks for coming! Examples of responsive design: http://mediaqueri.es http://www.starbucks.com/static/reference/styleguide/ http://remodelista.com/ Software: http://www.axure.com ( excellent tutorials, examples and support) http://phonegap.com ( step by step instructions on how to convert your HTML to apps for android and iPhone) http://www.balsamiq.com/ (less expensive interface sketching software) http://www.apple.com/ibooks-author/ (Free! Easy drag and drop interface allowing you to create and publish eBooks in the Apple iBookstore.  Allows you to rotate, annotate, add videos, html, quizzes and keynote files and easily preview the whole thing on your iPad)

title: UX Prototyping Tools Workshop
description: This is a followup to the Rapid UX Prototyping Applications (mobile and web) session presented Friday, June 22nd.  If you were unable to make that session, feel free to come in and join us anyway. http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2012/?p=2315 In that session, I gave a quick overview and demonstration of the tools and techniques for rapid prototyping.  This session is a work session where we can play with the software as a group to build a quick mobile prototype that you can interact with on your phone of phone simulator. We will be primarily using Axure (http://axure.com , 30-day free trial) which is a popular development platform for UX developers (Mac OS X and Windows).  I'll also demo other less expensive alternatives. I hope this session can be a little looser and open so any lingering UX or prototyping questions can be answered.  Feel free to add topics you wish to cover in the comments. UPDATE 1:  There is a lot to do during this workshop.  This is also being streamed (my first time!) so I took the liberty of compiling the following PDF that goes over the bulk of the presentation with step-by-step instructions.  Hopefully this will help.  Also I added phone gap and Xcode installations to the process which will add about 20-30 minutes at the beginning to get everything set up. https://www.dropbox.com/s/bo05hwq4l9cx9b4/UX%20Prototype%20Workshop%20Tutorial%2006.26.2012.pdf Let me know if you have problems seeing the file. UPDATE 2: June, 27th, 2012.  The day after the UX tool work session.  A question came up after the Dreamweaver QR code distribution of the apps.  While that was cool, it would be nice to do the same with iPhone/iPad apps for the uses Laurie mentioned.  I researched it a little this morning and remembered a free service that allows you to test your apps with clients without having to go through the iTune app store. https://testflightapp.com/ What you do is upload the beta built app to this service and it supplies links that you can distribute to your clients so they can install the apps and test it out before you submit it for Apple's approval. UPDATE 3: Reading list for best UX practices.  These days development in the UX field is moving so fast that certain books are not keeping up with the latest innovations.  I still read some seminal texts, but more often these days, I find that the more compelling information is being written online.  Here is a rough list off the top of my head. Sites: http://konigi.com/  <--- A good blog with downloadable resources and stencils for UX professionals http://www.alistapart.com/ http://www.topsite.com/best/ux <--- a list of other sites including the ones above. Apps: Zite  <--- Free app (android and iOS), has a Web Design & User Experience category that you can add that pulls up fresh content daily from many different UX sources.  I've discovered tons of excellent articles that I would not have discovered on my own.  Zite's interface is a little awkward, but the infer it provides is really good. Flipboard <--- Free app (android and iOS) - good source of information on various categories.  You can add User Experience as a category and flip through articles and blogs in you spare time. Dan's book recommendations This is a hard one.  I'll have to think about this a little more.  To tell you the truth I have a lot of these books on my bookshelf, but some are more academic and to be frank, boring.  But you will see the same books reoccur on many other lists (google user experience book recommendations).  It is hard for me to be objective and say definitively that these are the books you should absolutely read if you are going to get started in the field.  If you can still find a bookstore, I would take these lists and flip through the books listed and see which one presents information in a way that you can digest. Nick Finick's list of UX Books Amazon's list Here is a picture of my messy bookshelf of some UX books. Book recommendations from Bob Holling from his ITP Camp email.  Thanks Bob! Mobile First by Luke Wroblewski Responsive Web Design, by Dan Cederholm The Elements of User Experience, by Jesse James Garrett If you have any questions going forward please feel free to email me (dkawasaki at gmail.com) or follow on twitter @dansempai (starting to use it a little more). Thanks, -Dan

title: Lasersaur build Sat. June 23
description: We worked on the gantry system, building the x-cart. We fussed around a lot trying to get it on the y-cart precisely.

title: Lasersaur Build Sunday June 24
description: We spent a lot of time adjusting the y-cart placement, which was out of alignment. This involved taking the x-cart off, as well as the middle extrusion, and reattaching them. Next we started on the x-drive.

title: Building Apps with Processing for Android
description: The name says it all!  We'll spend the session learning how to build apps for Android with Processing.  Bring your Android phone (or use a borrowed one from ITP though we may have to share) and your laptop. It would also be helpful to download and setup the requisite software beforehand.   See the "Instructions" and "Download" portions of this page: http://wiki.processing.org/w/Android

title: Lasersaur Build Friday June 22
description: The parts are in (thank you Jaymes Dec for re-cutting the acrylic parts) and the motors arrived, so we continued to work on the gantry system. We installed the y-cart, then built out the y-drive, building and installing the shaft, then attaching the timing belts.

title: Intro to Rhino 3D Modeling
description: 3D modeling allows us to virtually examine work-in-progress from a rotational, 360-degree view, and provides crucial perspectives into identifying design flaws, visualizing aesthetic choices and drafting multiple iterations before construction or fabrication. This workshop is an introduction to the NURBS based 3D modeling software Rhino – a virtual space to explore, create and manipulate designs. Learning Objectives -    Introduction to Rhino as a modeling tool -    Translating data Rhino and other software (Processing, Illustrator, Python) -    Understanding the uses and limitations of Rhino and other 3D modeling software

title: Inspiration Cinema
description: Come and join "Inspiration Cinema"! A 2 hour session where you can get inspired by a program of shorts curated by the other participants... This is the plan : Everyone attending the session seeks two inspiring videos of maximum 5 minutes in length. These can be anything!  A lesson in history, a tutorial, an artist at work, crazy conspiracy theories, a music video, anything as long as you think it is interesting to share. It's a good idea to try to find videos that most other participants probably have not seen yet.  Ow and maybe not NSFW. During the session everyone gets one (1!) minute to introduce his or her video (if they want) and then we watch it together. There will be popcorn! To facilitate the flow during the session I would like everyone to email me ( anner dot tiete at gmail) links / the files for the video they will be presenting so I can prepare a playlist...

title: SHANTELL MARTIN: The bigger picture
description: An introduction to the simplicity and strength of a drawn line over different mediums. I’ll discuss about the journey of my line, how it has developed over the years, performing with a line and what the future holds. Bio: https://dl.dropbox.com/u/676677/Shantell_Martin_4pg.pdf Website: http://www.shantellmartin.com/ Tumblr: http://shantellmartin.tumblr.com/

title: Intro to OpenFrameworks
description:
If you're familiar with Processing, and want to get an idea of how OpenFrameworks, that other creative coding environment, works, please join ITP resident Rune Madsen for an introductory session to programming in C++ with OpenFrameworks.

He'll cover the basics of getting OpenFrameworks up and running with the XCode IDE (Mac), or Code Basics/Visual Studio (Windows/Linux), the difference between a header and cpp file, how to install addons, and basic syntax of C++.

title: 1 on 1 Help Session
description: Need some help with fabrication, pcompy stuff, Computer Vision, finishing touches, or making hard decisions right before Show time? RSVP here to book a spot!

title: 1 on 1 help session
Lasersaur build: Monday June 25
description: Build continues! We finished up the x-drive, then took a careful look at the electronic sub-system, checking the parts and also the schematic.

title: Lasersaur build continues
description: We measured the cabling for the switches and motors, and soldered the switches. We also skyped Stefan to ask a few questions about the wiring of the motors and switches.

title: Lasersaur build continues
description: We installed the limit switches on the mount panels, then on the Lasersaur.

title: What can Open Hardware do for creative practice?
description: Alicia Gibb will introduce the Open Source Hardware Association and its goals. There will be an open discussion of how the association can help artists, designers and creatives to use, produce and be part of the open hardware ecosystem. Open Source Hardware Association announcememt: http://blog.makezine.com/2012/04/12/open-source-hardware-association-announced/ Interview with Alicia Gibb: http://blog.makezine.com/2012/04/23/makes-exclusive-interview-with-alicia-gibb-president-of-the-open-source-hardware-association/

description: Blow your own mind with projectors!
