title: Intermediate openFrameworks
description:
During this workshop we will discuss higher level concepts involved in developing openFrameworks applications. We'll focus on interactive installations and talk about important design patterns that you normally learn through years of difficult trial and error. There will be a lot of teaching by example. Participants should have some experience with openFrameworks: maybe you've used it for a project you've worked on, or you've even taught it to others.

This workshop will be lead by Kyle McDonald and Zach Lieberman.

title: Nerdy Derby Car Workshop
description: Grab a kit from the counselor desk and build a car for our Nerdy Derby, the no-rules pine wood derby that we'll be hosting at Maker Faire New York. During this session, we'll be in the shop helping out with car construction. Since there are no rules, you can totally trick out your car in any way you want.

title: Nerdy Derby Car Workshop
description: Grab a kit from the counselor desk and build a car for our Nerdy Derby, the no-rules pine wood derby that we'll be hosting at Maker Faire New York. During this session, we'll be in the shop helping out with car construction. Since there are no rules, you can totally trick out your car in any way you want.

title: Lasersaur build continues
description: We are working on the electronics, soldered motors and started wiring gecko drivers, attaching them to shield and to board.

title: Imagining Camp 2013
description: Now that you're a Camp expert, what do you think is next? How can ITP Camp grow, shift, and take further shape? What would you recommend or what would YOU like to do?

title: Meet and Eat
description: Time to kick off camp! Join us for some snacks and getting to know your fellow campers!

title: End-of-Camp Shindig
description:
Half show & tell, half party, the End of Camp Shindig is an opportunity to celebrate the month we've spent together and share what we've created.

This is a great opportunity to see what everyone has been up to this month. Share your hello world demos, work in progress materials, project documentation, and fully functioning projects. Leading up to the event the camp counselors will be compiling a list of who's sharing what so please stop by to let them know.

Setup will happen during the day on Friday. If you need a special staging space please contact Rob Ryan by Wednesday at 5PM at the latest.

We'll have eats, drinks, and good tunes. And maybe some camp songs by the fire.

Please RSVP here so we can make sure we have enough food!

title: "Noticing" Workshop
description: This workshop teaches techniques and tools for noticing—seeing, hearing and comprehending something new. In a short series of exercises we’ll explore the observation process in an array of domains, from cognitive psychology to ethnography and drawing to data collection, with techniques for reaching that moment we all crave: when something unexpected and terrific bursts forward into consciousness. Participants will leave with their eyes wide open to the inspirations and complexity that surround us all and their minds full of techniques for learning more.

title: Introduction to Max/MSP/Jitter
description: Max/MSP/Jitter is a multimedia authoring environment that enables you to create programs for real-time manipulation of media (data, audio, video, 3d). It is used in performance and installations by artists, composers, and people just like you! This 2 hour workshop will be a (super speedy) introduction to Max and its workflow. Applications are called "patches" and use a paradigm similar to a flowchart, radically different than the text based programming you're more likely familiar with. Max is made by Cycling '74. You can find out more information about it on their product page. You can download a free 30-day unlimited trial for OSX and Windows. I would suggest you do this a few days before the session so we can have "happy patching" during the meeting. The presentation from the session can be found here : http://bit.ly/18SkLUh The patches can be found here : https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/7095089/MaxMSPJitterCamp2013.zip

title: Dancing with the Arduino Due
description:
Now that you're a couple weeks into camp, you've probably bumped up against the glass ceiling of the hardware you're using. Common issues expressed by campers in previous years have been "My death robot has no more memory for kill routines!", or "I want to just plug a mouse into my Arduino  to control my hypnotronic LED array"

Fear not, for there's a next generation Arduino called the Due that features a faster processor, more memory, many more pins for in/out, and can act as a USB host (so you can plug in a mous/keyboard direct to the Arduino).  It also has the capability for sound playback and the beginnings of a scheduler for handling multiple tasks at the same time.

In this one hour session, we'll look at some of the things that set the Due apart from its predecessor, the Uno, and  create some fun interactions that are either wicked difficult, or not possible with other Arduino boards.

title: <del>Gettin' jiggy with the GSM shield</del>
description:
<del>The Arduino GSM shield allows you to make and receive voice calls, send and receive SMS messages, and send data over a cellular network.</del>

<del>In this one hour session, we'll go over the basics of using the GSM shield and look at creating some mobile hardware applications.</del>

Hey Campers, my apologies, but I will need to reschedule this session. Sorry for the last-minuteness of this.

-scott

title: Hacking Higher Ed
description: Exciting innovation is happening in the area of higher education. This session will ask participants to look at ways to reinvent higher education to increase its accessibility and exceed the current quality of the experience. We will do a brief survey current experiments such as Udacity, Khan Academic, O’Reilly, Code Academy, Meetups, TED Talks, General Assembly, Hackerspaces.   Topics will talk about new way of thinking about Curriculum, Content, Conversation, Motivations and Outcomes, Community, Physical Space, Economics, Research to create new institutions for higher education.  These topics are based on the syllabus for this course http://itp.nyu.edu/~dbo3/hack-ed/

title: Rest Of You: Digital Edition
description: Life is what happens to you will you are busy doing other things.  You pay attention to a small part of your experience when it is the rest of you that is more important.  The Rest of You is a class about trying to get a better picture of those parts that you don't pay attention to.  This session will zero in on one week of work in the Rest Of You class that tries to cull through your digital footprint to give you a more accurate picture of yourself and perhaps suggest some interventions to change the rest of you.    Here are some assignments from the digital week of this class http://itp.nyu.edu/~dbo3/roy/?cat=12

title: Nudgeables Workshop
description: Sometimes we use secret codes to communicate with our friends, partners, or colleagues while in the company of a larger group of people: a nudge, a cough, a scratch of the nose; something that says “I'm thinking of you...”, “Save me from this conversation!”, or “Let’s get out of here!”.  What if our clothing could communicate these messages for us? The Nudgeables Accessory Kit is a modular hardware kit that invites artists and designers to create sets of wireless wearable communication accessories.  A Nudgeables device employs a radio transceiver, a “Nudger”, and a “Notifier” to enable a pair of people to nudge each other from across a room.  Because the Kit attends to most technical needs, such as circuit design and radio configurations, focus is placed on the designing both the interaction and the wearable. In this workshop, participants will have the opportunity to learn about designing for wearable technology and design and produce their own Nudgeables devices!

title: Intro to Jitter & computer vision
description: Jitter is a video library for Max, by cycling 74. There's a lot to explore in this toolset : real-time video manipulation, OpenGL, computer vision, physical modeling. So many things! You can find out about more about the package at the cycling74 website. In this session, we'll focus on playing back and manipulating pre-recorded video and getting a live camera input.  We'll also look at cv.jit, a computer vision package that allows you to analyze video and use it as a control system. You should already be familiar with Max/MSP or Pure Data before coming to this workshop. This is the Jitter resource document from the session : http://bit.ly/1886CTo Patches from the session : https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/7095089/CampCVExamples.zip

title: exploring biomimicry
description: This 2-hour workshop on biomimicry will address nature as inspiration for design and technological solutions. We will consider the biological and natural world, and work hands on to create quick prototypes using paper, pen, and some building materials, on topics that might include re-designing social networks, mapping urban spaces, and re-defining user interfaces.

title: Sensing our surroundings : log sensor data using arduino
Faster Fashion - Rapid Prototyping and the Things We Wear
description: **YOU MUST HAVE HAD A SHOP SAFETY TRAINING IN ORDER TO TAKE THIS CLASS.  NO EXCEPTIONS.** From decoration to precision, other worldly forms to on demand creation, digital fabrication technologies are finding their way into the world of fashion. Textile designer, Hillary Predko, will give a short lecture on digital fabrication and fashion and hands on workshop with the laser cutter and various textiles. Learn how weave structure and material content react to the laser cutter and how these effects can be used to your advantage in projects. Experiment with conductive fabric to create flexible, iron on circuits.

title: Hello PhoneGap
description: The miracle of mobile computing has arrived. Exceedingly powerful computers, seamlessly networked and with a variety of in-built sensors... all right in your pocket.PhoneGap is an open source framework that lets you program cross-platform mobile phone apps using HTML, Javascript and CSS. Providing a Javascript API to access  the accelerometer, GPS, notifications, and other hardware capabilities of your phone, you can write your code once and deploy the app to Android, iPhone, Blackberry and several other platforms. The class will go from zero to Android app, walking through installation, some tips and tricks and a few examples to get you started. We'll discuss the benefits and limitations of PhoneGap and demonstrate how you can leverage your skills using HTML/Javascript/CSS to make phone apps. While this class will focus on Android development, the apps you create with PhoneGap will also be transferable to your iPhone. Come to class with your computer. If you have one, bring your Android phone. If not, you can use the Android emulator in Eclipse. More information here - http://produceconsumerobot.com/mobileweb2012/week1.php

title: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium
description: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium is the first installment of a 3 part series on creating narratives within in the framework of a app. This lecture is a survey of current artists and projects using the mobile platform to create innovative narrative forms (i.e: Christoph Niemann’s “Petting Zoo”,  David Benqué’s “The Infinite Adventure Machine”, Works from “Les Editions Volumiques” etc…). Anna is a visual artist who uses technology to explore our human drive to collect stories and objects.  She teaches digital media and art at various universities in the New York area. Lia is an artist and creative coder with a special focus on digital media for children. She is currently aresearch resident at ITP and will be teaching at ITP in the fall.

title: Introduction to HTML / CSS
description:
Part 2 of 3 in a series of sessions that provide a framework for creating narratives in the form of mobile apps.

This workshop goes over basic HTML/CSS syntax and its place in mobile app development. If you want to code along, we recommend that you download a code editor like Sublime Text, Coda, or Text Wrangler (free). This is a beginner class. Anna is a visual artist who uses technology to explore our human drive to collect stories and objects.  She teaches digital media and art at various universities in the New York area. Lia is an artist and creative coder with a special focus on digital media for children. She is currently aresearch resident at ITP and will be teaching at ITP in the fall.

title: Simple Animations for Digital Narratives
description: Part 3 of 3 in a series of sessions that provide a framework for creating narratives in the form of mobile apps. This workshop takes a  look at animation principles and at how to apply them to an HTML page with CSS. We will also discuss how to bundle files to create a self-contained mobile app with JQuery Mobile and Phonegap. This is a basic class for web beginners. If you want to play with the examples while in class, we recommend that you download a code editor like Sublime Text  and XCode (both free). Anna is a visual artist who uses technology to explore our human drive to collect stories and objects.  She teaches digital media and art at various universities in the New York area. Lia is an artist and creative coder with a special focus on digital media for children. She is currently aresearch resident at ITP and will be teaching at ITP in the fall.

title: XBee Basics Workshop
description: Learn the basics of XBee wireless communication with 802.15.4 (Series 1) radios. We’ll demystify the various different types of radios and wireless networks, work through a basic wireless serial connection and talk about direct pin access. I’ll provide loaner XBees, but if you’d like to bring your own, we’ll be using XBee Series 1 with Sparkfun’s XBee explorer. Also, please download Coolterm and FTDI drivers if you haven’t already.

title: the beauty of ephemeral life
description: A talk about my work in recent and past. Since the artist statement and general information about my work is available on the web < http://takafumiide.com >, I think I can show "behind the scene" and answer your question; e.g. what did I use to create these works? Hope this works out for you. Thank you!

title: From Story to Tech: a methodology project
description:
Often times, it seems that tech projects can come off as nothing more than technological masturbation. Many of us know what it's like to witness a new project with cutting-edge tech only to feel disappointed, likening the experience more to a technical demo than something poignant and worth remembering. This may happen with projects of any nature, of course, but tech projects are especially prone to the pitfall of gadgetry taking precedence over meaning.

For creating engaging projects, a good place to start is with stories. And although new media practice is all about infusing narrativity nowadays, I wish to take it one step further – or one step more "literal" – with this session. I propose a lecture / workshop in which I provide familiar stories from literature, etc. as our base material for creating potential tech projects. My objective is to guide participants through the exercise of using the methodology that I've started to develop through my own projects, extracting story elements and structure for guiding user experience & interaction, then leading to the choice of technologies most suited to the project, as a whole.

Thus, this method can be seen as the opposite of what we often encounter with tech projects: instead of starting with a technological choice and then trying to stick a narrative on top of it, we would work the other way around.

title: Re-wiring for Re-cycling
description: Physical Computing strikes me as a unique opportunity to recycle materials destined for landfill while creating unique objects and experiences. I've recently come to realize that a large part of my increased comfort level with electronics derives from a shift in perspective; no longer do I simply see a lonely rusted bike wheel littering my neighborhood, but raw materials such as spokes that make great axles for rotating propellers and mirrors. The VCR I found outside my friend's studio became a drawer of motors, buttons, and a tape reader that now scans discarded video tapes in tandem with that bike tire! So for this session I'd like to lead a conceptual and hands on workshop in which we dream up ways to use discarded electronics (which I will provide). What inventive ways will we think to use an air mattress pump? A robotic aerosol sprayer? A game involving a levitating object? The possibilities are vast and can only improve with a conceptual shift concerning everyday objects.

title: Quantified Self: Tools, Trends, and Applications
description: When Forbes called 2013 "the year of the Quantified Self" at CES it became clear that this is no longer a niche field just for life loggers. In this session I will go through the history of the quantified self (QS) movement, the existing apps/devices available, ways to hack together your own tools, trends in the industry, and discuss areas that are still untouched by this phenomenon that seems to be the new buzz word of 2013. A year and a half ago my life changed when I began tracking what I ate and how I felt, eventually leading me to cut gluten and dairy out of my diet. Since then I have become immersed in the QS field, helping to co-organize numerous Quantified Self Meetups here in NY, experimenting with dozens of QS tools/apps, and hacking together numerous quantified self tools of my own and in groups with others. By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of the existing QS landscape, be aware of industries ripe for QS development, and be primed with some easy ways to hack together their own projects and tools.

title: Collaborative Mobile Design for International Development
description:
The world has nearly as many cell phone subscriptions as inhabitants, and 75% of them are in the developing world, with Africa leading the way. As the majority of mobile phone users live in emerging markets and developing economies, how do we design collaboratively with their needs, cultures and dreams in mind? How can mobile phone apps change informal economies and what goes into design considerations? How can we work together to improve billions of lives?

This session will look at the work of several innovative mobile-based solutions including Khan Academy, Carnegie Mellon’s Mobile and Immersive Learning program, and my own organization, Mobile Movement, which began as a project of Microsoft Research India and UN HABITAT.

During the workshop we will brainstorm together new apps and solutions. We will discuss the needs and challenges of designing for the “bottom billion” and how to work iteratively and collaboratively with the community. Participants in this session will also be invited to participate and present in a regular Google Hangout on Designing Mobile for Development.

title: Pop-up books and paper circuits
description: Pop-up engineering is really fun and extremely satisfying - for adults and for kids. But how might we use electricity to change the idea of what "interactive" books can be? In this session, participants will create pop-up cards that use the affordances of our materials to really investigate how circuits can change the idea of what a book can be. We'll also consider where soft circuits are going by looking at examples in toys and wearable technologies.

title: Introduction to Soft Circuits
description:
In this class, we will go over conductive materials used in creating soft circuits, such as different thread, fabrics, inks and fasteners, along with looking at microcontrollers designed specifically for wearable electronics. Projects that have been created utilizing these techniques will also be shown. We will then create a simple soft circuit with a switch and that lights up a LED. Attendees will have the chance to learn or expand on basic hand sewing techniques and experience working with new materials and skills.

*** If you are planning on attending tonight, please bring fabric scraps, LEDs (you just need one or two), and needle nose pliers if you have em!  I have supplies but may run out depending on how many folks show up.  Thanks! *****

title: Beat Making for Babies
description:
Beat Making for Babies is a fool proof introduction to making music with your computer. We'll cover the basics of how to make simple beats using Midi, crafting beats from original & found sounds, and the seeds of combining our beats with emerging technologies.

By the end of the session every Camper will have made their own original ringtone. And as a crew we'll create and jam on an interactive percussive instrument made from all our original sounds.

title: What the Glyph? Finding and Using Fonts for Your Projects
description: What's a font? What's a typeface? Why would you spend good money on buying a font when there are so many of them floating around for free? This introduction to using typefaces will walk you through some basic type definitions, where to buy typefaces, how to manage them on your OS, and how to access them using Adobe Illustrator, Indesign or Photoshop. Learn some of the principles behind selecting a typeface for a project or a logo. "People who love ideas must have a love of words, and that means, given a chance they will take a vivid interest in the clothes which words wear." —Beatrice Warde Slides from the lecture are here: typography-presentation (PDF)

title: ITP Mappathon: Content Making for Projection Mapping
description: Step 1 This week, we will learn how to make visual content using Modul8. We will use a png, a jpg and a movie files to make a moving image using Modul8. This method is a great tool to camp your idea. Next week, we will learn how to connect your content to mapping software, MadMapper. ------------------------------------------------------------------- Projection mapping is an amazing technique for manipulating video to create illusions of deconstruction and redefinition of physical shapes by moving away from traditional flat projection surfaces. This serves as a comprehensive introduction to methods for creating projection mapping. The tools used in the workshop are MadMapper and Modul8. The students will get fully-functional 30-day trial versions of the software to create a collaborative projection mapping installation for the end of ITP Summer Camp. This workshop is intended for the students who want to learn how to develop projection mapping projects for future events, art installations, and performances.

title: ITP Mappathon: Projection Mapping with MadMapper
description: Step 2 This week, we will learn how to connect your visual content created from Modul8 to a projection mapping software, MadMapper. Last week of ITP Mappathon, we will learn how to connect other software like processing, jitter and Openframworks to MadMapper. This will allowed you to make an interactive projection mapping installation. ——————————————————————- Projection mapping is an amazing technique for manipulating video to create illusions of deconstruction and redefinition of physical shapes by moving away from traditional flat projection surfaces. This serves as a comprehensive introduction to methods for creating projection mapping. The tools used in the workshop are MadMapper and Modul8. The students will get fully-functional 30-day trial versions of the software to create a collaborative projection mapping installation for the end of ITP Summer Camp. This workshop is intended for the students who want to learn how to develop projection mapping projects for future events, art installations, and performances.

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple's native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the "Hello World" stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We'll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time. Workshop attendees will receive a free copy of my O'Reilly book, Learning iOS Programming (3rd ed), or at least until supplies of books run out. Note: While this workshop assumes no previous knowledge of Objective-C, some coding knowledge is assumed. Additionally attendees should already be members of the iOS Developer Program, and have access to Apple's provisioning portal before attending the class. If anyone needs any help with signing up to the program, I'll be around ITP all from the start of the camp and I'm happy to help. Attendees should bring a Mac, with the latest version of Xcode installed, and an iOS device of some kind (an iPhone, iPad or iPod touch) along with a cable to connect the two.

title: iOS and Serial Hardware
description: A workshop on how to use the Redpark Serial Cable for iOS to talk to an Arduino, or any other bit of external hardware that talks RS-232 or TTL serial. This workshop is for people that already have a little bit of experience with iOS (and Arduino). We'll start off with the classic hardware "Hello World" project to blink an LED connected to to an Arduino, but this time we'll do it from your iPhone. Workshop attendees will receive a free copy of my O’Reilly book, iOS Sensor Apps and Arduino, or at least until supplies of books run out. Note: This workshop assumes some knowledge of Objective-C, although attendance at the iOS Boot Camp the previous week might well be enough background, and a working iOS development environment that will let you deploy code onto your iOS device. Attendees should bring a Mac, with the latest version of Xcode installed, and an iOS device of some kind (an iPhone, iPad or iPod touch) and a cable to connect them. You'll also need a Redpark Cable, some jumper wires, an Arduino board and an LED or two. A limited number of Redpark cables will be available to purchase at the start of the workshop if you haven't already picked one up beforehand.

title: Connect iOS & Arduino with Bluetooth LE
description: This is a one hour crash course on how to get your iPhone (or iPad, or iPad touch) to talk to your Arduino using the new Bluetooth Low Energy (aka the Bluetooth 4.0) standard. I'll look at the various hardware options, and do a "show and tell" with some of the available hardware that I'll bring along for attendees to look over. I'll finish off with a live coding demo that'll walk people through the basics of sending data to and from an Arduino with the classic hardware "Hello World" project; I'll blink an LED on and off, but this time I'll do it from my iPhone over Bluetooth LE.

title: Introduction to Distributed Sensor Networks
description:
Sensors are the future of distributed data. General-purpose computing is dissipating and becoming increasingly embedded into our lives. We will soon begin to move in a sea of data, our movements monitored and our environments measured and adjusted to our preferences, without need for direct intervention. What will this look like? How can we create and shape it? This is a basic hands-on introduction to using Arduino, XBee and off-the-shelf parts to build a small distributed sensor network. You'll be walked through the entire process, from prototyping a simple sensor node to performing real-time analysis on data captured by a deployed multi-sensor network. Note: A limited amount of background with the Arduino platform is assumed, but not that much beyond blinking an LED and talking to the serial port. If you're confident you can probably pick it up as you go along. However it would be helpful if you could come along with the Arduino IDE already installed and working on your laptop. Note: We intend to demo an many-to-point (or star) network of bread-boarded sensors motes using Arduino and XBee. We'll talk you through building the hardware and the software. If you want to follow along as we build them and replicate what we're doing you'll need to bring your own hardware. We can't possibly bring enough for everyone. What you need to bring If you want to fully participate you'll need to bring along;
  • 2 × XBee Series 1 radio
  • 2 × XBee Adaptor Kit, plus 1 × FTDI cable, or 1 × XBee Adaptor Kit plus 1 × another type of XBee adaptor
  • An Arduino Board
  • A Solderless Breadboard
  • Some sort of analog sensor, e.g. for temperature and humidity.
You'll also need the follow items,
  • A bundle of Jumper Wire
  • Some resistors and some LEDs
but you can probably scavenge these from around the floor here at ITP. What will be provided Workshop attendees will receive a free copy of my O’Reilly book, Distributed Network Data, or at least until supplies of books run out.

title: Now What?! How to turn your prototype into a product
description: When individuals and companies want to bring their product to the market, they run into hurdles like how to source materials, how to access a group of people who will buy it, and how to do it in a way that it doesn’t eat up all their savings and free time. This session is a crash course in the commercialization arc that includes product development, validation, and commercial ramp up.  Issues that arise in these post-prototype stages are important design insights that will make your product idea stronger. We’ll get into practical examples of how to connect with funding sources, user communities, and manufacturers while sharing resources that’ll be ready and waiting once camp is over.

title: Introduction to Rhino
description: Thank you for signing up, I'm looking forward to meeting you all. PLEASE BRING the following items tomorrow: a) Your computer with Rhino 5.0 installed. If you’re using a mac, download Rhino free at this website http://mac.rhino3d.com/content/DownloadWIP5.aspx. If you’re using a PC, download a trial version of Rhino for free at this website http://www.rhino3d.com/download/rhino/5.0/evaluation. b) A mouse with TWO buttons and a SCROLL. Some people last year brought their mac mice without these thinking it would be fine and they could not keep up, because there are basic things you can’t do in Rhino without TWO buttons and a SCROLL. So if you don’t have one, please buy one (it costs like $5) or you can borrow one from the ITP tech people. See you all tomorrow!! ____ Here is a link to the dropbox files we will be using in class, please download all the files. https://www.dropbox.com/sh/hwz660igvu0xg9m/MgTAGsqjGH Here is the one of the tutorial we will be doing in class: http://4.rhino3d.com/4/help/getting_started/Flashlight_014.htm ____ Here is a list of tutorials for Rhino that I assign to my students during the semester. Personally, I think video tutorials are the most effective way to build 3D modeling skills. If you’re serious about learning Rhino, going through these after this workshop would be the best way to go.  Also, you can check out videos tutorials I made for my class Sculpting Data into Everyday Objects. These tutorials were designed specifically for the class so are less for beginners, but still may be of interest. Thanks for attending and happy modeling! navigation tools http://wiki.mcneel.com/rhino/introductiontorhinointerface rhino interface tutorial http://vimeo.com/2838585 geometric continuity tutorial http://vimeo.com/2850159 three drinking glasses tutorial http://vimeo.com/15033291 Y-branch polysurface tutorial http://vimeo.com/3297459 surface creation tutorial and http://vimeo.com/16707257 plywood chair tutorial and post online http://rhinotuts.com/646/modeling-a-chair-from-reference-images/ modelling 3D textures tutorial http://vimeo.com/19501064 control point editing tutorial http://vimeo.com/4283768 flow objects along surface tutorial http://vimeo.com/3111916 arraying patterns http://vimeo.com/3289123 and post online modelling stereo headphones part 1 http://vimeo.com/30140235 modelling stereo headphones part 2 http://vimeo.com/30142419

title: Command-line Fu: How not to get eaten by a Grue
description: Are you afraid of the command line? Scared to type something wrong into your computer? Afraid of being eaten by a Grue? Well, pick up your torch and shovel and together we'll navigate the labyrinth known to those in the know, as the "Unix Filesystem". There is a fearsome tool at your disposal for casting spells of awesome power, loved and reviled the whole world over. Come learn why Geeks prefer text over GUI's, editors over IDE's, and 25 shell scripting recipes that will make you the envy of your friends as you fearlessly transmute data like Unix Wizards of Yore!

title: Teaching Physical Computing
description:
Do you teach physical computing?  Do you plan to teach it? Do you use it in your teaching?  Then this session is for you. There are plenty of people teaching using physical computing methods (electronics, microcontrollers, interaction design, fabrication) at many levels.  Let's all get together and trade tips and tricks.

Tom Igoe (that's me) will also talk about the origins of the physical computing class at ITP, and what we've learned about how to teach it along the way.

WARNING: No actual physical computing will take place during this session. It's all about the talk, this one.

title: Intro to PhoneGap and NFC
description:
So you already went to Sean Montgomery's session, "Hello PhoneGap" last week, or maybe you didn't.  But you know what HTML is, and you know a little JavaScript, and you're thinking, "Gee, I wish I could develop mobile apps that use Near Field Communication on Android!"  Yep, this session is for you.

Or, maybe you're wondering what the hell PhoneGap is.  It's a framework for developing mobile apps with HTML5 and JavaScript.  Now you're all set.

You don't know what Near Field Communication is?  It's like RFID on steroids. It's a way for devices to communicate short-range using radio identification.  It's neat, and you can do it on some Android phones, and you can do it using PhoneGap, and I'll show you how.  Come on along.

Oh yeah: my name is Tom Igoe. I'm writing a book on PhoneGap and NFC on Android with Don Coleman and Brian Jepson.

title: Guest Speaker: Clive Thompson - "the new literacies"
description: Clive will talk about "the new literacies" -- one of the chapters in his upcoming book. "Basically it's asking the question, what sorts of new modes of thinking are opened up by new tools for creation/expression/communication? I start off talking about the forms of thought that were made possible by things like writing, cheap paper, cheap functional pens ... then talk about the newer literacies emerging as new forms (video, 3D design, games) become as plastic and flexible as the written word became with writing tools. I'll open up nicely to asking people about what they're working on, because I'm super interested in the weird new types of ideas that occur to people as they begin using new tools to make stuff."   You can also follow him on Twitter https://twitter.com/pomeranian99 Some of his recent Wired columns http://www.wired.com/opinion/author/clivethompson/ New York Times Magazine Articles (subscription may be required) http://query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch/#/clive+thomson

title: 3D Printer Camp Group - Make One Now!
description:
Do you want to build your own 3D Printer? I'm adding this group gathering to the first day of camp to gauge interest in how many people would be interested in getting together to source parts, order and build their own Open Hardware 3D printer over the course of camp.  I have built a couple of printers (Makerbot Cupcake CNC, Rep Rap Prusa Mendel i2) and the process has gotten mainstream enough that one can be built with moderate-level of technical skills (it is a great way to learn).  I've also recruited a fellow camper, Fred Kahl (AKA The Great Fredini), to help me. Together we have 5 printers (of various working states - Fred: Printrbot, Rostock and Replicator) between us.  Fred is active in the 3D Printing community and has recently started his new venture, the Coney Island Scan-O-Rama! UPDATE (06.06.2013): I sent an email out a couple of days ago, but ITP camp has been flooded with emails and ti may have been lost in the shuffle.   I reposting the message here so people can use this as a reference.  I think we have narrowed the printer versions down to either a Rep Rap Wallace or a PrintrBot LC.  The PrintrBot is a strong viable candidate because it is mostly laser cut parts.  This will save us a ton of time and possibly ease the build time and level of accessibility for beginners.  The printer kit retails for $650, but we will be taking the Open Source plans and source our parts out through different vendors to cut the costs down to the target of $300-400.  Based upon my initial estimates and number of interested participants, I think we can get this closer to the $300 range.  Stay tuned.  Things will start to happen fast. The email sent June 4th around 8:30pm:
Thank you all for attending the 3D Printer group session yesterday. We had a lot of fun doing it. The primary goal of the meeting was to generate interest in 3D Printers and techniques. We also wanted to determine who would be interested in building one during camp. We intentionally held the session on the first day to get as much lead time as possible to get a head count and source parts for "the big build." We have been busy today trading emails about Open Source/hardware options (narrowed down to Wallace or Printrbot) and connecting with the larger 3d printer community outside on how to do a large build. We have also been working with the camp staff to see how best to purchase and source parts for a large group (i.e., purchasing it all at once and collecting funds from interested parties). Stay tuned. Once we work out these details this initiative will move fast. Ideally we can do a "big build" with enough time to tune and use it for your final project. 
 
Please fill out the following survey so we can get a more accurate count of who is interested. Any feedback about the session would be appreciated.
 
SURVEY
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1w9AdDxKuypSWTll0GEaFML39orT3ilwWy_Wi5H6-f8o/viewform
 
We'll be publishing Matt's slides for you shortly. Matt is going to create a PDF of the document with hyperlinks to the video.
 
Wallace printer (printed parts)
http://reprap.org/wiki/Wallace
 
Printrbot (more laser cut parts)
http://reprap.org/wiki/Printrbot
Thank you,
-Dan, Fred & Matt
UPDATE (05/29/2013): Time changed to 8:30pm-9:30pm. A bunch of kickoff & intro events have been added to the calendar. To avoid any conflicts, we've moved this event a little later. Sorry about the confusion. Based upon the feedback, we'll add a followup meeting to continue the conversation. UPDATE (05/13/2013): We have added guest speaker Matt Griffin!  He'll talk for 30 minutes about the latest developments in 3D Printing revealed in the latest Makerfaire in San Francisco (May 18-19th), and present excerpts from his recent talk at the "Inside 3D Printing" conference and expo. http://www.adafruit.com/blog/2013/04/18/matt-griffin-to-speak-at-inside-3d-printing-on-monday-april-22nd-3dthursday/ As a group, building it together it will be easier, less expensive and more fun than doing it alone. This initial meeting will provide an intro to 3D Printing, the technology and uses and then get down to the process of figuring out how we are going to build our own printer that you can take home at the end of camp.  Along the way, we also hope to bring in speakers and talk about the community, techniques for modeling and scanning things, and the future of 3D Printing. Based upon my last build I estimate that the the costs of the parts, if we purchasing in bulk and are resourceful, could fall in the $300-400 range*. I also estimate that the total build time would be between 15-20 hours**. Major parts:
  • Power supply (1)
  • Controller board (1)
  • Stepper controllers (4)
  • Stepper motors (5)
  • Smooth & threaded rods
  • Extruder (1)
  • Washers, nuts & bolts
  • Bearings (linear and regular)
  • 3D Printed parts (what came first the 3D Printer or the 3D Printer?)
  • Plastic filament
Let us know in the comments section if you are interested. If we have a ballpark number, we will have a better estimate of the costs and what parts we may need to possibly pre-order to maximize our time. Other volunteers and expertise welcome! * Always budget for a little more for unintended circumstances. ** Not including configuration and tune-ups

title: Introduction to User Experience (UX)
description:
What is User Experience? User Experience (UX) affects almost everything you interact with on a daily basis.  It is a philosophy, a skill, a technique and a way of thinking about human and computer interfaces, the challenges it creates and how to solve them in an simple, intuitive and elegant manner.  Done well, UX can be almost transparent to the end user.  Done poorly, the results can be frustrating and even disastrous. UX is an evolving field with many facets.  As new technologies and media arise, so do the challenges and obstacles they create.  Specialties within UX attempt to address those needs from various angles: usability, prototyping, sketching, brainstorming, wireframing, testing, specifying, etc... Join me and we will go through the evolution and growth of the field of UX from the beginning to where we are today. Here is a rough outline of what will be covered today:
  • Introduction (5 min)
  • What is User Experience? (10 minutes)
  • Past work/experience/examples (15 minutes)
  • User Experience as a career - UX/IA/IxD/CS (10 minutes)
  • Tools & Techniques Overview - (15 minutes)
  • Q&A (5-10 minutes)
  • >>Followup session - UX Brainstorm led by Jody (30 minutes)
UPDATE: 06.05.2013 Wow!  So far we have ~44 people signed up! We are going to need a bigger boat. I've added a special guest to todays session.  Jody Hankinson, Associate Creative Director from, R/GA!  I've been talking about UX at ITP Camp the last few years so I thought it would be nice to bring in another UX practitioner from a separate digital agency to give some added perspective about this rapidly growing field.   I want to keep the intro to UX session to the original 1 hour time slot, but I've added an optional followup session immediately afterwards to go through a UX brainstorming exercise led by Jody.  About Dan Kawasaki:
I've been practicing User Experience for over 15 years.  This will be my fourth year presenting various UX ideas and techniques at ITP Camp.  Each year there is something  new and exciting to present.  This year, changes within the industry has accelerated to exciting new levels with the emergence of new platforms such as Google Glass, the rise of Responsive Web Design and the continued growth of Mobile devices and social networks. Who knows what will come next?  UX will always be there in some capacity. I am the Director of User Experience at Ogilvy in New York City.
About Jody Hankinson
A senior usability, IxD practioner with almost 15 years of experience. Practice includes design research (both qualitative and quantitative), content strategy, and product strategy and management. Cross industry experience, including pharmaceuticals, financial services, retail, non-profit and telecommunications.

title: UX Skill - Responsive Design Process
description: Do you create UX documents in Omnigraffle, Visio, InDesign, Axure or Illustrator?  Does the design team still create Photoshop PSD files to hand off to the developer?  That no longer works in the responsive design world we live in. You simply cannot get away with targeting specific devices for your designs anymore.  Responsive web design has changed a good portion of how we should approach web design for desktop, tablets and mobile.  No longer can we just make sketches/wireframes for different fixed screen sizes and hand off the resulting Photoshop PSD files to developers.  There are too many subtle nuances that can add up to a poor user experience.  As the number of screen sizes, pixel densities and device dimensions grows, the thought process must also change to accommodate the display of the content must also change to address the immediate and future needs. This session will go over the latest techniques on how to deal with responsive design.  The second half will be a workshop to show how to use one of the most popular HTML5 frameworks, Bootstrap*, to prototype and serve as the foundation for your next project. Things are moving incredibly fast in this space.  By the time of this lecture/workshop, I'll probably have 2 or 3 other tools and techniques to share. If you want to help out or have other topics to add, please let me know in the comments. * Bootstrap for now, but it may change as new tools come to market. UPDATE 06.15.2013 I would like to thank everyone who came to the Responsive Design Process session last night. Please feel free to email or grab me on the floor if you want to talk more about this. Following below are some links to the the articles, software, frameworks and web applications that were demonstrated last night. FRAMEWORKS and GUI Tools Boostrap http://twitter.github.io/bootstrap/ Jetstrap (bootstrap web IDE) http://jetstrap.com LayOutIt http://www.layoutit.com (different variation of bootstrap web IDE) Froont (nice new non-bootstrap drag and drop interface) http://froont.com Foundation (an alternative framework to boostrap) http://foundation.zurb.com ARTICLES The one that started it all. http://alistapart.com/article/responsive-web-design .NET Magazine http://www.netmagazine.com/features/new-responsive-design-process Stats from the slides http://karenmcgrane.com/2013/06/13/state-of-the-mobile-web-sources/ Other http://responsiveprocess.com http://responsivedesignweekly.com (weekly newsleter mangazine) SOFTWARE Proty (firefox plug-in - interesting) http://www.protytype.com Adobe Reflow http://html.adobe.com/edge/reflow/ More applications are popping up each day so watch this space... I've also added this to the session descripion page for future reference. Thank you, -Dan

title: Acrylic Cutting and Bending
description:
Learn a fast and easy way to prototype precision parts using the laser cutter.  And then literally take it in a new direction with the acrylic bender.  Quickly turn 2D parts into 3 dimensional objects.

Please bring project drawings (Adobe Illustrator) or concepts and a sheet of acrylic.

Local resource for acrylic: Home Depot on 23rd St, Canal Plastics (http://www.yelp.com/biz/canal-plastics-center-new-york)

title: Creating a Killer Finish
description:
We have two great tools in the shop for applying a fantastic finish to wooden and metal projects.

If you have a wooden object that you created on the CNC, laser, lathe, or built the old fashioned way you can add an amazing wax finish using a 3 part buffer.  It is a simple and quick technique that gives the object a glass like finish.

If you have a small metal object (has to be able to fit inside a toaster oven and withstand 400 degree temperatures) you can apply a powder coating.  You spray on the colored  powder you like and then bake it in an oven.  The finish is similar to a car's paint job in looks and durability.

title: Turning on the lathe
description: **YOU MUST HAVE HAD A SHOP SAFETY TRAINING IN ORDER TO TAKE THIS CLASS.  NO EXCEPTIONS.** Learn the basics of wood turning.  We'll get everyone up to speed and turning on the lathe by the end of the demo.

title: Project Enclosure Making
description:
Now that you're pretty far along on your PComp project, you want to put inside a slick looking enclosure.

We'll go over multiple techniques using just about every tool in the shop.

Please come with projects that need boxes.

title: 3D Scanning Workshop with the Kinect & ReconstructMe
description: We'll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models. I have built a rig for doing full body human scans. The rig builds on this turntable I built last year: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28454 We'll cover my scanning technique then a workflow for taking scans to a printable mesh using Netfabb Basic. I can also touch on some tricks with Meshlab if we need to combine meshes, remesh or reduce polygon count. Softwares we will work with: ReconstructMe http://reconstructme.net/ - this is a commercial software for PC only, but a trial is available. Mac users can install it under a bootcamp partition. Not recommended for parallels. Please also note that I am not going to help you with installing this software. The ReconstructMe support page http://reconstructme.net/faqs/ or Google Group is a great place for support: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/reconstructme Netfabb Basic- free download http://www.netfabb.com/download.php Meshlab- free download http://meshlab.sourceforge.net/

title: Midi, Sysex, and the Arduino. New tricks for an old dog.
description:
Of all the protocols used in the realm of physical computing only MIDI is designed to read gestures, take notes, play sequences, identify what equipment is available, set parameters, load code and make things happen in real time. Through sysex, the 20+ year old MIDI standard allows for arbitrary data to be sent between devices allowing for seamless debugging and out of band communication between devices.
In this session we will discus Midi technically (both traditional midi and usb midi) and how Midi System Exclusive messages work and should be used to to program and debug the arduino/wiring platform.
As working example I will use the current state of "Lets Get Loaded!" as discussed at http://www.suspectdevices.com/blahg/proposals/lets-get-loaded-a-midi-sysex-ecosystem-for-loading-and-debugging-code/ and which I am developing on the leaf-labs maple platform.

title: Really Big Video Part 1
description: This session will introduce Big Building Mapping and Video Projection. I will begin by showing examples of site-specific and video mapping pieces and then we will map a real building using a spatial scan in Mad Mapper. For homework each camper will get a scan to work from and some tips on how to create giant projections. Part 2 of the session will allow campers to showcase their mapped work projected 3 stories tall on an actual building on broadway. [caption id="attachment_2429" align="aligncenter" width="294"] Color Building by Louise Foo for Video Sculpture Class at ITP[/caption]

title: Really Big Video Part 2
description: In this session, campers will compile and project their work from the previous week onto a giant building on broadway using video mapping and one really big projector. Taught by Gabe BC [caption id="attachment_2429" align="aligncenter" width="294"] Color Building by Louise Foo for Video Sculpture Class at ITP[/caption]

title: C4 - Media, Interactivity & Audio for iOS
description:
C4 is a new API designed for interaction, creativity and expression that brings creative coding directly to mobile devices. Designed for iOS, C4 makes it extremely easy to create apps for iPad, iPhone and iPod devices. Initially developed as a platform for quickly creating interactive artistic works, C4 is developing into a more broad-based language for other areas such as music and data visualization. In this workshop, participants will have the opportunity to learn how to easily create dynamic animations, and all kinds of media including audio, video, shapes, OpenGL objects and more. In addition to this, participants will learn how to easily add the full suite of iOS gestural interaction to their applications and objects. There’s already a TON of stuff you can do with C4. This workshop is going to blitz through the API giving you a good overview of its capabilities so that you can start to envision projects, concepts and artworks through C4. After this workshop you’ll have the chops to dig into the API, navigate our site’s 215 code examples and 30 in-depth tutorials, ask questions on the C4 / StackOverflow forum and grab code from the various GitHub accounts. http://www.c4ios.com ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Things you need: If you want to be building iOS apps you should bring a Mac with the latest version of Xcode installed. The following configurations are okay:
  • OSX 10.8 with Xcode 4.6 (preferred)
  • OSX 10.7 with Xcode 4.5.2
Things you may want: If you want to build your projects to an actual iOS device that you have, then you need to get yourself an iOS Developer membership. You can also bring a device (iPod, iPad, iPhone, etc.) and we'll get you running. Things you don't need: You don't need a lot of programming knowledge, C4 has been designed to be pretty easy and we'll have you building apps in a snap. If you've got a bit of programming experience with other creative-coding APIs like Processing and OpenFrameworks then you'll find the C4 syntax is quite similar. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Dates: June 10, 11, 12 Time: 7pm - 10pm Structure: All sessions will be structured the same way. 7:00 - 7:15 Intro to the day’s content. 7:15 - 8:30 Code, Scramble, Learn. 8:30 - 8:45 Break. 8:45 - 20:00 Discussing essential concepts in C4. Participants should ask lots of tough questions, always, and at any point in the session or after or before. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Sessions: June 10 - Introduction - Building Dynamic Animations In this session, we’ll work through building complex effects made out of simple embedded animations and shapes. This will cover concepts such as building basic apps, classes and properties. June 11 - Embedding Media in Apps & C4PD In this session, we’re going to construct a media player that you can pull into pieces. This will cover media, interactivity and gestures. We’ll also introduce C4PD a wicked way of creating dynamic audio apps using C4 as the interface for Pure Data projects. June 12  - Advanced Topics - Q&A There are some pretty sophisticated things that come cooked into all objects in C4. We’re going to introduce the concept of notifications and communication between objects. We’ll also cover topics like embedding OpenGL in your apps as well as using multiple canvases to create full-blown apps. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Audience: If you’re interested in getting into creative exploration of mobile devices as an expressive medium you want to join this workshop. Within the first few minutes of each session you’ll be building your own apps for iOS. We’ll tailor the content to beginner / medium-level programming and just go from there. If the audience wants a different pace we’ll kick it up a notch. Like Emeril. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Instructors: Travis Kirton, Adam Tindale, Greg Debicki Bios: Travis Kirton is an artist specializing in the production of performance, tangible, and interactive media. He holds a BSc Interaction Design and MA Interface Culture. Recently, he was an instructor and artist in residence at the Alberta College of Art + Design as well as an Information Visualization Researcher in the Innovis Lab at the University of Calgary. Travis is the creator of C4 and partner at Slant Design. http://postfl.com Adam Tindale is an electronic drummer and digital instrument designer. He is an Associate Professor of Human-Computer Interaction in the Digital Futures Initiative at OCAD University. Adam performs on his E-Drumset: a new electronic instrument that utilizes physical modeling and machine learning with an intuitive physical interface. He completed a Bachelor of Music at Queen's University, a Masters of Music Technology at McGill University, and an Interdisciplinary Ph.D. in Music, Computer Science and Electrical Engineering at the University of Victoria. http://www.adamtindale.com/ Greg Debicki is a composer and new media artist based in Montréal. He completed a BFA from Alberta College of Art and Design and studied music composition at the Dartington College of Arts, UK.  He writes generative music software, designs interactive projections and composes glitch music. Currently he is working with writer and theatre artist Kathleen Brown on investigating the intersection of poetry and sound through glitch and performance. http://www.gregdebicki.tumblr.com/

title: Harvesting Defecͫ̑̑ͫͦ͗̔͆͂̍͌͗͌ͦ̈̑̔̐̔͢͢t̔s; in A̵̡bleton Live.
description:
Thinking of destruction and glitch as a creative method, this workshop explores subversive methods of sound design and composition in Ableton Live.  A variety of techniques will be demonstrated and discussed. All levels of user are invited to join.

Ableton, like any tool, has a specific way that it is meant to be used, which has limitations.  The “correct” way of doing things can lead to writers block, or simply rehashing old ideas over and over again. By looking at ways of breaking elements of the software it is possible to find new ways of composing and new ways of creating and manipulating sounds. Breaking things (or, glitch), introduces randomness into the process.  While randomness does not always create favorable results, the results can often be fixed up to create something that couldn’t have been thought of otherwise.  There are also numerous ways of subverting the intended working methods that do create interesting sounds on their own.

The workshop will be divided into two segments over the course of two hours.  The first segmenͥ͐̑ͨt̵̏ ̨ͮw̿ǐͯͧͤ̿l̡̊ͨ̒lͣ̽̒̋ͤ̌̚͠ be structured as a lecture covering specific techniques and in the second segment we will experiment together to find new tricks and methods.

 

First segment

Resampling

  • stretching/granulating
  • cut ups
  • resonance/physical modeling
  • alternative vocoder uses

Effects

  • beat repeat racks
  • multi-effect switches/combinations
  • gating
  • alternative sidechaining
  • distortion/downsampling/etc

Glitch

  • recording while saving
  • recording while skipping
  • reverb room size
  Second Segment
  • Developing new methods
  • Free time / one-on-one
  • General discussion
  Date: June 14th - 5:00pm to 7:00pm Bio: Greg Debicki is a composer and new media artist based in Montréal. He completed a BFA from Alberta College of Art and Design and studied music composition at the Dartington College of Arts, UK.  He writes generative music software, designs interactive projections and composes glitch music. Currently he is working with Derek Demassi on a project called Swimming with Pask; a digital media performance/installation that uses software and technology to give bioluminescent algae creative agency allowing it to perform audio/visual collaborative improvisations with their breath. He is also working with writer and theatre artist Kathleen Brown on investigating the intersection of poetry and sound through glitch and performance. They have been creating work that pushes glitch (a mixed media and music form and movement) into language and sound work. Greg produces music as Woulg. In November 2012 he performed at the Soundasaurus Festival with Matmos at the Epcor Center for Performing Arts in Calgary. Woulg’s albums include Tussed and Floating Longingly Toward the Sun with Outlier Recordings; and Hinchcliff Shuffle with Enig’matik. gregdebicki.tumblr.com

title: Intro to Second Life (workshop session 1 of 2)
description:
Come with your avatar + preferably a headset  +  mouse - not vital but makes communication eassier.  (I will send instructions to anyone interested). I will also have a few 'loaner avatars' available. We will spend 1.5 hours getting the hang of moving, communicating, buying, and organizing your stuff. Add on some coordinate system basics. No prior 3D experience necessary.

You need a laptop with Second Life (http://secondlife.com/support/downloads/?lang=en-US) installed prior to the workshop. Then choose an avatar type (you can edit that later) + a user name (you cannot edit that later). Your first avatar in Second Life is free. I will have some LindenDollars for you to spend inworld.

We will meet on  NYU island in Second Life: click link to teleport to meet at our virtual ITP CAMP FIRE

http://slurl.com/secondlife/New%20York%20University/219/208/21

Check the next session from 6-8 for Second Life building + sculpting.

My SL  background: I started in SL in 2006 + have since then used it for my art and in my NYU classes, many workshops among them.

title: Building + sculpting in Second Life (workshop session 2 of 2)
description:
You know the SL basics or just attended the 4pm session.

If you need to download SL check description on 4pm session

We will use the simple real-time  3D  building tools and add complexity with physical properties, textures, alpha channels and simple scripts. We will use Photoshop to make textures to import and apply to SL objects. To save time, all will receive a 'gift box' with starter items and workshop elements.
Your fantasy is the limit.

You need a laptop with Second Life (secondlife.com) installed prior to the workshop. A mouse + headset are helpful but not vital.

We will meet on NYU island in Second Life: click link to teleport to meet at our virtual ITP CAMP FIRE
http://slurl.com/secondlife/New%20York%20University/219/208/21

My SL  background: I started in SL in 2006 + have since then used it for my art and in my NYU classes, many workshops among them.

title: Blender for the 3D Maker
description:
UPDATE: Blender wins! (With OpenSCAD a close second.)

We will be focusing on Blender, though the skills explored would be useful for a variety of tools. Depending on how things go, I will do a second session with OpenSCAD later in the camp. The good news for Rhino fans is that someone else is already going to give a Rhino dedicated session!

This workshop will get you from "zero to plastic" for Blender 2.67b, showing you how Blender fits into your designing/making pipeline (along with other tools to get these files to your 3D printer) and will highlight a number of the new 3D printing tools recently launched: the 3D Printing Toolbox, 3D Ruler/Protractor, and real-time Mesh Analysis in particular.
Based on a simple show of hands during the Monday 3D Printer Camp session, we chose (updated!) to tackle one of these three easily obtainable 3D design apps. Kicking off with the spine of a "zero to plastic with Blender" Adafruit Learning System tutorial, the workshop will focus on arming those who attend with all they need know to start with a PCB, an electronic component, a sensor, or other project element, and explore a few ways to get pertinent measurements into the digital domain for the construction of 3D printable cases, enclosures, and sculptural cavities.

Pre-Session Prep

Show up with a laptop, a 3-button external mouse, and the software installed. (Because really, is it exciting learning how to install software or more exciting to use it?) Completing the basic tutorials will help you get more out of the session, but not required.
  • Blender: http://www.blender.org/download/get-blender/

And also check out these apps!

  • OpenSCAD: http://www.openscad.org -- bug Matt if you really want this as well!
  • Rhino: http://www.rhino3d.com/download (There's another Rhino session in this year's camp!)
About Matt Griffin
Matthew Griffin is Director of Community Support & Evangelism at Adafruit Industries. Griffin is currently writing a book for MAKE titled Design & Modeling for 3D Printing (Sept 2013) and is a contributor to Make on topics of 3D printing, including the Make:34 Skill Builder — Finishing and Post-Processing Your 3D Printed Objects and the Make: Ultimate Guide to 3D Printing.

title: PCBs - Make them yourself!
description: Learn to Make Your Own Printed Circuit Board   Making your own printed circuit board ensures that your projects are set in stone (or in this case, copper).   Now that you've been introduced to building circuits on breadboards, etching your circuit in copper means you'll have a clean, slick looking circuit that can't get shorted because parts move or touch.  In this workshop I'll take you through step by step what the PCB community calls the "heat transfer method" of printing your own circuit board.   Just in time for summer, we'll be making a mosquito repeller circuit, that I've prepared.  If you've ever taken a darkroom photography class, or dabbled in crafts, you'll catch on quick.  I'll be providing the EAGLE files necessary to complete our PCB, however if you want to learn the software side to this hands-on process, I'll also teach you that in the EAGLE session Wednesday June 26th.

title: EAGLE PCB Design Software - Intro Session
description: In this session we will be learning the Design Software EAGLE, a CAD program used by industry standards to make Printed Circuit Boards.  We'll start by familiarize ourselves with reading simple schematics and component Data Sheets.  By the end of the class, we'll be producing a simple schematic and design layout that can be made into your very own Printed Circuit Board.  A free version of the software is accessible for download online:  http://www.cadsoftusa.com/

title: Introduction to the Arduino Yún
description: So you want to network your microcontroller. These days, you've got a lot of options. Here's the latest from Arduino, the Yún. This board has the heart of an Arduino Leonardo attached to a WiFi-equipped Linux processor. The Yún (which means cloud in Chinese) was developed this new board in conjunction with Hong Kong electronics manufacturer Dog Hunter, and is designed to give you the simplicity of Arduino, combined with the power of  WiFi and the OpenWRT Linux distribution. The Yún isn't due for release until later in June, but in this session, I'll give you a sneak peek at the Yún and show you what it's capable of. Most Arduino users are familiar with how to connect an Arduino to another computer via the Serial port, and the Yún builds on that mental model, using a new library called Bridge. Bridge lets you reach the command line interface of the Yún's linux processor over a serial interface. It features a few extra commands that allow you to start and run linux Processes from the Arduino environment as well. If you're already familiar with Arduino, you'll be very comfortable in this session. Brand new Arduino users may want to take a simpler session first. -Tom Igoe

title: Designing for Creator Communities
description: As an ad hoc community of makers ITP accelerates social creativity and exploration, but how can you sustain and scale creative social communities when you don’t have the benefit of physical proximity? So.cl is a creator network experiment by FUSE labs that provides tools to create, share and browse a range of media like memes, collages, and animated gifs  within people’s existing and new social networks. We’ll give a quick overview of So.cl, and the emerging creative tool app ecosystem built on top of it. We’ll conclude by breaking into groups for micro brainstorms to dream up the creative tools you’d like to have when you leave ITP camp. We’ll close the session with 2 minute lightening presentations by each of the groups.

title: Film Cutting, Knot Tying, and The Ethics of Storytelling
description:
In this participatory lecture, we will discuss the ethics behind story telling in interactive/immersive documentary, while cutting film and learning how to tie knots.

Given the hardwired linear context of film…the making of context by the viewer, we ask…

"What is true and what is real?" all the while tying knots and cutting film, kinesthetically sorting where these ideas cut and cross

 

Let's think out loud.

title: ITP Thesis Spotlight
description:
Join us for a spotlight on 4 ITP 2013 Thesis Projects!

 

Josh Begley

Dronestre.am: a publicly-accessible API for real-time and historical data about United States drone strikes. The Dronestream API is a simple way of engaging an eleven-year historical archive -- helping visualize the entire history of known US drone attacks in Pakistan, Yemen, and Somalia. Built as a tool for researchers, legal scholars, and web developers, the API takes data that has already been collected by The Bureau of Investigative Journalism and makes it machine-readable. Whether you want to download everything as a spreadsheet or write a web application that pulls in real-time information, Dronestream allows you to dig into a largely hidden data set and display the contours of covert war for yourself.  

Christie Leece

Superfund Salvage is a research investigation into the possibilities for remediation and reuse of toxic soils. I used mushrooms to mine heavy metals from Brooklyn's Gowanus Canal and transformed them into ceramic glazes. Through research and experiments growing mushrooms, extracting metals and processing soil and creating ceramics, I have been exploring alternative and more productive ways we can address toxic sites.  

Phil Groman

Stringwire is a tool to crowdsource and manage multiple live video feeds from eye witnesses in reporting breaking news.  

Allison Eve Zell CANCELLE DUE TO FAMILY EMERGENCY

WHO BOOTH is a repurposed photo booth that maps girls' aspirations today to inspirational women throughout history, in a digital merge experience.

title: Aerial Photography of Fresh Kills Landfill
description: Fresh Kills is one of the most infamous landfills in the United States containing all of New York city's waste for over 50 years.  Visible from space and as large as the Great Wall of China, Fresh Kills is a New York secret located in Staten Island and currently being converted into a public park over the next thirty years.  Join us for a field trip to this epic landscape to discover the final resting place of our trash and experiment with aerial photography using kites and large helium balloons.  WIth these grassroots mapping techniques, we can begin to develop a high resolution map of the landfill, investigate vegetation growth and begin to better understand what happens to the things we throw away. Because Fresh Kills is not currently open to the public, we are being given special permission from the New York City Parks Department and the New York City Department of Sanitation to access and tour the site.  We will be departing Manhattan via the Staten Island Ferry and will travel the rest of the way in a Parks Department vehicle.  This will be an all day outside event so please dress accordingly and bring food and water.  To attend this event please RSVP no later than June 15th. The adventure will take place on Saturday, June 22nd. Grassroots Mapping is part of the Public Laboratory for Open Technology and Science, founded by a group of activists, educators, technologists, and community organizers interested in new ways to promote action, intervention, and awareness through a participatory research model.  The tools and techniques developed by the Public Laboratory are being implemented internationally and were highlighted for its success during the BP oil spill in 2008.  For more information visit publiclab.org.

title: Hello Laser cutter!
description: Hello World for the Laser Cutter!

title: Hello Neighborhood!
description: What's around ITP? What do I eat? What can I do around the Floor?

title: Who's your data? : A guide to Social Network mapping for fun, self knowledge and community building in the digital age.
description: Gephi is a powerful social network modelling tool. It also has the great advantage of simplicity: there is no need of any special skills to use it, except curiosity! You don't need to know how to implement a "force directed graph algorithm" to select it from a drop down menu to see clusters of your friends. ;) Last year I happened upon this awesome tool, and it changed the way I socialize. Come learn the insights to be gleaned from your own data,  the pitfalls, and discuss the ramifications of what it means to be networked in the digital age.

title: Networking with the Raspberry Pi + Node.js
description: Ever wanted to run your own wireless BBS broadcasting from your house or local café? Or create a network in places that usually have no connectivity (for example, the subway station)? This session will show you how to potentially do that by setting up a Raspberry Pi as a web server and wireless access point. We will cover how to create a local area network with a captive portal for directing users to your web app. If time permits, we will also discuss mesh networking and how to configure the Raspberry Pi as a mesh node. This will be a hands-on workshop where we will do the following: - Configure the Raspberry Pi with a wireless adapter as an Access Point - Configure a web server running Node.js - Create a simple chat application with Node - Create a startup script that automatically boots up your network and node app on power up Required supplies - Bring your laptop (with an ethernet port!) and an ethernet cable - Raspberry Pi Model B with 4GB SD card, RALink RT5370 chipset wifi dongle (bring two of these if you can!), and a 700 mA 5V microusb power supply. Links for purchasing supplies - Raspberry Pi Model B - 4GB SD card - USB Wireless Adapter - Battery Charger - Wall Plug Charger

title: Hello Arduino!
description: Learn the first steps to getting started with the Arduino microcontroller.

title: Hello Arduino!
description: Learn the first steps to getting started with the Arduino microcontroller.

title: Creative Coding with Processing
description: This workshop will give you an introduction to the basic principles of creative coding with Processing. Processing is an open-source coding platform used by designers and developers to create interactive installations, data visualizations, software tools, and much much more. In this workshop we'll go over some programming fundamentals and then dive into code examples. We'll cover the basics of drawing shapes to the screen, animation, image processing, and video input. If there's time we can go over other topics specific to your own projects. Processing is free, and can be downloaded at the processing website: www.processing.org. Please come with the software installed on your computer. Code examples we went over in class are hosted on github: https://github.com/veev/CreativeCodingIntro Useful links for tutorials and other Processing resources: www.learningprocessing.org Shiffman's Nature of Code videos on Vimeo Nature of Code Book website Processing category at CreativeApplications.net Jer Thorp's Dataviz Tutorial   Some links for inspiration: Unnamed Soundsculpture NYT and Jer Thorp's Cascade Aaron Koblin's Sheep Market

title: Dirt cheap solar power with BjornQorn
description: Come chat with Bjorn and Jamie as they try to explain how an artist/inventor and a musician from Minnesota's Scandinavian corn country stumbled onto the cheapest way to build solar mirrors on the planet. Armed with thousands of watts of low cost solar power, the two launched the first solar popcorn company this spring. We'll tell our story but we'll also try to wrap our brains around the modern scale of energy, featuring a lump of coal, thermocouple calorimeter and hopefully some kind of minor explosions. We promise you'll leave the evening ready to scoff at articles that mix up kilowatts and kilowatt-hours.

title: Face It
description: In this short workshop, we will examine the human face. We'll look at the differences between face detection and face recognition as well as demonstrate examples that track the contours of the face. In addition, we'll look at some image processing techniques for face morphing. Examples will be demonstrated in Processing.

title: Wearable and Mobile Accessories
description: Kate Hartman and Shawn Van Every will give a tour through some of the recent wireless and wearable platforms and products that are emerging and give a workshop on how we might prototype some ideas of our own. Here are some notes: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bSZ3wwtHB_5bjQp_Vr5KsQs5jY1ayvvtteN-cSKescA

title: Arduino 101
description:
Learn the very basics of how to program with the popular platform for physical computing projects. If you took the "Hello, Arduino" session on Monday night, this session will cover that information, but also delve deeper into the topics of digital input and output as well as analog input and output.

If you want to follow along, bring an Arduino UNO, a USB A-to-B cable, and a computer loaded up with the Arduino IDE. For some demos, we'll be using some Physical Computing supplies like buttons, breadboards, jumper wires, sensors and LEDs. If you have anything like this, please bring it. Otherwise, I will try to provide as much as I can round up on the floor.

title: Getting Started with Raspberry Pi
description: Learn the fundamentals of Raspberry Pi, the $35 learning computer and why people are so excited about it. This workshop will be a demo of the platform and a Raspberry Pi is not needed to participate.

title: Wearables Hack Day
description:
Do you sew? Do you play with microcontrollers? Then join us for ITP Camp wearables hack day!

Bring some clothing you'd like to hack and your arduinos and raspberry pi's (etc.) and lets make some wearable fashions!

You can work alone or in teams. We'll pick three themes for the day with which to base projects on. Feel free to suggest your own themes in the comments section. Themes can be anything, so be creative! We'll vote on them at the beginning of the event and then begin hacking based on those themes. Hope to see you there!

title: Your Community Initiatives around Tech
description: Come share what your communities are up to and let's learn from each other! Whether you're part of a collective creating workshops for kids, encouraging more women to get involved in tech or if you're part of a hacker space or fab lab in your area, organizing hackathons etc., let's find out whats going on globally and see how we can implement some cool ideas from different communities into our own! For those who are up for it, afterwards we can all go out to dinner or do something else fun and social. Bring your suggestions with!:)

title: Shop Safety!
Shop Safety!
Shop Safety!
Shop Safety!
Shop Safety!
Shop Safety!
Shop Safety!
Shop Safety!
Prototype to Performance, Will it survive onstage??
description:
So you just built this fancy "whatchamacallit" and it works perfectly on the bench, but what happens when you have to hand it off to someone else to be used in live performance, in the desert, on a mountain, in a forest or really anywhere else other than a nice neat controlled environment?  Build your device to be performance proof...

Come with some napkin sketches and we can hash through the parts of the physical design. Part lecture, part workshop. Who is your audience? Is your device 'exploratory' or needs to be run by a skilled operator? An engineer needs to stamp this... nah?? what??
