title: Disruptive design for future environments: Fashioning personal protection with smart fabrics
description: With seemingly fantastical talks of human colonization on Mars by Space X's Elon Musk to the inevitable infestation of drones, it is really NYC's own Mayor Bloomberg who says it best: "We're going into a different world, uncharted... you can't keep the tide from coming in."  But wait just a second Bloomberg, oh yes we can!  Come and join a talk and demonstration of disruptive design solutions for our not so distant future environments.  I will discuss a diverse spectrum of highly specialized fabrics and materials that are currently being used in applications from aerospace to counter-surveillance.  Take a look at fabrics that provide radiation protection, micrometeoroid  protection, thermal reflection, RF signal blocking and puncture resistance...just about everything you will need to fashion a wardrobe of personal armor that will protect us from galactic cosmic radiation on our journey to Mars, or from the expected 30,000 drones that will be floating about our skies.

title: Seeing Like a Network: Learning to think about digital security
description:
This is an interactive workshop in digital security focused on what's called "Threat Modeling" in the computer security world -- understanding how the networks you use see you, and how to realistically defend against the most likely attacks. We'll cover some security tools and techniques, but we'll focused making the networked environment legible enough to let you seek out tools and techniques suited to your situation.

We'll begin by looking at the networks we use everyday, how we relate to them, and how they are used by others. In the second part, we'll go over some real world examples of attacks, ranging from direct hacking, traffic analysis and implicit information, all the way to jurisdictional attacks such as subpoenas. Finally, if we have enough time, we'll play through red team/blue team scenarios based on real world situations. Bring pen and paper and be prepared to move around!

title: Friday Social Hour
description: Dumplings!

title: Intro to Makerbotting
description: Learn how to go from file to print. In this lightning session, you will learn how to calibrate a MakerBot, prepare a 3D file (STL) using MakerWare, and then print it on the machines. That's all there is to it!

title: Field trip to goveners island for the opening of Figment NYC 2013.
description: GIVEN THE RAIN I AM RESCHEDULING THIS TO SUNDAY....   I was invited to this event by a local artist and ITP Camp alumni friend of mine who will be working out there . I thought I would see if anyone was interested in making a field trip to the opening of this two day event. http://newyork.figmentproject.org/figment-nyc/

title: Github
description: What will the session cover? We can cover the general mechanics: basics of making an account, installing git on a machine, creating a repository, commiting files, branching, merging, and rolling back. ​This will be targeted to beginners of git. I probably can't answer complicated questions relate to rebasing/merge conflicts/edge cases. The session will provide enough experience for attendees to use Git and Github for their personal projects. Attendees should have some experience with the command line, but those without it are also welcome. Command line experience can be gained at the Command line-fu session. Attendees must bring their own computer. OSx systems are recommended, but Windows and Linux systems are also welcome! What is Github? Git is a fast, open source, distributed version control system that is quickly replacing subversion in open source and corporate programming communities. Github is a social network for the git repositories. Learn more here Who is teaching this? I am Lenny! I do front-end development and make WordPress themes. I use Git and Github on a daily basis for professional, personal, and public projects.

title: Fathers Day 3D Scanning Portrait Studio
description: Hey Dads! Bring your kids and get 3D portraits shot, so you can print them out yourself. After our classroom session on using ReconstructMe to scan and clean up models for 3D Printing, we'll set up my invention the Scan-o-tron 3000 and do 3D portraits of anyone who is interested. Here's a sample of scans I've done at other events: http://www.thingiverse.com/fredini/collections/coney-island-scan-a-rama

title: Intro to UX Workshop - UX Brainstorming with Jody Hankinson
description: Time for some fun!  Turn off your laptop, put down your phone and tablets and lets get more interactive.  This is the followup the Introduction to UX session immediately prior to this session.  Jody Hankinson will be demonstrating an effective brainstorming technique.  Participants of the workshop will interact with each other and use pens and sticky notes.  Stick around immediately after the UX intro session and have some fun by applying this technique. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] Jody Hankinson[/caption]

title: 2D+3D Zoetropes
Experiment Design Workshop
description:
Designing a proper experiment is not a trivial task: and the questions to ask are dependent on your field of study.  In this workshop we will discuss the design of usability studies and scientific studies, and how to use science to get at the truth of the matter your interested in Parte Prima: An overview of Experimental Design
  • Usability Studies
  • Designs of experiments for Psychology and social sciences
  • Interviewing (ethnographic techniques)
  • Surveys and Questionnaires
Parte Due: Your problems - discussed
  • We will collaboratively attack your questions - whether it's how to understand home energy use, barcode scanner handgrips, or attention in driving, we'll get towards the bottom of it!
  About me: I'm a doctoral student at Stanford University, in the Department of Communication.  My major area of interest is behavior design--how products and interfaces can influence behavior and beliefs.  Right now I'm running a study on how automotive instrumentation can encourage or teach drivers to drive more efficiently (in a simulator study) and also working with a group on understanding the cognitive issues with automated driving (we've got brainwave measurement, eye tracking, skin conductance sensors, and a super whole car simulator!) Prior to starting my PhD, I received my master's degree from NYU in behavior design, running a large study where I instrumented a fleet of washing machines and used interface design to steer users towards using cold water (and thus saving energy).  Before that I worked for several years in usability research and industrial ergonomics, studying products including barcode scanners and industrial equipment, and providing ergonomics services in areas as diverse as Disney character suit design and airport baggage handling.

title: Introduction to the Brooklyn Museum Collection API
description:
[caption id="attachment_3045" align="aligncenter" width="384"] Francis Guy - Winter Scene in Brooklyn[/caption] The Brooklyn Museum has a long legacy of making its artwork collection accessible to the masses, including putting it online. As part of it's online offerings, the Brooklyn Museum also has an API available for developers to use for whatever developers want to use the data for. In this session, we'll dive into various data and media the API makes available and build a simple, web-based search engine for finding art in the Brooklyn Museum collection. Prerequisites:
  • Basic web programming knowledge (PHP and JavaScript)
  • Laptop, netbook, rooted Nokia N900 or whatever you usually code on
  • Some kind of web server on said device
  • Your very own API key
  • Imagination!

title: Product Design/DigiFab
description: We will be covering design tools (software and hardware) for digital fabrication.

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple's native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the "Hello World" stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We'll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time. Workshop attendees will receive a free copy of my O’Reilly book, Learning iOS Programming (3rd ed), or at least until supplies of books run out. Note: While this workshop assumes no previous knowledge of Objective-C, some coding knowledge is assumed. Additionally attendees should already be members of the iOS Developer Program, and have access to Apple's provisioning portal before attending the class. If anyone needs any help with signing up to the program, I'll be around ITP all from the start of the camp and I'm happy to help. Attendees should bring a Mac, with the latest version of Xcode installed, and an iOS device of some kind (an iPhone, iPad or iPod touch) along with a cable to connect the two.

title: Shop Safety!
description:
Get Shop certified!

Please RSVP for the session you want to attend and un RSVP if you can’t come as we are only doing groups of 12.

If there are 12 already RSVP’d for a session, RSVP for another!

title: Shop Safety!
description:
Get Shop certified!

Please RSVP for the session you want to attend and un RSVP if you can’t come as we are only doing groups of 12.

If there are 12 already RSVP’d for a session, RSVP for another!

title: Shop Safety!
description:
Get Shop certified!

Please RSVP for the session you want to attend and un RSVP if you can’t come as we are only doing groups of 12.

If there are 12 already RSVP’d for a session, RSVP for another!

title: Build an Ultimaker 3D Printer!
description:
The Metropolitan Museum Media Lab has recently got its hands on a shiny new Ultimaker 3D printer. As it turns out though, these come shipped as kits which have to be assembled, so we're bringing it to camp and building it here! Using our collective skills we can probably build it pretty quickly. If you've ever wanted to get your hands dirty in building a 3D printer, join the Metropolitan Museum's Jonathan Dahan and the Brooklyn Museum's David Huerta in an adventure of crowdsourced construction! Some skills that might be handy but not required:
  • Soldering
  • Wiki searching
  • Lifting bulky, heavy things

title: Build a music visualizer from scratch in Processing
description:
So!  Sunday night, after you've hacked some wearables, get down and dirty with an excellent intermediate level processing session on crafting a music visualizer.  I find it's easiest to learn how to do something new when you have a project to try it with, so lets make a music visualizer!

We'll discuss several techniques for acquiring sound data in real time, and try to come up with clever mappings of audio data into visual images.  Then we'll build the app as a group and maybe iterate through a few versions in order to give you a testbed to try out / improve those new / rusty processing skills.  If there's time, we might dabble with adding an interface using one of the awesome processing GUI libraries so you don't have to remember esoteric key combinations to work your project!

Bring a laptop if you want to code along with processing pre-installed.  We'll also be using some libraries, but I'll provide them during the talk so you can all download em from my server (nothing esoteric or custom or anything, but it'll be nice to download them all together as a group so we can be sure we're all using the same version)  I've got a few examples of stuff I've built in the past that I can show off and dissect.

WHO'S WITH ME?!

title: Conductive Lace Making
description:
Crochet, knitting, bobbin lace -- join this session if you want to explore possibilities of lace as conductive material and if you want to learn basics of lacemaking.

I'll bring some supplies, but you are welcome to bring your own if you wish. That's a hands-on session.

Please note that time is somewhat off -- 3pm is a start time.

title: Dying Hungry: Learning to write from lede construction
description:
"As Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from uneasy dreams he found himself transformed in his bed into a monstrous vermin."
If you can get this part down, the rest is easy. The lede (a news business misspelling of lead) is the first sentence or two of your narrative. Once you nail the lede, you nail the reader. A good lede makes the reader need to follow the story, to understand it, to the very end. There’s more tricks and skills to the story, but without this one the rest of them never get read.
“Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.”
In this class we’ll sit there, for hours, and talk about how to build a lede. You'll write, and read, and write again. It'll all take too long. It won’t be anywhere near enough time. You can’t do it until you know what you think; that can take years. But once you have the lede down, the stories you tell will be more true, even the fake one.
“His followers called him Mahasamatman and said he was a god. He preferred to drop the Maha- and the -atman, however, and called himself Sam. He never claimed to be a god. But then, he never claimed not to be a god.”
It’s not just about fiction, it’s not even just about writing, it’s about any idea that takes the form of a narrative, that contains an arc.
“Depression is the flaw in love.”
It’s where writing comes together, if it manages to come together at all. It’s the heart of the matter, the tl;dr. It’s the grave where, when we speak badly, we bury our meanings in misplaced efforts to stay safe. The lede is a place where we boil down and clarify, and once we have it nailed, it protects the rest of the story.
“Frank Sinatra, holding a glass of bourbon in one hand and a cigarette in the other, stood in a dark corner of the bar between two attractive but fading blondes who sat waiting for him to say something.”

title: Intro to the Soft Lab
description: This workshop will introduce you to the basics of using ITP's soft lab resources -- specifically the sewing machines, the embroidery machine, and the vinyl cutter.  This will mostly be a demo session, so no materials are required!

title: AT&T AdWorks Lab Tour
description:
I'll give a quick and informal tour of the AdWorks Media Lab.  We'll look at how we used Cinder to create some very cool (at least we think so!) data visualizations and explain how we developed the narrative for the entire space.  You can see the pool table that will soon be transformed into a completely, interactive experience!    Lastly, you'll also get a sneak peek at the redesign that we're currently doing that will launch in September.

I do need to give names to security, so if you're thinking bout coming, please let me know so I can put you on the building security list.  It'll be informal and casual!  Don't hesitate to holler if you have any questions.

And if you can't come on Friday and still want to see the space, just let me know. I'm always happy to give tours!

title: Kids Day
description:
ITP Camp is a summer camp for adults. But for two hours on June 19th we are going to open the doors to children of all ages. Please sign up for one ticket per child so that we have a sense of how many are coming. http://itpcampkidsday.eventbrite.com/ Thank you! Come join us for two hours of technology workshops for kids: Activities will include:
  • Minecraft Mania
  • 3D Scanning with the Great Fredini!
  • Scratch 2.0 - Say Hello to the Camera
  • Paper Circuits - Light up Cards
  • Projection Mapping with Gabe B.C.
And more... If you have any questions, email jaymesdec [at] gmail [dot] com

title: Smart Dust – is it inevitable?
description: I'd argue that the era of the commodity beige box is coming to an end, and the days of the general purpose computer are almost over. Most people never needed or wanted a computer, and they're going to be happy with more limited devices optimised for a single, or a few, purposes so long as those devices just work. Today the black rectangle has replaced the beige box, but don't get too comfortable, because it won't last as long. Today's cellphones and tablets are transition devices, dependent on our current level of technological progress, and around you everyday objects are already becoming smarter. In ten years' time, every piece of clothing you own, every piece of jewelry, and every thing you carry with you will be measuring, weighing and calculating. In ten years, the world — your world — will be full of sensors. The end point of this evolution is already clear: it's called smart dust. General purpose computing, sensors, and wireless networking, all bundled up in millimeter-scale sensor motes drifting in the air currents, flecks of computing power, settling on your skin, ingested, will bemonitoring you inside and out, sensing and reporting — both for you and about you. Note: I'm going to talk for about twenty minutes and present the argument for smart dust, and then open the floor for debate. I welcome dissenters and neutral parties to bring their own opinions, and their own twenty minutes of slides and argument, and then let's get some discussion going.

title: VJ demo/workshop
description: Since there are so many tools being presented at camp I'd like to demo a few ways to make them talk to one another. How can you bring a visualization sketch you wrote in Processing into MAX/MSP/Jitter or VDMX? Syphon! How can you control multiple applications at once from a touch screen? TouchOSC! My experience in using these devices and programs is derived from VJing (can we come up with a better term, please?) So we can talk about that, too. I think a fair amount of time at the end will be dedicated to a discussion about using the Kinect's raw depth data, but we will not talk about OpenNI as I have no experience with that.

title: Kids Day Planning
description:
This will just be a quick chat to gauge interest in helping to plan activities and brainstorming for Kids Day -

Kids Day will be June 19th 3 - 5:30

title: Intro to Kinect & Processing
description:
more to come but...

 

the goals are:

1. get everyone set up with simple Open NI & Processing

2. Get a basic understanding of some code

3. Get everyone comfortable with playing with the kinect.

 

Because of Kinect Availability, This workshop will be limited to 18 participants.

title: Making Fireworks in Three.js
description: Make a neat fireworks animation just in time for the Fourth of July! Switching gears to three. js Requirements: - novice to intermediate knowledge of Javascript - a computer that can run WebGL (go to http://mrdoob.github.io/three.js/ and see if you can run any of these) Topics covered: Overview of 3D animation thinking in three dimensions Renderer, Camera, Scene, requestAnimation - basic three.js concepts you need to get stuff to show up on the screen Particles for everyone! - creating particles and adding textures

title: Early version - From Story to Tech: a methodology project
description: Advanced, earlier date of my presentation on the 17th for those of you who wish to get ideas for your Camp projects a little sooner. Might do one next week as well if Campers are interested!

title: Intro to Python
description: This workshop will serve as an introduction to the Python programming language.  Topics covered will include: * basic syntax and deploying scripts from the command line * writing to and reading from text files * manipulating strings and text * basic user input Please come with a version of Python installed on your laptop.  If you have a Mac, this should be pre-installed on your computer, but if you're unsure or need to check, follow the instructions here: http://wiki.python.org/moin/BeginnersGuide/Download (if you need command line assistance, feel free to ask me or one of the other counselors!) You will also need to have a basic text editor installed on your computer.  I personally love Sublime Text, but other options include TextWrangler or TextMate.

title: Arduino 101
description: Learn the very basics of how to program with the popular platform for physical computing projects. If you took the “Hello, Arduino” session on Monday night, this session will cover that information, but also delve deeper into the topics of digital input and output as well as analog input and output. If you want to follow along, bring an Arduino UNO, a USB A-to-B cable, and a computer loaded up with the Arduino IDE. For some demos, we’ll be using some Physical Computing supplies like buttons, breadboards, jumper wires, sensors and LEDs. If you have anything like this, please bring it. Otherwise, I will try to provide as much as I can round up on the floor. Feel free to stay after this session for Arduino Programming Basics, which builds on what we learn in this session!

title: Arduino Programming Basics
description:
So if you want to move beyond the blinking LED and learn some more coding for the Arduino, this is the class for you. We'll review some of the coding from Arduino 101 and then move onto variables, for loops, while loops, and writing your own functions. This class mostly covers coding, but for demonstration purposes, I'm going to be using digitalRead, digitalWrite, analogRead, and analogWrite. I'll be using a circuit like the one pictured above. It consists of:
  • a 2K potentiometer hooked up to analog input pin 0
  • 3 LEDs connected to pins digital 3, 4, and 5
  • 1 pushbutton switch connected to digital pin 2
You don't need to replicate this circuit in order to follow along in class, though you can if you want. Here's some base code we'll be using to setup these pins:

title: Coding in Assembly
description:
Tristan Perich presents an introductory workshop on hardware programming in Assembly, providing an understanding of how these systems function at their lowest level. As the technology in our lives becomes faster and more complicated, our understanding of it has decreased, forcing us to put an implicit faith in its design, inner workings and safety. While Perich's work aims to integrate low-level computation with traditional artistic media, this workshop intends to teach a basic understanding of Assembly, a low-level programming language that drives most hardware at its foundation. The workshop is intended for those with a basic understanding of computer programming, though it is not necessary. Participants will learn how to program an Amtel microprocessor, a low-cost, highly versatile microchip similar to those used in Arduino boards and in Perich's own 1-Bit Symphony. Requirements:Mac laptop,
Software
Mac: please download the following software prior to the workshop
If Mac OS 10.8 gives you a warning about installing software from an unknown developer, right-click the installer and select "Open" from the context menu to allow you to override the message.
AVR Cross Pack: (Programming tools)
Info: http://obdev.at/products/crosspack/download.html
Direct Download: http://obdev.at/downloads/crosspack/CrossPack-AVR-20130212.dmg
FTDI Chip Driver: (Driver for hardware programmer)
Info: http://ftdichip.com/Drivers/VCP.htm
Direct Download: http://ftdichip.com/Drivers/VCP/MacOSX/FTDIUSBSerialDriver_v2_2_18.dmg
Tavrasm: (Mac Assembler)
Direct Download: http://tristanperich.com/files/tavrasm/tavrasm.zip
STK Friend: (User-friendly programming tool)
Dirct Download: http://tristanperich.com/files/stkfriend/stkfriend2014b.zip
And a good text editor!
This session is limited to 10 participants. First come first serve. If you are unable to attend, please delete your RSVP. Materials will be provided for the workshop, however, if you want to take home what you've made, the cost is $10 for the basic parts and $50 for the AVR programmer.

title: After Effects questions - answered
description:
Have specific questions about After Effects? Having trouble creating an animation? or exporting, or...anything.

I will answer it (if I can!). I've been working in After Effects for 8 years. I use it to make TV Commercials, demo videos for start-ups, and Film graphics.

Come with specific questions.

I'll come with answers and a list of external resources.

This could be viewed as a follow-up class to the 'Intro to After Effects' class as well.

title: Crazy Data Circles with d3.js
description: Sometimes you want to use circles to clearly present your data; sometimes you just want to fill circles in with pretty colors and have them fly around the screen, because it looks awesome. This off-kilter introduction to D3 will teach you how to do both of those equally valid, time-honored activities. We’ll cover the fundamental concepts of D3 — loading data, generating visual elements based on that data — and then walk through several code samples, illustrating some of the nutty things you can do with this serious tool. We’ll move quickly, so you should already be familiar with HTML, CSS, and a bit of JavaScript or another programming language. (For example, if you’ve noodled around with jQuery or Processing, and variables and for() loops don't scare you, you’ll be fine.) Requirements: You will need your own laptop with the following installed and ready to go: a text or code editor of your choice, a new web browser (Chrome is best for our purposes), and a local web server (e.g., MAMP or Python simple server).

title: Akimitsu Sadoi - LED Artist Workshop
description:
Aki has offered to do a build workshop which should be quite fun and you'll have something to take with you. It's the simplest circuit with the least number of components (see image below). Yet it does share the same technical principle (multiplex LED drive with PWM) with more complex designs of his. He also think it's a good material to get started with surface mount soldering.
Even experienced electronics builders tend to be intimidated by SMT (surface mount technology), but it's actually very easy to do. Now so many electronics components are only available in SMT package, SMT soldering skill is becoming essential for makers and alike.
The cost for the materials will be around $10 per student.
It should take about an hour to complete the assembly and he will stick around afterwards to help fix problems with some student as needed.
  http://www.theledart.com/blog/

title: Intro to Scratch (and Makey Makey)
description: Scratch is a free program geared towards teaching kids introductory programming skills through gamemaking and animation. It can be paired easily with the Makey Makey, an extremely easy-to-use microcontroller that can turn anything into a keyboard. Come check it out!

title: Introduction to Hacking Your Voice
description: This session will: -Take you through some of the basic physical components of your voice -Go 'under the hood' in ways you might not have the chance to outside of a traditional voice or medical program -Give you a chance to try out some activities using your voice within healthy 'normal' parameters -Leave you with some practical hacks

title: Making midi devices with the arduino micro/leonardo
Learn vim
description:
Attention campers!  Anyone wanna learn vim?

For those who don't know, vim is one of the most powerful text editors around...a program that can be run entirely from terminal that can be used to write and edit code, markup or even a novel.  In it's almost 40 year history, vim has been sharpened into one of the most powerful and fastest tools in our cultural arsenal for writing and manipulating text.  Complex edits that would take you several seconds or even minutes in microsoft office / eclipse / xcode / processing / coda can be done in a few keystrokes.

Most people who use / are aware of it are from technical backgrounds, but once I picked it up, I've used it for all sorts of writing and journaling.  

vim has a notoriously steep learning curve, but as an experienced vim user and a decent explainer, I think I could help demystify it.  I'd be happy to put on an 1.5 hour long vim session to show off some of the powerful features of this program, and help everyone write faster, feel geekier and ditch microsoft office for an incredible piece of free open source software!        

Please come with gvim pre-installed on your computer:
windows installer link: ftp://ftp.vim.org/pub/vim/pc/gvim73_46.exe
mac installers (pick correct one for your OS version): https://code.google.com/p/macvim/downloads/list

title: TinkerCAD - 3D Design for Toddlers
description:
This is the easiest 3D design program out there. I use it to teach 3D design and printing to toddlers. Seriously.
But it's also really powerful. You can use javascript for parametric modeling, import and extrude svg files, and import/alter existing STL files. Don't worry if you have no idea what any of that means, because you will after this session!
It's cloud based, so no download required. And it's free[mium]. I'll show you enough to get started with their built-in lessons, but then I'll show you some advanced features that are really fun, easy, and handy.
You can read more about my experiences with TinkerCAD on their blog: http://blog.tinkercad.com/2012/02/15/the-designers-of-the-future/
http://blog.tinkercad.com/2012/10/31/profiled-jaymes-dec/

title: Wearable Computers
description:
Okay...you sewed a simple circuit with a battery and some LEDs. Maybe you added a button or a switch.
But what if you want your wearable project to be smart? What if you want your clothes to monitor your environment? Or make decisions? Or communicate? What if you could sew a computer into your clothes? Well you can!
In this session, you'll get started with the Arduino Lilypad or Adafruit's Flora.
You'll need one of those two sewable microcontrollers for this session. I also recommend that you bring at least one sewable sensor and one actuator (light/buzzer/motor/etc). Also, come with the Arduino IDE installed on your laptop. If you have any questions, or anything specific you want me to cover, send me an email: jaymesdec@gmail.com

title: Garment District Field Trip!
description:
Group trip to the garment district!

We're meeting at the ITP floor at 11 am.

Schedule is TBA is open to suggestions !

title: OpenNI Kinect with Osculator, Max/Jitter, Processing, Ableton Live etc
description: 10am - 12 (some calendars are showing 11am for some reason) Last minute note:  I  created a sound patch working in Pure Data. It is a free program - if you'd like to download it you can get it here http://puredata.info/ grab the extended version. I will put these downloads on a jump drive too and bring them. We will explore the OpenNi code framework and how to use the skeletal data in various programs. Osculator is a great tool for many things, including visualizing these messages. it can be downloaded here  (mac only) if some of you on Windows want to attend, please let me know and I will find some workarounds for osculator http://www.osculator.net/ Synapse is another favorite program but it only works with the Xbox 360 Kinect, not the "Kinect for Windows" model. I use it a lot for getting data to other programs. http://synapsekinect.tumblr.com/post/6305020721/download I will demo projects in Max/Jitter, Processing, Osculator, and Ableton Live and we will go over coding options for getting the kinect data to your programs of choice. Pure Data is an option also if there is interest. Let me know! Processing and Pure Data are absolutely free and robust programs.  Trials are available for the others listed.  Osculator is shareware so you can download and use it without problem. Please bring your kinects with your OpenNI libraries, Synapse and and other software that you want to talk to installed! NOTE : the newest Kinect for Windows model will not work with Synapse unfortunately. Look on the front of the kinect for the "Xbox 360" label and bring that one if possible. Contact me with any questions or requests! Thanks! Robbie PS I'm hoping to keep this a little small- maybe 12 people? so please sign up here if you are interested.

title: Shop Safety!
description: Mandatory if you haven't had one already!!!

title: Don't Go Back to School--independent learning for everybody
description: Forget education reform, let's transform learning itself! I'm excited to share the research that went into my recently published handbook on independent learning called Don't Go Back to School, based on interviews with 100 independent learners. Let's talk about how independent learning works, and how to get more people doing it and taking it seriously, and how it fits into the future of education, daily life, and the world we want to live in. My next contribution to the cause will be a set of guidelines for learning oriented working groups. I'd love to hear your approaches.

title: Designing Interactive Experiences for Public Spaces
description: Building on a few case studies from projects realized over the past few years – this workshop will cover key design strategies to help create compelling and engaging interactive experiences in Public spaces. This will be a hands-on workshop with a focus on coming up with conceptual prototypes for an existing location and context. Suggestions for specific questions that you would like to see addressed are welcomed.

title: Designing Projections for a Chamber Opera
description: I recently created video projections for "Lotus Lives," a new independent one-hour opera written for two singers, a brass quintet, percussion, and audio-video playback. I tackled everything from content design and creation, through coordinating six projectors with a live performance on a limited budget, and making sure it ran smoothly. The setup used a bunch of the tools being covered at camp (After Effects, MadMapper, VDMX, Max/MSP) -- so this is a show-and-tell presentation of what worked and my plans for next time. I'll discuss: - Designing a concept that would be appropriate to the story and feasible with our resources - Creating a system that could adapt to the performers in a changing, live situation - Designing the set for the video, and vice versa - Shooting the content: gathering images on location in Malaysia, designing and building shadow puppets, and collaborating with dancers - Editing and compositing the content [Final Cut Pro and After Effects] - Prepping the video for playback [After Effects and Compressor] - Designing the playback [Akai Midi controller -> networked through Max/MSP -> video playback with VDMX on multiple systems -> mapped with MadMapper -> split up with TripleHead2Go hardware] Here's a video trailer for the opera: http://timbartlett.net/lotustrailer/

title: Field trip to Bitfoms Gallery and Eyebeam
description: We're going to visit http://www.bitforms.com and http://www.eyebeam.org. Feel free to join us.

title: Intro to openFrameworks
description:
This will be a quick intro into openFrameworks, aimed at people who never used it.

If you never did any programming at all this might not be your thing - check out Processing, JavaScript or similar languages instead.

Please install oF for your platform before the workshop: http://www.openframeworks.cc/download/. Note that this involves downloading oF itself + an IDE like Xcode or code::blocks.

title: Shop Safety!
description: Get shop certified! Mandatory for all campers.

title: Laser Cutter 102
Intro to Soft Circuits round 2
description: Did you miss the Intro to Soft Circuits workshop? Well no need to feel left out anymore! I will be doing a condensed version of the Intro to Soft Circuits workshop and we will go over materials and techniques that can be used for soft circuits. Afterwards,  you should go to the Wearable Computers session happening later in the afternoon!

title: Building Websites with Twitter Bootstrap
description:
Hi! This is a hands-on workshop where we are going to build a single page portfolio site with Twitter Bootstrap. This workshop presumes a beginner to intermediate knowledge of HTML/CSS/Javascript (JS). Come with a computer with the Chrome browser and your favorite code editor. Also download this starter template: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/20707077/bootstrap-workshop/site.zip

Overview of the Bootstrap Framework

  • what is it, why people use it, and how all its parts fit together.
  • what the heck is jQuery?

Laying out the grid

  • We're going to make sure all our content line up

Adding a Carousel/Slideshow

  • learning how HTML integrates with Javascript
  • an in-depth look into the source code of the carousel plugin to gain an understanding of Javascript/jQuery
  • a VERY brief overview of animations with CSS3 or Javascript

Adding An Image Gallery

  • more practice with writing HTML and adhering to the Bootstrap grid system

Customizing the look and feel

  • learning how use Chrome DevTools to customize the included CSS
If there's time, I'll cover the following topics: - Hosting your website on GitHub - Dissecting sites I've worked on to better understand how HTML/CSS/JS work together - learn how to modify features and designs we like from other websites

title: Jitter Workshop: Coding for Video Art
description: Intro to Jitter with the focus being on creating interactive video installations taught by Gabe Barcia-Colombo I will start with the basics and move on from there. Learn how to play movies within jitter. Syphon videos from Jitter to Madmapper. Do basic camera tracking and connect physical sensors to Jitter. This was created because so many of you asked for a Jitter workshop during the Really Big Video session.

title: CNC Fun Day
description:
Stacks on stacks of CNC education! You don't really need anything to attend this session, just a good attitude!
It's gonna be rad!

You need to have taken a shop safety session to attend this class. DOOOOO IIIIITTTTTTT!

See ya there

title: Improv Electronics with TinkerKit for Arduino
description: TinkerKit is a shield for Arduino that makes it super fast and easy to prototype interactivity by just plugging in sensors and actuators without having to worry about extra circuitry, breadboarding, etc... Combined, TinkerKit and Arduino make it fast and easy to prototype physical computing ideas. I've introduced the combination to kids and watched them make really cool projects in an hour or two. Think: Lego gun turrets controlled by accelerometers and high frequency hearing tests for kids vs adults. I have 10 shields and a lab kit of parts that I can lend out for this session. In this two hour workshop, you'll have to choose a sensor and an actuator from a grab bag and then make a project with them and some craft materials. This workshop will be facilitated by Scott Fitzgerald and Jaymes Dec

title: Making Things Move with Arduino
description:
Want to make things move with an Arduino?  Let's look at how we control motors, and how we design and make the gears that will let the motors move things.  Note: the first half will be dedicated to controlling motors the second half will cover gears.

The motors section will focus on 4 tools every artist should eventually have in their toolset. Darlington transitors, Darlington arrays, hbridge drivers (like the l293D), and hobby servos. If you bring these with you can follow along as we demonstrate each using the Arduino platform. Given the short time to plan this class you are not expected to have parts on hand but I would be happy to facilitate a group order of parts at the end of class.

title: ITP CAMPER PECHA KUCHA
description:
This Friday at 6:30pm we're hosting our First Annual ITP CAMP Pecha Kucha!
"PechaKucha 20x20 is a simple presentation format where you show 20 images, each for 20 seconds. The images advance automatically and you talk along to the images."

This one will be made up of short camper talks about, well, anything. It could be a micro talk about something camp/tech related, something hilarious or interesting that happened to you or some idea, knowledge or history that you would like to share with us. 

The only difference, is that we're knocking it down to 15 SECONDS per slide, a la IgniteNYC, because really, 20 seconds is just gluttonous. Consider it an austerity measure. So what do you do now? Email me with your name and the subject of your talk, and we'll queue you up. After that, get us a folder with 20 images in it. The folder should be named "PK_*yourname*" and each image should be named and numbered for order (e.g. jw_1, jw_2, jw_3). Please have those to us by NOON Friday June 14th. You can either bring a thumb drive to the Counselors Station or you can use WeTransfer to send it to this email address. Let us know if you have any questions. Looking forward to your talks! Here are some other examples of successful talks:

Kim Boekbinder

Dennis Crowley

Dr. Who

A Guy Called Gerald

title: Data Visualization with Processing!
description:
This session will be about creating data visualizations using Processing. We'll go over things like:
-the basic dos & don'ts of data viz
-how to read CSV files into processing
-tricks to make your visualizations look nicer & transition smoother
-which functions in Processing will make creating data visualizations a lot easier
-working in Processing.js
This will be a course for beginner data visualizers, though at least basic experience with Processing would be great!

title: Streaming Kart 101
description: Want to learn how to use the fabled ITP Live Streaming rig? Interested in Live Streaming in general? Shawn Van Every walks through the basics of both.

title: Gloves Meetup
description:
So you want a glove that communicates to all of our wonderful programs we are learning?

We will be meeting up to look at the steps necessary to complete this using Arduino or the proposed ArduiMU chip. The idea is to each make our very own glove from scratch and program it using bend sensors, LEDS, and any other sensors we can come up with.

Costs: With the ArduiMU chip (allows for accelerometer and gyro detection)

$250 for 1 Glove wireless

$200 for 1 Glove wired

Using an Arduino without accelerometer and Gyro will be roughly $150.

I strongly suggest we use the ArduiMU processing.

This session is just to break the ice and find out who would like to be involved. We hope that with all of our combined skills we can have fellow campers lead certain steps in the process, i.e. sewing, programing, soldering.

We will come up with a schedule for production as well as a order for parts. We can have someone purchase all of the fabric and sometime next week we can have a sewing day while we wait for parts to come in. I am hoping we can accomplish this in a few sessions.

If you are interested please join in the conversation.

 

Steps we will be using.

http://theglovesproject.com/materials/

title: Visual Effects and Compositing using After Effects
description: In this workshop we'll look at using After Effects for visual effects and compositing, including green screen and motion tracking.

title: Flying Robots
description: There is a growing community interested in building flying autonomous robots.   We will go over the history of flying robots.  The current and future roles these robots will play in our society. We will then dive into how to build your own robot.   The session will go over the components and how they work together to create a autonomous flying robot.  Followed by a Q&A. For more information visit: www.scoutuav.com

title: Working with Words
description: Artists and programmers have long had a fascination with words. They can be easily manipulated in code and can carry great emotional weight. We will cover some techniques used by artists and programmers to manipulate language, and examine the intricacies of a word-association database which we will explore with Processing. Some familiarity with code and Processing will be very helpful.

title: Zero to Plastic Part 1: Using SketchUp to design for 3D Printing
description:
Your host the Great Fredini will go through the basics of 3D design in SketchUp. We'll cover Sketch up's basic tools and the use of digital calipers to design a 3D object based on real world measurements. Once parts are designed, we will export them as STL files and prep them for 3D printing with Netfabb Basic and slice the file with Makerware for printing on the ITP Makerbot. 


If you want to follow along, bring a mouse and have SketchUp installed.
http://www.sketchup.com/

title: Zero to Plastic Part 2: 3D Scanning with ReconstructMe
description: We'll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models. Softwares we will work with: ReconstructMe http://reconstructme.net/ - this is a commercial software for PC only, but a trial is available. Mac users can install it under a bootcamp partition. Not recommended for parallels. Please also note that I am not going to help you with installing this software. The ReconstructMe support page http://reconstructme.net/faqs/ or Google Group is a great place for support: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/reconstructme Netfabb Basic- free download http://www.netfabb.com/download.php Meshlab- free download http://meshlab.sourceforge.net/

title: Tom Igoe Mystery Talk
Breadboard Analog Synthesizer Workshop
description: Lets make some noise.  In this workshop we will make clicks beeps and drones with analog chips and a breadboard.  Bring  as many of the following supplies if you have them: a breadboard, alligator clips,  a 9Volt Battery (or another power source), hookup wire, switches, potentiometers, photoresistors, 8ohm hobby/ toy speaker. If you dont have this stuff dont worry i will have some limited supplies that we can share.

title: Intro to openFrameworks, part 2
description:
Part 2 will cover:
  •  creating classes
  • images
  • video
  • a simple particle system
If you missed part 1, then make sure you install oF (see http://www.openframeworks.cc/documentation/) and go through the tutorial at http://www.openframeworks.cc/tutorials/. This will take you around 2 hours to complete. Let me know if you have any questions.

title: The Glove Project
description: Learn about the glove project by the artist Imogen Heap http://theglovesproject.com/ the Gloves team have put up their DIY instructions with coding on their website and the glove group at ITP has gotten together to assemble their own data glove based on the bill of materials given (http://theglovesproject.com/materials/). During this evening session, guest speaker Noah Zerkin will run through code and tricks to get gestural data flowing from ArduIMU boards into processing visualizations. If you have your ArduIMU in hand and ready to program, please make sure to bring a ftdi programmer to load your code.

title: VJ - Syphon / VDMX / Jitter / TouchOSC
description: Another quick introduction to VJ software! Of course many of the things we'll discuss are applicable to the larger world of visual art. Topics include Syphon, a nifty library that allows you to create a video wormhole from one application to another; TouchOSC, the touch interface that lets you adjust virtual knobs which you can use to control variables in Max, VDMX, etc.; and using the Kinect to create a depth map video mask. If you'd like to follow along, please download: VDMX Demo Syphon for Processing and Max TouchOSC Freenect Kinect library for Max

title: Physics Simulations in Processing
description: This workshop will give a condensed overview of various kinds of physics simulations in Processing. We'll go over oscillation, a basic Particle class, attraction and repulsion forces, collision detection, and an introduction to the Box2d library, the physics engine behind a little game you might've heard of by the name of Angry Birds. Hopefully by the end of the workshop you'll have a better understanding of the PVector class, applying forces to objects onscreen, and you'll be ready to dive into more Nature of Code material on your own. The code examples we went over in class are hosted on github: https://github.com/veev/Simulations-in-Processing Box2D on the Big Screen Analyzing the physics of Angry Birds Here's a nice tutorial if you're interested in combining Box2D with the Kinect.

title: Genspace Tour
description:
We'll meet at 33 Flatbush Ave in Brooklyn at noon for an hourish-long tour of the biohackerspace: "Genspace is a nonprofit organization dedicated to promoting citizen science and access to biotechnology. Since 2009 we have served the greater New York area by providing educational outreach, cultural events, and a platform for science innovation at the grassroots level. Genspace was founded by a group of science enthusiasts who come from different professions - artists, engineers, writers and biologists. Unlike traditional institutions, our diversity is our strength and the source of our innovation. For a reasonable monthly cost, members can pursue a wide variety of biotechnology-related projects that can be commercial, artistic, or just fun." Recent projects out of Genspace include:
  • Strange Visions, a collection of 3D printed portrait sculptures based on found genetic material.
  • WetPong, a video game you play by controlling live paramecia
To get there:
Take the 2,3,4,5 trains to the Nevins st.
Station or the B,Q,R trains to DeKalb Ave.
Please RSVP below so we know how many people to expect. Thanks!

title: ITP CAMP PECHA KUCHA (For Riz)
description:
This Friday at 8:30pm we're hosting our First Annual ITP CAMP Pecha Kucha!
"PechaKucha 20x20 is a simple presentation format where you show 20 images, each for 20 seconds. The images advance automatically and you talk along to the images."

This one will be made up of short camper talks about, well, anything. It could be a micro talk about something camp/tech related, something hilarious or interesting that happened to you or some idea, knowledge or history that you would like to share with us. 

The only difference, is that we're knocking it down to 15 SECONDS per slide, a la IgniteNYC, because really, 20 seconds is just gluttonous. Consider it an austerity measure. So what do you do now? Email me with your name and the subject of your talk, and we'll queue you up. After that, get us a folder with 20 images in it. The folder should be named "PK_*yourname*" and each image should be named and numbered for order (e.g. jw_1, jw_2, jw_3). Please have those to us by NOON Friday June 14th. You can either bring a thumb drive to the Counselors Station or you can use WeTransfer to send it to this email address. Let us know if you have any questions. Looking forward to your talks! Here are some other examples of successful talks:

Kim Boekbinder

Dennis Crowley

Dr. Who

A Guy Called Gerald

title: Jitter-centric Weenie roast
description: A bunch of people have asked for some specialized help with Max/Jitter to supplement the intro sessions Gabe and I have run. However, there's little consensus on what people want to get out of it. Requests have come in for OpenGL help, video tracking, and affirmation of life goals. The Weenie roast is an excuse for me to write the word weenie as much as possible. It's also an opportunity for you ask questions and run an informal workshop session. You're all free to come and go as you please for the duration. There won't be any sort of step-by step instruction, I figure it will be more like a quiz show! Drop a note in the comments identifying what you are interested in talking about so I can best prepare. Hey everyone, thanks for making it out yesterday! The patches can be downloaded from here.

title: Revisiting the GSM shield
description: This is a make-up session from the other week. The Arduino GSM shield allows you to make and receive voice calls, send and receive SMS messages, and send data over a cellular network. In this one hour session, we’ll go over the basics of using the GSM shield and look at creating some very simple mobile hardware applications. SMS to LED sketch can be downloaded here

title: Mobile Culture: How leading startups create and unleash mobile behavior
description: Learn how 3 top startups create mobile experiences around specific user groups, tapping into existing behavior and unleashing new one. Participating: Ruti Wajnberg, Director of Product @ HowAboutWe.com (New York Times) Diego Saez-Gil, Founder of WeHostels (VentureBeat) Fritz Charles, Data Scientist @ iROKOtv and iROKING, the Netflix and Spotify of Africa.

title: Hacking the Kinect skeleton into Processing - follow- up
description:
This is an informal follow-up to the OpenNI in Osculator, Max Jitter Ableton class.

This session will assume that you have your kinect OpenNI library working with Processing as we will not spend time on set up. 

Please choose any interactive Processing sketch that you want to control with a skeletal joint or two.These are sketches that use mouse control. 

I will help you walk you through hacking your sketch for use with the OpenNI library,  and hopefully you will all have your own sketch by the end of the session!

Please download this library and these files from the earlier class here
http://tinyurl.com/l5qfn6x

Still no love with adding links here...
just copy and paste it!

title: Guest Speaker: Andrew Dent from Material ConneXion
description:
Andrew Dent will be joining us to discuss what's happening with materials and what's soon to come. From the Material ConneXion website:
Andrew H. Dent Ph.D.  Vice President , Library & Materials Research Dr. Dent received his Ph.D. in materials science from the University of Cambridge in England and plays a key role in Material ConneXion’s expansion of its technical knowledge base. Dr. Dent’s primary function is to direct research into innovative products and processes. His role includes coordinating the monthly jury selections that vote new materials into the our libraries in New York, Bangkok, Cologne and Milan as well as management of the physical library team and our online database. Dr. Dent is also charged with guiding the implementation of research in consultancy projects for our clients. Prior to joining Material ConneXion, Dr. Dent held a number of research positions both in industry and academia. At Rolls Royce PLC, Dr. Dent specialized in turbine blades for the present generation of jet engines. He has completed postdoctoral research at Cambridge University and at the Center for Thermal Spray Research, SUNY, Stony Brook, NY. Other research projects, during this period, included work for the US Navy, DARPA, NASA, and the British Ministry of Defense.

title: Guest Lecture: Inventing a mechatronic transmission
description: In this talk and workshop, Tony Wong will discuss his invention: A new kind of transmission that uses high speed mechatronics to instantaneously "change gears" in a way that has never been done before. Tony will share technical information not previously released in public, and will also talk about his company's challenges of developing and patenting his invention, raising capital, and the current endeavor of bringing it to market. Faster than the human eye can observe, the Mechatronic Variable Speed Drive (MVSD) toothed sprocket changes size while transmitting full torque load with zero slippage. The "shift" is fully synchronized by a microcontroller which orchestrates the movement of sprocket segments, ensuring that the teeth of the belt are always fully engaged - even while shifting within 30 milliseconds while spinning at 2000rpm.

title: Mechanisms & Gears
description: This session will cover the key steps of rapid prototyping and building your own mechanical constructions. This includes useful hardware tips, designing and manufacturing your own parts using 2d and 3d software, and materials. There will also be a special focus on gears and gear-based mechanisms. This lecture will be taught with a hobbyist perspective in mind.

title: Build an Ultimaker, the Sequel!
description: Last week on Ultimaker Galactica, we totally made lots of progress on building the Ultimaker's frame and some blocks for the XY axis. This week we'll finish the XY axis and build as much other stuff as we can! If you’ve ever wanted to get your hands dirty in building a 3D printer, join the Metropolitan Museum’s Jonathan Dahan and the Brooklyn Museum’s David Huerta in an adventure of crowdsourced construction! RSVP in the comments or just stop by unexpectedly!

title: How to Teach Yourself How to Code
description:
Led by a person still learning how to code, this session-discussion will explore methods for teaching yourself how to code. I've been a bit dissatisfied with the resources currently available, and aim to develop a workshop presenting a framework of tools to scaffold self-teaching for those without a STEM background.

I'll begin by describing my journey to and struggles in coding, and what patterns I've discovered in my learning. Next, I will present an exercise to facilitate the discussion on new approaches to guide beginners. 

Feel welcome to bring tutorials, links to videos, or personal breakthroughs to share during the discussion.

title: 3D Printer Group - "The Big Build"/Make Your Printrbot - Day 1
description:
It is happening!  We are building our printers.  This will be going all weekend.  Come in to ITP,  get your kit and start building.  We'll provide instructions and assistance for the build.

Estimated build time for the kits is 4-6 hours.

title: 3D Printer Group – “The Big Build”/Make Your Printrbot – Day 2
description:
It is happening!  We are building our printers.  This will be going all weekend.  Come in to ITP,  get your kit and start building.  We'll provide instructions and assistance for the build.

Estimated build time for the kits is 4-6 hours.

Dave Reeves of Hack Manhattan is here to help and you can build the extruder part today even if you don't have the rest of the parts.

title: Prototyping Interactive Spaces with Spacebrew
description: Spacebrew is a service (and software toolkit) that was built for prototyping interactive spaces and internet of things objects. It makes it easy to connect applications and interactive objects by supporting a wide selection of languages and platforms. What You'll Learn: You'll learn to connect a processing sketch to Spacebrew so that it can be controlled by, or function as the controller of other Spacebrew-connected applications and objects. Knowledge Requirements: Novice knowledge of Processing (and, optionally, Arduino) What to Bring: computer with Processing (and, optionally, Arduino) installed and a simple Processing sketch (or Arduino connected to a Processing Sketch). More About Spacebrew: Spacebrew is an open, dynamically re-routable software toolkit for choreographing interactive spaces. Or, in other words, a simple way to connect interactive things to one another. Every element you hook up to the system is identified as either a subscriber (reading data in) or a publisher (pushing data out). Data is in one of three standardized formats: a boolean (true/false), a number range (0-1023) or a string (text). Once these elements are set up, you can use a web based visual switchboard to connect or disconnect publishers and subscribers to each other. Learn more at spacebrew.cc Spacebrew is an open source project that was originally developed at the LAB at Rockwell Group. Thank You Thanks to everyone who joined the workshop this week. If you want to get the cleaned up code that we put together in our session you can find it here.

title: Intro to Photography
description: In this Intro to Photo class, we'll touch upon exposure and composition and weaning off of automode! Topics: - Intro to exposure: covering f/stops and iso/asa; how it affects lighting, mood and how your subjects look regarding depth of field, how to include motion or reduce motion in your photos - Intro to the zone system and how possibly that can help you expose photos - Composition and some tips to remember when you're shooting - Brief discussion on how to take better cell phone pictures (cause why not) - Discussion on how to edit cell phone photos on free app called snapseed. - Short discussion on self portraits if there is time.. No equipment necessary, we'll use what's available in the ER This is an intro class and will be boring to those familiar with their cameras.

title: Last words!
description: Open mic! This is the opportunity to say any last words you'd like to the ITP Camp crew. Kate will kick it off with some comments about Life After Camp and we'll see what follows...

title: Funding Your Work: Grants and Crowd Funding
description:
Ann Bennett and Theresa Loong will be presenting from 7-8:30pm.

We have experience with foundation, government and crowdsourced funds to support transmedia and documentary projects.

We'll spend the first part of class talking about which funds are best for which types of projects (art/social issue/affinity group) and how to refine your concept, treatment, project plan and initial budget to optimize your chances of success.

We'll spend the second part of class talking about different techniques to prepare and manage your crowdsourcing campaign.

And, we'll provide additional resources and upcoming deadlines.

Please RSVP if you can attend!

title: CNC Round II
description:
Because one just wasn't enough!!!

Even if you don't have a project in mind, come for the fun!

Stacks on stacks of CNC education! You don’t really need anything to attend this session, just a good attitude!

It’s gonna be rad! See you there.

title: Camp Fellows Lightening Talks!
Intel Perceptual Computing Lab
description: Hear about the latest projects from the Intel Perceptual Computing Lab!

title: Building + Sculpting in Second Life (continued from Monday)
description:
This is an extra SecondLife hour on the calendar for Wednesday at 5pm to finish our building tutorial. Hope you can attend.

If you did not attend Monday feel free to  join us  with your own avatar or to observe.
Mechthild

title: StoryCode Meetup
description: StoryCode welcomes documentary collaborators and pioneers in the interactive documentary arena - Ryan Jones(producer/director) and Mark Catalano (developer). Called a "beautiful multimedia newspaper" by Fast Company and an "evolving online documentary" by the creators, Dadaab stands out in the sea of new interactive docs. Join us as the creators present the inside scoop on their process. DADAAB STORIES is an interactive documentary and a place for those stories to live, and be shared with the world. This ongoing project includes video, poetry, art, photographs, blog posts. One of the most interesting aspects of this project is that the creators enabled the subjects to create various elements of the project themselves. This excellent example of community journalism was a 2011 recipient of a Tribeca New Media Fund grant.

title: Air Quality Sensor Hacking Session
description:
We're working on an air quality project based on Boarduino and are hosting a hacking session around the project. What we will do:
  1. Solder a boarduino
  2. Connect it to various sensors that measure air quality and an RGB LED
  3. Change the color of led based on amount of pollution
  4. Brainstorm various design cases / interactions with it (weather balloons, ping-pong balls)
We're planning to do this in workshops in China, Egypt, Mexico and many other countries that face serious problems because of the poor air quality in order to raise awareness around this topic so your contribution would be more than helpful.
Check this PDF to read more about the project:
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/1061304/Presentations/Air%20Quality%20Toolkit.pdf

title: Camp Kick Off Party!
description:
Here's what will be happening:

* Check in: We'll take your picture and get your ID made so that you can get in and out of the building easily. (Don't worry - you won't need this to get in on June 2nd!)

* Party: Starting at 6PM we will have tons of food, drink, and mingling. This will be a great opportunity to meet your fellow campers.

* Announcements: We'll tell you a bit about camp as well as introduce the staff that will be around for the month. This will probably happen around 6:45 or 7PM.

* Hello World session: Starting at 7:30PM we'll have a wide range of "Hello World" sessions running on repeat. They're 20 minutes each so you can get a taste of a few new things before you head home for the night.

For those of you who haven't been to ITP before it is location at 721 Broadway in Manhattan, between Broadway and Waverly. Enter the building and take the south elevators to the 4th floor.

title: How to Teach Yourself How to Code
description:
How To Teach Yourself How to Code
=================================

Led by a person still learning how to code, this session will help you establish a framework for teaching yourself how to code. Having become a bit dissatisfied with the resources currently available for novice programmers, this is a practical workshop designed for new learners without a STEM background.

The two goals in learning how to code successfully is to 

1. always be "productively lost"
2. how to effectively and succinctly articulate what it is that you don't know how to do.

I'll begin by describing patterns I've found across popular programming languages. Next, we will apply those patterns by going through examples. The last third of the workshop will be a summary of resources.

## Agenda 

We will:

* pseudocode a small program 
* Go through best practices for reaching out on mailing lists and IRC
* Setting up an IRC client
* Opportunities to apply your burgeoning skills 
* Overview of some resources. 
* **Extra, extra** ==> A documentation call to action.

[Link to Slides](http://bit.ly/1kHy9eF)
[Link to Resource List](http://bit.ly/1mPqRIG)

title: HTML, CSS, and Javascript Kick Start
description:
Rapid prototyping of web pages with emphasis on the foundations of HTML and CSS. We'll do quick CSS positioning demos and add a little Javascript into the mix to round out the triumvirate of client-side technologies. Targeted towards beginners, but also good for people who want to brush up their skills. 

Led by: Robyn Overstreet 
robynover@gmail.com

title: Intro to the Laser Cutter
description:
Learn how to use the laser cutter.  We will cover drawing in Adobe Illustrator, cutting wood and plastic with lasers, and fabrication tips and tricks. 

Led by: Ben Light
ben@blightdesign.com

title: Video Essentials, Part I: Storytelling, Documenting, & Moviemaking
description: With the ever increasing importance of video documentation for projects, understanding the language of cinematic storytelling can greatly improve the quality of one's video productions. This workshop will provide students with essential visual tools and techniques for effectively conveying their ideas through moving images, as well introduce necessary skills for surviving on video shoots. The fundamentals of pre-production, production, and post-production will be covered, including such topics as shot lists and storyboards, camera angle choice, production planning, lighting basics, set safety, and editing theory.

title: iOS Bootcamp
description:
Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple's native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the "Hello World" stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We'll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.

Note: While this workshop assumes no previous knowledge of Objective-C, some coding knowledge is assumed. Additionally attendees should already be members of the iOS Developer Program, and have access to Apple's provisioning portal before attending the class. If anyone needs any help with signing up to the program, I'll be around ITP all from the start of the camp and I'm happy to help. Attendees should bring a Mac, with the latest version of Xcode installed, and an iOS device of some kind (an iPhone, iPad or iPod touch) along with a cable to connect the two.

title: Learn to use Git and Github for your projects
description:
This is a hands-on class. You must have a laptop.

Coding a project? Do you want to open source your work? Afraid of losing your code?

Git is a commonly used version control software. Github is a online service that makes using Git easy. 

Come and learn how to use Git and Github for your own projects.

Led by Leonard Bogdonoff
lkbgift@gmail.com

title: Getting Creative with C++
description:
Using C++ is hard but it doesn't have to be. When applying creative techniques to C++, a whole world of bits, bytes, glitches and control opens up to you.Using the creative coding framework Cinder, I'll be introducing you to concepts specific to C++ and showing you a large part of cinder. In the class we'll create a particle system and use cinder's vast typographic and design tools. By the end of the class you'll know a large amount of what makes c++ and Cinder great. Come with a passion to learn and an excitement to explore!

Please do the following before classtime: Download Xcode (or similar for windows or linux) and download Cinder (Here: http://libcinder.org/download/). Take a look at Hello Cinder (http://libcinder.org/docs/v0.8.5/hello_cinder.html)

title: Intro to Data Viz + Processing
description:
This session will introduce participants to the basics of data visualization, using the Processing programming language.  We will cover loading data into a sketch, parsing and categorizing it, and creating a variety of basic visualizations.  We will also take a look at different types of data visualization, from screen-based and interactive pieces to the more sculptural, visual, and abstract.

A basic understanding of Processing is recommended.  Bring any data sets or ideas that you'd like to create visuals for!

title: Connecting things with Bluetooth LE
description:
This is a one hour crash course on how to get your iPhoneâ€”or iPad, iPad touch, or even your Macâ€”to talk to your Arduino using the new Bluetooth Low Energy standard. I'll look at the various hardware options, and do a "show and tell" with some of the available hardware that I'll bring along for attendees to look over. 

I'll finish off with a live coding demo that'll walk people through the basics of sending data to and from an Arduino with the classic hardware "Hello World" project; I'll blink an LED on and off, but this time I'll do it from my iPhone (or maybe my Mac, I can't decide) over Bluetooth LE.

title: Beginning Eagle CAD
description:
This class introduces students to the program used in engineering standards, Eagle CAD.  Students will create a schematic and design a circuit in Eagle that can be used to order board from a board house or produce a hand-made printed circuit board.  

by Michelle Temple
michelleleannetemple@gmail.com

title: Network Mapping and Analysis Workshop
description:
This 3 hour workshop focuses on the design and understanding of complex networks through mapping and visual analysis in order to expand the individual's thinking about the network as a creative medium. Starting from hand drawn simple graph diagrams, participants gradually build complex network models. Emphasis on network mapping, modeling, relational thinking, protocol authoring, centrality analysis, clustering analysis, and information design. Participants learn the most through observing and extracting networks from their area of interests, collaborative mapping, sketching, and discussing diagrams.

1hr - How to map networks? Introduction lecture, theory and discussion

1hr - Mapping: Hands on drawing and using Graph Commons

1hr - How to analyze networks? Presentations and analysis

Graph Commons is used at the workshops for collaborative / group mapping, so bring your laptops! http://graphcommons.com More information at the Workshop Archive http://teaching.burak-arikan.com/creative-networking Led by: Burak Arikan http://burak-arikan.com/contact

title: #protip: Learn Adobe Illustrator
description:
Learn the basics and not-so-basics about vector-based graphics and the cool tools used to create them. A good sister class to creative coding in Processing, which uses a lot of the same techniques.

Led by: Sarah Hallacher
http://sarahmak.es

title: Intro to Python
description:
This session serves as an introduction to the Python programming language.  We'll look at applications and projects created with Python, and examine why its simplicity and readability makes it so awesome.  We will then cover basic UNIX commands, Python syntax and structure, and learn text manipulation and generation strategies.  Participants will also learn how to import text or data from external files, and analyze, parse, or remix that info.

Please come with a text editor installed (I like Sublime Text, but there's also TextWrangler or TextMate) and make sure you have Python installed on your laptop.  To check, open Terminal and type "python" (no quotes) at the prompt.

If you get a version number, you're good to go!  If not, please download and install Python (from here: https://www.python.org/download/) prior to the session.

title: Friday Fireside Chat: Clive Thompson
description:
Clive Thompson is a longtime contributing writer for the New York Times Magazine and a columnist for Wired.

As a child growing up in Toronto of the 1970s and 80s, Clive Thompson became fascinated with the first â€œhome computersâ€â€”the ones you plugged into your TV, like the Commodore 64, and programmed using BASIC. He was hooked, spending hours writing video games, music programs, and simple forms of artificial intelligence. The obsession stuck with him, even as he went to the University of Toronto to study poetry and political science. When he became a magazine writer in the 1990s, the Internet erupted into the mainstream, and he began reporting on how digital toolsâ€”everything from email to digital photography to instant messagingâ€”was changing society.

Clive started out pessimistic about the impact of the Internet on life. He worried, like many social critics before him, that society and civility would fall off a cliff. But over the next twenty years he realized that when everyday people were given remarkable powers of self-expression on a global scale, amazing things happened more often than not: Wikipedia, YouTube â€œresponseâ€ conversations, collaborative art, crazy new forms of writing like TV recaps, collaborative problem-solving, and the ESP-like awareness that comes from the status-update universe.

Today, Thompson is one of the most prominent technology writers, respected for doing deeply-reported, long-form magazine stories that get beyond headlines and harness the insights of science, literature, history and philosophy. He specializes in writing not merely on the inventors of technologies, but about how everyday people use themâ€”often quite unpredictably. In addition to the New York Times Magazine and Wired, he writes for Mother Jones and Smithsonian. He is one of the longest-running bloggers, having launched his science-and-tech blog Collision Detection since 2002. In his spare time heâ€™s also a musician, performing in The Delorean Sisters and writing original music as part of the duo Cove. He is married and lives in Brooklyn with his two children.

title: Flying Robots Workshop
description:
It used to be that only governments and news agencies could put eyes in the sky, but as drones become more accessible to the every day person, the status quo stands to be radically altered.

This workshop will serve as an introduction to drones as an artistic and journalistic tool. We'll cover:
- Social and legal landscapes surrounding civilian drone use. 
- Flying AR Parrot drones
-Programming AR drones with node.js 
-Drone journalism and cinematography

title: Turning Data into Matter | Session 1
description:
Data visualization is an everyday part of modern life, especially in the digital age.
Recently, turning data visualization into physical form has revealed itself as the next logical step to visualizing the data around us.

This course will cover:  
    * Session 1, Saturday June 7: a historical and contemporary review of the dataviz field, an intro to datasets as a basis for dataviz, some concepting to extend the provided datasets, beginning of coding your visualizations in Processing. After class, students can follow us on a shopping spree for laser cutting materials.
    * Session 2, Sunday June 8: continuation of coding activity and artefact concept revision, exporting files for the laser cutter, and production on the laser cutter.
    * Session 3, Monday June 9: installation & presentation of your artefacts, global review and future possibilities.

Recommended:
- bring your laptops with Processing & Adobe Illustrator installed
- definitely go to "Intro to the Laser Cutter" on June 3rd @ 6pm
- if you want a leg-up on Processing, go to "Intro to Data Viz + Processing" on June 4 @ 8pm
- anticipate providing a small amount (Â±10$) for materials on Saturday

JC and Bert are two dataviz professionals and hardcore nuts. Bert teaches it at School of Arts, Ghent in Belgium while doing it for his design studio Rekall, and JC does it at Sosolimited as a designer/coder.

title: Futurematic Workshop (morning shift)
description: Futurematic: Canal Street is a design jam to create artifacts from futures that you might find in a street sale a decade, a generation, or a century from today. What are tomorrow's irresistible bargains, knockoffs and impulse buys? Let's imagine and bring them to life! Jointly designed and run by The Extrapolation Factory (NYC) and Situation Lab (Toronto), two renowned creative collectives on the frontier of experiential and guerrilla futures practice, Futurematic provides a compelling way to conceptualize and execute designs for future objects. The process focuses mostly on rapid prototyping and packaging design as ways of exploring and representing possible worlds. The day includes an opportunity to play the Situation Labâ€™s acclaimed imagination game "The Thing from the Future". Futurematic takes place Sunday June 8, 2014. To be able to accommodate more participants, the workshop takes place in two shifts, morning (11am-2pm) and afternoon (2pm-5pm), leading into the opportunity to actually sell the stuff on Canal Street afterwards. THIS LISTING IS FOR THE MORNING SESSION (11AM-2PM). TO SIGN UP FOR THE AFTERNOON SESSION INSTEAD PLEASE CLICK HERE. RSVP as soon as you can in order to help us organize space and materials for everyone!

title: Turning Data into Matter | Session 2
description:
Data visualization is an everyday part of modern life, especially in the digital age. From signage to our daily budget, we use it to understand simple to complex pieces of information in an easy-to-read format. However, it's real potential lies in its ability to reveal new information and understanding of everyday data. It is a way to highlight things differently. This increased understanding provides new points of view that can be inventive, shocking, and even transformative. From the National Geographic to Washington Post, to Nicholas Felton and Giorgia Lupi, "dataviz" is an important tool & contemporary weapon of mass information.
