This extended workshop provides the opportunity to dive into the specifics of data visualization today, and does so in two different/complementary forms: digital and physical. The basic idea of the workshop is: turning data into matter. Information is immaterial. What happens when we transform data into something physical, something we can see, touch, feel and hold in our hands? There is more than one way to get there: we can focus on explaining the data, making something invisible visible, or we might go for a more artistic approach, depending on each participant's interests.

Workshop outline:

We will start with the basic fundamentals, historic evolution, commercial and artistic approaches, various data collection methods, showing examples from science, journalism and the arts.
Then we will each define our general subjects of interest. We'll be using JC's method map from last year's fellow presentation to bridge the gap between idea and execution. We also have some suggestions for a common topic that we could explore as a group.
Then it's time to venture out into the world and collect data.  We will show participants that they can use either analog or digital tools, such as pen and paper, smart phone apps, open data, etc.
Next we'll show how we might turn data into a physical object. The goal is to produce a physical representation of our data visualization using digital or analog fabrication, based on preference.
The final goal is an exhibition of our work.

Schedule:

Session 1: introduction to the field and the workshop
Session 2: project ideation
Session 3: collecting data + shopping for materials
Session 4: teaching digital and analog production tools
Session 5: finalizing + presenting results

Expected audience:

Open to anyone. No technical knowledge or coding skills required. We'll do a quick introduction of Processing and d3, but keep in mind that many interesting dataviz projects can be realized with simple tools. 
On the other hand, if you know a little Processing or a related programming language, then this is a great opportunity to use those skills.

JC and Bert are two dataviz professionals and hardcore nuts. Bert teaches it at School of Arts, Ghent in Belgium while doing it for his design studio Rekall, and JC does it at Sosolimited as a designer/coder.

title: Bluetooth Low Energy doc-a-thon with Tom Igoe, Shawn Van Every,  Don Coleman, and Alasdair Allan
description:
Note: there will be no actual presentation or instruction in this session. We're just going to sit around writing documentation, but LIVE!  

If you want to actually learn something about Bluetooth Low Energy, I recommend instead Don Coleman's ["Understanding Bluetooth LE" session](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2014/session/144), and Alasdair Allan's ["Tearing down the iBeacon" session](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2014/session/35). 

If you've done some work with Bluetooth LE and you want to help us write, or test things, then come along any time from 10 - 6 each of these days.

description:

JC and Bert are two dataviz professionals and hardcore nuts. Bert teaches it at School of Arts, Ghent in Belgium while doing it for his design studio Rekall, and JC does it at Sosolimited as a designer/coder.

title: From Processing to OpenFrameworks
description:
An introduction to OpenFrameworks: learn how your Processing experience translates to OF. Please come with OF and XCode installed: follow these instructions and make sure the emptyExample runs on your computer: http://www.openframeworks.cc/setup/xcode/

By Luisa Pereira, Jihyun Lee
luisa.ph@gmail.com, jihyun.lee@nyu.edu

title: Rhino + 3D modeling Crash Course
description:
This session will cover the basics of 3D modeling in Rhino. We'll talk about curves, surfaces, and solids. 

Before the session begins, please install Rhino:

Macintosh users, download here: 
http://www.rhino3d.com/download/wenatchee/5.0/wip

Windows users, download the trial version here:
http://www.rhino3d.com/download/rhino/5/latest?PageSpeed=noscript

Please also download the sample file I've put together here:
http://davidptracy.com/files/RhinoIntro.3dm

Link to the command cheat sheet:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uqgiBnPsjiGbXIKMy0yyjqSjBtNKoWfLU_bsOrhNqTA/edit?usp=sharing

led by: Counselor David Tracy
davidptracy@gmail.com

title: Make Your Own Printed Circuit Board
description:
Using the heat transfer method, students will etch their own printed circuit boards.  Making your own printed circuit board assures for a more robust circuit/project.  Prior Eagle CAD experience is preferred, however not a necessity. 

NOTE: For safety reasons this session is being limited to 10 participants. It will be run 2 other times -TBA. Please cancel your RSVP if you do not plan to attend.

title: Intro to Pure Data: Making Matter Sing
description:
Intro to Pure Data and Arduino using sensing for sound making. No previous knowledge needed. This hands-on session will cover how to set up Pure Data using both sound synthesis and sound files, to manipulate the data using a range sensors. Focus will be measurements of (invisible)matter in our physical environment. Bring you laptop, headphones, Arduino and any sensor you have. There will be some sensors available during session.

Led by:Eva Sjuve
Eva Sjuve

title: Intro Game Design
description:
What makes a game fun? What makes a game engaging? Can we learn or take something away from games? This 3-hour workshop will involve a crash-course in the theory of game design, an exercise in designing your own (non-digital) games, and lots of play!

Led by Sharang Biswas
sharang.biswas@gmail.com

title: Culinary Physics: Food As Material
description: This class explores the basic principles of food biochemistry and food science as a platform for using food as a material. Students will learn basic principles of molecular gastronomy and modernist cuisine as framing devices for understanding how food also functions in the context of bodily health, environmental health as well as cultural and political narratives. Assignments for the class will be based on the incorporation of food science into design and technology projects that uses food as a substrate to explore and illuminate ideas. Workshops include spherification, reverse spherification and emulsification. First part of the workshop will meet at ITP, 4th Floor of Tisch and the second half will meet over at the NYU Education Building at 35 West 4th Street room 1080 to use the Food Studies Kitchen. Bring a Lab Coat or Chef's Coat!!!

title: Building a ball jar lantern
description:
Learn the basics in programming NeoPixel LEDs, and build a flickering candle in a Mason jar! The NeoPixel is an addressable, full-color LED, that is run with code from a microcontroller (like an Arduino). The addressable part means that you can individually control many LEDs from one data pin. It's popular for all sorts of projects, especially wearables. In this workshop, we'll solder one NeoPixel to a little Arduino-compatible board and program it to flicker like a candle. This won't be an in-depth intro to the Arduino platform or soldering, but first-timers are welcome. I'm going to place a group order which will come out to $19 per jar. If you want to opt out of the group and order separately or not build a jar, please email me at timbartlettpear@gmail.com before Friday 6/6. The parts we're using are listed below just for reference. Before class, please have Adafruit's Arduino IDE (programming environment) installed on your computer (https://learn.adafruit.com/introducing-trinket/setting-up-with-arduino-ide). Please download this even if you already have the Arduino IDE, since this version is required to program the Gemma board that we'll be using. Also download and install the NeoPixel library (https://github.com/adafruit/Adafruit_NeoPixel) for Arduino. Finally, please bring a USB mini cable for programming the board. You can borrow one from ITP while supplies last. =============================================== PARTS (I will order everything for us at a group discount, for a total of $19, unless you email me otherwise.) From Adafruit:
â€¢ Flora NeoPixel 4-pack (you just need one LED)- $7.95 - http://www.adafruit.com/products/1260
â€¢ Gemma Microcontroller - $7.95 - http://www.adafruit.com/product/1222
â€¢2x Coin Cell Battery Holder with Switch - $1.95 - http://www.adafruit.com/product/783
â€¢ CR2032 battery - $1.50 (buy two) - http://www.adafruit.com/product/654 From Elsewhere:
â€¢ Ball Jar and Lid
â€¢ Diffusion
â€¢ Solid Core Hookup cable
â€¢ Solder
â€¢ Double-sided foam tape Led by: Tim Bartlett
timbartlettpear@gmail.com

title: Smart Illusions with Dumb Stuff
description:
In this session campers will get to understand and explore the tools that enable us to see illusions.  We'll discover how we see dimension, how visual cues work, and how we can use them to trick the eye and mind to manipulate human perception.  Among other things campers will experiment with their smart phones and tablets to create images that appear to float in the air.  There are two components to creating an illusion; creating the content and the means to display it.  We'll be doing both.  With imagination as our canvas campers can work in the medium they are most comfortable in whether it be 3D modeling, video, or animation. Be ready to play with common items like duct tape, plastic, and cardboard if you would like to make an illusion of your own.  

Led by: Jason Sapan
drlaser@gmail.com

title: Reviving Urban Spaces through Creative Interventions
description:
We will be using examples from our past work in the field to jump start a conversation around how creative placemaking can turn vacant unused urban spaces into neighborhood destinations. This session will be part lecture, part workshop in order to understand what goes into creating spaces that tell stories, share information, and are interactive. 

We will focus on developing successful strategies to reinvent, re-explore, and rediscover underutilized urban spaces.  There will be particular focus on approaching local government agencies and private companies for support.  Please bring your ideas, questions, and spaces you'd like to see revived.

Led by:
Shagun Singh 
shagun@urbanmatterinc.com 
urbanmatterinc.com

title: Tearing down the iBeacon
description: A one hour crash course on Apple's iBeacon technology. We'll look at off-the-shelf iBeacon hardware like the Estimote and how you can replicate iBeacon functionality with cheap open source hardware, or even more simply, just using software and your laptop (or phone). We'll look at the potential security vulnerabilities of the iBeacon stack and point out where iBeacons should be used, and where it shouldn't.

title: Designing Data Visualizations with d3.js
description:
Our world is brimming with data, and always has been. Now, more than ever, we have the ability to record and access massive amounts of information as well as free tools to work with those records. In this session, we will delve into why a set of data requires depiction, research to uncover the story within, and strive to integrate our visualization and its narrative. 
We will discuss various methods of representing data and learn to design interactive data visualization on the web. We will work with data using the d3/javascript framework and understand its integration with HTML and CSS. 

The course has two main goals: first, to provide grounding in the design of elegant and meaningful data visualizations, and second, to provide a technical introduction to implementing data visualizations using D3 and web technologies.  

Led by Annelie Berner
annelieberner@gmail.com

title: (Cancelled) Commanding the Command Line
description:
We'll cover a bunch of helpful command line tips and tricks that'll help you work faster and feel like a computer wizard. We'll start with the basics, and then move on to topics like cleaning and manipulating data, and batch processing images with Imagemagick. 


Led by: Jen Lowe
jen@datatelling.com
http://datatelling.com/

title: Computer vision in the browser
description:
Ever wonder how facial recognition work? Familiarize yourself with basics of computer vision and javascript. This session will a high level HANDS ON overview of the implemented computer vision technologies, how they work, and most importantly, what you can do with it!

Led by Leonard Bogdonoff
lkbgift@gmail.com

title: Friday Fireside Chat: Hacking Higher Education with Dan O'Sullivan and Clay Shirky
Stupid Hackathon
description:
The STUPID HACKATHON returns to ITP for a special summer session.

The purpose of this HACKATHON is to conceive of, and then create, projects that have no value whatsoever.

You will have a full day to work individually or in small teams to produce worthless projects. Afterwards there will be JUDGEMENT and PRIZES.

The HACKATHON is open to ITP campers as well as year-round students. 

This is a REAL EVENT and likely the ONLY RELEVANT HACKATHON IN THE WORLD.

[Click here see some projects that people made in the first STUPID HACKATHON.](http://www.stupidhackathon.com/)

[WATCH THE STUPID PROMOTIONAL VIDEO HERE.](https://vimeo.com/97500627)

title: Intro to the CNC
description:
Led by Ben Light

NOTE: People who RSVP must commit to attending and come for the whole time. Enrollment limited to first 5 RSVP's. If this is popular we will look into holding more sessions.

title: Family Day!
description:
Come one, come all to Family Day! Bring your kids, significant others, and friends to see what you have been working on and for other fun activities.
We will have:
â€¢ Nerdy Derby
â€¢ Make your own paper speakers
â€¢ Build a wooden toolbox
â€¢ Henna
and more!
Snacks will be provided.

title: Build a Wooden Toolbox
description: Put together an old-timey wooden toolbox.  Fun for the whole family.

title: Art of the GIF
description:
Gifs are all around us (around us, around us, around us)! What are the secrets of these mesmerizing images?  

In this workshop, we will look at some of the best gifs out there, talk about their historical predecessors such as phenakitoscope and other looped moving images. 

We will also learn how to make gifs using photography, original animation, and other popular techniques. We will cover best practices for creating gifs for websites, displaying gifs in processing, and touch on the giphy API, which allows us to harness the power of search for the millions of gifs that already exist for installations or websites.

title: Introduction to the Raspberry Pi
description:
The raspberry pi is a very capable, cheap computer that can be used for all sorts of hardware and software and art projects. Let's explore this platform to understand how it can fit in to existing projects, or inspire new ones.

 Learn How to setup a pi, what the hardware can do, and software. 

Students are required to have: 
a) Raspberry Pi Model B
b) 8GB or larger SD card
c) Power supply + microUSB cable
d) screen + hdmi OR ethernet port on their laptop

title: R in a Nutshell
description:
We'll get to know R, a powerful open source statistical software package that's great for investigating data. We'll cover the most useful commands and libraries, and the common errors to watch out for.

Led by: Jen Lowe
jen@datatelling.com
http://datatelling.com/

title: The evolution of design in Europe
description:
How did mass production affect design? How did Gustav Klimt influence product design and what is a "Women's laboratory"? Those questions will be answered in the course of"The Evolution of European design".

The designed environment lives in a social Context. Design of furniture, clothing, devices, spaces are not neutral. They entail opinions and perceptions of how humans should live and act. In this course will look at how culture and politics influence the design of products. We will analyze the interaction between the designed object and the quality of the social and political life in Europe from the 1900s to today.

Led by: Jessica Covi
jessica.covi@gmail.com

title: Electric Needle Felting
description:
Learn the basics of this simple craft. From puppets to stop motion animation, needle felting can be used to sculpt beautiful wool animals and creatures, or even patch holes in sweaters.

I'll teach the basics of needle felting, show you some techniques you can use to create better sculptures, and we'll play around with using conductive fibers to light an LED.

Give your brain a rest! This is a fun way to think with your hands.

Led by Ken Amarit
kenamarit@gmail.com
http://www.kenamarit.info
http://www.ohmy.me

title: HTML5 Canvas with Javascript
description: The HTML5 Canvas element provides a level of interactivity not seen in previous versions of HTML; much of what once required Flash now can be done in the browser with HTML and Javascript. There are myriad javascript libraries that wrap Canvas functionality for rapid development, but in this workshop we'll look at Canvas unwrapped to get a sense of what the W3C spec is all about.

title: Drawing Dojo
description:
This is not a drawing workshop, but a workshop that makes you draw. Let go of all your preconceptions about what drawing is / should be and show off your artistic side! Led by Shantell Martin and Vicci Ho, this workshop will include a range of exercises that will encourage you to draw spontaneously, to trust your instincts and have fun in the process!

To ensure there is enough drawing material for everyone, we can only accommodate 30 campers in this session.

Led by: Vicci Ho and Shantell Martin
vwh216@nyu.edu

title: Project Enclosure Building
description:
An overview of all of the different types of enclosures you can build for your projects.  We'll cover building a box, panels and stand-offs, ready-mades, and laser cut controller panels.

Led by: Ben Light
ben@blightdesign.com 

blightdesign.com

title: Glitch Yoself!
description:
Apple's photobooth is boring!! Build your own in Processing, then learn a bit about bit-shifting to create a glitchy selfie.

Led by: Sarah Hallacher

http://sarahmak.es

title: Lathe: metal and wood
description:
Both precision parts and sculptural objects can be made on the lathe.  Come learn how to turn wood and metal on the lathe. 

Enrollment limited to first 5 RSVP's.

title: 3d on the web
description: Webgl has brought 3D to the web.  This means that cloud based 3D modeling and animation tools, virtual worlds, games and more are accessible without the need for plugins.  Three.js is the most popular library for creating 3D content on the web.  This session will cover some of the basics of Three.js and provide a grounding to learn more.

title: POSTPONED: Python + Sublime Text
description: Want to work with Python but finding it hard to set up a workflow? This session will get you up and running with Python and installing Python libraries so they all work together in Sublime Text. We'll look at a few useful libraries, like twitter (for accessing twitter data) and nltk (the natural language toolkit - great for working with text).

title: Fireside Lunch with danah boyd
description:
This is a special lunchtime edition of Fireside Chats.

danah boyd is a Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research, a Research Assistant Professor in Media, Culture, and Communication at New York University, and a Fellow at Harvard's Berkman Center for Internet and Society. She is also the founder and president of a new think/do tank called the Data & Society Research Institute. Her research examines the intersection of technology and society. Currently, she's focused on research questions related to "big data", privacy and publicity, and teen culture. Her 2014 book - "It's Complicated: The Social Lives of Networked Teens" - has received widespread praise from scholars, parents, and journalists.

Blog: http://www.zephoria.org/thoughts/
Twitter: @zephoria

title: Friday Fireside Chat: Mark Hansen
description: Mark Hansen joined Columbia Journalism School in July of 2012, after a decade of shuttling between the west and east coasts. In Los Angeles, he held appointments in the Department of Statistics, the Department of Design Media Arts and the Department of Electrical Engineering at UCLA -- literally forming a triangulation of data, art and technology -- and was a Co-PI for the Center for Embedded Networked Sensing, an NSF Science and Technology Center devoted to the study of sensor networks. While in New York, Hansen was a long-standing visiting researcher at the New York Times R&D Lab and a consultant with HBO Sports. Hansen works with data in an essentially journalistic practice, crafting stories through algorithm, computation and visualization. In addition to his technical work, Hansen also has an active art practice involving the presentation of data for the public. His work with Ben Rubin at EAR Studio has been exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Whitney Museum, the Centro de Arte Reina Sofia, the London Science Museum, the Cartier Foundation in Paris, and the lobby of the New York Times building (permanent display) in Manhattan.  Hansen holds a PhD and MA in Statistics from the University of California, Berkeley and a BS in Applied Math from the University of California, Davis.

title: Parametric Fabrication - Modeling the making of things
description:
Connecting physical fabrication techniques with digital processes has aided new forms of artistic expression. With digital modeling software and rapid prototyping tools like 3d printers, CNC routers, and laser cutters, designers can leverage data and algorithmic processes to realize new forms of art. This workshop will explore the modeling software Rhino, an algorithmic plugin Grasshopper, and some of the possiblities for scripting data into real world products.

We will introduce Rhino and Grasshopper. Currently Rhino WIP Beta is available for Mac for free. Grasshopper is a free plugin for Rhino, but currently only supported on Windows.


[Rhino for Mac](http://www.rhino3d.com/download/wenatchee/5.0/wip)

[Grasshopper 3d](http://www.grasshopper3d.com/)

If you don't have Rhino, we will also be exploring Autodesk's free 123D software.

[123D Make](http://www.123dapp.com/make)

[123D Design](http://www.123dapp.com/design)


Led by:
Scott Leinweber
scott@digitaltoolbox.info

title: Oculus Rift Workshop
description:
Ever get tired of real reality and want to escape to a virtual world of your own making?  With emerging consumer-level Virtual Reality products like the Oculus Rift, making immersive, programatic 3D environments is now more possible than ever.  3D programming is very hard, which is why we will be using the Smolder interactive 3D graphics library for Cinder which does all the hard work for us allowing our imaginations to run wild in this intensive one day workshop. 

In the first half of the session we will cover basic 3D programming concepts, downloading/installing/using Cinder and the Smolder Library, and making our first "Hello 3D World" environment. After a break, the second half will be a hands on workshop where students will make their own worlds and at the end we will show and tell our creations! 

Requirements: At least basic to intermediate knowledge of programming required.  Prior knowledge of C++ or Cinder is not required, but encouraged.  

Because it is not out yet, students will only have access to the oculus dev kits at ITP and they are limited in number, so we will be sharing in class. My goal is to show the students that as VR tech begins to hit the market, they can be equipped, at least fundamentally, to engage in this exciting new format.

title: Apply a Great Finish
description:
A great finish can really take a project to the next level.  We will cover how to powder coat metal, apply oil and wax to wooden, and how to polish plastic. 

Led by: Ben Light

title: Interactive Music with the Web Audio API
description:
Web Audio is an HTML5 Javascript API for audio input, playback and synthesis. With expanding adoption in both desktop and mobile browsers, Web Audio is the new frontier for rich and powerful audio applications. Combined with other HTML5 features, Web Audio sets the foundation for a new kind of musical experience combining elements of games, instruments, and music videos all with the ability to be collaborative and distributed instantly around the world over the web. 


The class will provide a high-level overview of Web Audio starting with a survey of existing Web Audio applications. It will give students an overview of digital audio in the context of Web Audio. The later part of the workshop will walk students through getting up and running with Web Audio by demonstrating how to make a simple synthesizer. 


Led by:Yotam Mann
yotammann@gmail.com

title: Space, Light, and other waves
description:
In this session we will look at contemporary practices evolving around lit spaces.
Architectural lighting, projection mapping, DMX controlled environments have migrated into the "mainstream" of creative practices in the past 3-4 years and have become an integral component of nearly any event based creative planning. This session aims to provide participants with an understanding of the basics of these practices focusing on readily available hardware and software. A main focus will be on audio-reactive lighting.

Led by: Neil Hickey
nh724@nyu.edu

title: How to Mount Motors, Servos, and Solenoids
description:
If your project moves chances are you are using a motor or solenoid.  The key to functioning mechanisms is how you mount the movers. 

Led by: Ben Light

title: Video Essentials, Pt. III: Submitting & Promoting Your Video
description:
After spending hours soldering, coding, hacking and fabricating -your awesome interactive project is finally ready. Hooray!
Now it's time to share your creativity with the world. A well documented project could give you the opportunity to present it in international festivals or receive some feedback from the global interactive community.

This workshop would give you a step by step guide to video documentation and online promotion in blogs, festivals,  social networks and on Vimeo ( the biggest creative video social network). We would explore the ways you could identify  & reach specific online communities, how to find and submit your press kit to specific blogs & how Vimeo could help you target and analyze your audience.

title: Robot Recipes
description:
Build durable metal robot toys with cans from last night's dinner.
Led by: Ben Light

title: Talk to Things Around You
description:
Talk to Things Around You is a workshop that explores possibilities of Bluetooth LE (Low Energy) in our lives. BLE technology allows us to set up iBeacons so we can listen and broadcast real time proximity based information. We will focus on setting up high quality user experiences based on these new capabilities.

In this workshop, we will build a simple mobile application that enables us to listen and talk to things around us via Bluetooth LE. Since we are going to use PhoneGap (Cordova) as a tool to build the app, basic web programming is required and basic physical computing skills are recommended.

#BluetoothLE, #iBeacon, #InternetOfThings

Led by Jihyn Lee
jihyun.lee@nyu.edu

title: All You Can Eat APIs
description:
Learn how to pull content from external web sites to use in your applications. We'll use Javascript to quickly parse, process, and output data. We'll fly through a number of APIs, chosen based on the interest of the group. Some possibilities are: Instagram, YouTube, FourSquare, GoogleMaps, Sunlight Foundation, and OpenWeatherMap

Led by: Robyn Overstreet 
robynover@gmail.com

title: Show & Tell & Party Tricks!
description: This is an opportunity to celebrate the end of camp and share what we've made, learned, or even just something fun for the party.

title: Breadboarding Simple Synthesizers
description:
This is a hands-on workshop where we will prototype a simple faux-analog synthesizer on a breadboard using CMOS digital logic gates. 
Please bring headphones or a portable speaker.

title: Henna Stuff
description:
This is a hands on session where we will be learning basic henna patterns. Then hennaing different materials from wooden frames, fabrics, cardboard, etc. with acrylic paints.

Bring in things you want to henna and/or your favorite colors in acrylic paint

title: Comics Storytelling: The Sequential Visual Narrative
description:
Comics have been a pervasive art and literary form and part of popular culture for over a century. Comics feature the combination of images, words, and the ability to move through time, and the interplay between these three elements create unique storytelling possibilities that are applicable beyond the comic medium into such areas as UI/UX design, filmmaking, and animation. In this workshop, students will be introduced to the history of comics, the evolution and implementation of comic storytelling techniques, and various approaches to planning and executing ideas as sequential visual narratives. Students will have the opportunity to learn through in-class exercises which will take them through idea creation, story structure, and execution.

BRING: the drawing materials of your choice (i.e. paper, pens, etc.)

title: Watertight Models for 3D Printing (updated)
description:
This is an overview of methods to build clean models and ways to repair meshes for 3D printing. It will be an introduction to free online applications for optimizing meshes and the problems to look for in the model before it is printed: correct file formats, manifold edges, holes, wall thickness, polygon count, aligned normals.

This will be a demonstration but if you want to follow along I highly recommend you bring a 3-click mouse and install the free software.

Blender: http://www.blender.org/

netfabb Basic: http://www.netfabb.com/basic.php

Notes PDF: https://drive.google.com/?tab=mo&authuser=0#folders/0B5XTenHvIRAJN1R3V3F4X0lkcVE

title: Stuff*Swap
description:
Many folks acquire "stuff" during camp that they don't need afterwards: Books, electronic bits, etc. And, many folks would love to take that stuff off your hands! Let's block off a space for a stuff exchange .. just drop by with the stuff you don't need anymore, and pick up stuff you want. I'm a teacher, so I'm always looking for used things I can play with and learn from.

If we get 10-15 folks who think they'll want to participate, I'll post this to the calendar.

Christina / jenksbyjenks

title: Women, Tech + Dangerous Things
description:
I teach feminism, computing and other things at the NYC iSchool, a public high school downtown. I'm very interested in getting together with folks who have similar interests to learn more about projects, places, and people who are doing exciting work in this space. Topics might range from Double Union (the hacker/maker space for women in SF) to Libs Elliott's Processing Quilts to the Art+Technology Wikipedia Edit-A-Thon.

If we get 10+ RSVPs, I'll post to the calendar. Would also love to hear from folks who are interested in facilitating the conversation.

Christina / @jenksbyjenks

title: Just my Type
description: This session will cover typefaces. We'll look at various styles of type and their historical and cultural associations. The discussion will include a brief survey of mechanical invention related to the design of letterforms. We'll also look at the practice of design. How do you combine typefaces for maximum impact? The differences between type on the web and type in print will be examined.

title: About Animatronics
description:
Animatronics are robots with skins! 
The robots are created from  servos, steppers, sensors and mechanics in conjunction with electronics, then covered with stretchy skin. The skin is often made from silicone or latex, but can also be made from fur.
Famous animatronics include Chucky (movie prop from the 80s) and Teddy Ruxpin and Furbys! Animatronics are used primarily in theme parks and movies.
We will discuss some of the processes by which these things are made, from creating the armature/skeleton, to determining the movement, to making the robotics, to sculpting the skin, and the final animatronic. 
Bring your questions and your creature drawings!

title: Product/UX Research Techniques
description:
This is a participatory workshop on UX research techniques for those who design or build products. (Note that a few of the methods are more applicable to digital products/software). 

* Learn how to properly conduct user testing sessions to get better quality feedback on your prototypes or products. 
* Discover qualitative and quantitative research methods beyond A/B testing and surveys to learn about user attitudes and behavior. 
* Learn when to use which methods before, during and after you have built anything.
* Perfect the art of interviewing for insight

## Submit a Product Problem Scenario 
Since this is a participatory workshop, participants are invited to submit a product problem scenario to use as a context for applying research. Please email me at femmebot@gmail.com no later than Friday, June 6 so we can work out the details in advance.

## A Note about the Wait List
I'm working on putting together another workshop or lectureâ€”depending on how much interest there is. Please add your name on the wait list so I can estimate headcount. [Please fill out this survey](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1HV5zb3tF6uV-POT5zE0MKfPmKbMEA_mjeMDks5Ozn4Q/viewform)  to help me figure out the best date/time and format.

title: Live Electronic Accompaniment - CANCELLED
description:
Sorry fellow campers-- There will be only one session, June 21.  I hope you can attend then.

....

With signal processors and a mixer we'll selectively modulate pre-recorded audio.  Attendees can play with the gear and provide source material.  Participation is encouraged.  This workshop will be free-form so come and go as you want.

For a follow-up June 21st we'll plug in mics to provide live input.

title: Updated! Live Electronic Accompaniment
description:
With signal processors and good speakers we'll discuss and explore audio. Attendees can play with the gear and provide source material. Participation is encouraged. Class will be free-form and stand-up so come and go as you want.

We'll also discuss and explore the physical properties of sound.

Bring any songs on any audio playing device. And BYOB.

Class time has updated too:  Starting at 6:00 we're setting up equipment.  You're welcome to help if that's interesting to you.  Everything should be plugged in around 6:30.  I'll show some examples, invite participation.  Hopeful ascent into free-for-all.

title: YES AND!  Become a Confident Public Speaker Through Comedic Improvisation!
description:
Become a better public speaker and creative brainstormer through comedic improvisation!  

Everyone at ITP Camp has brilliant brain worms, and exciting ideas to share; learn how to own an audience and speak about your ideas without inhibition or apology!  

Improv is also a fantastic team-building device!  

I will be teaching the basics of comedic long-form improvisation: "yes-anding," playing at the top of your intelligence, and supporting your fellow team members.  

We will be moving around a bit, so wear your prancercise outfit!  

About me...
I have been doing improv, and musical improv for the past two years training under the lovely comedic minds of:  Chelsea Clarke, Patrick Clair, Doug Moe, Shannon O'Neill, Amber Petty, Ashley Ward, Chris Grace, Geoff Garlock, Lydia Hensler, Jody Shelton, and Brian Faas.  I have performed at UCB, The Pit, QSIC, Chicago City Limits, and other fancy places like bars.  

*15 people max (but I have added a new session!): http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2014/session/164

title: Making lots of things with Processing - Objects and Arrays
description:
Object-oriented programming is a widely used pattern in the computer science world and it makes programming in processing even more powerful and fun!  But whats more fun than learning how to make a single object in Processing?  Learning how to make and manage thousands of them with just a few lines of code!

In this two hour session we will learn about Classes (objects, methods, constructors, and member variables) and how to create, store and manipulate them by the droves by using arrays and array lists.

title: Processing Designs
description:
When you see a Processing project that you admire, do you ever wonder how the program actually works and why it does what it does? In this session, we will present cool Processing projects we have done, with an emphasis on explaining the design and implementation of the project. You can learn from working examples to see how Processing is actually used in wild.

For the first hour, Tomas, Nien and I will present several Processing projects, spending about 10 minutes on each to show you the code and explain the salient points of how they work. For the second hour, as a group we will think through technical design approaches for new ideas. 

If you have Processing experience and are interested in sharing your work in this session, Tomas and I would love to hear from you.

title: DIY Radio Station - Broadcast Live or Stream Audio Over FM Using Raspberry Pi
description: Here's the link to the slides for this session: Click here Start your own pirate radio station or broadcast your own voice, live on any FM radio! Using the Raspberry Pi as your transmitter and some simple open source code, this session will cover the basics of creating an antenna, running the code, and tweaking performance. UPDATE Hi everyone, I'm going to change things up a bit so more people can attend. Per request, this is now more of a demonstration and explanation session than a hands on one. You will not need to own a Raspberry Pi or SD card to attend, and you don't have to bring anything either. I will give out the FM radio image file on hand so you can put them on your laptop, and show you how to put the file on an SD card so you can use it on your Raspberry Pi. It's not required anymore, but if you'd like to buy a Pi, however, you can do so at the NYU Bookstore; I recommend getting an SD card with at least 4GB as well.

title: Storytelling Workshop
description: We all have a story to tell.  Whether it's a story that spans your entire life, a story about a particularly meaningful sandwich you once had, or the story behind a project you're working on.  This workshop will talk about crafting a narrative, outlining,narrowing down your story to a 6-10 minute format, and then look at how to convey that story out loud.  If you have a story you would like to bring in, please do!  If you don't, that's ok too, but do expect to tell something out loud to the group by the end of the workshop.

title: Creating the conditions for invention
description:
Come and learn what you need to unleash invention!

WE TRIED ALL THE SYSTEMS THAT HAD BEEN TRIED BEFORE, THEN WE TRIED OUR OWN SYSTEMS AND WE TRY SOME COMBINATIONS THAT NO ONE HAD EVER THOUGHT OF. EVENTUALLY, WE FLEW. 
â€“ORVILLE WRIGHT, INVENTOR OF THE AIRPLANE

Allowing people to experiment, take risks, and play with their own ideas, gives them permission to trust themselves and they begin to see themselves as learners who have good ideas and can transform those ideas into reality. While inventing we need to acknowledge that there is more than one right answer and that gives us permission to feel safe while learning and problem solving.

I'll be teaching how to use digital fabrication and design thinking to foster invention, specially for learning environments.

About me :) I have been designing learning environments and invention programs for the last few years. I trained under the Stanford d.school and the Transformative Learning Technologies Lab with Prof. Paulo Blikstein

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Every Camper is required to take one shop Safety Session!

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Required for every Camper!

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Required for all Campers!

title: Digital Fabrication in Learning Environments
description:
What are the next generation users like? We'll take a look at the experience and understanding that high school users from different backgrounds have operating cutting edge technology for the first time. 

KNOWLEDGE IS TREATED LIKE MONEY, TO BE PUT AWAY IN A BANK FOR THE FUTURE
--PAULO FREIRE

I'll be showing examples of successful programs that include digital fabrication in learning environments, such as schools, museums and after school programs. I'll be teaching what are the best practices for developing a Maker Spaces or FabLab for students. 

About me... I have been designing learning environments and invention programs for the last few years. I trained under the Stanford d.school and the Transformative Learning Technologies Lab with Prof. Paulo Blikstein

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Required for all campers!

title: Connecting Arduino to Node.js
description: Ever wanted to make a web interface that could control an Arduino?  Tom Igoe will show you how, using the node serialport library and websockets and a little REST.  BYO Arduino, download node.js onto your computer and come out for the fun.

title: Espruino -- Microcontrollers meet JavaScript
description:
[http://www.espruino.com/]Espruino is a new microcontroller board that runs JavaScript. Despite a horrible name (come on, the Italians have 30 words for coffee, you couldn't pick one rather than make up a word?), it's pretty interesting, and no one's really used it yet. Let's get together and hack on it for a bit, see what we can make it do. 

This session will be more group experimentation than instruction. I'll assume you know some JavaScript and the basics of microcontrollers. I'll give you the basic intro, then we'll sit around seeing if we can get it to do anything.  We'll have half a dozen Espruinos on hand to experiment with, but you can also get your own from https://www.adafruit.com/products/1887

description: Required for all Campers!

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Required for all Campers!
