description: Required for all Campers!

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Required for all campers!

title: Activating Wearables
description:
Wearables have been all over the internet and are making their way into our homes! In this workshop you will explore the basics of wearable technology from soft circuits to smart fabrics. In the first part of this workshop you will be presented with different forms of wearable technology and future speculations of how it will integrate into our lives. We will discuss different ways to create responsive environments through interactive wearable design. In the next part you will get to make your own project with a special sample kit of low-tech sensors, electronic textile components, and special fabrics that you can purchase at the class! You will learn fundamental concepts of analog circuit skills that will guide through simple example projects and allow you to explore deeper into the realm of wearables. The focus of the project will be on using our own physical actions to activate different outputs on wearable objects, but you will be encouraged to use your imagination to envision different mechanism and reactions. 

Basic sewing kit will cost $10/person. Feel free to bring your own fabrics, and e-textiles parts to incorporate.
No electronics experience necessary. Basic sewing skills recommended.

title: Video Essentials, Pt. II: Video Editing Fundamentals
description:
This workshop will provide an overview of all aspects of video editing and storytelling. Through examples, we'll discuss best practices, tips, tricks, and techniques for all interested in video editing (no experience required). 

Emphasis will be on techniques and approaches rather than the nitty-gritty of tools; we'll talk about basic theory behind editing and structuring video pieces (both documentary and narrative), techniques to keep footage organized and properly export Quicktime files, and sound. We'll also do a quick overview of different editing program options, and do a walkthrough of basic tools in Premiere Pro.

title: Understanding Bluetooth Low Energy
description:
Bluetooth Smart, or Bluetooth Low Energy, introduces lots of terms: ATT, GATT, profiles, services, characteristics, descriptors and declarations. This talk attempt will to demystify Bluetooth Low Energy and explain it in human friendly terms.

I'll demo using generic clients to control Bluetooth peripherals and look at how to write code to interact with peripherals.

There will be time for questions and discussion.

title: The inevitability of Smart Dust
description:
Iâ€™d argue that the era of the commodity beige box is coming to an end, and the days of the general purpose computer are almost over. Most people never needed or wanted a computer, and theyâ€™re going to be happy with more limited devices optimised for a single, or a few, purposes so long as those devices just work. Today the black rectangle has replaced the beige box, but donâ€™t get too comfortable, because it wonâ€™t last as long. Todayâ€™s cellphones and tablets are transition devices, dependent on our current level of technological progress, and around you everyday objects are already becoming smarter.

In ten yearsâ€™ time, every piece of clothing you own, every piece of jewelry, and every thing you carry with you will be measuring, weighing and calculating. In ten years, the world â€” your world â€” will be full of sensors. The end point of this evolution is already clear: itâ€™s called smart dust. General purpose computing, sensors, and wireless networking, all bundled up in millimeter-scale sensor motes drifting in the air currents, flecks of computing power, settling on your skin, ingested, will bemonitoring you inside and out, sensing and reporting â€” both for you and about you.

title: Hands on Intro to Processing
description:
In this short introduction we are gunna get our hands dirty with Processing and make some balls bounce and some interactions happen.  This session is for people that have not ever used Processing or those who want a refresher on how to get started. 

We will download Processing, learn about how to set up a new sketch, how to access built-in functions and variables, and how to add a library.

Campers will walk away with a couple sketches and a headfull of knowledge.

title: Intro to javascript in AI
description: Scripting in Adobe Illustrator can be powerful. You can create complex data visualizations or parametric designs like you do in Processing and it's already in vector format! In this session we will learn how to code simple tool blocks in Javascript for any number of specific tasks like rounding all the corners, randomize colors, create fractal systems, and much more.

title: GitHub - The Best CMS Ever (!?) (or how to use GitHub and GitHub Pages to host a site quickly and for free!)
description:
GitHub - The Best CMS Ever (!?) (or how to use GitHub and GitHub Pages to host a site quickly and for free!)
=====

__Time__: Maybe an hour tops

__Objective__: publish a "static" site and manage its content through git or online tools for free on GitHub

__Description__: Github has a feature called [pages](https://pages.github.com/).  It basically lets you host a site on GitHub just by pushing your code to a GitHub repository.  You can write your pages in plain HTML and CSS, or you can use MarkDown.  You can use git or GitHub's web interface to manage your content.  



Here's what we can go over in detail:

* a few basic git commands
* a whirlwind tour of GitHub
* some simple Markdown
* jekyll (static site generator)

title: Editing Text with vim
description:
Text Editing with vim
=====

__Time__: About 30 minutes

__Objective__: Edit some text using vim

__Description__: vim (obligatory [wiki](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VIM) and [game](http://vim-adventures.com/)) is the most difficult text editor to use.  Ever. So... if you now it a little bit, you'll look suuuuper 1337.  Or, at least you'll be able to edit files on a remote server.

Some things to know about vim/vi:

* it's kind of the defacto text editor in Unix and Unix like operating systems(most likely installed by default on whatever system your own, like Ubuntu or even OSX).
* can be used within terminal / the commandline
* consequently all commands are keyboard driven (no mouse or trackpad here!)
* [commands can be constructed like sentences, and they tell your text editor what to do](http://yanpritzker.com/2011/12/16/learn-to-speak-vim-verbs-nouns-and-modifiers/)
* ...and because of that, is pretty powerful!

In any case, I can talk about how to use vim, since it's the text editor that I use daily (maybe not such a great life choice, but _whatevs_).

title: Node.js, Express, and MongoDB
description:
Node.js, Express, and MongoDB
=====

__Time__: 1 or 2 hours

__Objective__: Create a tiny, real-time web app using Node.js, Express, and MongoDB

__Description__: Soooo... I'm choosing a web framework to teach for a full semester class on web development this Fall.  I'm thinking of using a few technologies that I'm not so familiar with: 

* [Node.js](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nodejs), a server-side JavaScript framework, 
* [Express](http://expressjs.com/), a minimal web framework, and...
* [MongoDB](http://www.mongodb.org/), a document oriented (er... _NoSQL_?) database.  

_Do you want to be my test group_?  Maybe we can build a quick real time web app using Node, Express and MongoDB (and possibly even Angular!).  We can talk about how this particular set of technologies differ from more traditional set ups, like Ruby/Ruby on Rails, Python/Django, PHP/ ... etc.

Fair warning, I'm using this workshop as a chance to learn these techs myself... this will be a bit _more_ on the casual side.

title: Intro to Programming Using Python
description:
Intro to Programming Using Python
=====

__Time__: 1 or 2 hours

__Objective__: Write some simple Python programs

__Description__:So... you might know Python from some fancy websites like Pinterest or Instagram (or, I guess, [Python's cameo on xkcd](http://xkcd.com/353/)).  Or perhaps you've used the original Bittorrent client (c'mon, I know you did!), which was also written in Python.  In any case, Python is a super friendly language, and it's great for beginners.  I'll try to cram in one semester's worth of material into 2 hours.  

Some things we may go over:

* basics
  * values and types
  * operators and built-in functions
  * control structures
  * various data structures, like lists, dictionaries, etc.
* intermediate stuff
  * list comprehensions
  * decorators
  * generators

title: Art from Data....human data portraits and the future of surveillance
description:
Come ready to open your mind that in the very near future...art is the thing that will make data sticky. Everything about us is known or will be known - what if we could see begin to see ourselves as pattern? Human data portraits. 

I talk about how I came to experiment with self-tracking data, show lots of images of data and the resulting hand-built art and installations. Demonstrate the secrets of using Tableau for data visualization, yes...it's coming soon on a Mac. See links at bottom for downloading free version. And we can talk about transparency, privacy and what it might all mean.

Iâ€™ve been experimenting with a future where everything about us can be instantly measured and significantly added to my daily regimen to develop a patterned vocabulary and language for self-tracking. Steps walked, calories expended, weight, sleep cycles, time-online, activities, location, daily mood, micro-journal of food ingested are all part of my daily tracking -- simple and easy to collect using iphones and gadgets that point toward a time where complete self-surveillance is the norm. My current motto about self-tracking data is "don't hide...get more".

Tableau is amazing for doing really fast 'what-if' on massive amounts of excel data for both numerical and content type data. You can run Tableau public on a virtual environment or Windows. Link to free trial here. 
http://kb.tableausoftware.com/articles/knowledgebase/tableau-public-system-requirements

http://www.geekwire.com/2014/tableau-mac-coming-finally/

This is me: http://www.lauriefrick.com/

title: Conductive Lace
description:
Crochet, knitting, bobbin lace â€” join this session if you want to explore possibilities of lace as conductive material and if you want to learn basics of bobbin lacemaking.

Iâ€™ll bring some supplies, but you are welcome to bring your own if you wish. Thatâ€™s a hands-on session.

title: Single page JavaScript Web Applications
description:
Introductory session on modern front end web development.

Tools you will need: 
- Firefox browser with Firebug plugin installed.
- Sublime Text, or IntelliJ

We will use HTML5, JavaScript, CSS to start simple, and see if we want to go further, where, why and how.

We will touch up on design patterns: MVC and MV* approach.

We may want to get a glimpse on useful tools and libraries. 

We will most definitely use debugging tools to see what's going on behind the stage.

Please note that this is not an absolute beginner session: it would be nice if you had some prior understanding of programming.

title: Firmata - Simple Communication between an Arduino and a Computer
description:
Many projects require values to be passed from an arduino to a computer or vice versa. Reading sensors or testing servos, for example. Firmata eliminates the need to rewrite your own communication protocol each time you start a new project (remember how much of a pain handshaking is?!) and allows you to quickly test hardware in a language and environment you already use such as Processing, openFrameworks C/C++, Node.js, etc.

In this workshop we'll talk about what Firmata is, when to use it, and how to do so. Please bring a computer with the Arduino IDE installed, an Arduino UNO or compatible microcontroller and any sensors, knobs, inputs or outputs you want! We'll spend some time talking, and then we'll start playing around and remixing each others' hardware and software.

title: Even better search: Google like a pro
description:
You may think you're a Google super user but there's always more to learn about this ludicrously powerful tool. Join me for an hour-long session with live demonstrations followed by hands-on interactive search challenges. 

Background:
While at Google I volunteered with the Search Education team to help teach search literacy and develop educational materials. I'll spend a few minutes on the 'common' advanced options and useful tips like figuring out what to make for dinner based on ingredients in your fridge before we dig into the really weird and cool stuff, such as how to find a book title if you only remember the color of the cover.  

To bring:
A laptop.

title: CUT. IT. OUT. Analog-to-Digital Collage + photoshop
description: Bring your old newspapers, magazines, embarrassing poster collection from college, and unloved books (single tear) and get ready to cut 'em up! Learn the art of collage and bring your creations alive in the digital world! This workshop will help you with basic photoshop chops, layout and design skills for the coolest collage, and maybe even a gif or two.

title: YES AND! Become a Confident Public Speaker Through Comedic Improvisation!
description:
Become a better public speaker and creative brainstormer through comedic improvisation!

Everyone at ITP Camp has brilliant brain worms, and exciting ideas to share; learn how to own an audience and speak about your ideas without inhibition or apology!

Improv is also a fantastic team-building device!

I will be teaching the basics of comedic long-form improvisation: "yes-anding," playing at the top of your intelligence, and supporting your fellow team members.

We will be moving around a bit, so wear your prancercise outfit!

About me... I have been doing improv, and musical improv for the past two years training under the lovely comedic minds of: Chelsea Clarke, Patrick Clair, Doug Moe, Shannon O'Neill, Amber Petty, Ashley Ward, Chris Grace, Geoff Garlock, Lydia Hensler, Jody Shelton, and Brian Faas. I have performed at UCB, The Pit, QSIC, Chicago City Limits, and other fancy places like bars.

*15 people max

title: Digital Literature: Making Poetry Cool Again
description:
Digital Literature uses computers and technology to present text in a new way. This could mean playing with the visual form of the words on the screen, adding sound to words, weaving text into images, all kinds of things.

This class will cover some notable works of digital literature, and lay out a framework for adapting your own writing to the digital realm. Class will be predominately lecture with some time for spitballing ideas at the end.

All types of writers welcome, or just literature fans looking to explore something new.

--------------

About Me: https://medi.ci/toddanderson

title: Intro to the Laser Cutter - another round
description:
This is the same as the 6PM session!

Learn how to use the laser cutter. We will cover drawing in Adobe Illustrator, cutting wood and plastic with lasers, and fabrication tips and tricks.

title: AutoHotkey for Fun, Profit and Projector Art
description:
AutoHotkey is a PC-only scripting utility that can be used to auto-replace/expand text, send keystrokes, seamlessly open and switch between programs and even make music. 

It can be used to dramatically speed up your workflow by automating common actions and phrases, but it also happens to be great for projector art since it gives you unparalleled control of what shows up on the screen using only a few keystrokes.

I will be covering both business and artistic applications of AutoHotkey including text manipulation, running and switching programs and playing sounds.

Please bring a PC laptop (sorry Mac users!) with AutoHotkey installed to get the most out of this session, though if you just want to watch and take notes that is ok too.

title: Hack Your Brain
description:
Let's play games with our brains and each other! 

In this session we will explore perception with hands on fun. Expect to experience visual and tactile illusions, and if you're lucky some hallucination. After each activity I'll chime in with a brief neuroscience explanation of what you experienced and why it happened.

Disclaimer: If you have issues with touching other people, being touched, sensory deprivation or lying on the floor- this session is probably not for you.

title: ITP Camp 2014 Book Club - Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
description:
Read science fiction classic work by Philip K Dick, "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep."

To be followed by a discussion and viewing of the film adaptation, "Blade Runner."

But we're open to other ideas.

-Ray

title: Interactive Graffiti and Street-Art
description:
Graffiti and street art are the coolest things that happens to the graphic art world at the last years-

Through this session we'll see how technology contribute to the Graffiti development from the early 80's till today Interactive and technical street art.

In this session i'll share artists works who  deals mainly with interactive methods in the streets.

I promise it's going to be fun :)

title: Your Video Game Politics are Fucking Boring
description:
Video games are becoming more and more pervasive in our daily lives, but they're generally played it pretty safe in their portrayal of society, their history, and the general gaming world. We'll spend some time learning about the alternative history of the gaming industry, how we got to the place we are today, and what is going on with video games now.

Depending on interest, I can also run a super fast crash course on Unity and how to get started making your own video games!

title: Introduction to humans (1)
description:
Have you ever wondered what is the bandwidth of our perceptual system? Have you ever thought about what do we mean by seeing, hearing, or touching? What are the foundations and the limits of our sensing of the world? How would modeling that impact on our interactive designs be? 

These and many other questions will be left unanswered in this session! However, we will introduce some models that get us closer to understanding the humane component of interaction.

We will discuss some models of perceptions, we'll see some truly bizarre facts, and we will do some experiments too!

The session will finish with a brief discussion of the possible impacts of these models on our interactive designs, including a couple of examples of "good" and "bad" designs.

Also, if at the end of the session is enough interest, a follow up session will be proposed :) 

Session led by Tomas Laurenzo 
(http://laurenzo.net / tomas@laurenzo.net / @krahd)

title: CRYPTOPARTY
description:
Be as cool as Edward Snowden!

Learn how to use PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) to securely send and receive emails.

Learn more about crypoparties here:
https://www.cryptoparty.in/

title: (Cancelled session) Hacking visual design
description:
This session will cover the basic principles of visual design. You will get to know about typography, grid-systems, color, hierarchy and go through the basic steps of designing a product (brainstorming, researching, analyzing, prototyping, etc.)
Be ready to give feedback, since examples of successful and not very successful designs will be shown.

title: Kickstarter School
description:
Hi! My name is John, ITP '09, currently lead for tech and design partnerships at Kickstarter. I will take you through a short presentation on what Kickstarter's all about, what the trends our in our product and tech categories, and and  share some stories about specific projects we've had come through our site.

The Q&A is the most fun, so we'll have plenty of that. Show up! I usually do this for hardware incubators and big project creators, so I'm looking forward to bringing it back home.

title: Server-side Web Development 101 with Servi.js
description:
Sam Lavigne and Shawn Van Every go through the basics of server-side web programming using servi.js, a JavaScript and Node.js framework inspired by Processing.

servi.js makes it easy for beginners to get started developing server-side web applications. In this session we'll show you how to use servi.js to serve static files, store and retrieve data in a database, leverage cookies, handle form data, and more.

title: KINECT the dots
description:
What the heck is a kinect and why do people keep talking about it?! 

Well I will tell you in this 2 hour hands-on session.

We will learn about getting setup with processing and the kinect camera, how to get and work with the depth data. 

This device is great for tracking and sensing presence, perhaps it will be how the interaction on your project works!

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Mandatory for all campers!

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Required for all Campers

title: Intro to Arduino : Digital Input & Output
description:
A quick introduction to the basics of digital input and output with Arduino. Suitable for beginners, or the curious.

Bring an Arduino, breadboard, LEDs, switches, resistors, and a USB cable if you have them! Don't be shy!

title: Intro to Arduino : Analog Input and Output
description:
A basic introduction to analog input and output with Arduino. Suitable for beginners, the curious, or skeptics.

Bring an Arduino, breadboard, LEDs, switches, variable resistors, servos, piezos, and a USB cable to play along. (You don't have to bring this stuff, but you may want to).

title: Intro to Arduino : Serial Communication
description:
A crash course on serial communication with Arduino and a software of your choosing. Experience with Arduino (like the 2 other intro sessions) would be beneficial, but not necessary. 

Drop a note in the comments about what programming language you want to communicate with an Arduino, and I'll do what I can to accomodate. At the bare minimum, I'll be addressing Processing and Max/MSP/Jitter.

title: Physical Product Prototyping and Small Series Manufacturing
description: I will tell you how professionals prototype their designs, how to do it using tools and materials available at home and where to get tools if you don't have any, I will also mention resource to get help with it. Moving from prototyping to manufacturing could be tricky, I will mention the various prototypes you should have available before you move on to manufacturing. Small series is something that one can do before going large, or instead, not all products have to be mass produced. I will talk about how to achieve that, how to use the tools and professionals available to you and how to move from the previous faze to this one, as well as what's next? Here you can see the slides that I'm planning on using

title: Intro to Metal Lathe
description: Kina and Wyna will go over how to do things on the metal lathe!

title: New Media Dinner Party
description:
**Because of the nature of this small gathering/session I'm not using the RSVP's in a typical way.** So, please ignore the RSVP max for this event. I'm planning for a total of 12 seats. Folks who have contacted me directly, you know who you are, just confirm with me in person. If you are waitlisted, also come talk to me in person-I'm at ITP everyday. Event description follows:

A memorable dinner party is more than its accumulated parts. The music, food, wine, flowers and table dressings are only players in the overall experience. The energy captured in your experience makes or breaks the gathering. I endeavor to lead the construction of a dinner party made magical through technology that affects lighting, music, and table top/ food aesthetics.

I'm looking for collaborators! I need the aid of others who specialize in programming, electrical wiring and videography. In exchange for their help those individuals will have a seat at the dinner party and due credit attributed at the end of the event video which will be produced for publication on Vimeo.

This is going to be so much fun, but it's hands on and will be an intimate gathering. If you want to join me please let me know. For more information please read the full proposal on my profile page under the projects tab.

**This event will be limited to RSVPs and a donations for the cost of food are encouraged.**

title: Atoms>>Bits>>Atoms: Cost Effictive 3D Scanning for 3D Printing
description:
This session will give an overview of several techniques for 3D scanning objects from the world around us. We'll attempt to quickly cover photogrammetry using solutions such as 123D Catch or Agisoft PhotoScan as well as various Kinect based solutions such as ReconstructMe, Skanect and Sense. 

After reviewing these various techniques for generating 3D meshes, we will then look at how to convert them to watertight meshes using the free Netfabb Basic tool (http://www.netfabb.com/ ) . 

[Lecture Slides Link](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/10WVqi7hC4Jd0NoNmZTAmvM3N878e-9NqQHWDsGrsM8U/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Yoga Break!
description: Let's move around!  Mats will be provided, all levels welcome.

title: Yoga Break!
description: Let's move around!  Mats will be provided, all levels welcome.

title: Let's Get Zazzy with Zbrush!
description: Zbrush is a very powerful artists tool for 3D modeling, but if you're like me you are very confused as to what is going on in it. In this crash course, I'll walk you through the basics of navigating the program, using the brush system, masking, working with topology using dynamesh, deformation, the Transpose tool and working with subtools. We'll finish up by using the 3D print exporter.

title: Yoga Break!
description: Let's move around!  Mats will be provided, all levels welcome.

title: Yoga Break!
description: Let's move around!  Mats will be provided, all levels welcome.

title: Everything You Wanted to Know About Book Publishing and the Industry
description:
WHAT THIS SESSION ISN'T

A get rich quick guide to becoming a best-selling author, or a crash course in finding a publishing job. There are plenty of courses, blogs, and books on these topics (in fact, I can recommend some very good ones to you). 



WHAT IT IS

This is instead a session covering what the business of publishing is, where to look if you're thinking about turning your work into a book or ebook, and how to approach publishing industry professionals about it. I will cover topics such as:

--The current state of the publishing industry, and the impact of growing ebooks sales; what this means for the future of the industry

--Turning an idea into a book, asking yourself if someone will actually buy it, and if not, when to publish anyway

--Getting your book or ebook to a publishing house--where and when to look for someone to do the hard work of selling your book for you

--What editors and art directors want from an aspiring author or illustrator; finding an agent and why you may or may not need one

--Self-publishing (and therefore, self-promoting, self-distributing, and self-marketing); say goodbye to sleep



I've worked in the trade book publishing industry for almost eight years. I know quite a bit about editorial, production, and design, having worked in managing editorial for a couple of years and at the copy editing department several more. My photographer friend and I self-published a concert photography book a couple of years ago and we learned much about the self-publishing process. I've also interned at various publishing houses and worked freelance for them too. I know a bit about adult fiction and non fiction, young adult (YA) books, children's picture books, and a tiny bit about educational, scientific and scholarly publishing (journals and textbooks); I'm also up to date on current on trends in the industry.

https://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=81070541&trk=nav_responsive_tab_profile

title: Canoeing in the Anthropocene
description:
The New Jersey Meadowlands is fascinating recovering wilderness that is in a tidal wetland just 9 minutes by train from Penn Station.

This will be an opportunity to do a day-trip using rented kayaks and canoes from the Hackensack River-Keepers. We'll have a chance to explore abandoned railroad tracks, garbage dumps, and old factories. We'll also be on the look out out cormorants, muskrats, and herons. I've led several multi-day trips through Meadowlands so I have plenty of stories to share. 

We'll stop for lunch and talk about wilderness in the not-to-distant future, superfund sites, tidal surges, and invasive species. 

The weather is supposed to be perfect. Sunny and 82F with a high tide at 12:20pm. We'll be switching to solo kayaks which will be faster and let you explore more on your own. There will be 1-2 canoes if you'd prefer that.

We'll meet at 9am at Penn Station and get on the 9:14am train to Secaucus Junction stop. Let's meet under the huge black timetable board in the middle of the Amtrak portion of the station. My cell is 971.404.1463 if you need to reach me. Please buy your train ticket before we meet up; round-trip, New York Penn Station to Secacus Junction. 
There's an app for the that: http://www.njtransit.com/var/var_servlet.srv?hdnPageAction=MobileTicketingTo

Please bring:
    - a pack lunch
    - water (a least a liter)
    - sunscreen
    - rubber boats or shoes that can get muddy
    - a hat and sunglasses
    - $25 for the kayaks and $4 (I think) for the train.
    - if you bring a camera, bring a dry bag. (I'll bring a couple of extras)


Some links on the Meadowlands history and Hackensack Riverkeepers:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Jersey_Meadowlands
http://hackensackriverkeeper.org/
http://mec.rst2.edu/environment/
Robert Sullivan's book:
http://www.amazon.com/Meadowlands-Wilderness-Adventures-Edge-City/dp/0385495080

title: Stalking the Wild Street Art-  Rescheduled
description:
A tour of the latest and liveliest -- in the Bushwick area of Brooklyn --  led by my wonderful colleague Charlene Weisler who has hunted and photographed street art since its early glory days.

Leaving from ITP camp building lobby at 10.  (DOWNSTAIRS)

Brooklyn residents can meet us at the Jefferson Street stop on the L train at 10:45.    Please let us know if you plan to do so.  (Already expecting Ms.'s Frick & Otero to meet there.)
tag_list: monsters!   visual mayhem!  where is zeitgeist heading?

title: Technically Creative: Technical Drawings, Diagrams, and Design Process
description:
We will break down a creative idea into manageable chunks. The processes we will review are practical steps to help bring a chaotic dream into an ordered reality. I have done a number of hardware, software, and sculptural projects that use some of these elements. 

**Class Outline** 
---
First Half
---
*Processes:*

 * Centered Problem Solving

 * Project Diagrams

 * Technical Specification  

 * Flow Diagram

 * Material Resourcing


---
Break: 10min 
---

---
Second Half
---
*Software:*

   * Sketch - 2D interfaces

   * SketchUp - 3D printing 

   * Illustrator - Laser Cutting

*Resources:*

* 3D Warehouse

* Data Resources: Data.gov and how to unearth the data you want.

---
Class Details
---
**Centered Problem Solving** is the method of putting yourself in another person's shoes so you understand what causes them pain and what makes them happy. This process will look at how you solve problems for people you've never met. The best way to do this is by talking to people, doing second hand research, and being open to surprises. You will be wrong sometimes, do be prepared to throwing your ideas away and be wrong early. 

P.S. Don't be anthropocentric, these principle can be used to solve problems for animals, plants, the climate or whatever. It is a centered approach to thinking.

**Project Diagrams** look at encapsulated constituent components and connects them in a logical way. For instance, a new pair of shoes need shoe laces, socks, and the shoe bodies. How do we fit them together to make something awesome? This illustrates how the parts make a whole.

**Tech Specs** analyzes what aspects of a component are required to work for the project. The shoe laces must be 12in for dress shoes, but 26in for lace up boots. What color, what material, what thickness etc? The wrong size screw can hold a project up for hours, a missing sensor for days, an unknown variable for weeks. Plan ahead! 

**Flow Diagram** think about how your project lives in the real world. Are your shoes on display? Are they in a production line for 10,000 units? Are they going to space? This process looks at how the project fits into the real world.

**Resource Acquisition** is the art of collecting the appropriate elements to execute you vision. Where do I get the leather for the shell of the shoes? Where do I find the 3D printer with the right material to print the sole? Where do I find aluminum sheeting for the aglets on my shoe laces? This part I affectionately call enphysication - making your dream a reality. In software, this is finding the frameworks, libraries, and people you need to make the project.

This will be covered in a way generic enough to apply to Software, Hardware, and Sculpture, or whatever you can imagine. 


The Second Half of the class will look at the best programs and resources I have found to execute my designs and communicate my vision. These programs help fill in the gaps that sketching and concepting miss. The more you translate your physical designs to digital assets the easier it is to document, reuse, and communicate your ideas.

Physical drawing are wonderful, but you can only ever have one copy, and you can't undo changes. Whiteboarding is cool, but only people drawing with you at the time will understand the images.

This is how we make order from imagination. I look forward to sharing my process with you. 

Thanks!

James W. Donovan

James@DonovanJames.com

jamesnova.com

title: Discuss Art and Games! Especially  physcial ones made with sensors, Unity and Kinect
description:
Discussion group to talk about physcial games and art pieces made with Unity, sensors, Oculus Rift and Kinect in general. 
For inspiration, take a look at http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2623421/Now-fly-like-BIRD-Flapping-Oculus-Rift-machine-makes-humans-feel-soaring-skies.html

title: Processing and Eclipse: Switch development environments to program more effectively
description:
Processing comes with the the "Processing Development Environment" (PDE). Although it is a good tool, there are other programming tools available to you that offer more features. Processing really is Java programming under the covers, and if you understand that you can use other development environments like Eclipse and program more effectively.

In this session I will show you how to setup Processing in Eclipse and then do some simple sketches in both the PDE and Eclipse so you can draw a parallel between the two.

title: Nerdy Derby Curriculum Brainstorm
description:
For Family Day we are going to set up the [Nerdy Derby](http://nerdyderby.com/) Track. 

Nerdy Derby Inc. began at ITP as a no-rules miniature car-building and racing competition where participants built their own cars using simple materials in an informal, hands-on environment. 

The Nerdy Derby Inc., was established as an educational not-for-profit corporation with the mission to provide students and educators with hands-on learning activities that are creative and engaging. 

Our mission is to set up the track at schools, museums, libraries, and other education institutions to pair tactile learning experiences with core academic curricula in a fun environment. 

We want your help in developing learning experiences around the track. Come build and race your own cars. Then help us brainstorm new ideas for fun activities!

title: Futurematic Workshop (afternoon shift)
description: Futurematic: Canal Street is a design jam to create artifacts from futures that you might find in a street sale a decade, a generation, or a century from today. What are tomorrow's irresistible bargains, knockoffs and impulse buys? Let's imagine and bring them to life! Jointly designed and run by The Extrapolation Factory (NYC) and Situation Lab (Toronto), two renowned creative collectives on the frontier of experiential and guerrilla futures practice, Futurematic provides a compelling way to conceptualize and execute designs for future objects. The process focuses mostly on rapid prototyping and packaging design as ways of exploring and representing possible worlds. The day includes an opportunity to play the Situation Labâ€™s acclaimed imagination game "The Thing from the Future". Futurematic takes place Sunday June 8, 2014. To be able to accommodate more participants, the workshop takes place in two shifts, morning (11am-2pm) and afternoon (2pm-5pm), leading into the opportunity to actually sell the stuff on Canal Street afterwards. THIS LISTING IS FOR THE AFTERNOON SESSION (2PM-5PM). TO SIGN UP FOR THE MORNING SESSION INSTEAD PLEASE CLICK HERE. RSVP as soon as you can in order to help us organize space and materials for everyone!

title: The Sound of Trash - Repurposing Junk to Make Audio Speakers
description:
I've been making real working audio speakers using magnets, wire, and paper for fun. I ran this as a workshop with students and teachers a few times in the last year. The simplicity of the design really demonstrates how speakers work using the relationship between electricity, magnetism, and vibrating materials. 

Come learn how to make real working audio speakers. We will explore the variables that effect the sound of the speakers and then head out to the junk shelf and see what we can scrounge up to make vibrate and rock. 

Resources for this workshop:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Paper-Plate-Speaker/
Magnet source: http://www.kjmagnetics.com/
How Speakers work: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DMxn3CPLe-A

title: CNC Router Session #1: Rudimentary Mastercam Educational Session
description:
During this session we will be going over the beginnings of Mastercam. How to export from an illustrator file and import it into Mastercam, move and manipulate drawings within Mastercam, and generate toolpaths for our CNC router for doing 2d cutouts. 

This is a software only, but a prerequisite if you want to make things on our CNC router. As with all digi-fab tools, knowing the software is the MOST important. The machine is dumb and simply follows the instructions we give it.

title: Kinect + OpenFrameworks. From 0.0 to 0.1
description:
The idea is to get started using Microsoft's Kinect and OpenFrameworks.

We'll go thru the basics of OpenFrameworks, then we will build something simple that uses the Kinect together.

Hopefully, we'll have time to hack something interestingish together.

The session will be led by me (http://laurenzo.net - tomas@laurenzo.net - @krahd). 

Some important notes, please read them all:

* DISCLAIMER: Even though I do have experience using Kinect, I tend to forget and re-learn lots of things every-single-time. Expect some trial-and-error, mistakes, and befuddlement. 

* You need to have a IDE installed BEFORE coming to the session. In OSX get xCode running. In Windows, you can pick between Visual Studio and Code::Blocks. In Linux, Code::Blocks is the way to go. Please note I have zero (0) experience with Code::Blocks.

* It'd be good if you have OpenFrameworks downloaded and "installed". Go get it at http://openframeworks.cc/download/

* It'd be great if you can get any of the examples that come with OpenFrameworks running before the session.

* We'll invest the first minutes of the session making sure that everybody's OF works.

* We'll use the "classic" kinect camera, not the new one (which is named "Kinect ONE" but is the second one (!)). DO CHECK ONE OUT FROM THE ER AND BRING IT TO THE SESSION. All the sub-models should work (as long as they have never been connected to an actual XBox). In my experience the first iteration ones are better.

title: Responsive and Adaptive Design
description: With the ever growing number of screen sizes and device capabilities, a new standard has emerged in designing and developing for the web. We want to make sure that our sites and applications provide the best possible experience to all users whether they're at home or on the go. In this class you'll learn and understand the core concepts behind Responsive and Adaptive design, as well has how they work together versus having to choose between the two. We'll also touch on other techniques like Mobile First. However, this is not just a design class, it's a workshop, and you'll be designing with code. So bring your laptops! We'll cover the standard technologies that enable these concepts, from CSS media queries to device feature detection and some popular libraries such as Modernizr. At the end of the class, you'll walk away knowing how to design and build web sites and applications for the future.

title: Understand Object Oriented Programming
description: General explanation about what object oriented programming is with explanation about commonly used terms. I'm also going to mention the following: 2. What is code encapsulation 3. What is a class and a constructor 4. What is a collection 5. How to iterate\loop through a collection of objects. The session is without any specific demonstrations. Its all just a verbal explanation and time for general questions Here is the presentation I'm going to use during the session

title: User Research & Prototyping Workshop
description:
A day long prototyping workshop.

We'll discuss:
- Why Use Prototypes and User Research 
- Different kinds of prototypes
- Interviewing Users
- Creating Scenarios
- Building Prototypes with Keynote 
- Testing prototypes with real users

title: Introduction to Gamefication and how to use Game Theory in Practical Applications
description:
Playing is a natural part of human interaction. As we've moved into the digital age, our idea of play has shifted and expanded into new dimensions. How do we use play to engage people? How do we use games for education, medication, or other practices.

Think about what it is you want to gameify, and we'll go through the basics of how game theory can apply to things broadly, then brainstorm specifics.

title: Intro into programming
description: Intro into programming. Some of the topics are going to be:What can you build with various languages? Which one would you use over the other? What are some current programming trends? The difference between front-end and back-end web development? Here is the presentation I'm planing to

title: Unity3D : Beginner & 2D
description:
Sophi started a great conversation about Games & Kinect & Unity and consensus seems to be that we should continue meeting ... 
Both to share general ideas and also with specifically software.

Many of us use Unity3D in diverse ways, and it feels like a few tech sessions where we can learn from each other are in order.
A few of us might generally lead these (Brian, Chris, James Alanna ?). they are to be thought of as work sessions, where everyone can share information they know.

Topics below are an outline we might follow:

Unity Part I: Introduction to the Basics & 2D
- Creating a project
- The Unity Interface
- Game Objects and Components
- Scripting
- 2D Workflow (Sprite, Simple Animation)
- 2D Physics

 
*NOTE: This session had been originally proposed for another date


Additional resources:

Unity's Own Documentation is your friend: 
http://unity3d.com/learn

Basic tutorial introducing Unity:
http://www.raywenderlich.com/25205/beginning-unity-3d-for-ios-part-13

Great 4-part tutorial to introduce 2D animation in Unity:
http://www.raywenderlich.com/61532/unity-2d-tutorial-getting-started 

50 best practices tips (something for everyone...designer to coder):
http://devmag.org.za/2012/07/12/50-tips-for-working-with-unity-best-practices/

title: Unity3D Part II: Introducing 3D & Going Deeper
description:
Many of us use Unity3D in diverse ways, and it feels like a few tech sessions where we can learn from each other are in order.
While a few of us might generally lead these, they are to be thought of as work sessions, where everyone can share information.
Topics below are an outline we might follow
 
Unity Part II: Introducing 3D & Going Deeper:

- Player Characters & First Person Controller
- Materials and Textures and Terrains
- 3D Physics and Rigidbodies

- Audio
- (Assets store?)

title: ActionScript for IOS, Android, the Web and Desktop platforms
description: I will use ActionScript and Flash Builder to teach an Introduction to Programming where we will learn a little about: * Data Types * Variables * Functions * Events * Classes We will start by creating "Hello World" and get it to appear on every platform before moving forward. At the end, we'll have a little application that lets you create a custom Avatar by selecting head, torso and legs, dragging and dropping their features into place. Please download trial versions of Flash Builder and Flash if you don't already have them. Flash Builder * http://creative.adobe.com/products/flash-builder Flash * http://creative.adobe.com/products/flash Also, I will be working with files on GitHub which you will be able to download, but if you want to learn a little about working with git, please install it before you arrive. You can get it from the GitHub website, or this URL: * http://git-scm.com/downloads

title: Building Speakaboos - A Children's Storybook Application
description:
I'm going to give a talk about an application Iâ€™ve been working on called Speakaboos. Itâ€™s a childrenâ€™s storybook app that features over 75 stories, from Humpty Dumpty to The Little Mermaid, and lots of original content. Weâ€™ve partnered with several publishers and content developers, and have created a system for developing storybooks in Flash that can be downloaded into our app.

After I joined the team, our first step was to get an iPad app into the IOS AppStore. After that, we signed deals with a few Android tablet manufacturers, Nabi, Kyowon and Samsung. I just finished up these Android products where I had to write Adobe Native Extensions to integrate with their Java based app stores and user management systems. Next, weâ€™re going to support smaller screens, enter the Google Play app store, and add support for the new x86 based Android processors.

Thereâ€™s a lot going on, and things have gotten a lot more complicated with the addition of new partners and platforms. Somehow though, weâ€™ve managed to do all this with one codebase. The same code that runs on iPads runs on Android and on Desktop machines. Soon, it will run on the web too. 

This will be a fairly technical talk, but there are no prerequisites and non technical people are welcome. There will be something for everybody who has ever wanted to create an app, or wondered why software doesnâ€™t always work the way they think it should.

title: Weaving Soft Sensors
description: In this session we will lasercut hand looms from cardboard or acrylic and weave both conductive and nonconductive yarn in such a way that they can be utilized as sensors for Arduinos and other microcontrollers. Please bring your own yarn and conductive thread (for sale at the computer bookstore across the street).

title: Embroidering Soft Sensors
description: In this session we will embroider conductive and nonconductive thread in such a way that they can be utilized as sensors for Arduinos and other microcontrollers. Please bring your own cotton or polyester thread and conductive thread (for sale at the computer bookstore across the street).

title: VJing with VJ Miixxy and VIDVOX - learn how, demo tools and jam at the after party!
description:
Join VJ Miixxy (aka Melissa Ulto) and David Lublin, developer of VMDX and other amazing VJ software for his company VIDVOX (http://vidvox.net/) for an evening salon of VJ'ing:

- learn what a VJ REALLY is (not that old MTV stuff - VJs existed before that)
- learn what a VJ does
- learn how to VJ using VDMX
- learn about some cool tools on your iPad 
- learn about OSC controllers and other fun peripherals
- learn how VJing has become a necessary part of the entertainment industry
- learn how VJing/video art has become a necessary part of the retail digital display industry

THEN:

- we JAM out
- BYOB
- Bring a bank of clips or create ones on the fly 
- we'll help you pick your VJ name! every VJ gets one!
- we'll even livestream it!

9 PM is the estimated lesson end time, but the jam can go until midnight, when ITP Camp closes. 

This is a great companion class to Chika's Mapping class earlier in the day. 

About your session leaders:

VJ Miixxy (aka Melissa Ulto) is an international infamous liminal light criminal who participates in mainstream and underground projection events. She has held several year long residencies at various large scale nightclubs in NYC, including Spirit, CROBAR, GLO, the Roxy, Avalon, the Limelight. She has gone on tour and performed her visuals with acts as diverse as Busta Rhymes to GWAR. VJ Miixxy has also been a media activist with light collectives in OCCUPY (for street livestreaming and rouge street projection), GUERRILLA GIRLS and CODE PINK. During the day, VJ Miixxy dons respectable attire and masquerades as a Director of Digital for luxury brands, creating digital signage content and interactive retail installations. Her understanding of light as an ambient aesthetic element and how to best use it in all environments will be shared in this session.

David Lublin is a creative nerd, a secret rockstar, a day dreamer and amateur telephone operator. He also makes Mac software and sometimes art. He is also a friggen genius, as described by VJ Miixxy. David has the software hookup. He also performs as a video artist at times, while running a very successful software company - VIDVOX. 

The post-lesson jam is our tribute to Eyewash, the fabulous VJ event series of the 2000's.

title: Running a Makerspace
description:
Space and resources are hard to come by anywhere, especially a city.

This session will go over some practical advice for keeping the doors open at a makerspace or hackerspace while maintaining your sanity. Running a makerspace is hard work, but it's worth the time and effort to create a thriving community.

Hillary Predko is a member of the board of directors at Site 3 CoLaboratory (http://site3.ca) in Toronto, Canada and manages day to day operations.

title: Stahp with the Mousing: Improving Your Mac Productivity
description:
Do you use a Mac? Are you tired of clicking around in order to get things done?

Come learn some tips, tricks and tools for becoming more productive with your Mac. Weâ€™ll cover the basics of using the Terminal (and replacing it with the far better iTerm), handy keyboard shortcuts for various programs and Mac OS X itself, and delve into Alfred, the all-purpose Mac productivity tool. If we have time, Iâ€™ll even show you how to write a custom Alfred workflow script to add new shortcuts to your Mac! (Canâ€™t make it interactive since the add-on to Alfred is pay ware.)

title: The Humanistic Side of Task Management - or How to Manage a Project When You Can't Control Everything
description:
Ever had a project derail, fail, or otherwise blow up? Me neither. Just kidding! In this session we'll look at the theÂ humanistic side of task management using a simple communications framework informed by the work of Chilean philosopher, entrepreneur and politician Fernando Flores. This session is ideal for project managers/team leaders but can be useful to ANYONE in a situation where you have to manage the keeping of promises (with colleagues, family, friends etc.), and you can start using it immediately. You'll walk away with a clear framework for how to identify and anticipate communication pitfalls to ensure the success of your project.

This will be some lecture and lots of conversation. This is not a technical session. We'll discuss challenges in managing promises, whether in a professional or personal setting; review basic distinctions of task management that, if overlooked, cause communication breakdowns; and explore the framework and it's application.

title: Unity and Kinect study group
description:
Come and play! 
Let's hack the Kinect into Unity together (I've got a working demo). We can also do some self-guided tutorials. This is not a class.

~Download Unity free here:
https://unity3d.com/unity/download

~There are Kinects in the ER.

~Suggested tutorials: 
http://forum.unity3d.com/threads/finally-an-interactive-tutorial-series-that-will-teach-you-c-for-unity3d.175410/

A collection of C# tutorials (you can use Javascript instead of C#, or both):
http://catlikecoding.com/unity/tutorials/

title: Introduction to JavaScript
description:
We'll start from zero and see how much ground we can cover in an hour.

If you want to code along, it would be nice to have Firefox browser with Firebug plugin installed and Sublime Text, or IntelliJ

Here is the link to the code we've written during the session https://github.com/voidit/itp2014-js101

title: Handbuilding with Clay Part 1
description: Come learn the basics of handbuilding with ceramic clay. Session-Part I, will offer campers the time and materials to explore various handbuilding techniques. Objects made during this session will be kiln-fired and returned to campers on Wednesday, June 18th. Session- Part II will offer campers time to glaze their pieces. Final clay pieces will be returned to campers on Tuesday, June 24th. All materials will be provided.

title: Handbuilding with Clay Part II
description: Handbuilding with Clay, Session II is offered to only those campers who participated in Handbuilding with Clay, Session I. In this session, campers will add glaze to their kiln-fired objects. Glazed objects will be kiln-fired and returned to campers on Tuesday, June 24th.

title: SOFT LAB: Vinyl cutter, sewing machine, and embroidery machine 101
description: We will be going through the basics of the sewing, vinyl and embroidery machine.

title: Processing, NeoPixels, and FadeCandy
description:
Need a quick and easy way to add LEDs to your project?

Weâ€™ll take the bouncing ball example from the Intro to Processing session and use the new FadeCandy board to display it on a grid of RGB LEDs called NeoPixels.

Weâ€™ll cover everything you need to get NeoPixels up and running with your Processing sketch including basic soldering and how to pick a power supply. Weâ€™ll look at the hardware: what it is and how to wire it up and power it. Then weâ€™ll discuss what to add to a sketch to communicate with the FadeCandy. By the end of the class youâ€™ll be able display most existing Processing projects with just a couple lines of additional code.

There will be plenty of extra time for questions and for campers to try out the hardware. Once the session is over, Iâ€™ll leave a FadeCandy kit in the Equipment Room for the rest of camp so everyone can try it out.

title: Jamming with Pixels - Image, video and glitches in Processing/OF
description:
Get hands on with pixel manipulation in Processing and openFramworks

Want to mix videos?  Want to use an image as a point sprite?  Want to programmatically distort your image?  Want to pixel sort?  What are pixels anyway and What happens when you mess up the pixels in an image?

This two hour work shop will dive into getting images and video on the screen and understanding what they are made of so we can start abusing the data and getting the cool programmatic results we want!

title: Connecting Computers and Your Unconscious
description: This session is a digest of an ITP class called The Rest of you. Discussions around how overrated your consciousness is and how we should build interfaces with that in mind. Ideas and experiments from fields like evolutionary psychology, social psychology and behavioral economics often come into it. Participants can talk about project ideas they might have. I will outline some simple opportunities for sensing your autonomic nervous system with an Arduino and for doing some textual analysis on your writing in Processing.

title: Make Your Own Printed Circuit Board
description:
Using the heat transfer method, students will etch their own printed circuit boards. Making your own printed circuit board assures for a more robust circuit/project. Prior Eagle CAD experience is preferred, however not a necessity.

NOTE: For safety reasons this session is being limited to 10 participants. It will be run 1 other times. Please cancel your RSVP if you do not plan to attend.

title: Make Your Own Printed Circuit Board
description:
Using the heat transfer method, students will etch their own printed circuit boards. Making your own printed circuit board assures for a more robust circuit/project. Prior Eagle CAD experience is preferred, however not a necessity.

NOTE: For safety reasons this session is being limited to 10 participants.  Please cancel your RSVP if you do not plan to attend.

title: Learn how to draw
description:
Have you ever wanted to learn how to draw? Were you ever interested in knowing what makes a good drawing?
This workshop will help you to acquire better skills and to get closer to understanding drawing. A short introduction of the tools/materials/drawing techniques will be given in the beginning of this workshop. Then we will switch to drawing rounds of 10-20 minutes, we will be analyzing and commenting on our drawings after each round.

Please bring pencils, sharpies and paper.

title: Kinect and Unity
description:
Come and play! Let's hack the Kinect into Unity together (Many of us got a working demo yesterday). We can also do some self-guided tutorials. This is not a class.

~Download Unity free here: https://unity3d.com/unity/download

~You can use ZigFu plugin for Mac and Kinect- free version gives you a watermark, you will need the Open NI drivers to make it work

~There are Kinects in the ER.

~Suggested tutorials: http://forum.unity3d.com/threads/finally-an-interactive-tutorial-series-that-will-teach-you-c-for-unity3d.175410/

A collection of C# tutorials (you can use Javascript instead of C#, or both): http://catlikecoding.com/unity/tutorials/

title: APIs in Processing with Temboo
description: We'll be covering how to use the Temboo Processing Library, which makes it easy to connect to over 100 different APIs. In this workshop, we'll use Google, Twitter, Yahoo Weather, and more to send emails, tweet, and visualize data in Processing.

title: APIs on the Arduino YÃºn with Temboo
description:
In this session, we'll cover how to use the Temboo Library to connect an Arduino YÃºn to over 100 APIs. First we'll get the YÃºn set up and connected to the internet. Then we'll trigger sending an email via Gmail and record sensor values to a Google Spreadsheet.

NOTE: If you already have an Arduino YÃºn, please bring it, along with any other pcomp tools or sensors you'd like to try.

title: Intro to CNC (Machine Edition)
description:
This will be a quick introduction on how to take a pre-prepped file and using the CNC to cut that shape.  

This is merely a quick glance on how to use the machines to cut an existing design.

What will be covered:
- Taking a Vector design into MasterCam and prepping it for the CNC.
- Setting up the CNC and cutting that design.

What will not be covered:
- Designing for the CNC
- Illustrator/ CAD drawing

title: Let's Talk About {Music}
description: ....in which we bring a group of music-loving ITP Campers together in one room with the goal of learning who else at camp is interested in making musical things. Format will be a casual conversation where attendees will each take a few minutes to talk about: - Interest and background in music - Possible music technology projects or ideas they've been kicking around

title: The Gaze, Movement, and Metadata
description:
**â€œThe painter constructs, the photographer discloses.â€**
â€• Susan Sontag, On Photography

What do you think you disclose when you're behind the lens? How does your physical interaction with your equipment shape your process? How does your choice of time and place contribute to your statement? **Let's explore that connection between the artist's movement in space with the actual data (and metadata) that produces.**

During the first half of this workshop, we'll be taking photos around the city with cameras specially-designed to capture data from accelerometers, compasses, light meters, as well as wifi networks, bluetooth, GPS satellites, and cell towers. For the second half, we'll design visualizations to accompany our photographs and see how this changes our artistic statement.

BYO Phones: The software is only supported on __Android phones and tablets__ please bring yours!  A limited number of devices will be available on-site for iPhone users.

title: Concept to Kickstarted: Developing the Vega Edge
description:
What does it take to move from concept to prototype to product? 

The Social Body Lab is a research group in Toronto that focuses on exploring body-centric technologies in the social context. The Vega Edge is a simple, elegant wearable light co-created created by the Social Body Lab and fashion designer Angella Mackey.

In this session the SBL team (Jackson McConnell, Hillary Predko, and Kate Hartman) will review the design process of bringing the Vega Edge from concept to prototype to product. We will discuss our material research and development, the preparation and management of our successfully funded Kickstarter Campaign, and the production process for our first 500 orders. 

We'll also tell you a bit about the lab and what goes on there!

[About the Vega Edge](http://www.fastcoexist.com/3029401/a-bike-light-that-youll-want-to-wear-around-all-day)

[Kickstarter Page](https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/868814363/vega-edge)

And for more work from the Social Body Lab, check out this session: [http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2014/session/268](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2014/session/268)

title: Prosthetic Technologies of Being
description:
The Social Body Lab is a research group in Toronto that focuses on exploring body-centric technologies in the social context. This talk will highlight our recent collaboration with Intel User Experience Research on a project called "The Prosthetic Technologies of Being." This project explores ways in which technologies can feel like an extension of self. Through the development of a series of three prototypes we have been exploring how technology can extend our ability to sense our surroundings and express our emotions in a visceral way.

In this session we will discuss our prototyping process as well as the results of our recent user testing of the [Monarch](https://vimeo.com/89654806) prototype.

title: Counselor 3D Study Group
description:
Get some one on one first come first serve 3D help with the counselors!

To make room for as much help as possible, 'office hours' will be limited to 20 min or less. 

This is a great opportunity to get some direction from an expert with 3D modeling or the Makerbot!

title: ActionScript for IOS, Android, Part II
description:
We will be continuing the project started on Wednesday June 11

http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2014/session/230

title: Survival Tips for Filming on the Go
Counselor Study Group (Fabrication)
description:
Building something? What to hang out and watch videos of people making miniature engines? Want to make jokes about concentric cams or chicago bolts? Need some kinetic sculpture inspiration? Want to talk materials?

Come work on your designs and ideas. We will be available for consultation and consolation.

title: Counselor Study Group (Programming)
description:
Get some one one one programming help with a camp counselor!!!

Note: This session will be led by Xuedi!

title: Counselor Study Group (Physical Computing/ Circuits)
description: Get some one one one help with an ITP Camp Counselor!!!

title: Counselor Study Group (Project Development)
description: Ideate Ideate Ideate! Get feedback on a project! Get some inspiration!

title: Capoeira!!
description:
Capoeira is a Brazilian Martial Art. It uses a mixture of fluid dance like movements, kicks and other tricks as its foundation.

Here is an example:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6H0D8VaIli0


In the class I will share a bit of its history as well as go through some of the basic defensive and offensive movements.

The class will look like this:
- A very very brief explanation of history
- A short 10-15min warm up
- Some basic movements
- A â€œRodaâ€â€” this is where sparing or the game is practiced (similar to the people in the video)

To participate I would suggest that you bring:
- loose fitting pants
- We generally train bare foot, but I would suggest sneakers that have a flexible (not so think) sole.

title: Critical Digital Media Skills
description: As problem solvers, we must be aware of the larger context in which tech exists. For example, our inventions can have unintended consequences that we need to be prepared to confront. This session will involve a conversation on how to think about and understand the tech world. It will brief you on important thinkers in the digital realm, such as Evgeny Morozov, Sherry Turkle, and danah boyd. We will explore digital news outlets, popular ways of thinking about the internet, and how to remain analytical when we are putting forth tech-centric answers to problems in the world. To be most effective in the innovation and development of digital technology, we must simultaneously train ourselves in the capacity for critical analysis.

title: After Effects: Animating is good
description:
Make video better. Animate, and create with After Effects. 

The first hour will be project based instruction for beginner to intermediate skill sets. The second hour will be open workshop where you can create a video to VJ. Abi and Mitch will provide hands-on help.

**Another session has been added on Thursday, June 19

title: Invasion of the body sensors - Hands-on discussion of how sensors are changing the way we see each other
description:
The ability to sense signals from the human body is beginning to change the ways we interact with the objects and people around us. Anytime you think, feel or act, electrical and chemical signals carry messages through your body. Everything from intentional eye movements to subconscious changes in electrodermal activity and patterns of neuronal firing can be measured to augment interaction. More than just basic vital signs, combining bio-sensors with state-of-the-art algorithms makes it possible to identify up to 8 or more distinct emotional states and is beginning to open the door for greater understanding of ourselves and each other.

In this session we'll pass around a few different types of bio-sensors to see how they work and discuss how bio-sensing can be used today and in the years to come to revolutionize all aspects of our lives from health and education to art and retail experience. 

Links:

[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-j7LtMwhEpKd3kza0tCRThucTA/edit?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-j7LtMwhEpKd3kza0tCRThucTA/edit?usp=sharing)

[http://produceconsumerobot.com/biosensing/](http://produceconsumerobot.com/biosensing/)

[http://produceconsumerobot.com/pickyourbrain/](http://produceconsumerobot.com/pickyourbrain/)

title: Painting is Dead
description:
Part I: Painting and Technology, a brief history.

How painting has paved the way for technology and vice versa. 
What is abstract art? 


Part II: Painting in the 21st Century.

Demonstration of new applications to create digital and moving paintings.
The use of light as a material and gifs as a new art form. 
What is the Time Dimensional Painting project? 

Part III: Open Session

Try your fingers out at some digital extra dimensional painting. 


Note: if you have an iPad bring it along. You can download the applications ArtRage and Tagtool on the appStore to follow along. If not no worries, you can have a go on mine.

title: Fun with the New Kinect
description:
A lot of folks have expressed interested in seeing the new Kinect in action. This session I will demo my company's virtual try on software that uses the new kinect.
this is just a fun session, I'm not the developer but it is a chance to play a bit.

For those of you who have installed the new kinect SDK we can plug in the camera to see if we can get something working too

title: Family Day -- MaKey MaKey
description: Learn how to make something fun with MaKey MaKey!

title: Drawing and Designing for the CNC (CAD Edition)
description:
In order to get the most out of the CNC we need to be able to draw out our designs.  This session will be a quick introduction to drawing for ITP's CNC router.  We will go over CNC design and drawing basics.  
    
The session will be led in Vectorworks, however participants can follow along in other vector drawing programs such as Rhino, autoCAD, solidworks, Adobe Illustrator etc.

title: Intro to CNC (Machine edition)
description: Introduction to MasterCAM and cutting on the CNC

title: The Maker's Materials
description:
This session is a primer for people who looking to physically build things for the first time, or if you want to broaden your range of knowledge to help stimulate the possibilities. 

We will start with an outline of the major digital fabrication processes, and then cover basic user-centric information about the materials.  We will cover the various names, available sizes, cost, and possible pitfalls in fabrication for common types of materials in the following categories, wood, metal, plastics, as well as a review of adhesives and fasteners. This session will be complemented with an extensive materials sample library to provide a complete "sensory experience".

John is a 20 year veteran of "dirt under his fingernails" in the fabrication world, and has started an educational non-profit centered around learning though digital fabrication.  www.adFABe.org

Session presentation link;
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B6xkYUBvqo_YTGdzUm8zM0tKVnM/edit?usp=sharing

title: After Effects Round II
description:
Another session on AE!! This one will supplement Mitch's session by being a review for those who went and covering some of the same basics for those who couldn't make it

Half of this session will be dedicated to making your own clip or animation, which you can use at the VJing session on Saturday if you want. This means there will be plenty of time for individual question answering

Here is the breakdown:

1. example videos (if u want)
2. AE file structure and preferences
3. all the tools you can use (making shapes, text, moving it)
4. bringing stuff in from Photoshop and Illustrator
5. makin stuff

if you have an idea, feel free to bring it!!

title: DIWire: The First Desktop CNC Wire Bender, Demo & Workshop
description:
The DIWire is the first desktop wire bender, a new archetype for digital fabrication and rapid prototyping, that transforms drawn curves into bent wire that can be assembled to make just about anything.

During the session, we will run a quick demo of how to use the DIWire. After that, attendees are welcome to use the DIWire themselves!

To Learn More: http://www.pensalabs.com/

title: Product Research Workshop
description:
This is a participatory workshop on UX research techniques for those who design or build products. (Note that a few of the methods are more applicable to digital products/software).

* Learn how to conduct user research interviews for insight
* Discover qualitative and quantitative research methods to learn about user attitudes and behavior.
* Learn when to use which methods before, during and after you have built anything.

# Submit a Product Problem Scenario

Since this is a participatory workshop, you're invited to [submit a product problem scenario](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1ntFjZPjNkaa2bVYoznorR_RgcWQdoKXY0Ru3LtZPIx8/viewform?usp=send_form) to use as a context for applying research. Please submit by Friday, June 20 so we can work out the details in advance.

title: Get to know your sewable brain
description: For those of you who wanted something a little more advanced than the basic wearables workshop I am proposing a basic overview of wearable microcontroller platforms LilyPad and Flora.  We will go over how the board works, what materials you can use and where you can purchase them, and learn how to program an RGB LED to flash in different sequences. Bring your own LilyPad or Flora, or come watch and take notes if you just want to learn.  Conductive thread/fabric also recommended but I will have some available.

title: Analyze words, text, books, anything....with LIWC
description:
Group session to work with LIWC. Bring some text, come prepared to collectively help work with this online tool from UT. If you have any experience with LIWC or are simply curious, come for a bit and provide some help!

Link to free site: http://liwc.net/liwcresearch07.php

James Pennebaker work: http://www.amazon.com/The-Secret-Life-Pronouns-Words/dp/1608194965
 
Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (LIWC; pronounced "Luke"), a computerized text analysis program that outputs the percentage of words in a given text that fall into one or more of over 80 linguistic (e.g., first-person singular pronouns, conjunctions), psychological (e.g., anger, achievement), and topical (e.g., leisure, money) categories. It builds on previous research establishing strong links between linguistic patterns and personality or psychological state, but makes possible far more detailed results than did hand counts.
 
Iâ€™ve done a little work with the data analysis, but most my value will be that Iâ€™m very good friends with James Pennebaker and can ping him if we need to get something from his lab at UT. He is also known to give access and help for interesting projects for free.

I took a stab at a time, if this is a problem...we can juggle the timing, just add your desires in the comments ;-).

title: Brain-computer interfaces with the Emotiv (EEG) headset
description:
Instructor: 
Alvaro Olsen, Adjunct Professor 
Computer Science Department, New York University

This session will cover an introduction of what Neuro technology is, and the benefits of EEG data for Entertainment, Productivity and Learning.Â 

A brief walk through of Emotiv, and its affordances, will be discussed along with an introduction on how to integrate Emotiv's SDK into your applications and the potential for these applications in real-world contexts.Â 

There will be a discussion of real-world applications that have used this headset in music therapy, games and for people with disabilities.

A working Demo of an integration of Emotiv's SDK for an app research of emotions will be shared and discussed. Followed by a short workshop on how  to integrate the Emotivâ€“â€“where participants can develop simple JAVA applications using the SDK to be used in their apps.
[This is the course proposed in a 'vote' by Brent Dixon under the same title]

title: STUDY GROUP: Let's Document those projects!
description: For this session I will set up a 5D camera, some nice lights, and show you how to document your projects! Come handy with your projects, no need to be necessarily done, but complete enough to document!

title: STUDY GROUP: Let's Document those projects! II
description: For this session I will set up a 5D camera, some nice lights, and show you how to document your projects! Come handy with your projects, no need to be necessarily done, but complete enough to document!

title: Live Video Manipulation for Live Performance or Installation in Max MSP Jitter
description:
In this 4-hour workshop we will explore the OpenGL framework within Max MSP Jitter to create custom software for Live Visuals in Performance and Installation. We will look to Blender (a free and open source 3D modeling software, www.blender.org) to build our own 3D object models and create wholly unique navigable worlds in Jitter. Participants will leave equipped with an understanding of GPU accelerated video manipulation and a trove of tools and reusable code to create their own Custom Interactive Video Software. 

This workshop will be geared towards beginners but will dive right into 3D and OpenGLconcepts in Jitter, therefore even seasoned but patient Max users may benefit from the course. Ableton Live users wishing to learn more about sound responsive Visuals in Max are also invited to participate.

Using a series of pre-made examples and reusable code we will discuss the 
following practices in Max MSP Jitter for Interactive Installation and Live Visual Performance:

â€¢ Importing your own Media to the World Space - Sound/Video/Still Image

â€¢ Video Mixing

â€¢ Utilizing Shader Programs for high performance video effects

â€¢ Basic 3D modeling and sculpting techniques in Blender

â€¢ Creating Real-Life Spatial Attributes for 3D Objectsâ€“ Physics/Light/Texture/Material

â€¢ Manipulating Models and Media in Real-time - Spin/Move/Warp/Destroy 

â€¢ Have your program react to Sound

â€¢ Video Mapping

â€¢ Technical Walk-Through for Installation and Performance Setup

â€¢ Controllers and Camera Sensors (Midi, Webcam) 

â€¢ Building A Sleek User Interface for your Software

Participants should bring their own Mac laptops (OSX Snow Leopard or later). 
Interested Windows users should get in touch before signing up. Depending on what Mac generation you are using, for modeling purposes, it may be necessary to obtain a mouse with a scroll wheel.

A free 30-day trial of Max/MSP Jitter is available here http://cycling74.com/
downloads/ â€“ A full version of Blender is available here for free (http://www.blender.org/download/). 

*Software should be downloaded and installed prior to workshop date.

(Please note that you must provide your own computers, if you have any questions about workshop or materials email: thomasjohnmartinez@gmail.com)

About the Instructor:
Thomas is a New York City based musician, artist and programmer. He makes works employing multi-channel sound, video and custom software. 

As a programmer he designs and builds new technology for Artists working with Audio and Video. Specializing in finished products for Gallery Installation and Live Performance, his work has been featured in some of the most well known spaces in the world and web. 

www.thomasjohnmartinez.com/customarttools
www.thomasjohnmartinez.com

title: MAPARAPA! Web-based projection mapping
description:
MAPARAPA is the first web-based projection mapping tool, making this once shrouded in mystery and expensive art form, easy for everyone of all skill levels to use. Initially developed from Tony Lim's 2013 thesis project at ITP, MAPARAPA has grown to become a powerful tool, pulling in content from numerous social APIs and websites, it even has the ability to map Processing and Javascript in real time!

Come join us for a Maparapa crash course and we'll have you mapping in no time!

Thanks,
