Winslow, Tony, Archana, and Elise

title: Interacting With An Autonomous Mobile Robot
description:
We will present a real mobile wheeled robot, CoBot. We will explain the function of the robot in particular its ability to autonomously navigate in the environment. The Robot performs service tasks going from place to place. Furthermore, of special interest to this session, will be the ability to interact with the robot through spoken language. During the session we will identify the projects that we will be interested in pursuing in the next 4 days. This session will include a presentation followed by work with the real robot. More sessions will follow from Tuesday to Thursday during the same time.

We will use Python and/or C++

title: Interacting With An Autonomous Mobile Robot - Session 2
description:
We will present a real mobile wheeled robot, CoBot. We will explain the function of the robot in particular its ability to autonomously navigate in the environment. The Robot performs service tasks going from place to place. Furthermore, of special interest to this session, will be the ability to interact with the robot through spoken language. During the session we will identify the projects that we will be interested in pursuing in the next 4 days. This session will include a presentation followed by work with the real robot. More sessions will follow from Tuesday to Thursday during the same time.

We will use Python and/or C++

PART II

title: I Got Yer F-Stop Right Here: A Digital Photography Workshop
description:
Ahoy!

So figure we'll do a crash course workshop in some of the basic aspects of digital photography, soup to nuts.

But condensed!

I'm going to try to design something for everyone.  We'll go over scary technical things to demystify terms like "F-Stop," "White Balance," "ISO," "RAW," "Selfie."  But also get a little bit into that heart of how to take good photographs, which is mostly non-technical.

It'll be a practical workshop, so any concepts and theories we talk about you can put to use immediately in your snapshots.

Then we'll get into the wonderful new world of Adobe Lightroom, where we'll learn all about editing and basic color grading.

11 - 1  Let's talk about Shooting!
1 - 2    Go out and shoot!
2 - 4    Editing and Lightroom

So bring the following:

1) A camera

2) Whatever cables you need to get pictures from your camera to your computer

3) Download a free 30-day trial of Lightroom 5 (http://www.adobe.com/products/photoshop-lightroom.html)

4) Bring a photograph or two that you love.  Could be anything from an Ansel Adams to a drunken picture from last night to something you saw on instagram.  If you can email them to me beforehand, that'd be best!!

Rock.

title: XCode, what are you!?
description:
A quick intro to how to use the apple IDE xcode, its power and its pains. 

We will talk mostly about header search paths, build settings, build phases, debug vs release, linking, debugging with and without the debugger. 

come with XCode installed and with questions if you got em.

title: Intro to Programming Using Python Part 2
description:
A continuation of the previous intro course.  We'll pick up where we [left off](http://foureyes.github.io/itp-camp-python/).  Some things we'll likely be able to cover:

* review strings
* ints and floats
* conditionals and boolean logic
* built in modules
* maybe loops?
tag_list: new to this whole programming thing

title: Fun Times with Quartz Composer
description:
Quartz Composer is a visual programming tool (Mac only - it's Apple's) that can be used to create interactive visuals (VJs are the biggest user base), prototype interactivity (facebook uses it), or play with programming concepts and technologies.

In this session I'll do a quick introduction of how it works, how to install some of the more popular plugins, and then we'll create (together) a 3D music visualization that can be controlled via OSC commands from an iPad (or any other device, really, but I'm going to be using my iPad).

Here's a couple examples of what people have done with quartz on vimeo,

https://vimeo.com/30428350

https://vimeo.com/58754754

https://vimeo.com/41541591

Download Quartz Composer and install it by following these instructions:

http://www.iloveqc.org/tutorials/item/35-how-to-get-quartz-composer-installed

Download the June 2014 Graphics Tools for Xcode (the video says to download an earlier version)

title: Documentary Everything -- What is Real, What is True, and What is the Difference.
description:
Creating an experience that a viewer believes to be true -- although it may not be real -- is a "documentary".    Yet there are narrative works that feel true...

With examples and conversation let's talk hybrid.  Let's talk the narrative uncanny valley.
As an editor of fiction and documentary  for a long long time, I have spent a great deal of time constructing truth, reality, and emotional experience.  It is fascinating and I think applicable to any and all forms -- but would LOVE to talk it out!

title: A Brief History of Tech, Sex and Fashion
description:
What does the invention of the vibrator have to do with "hygienic underwear systems"? Who is the Herculin Barbin and why was there a zoologist performing their autopsy? WHY IS THAT LADY STICKING A VIBRATOR IN HER EYE?!

I'd like to share with you, fair campers, some of my top 10 fun facts that I discovered while researching the history of technology and sex/sexuality/&gender in the US at the turn of the 20th century.

This will be a more detailed [possibly silly] version of a TEDx talk I did back in 2011.

In the broadest strokes weâ€™ll be looking at what "fashion as technology" meant in the late 1800s and early 1900s.  How did sex shape tech and vice versa back then in some weird & hilarious ways?  What lessons can we learn from these logical and hilarious â€œmistakesâ€?

If we have time at the end, I'll facilitate an informal discussion about design && sex toys. <3!!

title: Hello 3D Modeling + Printing Beginners!
description:
A fun, interactive workshop focusing on 3D modeling + printing for beginners. We recommend that you bring an iPad, iPad mini or laptop to the workshop. Here is what we will cover:

Quick overview â€“ the 3D printing industry and its many players

Beginner 3D Modeling + Printing â€“ principles of good design; overview of 3D modeling software available for beginners for browser and tablet; the basics of 3D modeling; tips for modeling specifically for 3D printing; saving 3D files (STLs) and slicing STLs using Cura. Test printing may be possible as well, depending on our access to ITP Camp's 3D printers and time availability.

title: Pro Photoshop Keyboard Shortcuts: Design Your Business Card && Pro Retouching
description:
MAXIMIZE YOUR WORKFLOW! 
Learn how to use keyboard shortcuts in Photoshop and Illustrator to: 

(1) design a business card, and/or 
(2) to professionally retouch or alter your photos and artworks, and/or
(3) fulfill your fantasy of making Daily Show-type animated gifs at lightning speed!

This session would be great for beginners and advanced users alike.  In addition to learning some fantastic shortcuts, we will go through an advanced and efficient workflow for designing and retouching. You will walk away with a fully designed business card that we will send off to a professional printer. Additionally you will walk away with truly pro retouching skills. [Or to get that animated gif done 10x as fast!]

I will structure the workshop so we will spend the first portion learning shortcuts and then dive right into a hands-on design workflow.  Depending on everyone's interest I'll split the hands-on session in two parts (1) designing business cards and (2) retouching images.

Learn all the shortcuts you need to become a better, faster, stronger designer or artist!

Note: These shortcuts work in ALL versions of the software. So come with whatever version youâ€™ve got.

title: A Brief Survey of Video Art
description: A quick look at the last 66 years of video art. The time will be broken down approximately as follows: 10 min The "invention" of video art and its first practitioners 20 min Important and interesting video art works 15 min New movements in video art 15 min Discussion and suggestions for other video artists to check out

title: Swift : Apple's new programming language
description:
Introduction to Swift
The new language for iOS and OS X development

1) Language overview, and syntax

2) Some interesting features in Swift

3) Procedural and object oriented features

Level : Beginner

Prerequisites : Familiarity with at least one programming language such as JavaScript, Python, Ruby, C, C ++, Objective-C or Java

There will be no live coding, it is mostly just a language overview presentation, since Apple didn't change development environment (xcode) and swift language it is in beta state.

title: OpenSCAD : Creating solid 3D CAD objects
description:
OpenSCAD is a free software application for creating solid 3D CAD objects. It is not an interactive modeler, but rather a 3D-compiler. OpenSCAD reads from a script and renders a 3D model from it.

I will show you, how to create solid 3D CAD objects using OpenSCAD. During the session, we will be live coding all together. So, get ready to design stuff  with out a mouse! 

Please download the software before the session. It is at http://www.openscad.org/

title: Nerdy Derby Friendly Competition!
description:
Come build and race your own Nerdy Derby vehicles and bridges! 

The Nerdy Derby is a no-rules race track inspired by the Boy Scout's Pinewood Derby. 

On Thursday night in the lounge we will have two challenge tracks set up. Join us for drinks and fun as we host several friendly competitions on the tracks. 

The Inertia Track times how many milliseconds it takes a vehicle to climb and descend a hill. We will have a challenge to see who can make cars that take the longest and shortest amounts of time. 

The Mind the Gap Track requires you to build a bridge that will carry and guide the cars across a 3 foot long gap in the track. 

We will have some supplies for both vehicles and bridges, but you are free to bring your own or raid the junk shelf.

title: Cancelled: Python + Sublime Text
description:
This session will get you set up with Python + Sublime Text + Python libraries working together. This is a really useful stack that can sometimes be confusing to get set up, depending on your machine and what you've previously installed and where. Caveat: I've got a 100% success rate getting people up and running with this stack on both Mac and Windows; I promise I'll give your machine my best shot, but I make no guarantees.

I'll provide some example python code for testing that uses the twitter library and nltk (natural language toolkit) to look at word frequency in tweets.

This will *not* be an intro to Python, though you'll see what Python code looks like.

This *will* be somewhat chaotic, as I'll need to move around answering individual questions.

For best results, come with Sublime Text installed and a Twitter account.

title: Cancelled: Commanding the Command Line
description:
This is a session for command line beginners. We'll cover command line tools that are useful with text and data files. If there's time, we'll see how to batch process images at the command line using Imagemagick.

The session will work best if you have a Mac, mostly because I work on a Mac and I haven't worked with Windows + command line in a few years. If you're working with Windows, you're welcome to join, but please install Cygwin https://www.cygwin.com/ (or something similar) first, and know that it might be a little bit frustrating.

title: Launch Party!
description:
Here's what will be happening:

Check in: If you haven't posted one already we'll take your picture and get your ID made so that you can get in and out of the building easily. (Don't worry - you won't need this to get in on June 1st!)

Party: Starting at 6PM we will have tons of food, drink, and mingling. This will be a great opportunity to meet your fellow campers.

Announcements: We'll tell you a bit about camp as well as introduce the staff that will be around for the month. This will probably happen around 6:45 or 7PM.

Campfire Meetup & Magic: Starting at 7:30PM we'll break into smaller groups to get to know each other and jumpstart our camp brains with a special activity led by the camp counselors!

For those of you who haven't been to ITP before it is location at 721 Broadway in Manhattan, between Broadway and Waverly. Enter the building and take the south elevators to the 4th floor.

title: Closing / After Party!
description:
Hey Campers!

This is an opportunity to celebrate the end of camp and share what we've made, learned, or even just something fun for the party.

Remember in process or completed we want to celebrate you! 

If you are interested in showing something off please fill out this super quick form about the project: http://goo.gl/forms/6c3HKty5Vk

There also may be opportunities to run last minute sessions so just check in with the counselors if you have ideas!

+++Invite your folks :)

title: Friday Fireside: THE SHOW ONE THING SHOW
description:
An all-camp a hybrid talent show / open-mic / show-and-tell extravaganza!

Each person will have ONE minute + ONE slide to present ONE THING! 

For example, you could share:  a project you made / a place you traveled / a thing you ate / a dance you know / a song you wrote / a thing you do


It will be a fun opportunity to get to know each other better, we hope everyone will sign up to share something :)

- - - - - - - - - - - -

To participate:

ADD YOUR SLIDE TO THE PRESENTATION DECK, HERE: https://docs.google.com/a/nyu.edu/presentation/d/1hbAbLqEOfpO5sZND0N-oYap4lHbtpq2qARkEAgOHAlI/edit?usp=sharing

The only requirement for your slide is that it includes your NAME. 

Maybe youâ€™re thinking: What if I will be playing the ukelele and I donâ€™t have a slide? 

In order to participate, you still need to make a slide! Just include your name, thatâ€™s enough! This document will serve as our â€˜sign upâ€™ sheet for the evening.

title: Friday Fireside: Amanda Parkes
description:
This is an all-camp event where we get together to get to know each other or explore a particular theme. It can take the form of a lecture + discussion, a panel, or a group activity.

This week's Fireside speaker is Amanda J. Parkes, PhD, from Manufacture NY.

Dr. Amanda Parkes is a fashion technologist with over 10 years of experience in wearables, interaction design, and fashion innovation. She is the Chief of Technology and Research at Manufacture NY, a hybrid fashion incubator/factory/research facility in Brooklyn NY where she is leading the development of a high tech fashion & textiles R&D space with joint research around advanced digital fabrication, wearable electronics, and material science. She is currently a visiting scientist at the MIT Media Lab and an adjunct professor in the Columbia University Department of Architecture. She received a PhD & M.S. in Tangible Media from the MIT Media Lab and a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering (Product Design) and a B.A. in Art History from Stanford University. She is an international speaker & lecturer including TED, DLD, PSFK and the New York Times International Luxury Conference, and her design work has been awarded in forums including the ID Magazine Annual Design Review, the Prix Ars Electronica, and the D&AD Awards. She was recently named to the 2014 Business of Fashion 500 People Shaping the Global Fashion Industry. Outside the lab she likes to sew, surf and amass exquisite shoes.

Amanda's talk will be followed by discussion, snacks, and drinks.

title: How to - Wood Lathe
description:
Wood lathes are pretty cool; turning a piece of wood, chisel sharpening and smelling the wood chips ... etc. And wood lathe is a great tool for stress reduction and relief, too ;)

In this session,  I will show you how to use it to turn a piece of firewood into a mallet.

Tools we will use:

 * Wood lathe
 * Goggles or full face mask.
 * Dust mask 
 * Chisels
 * Flush cut saw
 * press drill
 * Forstner drill bits
 * Wood glue
 * Hammer

title: OpenSCAD - Creating solid 3D CAD objects
description:
[OpenSCAD](http://www.openscad.org/) is a free software application for creating solid 3D CAD objects. It is not an interactive modeler, but rather a 3D-compiler. OpenSCAD reads from a script and renders a 3D model from it.

I will show you, how to create solid 3D CAD objects using OpenSCAD. During the session, we will be live coding all together. So, get ready to design stuff with out a mouse!

*Please download the software before the session.*

title: Arduino - Coin Flipper Game
description:
This session is a quick introduction to the basics of digital input and output with [Arduino](http://arduino.cc). Experience with Arduino would be beneficial, but not necessary. 

It is %20 presentation, %40 hardware building, and %40 live coding.

We are building "Coin Flipper" game, so please bring your own hardware.

Things you will need in this session

* Arduino board
* USB cable
* Laptop ([Arduino IDE](http://arduino.cc/en/main/software) installed)
* Breadboard
* 2x LEDs
* 1x Button
* 1x 10K Ohm resistor
* 2x 220 Ohm resistors
* Jumper wires

title: How to - Wood Lathe (repeat)
description:
Wood lathes are pretty cool; turning a piece of wood, chisel sharpening and smelling the wood chips ... etc. And wood lathe is a great tool for stress reduction and relief, too ;)

In this session,  I will show you how to use it to turn a piece of firewood into a mallet.

Tools we will use:

 * Wood lathe
 * Goggles or full face mask.
 * Dust mask 
 * Chisels
 * Flush cut saw
 * press drill
 * Forstner drill bits
 * Wood glue
 * Hammer

title: How to - Solder
description:
Soldering is one of the most fundamental skills needed to dabble in the world of electronics. The two go together like peas and carrots. And, although it is possible to learn about and build electronics without needing to pick up a soldering iron, youâ€™ll soon discover that a whole new world is opened with this one simple skill. 

In this session, we will go over the basics of through-hole soldering. Each participant will get [Red Alert Alarm kit](http://vakits.com/nf-1729). This kit will make an alert sound similar to the Star Trek Red Alert alarm. Sounds like [this](http://youtu.be/KUnHb2jnbpo)!
 
This fun kit **doesn't include** a battery. Please bring your own **9 volts battery**.

It costs you **$5**. Here is the  [bill of material](http://bit.ly/1cqaq6B).

title: Android - Turn phone to flashlight
description:
This session is a quick introduction to the basics of [Android](http://android.com) app programming in [Java](http://java.com) . Experience with Android, Java and programming would be beneficial, but not necessary. 

It is %20 presentation, and %80 live coding.

We are writing an Android app that turns on/off the camera flash (LED), let you use the phone as a flashlight, so please bring your own Android device.

Things you will need in this session

* Android device (Any device phone, table, ... etc with camera LED)
* USB cable
* Laptop ([Android Studio](https://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html) installed)

*Please download the software before the session.*

title: Raspberry Pi - Introduction, Setup, & Basic IO
description:
The [Raspberry Pi](http://www.raspberrypi.org) is a very capable, cheap computer that can be used for all sorts of hardware and software and art projects. Let's explore this platform to understand how it can fit in to existing projects, or inspire new ones.

In this session, I will show you how to setup a Raspberry Pi, and what the hardware/software can do on it.

title: ITP Camp picnic with NY Philharmonic in Central Park
description:
Let's have picnic while listening to classical music at the park!

Bring your picnic blanket, a ton of wine and food to share and lets enjoy some great classical music in Central Park. Come alone or with friends, either way, we are a super friendly bunch of folks and we love meeting awesome people!

Find ITP Camp balloons, we will be under them ;)

Official details are at [http://nyphil.org/concerts-tickets/1415/concerts-in-the-parks-june-17](http://nyphil.org/concerts-tickets/1415/concerts-in-the-parks-june-17)

title: Data Representation & Processing
description:
This session will introduce participants to the basics of data representation, using the Processing programming language. We will cover loading data into a sketch, parsing and categorizing it, and creating a variety of basic visualizations. We will also take a look at different types of data visualization, from screen-based and interactive pieces to the more sculptural, visual, and abstract.

A basic understanding of Processing is recommended. Bring any data sets or ideas that you'd like to create visuals for!

title: Intro to Python
description:
This session serves as an introduction to the Python programming language. We'll look at applications and projects created with Python, and examine why its simplicity and readability makes it so awesome. We will then cover basic UNIX commands, Python syntax and structure, and learn text manipulation and generation strategies. Participants will also learn how to import text or data from external files, and analyze, parse, or remix that info.

Please come with a text editor installed (I like Sublime Text, but there's also TextWrangler or TextMate) and make sure you have Python installed on your laptop. To check, open Terminal and type "python" (no quotes) at the prompt.

If you get a version number, you're good to go! If not, please download and install Python (from here: https://www.python.org/download/) prior to the session.

title: Basic Digital Signal Processing
description:
prerequisite: coding and mathematics.

This workshop covers average filtering, hysteresis, peak detection, envelope detection. The skills can be both used in Arduino or Computer application involves microphone or camera.

Hand on parts will use camera as signal input. Code will be written in Javascript. A computer with webcam is required for this workshop. 

The workshop will be about 60% lecture and 40% hand on.

Slides:
[google doc presentation](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1TApMrwrA7XBG5oQ5tKh7ZBJyj0iNbGzWPA_iuJhdl1s)

title: Prototyping well
description:
prerequisite: How to light up led with resistors and battery (almost nothing)

This workshop will cover basics on how to connect breadboard tidily. Usage of heat shrink. Usage of hot glue and shape forming. Wire labeling. etc.

ITP do have some wire strippers. But try to bring you own as the strippers are not always there.

Bring your own Breadboard, Wire, Wire stripper and cutter. Hot glue gun.
Bring Arduino if you are familiar with it and willing to help others.

The workshop will be about 20% lecture and 80% hand on.

Slides:
[google doc presentation](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1GhgDtan9j4pPximx9rcvKzvHLmdLgsF-3vUdJcNkkGY/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Field Trip to Stoll Fashion and Technology Center, Tour 1
description:
Stoll is a knitting machine manufacturing company with headquarters in New York. The Fashion and Technology Center is an amazing resource. Artists and designers can produce samples. They also offer classes and workshops. One of the best parts of the Fashion and Technology Center is the Stitch and Pattern Archive, where we can look at samples spanning from 1873 to present. 

Details are TBD, but I hope that we will be able to visit the facilities and see samples of some of their technical and innovative knitwear.

title: MVP JavaScript Web Apps
description:
Prerequisites: Attendees ideally know basic programming fundamentals in at least one language, and have dabbled with web development (HTML and CSS).

Beginners are welcome though. :)

This session will introduce attendees to building minimum viable product (MVP) web applications using JavaScript across the stack, from the database to the front end. First, we'll cover the architecture of a web app (model-view-controller). Then, we'll introduce a number of JavaScript frameworks (Express, Angular, Node) to build a basic web page that serves data from a database (MongoDB).

title: Lines become Objects! (Adobe Illustrator for the Laser Cutter)
description:
With the laser cutter, a boring 2D drawing in Adobe Illustrator can become a real object, sign or tool in minutes! Have a company logo? Laser it. Need a new dog tag? Laser it. Need an enclosure for your Arduino project? Thats right - laser it. 

BUT FIRST... Let's get to know Adobe Illustrator to transfer our ideas into reality. In this workshop, we'll work with vector and raster graphics, drawing tools, and tips for joining multiple pieces together. Then, we'll talk about preparing our files to be cut on the laser.

title: Electronic Esperanto - Communication among devices and software
description:
As software and devices become more connected, opportunities abound to use them in unique ways perhaps unanticipated by their original creators.

 In this session we learn about some of the methods of getting software and hardware to talk to each other. 

We will look at a few examples, including:

Controlling a 3D Environment in Unity using an iPad as a controller

Turning a common desk lamp on and off over the internet with the help of Arduino

Compositing  a webcam video feed from Open Frameworks in which our face has been substituted with someone elses into Max MSP, while chroma-keying out the background so that we can see a video of our choosing playing behind us (phew!)

Once we've seen these examples, we'll use any extra time to play around with the examples and try to push them a little farther.

Familiarity with coding, OSC, or Arduino is not necessary but worth exploring beforehand, as we won't focus heavily on the principles behind these technologies themselves.

Additional sessions will follow, in which you will be given time and support toward getting these things running on your own computers, but bear in mind this session will be a bit more guided, and the examples will be running on pre-configured machines / devices.

If you would like to attend this session but would prefer another time, please leave a comment with your preferred date / time and I'll see if I can make it work. Cheers!

title: Embodied cognition and design
description:
How do our physical experiences touching, hearing, and seeing the world around us affect the way we think every day? Does the way you move your body change the content of your mind?

I'll be talking about some findings of embodied cognition, a subfield of cognitive psychology that investigates how the body shapes the mind (and the topic of my graduate research). What lessons does this science of the mind have for the way we design the products and experiences we design?

title: Preparing Your PCBs for Manufacturing
description:
Get your PCBs ready for mass production!

I'll cover what I've learned running manufacturing at Adafruit, explaining the basic steps involved in preparing your PCB designs for small to large runs.

topics:

 * choosing surface mount parts for pick and place machines
 * panelization
 * fiducials

title: Making 3D Holograms with Lasers
description: This is a hands on workshop where you will get to work with lasers and make a real 3D hologram of your own.  A hologram is an incredibly powerful medium with resolutions as high as 10 billion pixels/in by 3000 deep.  The session will begin with a lecture explaining what a hologram is, how it works, and how they are made.  We'll also learn the difference between true holograms and other 3D media that have been referred to as holograms.  You'll get to see several different types of holograms and pseudo holograms and learn how they are used.  Then we'll set up a small holographic camera and shoot holograms on photopolymer film.  The image will be in full three dimensions and can be seen in white light without the need of any special eye wear.  This session will run approximately three hours.

title: Alter Interface: possibilities in body and physical controls
description: Alter Interface looks at how we interfaces with and experience technology through discussion, and hands-on introduction to experimentation with alternative physical controls. the session will look at, expanding possibilities of body, negotiating technological relations as well as, using mechanics to question and explore experience.

title: Data Visualization: A Brief History in Time, Space, and Culture
description: What is data visualization? Why do we do it? How do we do it? This session will take you through the process of considering these questions in a historical, cultural, and aesthetic context. This session is for all designers seeking to explore data visualization's role in our rapidly evolving information landscape.

title: Data Visualization Toolbox: A Survey of Multidimensional Strategies
description: What kind of data that is best for visualization? How do you access the data? How do you visualize it? In this session, we'll examine some production pipelines for data visualizations of various temporal, spatial, and physical parameters. This session is for anyone working with data and looking for ways to structure and expand their visualization toolbox.

title: Intro to Tapestry Weaving
description:
In the session, we will build a basic tapestry loom out of cardboard. The first part of the day will serve as an intro to weaving and the various techniques used to construct cloth. Then we will move onto a more advanced step by making our own 'cartoons' to plan out the design of the cloth. The idea is that by the end of the day we will be able to create our own cloth "breadboards", of our own design. 

Materials Needed:
Ruler
Cardboard
Scissors
Darning Needle
Non-Conductive Yarn
Conductive Yarn or Thread

title: Stitch 'n' Bitch
description: Learn to knit, embroider, crochet and more! Share your skills in these areas or more! Quilting circles go back decades. During these circles, women would sit around and help each other finish a quilt. They would also talk. With this first meeting, I would like to see how much interest there is in making this a weekly group. And what skills and projects people may be interested in working on.

title: Arduino - Dice Game
description:
This session is a quick introduction to the basics of digital input and output with [Arduino](http://arduino.cc). Experience with Arduino would be beneficial, but not necessary. 

It is %20 presentation, %40 hardware building, and %40 live coding.

We are building "Dice" game, so please bring your own hardware.

Things you will need in this session

* Arduino board
* USB cable
* Laptop ([Arduino IDE](http://arduino.cc/en/main/software) installed)
* Breadboard
* 7x LEDs
* 1x Button
* 1x 10K Ohm resistor
* 4x 220 Ohm resistors
* Jumper wires

title: How data became the new medium for artists
description:
Artists reflect the times, if you want to understand how this moment will be seen in 20 years, look at what artists are doing now. Data art is beginning to demonstrate how we will live and experience our personal data "...data art may be the apogee of self-expression". 

This will be a fun chatty session about the ways to make hand-built art from self-tracking data, how to make data beautiful, and my ideas about how data will be experienced in the future. 

Here is an article from the Atlantic Magazine that describes the rise of the data artist and features my hand-built artwork.
http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2015/05/the-rise-of-the-data-artist/392399/ 
Also I have a solo show up during the whole month of June in New York at Pavel Zoubok in Chelsea. Hope you can pop-in and see it during camp. 531 W 26th.
http://pavelzoubok.com/node/laurie-frick. 

I'll quickly introduce FRICKbits - a free iphone app, take back your data and turn it into art. http://www.frickbits.com/ (inspired by past ITP summer camp sessions). And this year I'm looking for a way to make the code open source. Will put this in a later session, but download and begin tracking...see that your data can be beautiful.

title: Introduction to SPA (Single Page Web Apps)
description: Beginners intro to developing Single Page Web Applications (SPA)

title: Intermediate SPA
description:
That session will continue the topic with more focus on commonly used JavaScript libraries, such as Express, Backbone and Angular.

Here is a list of useful links covered in our session:

   * [NodeJS](https://nodejs.org)
   * [npm](https://www.npmjs.com)
   * [Express](https://www.npmjs.com/package/express)
   * [MongoDB](https://www.mongodb.com)
   * [Grunt](http://gruntjs.com)
   * [yo](http://yeoman.io)
   * [Bower](http://bower.io)
   * [Angular](https://angularjs.org)
   * [Backbone](http://backbonejs.org)
   * [yo generators](http://yeoman.io/generators)
   * [MEANjs](http://meanjs.org)
   * [Karma](https://karma-runner.github.io/0.12/index.html)

title: Cinder: a crash course in creative coding
description:
In this course, we will jump into the deep end of creative coding in c++ using the cinder framework. (more info at http://libcinder.org)

We will become familiar with the ecosystem of creative coding (xcode, compiling, c++), some basics about c++ programming and get our hands dirty with cinder going from 0 to the bouncing ball in 3 hours. 

Come along for the ride.  Some processing or equivalent basic programming knowledge is highly encouraged as this is not for the faint of heart! :)

title: WTF do you really want?! Consumer hacking prototyping
description:
A big problem about coming up with a prototype is, of course, getting it done in a way that is compatible with the demands your users/clients/stakeholders. Or even better: how to come up with something completely new of the 

This workshop explores how to get know the acutal demands of the market, coming up with an initial design, and to how to prototype according to the affordances of you company/collective/team.

It begins with market and consumer research techniques. How and when to use of each them. The next step is getting to analyse the data properly in a Design Thinking manner. Once you have that, the two option are: a) how to put it on a Canvas (BMG style) or b) how can I use that on an already mature company. And the best part: coming up with an actual prototype.

title: Create Custom Input Devices for your Mac
description:
Have you ever wanted to use a game controller or other device for your software which does not know about your device? Enter an indispensable software package called ControllerMate. This software allows you to visually map input signals from devices like a PS4 GameController to any software application running on your Mac. 

I will be illustrating this software with the Sony PS4 and Xbox360 Game Controllers. This will be a hands-on how-to session. So bring your Mac and some input device!

title: Live Lighting
description:
Live light design mixes art (color, composition, texture, focus) with technology (light emitters, control systems, timing, and robotic motion).  Good light design can be invisible or spectacular, and an understanding of light design and what it can do will improve basically any job that includes vision.

I'll do a live light design demo using LED pars, small moving lights, an arduino, and a hacked lighting console.  Then together we will design a sunset (which will be happening live outside at 8:22 during our session).

title: Digital Audio Basics and MAX/MSP
description:
An introduction to digital audio. Looking at:
How do we get sound into the digital domain?
How is digital audio represented?
What we need to know about it to mess with it?
How can we mess with it in MAX/MSP?

title: Making Wearables Move
description: What if a wearable could respond to the movement of your muscles? Monarch is a muscle-activated kinetic wearable created by the Social Body Lab at OCAD University. This talk and demonstration will explain the details of how it was designed and how it is made.

title: Origami 101
description: In this first class, we will focus on foundation elements of origami. We will focus on compound folds, bases, technique, and a casual overview of history and theory. We will fold a few basic models, which demonstrate them.

title: Origami Aircraft aka Paper Planes
description: Last class was pretty tricky, but everyone did great. We're going to apply some origami folding techniques to make paper fly. Also, talk a little about flight mechanics. It'll be fun.
tag_list: origami paper folding sculpture paper planes

title: Origami 2
description: In this session will tackle 2 intermediate / advanced models. Don't worry. I'm here to help.

title: Collaborative Performance via Wireless Wearable Devices
description:
I will run a similar workshop to this one: [Wearables and Collaborative Performance](http://www.interaccess.org/collaborativewearables)

##### Description from the above link:
> In this full-day workshop you will learn to use Bluetooth and Arduino (in the form of the LightBlue Bean) as well as various body sensors to create generative designs through collaborative performance. You will get your feet wet with writing Arduino code, reading and managing sensor data, sending wireless messages and interfacing with Processing.  You'll learn to think conceptually about the body and its relationship to time, space, and technology. You will create live generative art in a collaborative setting (!!!). This workshop will get you sensing, moving, playing and drawing in code using your body.  

#### Session

We will use Punch Through's [Light Blue Beans](https://punchthrough.com/bean/) as a rapid prototyping tool for wireless wearables. All participants will interact with a single display. And will use movement and other physical input in order to manipulate a visualization together. 

##### You will come away with:

* Examples of communication via BLE scratch [characteristics](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bluetooth_low_energy#Software_model).
* Ideas on capturing and adjusting movement/sensor data to allow for more directed interaction. (aka lets not *just* shove raw accelerometer data into our visuals.)
* Hopefully fun, and project ideas.

### Intro Sessions:

**If you *just* want an introduction to the Light Blue Bean as a better Arduino platform, or get comfortable with it before this session, I will be running short demos though the week. Will link them here.**

### MANY Exciting notes:

**No Beans will be provided. Please bring your own! [They are USD $30.](https://punchthrough.com/bean/buy/) Watch out for shipping times!** 

**Main skill prerequisites:**

* You have used an Arduino before, at any skill level. Its important that you are familiar with the basic Arduino interface, (compile, upload, select board)

**Nice to have, but not must have:**

* Soldering, if you are planning to add additional hardware to your Bean.
* Sowing, if you plan to connect soft circuits to it.
* Basic understanding of Arduino programming.

Your computer needs to be compatible with Bluetooth 4.0 / Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) If you have a Mac, search Google for your model, it is listed in the specs on apple.com.

WINDOWS USERS: The bean loader application is only compatible with windows 8.

**We will have soldering irons but bring what you need to make-it-wearableâ„¢**

Get in touch if you need any further information!

![A bean!](https://punchthrough.com/bean/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/bean-overview1.png)

title: Animation that explains stuff
description:
This session will look at a variety of animations and animation techniques that are used to explain or instruct. It will focus on animations that explain technology, other topics will be examined as well. This will be an overview, but we will also look at some techniques, ranging from the simple animated gif to 3D modeling. [Session slides](http://bit.ly/1f7m87v
 "Slides") are here.

title: Kinetic Toys - Building your own automata
description:
Have you ever wanted to build your own mechanical toys? ITP camp is the perfect place to begin experimenting! In this session we will talk about the various tool resources available to you on the floor for prototyping your ideas, some basic mechanisms for simple or complex motions, and begin prototyping our ideas using cardboard and card stock. Come in with an idea or we will help you brainstorm one on the spot!

Please bring a pair of scissors or an x-acto knife for a small group exercise.

[Presentation can be found here.](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1BU6xA548BBUrTQ_cAPBFMPf8wofbCMe6G8QVK-zquKM/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Sticky Situation - Fabricating with Sugar
description: If you have ever baked or decorated a cake, you know that sugar can be a great creative medium. In this session, we will explore alternative ways outside of food products to build art projects with sugar. We will talk about casting, coating, sculpting, and other fabrication techniques. There will also be an opportunity to experiment with making your own test pieces. Come prepared to get messy! Presentation can be found here

title: Whoâ€™s in the room? Checkout SeeWho, a proximity-networking app for ITP Camp 2015.
description:
Get to know your ITP Camp mates using SeeWho, a real-time people discovery app that enhances in-person networking and brings social serendipity to live events.  

This session will help you setup SeeWho (on your iPhone, iPad or iPod) and learn more about your fellow campers. Use SeeWho throughout your camp session.  Drop in and get started, 15 minutes is all you need.  You can also come prepared for networking by downloading SeeWho anytime before you arrive.

Real world example involved in rolling out a proximity app including discussions about design, UX, technical, tools, marketing and business issues.

GET STARTED
Download and install SeeWho. Itâ€™s free and available on the App Store on iTunes here: http://seewho.me/app 

Then sign into SeeWho with your LinkedIn account.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ABOUT SEEWHO
SeeWho helps people connect with each other, network for new opportunities or can simply just put a name to a face. SeeWho is a Bluetooth Low Energy 4.0 iBeacon app and is designed to discover people nearby, within a distance of 230 feet/70 meters.  Zero configuration required and immediate benefit. Weâ€™re calling it "smart networking." We believe it will make your networking events more social, productive and fun.  SeeWho was developed by two ITP alums. Learn more at: http://seewho.me

Get started with SeeWho now and see who you'll meet!  Any questions please email me at hello@seewho.me

title: Introduction to Clojure for Artists
description:
**enough people have registered interest! Yay**

This workshop will provide a brief glance into [Clojure](http://clojure.org/)

[> Recent examples of creative work built using Clojure.](http://radar.oreilly.com/2015/05/creative-computing-with-clojure.html)

#### Tentative Goals:
* I will modify a live program throughout the session. *(Sound / Visual / Both, not sure yet)*
* Demonstrate what makes Clojure wonderful for creative work. 
* And attempt to merge answers to questions into the running code.

If you are interested in a lighthearted, possibly even fun, introduction to Clojure take a look at this free book: [*Clojure for the Brave and True*](http://www.braveclojure.com/)

title: Doll Wiggling 101 (puppeteering for film and television)
description:
Doll Wiggling 101 is a crash course in hand and rod Muppet style puppeteering.  Campers will learn the fundamentals of film and television puppeteering including: monitor work, breath, eye focus and assisting. 
 
Puppets will be provided in a variety of shapes, sizes, materials, and of course, costumes. I will also include a PDF guide to puppteering learning opportunities in the NYC area for campers interested in exploring the art form.

RSVP LIMIT
Because of the number of puppets needed, as well as on screen camera space, the session is limited to 12 RSVPs

title: Embodied music and physical computing
description:
Music induces movement and pleasure. 

What if the music you listen to responds to the way you move? How does interacting with sound and music differ from interacting with visual representations? What would be an enjoyable way of interacting with music through bodily movement? 

I will bring a prototype that utilizes Kinect and Max/MSP to control the tempo of a piece of music through bodily movements. Join me in a hands-on exploration and discussion of how sensors can be used to create meaningful couplings between human movement and musical expression. Bring files of your favourite music (mp3, m4a, wav, aif).

title: Kinect V2 & Visual Effects with Macs
description: Up and running with Kinect V2 in Mac's OSX and OpenFrameworks. Basic coding is encouraged but not required.

title: GET UNREAL: An Introduction to Unreal Engine 4
description: The Unreal Engine isnâ€™t just for big budget AAA games anymore. Move over Unity, now that Unreal Engine 4 is freely available with full access to the source code artists are able to make use of its beauty and power. Perhaps youâ€™ve heard of the Unreal Engine but never tried it out. Maybe youâ€™ve never used a gaming engine. This is an introduction class for Unreal Engine 4 meant to wet your appetite. No previous knowledge of any gaming engine or 3D environment is required. Programming knowledge is also not required. UE is free to download (www.unrealengine.com) and is supported on PC and Mac. Installation of the engine prior to the session is recommended as itâ€™s quite large. The more powerful your computer the better experience will be. This is a hands-on session that will cover topics such as background, interface, importing assets, materials (shaders), environment design, matinee (animation, blueprints (visual scripting), Kinect, Oculus Rift, mobile, packaging, etc. If you want to make a first person shooter thatâ€™s fine but the session is more geared towards using the engine in alternative ways. Got some dope swag for ya'll too...

title: 3D tracking techniques in After Effects
description:
After Effects is a powerful tool to create a fast visual mock to communicate your idea before you dive into coding.

In this After Effects session we'll learn the magic behind 3D Tracking and create some poetry in motion or add some zombies to ITP's floor.

We'll learn:
1. How to use AFX to analyze a footage and create a 3D camera
2. How to add text /graphics that will match our camera motion
3. How to export our final movie


Here are some cool example of the stuff we'll learn:

Augmented Reality Mock :
https://vimeo.com/94188375

3D Motion Graphics
https://vimeo.com/44103009

Visual FX
http://youtu.be/sO1wMjBpl0w
The process is very easy  - if you have a very basic understanding of After Effects you'll have tons of fun.
Bring some footage you want to try and track  ( or you can use my own files) + After Effects installed.

title: RoboCakes - Cakes that Move You
description: Cake is great. Cakes that move and blink are greater. Come learn how to add lights and motors and even a firework or two to your next creation. We'll talk about all the ways cake wants to fail and what you can do about it.  We'll learn why fondant is your best friend. We'll totally accidentally probably eat some cake.

title: Your First Realtime, Reactive Web App
description:
Got an idea for a web app but have no idea where to start?  We'll build a fully reactive, realtime web application for both desktop browsers and mobile devices in just one session!

Reactive applications are increasingly common and desirable: user interfaces that don't have to be refreshed or reloaded, in which data is seamlessly transmitted and displayed, such as Facebook, Gmail, and many more.  We'll discuss the principals and technologies involved in modern web applications and make one ourselves with Meteor, a full-featured Javascript framework based on Node, MongoDB and Cordova.

Experience with Javascript or similar dynamic language is preferable.

Audience: designers, prototypers, artists, idea people, programmers, code crafters

title: Creative Text Manipulation with Python
description:
Code poetry. Computational creative writing. Digital poetics. Electronic literature. 

All of these names refer to creative manipulation of words with computer code.

This workshop will serve as an introduction to natural language processing, with a focus on creative applications of the technologies introduced. The first part of the workshop will provide a crash course in Python basics, including the syntax and features that make the language a popular choice for handling, analyzing, and manipulating text. The rest of the workshop will focus on Pattern (http://www.clips.ua.ac.be/pages/pattern), a powerful Python library for natural language processing, as well as other tools and resources available for creative text manipulation.

Topics covered will include (but won't be limited to):
* Word tokenization
* Markov chains (Ngram generators)
* Sentence parsing / part-of-speech tagging
* Sentiment, mood, and modality analysis
* Stop words and stemming
* Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) analysis

At least some minimal experience with programming (in any language) is recommended.

In addition to a text editor (I recommend Sublime Text), please ensure your computer has Python installed. You can verify this by entering "python" (without quotes) in the Terminal. If, for some reason, you find that you do not have Python installed, please follow the instructions for installing version 2.7.9 at python.org. (Don't install Python 3.)

You'll also need to install pip, the Python package manager. On Mac, run the following command in the terminal to do so:
$ sudo easy_install pip

Finally, use pip to install the virtualenv library (its purpose will be explained at the beginning of the workshop):
$ sudo pip install virtualenv

title: Controlling Chaos : Harnessing the power of Random Number Generators as creative assistants
description:
Prerequisites : None

Have you ever wanted an army of assistants to help you make decisions or quickly add layers of complexity to a project? Coupled with the use of simple rules or grammars, random number generators offer excellent creative partners and muses - they always show up on time and don't need to be paid for their work! 

Through a handful of examples, we'll look at how random number generation can bring the static to life in beautifully unpredictable ways. Examples will be discussed in high-level psuedo-code so that they can be transferred to any platform or application : audio, lighting, algorithmic art, etc... I'll also present concrete examples from my own work in the form of music and lighting so that you know I'm not making this stuff up. 

While the class will be asked to help guide the discussion as applicable to their work or interests, topics will include (but not necessarily limited to) Markov chains, decision trees, effects of initial conditions, layering random decisions, and of course a little bit of history interspersed.

title: Brainstorming
description: Bouncing the ideas that are brewing in your head off other minds is an amazing way to take a concept a step closer to reality.  In essence this is a conceptual get to know you session.  We'll play games and use the concept of speed dating to ignite our ideas and lend our brain power to other people's pet projects.

title: Field Trip: Bang on a Can Marathon
description:
This session is a field trip, come in and leave any time between 12pm and 10:00pm.
This event is free and open to public.
There is also free WiFi in the venue.

The Winter Garden at Brookfield Place NYC

[More info here and full lineup is here](http://bangonacan.org/2015/june/bang_on_a_can_marathon_the_winter_garden_at_brookfield_place)

title: Stand on your Hands
description: Balance is an amazing game to play with yourself, full of micro adjustments and achievable tricks.  Take this opportunity to get into your body a bit and improve your handstand in a mere 30 minutes.

title: Spectral Processing : Applications of the DFT/FFT for analysis and manipulation
description:
Prerequisites : You have to be able to add, multiply, and plug in a square root to a calculator. High school right-triangle trig and some programming will also help, but not necessary. If you're nervous but interested, please feel free to contact me about your hesitation(s) and I'll try to walk you through a confidence boost - I used to tutor DSP to musicians, I'll get you through.

So, the Fast Fourier Transform, eh? Everyone knows what the FFT does and how it works, or do they? Looking at forums and discussion boards, the FFT is arguably one of the most misunderstood topics floating around, but is too powerful of a tool to sort of understand (at least in my opinion). I'm going to dispel the myths, explain its high-level mechanics, and show various applications for using it. While audio is the focus, you can apply the same techniques to any stream of data, including things like video or information from sensors.

Examples will be spread over an ARM Cortex-M4F processor, Python, and Max/MSP,  so you can actually see the results of what I'm talking about. I'll also provide a list of resources so you can continue to pursue any topic that tickled your fancy.

The basic flow will be as follows : 
1)Down and dirty of digital audio and sampling. 
2)Frequency vs Time Resolution, Windows and Hopping!
3)What the FFT actually produces : Phases and Magnitudes
4)Applications : Analysis (Magnitude Spectrum, Peak Picking, Cepstrum & LPC, Centroid, Flux)
5)Applications : Manipulation (Up/Downsampling, Filtering, Noise Removal, Vocoding/Cross Synthesis, The Phase Vocoder)

This is a long session, so we will take short breaks throughout, or you can just check out the portions applicable to you. Parts 1-3 will be re-iterated continuously through 4 and 5, as well as 4 re-iterated during 5 to ensure the concepts connect and sink in.

title: Beyond Proof-of-Concept : Low-Cost/Free Tools for Engineering Production-Ready Microcontroller Applications
description:
Prerequisites : Some experience with Microcontrollers and basic hardware design is recommended. Not necessary, but helpful will be knowledge of basic programming (C/C++), and the ability to read basic schematics and data sheets. 

So, you've built out this amazing proof-of-concept (POC) and shown it works on Arduino, Beaglebone or some other platform -  what now? How do you go from POC to a full-blown stand-alone? 

This session is a survey of techniques and tools for taking your POC and putting it into a stand-alone piece of hardware using a variety of methods. With virtually no formal education in Engineering, I'm going to bring the last year and a half of my commercial development experience into the fold so you can learn from my growing pains.

I will cover popular free software development environments for MCU's by Atmel, Freescale, and Microchip and display how to use their low cost hardware tools to port your application cheaply and quickly. I will also discuss some of the advantages of these platforms including code compactness and efficiency,  API's, identifying the right MCU for the job, scoring free parts, break-point debugging, and tips on designing your final hardware.

title: Intelligent Feature Extraction : Imparting intelligence in audio (or other) transforms
description:
Prerequisite : A basic understanding of digital-audio or sampled data streams. Some knowledge of MAX/MSP or another platform with signal-processing capability, will be helpful to get hands on, but not necessary.
Please note, while audio will be the focus, the same techniques can be applied to data streaming from the web, sensors, or pretty much anything you can imagine.

Borrowing heavily from music information retrieval (MIR), a field exploding with big data for the last ten+ years, we're going to cover how to extract various features from a digital audio signal or other data stream.  With a little bit of effort, these machine listening techniques can be applied so that the content of the signal directly controls parameters of a transformation - akin to a bunch of people listening to a guitarist and turning the knobs on their pedals, so that the effects closely follow aspects of the playing. We'll also see how various features can be used to control virtually anything outside of the source signal, such as auto-generation of visuals or motion. I'll also briefly touch upon the inverse - how to generate audio from features extracted from other sources.

We'll cover things like Chroma for Automatic Key and Chord Recognition, recognizing/classifying signals by spectral content, beat tracking, and basic strategies for mapping features onto controls. All discussion will be relatively high-level, while examples will likely focus on MAX/MSP.

For an "extended" preview, you can check out my Master's Thesis.

title: Sass-ercise â€” Have a Preprocessor Write Your CSS
description: Writing CSS by hand is so 2000s. A CSS precompiler, such as Sass, brings your CSS workflow to the 2010s, bringing with it variables, file separation, and programmatic structures.

title: Successful User Testing and Concept Validation
description: You always learn how to make. But how can you evaluate and refine your designs? You should now be aware that understanding users and their needs is essential to success in your business or designs. In this session you'll learn the preparation procedures in user testing and some techniques on how to successfully complete user tests. You will be introduced to various types of testing depending on the products and services, and we will do some exercises for clearer understanding.

title: Getting Started with Bluetooth Low-Energy part II
description:
---This is a second part of Getting Started with Bluetooth Low Energy. Attendance to the first one is recommended but not required. 
In the first half hour, there will be a quick review from the first session.---

In the previous session, we learned how to make a BLE peripheral that can receive or send data. Now we're going to use Cordova/Phonegap to create an app that communicates with this peripheral or with any other BLE enabled device. 

Please, come with Node.js and Cordova installed in your computer.

The previous session happens on June 3rd. Come to both!!

title: Wet Leather Forming
description:
Vegetable tanned leather is an interesting medium because of its ability to bend and stretch while wet, and hold a shape when dried. In this state it is also possible to leave impressions in the leather. Vegetable tanned leather can be used to conceal and protect electronic elements when working with wearable technology in particular. It can also add sculptural elements and artistic flares to many other mediums. This session will allow campers to discover the possibilities of incorporating leather into their own work. A follow- up session will be available to learn how to dye, seal and protect the raw leather when it is dry. Due to limited materials, no more than 20 people can RSVP. 

REQUIRED MATERIALS: Bring a hard water bottle or a wooden/ceramic/glass box or object etc. You will need something hard that can get wet without getting ruined to be able to wet form around.

title: Dying, Sealing and Protecting Veggie Tanned Leather
description:
This session can be joined on its own, or as a follow up to 'Wet Leather Forming'. In this session, campers will learn the basics of using Eco-Flo dyes and sealants for use on vegetable tanned leather. Due to limited materials, only 20 campers will be able to join, so RSVP soon! HOWEVER, if you already have a piece of leather from last week feel free to just show up! If you happen to be one of those people please take down your RSVP to allow new comers. If this class overlaps with other courses, feel free to show up or leave whenever neccessary. This will be more of a walk in and join whats happening and ask questions sort of session. 

IF ANYONE HAS A HAIRDRYER PLEASE BRING IT!!! It will speed up the process significantly.

title: Playing with Analog Oscillators
description:
In this session we will get loud. The first part will be demo and play time with analog oscillators I have already built. We will play with potentiometers I have already constructed and talk about other options. We can hook up potentiometers you bring in! The second part will include mocking up some of your own oscillators on breadboards.

Please bring anything you might like to use as a potentiometer!

Other materials needed:
Breadboard
9v battery
Small portable or raw speaker 
Alligator clips

title: Make it Soft: Knit Your Own Sensors
description: Bring your knitting needles and learn about making your own sensors!

title: Make it Soft: Tilt Sensor
description:
In this session we will explore making soft tilt sensors with a variety of materials. Bring your own conductive materials to experiment with!

Materials:
Embroidery hoop
Scissors

title: Mermaid Parade
description:
[http://www.coneyisland.com/programs/mermaid-parade](http://www.coneyisland.com/programs/mermaid-parade)

Tip: Take Q train (head of the train) to Ocean Parkway and walk towards broadwalk, because it gets crowdy around Coney Island subway station, and you won't see anything.
Don't forget your swimming suite and a hat, or even umbrella.

See you there!

title: Rhino 2D: Rhino for the Laser Cutter
description:
Please come with Rhino for Mac or PC installed (free 90 day trial is available from https://www.rhino3d.com/download)
Also, please bring a three button mouse (right click, left click, middle scroll)

title: Yoga!
description: Let's move!  All levels welcome.

title: You, Me, and Unity3d: An Intro
description:
Have you ever wanted to make 3d environments, 2d games, interactive digital installations, virtual reality apps, playstation games, mobile apps, (and/or some other digital world things) but felt like straight-up coding wasn't your jam? UNITY3d might be for you!

Unity3d is an powerful game engine that combines that power of an easy to navigate wysiwyg (what you see is what you get) interface and programming.

In this soft introduction, we will walk through the interface and how to get you up and running with a navigable, real-time 3d environment that could be exported as a standalone-app, website, virtual reality thing, or... any of the other platforms that unity ports to!

Open to absolute beginners, as well as people with other programming or 3d experience who want to get up and running with Unity.

Please come prepared having downloaded Unity5 personal edition (free!) and, if possible, a 3-button mouse.

title: Open Source Performance Art
description:
Choreography in Everyday Life and Open Source Performance Art is a workshop and performance where students look at how to mine data in their everyday experiences  for inspiration for interactive live performance.  The class will create a site specific performance communicating with the architectural and social spaces of Manhattan inspired by the workshop.   Please wear comfortable clothes- there will be exercises, games, and shenanigans.

Included in the workshop is a short introduction to the history of Performance Art and specifically Open Source Performance Art - a performance method and framework developed by Amelia Winger-Bearskin while she was an assistant professor of performance art at Vanderbilt University
(students do not need to bring a laptop).

title: Auditory Stories
description:
Discover unconventional ways of making sounds, music + tell stories! Campers explore the emotional artistry of sound while learning about technical aspects of field recording. 

This workshop session consists of teaching about using a Zoom and shotgun microphones (from ER) to record voice, self created sounds with objects and field recordings! There will be examples of some sound works and music samples that act as inspirations. 

This workshop is focused on learning and practicing field recording; if time allows, campers can complete soundscapes/field recordings at the end of the session and present to the workshop. 

Campers are grouped in pairs of twos or more depending on equipment availability.

Please supply your own:

one SD card 8GB or bigger,
four AA batteries (rechargeable ones last longer in the Zoom H4N, which takes two AA batteries at a time to operate),
one pair of headphones (preferably over the ear ones for clearer listening),
your computer

title: Drawing With Pixels
description:
Few goals have driven the development of computers like the relentless pursuit of better graphics. Yet, in this era of HD videos and retina displays, the aesthetic of arcade-game pixel art somehow persists. These days, it's a luxuryâ€”just one of many visual styles that can be used on a whim, perfect for cultivating a bit of 80s nostalgia.

Not too long ago, these blocky images were the state of the art. Images that could say a lot with very little added as much clarity and understanding to early computer user interfaces as they added beauty to video games.

Pixel art offers a case study in economical design, as well as the creative possibilities that come from working within constraints. By examining the decisions made by a variety of pixel artists and designers, we can understand the types of technical challenges they were up againstâ€”the same technical challenges that shape computer graphics today.

The first half of the class will be a presentation on the history and technologies that shaped the development of pixel art, as well as some of the popular techniques developed by pixel artists over the years. In the second half, we'll get to explore these techniques while sketching out our own low-resolution artworks, either on the computer or by hand.

title: Intro to Eagle CAD
description: This session will introduce you to the basics of the CAD software used to design printed circuit boards.  During this 2 hour session we'll produce a simple schematic and board file.

title: Map Time: CartoDB
description:
With an open data set of your choice, use the CartoDB Editor, CartoCSS, and basic SQL queries to make an interactive map that can be easily shared and embedded. A hands-on overview of the CartoDB.js API will take your map to the next level as you achieve further customization.

***Map Time** is a series of two 2-hour workshops in which you will make beautiful, engaging maps using the popular platforms **CartoDB** ([June 9, 4-6pm](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2015/session/99)) and **Mapbox** ([June 10, 4-6pm](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2015/session/124)). You are welcome, but not required, to attend both sessions. Please RSVP to each session separately at the links above.*

*Note: Some coding knowledge is assumed, although not strictly required. Familiarity with **JavaScript**, **HTML**, and **CSS** is a plus, especially for the API section. Campers should bring their own computers.*

title: Make your own printed circuit board
description: Knowing how to make your own printed circuit board is an important tool in the prototyping process.  If you're circuit is working on a breadboard, you may want to consider making a more permanent connection between your components.  In this hands-on session we'll produce a simple printed circuit board using the heat transfer method.  Students will use equipment from the circuit fabrication lab.  All supplies are provided.

title: Making a Song in the Browser
description: This session will guide students through the process of creating a song entirely in the browser with Web Audio, a Javascript API for audio playback, synthesis and processing. The course will focus specifically on [Tone.js](https://github.com/TONEnoTONE/Tone.js), a Web Audio framework for making interactive music. After creating and dialing in some instruments and effects, we will trigger musical events along a timeline and make a simple tune. Familiarity with Javascript recommended.

title: 3D paper pop-ups with the Silhouette vinyl cutter
description: Like working with paper?  The Silhouette machine is adored by hobbyists and is most commonly used to make stencils.  In this session we'll make some basic 3D paper sculptures using an image file.  This machine saves you tons of time with rulers and x acto blades and can foster new creative ideas!

title: Simple Data Visualization with Processing, Part 1
Intro To The Command Line / How To Use The Terminal
description:
NO PRIOR PROGRAMMING OR TERMINAL EXPERIENCE NEEDED.
Underneath your attractive and ubiquitous graphical user interface of OS X, Windows or Linux lies the command line or terminal. The terminal is ideal when you want to do things super quickly without taking minutes or sometimes hours to do the same thing inside a traditional program on your computer. Instead of opening a program, clicking around, trying to find what you need, or maybe not not having what you need, you can type a few words and in seconds be finished. You can also use it to automate tasks, connect to remote servers, or alter system commands on your computer. We'll cover history and theory of the command line and basic commands with an introduction to shell scripting.

title: Intro To GitHub / How To Get Started
description:
GitHub is the open source platform for version control of software. It allows you to track changes to your code as you work on projects, share it with others, and even contribute to open source software projects. We'll cover the basics of creating repositories for your projects, uploading code, making changes, finding and forking others' code and making your own contributions.
No previous experience required, though some basic terminal experience is helpful.

title: How 2 Curate An Art Exhibit!
description:
Never before have so many people claimed to be curators. Let's delve into that term and talk about curating an art exhibit. What are the basic building blocks? We'll talk about developing an exhibition theme, writing a description, finding venues, selecting art, working with artists, promoting the show and building an audience.
No prior experience required.

If there is interest, I will put together a follow-up session where we actually put together and host a one-night-only exhibition opening.

title: Replace Yourself With A Twitter Bot
description:
We live in an age of bots. Increasingly in the past few years twitterbots have come to be a well-loved weird addition to our online life, with some bots reaching human audiences in the hundreds of thousands. We'll look at favorites such as Horse_ebooks, Everyword, GreatArtBot and many others and talk bot concepts. Then we'll use simple tools with and without coding to make our own bots.
BEGINNER-FRIENDLY, OPEN TO ALL SKILL LEVELS.

title: Mobile Health Apps: User-Centered Design
description: Apps have become ubiquitous in many aspects of our lives. They have yet to become a standard part of mainstream healthcare.  There is a great diversity in the consumer healthcare apps that are currently available however they are not used systematically by healthcare providers, patients or caregivers.  We will discuss, key stakeholders, app design and understanding how apps can play a role in the patient journey.  Participants should download proto.io before the class meets.  By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of user-centered design and create a wireframe paper prototype.

title: Introduction to P5JS / Processing in Javascript
description: Do you love Processing and wish that coding interactive online projects could be that simple? In this workshop we'll cover an introduction to P5JS - Processing in Javascript, look at the similarities and differences from Processing, and then start creating our own interactive web-based sketches.

title: Build A Fortune Teller (Divination and Chance Operations!)
description: We'll review random chance operations and computing, automatism, and look at a history of fortune-telling and divination including the I Ching, Magic 8Ball, Ouija, divining rods, and Zoltan from BIG - then we'll cover the basics of random generation in several programming languages and build our own fortune tellers out of physical materials or the programming language of your choice.

title: Make Your First Chrome Extension
description:
Chrome Extensions are a fun, powerful way to interact with web browsers.  You can change all photos on the web to Justin Beiber, track advertisements, and everything in between.  You can change how content is presented to users, alter their interactions with websites, or even send signals to an Arduino to bring in a physical element.  And when you make something you like, you can publish it so the world can use it.

In this workshop we will go over the structure and functions of Chrome Extensions, and walk through writing our own basic extension.

Having an understanding of HTML/CSS and Javascript is recommended.

title: Mobile UX 101 (Hello World UX)
description: What's the big deal with UX and why is it so important? How can I get a better understanding of this buzzword and design meaningful and comprehensive experiences? Learn the basics of UX design (for mobile in particular) and prototype your own screens for an app! Learn about prototyping software such as Axure and InVision. No prior experience required.

title: Make Your Own Jewelry
description: Beautiful jewelry can be found all around, in markets, art fairs and in boutique design stores. Many times the jewelry we come across is beautiful but just so expensive -- so why not make our own?! In this session you'll learn how to design geometric shapes, cut them on the laser cutter and make your own unique jewelry!

title: Making Chocolate Molds
description: Ever wonder what the world would be like if everything was made out of.. chocolate? Bring any solid small gadgets (2 * 2in max) and learn how to turn them into chocolate! This is a free flow session, so come anytime between 5-7pm!

title: Using Sketch
description:
Sketch is an awesome tool for designing interfaces and sketching quick logos and illustrations. Here, we'll cover the basics, and how to use lightweight Sketch instead of Photoshop or Illustrator. 

Open to all skills levels!

title: Hydrographic Print Transfer
description:
Water transfer printing is a fairly new, high tech method of transferring graphics from the computer onto a 3D object. The water transfer method uses PVA (poly vinyl alcohol) paper floated on water to transfer onto a painted surface. The water allows the print to perfectly conform to the objects contours. In this session we will learn to print, prepare, and transfer our patterns onto various objects using special paper and a normal epson printer.

Hydrographics is currently implemented in the hunting and car/bike community to transfer flame and camouflage patterns, but there is a chance in the art community for this process to bring about new and innovative works.

title: Computational Movement
description:
This workshop will explore movement through improvisation, choreographic techniques, and computational techniques. Come prepared to move! We will be working with both analog and digital technologies and creating relationships between people moving in space with newer mediums. Additionally, there will be a brief introduction into Max MSP, and we will be providing a variety of templates to jump start your exploration in the digital performance space. 

Most importantly, this class will explore what defines interactive dance and movement, and question where it is necessary and how it contributes to the overall expression of a piece. We will cover interactive sound, light, and video. 

Topics include:
Max/msp/jitter intro
Smartphone as sensor
DMX lighting with max

title: Document Your Projects Like a Pro
description:
When working with interactive technology, strong documentation is absolutely essential to build an online presence and effectively share your work. We are so accustomed to professional media production that poorly executed documentation will not only fail to explain the essence of your work, but technical flaws can become a distracting. 

In this session, weâ€™ll cover the basics of audio and video with a focus on documenting projects. On the visual side, weâ€™ll cover proper lighting, framing, camera settings, and shot selection. Weâ€™ll delve into proper audio levels, and recording environments. Weâ€™ll take the recorded content into post-production, and discuss basic editing, color correction, and audio mixing using Adobe Premiere. Extra attention will be focused on planning what to shoot and why. Attendees are encouraged to bring in any project that theyâ€™ve been working on (no matter how big or small!), and weâ€™ll make a fancy video for them to showcase their work.

title: Introduction to Interactive Video
description:
The Internet allows for some pretty great manipulation of what was once a fairly linear and passive experience of watching a video. We have a plethora of options now; we can choose our own adventure, watch parallel stories play out, and choose to learn more about a topic. Technology allows for almost anything we can conceptualize. 

In this session, campers will have an opportunity to experiment with making an interactive short video, using either the < a href="http://interlude.fm">Interlude  platform or Javascript with HTML 5 video. After a brief introduction to the possible tools, attendees will work in groups to rapidly form an idea, shoot a video, edit it together and introduce an interactive element. Focus will not be on the execution of the video, but on learning what types of ideas are conducive to interactive storytelling, and how to prepare and plan for these atypical stories.

title: Visual Storytelling
description:
Video is being further incorporated into many new media technologies. Projection mapping, 3D imaging, virtual reality, and image manipulation are often taking video of people and effecting the image to further enhance a story. But the original composition, lighting, and mood are important as well, and should be taken seriously. 

This session will dive into storytelling through video production through scenes setup in the class. Weâ€™ll cover advanced framing techniques, shot selection, effect of lighting on emotion, and pacing of shots in an edit room. Weâ€™ll work through camera and editing basics, but the expectation is that youâ€™ve had some experience with a camera, but want to learn to harness it and the editing tools to enhance your projects. 

If we can maximize out video input, we can greatly improve the quality of our finished product.

title: Map Time: MapBox.js
description: MAPS MAPS MAP! What better way to visualize and tell a story about a data set than through a map!?!
