With an open data set of your choice/or data set provided by the instructor,we will use MapBox.JS and Mapbox Studio to make an interactive map which can be easily shared and embedded. A hands-on overview of the MapBox.js API will take your map to the next level as you achieve further customization.

title: Lighting Control using the Philips Hue and JavaScript
description:
There are a number of different systems for controlling household lighting through the network these days. Of the ones we've tested here at ITP, the Phillips Hue system is the simplest and most flexible, and we have a few Hue hubs set up on the floor for general use. 

In this session, I'll introduce the Hue API, and show you how you can control lights on a Hue hub using JavaScript, both client-side using p5.js and server-side, using node.js.

Attendees should know basic HTML and JavaScript. You might speed things along by installing [node.js](http://www.nodejs.org) on your laptop in advance.

title: Mobile App Development using Cordova/PhoneGap
description:
Mobile app development can be a pain if you want to make something that runs on multiple platforms, but Apache's Cordova framework (aka Adobe PhoneGap) makes it easy to develop cross-platform apps using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. In this session I'll introduce the basics of building a Cordova app, show you how plugins work to give you access to the phone's sensors, and show you how to connect to a microcontroller using Bluetooth. 

Attendees should know basic HTML and JavaScript. You can speed things up by installing [Cordova](http://cordova.apache.org/)  and the development framework for your phone on your laptop in advance.  Shawn Van Every has [some good instructions for this](http://itp.nyu.edu/~sve204/alwaysonalwaysconnected_spring15/week1.html).

title: jQuery Deconstructed
description:
[jQuery](https://jquery.com/) is a popular JavaScript library that makes it easy to manipulate HTML elements in the [DOM](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_Object_Model). Some novice coders start with jQuery, bypassing any knowledge of pure JavaScript. For many simple applications, however, pure JavaScript is just as easy AND more efficient.

In this workshop you'll learn how to use pure JavaScript to implement some important jQuery manipulations, including:

* Finding and traversing elements
* CSS styling
* Event handling
* Window dimensions
* AJAX and callbacks
* Animation (time-permitting)

*Note: Familiarity with **jQuery**, **HTML**, and **CSS** is essential. Campers should bring their own computers.*

title: Programming for Beginners, Part 1/4 (JavaScript)
description:
Hey ... so I'll be teaching programming. Specifically for campers that have no prior programming background (or maybe just a very little bit). This will (hopefully) be a series of classes (maybe 4?) so that you get a deeper dive into the material rather than just a single session. I'll also give you some homework, of course! Soooo.... using JavaScript, I'll go over:

* variables and data types
* basic control structures, such as conditionals, loops
* functions
* arrays and objects

I'll schedule the other sessions and add topics if this first one is successful.

title: Creating Useful Documentation - Intro to Spin and Build in Progress
description: Session Leader: Tiffany Tseng, MIT Media Lab Want to create useful documentation for all the projects you build during ITP Camp (and beyond)? This session will be an intro / demo / hands-on session with two tools for capturing design process: Spin and Build in Progress. You will learn how to use Spin to create animated GIFs of your projects that you can share on Twitter, Facebook, or any other social network (there will be a Spin turntable set up at camp for anyone to use throughout the program). Youâ€™ll also see how you can visualize your design project and generate useful documentation (both for yourself and others) using Build in Progress.

title: Intro to 3d with Processing
description:
This class is an introduction to how computers work with the third dimension.  By the end of this class you will have a rudimentary understanding of how to move 3d objects around in digital space, as well as how to display them on your screen.


We'll be covering the basics, including:

  * Manipulating object in 3d spaces
  * Manipulating and managing multiple objects
  * Working with different aspects of the camera -- location, orientation, lens properties
  * Lighting a scene


We will use Processing's 3d context to explore these topics.  Please bring your laptop.  If you don't have Processing, you should download that as well:

[https://processing.org/download/](https://processing.org/download/)

title: Super Beginner HTML / CSS -- Anatomical Study
description:
**For absolute beginners!  Seriously, not a lick of experience necessary.**

This class will cover the very rudimentary basics of HTML / CSS.

This is mostly an interactive lecture where we dissect the anatomical structures of HTML and CSS.  After the class you should be able to confidently move into HTML.

Specifically, I'll cover:

  * Definition of HTML and why it's useful
  * HTML Anatomy
  * Selectors and how they work
  * Definition of CSS and why it's useful
  * CSS Anatomy

I think an hour and a half will cover all the basics.

title: Abusing Frag Shaders -- a totally different way to think about 3d
description:
This class covers the weird yet awesome practice of using "fragment shaders" (and only frag shaders) to generate 3d content.  Take a look at what some people are doing with it on [Shadertoy](https://www.shadertoy.com/)

We will discuss:

  * distance fields (describing geometry with functions, not polygons)
  * ray marching (a rendering technique for this kind of work)
  * how to do really basic lighting without any polygons
  * advantages and disadvantages to using shaders this way

This will be big picture overview where I'll be sharing my knowledge on the topic and I'll leave you with a collection of links where you can learn more about the topic.  Being knowledgable in vectors and matrixes would be helpful, but not totally necessary.

title: Digital Game Design, Art, and Development from Start to Finish with Construct 2 and Photoshop
description:
No programming experience is required in this hands-on workshop that covers the basics of digital game design, game art, and game development, using Construct 2 and Adobe Photoshop. This session is co-taught by [Brian S. Chung](http://www.brianschung.com) and [GJ Lee](http://www.leegj.com), who are game designers, educators, and the cofounders of [The Sheep's Meow](http://www.thesheepsmeow.com).

We will make art assets from scratch, import sounds, iterate on gameplay mechanics and levels, and run playtests in order to make refinements and finishing touches. Along the way, we'll cover topics like level design, game balance, user interface / interaction design, visual design, animation, polish, and more. 

Attendees will leave the workshop with fully playable HTML5 games, with the skills to create many more. We will also cover exporting and uploading your games to be shared on the web. 

**To participate in this workshop, you will need a laptop that can run Windows, and all software preinstalled. A computer mouse is highly recommended.**

Download and install the free version of Construct 2 (Windows-only) at [http://www.scirra.com](http://www.scirra.com) 

Download and install the free trial of Adobe Photoshop at [http://www.adobe.com/products/photoshop.html](http://www.adobe.com/products/photoshop.html)

title: Field Trip to MOMA: This is for Everyone: Design Experiments for the Common Good
description: Every Friday is free from 4-8 at MOMA. Let's all go to see the show 'This is for Everyone: Design Experiments for the Common Good'. Info for the show here: http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/exhibitions/1555

title: VJing- WTF is it? - Day 1
description:
Video Jockey â€“ in the 80's and 90's, the term â€œVJâ€ was popularly considered the video version of radio â€œDisc Jockeys,â€ the person who introduced the next song on television.

In the late 90's and early 2000's, as the world of DJing evolved beyond simple curation of music with specializations like scratching, sampling, remixing and the like, so have VJs expanded their set of tools and techniques for live performance and production.

Today someone who is a VJ might appear to be something more akin to a video instrumentalist or visualist, someone who creates and manipulates images in ways similar to how a modern musician works with sound.

Personally I think of a pro VJ as a video art ninja and rockstar in one; capable of bridging the worlds of preproduction, live performance and post production. The methodologies involved are evolutions of those used for early film special effects and avant garde video artists from the 60's and 70's, well before the introduction of the MTV VJ era.

GENRES OF LIVE VISUALS

Like the world of professional music, modern live video art has developed several distinct sub-genres of VJing. Some of the most commonly encountered today include:

Show Visuals
Media Remixing
Live Cinema
Set Design
Interactive Installations
Film and Music Video Production
Art Objects
While these are very different fields, there is often a large overlap in the skill sets involved. Many VJs eventually find themselves specializing in one or more of these areas, or at least assisting on projects that fall outside of the scope of traditional production techniques. Likewise many people who start in these fields may find VJing to be something they want to learn more about.

Day 1 - David Lublin, of VDMX, and Melissa Ulto, who performs professionally as VJ Miixxy, will lecture on the methods and tools used to create live video performance.  Then an informal jam session will allow everyone to try out being a VJ. 

Day 2 - David and Melissa walk you through a typical show or installation setup, from planning to breakdown - what to expect, what tools you'll need, and resources to continue on the professional VJ path.

title: VJing- WTF is it? - Day 2
description:
Video Jockey â€“ in the 80's and 90's, the term â€œVJâ€ was popularly considered the video version of radio â€œDisc Jockeys,â€ the person who introduced the next song on television.

In the late 90's and early 2000's, as the world of DJing evolved beyond simple curation of music with specializations like scratching, sampling, remixing and the like, so have VJs expanded their set of tools and techniques for live performance and production.

Today someone who is a VJ might appear to be something more akin to a video instrumentalist or visualist, someone who creates and manipulates images in ways similar to how a modern musician works with sound.

Personally I think of a pro VJ as a video art ninja and rockstar in one; capable of bridging the worlds of preproduction, live performance and post production. The methodologies involved are evolutions of those used for early film special effects and avant garde video artists from the 60's and 70's, well before the introduction of the MTV VJ era.

GENRES OF LIVE VISUALS

Like the world of professional music, modern live video art has developed several distinct sub-genres of VJing. Some of the most commonly encountered today include:

Show Visuals Media Remixing Live Cinema Set Design Interactive Installations Film and Music Video Production Art Objects While these are very different fields, there is often a large overlap in the skill sets involved. Many VJs eventually find themselves specializing in one or more of these areas, or at least assisting on projects that fall outside of the scope of traditional production techniques. Likewise many people who start in these fields may find VJing to be something they want to learn more about.

Day 1 - David Lublin, of VDMX, and Melissa Ulto, who performs professionally as VJ Miixxy, will lecture on the methods and tools used to create live video performance. Then an informal jam session will allow everyone to try out being a VJ.

Day 2 - David and Melissa walk you through a typical show or installation setup, from planning to breakdown - what to expect, what tools you'll need, and resources to continue on the professional VJ path.

title: Anaglyphs in Processing
description:
One of my projects for ITP Camp is to create a Processing Library to enable everyone to create 3D anaglyphs. These are the 3D images you look at with red-cyan tinted glasses. I would like to contribute this library to the open source community for all to use.

In this class I will show you how to use the library and tools I have built to explore this art form. I will discuss the limitations of anaglyphs and show you what works well and not so well. I will provide you with 3D glasses to get you started.

The library already exists and works great, but I need to create examples and documentation and make sure it is sufficiently user friendly and understandable. This class will help me a great deal, as any feedback will help me make a better contribution to the community.

I will tailor this class to beginners but please don't let this be your first class on Processing. I will review some of the basics of Processing in 3D for people who have not used it before.

title: Microscopic Cinema
description:
A journey through the inner layers and textures of microscopic lands. We will go through mise-en-scene, lighting and panning up/down and X/Y/Z. A DIY demo with a light stereoscope, microscope mount and DSLR camera will give you a glimpse into what can be done when organic and inorganic specimens are placed under the microscope. We will end with a series of films shot under the microscope from documentary to fiction to hybrids.

Type: Presentation. Demo Film Screening
Audience : Scientists, filmmakers, artists and other animals
Duration: 2 hrs (30 min presentation, 30 min demo, 30 mins screening)
Notes: Microscope with camera mount will be available for ITP Camp from then onwards for those who want to use it. People can come in / out.

title: Electronic Esperanto - Smart Appliances
description:
Bring an Arduino and learn how to control your household devices via the internet with Spacebrew (http://docs.spacebrew.cc/). 

For this class you will need to share or bring the following:

An arduino

A powerswitch tail  if you have one (http://www.powerswitchtail.com/Pages/default.aspx) or enough wiring / circuitry experience to safely wire a device to your arduino.

Something with an on / off switch (desk lamp, fan, etc. we can improvise)

In addition, it would be helpful to have downloaded Processing (https://processing.org/), Arduino (http://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software), and Spacebrew ahead of time, and go through the process of successfully installing them if you're able.

We will cover it briefly in class for anyone who has trouble along the way. 

Leave comments in the notes if you have questions, or if you have components you can lend to the session.

title: Intro to 3D in Fusion 360
description:
Learn basics of Autodesk Fusion 360 software.
We will cover all the basic tools needed to design and prepare a model for 3D printing.

Sketching/Modeling
Inserting image files
Creating text as sketch
Importing model
Customizing
Exporting .stl

Please pre-install the software before the session, available from Autodesk.com

title: Projection Mapping with Processing & MadMapper
description:
Learn how to take projection projects to the next level by using MadMapper to do projection mapping. We will demonstrate the basics of projection mapping, as well as how to integrate Arduino and Processing to do live, interactive graphical projections.

IMPORTANT :: 
Download the free trial of MadMapper at madmapper.com You can also find it for free if you look around. Import the Syphon library in Processing (Sketch > Import Library > Add Library, search â€œsyphonâ€).

title: Electronic Esperanto - 3D Environments driven by Open Sound Control
description:
We'll look at how to set up the 3D Program Unity to receive Open Sound Control (OSC) messages, allowing us to drive changes in our 3D scenes with virtually anything. 

We'll focus on a program for iOS called touchOSC, and if we have time we'll look at driving animations with sound.

Please download the programs in advance if you'd like to figure out how to get the class examples running on your own machine.

* [Unity3D](http://unity3d.com/)

* [touchOSC](http://hexler.net/software/touchosc)

* [OSCulator](http://www.osculator.net/)

* [Ableton Live](http://ableton.com) - totally optional but if you're into sound, we may have time to experiment with this

title: Electronic Esperanto - Compositing live video and effects between openFrameworks and Max MSP
description:
We're gonna do a big ol' mashup of stuff in this one - grabbing a live webcam feed and throwing it into openFrameworks to do some slitscanning and facial recognition, then taking all of that into Max MSP and Jitter to do some chromakey background replacement - all in real time.

You are encouraged to have the software installed ahead of time:

openFrameworks - http://openframeworks.cc/
Max MSP - https://cycling74.com/products/max/

If anyone is particularly good with openFrameworks or Max MSP, please let me know! Perhaps you can help us take our projects even further in this session.

title: Making a Living as a Creative Individual - an open forum on careers and funding
description:
You can multiplex an LED array. You know your way around a CNC router and a laser cutter. *You* can write your **ITP** session descriptions in [markdown](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax)! You've even learned how to augment sound with the movement of your body. You're ready to go out and do great things. Now what?

This will be an open forum where we will together discusse strategies, outlets, and experiences of making a living out of our passions.

* How do I find a sponsor / grant / residency / venture capital? What's up with kickstarter?
* Where do I find a venue?
* How do I develop a practical product that leverages my skillset?
* How do I find collaborators?
* Who do I approach to solve my knowledge gap?
* What do I do when someone wants me to work for free?

These are some of the topics we'll try to tackle. 

**DISCLAIMER** - I fall into the camp of someone who needs answers to nearly all of the above questions, so I will need help from some of you to volunteer your advice and time. If you feel like you have experience or success with any of the above and would like to participate, please email me to let me know.

If you feel like you're in the same boat as me, please feel free to email me with a list of your own pressing questions or thoughts so I can compile a general outline for the night's discussion. 

Let me know if you'd be interested in participating - mheavers@gmail.com

title: Unreal Engine Developers Meetup
description:
The Unreal Engine Developers Meetup is a monthly meetup where UE devs get together to talk shop, pitch projects, and show off their latest creations.  

This month is a show and tell format where a handful of devs will show a project they are working on with time for Q&A afterwards.  Past projects have been 3D games, mobile games, interactive installations, virtual reality projects, 360Â° immersive video, etc.  

This months presenters:
Reed + Rader
Matthew Rader from digital director duo Reed + Rader will talk about one of their latest creations Dubstep Dinosaurs 3D, show an in-engine look behind the scenes at their process, and talk about using the Unreal Engine to make videos.  

More presenters to come.

title: SOFT WEAR - Build your first soft circuit
description: Build your first soft circuit! In this session we will make a simple LED circuit using conductive thread and fabric. Supplies will be provided in limited quantities so please RSVP if you plan to attend!

title: Music Visualization with p5.js
description:
Letâ€™s use the web to design new music experiences and learn about p5.js, a JavaScript library that reimagines Processing's creative code methodologies for the web. 

Create audio-reactive online music visualizations. Weâ€™ll use p5.js to bring the Processing approach to Web Audio. Learn digital audio concepts through interactive, tinkerable code examples. We'll share methods for mapping sound data to meaningful visuals, and collaborate to create new music visualizations.

title: Making 3D Holograms With Lasers - Session 2
description: Due to an overwhelming response for the first session at Noon, this is a second chance to participate in a hands on workshop where you will get to work with lasers and make a real 3D hologram of your own. A hologram is an incredibly powerful medium with resolutions as high as 10 billion pixels/in by 3000 deep. The session will begin with a lecture explaining what a hologram is, how it works, and how they are made. We'll also learn the difference between true holograms and other 3D media that have been referred to as holograms. You'll get to see several different types of holograms and pseudo holograms and learn how they are used. Then we'll set up a small holographic camera and shoot holograms on photopolymer film. The image will be in full three dimensions and can be seen in white light without the need of any special eye wear. This session will run approximately three hours.

title: After Effects 101
description:
Get started with After Effects. After Effects 101 will get students started with one of the most powerful pieces of software available for animation, motion graphics, visual effects and compositing. 

The first hour will be for complete beginners and cover how to navigate the program and set up a composition. The second hour will focus on motion graphics (graphic design that moves) and animation (working with scenes and characters). The third hour will cover compositing (making video look good) and visual effects (camera tracking, motion tracking, making fiery explosions etc.) Time permitting, we'll also take a look at expressions and scripting (coding for After Effects).

Students should expect to gain a strong grasp of the capabilities that After Effects offers and a jumping off point for how to implement them.

It is strongly recommended that students come with a computer that has After Effects installed (and ideally Photoshop and Illustrator as well.)

title: Climate and Society: Using data to affect social change (workshop!)
description: Human activity is profoundly altering the Earthâ€™s climate â€” and the social, geopolitical, and human implications of these changes are already being felt around the world. The threat posed by climate change might well be the most important story of our time, but journalists struggle to tell this story in a way that is scientifically rigorous and compelling to a broad audience. This workshop will introduce you to the Data Library of Columbia Universityâ€™s International Research Institute for Climate and Society, which has more than 400 freely-available climate-related data sets to explore. Weâ€™ll provide some discussion about how it can be used to understand our climate, and look to you for a stimulating discussion of how data in general can best be used to tell compelling stories about climate change and its significance to their lives and well being.

title: Building Characters
description:
Q: What do Leonardo daVinci and Chuck Jones have in common? A: They both made cartoons! 

Drawing is one of the best ways to explore and present ideas, and a great way to find out what you understand. Whether you're constructing a classical drawing, designing a character, or sketching an idea for your next invention on a napkin, drawing is a straightforward way to discover key ideas and get them across.

The session will look at examples of classic drawing techniques from daVinci to Disney and see how they could apply to your drawing. There will be a live clothed model to work from. Please bring something to draw with and on - from paper and pencil to tablet and stylus. 

All levels of drawing are encouraged, from beginner to advanced. This could be a beginning for sessions of 2D and/or 3D animation if people are interested.

title: ITP NodeSchool
description:
Get to know the fundamentals of JavaScript, Node.js, WebGL, Git and more through
[NodeSchool](http://nodeschool.io/), a series of interactive workshops. You can
take these yourself online, but in-person workshops are held regularly in
different cities for feedback and guidance. Some of the topics include:

* [javascripting](http://ghub.io/javascripting)
* [learnyounode](http://ghub.io/learnyounode)
* [git-it](http://ghub.io/git-it)
* [how-to-npm](http://ghub.io/how-to-npm)
* [web-audio-school](https://github.com/mmckegg/web-audio-school)
* [webgl-workshop](http://ghub.io/webgl-workshop)
* [shader-school](http://ghub.io/shader-school)
* [introtowebgl](http://ghub.io/introtowebgl)
* [expressworks](http://ghub.io/expressworks)
* [learnyoureact](http://ghub.io/learnyoureact)

We'll start with a brief introduction to Node, NodeSchool and getting everything set up, followed by working through the lessons independently. The session leaders will be available to help you with any problems you run into along the way!

title: Interactive Video Art & Max MSP/Jitter
description: In this class we will look at new ways of implementing video as a medium for creating engaging interactive installations. How do we create video art and installations that move, emote and react to our presence? The course will focus on taking video off the screen and into three-dimensional space in the form of site-specific and or physical installation. Basic Max/MSP + Jitter will be taught as well as a lecture on contemporary video art.

title: Video Mapping a Big Ass Building PT 1
description: Have you ever wanted to project video onto a really big building? If so then this is the course for you. First you will see great examples of really big video being projected on big things and then we will scan a giant building. Each student will get the scan and then in two weeks at the end of camp you can project something interesting onto the building.

title: Video Mapping a Big Ass Building PT 2
description: Time to project the results of PT 1 of this workshop onto a big building!

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Required for all campers!

title: The Internet of Healthy Things
description: Technology is changing the way we experience and manage our health & interact with physicians. Connected health allows for remote monitoring, virtual care, smart homes and wearables.  In this class we will discuss the BJ Fogg model, how to build a habit forming product and discuss the challenges and needs as we move towards a patient-centered ecosystem.   We will discuss user experience and how different health conditions require different connected strategies, as well as how various pieces of hardware and technology can be used to produce connected health products.

title: Tour of the AT&T AdWorks Lab and discussion on creating place based experiences
description:
In this session you'll have a chance to see the AT&T AdWorks Lab, an experience created to showcase data and the future of TV. In this digital world, we'll also talk about the importance of creating experiences in physical place. We may talk about the future of retail, what's happening in theme parks and other topics such of interest. You can see the lab at https://vimeo.com/90078495

The Lab is at 810 7th Avenue at 53rd Street. You will need ID to get into the building.

title: Switching it up: circuits, switches & LED's (the basics)
description: Note: please come to this session with your Arduino Kits and a notebook to take some memorable notes!

title: Animation Studio
description:
Are you thinking of working with projections? Wouldn't you like to see animated characters zipping around a building? 

You have probably seen movies like Toy Story, Shrek and the Hobbit, or cinematic games, from Myst and Mario to No Manâ€™s Sky. Theyâ€™re amazing and exciting to watch, but to create them requires a steep learning curve and significant resources.  However, itâ€™s possible for a single person to create compelling animation. All you need is an idea, some basic techniques, and resources that you already have.

In this hands-on animation session, weâ€™ll explore examples, and try out techniques that you can use to create effective, compelling animations for games, video, or as art. Stop motion, rotoscoping, and cel animation are available to create digital animation without a huge upfront learning curve. And they are completely scalable â€“ you can make them as simple or as sophisticated as you want.

For your personal animation studio, all you need is a computer, a camera, and a way to put things together. That might sound like a lot of equipment to get, but theyâ€™re included in your phone, tablet, or laptop.

There are a lot of possible equipment configurations â€“ please bring something to draw with, and either a computer with access to Photoshop or similar software and a digital camera, or an iPad, iPhone or Windows/Android equivalent, or both. We will go over available software and apps, then look at several ways to create your own animations. We will have a dancer-model on-site to work with.

title: Art and Activism: How to Save the World with Interactive Art
description:
Want to make this world a better place with your creativity? Curious about art that carries political and social conscience? Tired of looking at war zone photographs and watching poorly made documentaries? You are in the right place.

We will look at contemporary art by artists from all over the world (Ai Weiwei, Olafur Eliasson, Alfredo Jaar, etc.), whose projects include social media art, art based on large community research and collective memory, and art that interacts with the whole world. We look at art from political, environmental, and human-rights perspectives. We will also have discussions and make our own activism projects!

Creativity defies boundaries.

title: Field Trip to Stoll Fashion and Technology Center, Tour 2
description:
Stoll is a knitting machine manufacturing company with headquarters in New York. The Fashion and Technology Center is an amazing resource. Artists and designers can produce samples. They also offer classes and workshops. One of the best parts of the Fashion and Technology Center is the Stitch and Pattern Archive, where we can look at samples spanning from 1873 to present. 

Details are TBD, but I hope that we will be able to visit the facilities and see samples of some of their technical and innovative knitwear.

title: Personal Cloud Servers: Take Back Your Data for Fun and Freedom
description:
Intro
--------
Cloud services offer remarkable convenience, but even free (as in "free beer") ones come at a price: you forfeit control of your data. Luckily there are some great free (as in "freedom") / open-source alternatives that you can host yourself. This session will focus on DropBox alternatives like OwnCloud, SyncThing, and BitTorrent Sync. (OwnCloud in fact does a great deal more, serving your calendars, contacts, music, notes, etc.)

Breakdown
-----------
I'll begin with a 20-30 minute introduction to existing FOSS cloud projects and discussion of some political and personal motivations for taking back the cloud. Then we will set up SyncThing, which is pretty quick (probably 15 mins), and OwnCloud, which is more involved (up to 75 mins).

Prerequisites
-------------
To get the most out of this session, you should be comfortable on the command line. For installing OwnCloud, you should have a Linux machine ready in advance â€” whether that's a physical machine like a home server or Raspberry Pi, or else a remote box through something like AWS or DigitalOcean. If this part interests you, please come to the session ready to SSH to whatever machine you plan to use to host OwnCloud. (And by all means, drop me a line in advance of the session if you'd like some help getting your machine set up!)

title: Data Sonification with Max/MSP and Arduino
description:
In this session we'll do data sonification (as opposed to data visualization) using Max/MSP as our sound engine and programming environment. We'll use serial communication between Arduino micro-controllers and Max to transmit data from sensors in real-time.

If interested, we can also do things like sonifying CSV, TSV, or other text-based data. Let me know in advance if these latter options pique anyone's interest. 

We'll go through the basics of serial communication, think about what makes for comprehensible (or simply aesthetic?) sonification, and explore digital synthesis.

title: Whoâ€™s in the room? Checkout SeeWho, a proximity-networking app for ITP Camp 2015.
description:
Get to know your ITP Camp mates using SeeWho, a real-time people discovery app that enhances in-person networking and brings social serendipity to live events.  

This session will help you setup SeeWho (on your iPhone, iPad or iPod) and learn more about your fellow campers. Use SeeWho throughout your camp session.  Drop in and get started, 15 minutes is all you need.  You can also come prepared for networking by downloading SeeWho anytime before you arrive.

Real world example involved in rolling out a proximity app including discussions about design, UX, technical, tools, marketing and business issues.

GET STARTED
Download and install SeeWho. Itâ€™s free and available on the App Store on iTunes here: http://seewho.me/app 

Then sign into SeeWho with your LinkedIn account.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ABOUT SEEWHO
SeeWho helps people connect with each other, network for new opportunities or can simply just put a name to a face. SeeWho is a Bluetooth Low Energy 4.0 iBeacon app and is designed to discover people nearby, within a distance of 230 feet/70 meters.  Zero configuration required and immediate benefit. Weâ€™re calling it "smart networking." We believe it will make your networking events more social, productive and fun.  SeeWho was developed by two ITP alums. Learn more at: http://seewho.me

Get started with SeeWho now and see who you'll meet!  Any questions please email me at hello@seewho.me

title: Costumes for Cyborgs_sound: experiments in sound and movement
description:
This presentation will go through technical and theoretical development of Costumes for Cyborgs, an experimental wearable device.  

Costumes for Cyborgs_sound creates performative articulation of the wearer's movement, producing sound through biofeedback. By placing devices on our bodies, the piece asks the wearer to engage physically with the myth of the cyborg: blurring lines between wearer and interface. In this engagement we allow for shifts and augmentations of the relationship to bodies, as well as to create space for an expansion of the idea of body via non-biological tools.

title: The Vinyl Cutter will blow your mind!
description:
The vinyl cutter is the ultimate desktop tool for paper, prototyping, crafts, fabric, and pretty much everything else that's flat! Make decals for your car, a greeting card for your friend of paper prototypes of your newest product. 

In this workshop we'll learn the Silhouette Studio software, talk about importing from other illustration software like Adobe Illustrator and Rhino, and start cutting on the best machine at ITP! (Really.... I freaking love this thing so much, I own one myself!)

title: Sci Fi + Social Justice Book Club
description:
> **Inventing the future makes it more likely**
>
> *Lucy McRae*

We'll be reading stories from the fiction anthology **[Octavia's Brood: Science Fiction Stories from Social Justice Movements](http://octaviasbrood.com/)** available from [AK Press](http://www.akpress.org/octavia-s-brood.html)  or [Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/Octavias-Brood-Science-Fiction-Movements/dp/1849352097). You can also find it at Strand Books, it's on the first floor table labeled, "New Fiction Just Arrived."

From the publisher:
*Whenever we envision a world without war, without prisons, without capitalism, we are producing speculative fiction. Organizers and activists envision, and try to create, such worlds all the time. Walidah Imarisha and adrienne maree brown have brought twenty of them together in the first anthology of short stories to explore the connections between radical speculative fiction and movements for social change. The visionary tales of **Octaviaâ€™s Brood** span genresâ€”sci-fi, fantasy, horror, magical realismâ€”but all are united by an attempt to inject a healthy dose of imagination and innovation into our political practice and to try on new ways of understanding ourselves, the world around us, and all the selves and worlds that could be. The collection is rounded off with essays by Tananarive Due and Mumia Abu-Jamal, and a preface by Sheree RenÃ©e Thomas.*

This session will be a round table discussion / book club of readings from the book, and ideation session how science fiction might catalyze social movements and generate new cultural forms.


Reading List
------------------
Attendees are encouraged to read the whole book, but if you can't make it from cover to cover, we'll start with these chapters:

*    *the river* by adrienne maree brown (p. 23)
*    *The Long Memory* by Morrigan Phillips (p.57)
*    *Hollow* by Mia Mingus (p. 109)
*    *Kafka's Last Laugh* by Vagabond (p. 177)
*    *Manhunters* by Kalamu ya Salaam (p. 197)
*    *Star Wars and the American Imagination* by Mumia Abu-Jamal (p.255)

Information about each of the authors can be found at the end of the text.

title: Physical Computing Meets the Browser: Controlling HTML using node.js and serial data
description:
Want to learn how to control things in a browser from an Arduino? Want to know how to turn on motors and lights from a web page? In this session, I'll show you how to use node.js and the node-serial port library to communicate with an Arduino microcontroller, and how to pass the data from the microcontroller to a web page served by node. This will allow you to build screen-based interfaces to physical devices in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

### What you might want to know (or learn) in advance: 

* What a microcontroller is, what an Arduino is, and how to program one to send serial data to a computer
* What JavaScript is, how it interacts with HTML in a browser, and the basics of how to program in JavaScript

### The tools we'll see in this session 

(you might want to load these on your laptop beforehand)

* [Arduino 1.6.4](http://www.arduino.cc/)
* [node.js](https://nodejs.org/)
* [node-serialport](https://github.com/voodootikigod/node-serialport) library
* [P5.js](http://p5js.org/)

title: Click Out The Jams: an Intro to DIY Digital Audio Recording
description:
This introductory-level lecture will cover principles of audio recording, various interfaces, and digital audio workstations for beginners. Even a basic understanding these concepts can help you improve the quality of any audio-related projects you might work on, such as interactive music, sound sculptures, documentation videos, song demos, rockstar dreams, etc.

Topics will include input/output, cables, digital recording, signal flow, music production workflow, and some basic mixing and effects. The lecture will conclude with a live demo of Logic X that will include hardware available for checkout from the ITP Equipment Room.

You will not need to bring anything to this session, but if you want to try out Logic, you can check out a production laptop from the ER beforehand.

title: Fabricating with Fungus
description:
In this hands-on workshop, we will first discuss fungi to lay a context for the class. For the bulk of the session we will explore mycelium as material for fabricating. 

The beginning of the workshop will be spent discussing the relatively unknown Kingdom of Fungi. Mycelial networks have been likened to social and communications networks. Fungi communicate, remediate, and decompose. They are used as food, medicine, spiritual guides, and material building blocks. Some are crucial to the soil food web; others will kill you. What do we have in common with mushrooms? What can we learn from them? 

Then we will move on to fabricating with fungus, using coffee chaff as our primary substrate. Each participant will fabricate a small mycelium form, which will take approximately 2 weeks to grow, and will be available for pickup once it's ready!

We only have supplies for 20 participants, but more are welcome to join us and check out the process.

title: Introduction to IP Telephony with Twilio
description:
Have you ever wanted to connect an incoming phone number to your maker project, either to process voice calls, set up an interactive voice response (IVR) system that will control your project, or even just respond to SMSes?

In this introductory workshop, we'll learn how to install and use Twilio, a cloud-based service that gives you a real phone number that you can connect to your application. We'll make a super-simple IVR system in PHP and call it from our cellphones! If there's time we can play with text messaging.

title: Future MappersÂ©: Map on Masks
description:
You know how to create a 3D object in 3D software but do not know how to make a object and map your favorite videos and images onto it.

We will be making a 3D paper mask and mapping visual contents in real time and introduce, miniMAD from GarageCUBE to make a projection mapping installation without a Mac computer.

You also get 30 day full access MadMapper and Modul8 which only work on Mac computer. Paper Mask template will be provided before the class.

title: What and Where is the Equipment Room?
description: If you would like to check out production laptops, OcculusRifts, Headphones,  Kinects, etc. you do it through the ER (Equipment Room)!  I will be walking through the Equipment Room and the checkout process.

title: What and Where is the Equipment Room?
description: If you would like to check out production laptops, OcculusRifts, Headphones, Kinects, etc. you do it through the ER (Equipment Room)! I will be walking through the Equipment Room and the checkout process.

title: Experimenting with Cartesian Co Argentum Desktop PCB Printer
description:
One of the updates coming out of the [Introduction session](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2015/session/144) last Wednesday was the offer by Cartesian Co to let us hack on an Argentum unit for all of ITPcamp -- to try a few things and strategies that might make these dPCB devices even more useful to makers & hackers. 

This session will be an open hands-on workshop to hack on the Argentum we were given. Attending this session will include basic training for all who attend for how to use the device -- and add you to the list of those who can check out and use the Argentum whenever someone else is not using it (and it isn't being used for a specific substrate or project workshop on the schedule) during camp. 

Come hang out with us so that more of us can have the training to keep this unit out and printing tests and experiments all camp!

I'm looking to add more sessions for specific experiments requested by those looking into this stuff -- make sure to reach out to me if you have a specific circuit you'd like to print or project to try with this device so that I can get the resources available to make this possible.  

From the [Introduction session](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2015/session/144):
This past year, a number of new startups have been pioneering the Desktop PCB (dPCB) fabrication printer category -- with a number of technologies ranging from Desktop PCB (dPCB - such as Cartesian Co, Voltera, and Botfactory), Desktop PCB Milling (such as OtherMill, Shapeoko3, Carvey, X-Carve, etc), Desktop 3DP (with conductive filament - such as Voxel8 / Project Wire), as well as more readily available handbuilding PCB tools than ever before (stickers, sheetcutters, conductive pens, and more). In his recent Maker Faire Bay Area talk, Chris Anderson singled out this new field as of particular interest to makers right now -- let's take a look at where things are so far and where they are going next!

title: Search High and Low
description:
> _"Leverett is a little better. They still make you search, but you can do an empty search and get links to pages with every studentâ€™s picture. Itâ€™s slightly obnoxious that they only let you view one picture at a time, and thereâ€™s no way Iâ€™m going to go to 500 pages to download pics one at a time, so itâ€™s definitely necessary to break out emacs and modify that perl script. This time itâ€™s going to look at the directory and figure out what pages it needs to go to by finding links with regexes. Then itâ€™ll just go to all of the pages it found links to and jack the images from them. Itâ€™s taking a few tries to compile the scriptâ€¦another Beckâ€™s is in order."_

> -- Mark Zuckerberg, October 28 2003, 1:52 a.m., "Harvard Face Mash | The Process"

Between storing and visualizing data comes the task of searching through it. Search tools give us the ability to make sense out of large, inconsistent datasets. They allow us to filter out noise and focus in on specific terms. They allow us to see emergent properties and patterns in data that can guide visualizations. Naturally, however, different kinds of datasets call for different kinds of tools. In this workshop we examine some of these tools: regular expressions, a means of identifying patterns in text; `csvkit`, a set of programs for working with csv files; and (time permitting) Elasticsearch, a search engine used by Netflix, GitHub and Etsy.

### Software
I'll demo everything so it's okay if you just want to watch. All the code/commands will be available afterwards. But if you want to follow along on your computer, use Terminal to install the following software:

#### `csvkit`
* `sudo easy_install pip`
* `sudo pip install csvkit`

#### `elasticsearch`
1. If you don't have it already, [install homebrew](http://brew.sh/)
2. `brew install elasticsearch`
3. If you get an error about Java, run `brew install Caskroom/cask/java` and try step 2 again
4. `sudo pip install elasticsearch`

title: Kids Day Brainstorm
description: If you're interested in helping us put together a kids day program, please join us for our first brainstorm. We need to pick a day/time and then explore what we can get together for kids to see and play. Email me with any questions/thoughts and if you'd like participate but can't make the meeting.

title: Mobile VR: Getting started with the Google Cardboard part1
description:
This is going to be an introduction on how to use the Google Cardboard Asset on Unity 3D, and the beginning on virtual reality production for your mobile phone. In this first session I'm going to be showing how to get every thing running on Unity 3D, and exporting the Google Cardboard Demo to your phone. 

Please go ahead and download Unity 3D, on this link http://unity3d.com/get-unity/download?thank-you=personal&download_nid=16340&os=Mac  and follow the installation.

If you are on Android phone, please download the Android Studio (http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html), or just download the "tools only" ( http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html#Other) you are fine with them too. 

If you are and Apple user, please go ahead and download Xcode from the Apple Store.

Hope you guys are as excited as me to get Virtual Reality running on your phone!!!!!

see you, any questions or anything just mail me. (casg1991@gmail.com)

Carlos Serrano

title: Mobile VR: Getting started with the Google Cardboard part2
description:
In this second part, we are going to experiment with the LeapMotion Sensor on your phone (this is an Android Only - Sorry Apple Guys), and the widgets they are creating to get it work with Virtual Reality!!!

Bring your phones, laptops, and the best Energy.

If you need help, or anything let me know.
see ya,

Carlos Serrano
casg1991@gmail.com

title: Easy 3D Modeling and Printing with Tinkercad and Makerbot
description:
TINYURL for the Hackpad: http://tinyurl.com/itpcamp3d 

The first half of the session will cover 3D Modeling, led by Don Undeen.
The second half of the session will cover 3D printing, led by Takafumi Ide.

Are you intimidated by all the options of complex 3D tools like Blender? MeshLab not doing it for you? MeshMixer too weird? Do you have a few cool 3D ideas floating around in your head, but always thought "gosh, I don't think I could EVER design in 3D!" If so, then you're like me. At least, until I discovered **TinkerCad** .

TinkerCad is a free web-based 3D modeling tool from AutoDesk. It's hella simple; with only a few operations, you can make all sorts of printable stuff. 

In this session, I'll go over the basics of navigation, combining shapes, using rulers for exact measurement, importing models, and using tinkercad as a final step before printing.

Being a Museum Person, I'll be showing how to make easy art mashups, and integrating sculptural scans with CAD-like elements.

Audience: This class is for people who don't think of themselves as 3D modelers, but want to make something they can print or share online.

In Advance: sign up for Tinkercad, and install Blender (I've got one good blender trick to show)
- https://www.tinkercad.com/
- https://www.blender.org/

2nd Hour: 3D printing with Makerbot: Led by Takafumi
- Based on your TinkerCad model, we'll learn how to set up prints in Makerbot's Software. We'll give you advice on how to make designs that will work well in the 3D printer. We'll also share examples of other work we've done with 3D printing.

Duration: 2 hour max.

For More Details and links for the class, check out our working lesson plan on hackpad here:
https://don_itpcamp.hackpad.com/Easy-Intro-to-3D-Modeling-with-TinkerCad-x6wrkA9wvKs

title: Make your own printed circuit board
description: Knowing how to make your own printed circuit board is an important tool in the prototyping process. If you're circuit is working on a breadboard, you may want to consider making a more permanent connection between your components. In this hands-on session we'll produce a simple printed circuit board using the heat transfer method. Students will use equipment from the circuit fabrication lab. All supplies are provided.

title: grow your own piezo crystal
description: Interested in learning to grow your own piezo crystal? If grown properly, piezo crystals can generate impressive amounts of voltage by converting mechanical stress to an electrical charge.  In this session we'll go through the steps necessary to create a rochelle salt piezoelectric crystal and discuss how piezos are used in electronics.

title: Learn to surface mount solder
description: This hands-on session will introduce you to basic surface mount components and their functions.  Don't fear the minuscule.  By the end of the session you'll learn to solder your first SM LED circuit.

title: Programming for Beginners, Part 2/4 (JavaScript)
description:
Picking up where we left off, we'll:

* review getting set up, variables and data types
* go over homework solutions
* discuss basic control structures, such as conditionals, loops

title: Looking Under The Hood: Augmented Reality Meetup, Informal Workshop & Skill Share.
description:
Do you have an interest in augmented reality? Better yet, have you worked on an augmented reality project that you want to share? Come out to this session and talk about your project. John will share and explain his entry into the Tribecca Film festival. Mike will discuss "Augmented Asbury," a project  that reconstructs historical structures on the Asbury Park Boardwalk. If time permits, we can go beyond a standard show and tell and "look under the hood" and give an account of how our projects were created. 

Depending on interest, we can go through a step-by-step demo on creating an augmented reality channel within the German augmented reality platform Metaio. Metaio was recently acquired by Apple, signaling yet another player getting involved in this field.

title: Custom Controllers, Max MSP & Arduino - Meetup, Informal Workshop & Skill Share
description: Looking for fun ways to get your max patch to talk to your Arduino? Have you built your own buttons and foot pedals? Would you like to share your project? No matter how crazy your project is, bring it in and talk about it. Show your Arduino sketch, your max patch, and your sensors. Talk about what worked and/or what failed miserably. Or just watch the blinking lights and hang out. Rune will speak about his work with Max MSP and the Microsoft Kinect. Mike will walk through a work in progress, "16 Step Social," a max patch/instrument that samples Instagram videos and plays them via a controller inspired by the Roland TR 808 drum machine.

title: Soundbite for WNYC - at a gallery show in Chelsea
description:
A producer from WNYC ( big NPR radio in NY) and Studio 360 program want to record a number of people in a gallery in Chelsea for just 3-5 minutes each. It's radio, so it's just your voice. She's looking for reaction and visual description of the work in the gallery show. 

OK if you know me, but haven't SEEN the show. Better if you don't google it ahead of time.

Please RSVP if you can drop by the gallery 3-5p Thurs - just pop in anytime in that window...it will take 5 minutes. The radio podcast/show will air later in June. Studio 360 is a very cool program. http://www.studio360.org/ 

She's looking for audio reactions...you don't need to know anything about art. She needs fresh voices. And a fresh response.

Address is: Pavel Zoubok Gallery 
531 W. 26th St, 2nd floor (between 10th/11th)

If you want to make the trip worthwhile, here a good link for other shows in the Chelsea neighborhood. The Kusama show at David Zwirner on 19th is very, very fun to see.
http://artcards.cc/newyork/shows/18th-to-29th-street-(Chelsea)/

thankyou!! it'll be fun, and seriously you can hear yourself on-the-raaaadioooo.

title: What and Where is the Equipment Room?
description: If you would like to check out production laptops, OcculusRifts, Headphones, Kinects, etc. you do it through the ER (Equipment Room)! I will be walking through the Equipment Room and the checkout process.

title: What and Where is the Equipment Room?
description: If you would like to check out production laptops, OcculusRifts, Headphones, Kinects, etc. you do it through the ER (Equipment Room)! I will be walking through the Equipment Room and the checkout process.

title: Field Trip to Brooklyn Fashion + Design Accelerator
description: On this field trip we will visit the facilities of the Brooklyn Fashion + Design Accelerator. At the end of the tour we will have snacks and drinks while we meet the research fellows in the t.Lab, a research group with an emphasis on fashion and technology. Tour plus reception (includes drinks) $125- cost will be divided by number of participants http://bkaccelerator.com/

title: Processing: Starting with VERY rudimentary basics
description:
Our two-hour programming session here caters to individuals with no experience using Processing programming. Individuals who need to refresh their memory are more than welcome. Youâ€™ll be guided through each step, first by opening up a new document (a sketch).

The teaching format is broken down into very small increments. First, Iâ€™ll use short example codes and explain each scenario, then you will execute the code step-by-step. Youâ€™ll then run the code; whereby, you will instantly see your own visual creations. You will be encouraged to play, help each other out and write code without fear.

We will download Processing in class. But to save time, it would be helpful if you would download Processing beforehand:
https://processing.org
 
Together weâ€™ll create interactive digital art using:

â€¢ 1: Primitives (circle, rectangle, line, arc and point)
â€¢ 2: Blocks of code (void setup and void draw)
â€¢ 3: Events (mouse & key press)
â€¢ 4: Variables (int, float, animation and random)
â€¢ 5: Booleans (if and else)
â€¢ 6: && (and)     || (or)     ! (not)
â€¢ 7: Text & fonts
â€¢ 8: Bouncing balls

title: Shop Safety! Mandatory
description: Required for every Camper!

title: How to Use CNC Router
description:
This session will teach you how to use CNC machine to cut plywood, including drawing a design in VectorWorks/Illustrator, importing it to G-code in MasterCAM, and cutting it on the CNC  machine.

CNC stands for computer numerical control. A CNC router is a computer controlled cutting machine related to the hand held router used for cutting various hard materials, such as wood, composites, aluminium, steel, plastics, and foams. CNC routers can perform the tasks of many carpentry shop machines such as the panel saw, the spindle moulder, and the boring machine.

title: Sonic Lab: CMOS Noise Circuits
description: Before computers, electronic music consisted solely of transistors and logic chips. In this workshop, we'll build some of the basic building blocks of logic-based audio circuitry, including how to build Voltage Controlled Oscillators, Voltage Controlled Filters, Low Frequency Oscillators, and Step Sequencers. We'll check out the 4000 series of CMOS chips introduced in the 1960s to produce the sine waves and square waves heard in most analog synthesizers and drum machines.

title: Kinect V2 & Visual Effects with Macs II
description: Revamped session from previous insights. Up and running with Kinect V2 in Mac's OSX and OpenFrameworks. Download Xcode before coming to this session. Basic coding is encouraged but not required.

title: Intro to the Light Blue Bean as a better Arduino platform.
description:
This session will introduce you to the [Light Blue Bean](https://punchthrough.com/bean/).

**If** this time doesn't work for you I am running this [twice](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2015/session/237)!

It will cover how to get started, how to program it, and provide tips on programming on the Bean. 

## You should attend if:

* You are looking for a painless way to make wireless projects.
* A good option for wearables.
* A better Arduino programming experience.

## What you need:

* If you want to follow along you will need a [Light Blue Bean ($30 USD)](https://punchthrough.com/bean/) but you can just watch as well if you will pick one up later, or decide if you want one at all.
* If you are following along: Your laptop has to support Bluetooth Low Energy. Check the specs for your manufacturer for: Bluetooth 4.0 or Bluetooth Low Energy usually found under Wireless. 

This will be a short session, and will give you everything you need to know to get started with using the Bean. 

## Followup

*There is a much more involved session [Sunday June 14th](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2015/session/59), which will focus on making some cool interactive work with the Beans. Please join!*

title: Field Trip: The LED LAB
description:
Spend an hour and a half (6:30pm to 8pm) exploring The LED LAB in Tribeca (http://www.ledlab.tv/).  The founder, Marcel Dekeyzer will meet us and do a small presentation about the kind of work they do at the lab and answer questions about the LED display technology.  This is a unique opportunity to see some architectural-scale LED display technology up close, and in an interesting setting with professionals and designers who are eager to discuss their technology.  Refreshments may be served.

We'll meet at ITP at 6pm and head to the LAB, which is located at 475 Greenwich St.  (https://goo.gl/maps/c1FTR)

title: Openframeworks: A Thousand Particles
description:
Animation is all about things that move... And code is all about numbers. In this class we'll use Physics and Mathematics to make thousands of particles move in different ways. Expect to learn a little about C++, Newton and Trigonometry. The class will be taught in  [OpenFrameworks](http://openframeworks.cc/), a C++ toolkit for creative coding. 

*Please download Openframeworks and go through the IDE setup guide ([available here](http://openframeworks.cc/download/)) before coming to class. IDE downloads are large and may take a long time, so plan ahead! Please use Codeblocks if you are on Windows.*

title: MANDATORY :: Shop Safety Session
description: MANDATORY shop safety sessions for all ITP Campers!

title: MANDATORY :: Shop Safety Session
description: MANDATORY shop safety session for all ITP Campers

title: Data Visualization with D3
description:
Learn to make cool, interactive data visualizations for the browser using the D3 JavaScript library.  D3 is a very powerful tool for reading and visualizing data sets by leveraging the CSS, HTML and SVG capabilities which already exist in your browser.  It provides data management and DOM-modification features which, while powerful and efficient, can take a little while to get the hang of.

In this class we will review the basics of D3, discuss the various idioms for coding up data visualizations, and take a look at some more complex examples.

Students should bring a laptop with an up-to-date browser (Chrome, Firefox, etc.) and a text editor.  It will be helpful to have some experience with JavaScript, as well as CSS, HTML and SVG as they live in web pages.  You can take a look at d3js.org for a preview of the kinds of things that D3 can do.  And if you have any data sets that you are itching to visualize, bring them along!
