title: ITP Camp Kids Day
description:
This is your chance to show off your mad camp skills to your children or bring some kids with you and get them excited about everything we do! We'll provide some refreshments, you supply the demos and materials! We've had great fun in the past and always had a great group of kids attend! Some examples of past events include:

Some things done previously include playing with LittleBits & Roominate, making pop up books, making their own Nerdy Derby cars, body scanning to turn the kids into action figures, stop-motion animation and making toy cars, but you design the sessions. Help us continue this fun tradition!

We put together a spreadsheet of session ideas and signups. Even if you can't lead a session, feel free to write down any ideas you have: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1EgR6sZ71PfVYLrGlSNXaRiFnt9GUVMBR8_tpP1IddLM/edit?usp=sharing

title: Games, Tools, and the New Language of Interactive Storytelling
description:
It used to be a simple thing, telling stories. You used to be able to get by with a little bit of Sumerian, an okay sense of poetic meter, and a penchant for exaggeration. Maybe you'd add a lyre for good measure, and that would be enough. And then someone said, "hey, let's put all of this stuff down on tablets!" and that's when the end of good ol' simplicity started...

Nowadays, interactive theatre exhibits like "Sleep No More" abound and the Museum of Modern Art actually has a hall devoted to video games -- video games of all things! Well if that's what the kids want, then that's what they'll get!

This session will be about: the state of storytelling in a world forever changed by the possibilities of physical computing, sensors, cinematic storytelling, electronic peripherals, and the Uncanny Valley. We will look at games that use forms of interactive storytelling that are unique to games ("Gone Home", "P.T."), as well as ones that adopt modern cinematic storytelling tropes a la "Bioshock". We will then examine in-depth the possibilities presented by VR headsets, motion-tracking, and other miscellaneous peripherals ("Dreadhalls", "Alien: Isolation, "Ether One", "Transistor", and "Rez"). 

No materials necessary other than questions and an open mind.

title: Digital Fabrication in the Classroom
description: In this workshop and discussion we'll take a tour of Makerspace/Fablab history, and their foundations, philosophy, research and methodology. We'll examine and share a variety of implementations and experiences of project-based curriculum inside schools.

title: Generative Design Using Processing
description: Generative design is a design method in which the output â€“ image, sound, architectural models, animation â€“ is generated by a set of rules or an Algorithm, normally by using a computer program. During this session we'll do create some programs using processing and we'll learn how to hack existing programs. Install processing before the session.

title: Intro to Paper Engineering and Pop-Ups!
description:
Get ready to make Paper POP!

In this session, we'll put down our computers and pick up our scissors! 

During the first hour we'll learn several common paper engineering techniques through demonstration and hands on building. Then, we'll apply what we've learned in an open workshop to build pop-up creations like cards, books, or anything else you can imagine!

-----
I'm Natasha - a recent ITP grad who loved the pop-up books class at ITP. Here's a link to my final project: www.everythingpopup.com
If there is a specific technique you are eager to try, please comment below and I will make sure to show the group! Can't wait! :)
tag_list: #Paper #Awesome #MakeCards #MakeBooks #Start a project to use later on the Vinyl Cutter!

title: Sci Fi + Social Justice Book Club PART 2
description:
This will be a second iteration of the book club, for those who couldn't make it on 7/21. We'll mainly discuss the readings (below) but please feel free to read as much or as little as you'd like. 

Please bring snacks to share!

> **Inventing the future makes it more likely**
>
> *Lucy McRae*

We'll be reading stories from the fiction anthology *[Octavia's Brood: Science Fiction Stories from Social Justice Movements](http://octaviasbrood.com/)* available from [AK Press](http://www.akpress.org/octavia-s-brood.html)  or [Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/Octavias-Brood-Science-Fiction-Movements/dp/1849352097).

From the publisher:
*Whenever we envision a world without war, without prisons, without capitalism, we are producing speculative fiction. Organizers and activists envision, and try to create, such worlds all the time. Walidah Imarisha and adrienne maree brown have brought twenty of them together in the first anthology of short stories to explore the connections between radical speculative fiction and movements for social change. The visionary tales of Octaviaâ€™s Brood span genresâ€”sci-fi, fantasy, horror, magical realismâ€”but all are united by an attempt to inject a healthy dose of imagination and innovation into our political practice and to try on new ways of understanding ourselves, the world around us, and all the selves and worlds that could be. The collection is rounded off with essays by Tananarive Due and Mumia Abu-Jamal, and a preface by Sheree RenÃ©e Thomas.*

This session will be a round table discussion / book club of readings from the book, and ideation session how science fiction might catalyze social movements and generate new cultural forms.

Reading List
------------------
Attendees are encouraged to read the whole book, but if you can't make it from cover to cover, we'll start with these chapters:

*    *the river* by adrienne maree brown (p. 23)
*    *The Long Memory* by Morrigan Phillips (p.57)
*    *Hollow* by Mia Mingus (p. 109)
*    *Kafka's Last Laugh* by Vagabond (p. 177)
*    *Manhunters* by Kalamu ya Salaam (p. 197)
*    *Star Wars and the American Imagination* by Mumia Abu-Jamal (p.255)

Information about each of the authors can be found at the end of the text.

title: Paper Circuits! The intersection of Craft, Electricity, and FUN! Circuit Sentiments Edition!
description:
Ready to play with paper and have FUN? 

When I discovered that copper tape and LED's could be embedded into paper and pop-ups, it blew my mind. 

In this workshop, we'll connect circuits using:

COPPER TAPE
A BATTERY
AN LED
A BINDER CLIP
& PAPER


Then, each of you will receive a FREE Circuit Sentiments Kit - A Light-Up Pop-Up Birthday card kit that includes all the pre-cut shapes and electronic components! 

The first hour will be a lesson in building a circuit and showing project examples, then the second hour will be building the Circuit Sentiments Kits, and an open workshop for making your own creations. 

Learn more about Circuit Sentiments here: http://www.natashadzurny.com/blog/circuit-sentiments/

Sign up to be notified when the Kickstarter launches here: http://circuitsentiments.com

title: The Vinyl Cutter will blow your mind! (again!)
description:
The vinyl cutter is the ultimate desktop tool for paper, prototyping, crafts, fabric, and pretty much everything else that's flat! Make decals for your car, a greeting card for your friend of paper prototypes of your newest product.

In this workshop we'll learn the Silhouette Studio software, talk about importing from other illustration software like Adobe Illustrator and Rhino, and start cutting on the best machine at ITP! (Really.... I freaking love this thing so much, I own one myself!)

(This is the same session as the one on June 7th)

title: Kids Day: Stop Motion Animation & Paper Collage
description:
As part of kids day, this workshop will be an opportunity to make scenes with paper and document them using stop-motion animation techniques. We will have tons of supplies including pre-cut shapes, scenes, and characters. We will also have materials to build paper circuits to bring your creations to life! 

We will have a few different stop-motion setups available to use, for kids of different ages/levels of interest. 

All ages are welcome!

title: Adobe Kickbox: an open-source process for innovation that includes free money
description:
Kickbox is a new innovation process that Adobe developed for its own use and then open-sourced so everyone can use it. It is both a process for individuals and a system for deploying that process across an organization at scale. Anyone can request a Kickbox which includes detailed step-by-step instructions, tools, chocolate, caffeine and a $1000 credit card.

As Chief Innovator at Digi International I'm currently piloting this process at our corporate headquarters. I'll give an overview of the entire program, we'll take a look at all the materials hands-on, and you'll learn how you too can use this new process to travel from raw ideas to excellent outcomes.

title: Open Trouble-shooting
description:
Is your ITP Camp Dashboard a whirlwind of activity? 

Is your inspiration brain in turbo mode?

Are you exploring strange new worlds of Arduino, Processing, and/or Javascript?

I don't know about you, but my brain is somersaulting with new ideas and projects that have seen their generation in the workshops over the past week. But sometimes a slight hang up can seem like an insurmountable roadblock when learning a new skill. Come hang out and navigate those challenges in your early-stage Arduino, Processing, or Javascript project.

This session is a co-working / troubleshooting studio.  It's a time to really dive into that project, in an environment where you can ask questions.

Alternatively, if you have a bit of creative coding experience, you're welcome to join for a session of co-working, as time set aside to delve into a project that might be migrating to the back-burner in the flurry of camp activity. 

PS - if you can't make it to the full session, that's totally fine! Stop by for as little or as long as you'd like :)

title: An iOS app in an hour(ish)
description:
This session is meant to serve as an introduction to making an iOS app. We'll cover how to display text, make buttons, and finally, how to make a web call and return a response! We will use Swift, Apple's new programming language.

Prior programming experience recommended, but no experience on the iOS platform necessary. This class will be run workshop style, so you would have a chance to code alongside and ask questions. If you want to follow along download the [Xcode 7 beta for free](https://developer.apple.com/xcode/downloads/) which allows you to build directly to your very own Apple device!

title: Favorite Gear for Making Wearables
description: Wearables sit at the intersection of electronics and fashion. How can we make those two worlds meet? This will be a quick, nerdy session that gives an overview of my favorite gear for making wearables, both from the book "Make: Wearable Electronics" and beyond!

title: Friday Fireside: Criticali-tay
description:
Fireside Criticali-tay:
Debunking the myths of tech in marginalized communities

Structured as a panel discussion; guests who work in marginalized communities will discuss the role of technology and its impact on their work as community organizers.

Note: This will be followed by some socializing with samosas & beverages!

title: Sewing 101
description: Learn basic sewing techniques while making your very own needle book! We will also review basic sewing machine skills. No previous experience required.

title: Getting started with Oculus in Unity
description:
Getting started with Oculus in Unity

Taught by Isi Azu, 
Chaperoned by Kyle Greenberg

This camp session will focus on working with the Oculus Rift (and possibly Google Cardboard SDK) in Unity 5. We'll get started by discussing how to set up our workspace in order to get the full experience with the Rift. After that we'll learn how to import the proper packages and assets to begin with Oculus in our Unity projects.

We'll discuss the different player control parameters attached to the Character controller. Then we'll learn how to quickly begin moving our character around by adding the Character Controller to our custom level. Lastly we will cover some of the ways we can use visual effects to enhance our VR experience. By the end of the session we will have created a basic VR experience using some of my prefabs and environments.

Download Unity prior to the session https://unity3d.com/get-unity/download

title: Laser Cutter: How-To
description: Want to learn how to use the laser cutter?! The basics/rules will be covered in this session! If you cannot make this session, keep an eye on the calendar for other Laser Cutter: How-To sessions!

title: Drawing & Animation using CSS and SVGs
description: Come draw and animate a monster creature while learning about some of the cool things you can do with CSS and SVGs! We'll start off by drafting and using Sketch or Illustrator (please have one of the two installed) to put our initial monster designs together, save them as SVGs, and then manipulate and animate them using CSS.

title: Detroit Music of the 80's
description: Detroit has one of the richest histories in american music (and otherwise) anywhere.  During the 80's Detroit saw a collision of influences that led to some of the most interesting music (and other things) to ever come from there.  This session will touch on some of my favorites, from the perspective of someone who grew up knee deep in the scene.  The journey will be mostly musical, but via this vehicle, we'll touch on history, politics, economics, and cultural poetics too.

title: Unity 3D Workshop(s)
description:
Iâ€™d like to do a few sessions of Unity3D on weekends to follow Sarahâ€™s intro class & also drill down deeper into special topics.
- First session will be a show and tell intro & whats new in Unity5.

Others might be:

- 2D games

- creating behaviors & physics

- Lights Shaders Textures

- the state machines & animation.

- Iâ€™d love to do an Oculus workshop 

- and maybe a Mo Cap with Kinect

Saturday Afternoons from 4/4:30 - 6 might be good.

title: Drawing The Figure and Characters: Take Two â€“ 2D & 2 1/2D
description:
Drawing is an iterative, interactive process.  Just like most things, the more time you spend with it, the better the result. Not only is each drawing a new beginning, but each new moment of a drawing is an opportunity to start again while keeping an eye on what you already have.

This session could be seen as the second half of the Building Character session, or stand on its own as a starting point. We will look at techniques for drawing flat and for representing 3D space on a 2D surface. There will be a live clothed model and a range of examples of artistsâ€™ work available as ideas and points of departure.

Please bring what you want to draw with and to draw on, from paper and pencil to tablet and stylus. All approaches, levels, and styles of drawing are encouraged - realistic to abstract, beginner to advanced, representative figures to characters.

title: Laser Cutter: How-To
description: Want to learn how to use the laser cutter?! The basics/rules will be covered in this session! If you cannot make this session, keep an eye on the calendar for other Laser Cutter: How-To sessions!

title: Unity 3D Workshop(s)
description:
Iâ€™d like to do a few sessions of Unity3D on weekends to follow Sarahâ€™s intro class & also drill down deeper into special topics.

- 2D games

- creating behaviors & physics

- Lights Shaders Textures

- the state machines & animation.

- Iâ€™d love to do an Oculus workshop 

- and maybe a Mo Cap with Kinect

Saturday Afternoons from 4/4:30 - 6 might be good

title: Working with Audio in OpenFrameworks
description:
In this session we will look at some examples of working with audio within OpenFrameworks. I have been working as a Sound Designer / Composer on a team that works heavily within OF so it has been important to utilize this development environment for the work I do. I will show you some simple examples I built out for quickly working with the ofxAudioUnits, ofxPureData, and ofxAbletonLive addons contributed by the OF community. 

This will be a very relaxed session so if you have no previous knowledge of OpenFrameworks or audio applications but are interested in seeing what you can do with these tools please feel free to stop by. 

I will however go through step by step on how I built these examples and how they were used so if you would like to follow along with your computer you will need the following.

- The latest Xcode
- The latest release ofOpenFrameworks for Xcode
- An installed OF Plugin
- ofxPd, ofxAudioUnits, ofxAbletonLive
- The latest release of Pure Data Extended for Mac
- These two free audio plug-ins: 
http://www.michaelnorris.info/software/soundmagic-spectral
http://www.alphakanal.de/automat.html
- If you want to actually build the examples in the session it will be important for you to already know how to insert an addon and build a project in OF.

title: Make Your Own Jewelry: Part 2
description:
Part 2:  The Laser Cutter!
We'll go over the settings and process of how to cut the jewelry you designed in the last session. Please RSVP only if you were in Part 1.

title: Porting Processing apps to Mobile Devices.  Beginning Processing Coders Welcome
description:
Have you ever written an awesome Processing program that you wish you could use on your phone? Or did you create a great game that would be me so much more fun with a touch screen?

Yes!

Were you frustrated by Processing or Processing.js's lack of support for mobile devices?

Yes!

Well then today is your lucky day! Processing Mobile makes it easy to add support for mobile devices to your Processing code.

In as little as five minutes, you can write your first Processing Mobile program.
With naturally named variables, Processing Mobile's syntax is so similar to Processing that you'll forget you are even using it.
Designed with beginners in mind, Processing Mobile has a very mild learning curve.

title: Make!Sense: Plug and Play Sensor Interface.  Easier than Arduino.
description: Fast prototyping of sensor ideas.  Great for teaching.  Make!Sense is my Kickstarter-funded sensor interface board, with sensor sets.  You'll be up and running with sensor input in a few minutes.  Lots of cool sensors that just plug right into the board.  Connects via USB cable to your computer.  Sensors include:  heartbeat, distance, temperature, light, tilt, breakbeam, etc.  For easy level:  sensor values come into the computer as keystrokes, great for Scratch, Javascript, Python, any language.  For Processing, you get a full stream of data from the sensors.  Great for beginners, teachers, quick prototyping and experimenting, fun.

title: Video Art History
description: A lecture on the history of video and interactive art with lots of videos and examples. From Nam June Paik and the portapak to Chris Milk and the kinnect. You will leave with knowledge and a burning desire to create something of your own.

title: A simple distributed video mapping system in Processing
description:
In this session we'll go through a simple distributed system I built for a video mapping project. The system allows you to use several computers with several projectors in a synchronized fashion.

We'll also cover the basics of video mapping and I'll talk a tad about my experiences.

Finally, we'll see a super brief tour of a VPT, a free opensource projection mapping tool.

title: Field Trip - NY Cake and Baking Supply
description:
We're going to make a Whale Cake that spouts sprinkles. (Because what else would a Whale Cake do, just sit there, being whale-y? Not at ITP!) 

So we're going to the greatest cake store ever to buy supplies, check out all the cool stuff they have and generally be floored by the sheer magnitude of things one can do with sugar. 

Meet us at:
NY Cake & Baking Dist.
56 West 22nd Street
Between 5th-6th

You don't have to join the Whaling expedition to come on the field trip, and vice versa.

title: Toast to Week 2
description:
With week 2 drawing to a close, we cordially invite everyone to join us for some burgers and moonshine (or whatever your pleasure) at an outdoor patio bar in alphabet city (just a few worthy walking blocks away from ITP). 

Meet in front of the campfire at 9:45pm to walk over or at the venue. 

Location:

Royale
157 Avenue C
New York, NY

title: Kids Day: Light-Up Pop-Up Greeting Card Making Extravaganza!
description:
I'm Natasha - And I've been working on Light-Up Pop-Up greeting card kits: http://www.natashadzurny.com/blog/circuit-sentiments/

I need your kids' help!

In this workshop, each kid will get a free kit, and will build the light-up pop-up greeting card. I believe it's best for kids around age 10-12, but I would love for parent /kid teams to try it with younger kids - let's see what they can do!

I'm looking for participants to test the kits and let me know if there is anything I can do better to make building a success! I hope you will participate!

(The session is limited to 10 teams of kid + adult, so that I have one kit for each team. Thank you!)

title: Board Game Night
description: Come play board games and drink beer!

title: Intro to 3D scanning
description:
An introduction to creating 3D scans of everyday objects and people using digital cameras, Microsoft Kinects, and your personal smartphones. We will do live demos on low cost scanning software that include PhotoScan, 123D Catch and Skanect. We will also discuss tips on getting a better scan, post cleanup and minor repair with Meshlab. 

Please come with these programs installed: 

123D Catch: for PC, iPhone and Android (not available on Mac)
http://www.123dapp.com/catch#download
Meshlab:
http://sourceforge.net/projects/meshlab/files/latest/download
*PhotoScan:
http://www.agisoft.com/downloads/installer/ 
*Skanect:
http://skanect.occipital.com/download/

*Photoscan and Skanect are not free software packages but both offer free demo version downloads. It's not necessary that they download these versions but are free to if they want to check out the UI.

title: Processing: Starting with VERY rudimentary basics â€“ Session 2
description:
Even if you didnâ€™t do Session 1, I trust you can easily follow along.

Our two-hour programming session here caters to individuals with no experience using Processing programming. Individuals who need to refresh their memory are more than welcome. Youâ€™ll be guided through each step.

The teaching format is broken down into very small increments. First, Iâ€™ll use short example codes and explain each scenario, then you will execute the code step-by-step. Youâ€™ll then run the code; whereby, you will instantly see your own visual creations. You will be encouraged to help each other out and write code without fear.

To save time, it would be very helpful if you would download Processing beforehand:
https://processing.org
 
Together weâ€™ll execute:
 
1: Variables (int, float, animation and random) â€¢ 2: Booleans (if and else) â€¢ 3: && (and)     || (or)     ! (not) â€¢ 4: Text & fonts â€¢ 5: Bouncing balls
 
Look forward to meeting you in class.
tag_list: Processing â€“ Creative-Programming â€“ Interaction â€“ Digital-Art

title: Programming for Beginners, Part 3/4 (JavaScript)
description:
Part 3!

We know enough programming to make a game! We'll be incrementally improving our game as we go over the following topics:

* conditionals with more sophisticated boolean expressions
* loops

title: LUNCH WITH DENNIS! (The Interactive Music Video Maker)
description: Creative coder and Google Creative Lab worker George Michael Brower runs Always and Forever Entertainment (http://aaf.nyc) and recently launched an epic, awesome interactive music video: http://www.dennis.video, which has been getting a lot of attention. He also made Staggering Beauty (http://www.staggeringbeauty.com ) and a bunch of other cool art, code and music. He will come in for a discussion of his process and aesthetic during lunch.

title: Toast to Week 3!
description:
Unwind and toast the close of week 3 with fellow campers, staff, faculty and counsellors. 

With only days left, this is a wonderful opportunity to strengthen the bonds with your fellow camp-mates so that you can really have reason to stay in touch after as well as possibly get to know those that you have yet to introduce yourself to. 

Family and friends are welcome. 

6 blocks from Tisch. 

124 Old Rabbit Club
124 Macdougal Street

NYMAG Review 

212-254-0575

Itâ€™s hard to find, and youâ€™ll have to ring the buzzer, speakeasy-style to gain entrance to this tiny subterranean beer bar. But once inside, youâ€™ll feel worlds away from MacDougalâ€™s student-clogged sidewalks. The dimly-lit interior looks like a catacomb where Trappist monks brew some of the divinely delicious beers served hereâ€”unfinished walls are covered with prison-style chalk scratchings, while arty chandeliers inject a touch of modernity. More than 70 semi-pronounceable imported brews are available, from the faintly carbonated licorice hints in the Scottish Old Engine Oil to the sweet, frothy punch of the monk-made Maredsous.

title: Sound Design in Performance - Basics of Acoustics, Psychoacoustics, and Multi-Channel Audio
description:
This will be an introductory session on sound in live performance.  Move beyond stereo!

We will be discussing the basic physics of audio briefly at the top of the session before moving into psychoacoustics - how our brains interpret the sounds they're hearing and how we can use that to shape an experience.

We'll use concepts of psychoacoustics to create (at least on paper) the fundamentals of a multi-channel sound system (this ain't your grandma's Dolby 5.1) and talk about sound system design - from stadium concert sound to Broadway musicals.  

Other topics I'm planning to cover include sound system "tuning" (how to EQ and delay your speakers into a cohesive and constructive system), [QLab](www.figure53.com/qlab) (a multi-channel audio and video playback program), and if there's time and interest, microphone/equipment selection.

I'm totally open to changing up the topics in this session, so if there's a topic I'm not covering, I'd be happy to add it.

title: Intro to the Light Blue Bean as a better Arduino platform.
description:
This session will introduce you to the [Light Blue Bean](https://punchthrough.com/bean/).

It will cover how to get started, how to program it, and provide tips on programming on the Bean. 

## You should attend if:

* You are looking for a painless way to make wireless projects.
* A good option for wearables.
* A better Arduino programming experience.

## What you need:

* If you want to follow along you will need a [Light Blue Bean ($30 USD)](https://punchthrough.com/bean/) but you can just watch as well if you will pick one up later, or decide if you want one at all.
* If you are following along: Your laptop has to support Bluetooth Low Energy. Check the specs for your manufacturer for: Bluetooth 4.0 or Bluetooth Low Energy usually found under Wireless. 

This will be a short session, and will give you everything you need to know to get started with using the Bean. 

## Followup

*There is a much more involved session [Sunday June 21th](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2015/session/59), which will focus on making some cool interactive work with the Beans. Please join!*

title: all about eBooks -- how to make them (your own) and break them (open)
description:
eBooks--what's inside? Learn about the surprisingly simple technology behind creating an eBook and hacking one apart!

Including:

--discussing the differences between various formats: azw, EPUB3, KF8, Apple iBooks, etc

--playing around with public domain epub files: examining the HTML and CSS within

--ebook creation software choices: turning your manuscript into an .epub file

--some best practices for ebook production

--The present, and future of ebooks (Whispersync, HTML5-powered "enhanced" ebooks)

--different devices and apps (if there's time)

Link to slides:

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1mv_ZtggAQvC8B9DWbXCjE51Bs4vP1BcObKL1rGzuzNM/edit?usp=sharing

title: Hacking visual design
description: This session will be covering the main steps of ideation process, typography, color theory, use of imagery, grid systems, hierarchy and most popular tools & resources.

title: Dang girl - How'd u make dat? Illustration, Comics, and stories from paper to web
description:
I've been asked by a bunch of people to teach a class on my illustration process! (see below for some links to my work)

The truth of the matter is that my process is an ever evolving and shifting thing. Creating art and stories is an exercise in creative problem solving, and there are always new and interesting ways to integrate my work into new mediums.

In light of this, I'd love to make this class itself a collaborative endeavor - Give me some feedback here about what kind of ideas or techniques you'd like to explore:
[http://goo.gl/forms/vDXikDODbS](http://goo.gl/forms/vDXikDODbS)

--------------------------

Things I will definitely go over:

+ Keeping the mind loose: sketching and note taking
+ Finding the right program for a project*
+ Let's talk about Illustration and comics ... on the web!!! (dun dun dun)
+ And whatever else the swarm deems important!

*I use Adobe Creative Cloud for everything (mostly photoshop, some illustrator) - if you'd like to mess around while I mess around, that's what I'll be messing around with. 

--------------------------

MAH WERK:

+ Portfolio: [http://hayleypowers.com/](http://hayleypowers.com/)
+ Comic: [http://hayleypowers.com/ripples](http://hayleypowers.com/ripples)
+ Blog: [http://hayleypowers.tumblr.com/](http://hayleypowers.tumblr.com/)

title: Field Trip to the Holographic Studios
description: Holography is one of the most powerful 3D visual storage media, yet few have actually seen it.  Jason Sapan has offered two session of making holograms at ITP Camp this Summer, but now you can get to see his studio where he makes them.  This is his 40th year as a professional holographer.  You'll  get to see many different types of amazing holograms, large and small including holograms of celebrities, sculptures, and even computer generated objects.  Best of all, you'll get a personal tour of his subterranean laser laboratory right out of Doc Brown's lab from Back to the Future.  And rumor has it, if you show up, he'll even give you one of his holograms.  He's smart, he's funny, and it will be fun!  Come directly to 240 East 26th Street where we'll meet in the gallery.

title: Personalizing music theory and recording
description:
First hour of the session will introduce students to theory of music, providing them with the skills needed to read an write Western music notation. It will cover basic harmony, rhythm and scales.

Second hour will cover how to record your own audio file (music, sounds, effects). It will cover how to add some effects, editing audio and bouncing it.

Software used for the session: LOGIC

title: Making Kokedama: Hanging Moss-covered Gardens
description:
Kokedama is a Japanese form of plant binding that enables moss-covered plants to live outside of a container and be suspended from string. These dreamy plants can transform any room into a tropical paradise! We will make a bunch of kokedama and learn some tips and tricks for materials, plant choice, and long-term care.

Let's get our hands dirty!

title: Movable Types
description:
The advent of movable type in printing presses radically increased the creation and decimation of ideas.  And the Internet has turbocharged the movability of text.

But telling stories in motion pictures is what really moves our culture now.  Visiting any movie set or watching the credits scroll at the end of a movie make it clear that we are still in the era of scribes in making movies.

New technologies like the Kinect camera can capture images broken into parts like words that might be recombined into movies more like word processing.  

This session is meant to look at the promise and problems of looking at visual storytelling as we do storytelling in text with a system of more flexibly captured and rearranged, potentially reusable and shared parts.

title: Creative Production from beginning to end
description:
This is a 2 hour session designed to take you through the creative production process from responding to a brief to delivery of your project to the client. We will cover the below, using examples from our work.

Brief
Responding to briefs â€“ doâ€™s and donâ€™ts
Examples of successful responses
Tips on how to get a commission
 
Process, for example:
	1.	Budget â€“ financial scoping
	2.	Research and Development - Scoping development (GDD / vision document)
	3.	Scheduling
	4.	Resourcing
	5.	Project Management - tools such as Base Camp/ Codebase how to make sure youâ€™re on budget / on schedule / sprints / â€˜agileâ€™ development
	6.	Production - prototyping, UX, design, filming, development, QA, user testing
	7.	Client/Artist Management - sign off process/ communication / managing feedback, creating a backlog
	8.	Delivery - for example, submission to Apple or client (e.g. BBC)

If you're interested in attending please let us know. If you want to join but can't make the suggested time also let us know!

title: PechaKucha Night - ITP Camp 2015 Edition
description:
PechaKucha Night, now in over 800 cities, was devised in Tokyo in February 2003 as an event for young designers to meet, network, and show their work in public.

The format is simple: the presentation is consisted of 20 images, 20 seconds each.

We way be making this PechaKucha Night so that everyone can show the projects they're working on, or things that inspire them, you name it. 

All presentations must be uploaded here:

https://drive.google.com/a/gambiarra.cc/folderview?id=0B5rKNkGkfKyYajFZbVJFYVpzREE&usp=sharing

title: Communicate (and maayybe monetize?) your creations!
description:
ITP campers have made some really cool stuff this year! Have you ever wanted press coverage about your work? If so, stop by the lounge for an informal class about how to talk to journalists (we can be strange creatures). We'll discuss how to communicate the complexities of what you're doing to those outside your circles.  

If we have time, we'll also talk about ways to think about monetizing your creative work!

title: Simple music instrument with openFrameworks
description:
Using openFrameworks, we'll build a simple music instrument from scratch. Nothing too fancy, but if you have no idea what a class is and want to learn how to create a simple class object, or if you just happen to like sine waves, you might enjoy the session.

The participants I'm picturing are beginners, somewhere between no coding experience and having installed + tried out tools such as openFrameworks or Processing a couple of times without really feeling familiar with the whole thing. You're still totally welcome if you have more experience than that.

Some things that will be addressed:

* drawing a line
* attaching simple sounds to lines
* making a whole lot of these things
* a few potentially helpful approaches for beginners to learning how to code

Helpful if you bring a laptop with these things installed:

* openFrameworks and IDE that corresponds to your OS (go to [http://openframeworks.cc/download/](http://openframeworks.cc/download/) and follow the instructions; another option is to just check out a production laptop from the equipment room. I can't say I'm really familiar with installation on Windows, but feel free to reach out if you need help in any case)
* Audacity [http://audacityteam.org/download/](http://audacityteam.org/download/)

Please comment or email me for any suggestions & Qs.

title: Shooting things is a disaster
description:
In this session weâ€™ll cover the basic elements of shooting a news documentary and discuss:
What makes a compelling story.
What makes a great character.
Some ways to film environmental disasters. 
What to do when everything goes wrong in the field.


Brendan FitzGerald is the Head of TV Development at Vice Media and senior producer on the Emmy-winning Vice on HBO Seasons 1 and 2.

title: Kids Day Hologram Workshop
description: Learn all about holograms and lasers.  Holograms are the coolest of 3D images with incredible resolution.  Unlike other formats you don't need any special glasses to see them.  You'll get to see how other types of 3D work and how they are different from true holograms.   Holograms are made using a real laser and special high resolution laser sensitive film.  You'll get to see some of the many different types of holograms made with different types of film and equipment of still and motion images.  If you've never experienced holography this is your chance to see and learn all about it.  We'll even be making holograms!

title: JavaScript, the Internets, and You
description:
We'll talk about how JavaScript integrates into a web page. We'll demo using plain JavaScript (no jQuery) to manipulate elements on a web page, and we'll also check out bringing in external libraries. Here's what we'll cover:

Background Info

* a very short primer on HTML/CSS
* a demo on functions and objects

Aaaand... the Fun Stuff

* manipulating a web page with vanilla JavaScript
* brining in external libraries, such as p5

title: Intro to Hacking Your Microbiome
description:
Did you know that you can track where you've been based on the microorganisms that you share your body with?

Dr. Gerard Honing, CEO of Symbiotica, a biotech startup from Harlem Biospace, will be joining us to explore the intersection of bacteria, fungi and the billions of other microorganisms symbiotically sharing your physical space. He will discuss how the theory and methods behind collecting and analyze them, but also interestingly what the data, especially visualized looks like and can look like. The applications with processing, 3D printing, and even more are boundless.

Will be followed by food and beer in the cafe to get a chance to get to ask any remaining questions and get to have some 1:1 time with our speaker.

title: Build session for Piccolo - The tiny CNC bot
description:
We are building this kit:
http://piccolo.cc

I only created 15 kits and I'm setting up sessions for the next few days to allow the selected campers time/space to build their kits. The final component for the kit was delivered today so we may as well start building. If you can't make it to one of the sessions (Tuesday and Wednesday), let me know and I'll give you the kit to assemble to fit your personal schedule.  Just don't take it home and forget about it.

If you did not make the random selection process cut, feel free to stop in and ask questions.

The kit goes together in about 2-2.5 hours.  There is some soldering involved, but mostly it is assembling the kits with nuts and bolts.

Install the software ahead of time to save some time.

title: Build session for Piccolo - The tiny CNC bot
description:
We are building this kit: http://piccolo.cc

I only created 15 kits and I'm setting up sessions for the next few days to allow the selected campers time/space to build their kits. title: Projecting on a Big-Ass Building (part 3)
description: Make up session!  NOW we're going to project your work on a building.

title: VJ'ing for Beginners - Getting Started (On the Cheap!)
description:
Interested in creating live visual art as a "visualist", or interested in vj-ing as part of a musical performance, but not sure where to start? Have you wanted to take a look at Modul8 or Resolume but your computer isn't up to snuff--or you don't want to take the plunge for hundreds of dollars worth of software without learning more? Then this session is for you!

Even if you have experience with other VJ programs, this might be a nice backup solution for you--OpenTZT is a tiny, free visual art program that does lots of what the more established video manipulation programs will do while being very light on system requirements--it even runs on my vintage 2001 Thinkpad!

Basic logo animation, image manipulation (rotation, scaling, wipes, dissolves) as well as real-time, live effects, frame blending, etc are possible with this program, as well as live video capture, text overlay, and other basic functions usually found in commercially-available video manipulation programs.

We will be working with existing images and animations and making some of our own, and learning how to trigger all of the effects, so download the program and install it on your computer before the class and we'll take turns showing our creations off on the projector!

http://opentzt.sourceforge.net/

This program is available for Windows-based computers only, but I'll have a demo PC set up for everyone to have a chance to try the program out.

title: Make a Simple Web App with Instagram API (For beginners)
description:
Have you ever used web API such as twitter, facebook, instagram, yelp, and etc? There are so many useful APIs on the Internet. In this session, we will try to make a simple web app step by step with Instagram API.

â†“We will make this
![what we will make](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2015/images/session_photos/large/session_323.png)

We can change schedule if you want 

Instagram API Sample
[http://koji.bugs3.com/insta/](http://koji.bugs3.com/insta/) 

agenda  
-What is API?  
-Why should we use API?  
-How to use API?  
-Write some codes  
-Tips (how to use terminal, what should we do next etc)

requirement  
MAMP/XAMP/Web server that can use php  
For Mac Users  [MAMP](https://www.mamp.info/en/downloads/)    
For Windows Users  [XAMPP](https://www.apachefriends.org/index.html)    

*text editor  
[https://github.com/noskiller/ITP-Camp2015/tree/master/dev_env](https://github.com/noskiller/ITP-Camp2015/tree/master/dev_env)

*Instagram account  
Please make sure that you can login [this developer's site](https://instagram.com/developer/)

title: A Seminar on Teaching
description:
Carol Dysinger, a long time professor, adviser and teacher of many things,
will do a limited workshop on teaching -- how to structure teaching artistic and technical material geared for a diverse set of individuals. 

[Learn More about Carol...](https://gradfilm.tisch.nyu.edu/object/DysingerC.html)

title: Interactive Lights & Music: Movement Controlled MIDI + DMX
description: In this session we'll explore how movement can be used for the real-time control of music and lighting design for live performance.  This session will cover the basics of DMX lighting, midi music production, and ways of sensing movement.  We'll be working with Max/MSP/Jitter, Ableton Live, OSC, video tracking, and your phone's motion sensors.

title: Create a Choose Your Own Adventure Text game with Twine
description:
BEGINNER FRIENDLY
Twine is the revolutionary, free open-source choose-your-own-adventure game-making tool that has taken off in the past few years. Literally thousands of experimental narrative games and stories have been written in it,  many by first-time game-makers, including hundreds of games by queer, minority and other makers not traditionally included in the AAA world of professional games.
Twine games are created in a beginner-friendly visual tool that is free for Mac, PC and Linux.
This workshop/jam session will be an overview of Twine, a getting started, and then a session where participants can both play and create their own Twine games with assistance or in groups.
More info on Twine at twinery.org Check out some games at http://twinehub.weebly.com/index.html or https://twitter.com/philomela_twine

title: Camp Clean Up
description:
Time to get packed up and head on to the next adventure!

Blue bins & lockers MUST be cleaned out by 3PM. Personal materials should be removed from the floor by 4PM. 

4PM marks the end of our glorious month together!

Note: The floor will not open until NOON this Saturday, not 10AM.

title: Screen Free Knitting (for all levels)
description: Come join our knitting circle. Learn to knit or pick up a new project. Enjoy screen-free time with the relaxing art of knitting. Needles and yarn will be provided.

title: Camp Orientation!
description:
LOCATION:
721 Broadway, 4th Floor South, New York, NY
Take the left elevators to the 4th Floor

WHAT'S HAPPENING:
6PM - Doors open. Food, drink, and mingling. 
7PM - Camp Orientation. Everything you need to know about ITP Camp.
8PM - Super Awesome Activity.

Look forward to seeing you all then!

title: End-of-Camp Show & Tell
description:
Food!
Drink!
Party!
Projects!
Performances!
Fun!

This is a chance to see what everyone\'s been working on and have a last hurrah. See you there!

title: Finish Projects / Get Ready for Show!
Clean Up & Bon Voyage
description: This is a time to clean up and pack up. We will be breaking down the counselor stand. You will be clearing out your blue bins and lockers (by 6:30PM!), cleaning up from the night before, and claiming all your personal belongings. And by 8PM we will have all said goodbye!

title: ALL CAMP: Friday Fireside / SHOW ONE THING SHOW!
description:
A hybrid talent show / open-mic / show-and-tell extravaganza! Each person will have ONE MINUTE + ONE SLIDE to present ONE THING! 

For example, you might want to share:

+ A project you made
+ A place you traveled
+ A hobby you have
+ A dance you know
+ A song you wrote
+ A thing you ate

[ADD A SLIDE TO THIS PRESENTATION DECK!](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1mkeGoQCRpQt2xmTDBr6d7jfqbO4Ubo6zHUs7HgEK7ns/edit)

There are only 2 rules for the slide: it must include your NAME, and it cannot include any video content. 

In order to participate, you must make a slide! This document will serve as our â€˜sign upâ€™ sheet for the evening. At a minimum, just write your name! But feel free to fancy it up with images / animated gifs / etc! (just no video!).  

It will be a fun opportunity to get to know each other better, we hope everyone will sign up to share :)

title: ALL CAMP: Friday Fireside
description:
How do we utilize the resources of the maker movement to design for individuals with disabilities?  How can we include individuals with disabilities in the process?

Adaptive Design Association builds custom adaptations for children with disabilities using a collaborative design process that includes therapists, parents, and makers of all ability levels.  Hear about the process of designing for one and including individuals with disabilities in the making process.  

Panelists will include:
Tamara Morgan, Development and Outreach, Adaptive Design
Julia Damon, Doctoral Candidate in Occupational Therapy, Pacific University

title: ALL CAMP: Friday Fireside - "High Tech, Low Life" - Cyberpunk and Afrofuturism in the 21st century
description: "High tech, low life" is an expression in cyberpunk culture that expresses society's advanced technology juxtaposed with its failure to eradicate social divisions. How do people of color and other groups living on the margins of society subvert those divisions? In this panel/discussion, we will look at Afrofuturism as a framework for creating imagined futures for the present, and how we can use today's technology to express, create, and wield the power to shape the future.

title: Bodies in the Browser
description:
In this hands-on workshop, participants will learn how to access to data from the Microsoft Kinect 2 Game Controller in a browser and share the data over the internet.  

The Kinect has a slew of interesting capabilities that we\'ll try out such as: 

* Skeleton tracking which allows users to do things like live puppeteer 3D avatars or interact with a webpage using their body instead of a mouse

* Depth images which allow software to determine how far a user is from the camera and can be used in combination with a regular RGB image key a user out from the background to do things like go on virtual street-view tours.

and more!

title: JavaScript 101 with p5.js
description: Learn the basics of programming interactivity in the browser utilizing JavaScript with p5.js (a library for creating graphic and interactive experiences).  This workshop will introduce basic programming concepts (variables, conditionals, loops) and give participants a starting point for creating in-browser applications.  The focus will be on interacting with the canvas (for animation or drawing), and user interface elements such as buttons, and text input.

title: Fun with Surveillance Cameras
description: In this workshop, we\'ll explore the capabilities of modern surveillance cameras and look at how we can with a little bit of programming use them for creative purposes.  We\'ll look at how to control their pan, tilt, zoom functionality and build applications that involve using face detection and other computer vision techniques for creative purposes.

title: 3D Printing Studio tour
description:
IMPORTANT: Meet in front of 545 LaGuardia Pl, New York, NY 10012 at 4 pm. This is NOT the regular NYU ITP Building. 

Join in for a tour of NYU's LaGuardia studio! This tour will offer students an overview of this exciting new media studio and introduce the technologies that are used for 3D visualization, prototyping, tooling, and fabrication.

The LaGuardia Studio is a state-of-the-art facility and advanced technology resource for the NYU community, providing professional services in 3D printing, 3D scanning, wide-format archival digital pigment printmaking, and project development consultation.

title: MANUSxMACHINA: Fashion in an Age of Technology (Met Field Trip!)
description:
Let\'s go see this exhibit at the Met! Details here: [http://www.metmuseum.org/exhibitions/listings/2016/manus-x-machina](http://www.metmuseum.org/exhibitions/listings/2016/manus-x-machina)

Great for anyone who\'s interested in fashion, costume, or wearable tech!

Meet on the front steps of the Met at around 9;45. We\'ll go in at 10:00.

title: Meet the Flintstones
description: This session will explore the history of technology through the body. From hunter-gatherers to hackers this lecture-style session will cover concepts of affordance and body schema, and how the technology that surrounds us influences our corpus. Although lecture-based, this session will include promtps for exploring new potentials for interaction between bodies and technology individually or in groups.

title: Speechless
description: In Speechless weâ€™ll look at the ways in which technology choreographs our movementsâ€”from refrigerators to stairs, remotes to iPhones. Weâ€™ll then weâ€™ll experiment with altering those choreographies, and improvise turning found objects into tools for communication. The session will expand awareness as to the ways in which our behaviors are hard baked into the world around us, and explore the means for expansion.

title: Tools for Impossible Ideas: Approaching Civic Freedom through Public Art
description: Interested in people and public space, and creating social or participatory interventions? This 3 hour workshop, will explore a history of ambitious public projects with 'impossible' dimensions, deconstruct methods and strategies behind some of these projects and take it to the street to sketch project ideas that put these strategies to work. Participants will gain experience in moving from public observation to ideas for interventions and experiment in moving from idea to participatory experience.

title: Fundamental Pop-Up Paper Engineering
description: Ever wonder how Pop-up books work? This is your chance to find out. Bring a decent pair of scissors. I'll provide the rest.

title: Understanding Diabetes
description: At least 29 million Americans have diabetes. I will give a basic explanation of the different forms the disease can take, followed by an account of how technological progress, the diabetic online community, and changes in health care have affected life for people with diabetes. There will be Q&A + discussion. There is a lot to cover here. We will keep the format loose, and see what direction it takes.

title: Anyone can make comics
description: Have you always wanted to tell a story, but lacked the confidence in your drawing / writing / storyboarding ability? We will cover some elementary techniques and approaches to visual storytelling, and do some exercises to overcome your cartoonist\'s block. Just bring something that will make a mark. All skill levels welcome.

title: Introduction to Microcontrollers: ESP8266
description:
In this introductory session we focus on setting up a working environment and learning the basics to work with the [ESP8266][2] and NodeMCU. 

You can checkout the material for this session [on github][1]. 


[1]:https://github.com/goliatone/wee-things-workshop
[2]:http://amzn.to/1UjqoxL

title: IoT with ESP8266 and NodeMCU
description:
Microcontrollers, sensors, and the internet of things using  [ESP8266][2] and NodeMCU. . 

We will build a project involving sensors and integrate it with a data collection system.

You can checkout the material for this session [on github][1]. 


[1]:https://github.com/goliatone/wee-things-workshop
[2]:http://amzn.to/1UjqoxL

title: Radical Ethnography for Social Networks!
description:
Radical Ethnography is a 3 hour workshop covering the communication design of various social media platforms and a study into how fandoms, social media campaigns, and harassment campaigns use the specific design and infrastructure of the sites themselves to craft these campaigns. 

This is part ethnography, part observation, and all exploration. 

Workshop breakdown:
30-45 min lecture

(15 min break) 

1-1.30 hours of workshopping and exploring

(5 min break) 

30 minutes to present

Does the design of a social media platform determine how language is amplified and how language is used and evolved? Does the infrastructure of a site shape the identity of the site itself and users within the site?

title: Your Brain is a VR Supercomputer
description: Inside your head is one crazy powerful virtual reality machine, able to create entire new worlds. Let\\\'s take a look at the latest discoveries in neuroscience and mash it together with the burgeoning Virtual Reality revolution. We will go through the tools, experiments and mechanics behind our perception and how to mess with it in amazing new ways.

title: Document Your Project
description:
A workshop discussing how to document your coding/hacking/art project using documentary filmmaking techniques. For instance, you may want to document your project for explanatory, archival, or fundraising purposes.

Topics include how to plan and film broadcast-quality video interviews, ways to cover an event or performance, working with the equipment that you\'ve got, and utilizing social media to build support and interest in a project, with a focus on Twitter and Snapchat.

I\'ll propose some best practices as far as workflow as well.

Examples of well-documented coding, hacking, and other art projects will be shown and there will be some hands on bits as well.

title: Git Involved
description:
Git is the distributed version control system (DVCS) that is taking over distributed version control systems, and is becoming the standard DVCS for all varieties of software and design projects.

In this workshop **for beginners**, you will learn to use Git (with and without GitHub) in solo- and team-based projects. You will learn to revise, compare, and reset files, and, at the project level, you will understand how to branch, merge, and issue pull requests.

**Digital designers, developers, and engineers who have never used Git are the intended audience for this workshop.** The only pre-requisite is the ability to use a command line interface, such as Mac OS Xâ€™s or Linuxâ€™s Terminal or Windowsâ€™s Cygwin.

**Before the first class,** please do the following:

1. **Open a GitHub account** at [https://github.com/](https://github.com/)
2. **Download the GitHub client** at [https://desktop.github.com/](https://desktop.github.com/)

Slides for the workshop are available at [https://github.com/code-warrior/git-workshop](https://github.com/code-warrior/git-workshop) under the `v1.0.0` branch. Theyâ€™ll be continually updated until a final version is posted at 12:30 PM on Saturday.

title: New Media and Story Development
description: Integrating new media into performance or product design? Go over elements of "dramaturgy" and "design thinking" in order to create a pitch and proposal for your project.

title: User-centered practices with apps you already use
description:
The essence of interaction is the experience of someone interacting with your project. There are a myriad of ways to be user-centered in your design process, and you\\\'re probably already using the tools that enable it. 

During this session we\\\'ll learn how to solicit lots of feedback and collaborate with future users to enhance the entire design process.

title: Arduino x Unity Workshop
description: This workshop is for users with little to no experience with Arduino and Unity. Using Arduino Unos and buttons, photoresistors, force resistors, joysticks, etc. Iâ€™ll teach how Arduino communicates with Unity and vice versa and applying the values the sensors sending to the Arduino to game mechanics in Unity. This would require participants to have laptops/computers with Arduino and Unity installed.

title: Connecting Weather APIs to Game Design - How You Can Make Weather From Any City Affect Gameplay
description: This course will give participants the method of connecting weather apis to Unity and extracting various variables like temperature and wind into game mechanics or the overall game environment/game design. This would require participants to have laptops/computers with Unity downloaded and prepared code that I can provide through Github.

title: Movement Workshop: Kinesthetic Conversations in Crowded Spaces
description: Every day in New York City we find ourselves interacting in urban space, on crowded streets and subway trains. Crossing paths with strangers, near collisions, conversations without words. How do we decode the grammar to these kinesthetic conversations? Learn how to inject fun, freedom, and a little bit of mischief into your everyday interactions and gain new insights for designing social experiences. This workshop will draw upon diverse disciplines including experience design, social science, martial arts, and choreography. Come ready to move your body. No dance or martial arts background necessary. All are welcome.

title: Open Video Collective: Hacking Election 2016 (meets Mondays)
description:
Starting in September 2016, we're inviting members of the extended NYU community into a free online event to learn about, collaboratively document, and make sense of the 2016 American presidential electionâ€”with video!

At ITP Camp, we invite you to join the team as a co-creator. People of all technical, educational, and political persuasions are welcome. Together, we will imagine, build and test interactive courseware and curriculum that uses video to interrogate:

*How television shapes the election

*Whether political ads are still effective

*How money and influence shapes TV coverage

*Comparative news, from cable to CSPAN

*Bias and polarization 

*The role of blogs, internet media, and fact-checking

*Gaffes, sound bites and the modern spin cycle

We will test and discuss new ways for people to understand and shape political discourse with video, like: hacking television archives, enabling Facebook users to quote and contextualize candidate speeches, mining terabytes of captioned video for patterns and insights, helping people more easily generate supercuts, and more.

If you care about politics, elections, video or media literacy, please join us to design (and facilitate!) this open online event.  It's your civic dutyâ€”we want you!

We will meet Mondays from 6:00pm to 9:00pm:

June 6

June 13

June 20

June 27

The open online event will run from September â€” November 2016.

Who's involved (so far)?

   â€¢Ben Moskowitz

   â€¢Dan Schultz

   â€¢Sam Lavigne

   â€¢others TBD

   â€¢...you!

For more info, contact benjamin.moskowitz@nyu.edu

title: A Brief Introduction to Drone Journalism
description:
Come learn how prosumer flying cameras are changing storytelling. You\'ll get a crash course in basic flight controls, production techniques and motifs, and relevant laws and norms.

We\'ll also go flying and produce test projects.

In this session you\'ll use AR Drones to learn (which are harmless toys) and then Phantom 2 Vision cameras (which need to be operated with care).

We will be meeting for 2 hours at ITP then leaving for a field trip.

title: How to Make A Selfie Drawing in Augmented Reality
description:
**Part 1** / 6:00-6:45pm / Presentation + Q&A

Sharing â€œThe Selfie Drawings,â€ an ongoing project that has traversed several digital media methodologies â€” from digital drawing, 4K video, animated gifs, to an augmented reality â€œbook object.â€ The project has also taken form as a collaborative curatorial  endeavor that included 58 artists from around the globe interpreting contemporary self-portraiture through gif art.

Relevant Links: 

â€¢ [The Creators Project, â€œHow to Draw Your Selfie-Portraitâ€](http://thecreatorsproject.vice.com/en_uk/blog/how-to-draw-your-selfie-portrait)

â€¢ [TRANSFER Gallery, â€œA Subject Self-Definedâ€](http://transfergallery.com/a-subject-self-defined-carla-gannis)

â€¢ [Elle UK, â€œSelfie Culture & Augmented Realityâ€](http://www.elleuk.com/now-trending/selfie-culture-and-female-identity)

â€¢ [NewHive Blog, â€œSelfie-Self Portraits: Lindsay Howardâ€™s Interview with the Curators of NarGIFsusâ€](http://blog.newhive.com/collection/animated-gifs/)

(15 min break)

**Part 2**/ 7:00-8:00pm / Workshop

Selfies 2.0: Experimenting with digital drawing, photo apps, & the Blippar AR (augmented reality) app in creating a selfie.
 
Note: Subversions of "classical" selfie aesthetics & reinterpretations of the "self" are highly encouraged. Faces are NOT required for selfie works.

title: The Curious Class: Part 1
description:
ITP Campers are members of an influential class of people called The Curious Class (exhibiting the 4 types of curious behaviors).  However, even ITP campers are living in algorithm bubbles and not realizing their full curiosity capacity.

The â€œCurious Classâ€ is a playshop (not just a lecture) about curiosity, exploration and discovery, designed to awaken curiosity and exercise your â€œcuriosity musclesâ€, even for insatiably curious ITP Campers.  You will learn techniques that you can apply to yourself, family and colleagues and to your work, to stimulate curiosity (seeking and discovering behaviors).

- Trends and cultural forces shaping the rise of  The Curious Class of people (why now?)
- How curiosity is tied to longevity, happiness and success (i.e., survival of the curious), and other great facts about curiosity
- The evolution of discovery and curiosity through the ages, and across cultures, and its connection to innovation
- 10 Habits of highly curious people
- 6 Curiosity Tactics
- 4 Curiosity Types (like a Meyers-Briggs profile of curiosity)
- 7 Tricks to increase your CQ (curiosity quotient)

Part 2:  On Saturday, June 18, I will lead an extrasensory, cultural excursion designed to pique your curiosity, accompanied by a Curiosity Field Guide, with exercises to push your curiosity, exploration and discovery.

title: The Curious Class: Part 2
description:
Curious about curiosity? Come on our Curious Xcursion. Bust out of your algorithm bubble, awaken your curiosity and exercise your CQ, on this extrasensory tour in NYC.

A guided tour (18 stops) of NYC (with an accompanying Field Guid). You will get
tips, tricks and techniques and exercises specifically for your curiosity profile to increase your CQ.

It will be a fun and memorable guided tour of some of the most unusual, curious places in NYC.

title: Intro to Augmented Reality with Unity
description:
This workshop will be focused on the workflow for implementing quick solutions in order to develop Augmented Reality applications.

After a quick overview of existing AR technologies and applications, we will dive directly into development using Unity and Vuforia in order to export a simple app to an Android mobile device. Attendees will walk out of the workshop with the knowledge of building and deploying an AR application in a game engine.

(Required: a laptop running the latest version of Unity)

title: Portable Prototypes in VR
description: With the recent development of highly-capable, highly-expensive Virtual Reality hardware, it becomes easy to lose track of the fact that VR development can cost as little as $10. In this workshop, we will look at how Google Cardboard integrates with the Unity game engine to design, develop and export VR apps in less than a couple of hours and accessible to the greater audience!

title: Intro to Game Development
description:
The free and versatile game engine has been gaining traction in the past years as a tool to develop anything from networked VR to audio reactive visuals for live shows. 

But this workshop will introduce you to Unity as its original purpose. We will learn about Unity\'s core features as we go along prototyping a simple game that will end up in a playable form by the end of the afternoon!

title: 3D Food Printing is fun
description: This is not the Jetsons or StarTrek. 3d food printing is fun, Learn the basics of a new technology that enables new creative ways in the kitchen.

title: Beginning Arduino Part 1
description:
The first of two session on the Arduino including the very basics for getting started with a project. We plan to include: 
What is the Arduino
Why do we use it
How to blink an LED
Using buttons to control when the LEDs work. 

Bring an Arduino Uno, a USB cord, a breadboard and a laptop to the session and we will have the other parts you need!

[Here are the notes for our session](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1kOdhgWHg-6QW6nrAjkB6R8XMbEc8lntajHrAv1cpCdM/edit?usp=sharing) 

If you want to download the software for Arduino before the session, here is the link: [https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software)

Where to get an Arduino Uno, a breadboard and a USB A-B cable?

Online vendors
[https://www.adafruit.com/](https://www.adafruit.com/) Adafruit is in Brooklyn, short turn-around time for shipping

[https://www.sparkfun.com/](https://www.sparkfun.com/) Sparkfun Electronics

[http://www.makershed.com/](http://www.makershed.com/) Maker Media\\\\\\\'s online store

Tinkersphere is located at 304 East 5th Street, within walking distance. They have a pretty extensive stock available at the store. [http://tinkersphere.com/](http://tinkersphere.com/) 

[Microcenter](http://www.microcenter.com/) is located in Sunset Park, and has a number of components (including inexpensive off-brand Arduino Unos).

Resources:
[Arduino Reference](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Reference/HomePage)

[Sparkfun Arduino Tutorials](https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/what-is-an-arduino)

[Adafruit Getting Started with Arduino](https://learn.adafruit.com/lesson-0-getting-started/the-lessons)

[Make Magazine Arduino Project Ideas](http://makezine.com/category/technology/arduino/)

[Fritzing](http://fritzing.org/home/)

[Jodys Arduino Comic](http://www.jodyculkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/arduino-comic-2014.pdf)

[Breadboard Comic](http://www.jodyculkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/breadboard.pdf)

title: Beginning Arduino Part 2
description:
We will continue to cover Arduino basics. In this session, we will focus on analog input and analog output (PWM). How do you hook up a sensor to an Arduino? How can you use the information that a sensor provides to control an output? How does the Serial Monitor work in the Arduino IDE? We will also discuss resistor color codes and how to use a multimeter.

Bring an Arduino Uno, a USB A-B cable and a breadboard, we will supply the rest. 

[Slides for the session](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1THy9Eh37heMniNUfDkFwZmJNlAZKLJnA-i_5F6YVSrQ)

Resources:

[Switch types on All About Circuits](http://www.allaboutcircuits.com/textbook/digital/chpt-4/switch-types/)

[Intro to sensors on the ITP physical computing site](https://itp.nyu.edu/physcomp/lessons/sensors-the-basics/)

[Series and parallel circuits tutorial on Sparkfun](https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/series-and-parallel-circuits)

[How to use a multimeter](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1E0nJBU8bRkRFVEbW5BNHlPdk0/view)

[How to read resistor color bands](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1E0nJBU8bRkcWtjNUtfMUVRQXM/view)

title: Making Maps for the Web
description:
Learn how to work with maps on the web!  We\'ll look at available tools, but mainly be live-coding our own web page.  We will start with a dataset, and go through the process of creating a website, putting a map on the page, then plotting out points on the map.  

We will be working in HTML, CSS and Javascript.  The javascript will not be very complicated, but having a basic understanding of javascript will be very helpful.  We will primarily work with the Leaflet mapping library, and jQuery.  All you need is a browser and a text editor (I like Sublime Text).

title: Intro to Python
description:
Let's learn Python!  It's an awesome, readable programming language with tons of cool uses.  We'll mostly be live-coding, going through the fundamentals of python and running through some use cases like how to sort data, or doing text analysis.  You'll get a feel for the way python works and the huge potential it holds.

We will start with a brief intro to the Terminal, and split the time writing code between Terminal and a text editor (I like Sublime Text).

title: Lenticular Imagesâ€“3D & Animation on the Printed Page
description:
Learn to create animated or glasses-free 3D images that can be printed on a static page! We will cover the formatting techniques for lenticular printing and scanimation in this session and will take time for hands-on practice to create our own lenticular prints!

Please bring a computer and 10-20 digital images (either frames of an animation, or multiple views of the same object from slightly different locations) so that you can create these prints using your own content!

title: Observing Periodicity & Sound (with Arduino)
description:
The world is rich with vibration, oscillation, and periodic events that happen too quickly for us to see. In this session, we will explore two ways of viewing this previously hidden information: cymatics, and optical interference.

We will be hacking a Liquid Crystal Shutter to blink at a variable rate (past the speed the human eye can see) to reveal previously invisible periodicity: whether the flicker of a fluorescent light, recreating the wagonwheel effect, freezing the standing wave of a plucked guitar string, and so on.

We will be utilizing the same function of the Arduino as signal generator to each create a cymatics apparatus. This will allow us to see the shape of standing sound waves in water as the nodes and antinodes create beautiful patterns.

Materials needed will be posted shortly.

title: Archival Storytelling
description: How can you use Archival Images to enhance the impact of your interactive project?  This two-hour workshop will introduce participants to strategies for researching, databasing, storytelling, and rights & clearances of Archival Images.

title: GROUP DISCUSSION: Pump Up Your Proposal - Strategies for Successful Proposal Writing
description:
The Pump Up Your Proposal workshop will explore the key elements of proposal writing including tips on how to describe your project, creating a realistic timeline, and, assembling the best support materials to make the most compelling case for your project.   

*Update on 6/5/16: The person who was supposed to lead it is unfortunately unable to attend ITP Camp. It has been converted into a group discussion in case there are still people who want to meet up and trade tips.*

title: Will it Blend? Solving social problems through Game Design, a Playcentric approach.
description:
Playcentric design is a new approach in game design where a developer comes up with a user experience goal before building prototypes and working in any certain framework.
Think Game Jam meets Social Architect.

In this workshop, our goal is to solve a common problem, it can be a large systemic problem, or just an industrial design issue. We will design games as a solution to the identified problem.

Suggested frameworks: social media, cards and dice, pen and paper, scratch, unity, email, playgrounds.

This class will follow a rapid prototyping approach, working through analysis, identifying playable systems to provide support to the problem, prototyping in a paper format and play testing first, then expanding to a digital prototype.

Playtesting throughout this process will be essential, as will having a flexible approach to problem solving and UI/UX design. This class will be a 1.5 hour class. There is no cap on the participants.

By the end of this course, participants will have a paper prototype to share and a working digital prototype to continue to iterate on and implement as a real world solution.

Useful Skills: Prototyping, Art Direction, Movement, Sound Design, Game Design, Architecture, Education

Prototyping Software: Bosca Ceoil, Piskel, Scratch, Asprite, Unity, Twitter, Instagram, Facebook

title: Open Video Collective: Hacking Election 2016 (meets Mondays)
description:
Starting in September 2016, we\'re inviting members of the extended NYU community into a free online event to learn about, collaboratively document, and make sense of the 2016 American presidential electionâ€”with video!

At ITP Camp, we invite you to join the team as a co-creator. People of all technical, educational, and political persuasions are welcome. Together, we will imagine, build and test interactive courseware and curriculum that uses video to interrogate:

*How television shapes the election

*Whether political ads are still effective

*How money and influence shapes TV coverage

*Comparative news, from cable to CSPAN

*Bias and polarization 

*The role of blogs, internet media, and fact-checking

*Gaffes, sound bites and the modern spin cycle

We will test and discuss new ways for people to understand and shape political discourse with video, like: hacking television archives, enabling Facebook users to quote and contextualize candidate speeches, mining terabytes of captioned video for patterns and insights, helping people more easily generate supercuts, and more.

If you care about politics, elections, video or media literacy, please join us to design (and facilitate!) this open online event.  It\'s your civic dutyâ€”we want you!

We will meet Mondays from 6:00pm to 9:00pm:

June 6

June 13

June 20

June 27

The open online event will run from September â€” November 2016.

Who\'s involved (so far)?

   â€¢Ben Moskowitz

   â€¢Dan Schultz

   â€¢Sam Lavigne

   â€¢others TBD

   â€¢...you!

For more info, contact benjamin.moskowitz@nyu.edu

   â€¢Dan Schultz
