   â€¢others TBD

   â€¢...you!

For more info, contact benjamin.moskowitz@nyu.edu

title: Understanding the Internet
description:
This session is for people who want a better understanding of how the internet works. We\'ll talk about routers and switches and hubs (oh my!), as well as communication layers, protocols, and how networks are structured.  You\'ll also learn how to use a few programs for understanding network connections.  In order to do this, I\'ll also give a brief introduction to command line interfaces.

This is an introductory session aimed at people who want a general understanding of how the internet gets to you. No programming experience is required, but bring your laptop so you can try stuff out as we talk about it.

This is a much-condensed version of the early weeks of ITP\'s [Understanding Networks](https://itp.nyu.edu/classes/undnet-fall2015/) class.

title: Zap: Understand electricity better by generating it
description:
A lot of your camp projects - and the rest of your life - run on electricity. But though fundamental, electricity is kinda weird stuff. It's not really like water or gears or any other explanatory analogies. 

I think one of the best ways to get a better sense for how electricity works is to make your own, using muscle power and hacked-together generators. In this session we'll do that, looking at ways to turn scrap motors, wires, and magnets into mini-power plants. 

We'll cover a bit of the physics behind what's happening, get a better handle on energy in general, and gain a deeper appreciation for the grid, where almost all the electricity you use is from spinning magnetic fields.

title: Clock Club
description:
We have an obsession with clocks and timepieces, and we\'ve been had a various clock ideas on our to-do lists forever. So a few months ago, we decided to make a regular habit of getting together to share our ideas, the techniques we\'ve learned, and the projects that have inspired us. We share electronic and mechanical tips and tricks with each other, as well as historical methods we find, tools we run across, and anything else that can move us along.

We\'re planning to hold two meetings of Clock Club during ITP camp. In these sessions, we\'ll share what we\'ve got so far, and talk about project ideas, ours and yours. There\'s no specific agenda to the session, except to move each other further along on realizing some of our clock ideas. If you share this obsession, come along.

We\'ll assume you have a basic familiarity with electronics, microcontrollers (or at least Arduino) and have tried some of the fabrication tools, like the laser cutter. This isn\'t an explicitly skill-building session, but we\'ll do our best to answer technical questions as they arise.

[This repo](
https://github.com/tigoe/timepieces ) will have more in it by the time camp rolls around.

title: Clock Club
description:
We have an obsession with clocks and timepieces, and we\'ve been had a various clock ideas on our to-do lists forever. So a few months ago, we decided to make a regular habit of getting together to share our ideas, the techniques we\'ve learned, and the projects that have inspired us. We share electronic and mechanical tips and tricks with each other, as well as historical methods we find, tools we run across, and anything else that can move us along.

We\'re planning to hold two meetings of Clock Club during ITP camp. In these sessions, we\'ll share what we\'ve got so far, and talk about project ideas, ours and yours. There\'s no specific agenda to the session, except to move each other further along on realizing some of our clock ideas. If you share this obsession, come along.

We\'ll assume you have a basic familiarity with electronics, microcontrollers (or at least Arduino) and have tried some of the fabrication tools, like the laser cutter. This isn\'t an explicitly skill-building session, but we\'ll do our best to answer technical questions as they arise.

[This repo](
https://github.com/tigoe/timepieces ) will have more in it by the time camp rolls around.

title: Shine: Meet some solar panels
description:
Almost all the electricity we get from the grid is generated from spinning magnetic fields (see my [other session, \\\"Zap\\\"](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2016/session/59)). But one of the fastest growing ways to generate electricity is with photovoltaics (PV), aka solar panels.

PV can seem almost magical, turning light into electricity with no moving parts and no fuel. It has fallen in cost dramatically over the last few years, and is beginning to compete with traditional electricity generation methods on cost alone. But it\\\'s not magic: most semiconductors exhibit some degree of photoelectric effect, and they\\\'re bound by basic physics that determine how much energy they can capture. 

We\\\'ll look at a collection of different types of solar panels, including mono- and polycrystalline Si and flexible thin-film materials. We\\\'ll discuss how much energy is in sunlight to begin with, and learn how to measure PV  (and other electrical generators)   using multimeters. Along the way we\\\'ll gain a deeper appreciation of energy at a global scale.

title: Introduction to Creative Coding with p5.js
description: p5.js is a tool for creating interactive visuals with code. In this three-hour workshop, you will learn the basics of programming, such as variables, loops, and conditionals, to create shapes and images that you can interact with. This workshop is designed for beginners and no programming experience is required.

title: Custom Keyboard Workshop (Pt I)
description:
In this two-day workshop (22nd and 23rd), campers will design and build custom keyboards using a person-centered approach. We will invite guests from the community with disabilities to speak about their needs and wants in terms of a keyboard and in teams, design and build for them. 

This workshop will be co-led with Ben Light and will help us in the development of a toolkit/refine the process of making custom keyboards.

Who\'s involved (so far)?

   â€¢Dan Schultz

   â€¢Sam Lavigne

   â€¢others TBD

   â€¢...you!

For more info, contact benjamin.moskowitz@nyu.edu

title: Expressive Code
description:
There is beauty and expressiveness in source code. We\\\'ll take a closer look at how programming languages inherently bear aesthetic value, and how source code itself can be more expressive than the compiled executable. While programs have traditionally been evaluated as functional artifacts, this workshop will challenge this paradigm by evaluating them based on their aesthetic properties. 

This workshop will consist in an overview of existing attempts at revealing the formal qualities of source code, along with examples of how low-level syntax can affect our lives on a daily basis, as well as hands-on work on how we can expressing stories, emotions and situations through source code that would then be lost in its running state.

title: 360 Virtual Reality Video Production
description: How do we shoot and edit video for virtual reality? This camp session will cover best practices for filming video and sound in 360 degrees. The first half of the session will feature a lecture about storytelling in 360 and show examples of what\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\'s already happening in the field.

title: Video Mapping a Big Ass Building Part 1
description: Have you ever wanted to project a story out onto a really big building? Learn how to video map a large building in New York. The first half of the session will feature a lecture on video mapping.

title: Video Mapping a Big Ass Building Part 2
description: Projecting on a build ass building!

title: Interactive Video Art
description: In this class we will look at new ways of implementing video as a medium for creating engaging interactive installations. How do we create video art and installations that move, emote and react to our presence? The course will focus on taking video off the screen and into three-dimensional space in the form of site-specific and or physical installation. Basic Max/MSP + Jitter will be taught as well as a lecture on contemporary video art.

title: Video Editing: Workflow and Aesthetics
description: In this session, I will run through the basics of video editing techniques for telling stories, demonstrate Adobe Premiere\'s capabilities, and explain best practices for project organization that will improve your workflow and creative productivity.

title: The Storytelling Language of Moving Images
description: In this session aimed at video beginners, I will break down the fundamentals of cinematic storytelling and use of different camera angles to effectively and clearly convey one\'s ideas. I will also explain the fundamentals of storyboarding for video. These techniques can be applied to narrative, project documentation, animation, and even comics or experience storyboarding.

title: Automate Your Web Development Workflow with Gulp
description:
Gulp is a Node-based JavaScript utility that automates non-programming tasks related to web development. Supported by a large community of contributors, Gulp is capable of tasks as varied as browser refreshing, HTML validation, and JavaScript compression. So, whether you want to verify your CSS or join various development files, Gulp likely has a task for that.

## Prerequisite

In order to follow along, youâ€™ll need some facility with JavaScript, understand basic web developer concepts, such as compressing files and validating web-specific source code, and the ability to handle the command line.

## Code for the Workshop

The code weâ€™ll use during the workshop is available from GitHub at

[`https://github.com/code-warrior/gulp-template-for-html-css-sass-js`](https://github.com/code-warrior/gulp-template-for-html-css-sass-js)

## Slides

Slides for the workshop will be available at

[`https://github.com/code-warrior/gulp-workshop`](https://github.com/code-warrior/gulp-workshop)

â€¦under the `v1.0.0` branch. Theyâ€™ll be continually updated until a final version is posted at 1:30 PM on Saturday.

title: Optical systems for new media tinkerers
description:
This is a workshop that goes over the FUNdamentals of reflective and refractive optics and how they can be utilized for all kinds of new media light art applications. It will involve props, diagrams, guided anecdotes and demos. Weather permitting, there will be a light walk, where concepts are discussed en plein air(that is french for outside).
â€¢Change the throw angle of your favorite projector
â€¢Build a projector from parts
â€¢Scavenge optics from yester-year's televisions
â€¢Have fun in the Sun
â€¢Light sources and their properties
â€¢Microscopes -vs- telescopes
â€¢Design and make your own lenses using CNC and elbow grease

The workshop is taught by Robb Godshaw. He wrote this bio about himself as if he was a third party. He is an artist who has a strong habit of making new media op-art. He designs and builds his own lenses for technical and wacky applications. He has shown op-art in various prestigious institutions such as the San Francisco Dump and the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts. He holds a BFA from Carnegie Mellon where he worked with light all the time. His work can be seen on the world wide web at www.robb.cc.

title: Field Trip to International Center for Photography's Re-Opening in the Bowery
description:
Let's go see the newly re-opened ICP in the Bowery!

Address is 250 Bowery.

Let\'s meet at ICP at 9:45 AM and we\'ll go in at 10a.

https://www.icp.org/facilities/museum

Free admission :-)

Maybe we can all grab a cheap lunch afterwards.

title: Discussion: Self-Care in the Arts, Media, and Tech
description: I\'d like to have an open discussion on self-Care in the Arts, Media, and Tech(other fields welcome too!), regarding what self-care actually is and strategies for taking care of your mental, physical, and emotional health as a working professional.

title: React Natural
description:
_Interested in making maps? Check out [Advanced Time Series Mapping Using Torque](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2016/session/239) at **5pm** on the **same day** as this session._

**SESSION REPO: [sighrobot/itpcamp-react](https://github.com/sighrobot/itpcamp-react)**

## The `tl;dr` version
Build a [React](https://facebook.github.io/react/) web app using a neat open-source tool from [Enigma.io](https://github.com/enigma-io/generator-enigma)!

## Full description
**React**, a JavaScript library for building user interfaces, has quickly become the golden child of scalable web app development tools. Companies like Airbnb, the BBC and Codeacademy use React, and you can too.

However, React is way more fun if you use the Enigma.io [React web app generator](https://github.com/enigma-io/generator-enigma) for Node.js.

Benefits of the generator include:

- [CommonJS](https://webpack.github.io/docs/commonjs.html) module bundling via [Browserify](http://browserify.org/)
- [ES2015](https://babeljs.io/docs/learn-es2015/) syntax support and transpilation via [Babel](https://babeljs.io/)
- Code quality assessment & style enforcement via [ESLint](http://eslint.org/)
- [Stylus](http://stylus-lang.com/) CSS preprocessing & automatic vendor prefix management via [Autoprefixer](https://autoprefixer.github.io/)
- Unit testing via the [Jest](https://facebook.github.io/jest/) framework and [Jasmine2](http://jasmine.github.io/2.0/introduction.html) test runner

The first hour of this session will be spent learning how to create a web app using the generator, React basics and best practices, Stylus basics and perhaps even a unit test or two.

The second hour will be hands-on as you develop your new app while receiving guidance and answers to any questions you may have.

*Attendees should have experience with JavaScript, CSS, HTML, and the command line. We will use ES6 syntax - see [ECMAScript 6](https://github.com/lukehoban/es6features) for more info.*

title: Super Suits: Utility Belts and Gadgets
description:
This week:

Every good hero needs a good utility belt.  We will discuss how to construct the belt, buckle, pouches, etc.  as well as go over potential gadgets: grappling hooks, communicators, etc.

About Super Suits:

In this series, we will research and create suits and accessories that grant the wearer â€œpowersâ€.  Guided by a comic book aesthetic we will dive into the worlds of wearables, speculative design, and movie prop replication.  

Each session will introduce a new set of ideas, tools, and techniques. Participants (including us!) will have the option of doing some "homework" and producing prototypes or tests to share the following week.

title: Super Suits: Super Senses
description:
This week: Super Hero character development, how to make electronics wearable.

Links:

*[Slides](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Lw3DG-WGZpFEeAdXOMM3ogkdEkK7HrdDSAT9OiL2k90)

*[Google Drive](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B5HFDPTSNkLxOUZGTWNGMkNfUHc) - includes Super Hero Profile Template

About Super Suits:

In this series, we will research and create suits and accessories that grant the wearer â€œpowersâ€.  Guided by a comic book aesthetic we will dive into the worlds of wearables, speculative design, and movie prop replication.  

Each session will introduce a new set of ideas, tools, and techniques. Participants (including us!) will have the option of doing some \\\"homework\\\" and producing prototypes or tests to share the following week.

title: Super Suits: Wrap Up
description:
This week:

We will start with 10 or 15 minutes about how you can use rapid prototyping (vinyl, lasercutting, 3D printing, CNC) to make more super hero stuff.

The rest of the time will be for show and tell and consultations. Feel free to bring stuff to work on. We can break out into the lounge or shop as needed.

About Super Suits:

In this series, we will research and create suits and accessories that grant the wearer â€œpowersâ€.  Guided by a comic book aesthetic we will dive into the worlds of wearables, speculative design, and movie prop replication.  

Each session will introduce a new set of ideas, tools, and techniques. Participants (including us!) will have the option of doing some \"homework\" and producing prototypes or tests to share the following week.

title: Building Kinetic Sculptures
description:
This session will cover the basics for building a kinetic sculpture including: what types of motion are you trying to create, are you going to employ electrical motion, what types of components do you need to create your project, and how can you prototype your idea while keeping your costs low. 

Bring ideas to the class and we can discuss how you can make them a reality at camp!

[Here are the notes for our session](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1BMrh5Ef-reazT6LIK7l8in_yyyWbAqQmB8Cp1QhaLtE/edit?usp=sharing)

[Here is a link to the illustrator design file I created to make the kits](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BwlG1iBAlH64bjIxZmFMVmtDUUE/view?usp=sharing)

title: Sea of Commodities: Making In China Show and Tell
description:
I went to China to find the places where everything gets made. This quest led me to factories in suburbs of megacities, towering electronics markets, apartments retrofitted as hackerspaces, alleys full of tiny workshops, and Hong Kongâ€™s highest heights.

I will share photos and stories of places I visited and people I met, along with some insights into the changing relationship to suppliers, and changing global markets. I will focus on Shenzhen and Yiwu, two very different cities that are integral to global supply chains.

This research has been driven by a personal obsession with objects and obsolescence.

Slides available here: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1Lp3L0kLVMQXxeI_IO3EUbpKWrTmIQBMrhNfF5DnwWUQ/edit#slide=id.g11b4f0b1c0_0_2

If you can\'t make it, here is a recording of a previous version of this talk: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aKCr6xm6LNo

title: Create a Web-Based Game with the p5JS Play Library
description:
In this session, we\'ll create a super simple web-based game in javascript with p5JS. We\'ll utilize the p5 play & sound libraries to help us out. No experience necessary. Bring a laptop so you can code along with me.

Example code is available here:
[SpaceFlyer](https://github.com/craigprotzel/space-flyer)

title: Real Time Collaborative Web Experiences with Socket.io and p5JS
description:
In this session, we will build a web application that allows for real-time creative collaboration. Both server-side and client-side web programming will be explored. For the server, we will use express.js paired with socket.io. For the client, we will utilize the p5js library. Some javascript or web programming experience is recommended. Please bring a laptop.

Example code is available here [SocketIO + p5JS](https://github.com/craigprotzel/socketio-p5-workshop)

title: Building A Universe
description: a workshop that aims to challenge participants to think about storytelling from a universe building perspective. In this two hour workshop we will build several universes based on common characters. We\'ll create visuals for our universe, scenarios, and take us through a day in the life of the character in your specific universe. The aim of the class is to exercise expanded thinking in order to better envision future projects in a holistic manner.

title: Twitter Maps and Twitter Bots
description:
In this three hour session we will be using Node and Socket IO to plot geolocated tweets on a map in real time.  We will first go through the basic concepts of client and server side programming, and then dive into node.  Please have node installed, and maybe some basic knowledge of javascript.  The goal here is for everyone to walk away with a working application that will constantly ( and in real time ) plot tweets about a given topic on a map.  We then will extend this application to make a bots that can listen learn and tweet.

Twitter, GoogleMaps, Express, Node

title: The Neural Aesthetic
description:
This is a (very) broad overview of machine learning for the arts. Mostly lecture-based with interspersed demos, the aim is to

1) Describe from the ground up how neural networks work -- convolutional and recurrent neural networks particularly
2) Show artistic applications of said neural networks
3) a survey of current events, trends, outstanding questions, and contemporary ethical dilemmas associated with the field and AI more generally

I will also present various applications, code samples, and resources for using this stuff in your own work. Not enough time to go into implementation details, but should give the intrepid student an idea of where to start using practically for their own purposes.

title: My Web Page Can Do What?!?
description:
In this session we will be using [PeerJS](http://peerjs.com/) to create a P2P website (based on WebRTC), and [MIDI.js](http://galacticmilk.com/midi-js/) to create a musical composition on the web, and connecting them together to make a collaborative composition.  If time permits, we will incorporate [P5.js](http://p5js.org/) as well.

Please bring a laptop with your favorite HTML/JS editor, and if possible please download PeerJS and MIDI.js before the session.

[Code](https://github.com/dtsadok/ITPCamp2016Demo)

[Slides](http://danieltsadok.net/ITPCamp2016.pdf)

title: City for Interaction Research - Designing living system for Public Places
description:
In this workshop participants will be asked to use simple found materials or build something specifically for the city\\\'s public places that will engender and influence conversations and a physical reaction between the passerby and the projects.   

Interaction design is about audience engagement and the street is perfect place to explore systems for building and testing engagement.  

The projects can be a street performance, objects with or without electricity, but the main goal is that they are inviting participation from strangers. 

 As a class we will research how interactive projects can extend it into something more poetic and whimsical in public space, and what a more analog and unplugged performance art practice can help teach us about our own medium. 

More links and inspiration coming soon:

title: Critical Maker Education
description:
From community bike shops, to maker spaces, to repair cafes, something big is happening. This culture of DIY fabrication and collaborative spaces is emblematic of the Maker movement. With over 757 maker-spaces worldwide, it is important we critically analyze the intentions and outputs of this initiative. The democratization of technology, tools and production has lead to the empowerment of populations. Objects once only able to be produced by large companies are now available as open-source projects for experimentation. What is the cost of these freedoms on our environment, economy, and education? This talk examines the realities of our 3D printed future. 

	This talk will critically examine the nature of Maker Education and how it is implemented in formal, informal, and institutional environments using examples and experiences.

title: Stop The Game I Have To Check My Facebook Notifications
description: How can video game design techniques be used in a physical space? This talk will in part be a synopsis of what I have learned during my thesis on integrating technology into physical with the Amenoia Night Parade projct as well as a conversation of other techniques to begin designing from.  This session will focus on creating effective immersive spaces using seamless integration of technology.

title: venture to the future of fashion @ Boston Museum of Fine Arts
description:
From New York to Boston: It only takes 5 hours on the bus to see the fashion of tomorrow! 

Immerse yourself in the gorgeous LED-lit, haptic feedback-enabled, and digitally printed projects of contemporary fashion. First, hear an overview of the current directions in technology and fashion by Sputniko!, whose recent work includes Amyâ€™s Glowing Silk and The Moonwalk Machine. Then, moderated by Sputniko!, hear from the Media Labâ€™s techstyle ML students, who reveal the future of fashion design with innovative projects including conductive makeup and tattoos, on-skin and nail interfaces, wearable lighting, and social textiles.
Buy the ticket here
http://www.mfa.org/programs/lecture/technology-fashion-projects-for-tomorrow-and-today

title: Creative Cardboard Construction
description:
Use scrus and cardboard to build your imaginative, fun or useful creations of any sizes. I have seen people build a big playground where people crawl through!
Best of all, you create with your peers together! 20 participants max due to limited scrus. Please feel free to drop in to watch
Please bring your own cardboard if you can

title: The current landscape of UX prototyping tools
description:
Do you want to build a native app, a web app, a responsive site or IoT interface? Chances are there is a tool that can help you in the conceptualization and development process.

It seems as if every week a new UX tool is released to the public. This session will present and demonstrate the landscape of tools out there and discuss their relative strengths and weaknesses. 

Among the tools that will be demonstrated will be:
- Sketch + Invision
- Sketch + Craft
- FramerJS
- Principle
- Axure
- Adobe XD
- Frameworks (Bootstrap and Foundation)
- Whatever tool comes out before this session...

title: Open Source Cellular Networks:  with Rhizomatica (Oaxaca, Mexico) and SayCel (Nicaragua)
description:
Have you ever wanted to know how to run your own cellular network.  Well now you can! Open Source communication tools like OpenBSC, Freeswitch, along with Software Defined Radios have lowered the barrier to entry.  Of course its not just knowing the technology, there are also political ramifications to such ventures.  

In this workshop members of Rhizomatica and SayCel will discuss how they got involved in setting up Community based Cellular Networks.  Rhizomatica currently runs 16 networks in indigenous villages in Oaxaca Mexico.  

In the second half of the workshop there will be a brief overview of GSM, a description of the Rhizomatica Community Cellular Network installations, a run down on the technology used, an update on recent changes and advances in the field of open source communications. 

We'll take a look at some of the problems encountered; remote networks in difficult to access places, users expectations - providing 'carrier grade' service on self owned networks while those networks still depend on connections to upstream non free (internet) networks.

title: Creative Text Manipulation with Python
description:
# Creative Text Manipulation with Python
### Sunday, June 5, 1-5pm @ ITP Camp

Code poetry. Computational creative writing. Digital poetics. Electronic literature.

All of these names refer to creative manipulation of words with computer code.

This workshop will serve as an introduction to natural language processing, with a focus on creative applications of the technologies introduced. The first part of the workshop will provide a crash course in Python basics, including the syntax and features that make the language a popular choice for handling, analyzing, and manipulating text. The rest of the workshop will focus on [Pattern](http://www.clips.ua.ac.be/pages/pattern), a powerful Python library for natural language processing, as well as other tools and resources available for creative text manipulation.

Topics covered will include (but won't be limited to): 

* Word tokenization 
* Markov chains (Ngram generators) 
* Sentence parsing / part-of-speech tagging 
* Sentiment, mood, and modality analysis 
* Stop words and stemming 
* Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) analysis

At least some minimal experience with programming (in any language) is recommended.

In addition to a text editor (I recommend [Sublime Text](http://www.sublimetext.com/)), please ensure your computer has Python installed. You can verify this by entering "python" (without quotes) in the Terminal. If, for some reason, you find that you do not have Python installed, please follow the instructions for installing version 2.7.11 at [python.org](http://www.python.org). (Don't install Python 3.)

You'll also need to install pip, the Python package manager. On Mac, run the following command in the terminal to do so: 

`$ sudo easy_install pip`

Finally, use pip to install the virtualenv library (its purpose will be explained at the beginning of the workshop): 

`$ sudo pip install virtualenv`

title: Typing Tones ( O o }===
description:
This session will provide an introduction to p5.sound, a JavaScript library that enables users to easily create and analyze audio inputs and music on a web page through programming. Participants will be taught how to install p5.js on their computers, and shown how to use a starter set of functions that will enable them to analyze and synthesize audio.

The session will be divided into two parts. The first part (45 min) will be a code-along where participants are introduced to the p5.js ecosystem, and will create simple audio tones along with the instructor. The second part (75 min) will be a collection of hands-on exercises where participants will create virtual instruments (like a digital piano), as well as audio visualizers to analyze music.

No programming experiences is required to attend this session. We will be covering the basic programming skills that you will need during the first part of the session. Participants are required to bring a computer running Windows or MacOS that they will work on during the session.

title: Photoshop Fun & Digital Art Break
description:
Photoshop is a program that can be used to create digital art, print materials, edit photos, + more. 

I'll start off by demonstrating  Photoshop's (Creative Cloud version) core features. We'll spend the rest of class using these skills to make (weird + wonderful) digital art! This session is for people of all skill-levels who just want to set aside some time to learn and create.

Class structure will be open, so if there is anything specific you want to make I'm available to help. All you need to bring is a laptop, weâ€™ll download the trial version together at the start of the session. Feel free to bring your own images for photo editing or adding to an art piece!

title: Using OpenGL in Max
description:
Cycling \\\'74\\\'s Max software toolkit is a hugely powerful and venerable environment for making A/V applications, installations and performance interfaces. The OpenGL implementation in Max holds enormous creative potential for campers interested in using node-based programming to build creative coding experiences.

The session will start with a quick and dirty introduction to Max itself, and move quickly through the following topics as needed:

- The structure of an OpenGL world in Max
- Basic object drawing and manipulation
- Generative shape creation with jit.gl.mesh
- Texture manipulation with Jitter Gen
- Flocks of shapes with jit.gl.multiple
- Exporting to Syphon (and thus the world)

On the way, there will be some work with generative audio, a lot of attention to visual feedback, some bizarre controllers and a great deal of profanity.

NOTE FROM DAY BEFORE:

Hello everyone! I am looking forward to tomorrowâ€™s class.

Four hours is a drop in the bucket when it comes to this stuff. I want to hit the ground running, and move fast. So here are a few ways that we can grease the wheels.

1) Download and install Max. Donâ€™t think, just do it. Make a Cycling74 account so you can register the demo. This will, no joke, save us fifteen minutes at the start of the session. If you have already popped the Max demo and it has expired, do yourself a favor and drop $13 ($10 if youâ€™ve got an academic ID) on a monthâ€™s license.  Youâ€™re going to want the 64bit version of Max 7, appropriate for your platform. Please note that those of you using Chromebooks or some other kind of non-OS X â€˜nix flavor will *not* be able to play along. Sorry!

2) Play with it. Really! Open some tutorials, get a sense of Maxâ€™s workflow: top down, left to right. Iâ€™m going to work on this a little, but I guarantee it will take a little bit of time to click. Be confused; itâ€™s the first step towards understanding.

3) Bring a sensor. Those of you with Arduino projects will want to bring them. Those of you with weird sensors in hand that have some kind of driver that works with your machine will benefit greatly from this session. If itâ€™s Mac-compatible, Iâ€™ll even work it into the session if itâ€™s weird enough.

4) Bring patches youâ€™ve built that donâ€™t work. Iâ€™m happy to spend the last hour of the session as a Max clinic, working with the patches that campers bring in. 

5) Bring questions. Iâ€™m going to run out of pre-prepared material around the end of hour two; this is deliberate. I want this to be as useful as possible, and merely going down my own rabbit hole will do little of value for campers who are stuck in holes of their design. 

In general, be prepared to speak up and complain if you donâ€™t understand something. If youâ€™ve really downloaded and launched and registered it, after that there are very few questions that will annoy me. Iâ€™ve taught this stuff for a long time and Iâ€™m happy to answer any and all questions once youâ€™ve passed the initial hurdle. 

Iâ€™m very excited for this session and humbled to have thirty RSVPs. Letâ€™s make it amazing!

title: Intro to Supply Chain Management
description:
From bottled drinks, clothing, to electronics. Every product has a path from when its conceived, to when it is put to rest. Since product development has become more accessible than ever, I want to share tools, techniques, resources, and lingo to help you navigate the world of manufacturing. 

During this session, the audience will have a chance to participate through a process of designing a fictional consumer product. Links and resources will be available via PDF at the end of the session. 

Ananda Gabo is an Industrial Designer and researcher based out of Toronto and works in Suzhou, China.

title: iOS Development 101
description:
Learn how to make iOS apps with Xcode & Swift!

Before the workshop, though, there\\\'s some things you need to do:

Have a Mac
Download Xcode from the App Store
Create an Apple Developer Account (with an existing Apple ID) here: https://developer.apple.com > Click on Account
Sign in to Xcode with that account
If you don\\\'t have an Apple ID, you should make it to complete the step above

It is absolutely crucial that you complete all of the above, because it takes quite a long time to get Xcode and set all this up and it would be unfair to you to waste our workshop time on that.


http://www.idownloadblog.com/2015/12/24/how-to-create-a-free-apple-developer-account-xcode/ - how to set up a developer account

Go here for further instructions & download the github repo:
https://github.com/leamars/MobileDev101ITP2016

title: Prototyping with Xcode & Swift
description:
Learn how to prototype app ideas with the IDE used to create that app. Prototyping in Xcode is super useful especially if you want to bridge the gap between developers and designers. This workshop will try to demystify Xcode for designers and introduce the concept that creating dynamic mobile prototypes in Xcode is actually simpler and much more valuable than prototyping with other tools. 

Go here to look at instructions, slides & download the github repo:
https://github.com/leamars/PrototypingWorkshopITP2016

title: 3D Scanning for VR
description:
In this session, we will cover two volumetric capture techniques for creating 3D assets for a VR experience - photogrammetry and infrared sensing with Skanect. 

We will cover the workflow for each capture method, from moment of capture to placing your assets in a Unity scene for use in VR or a 3D game. 

The specifics: 
[Photogrammetry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photogrammetry) is a technique for creating 3D models from a series of photographs of an object. Models created this way have high-resolution, photorealistic textures which render beautifully in a game engine if prepared properly. Our workflow will include: photographing an object, processing the model with Photoscan, and setting up the materials, shaders and lights in Unity.

[Skanect](http://skanect.occipital.com/) is a software program for creating 3D models with a Kinect. This method is ideal for full body portraits or for scanning a room. Our workflow with Skanect will include: scanning a person, cleaning the model in MeshLab and importing the model into a Unity scene.

title: Making a simple VR app with Unity
description:
using Unity3D to make a simple VR app for Android/iOS. Navigating Unity, creating a particle system, incorporating the Google Cardboard support and using gaze detection to interact with objects in the scene and trigger events.

Please install Unity prior to this session.  
Install Unity3D 
the Android SDK if you want to build to Android and Xcode if you want to build to iOS.

title: Photographic Thinking
description:
How do you tell a story in a single image? 

Photographic Thinking is a workshop geared towards honing our already acute photographic abilities. Through a brief lecture, technical demonstrations and hands on in-session work, we will discuss the myriad of cameras and workflows ITPers have access to and the best practices that result in the best images. When taking pictures for a vr, ar, web project or documenting an existing project: what form best conveys what you are trying to say visually? A single image, a short video or sequence of images? How to plan to shoot a 360 scene? When is a three point lighting kit necessary? Where to stand with camera in hand, etc...

A brief overview of photo fundamentals (aperture, shutter speed, focal length, white balance) will be followed by the basics of camera control by device and by participant demand. Although covering the basics, experienced photographers are encouraged to take part as application and communication are our primary concerns. Workshop members are encouraged to bring in their previous work (success and failure) for discussion. All still and motion cameras (and workflows) will be considered and invited, depending on participants needs.

title: A Discussion on Kaos
description: Working on the final details, but Simon Kavanagh from Kaos Pilots (http://www.kaospilot.dk/) will be in town and I thought that I\'d grab him. They\'re doing a workshop on designing spaces for collaborative education, so we will start there.  He will also talk about leading creative teams and staying in complexity. Should be a great conversation! More info on their design program at http://www.kaospilot.dk/kaospilot-educational-series/the-art-and-craft-of-designing-learning-spaces/ so you can start thinking about what you\'d like to discuss!

title: Mobile Health Apps: User-Centered Design
description: Digital Health Technology has the potential to support and improve disease self-management, care coordination and medication management for patients. There is a great diversity in consumer healthcare apps that are currently available however they are not used systematically by healthcare providers, patients or caregivers. We will discuss key stakeholders, empathic design, user experience and user interface design as well as an understanding of how apps can play a role in the patient journey. Participants should download proto.io before the class meets. By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of user-centered design and create a wireframe paper prototype.

title: Being There: Prototyping VR with 360 Video
description:
This workshop focuses on 360 video as an accessible tool for exploring and creating within the spherical space of VR. The workshop will cover the use and workflow of two kinds of 360 video camerasâ€” the Ricoh Theta and the Freedom 360 GoPro rigâ€” from setup to editing. The workshop will include a tour of 360 space as created by these cameras, and will explore some emerging ideas on lighting, sound and traditional video editing techniques that might enhance the 360 VR viewer's experience. 

Presentation Slides:
goo.gl/FEqP5l

title: A Crash Course in Game Design
description: What makes a game tick? What makes it fun (and does it even have to be fun?) Can you use games to provoke specific emotions, elicit certain reactions or teach particular skills or concepts? This workshop will cover some basic theories and principles of games and play, an exercise in designing your own (non-digital) game, and lots of play!

title: Designing Accessible Websites & Interfaces
description:
Not everyone who uses the internet has perfect vision, hearing, or mobility. Accessible web design makes it easier for people with disabilities to participate online, and creates a more quality experience overall.

In this intro session I\'ll explain:

- What web accessibility is  
- How to navigate guidelines  
- Design tips to improve interfaces   
- Examples of well designed, accessible sites and interfaces  

This is a design-oriented discussion but I\'ll also provide resources for developers! 

Accessibility is a large topic and canâ€™t be fully covered in a single session, but Iâ€™m hoping to give an understanding of what web accessibility is, and why/how it is important to achieve.

title: From Archive to Environment
description:
A brief exploration of the techniques and applications of converting flat archival imagery into 3-dimensional forms.  The session will begin with walk-throughs of two techniques, 1) constructing a model from a photograph using Sketchup\'s \"Match photo\" function and 2) constructing a model from video footage using Agisoft Photoscan.  

Participants will have time to practice these workflows on archival documents of their choosing.  This will be followed by demonstrations of applications in virtual reality, gaming, and 3D printing scenarios.  Session will end with a survey of example projects.  

Participants should have some familiarity with basic 3D modeling, but no experience with Sketchup or Photoscan required.  Participants should download free trials of the software prior to attendance.

title: Discomfort Design
description:
In The Art of Interactive Design, Chris Crawford makes an analogy between creating interactive media and holding a conversation.  Often, as designers we are looking to converse in a way that\'s comfortable and pleasurable, with a low barrier to entry for our audience.  At times, though, we may seek to engage in what Douglas Stone has termed \"difficult conversations\".  How do we design for these types of interactions?  

In this session participants will consider four forms of discomfort and reasons for their application in design: visceral, cultural, control-related, and intimacy-related.  Examples will be provided from fields of performance, memorial, and speculative design.

Participants will work in teams or individually in a facilitated workshop to come up with a design solution that employs one of these forms of discomfort.  This will culminate in a rough user-experience outline, sketches, or paper-prototype.  Participants will benefit from some prior familiarity with design-thinking, interaction design, or user-experience.

title: 3D Printing a headphone holder using Autodesk Fusion 360 and Meshmixer
Learning to teach
description: This class will introduce the history and theory of pedagogy, and critical issues of accessibility and diversity in learning environments. Taeyoon Choi is the cofounder of [School for poetic computation](http://sfpc.io) in New York City. He will share his research on non-accredited learning environments, such as artist-run schools, grass roots organizations, and maker spaces, and the alternative  platform for a wider community to embrace new ideas. Students will create a curriculum for a class they want to teach in the future.

title: Make Your Imagination Glow-sew electronics
description:
Everyone likes presents especially unique ones. The presents made by your hands either for yourself or your loved ones can\'t be found anywhere else. During this workshop I will show you how to sew electronics to textiles to make cards, dolls or art pins. It will be up to you what you would like to draw and make! Make your imagination glow and tell your stories through your unique presents. 
Show and Tell at the end of the workshop :)

title: If You Are the One?!
description:
With a viewing audience of up to 50 million per episode, this popular Chinese dating show is a cultural phenomenon. A lone male suitor has to impress a panel of 24 single women, who can then register their interest or disinterest in the man through the use of their podium lights. Popular host Meng Fei oversees the action in front of a large studio audience. 
I will share with you my insight to this show as I have a friends who have been on this show and I went to the panel discussion twice. 
Perhaps even a spontaneous If You Are the One at the end of this workshop?

title: Beyond WiFi & Bluetooth: Using RFMxx modules to go the distance
description:
UPDATE: New time!!!

WiFi and bluetooth shields/Arduinos  are great for getting your project online, but they are limited in distance by the 2.4GHz frequency, and can require more power than you\\\\\\\'re able to provide.  So what\\\\\\\'s the alternative?  Enter the RFMxx series of wireless modules.  These modules can provide extended range for your projects using tried-and-true transmission protocols.  Or you can take advantage of the new and extremely long range LoRa protocol to allow your Arduinos to transmit and receive even longer distances.  (We are talking several kilometers!)

This session will...

1.  Introduce you to some of the RFMxx modules available, the radio technologies they employ, and how they differ

2.  Introduce you to some Arduino-compatible products that already include RFMxx modules, as well as some breakout boards for the modules themselves

3.  Introduce you to the RadioHead RFMxx library for Arduino, as well as some other one-off libraries, and discuss strategies for using them in your project

4.  Show you how to wire a raw RFM module to your Arduino

title: #NeverTrump: Amplify our Voices!
description:
The views expressed below are mine alone and not those of NYU.

OVERVIEW

Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee for president of the United States of America is a xenophobe, racist, misogynist, bully and con artist. He has been compared to demagogues and elected strongmen. Trump has also shown himself to be a blatant liar who enjoys creating and promoting conspiracy theories. He has support from white supremacist groups. Trump has proven himself to be a master manipulator of the media and he so far has generated over $2 billion worth of free media, exponentially more than any other candidate. http://nyti.ms/1U4o1Ef Television networks and other media channels have unfairly provided Trump with unequal amounts of airtime and news coverage. Trump is an active user of social channels like Twitter, Instagram and Facebook.

Trump is a divider, not a uniter of people. His discourse and outrageous promises have reduced our civility. Most GOP politicians are shocked that Trump is their nominee. Many Republicans even though they said theyâ€™d never support Trump have quickly fallen in line. Other Republican party members are actively looking for alternatives.

GOAL

I believe Trump needs to be exposed in everyway possible, his support and ratings diminished.  To achieve this, average citizens must stand up and have their voices heard. This is also an urgent need as time is working against us. During the ITP 2016 camp I recommend that we allocate time toward this civil action using the unique expertise and talents of interested camp members and others. Iâ€™m recommending we come together, network, digest media, discuss and use our expertise in branding, writing, programming, media and content creation, data and analytics, social media, making stuff, etc. to create ways to attack, counter and take down the Trump ecosystems.

The session will be run like a basecamp where we can discuss critical concepts and strategies; find partners to work with and review work to date. I hope we can meet at least one time per week. The goal is to â€œmove the needleâ€ and achieve demonstrable results, to have our voices amplified and heard.  Sample outputs include:  

1.	Social media account, posts and targeted hashtags
2.	Organizing an event
3.	Viral content distribution
4.	Information graphics
5.	Digital agitprop
6.	Hacks & stunts

title: Git it Together: An Intro to Git
description:
So maybe you\'ve never heard of Git, maybe you\'ve heard about Git and want to know more, or maybe you\'ve heard about it a lot and you\'ve even fibbed a little about knowing what it is and now you live a life of lies. Fear no more! Kat will go over Git from the very beginning. 

Don\'t have a Git account? Don\'t know how to use the terminal? Do you think ssh stands for simply sitting at home? No problem! We\'ll go over everything you\'ve wanted to know and then some. 

At the end of the class you will:

Have a project in Github
Alter that project in Github
Alter your friend\'s project in Github

It is HIGHLY recommend that you install git BEFORE the flyby. Go here: http://git-scm.com/download/mac. We have a lot to cover and there will be no waiting for people to install Git. If you have questions about installing Git, ask a counselor.

title: Git it Together Part 2: Beyond the Repo
description:
We\'ll briefly go over the basics (cloning, pushing, pulling) and also \'branch\' out into forking, branching, gitignore, and more!

Please have a git repo set up before this session. If you need help, talk with one of the counselors.

title: Grow your own piezoelectric crystal.
description:
From phonographs to sonar - microphones to radios, piezoelectric crystals have been at the heart of many inventions. This course will be half lecture/discussion and half hands-on. We\\\'ll discuss the basics of crystallography and applications of piezoelectricity.  The lab will give you all the instruction and materials needed to start growing your own piezo crystal. Finally, as a class we\\\'ll examine crystals under a microscope in polarized light. 

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1Nk-jnJwkc85Ens9NoNGqXboDd0Zawe9WSwJluRi7V0Q/edit#slide=id.g1141bc4dc3_1_78

title: Multispecies robotic friendships
description:
Maria Yablonina is an architect working in the field of digital fabrication and robotics. She received her M.Sc. from the Institute for Computational Design at the University of Stuttgart where she worked as a member of a robotic fabrication team designing custom end-effectors for large-scale pavilion construction.

Her current research focuses on exploring various types of mobile robotic locomotion as well as developing hardware and software interfaces for multi-species machine collaboration and its potential applications to large-scale fabrication.

In this session she will give a talk about her current and previous work, about robots of different types, characters and origins and how she tried to build friendships between them.

title: Participatory Performance 01: small gesture to large-scale production
description:
Participatory Performance.  I cringe when I hear the word \"participatory\" being used in basically any context even though I\'m a performance artist that uses audience participation in my work. How can we break down the ideas of participation and interactivity within the frame of \"performance\" and build them up again as new tools we use in daily life?  

This is a two-part workshop. The first session begins with some context- discussing some of the founders of participatory performance: Antonin Artaud, Allan Kaprow, Japanese Gutai Artists,  Feminists such as Yoko Ono and Carolee Schneemann, and then moving into tech and current-day performers such as Tino Sehgal and Marina Abramovic (yes, she\'s overplayed these days but we will discuss). 

We\'ll then start getting our hands dirty, choosing a participatory performance paradigm or inventing our own....and this will frame our explorations.  

At the beginning of the next workshop, we will start with some performance exercises to get you thinking about different ways of engaging an audience. Then we\'re off creating our short-form performances that we will present for the show and tell on June 28, sharing our performance ideas with ITP in a renegade or organized way depending on what we decide. At the end of workshop 2, we will have a critique session for feedback, next steps, and a short discussion of venue spaces and residencies where these types of ideas are supported and can be explored further.

title: Participatory Performance 02: small gesture to large-scale production
description:
Participatory Performance. I cringe when I hear the word \"participatory\" being used in basically any context even though I\'m a performance artist that uses audience participation in my work. How can we break down the ideas of participation and interactivity within the frame of \"performance\" and build them up again as new tools we use in daily life?  

This is a two-part workshop, the first session happens on Wed June 22. In the second workshop, we will begin with some performance exercises to get you thinking about different ways of engaging an audience (don\'t be afraid, this is fun I promise). Then we\'re off creating our short-form performances that we will present for the show and tell on June 28, sharing our performance ideas with ITP in a renegade or organized way depending on what we decide. At the end of workshop 2, we will have a critique session for feedback, next steps, and a short discussion of venue spaces and residencies where these types of ideas are supported and can be explored further.

description:

title: UX Design Process 101
description:
Introduction to what user experience consists of and how to create a product from inception to end product. Will guide the users through user research methods, personas, and user journeys and what it takes to make a user centred product through wireframing and experimentation.

There will be a workshop on how design thinking works and then based on your ideas, you will be able to create a basic prototype by gathering insights from different users.

title: 3D Paper Fab
description:
This course will be an introduction to Pepakura for fabricating objects in 3 dimensions using paper!

In this hands-on workshop, participants will learn the workflow of digitally modeling a 3 dimensional object and then translating that object to a paper form. Learn the magic of working between 2 and 3 dimensions, and between digital and physical.

No experience necessary :)

title: Open Source Weaving
description: Weaving is the original binary. Come weave your own mini tapestry and take home your own open source loom and shuttle. You'll also have access to the files after the class so you can customize your tools. The class is taught by Teresa - a big believer in open source crafting. She designs and makes her own crafting supplies, which are free for public use. There will also be an open discussion about the history of weaving and its influence on computing, the role of craft in the maker community, and the potential in integrating craft and technology in the future.

title: Soft Lab Intro
description: Get to know the ITP Soft Lab. This session is not mandatory, but it's highly recommended if you'd like to incorporate soft fabrication in one of your projects. You will get a quick intro to the sewing machines, overlock machine, vinyl cutters, and more. There are lots of free materials and available resources for you to use. Find your soft inspiration.

title: Soft Lab Intro
description: Get to know the ITP Soft Lab. This session is not mandatory, but it's highly recommended if you'd like to incorporate soft fabrication in one of your projects. You will get a quick intro to the sewing machines, overlock machine, vinyl cutters, and more. There are lots of free materials and available resources for you to use. Find your soft inspiration.

title: Soft Lab Intro
description: Get to know the ITP Soft Lab. This session is not mandatory, but it is highly recommended if you would like to incorporate soft fabrication in one of your projects. You will get a quick intro to the sewing machines, overlock machine, vinyl cutters, and more. There are lots of free materials and available resources for you to use. Find your soft inspiration.

title: If you are going to sweat, make it worth it
description:
How to build something that people will like (aka buy and use)?

This camp session will cover some best practices for:
- validating your idea before spending time and money into making it
- building the right thing for the right users

During this two hour session we will go over some examples around how to design experiments to asses your biggest assumptions. Also, how to design and develop to quickly incorporate feedback during the process. Finally, we will discuss some real cases and show some tools out there to make it happen.

title: Effective Strategies for Dropping Out (or Career Transition for Professionals)
description:
In this session we will explore the topic of career transition with a focus on pursuing work at the intersection of technology and the arts. This session is particularly applicable to people interested in pursuing independent practice or looking to create their own business.

Working in industry, particularly technology, it is easy to get frustrated to the point of wanting to rage quit. This session will cover how to stay calm while you make a plan and intelligently transition your focus to something closer to your heart. 

The session includes a 40 minute talk followed by discussion with an open forum for participants to share their situations and approaches. A portion of the talk will cover independent practice and how to best distribute your work time between clients, work, and personal projects.

The talk is based on my own experiences transitioning from a tech focus to an art focus through independent practice. It also includes stories and anecdotes from many others who have pursued a variety of career transitions.

title: Intro to Unity3D for Non Gamers
description:
This is an intro to Unity class for people who don\'t play games and don\'t want to ...
What the hell is Unity? How it thinks and what you can do with it.
The Layout  / the Basics / the Assets and a little bit of code never hurt anyoneâ€¦
No blood will be spilt and no animals hurt in this 2 hour class.

title: What the hell is VR ... and Why?
description:
Really...?

Yeah...  

A brief presentation on the different aspects of what VR is now, from 360 Cinema to Game engines, from Cardboard to room scale, haptic VR... 
Just what it takes and where it looks like it's going.

title: Roll your own MFA (or Ã€ la carte Education)
description:
In this session we will discuss pursuing education in arts & technology through workshops, small programs, tiny schools, conferences, incubators, and other part time & short-term opportunities.

For many people professional degrees are out of reach for time, financial, or other practical/personal reasons. However there are many different ways to pursue learning in the arts & technology space outside of degree programs.

Session video is available here:
[https://vimeo.com/172792458](https://vimeo.com/172792458)

Session documentation is available here:
[http://bit.ly/schoolofme](http://bit.ly/schoolofme)

In this session I will give a short introduction to the idea of Ã  la carte education and building a school for yourself. I will talk a bit about my own attempts at achieving a self-education comparable to an MFA including some tips & tricks.

After the introduction we will build a course catalog together for a virtual school starting from a base list of educational opportunities and experiences. Participants can add other programs, opportunities, books, movies, and ideas to the list. We will then discuss some of these options and consider how you can put pieces from the catalog together to make your own educational program.

title: Programming for Vive
description: Now that the HTC Vive and higher end VR headsets have started to ship... how are we supposed to program content for it. I\'ll show some best practices for room scale VR creation with Unity & the Vive

title: Coloring with Basquiat (Field Trip)
description:
We will take a field trip to Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn where among many brilliant and famous people you will find Jean-Michel Basquiat. We will spend some time hanging out at Basquiat\'s grave and coloring with crayons. 

At 1PM Saturday meet at the \"Eastern Entrance\" to Green-Wood Cemetery located at Fort Hamilton Parkway & Micieli place (on the South end of the cemetery). The closest subway stop is CHURCH ST (F,G). 

Specific directions:
http://www.erikvp.com/Bio/JMB

Cemetery map:
http://www.green-wood.com/map-of-green-wood-cemetery/
(PDF download link on the page)

If you arrive late or a different entrance is more convenient no problem you can walk straight to the grave site. instructions for finding the site are available at the link above. it seems straight forward but i tell ya i got quite lost the first time i went. if you are having trouble finding the site you can reach me by text at (206) 683-4962. 

For those unfamiliar Basquiat has an amazing history and narrative which is well documented in the films \"The Radiant Child\" and \"Downtown 81\" (which you can find on-line.) I recommend watching at least one of the two before the field trip.

title: Glitch as Game Mechanic with Phaser.js
description:
A short talk about glitch as a mechanic in video games, followed by a session where we paper-prototype ways to include a meaningful breakdown mechanic for boardgames and video games. Come and think through what it means about the ways things fall apart!

Introduction to Phaser.js game framework included.

title: Lunchtime life sketching
description:
[Let's meet at the park to draw plants.](https://flic.kr/s/aHskBhFguJ)

Bring your own sketchbook and drawing supplies. I can share mine as well.
No prior drawing experience necessary: if you can sign a check -- you can draw!

title: Suminagashi
description:
Learn antique craft of Suminagashi (Floating Inks).

The best place to make it will be somewhere in the shop.

Suminagashi is a technique that uses water motion to produce prints on paper or fabric.

I\\\\\\\'ll have paper to play with, but you are welcome to bring your own paper if you want. Usually, thin uncoated paper works best, and watercolor paper doesn\\\\\\\'t perform very well. 
Rice paper, goshi paper, and such.

title: Electronics 101
description:
Come learn about the fundamentals of electronics! In this session we will discuss the very basics: What is electricity anyways? How does it work? We will talk about circuit diagrams and learn the most basic elements. 

This is a great session for anyone who feels intimidated by electronics and wants to learn about it!

title: Intro to Sound Design/Engineering
description:
This session will be a survey of sound design and engineering principles, techniques, and tools. No sound experience is required but would be helpful. 

I will go over signal flow, mixing, dynamics, analog-digital conversion, channeling, synthesis, spatialization, MIDI/OSC, dealing with noise, and field recording. I\\\'ll also share some tips and tricks I\\\'ve learned over the last eight years I\\\'ve been designing sound/producing music. Other topics can be covered as well -- just let me know what you\\\'re interested in.

The session is software agnostic as I\\\'ll be going over general sound theory/principles but I will use Logic, Max/MSP, Adobe Audition, and Audacity.

title: The Politics and Poetics of Agile Product Development with Scrum
description:
Scrum is an Agile framework for completing complex projects. It was originally formalized for software development, and has become a standard in the industry, but it works well for any complex, innovative scope of work.

Its methodologies are deceptively simple, and very effective.  Understanding them has become an important qualification for careers in technology development -- and not just for developers and engineers.  Scrum teams include designers, information architects, and other subject matter experts.  When Scrum is the production framework even the business stakeholders should understand the concepts.

This class will go over the basics.  We\'ll also cover some pragmatic compromises that may be necessary to fit practical realities.  We\'ll draw upon my experiences participating in Scrum teams at Conde Nast, NBC, and Daylife, and leading them as Product Owner at Reuters.

For more about Scrum see here: https://www.scrumalliance.org/why-scrum

title: Roundtable Discussion:  Getting and Keeping Young Women Interested in STEAM
description: There are so many women (and parents) at the ITP Camp, and this is very unique in the STEAM world.    I am working on a project that attempts to get young girls interested in STEAM (mostly Science and Tech), and keeping them interested.  I\'d be interested in sharing our stories on why we chose STEM (or chose to leave) and how we might have an impact on the next generation.

title: Digital Shoplifting :: From the Screen to Your Hands
description:
Learn how to appropriate the virtual world for the physical world!
Wait, what?  Internet images => For reelz.

We\'ll cover variety of techniques to save time in your prototyping process.  
Experience in any of the following a plus: Rhino, Illustrator, 3D Printing & Lasercutting.
If not, that\'s cool too!

Just have the free trial of Rhino and Illustrator installed before class!

title: CAD/CAM Software for OSX - Fresh Beginner to Intermediate
description:
A survey of free, open-source, paid, and otherwise available fabrication software for OSX for absolute beginners to intermediate design folks.

We'll be covering various levels of Autodesk offerings, but also OpenSCAD, Rhino, Grasshopper (!) various vector-based drafting packages, and online generation tools to help with project creation.

This is a talk intended to help you get started with a fabrication toolchain for physical projects using srz biznez equipment on a budget.

title: Intro To Data Analysis Using Python and Pandas
description:
The goal of this talk is to give you some concrete examples for getting started with pandas, a python library for data analysis. The docs are really comprehensive. However, I often hear people say they have some trouble getting started, so these are examples with real-world data, and all the bugs and weirdness that entails.

I will probably be working with 2-3 datasets including:

311 calls in New York, 
1MM MovieLens Data

At least some minimal experience with programming (in any language) is recommended.

The code and slides are in my github:
**https://github.com/GusSand/itp_talk_2016**  
they include instructions on installing the prerequisites:

title: Intro to Processing / Java-Based Creative Coding
description:
As requested, this session will be a beginner's guide to Processing. No previous Java or coding experience is necessary, though helpful.

Topics will include an assortment of the following: digital drawing, image analysis, image manipulation, text analysis, text manipulation, inter-software communication,interfacing with hardware (e.g. sensors), etc.

At this point I think I'll design three or four mini-projects that we can complete during the session. Feel free to request or recommend anything!

title: Eagle CAD 101
description:
This session will introduce you to the basics of the Eagle CAD software which is used to design printed circuit boards. 

During this hands-on session we\'ll produce a simple schematic and board file.

Please come with [EagleCAD](http://www.cadsoftusa.com/download-eagle/) installed on your machine.

title: Photogrammetry ... & the future of how we model the word
description:
Photogrammetry is Vastly Changing the areas of photography, 3D Modeling and 3D Fabrication... not to mention games, film and VR. 
We are now able to easily scan people and environments very easily using a number of methods. I will be giving an overview of a variety of methods with emphasis on  Photoscan and the Structure Scanner as well as going over some free tools from Autodesk... 
But this is an open discussion - I am by no means an expert in these things and if you would like to present something or add to the conversation please come ...

Also feel free to email me directly : john.benton@nyu.edu

title: Physical Interactions with Virtual Space
description:
VR is all around us, but when immersed in a virtual world most people want to reach out and touch it.  How can we enable physical interaction within VR experiences?  We will look at how VR creators have approached this so far, with solutions including gaze activation, headset buttons, the controllers of the HTC Vive, using on-headset cameras for hand detection, or full-body motion tracking platforms like the Holojam, and purpose-built hardware using microcontrollers and sensors.  What kinds of interactions have been tried, and what kinds can we imagine?  What are the limitations of existing approaches and challenges in developing new ones?  

After a survey and discussion, we will experiment with how to design and prototype some of these interactions.   Please bring a physical tool or object that you might want to use (as a virtual object) in a virtual experience.

Finally, time permitting, I\\\'ll go through code and hardware for a specific implementation using wifi microcontrollers and Unity.  If you\\\'d like to follow along, be sure to have Unity and Arduino installed, and bring a Yun or ESP8266 with a switch or sensor.

title: Applied Research of Open Experience Design
description:
This open discussion and lecture will showcase a few projects developed through applied research by Wendy W Fok and her team at WE-DESIGNS, a creative boutique agency and architectural design practice that provides creative strategy for the built environment. Wendy W Fok is the Creative Director and trained architect of WE-DESIGNS. She is completing her Doctor of Design at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, with collaborating department, the Harvard Law School. Her upcoming book â€œDigital Property â€“ Open Source Architecture\" explores the issues of ownership and authorship in the field of architecture and design, and the practice of Open Innovation systems and practices. 
This open discussion and lecture will discuss the ever globalized design practice, and the collaborative global leadership with a team of design managers and product line leaders across multiple cross-product initiatives.  Project examples will talk in brief of the high-stakes design challenges, particularly on complex and mission critical projects concerning private and public partnerships of crossover projects from architecture, product design, to experience design.  Larger goals of the talk will discuss the ever-changing strategies on building relationships with a wide range of stakeholders, from museums, fashion brands, to public projects from players such as the City of Boston and the Times Square Alliance. 
The on-going open discussion will continue to a larger dialogue on how the field of design and architectural practice is fostering the development of the visual design practice by staying abreast of design best practices, emerging interaction design patterns, and new technologies.

title: 3D Printing Studio Tour
description:
IMPORTANT: Meet in front of 545 LaGuardia Pl, New York, NY 10012 at 4 pm. This is NOT the regular NYU ITP Building. 

Join in for a tour of NYU\'s LaGuardia studio! This tour will offer students an overview of this exciting new media studio and introduce the technologies that are used for 3D visualization, prototyping, tooling, and fabrication.

The LaGuardia Studio is a state-of-the-art facility and advanced technology resource for the NYU community, providing professional services in 3D printing, 3D scanning, wide-format archival digital pigment printmaking, and project development consultation.

title: Getting Started With Ultimaker 2+ Desktop 3D Printer
description:
Quick crash course to get those new to Ultimaker printers (and/or desktop 3D printing in general) setup with the basic software, tools, best-practices, and troubleshooting tips to make use of the set of Ultimaker 2+ units that I am making available for camper use at ITP this June.

Those attending any sessions of this course will have priority access to printing time and donated filament, so make sure to drop in for one of these quick sessions early in the month for access to more training and materials later in the month!

NOTE1: I'll keep adding more sessions in the schedule (including sessions later in the evening during the week) based on requests. Is there a time that you'd really wish I'd offer this? Let me know then!

NOTE2: I'm looking to add more session co-leaders to provide basics for the entire set of desktop 3D printers at ITP this summer. Sound like something you want to help me do? Let me know!

title: Desktop 3D Printer Basic Training (Ultimaker 2+ and Beyond)
description:
Quick crash course to get those new to Ultimaker printers (and/or desktop 3D printing in general) setup with the basic software, tools, best-practices, and troubleshooting tips to make use of the set of Ultimaker 2+ units that I am making available for camper use at ITP this June.

SPECIAL NOTE - This session is likely to gain a co-presenter and add in the MakerBots and other desktop printers on the floor! I'll update this description to confirm, but I can at least get everyone up on the software and basic practices in any case.

Those attending any sessions of this course will have priority access to printing time and donated filament, so make sure to drop in for one of these quick sessions early in the month for access to more training and materials later in the month!

NOTE1: I'll keep adding more sessions in the schedule (including sessions later in the evening during the week) based on requests. Is there a time that you'd really wish I'd offer this? Let me know then!

NOTE2: I'm looking to add more session co-leaders to provide basics for the entire set of desktop 3D printers at ITP this summer. Sound like something you want to help me do? Let me know!

title: Lasercutting 101
description:
If you're doing any physical fabrication this summer the laser printer is a great asset to building clean looking, professional prototypes. 

Come to learn about the basics, including safety, formatting, helpful tips, discussion of materials and demonstration of ways to use the Epilog Laser Printers.

To make the best use of this class come prepared with adobe illustrator to follow along, or any open source software that supports illustrator.

title: Lasercutting 101
description:
If you're doing any physical fabrication this summer the laser printer is a great asset to building clean looking, professional prototypes.

Come to learn about the basics, including safety, formatting, helpful tips, discussion of materials and demonstration of ways to use the Epilog Laser Printers.

To make the best use of this class come prepared with adobe illustrator to follow along, or any open source software that supports illustrator.

title: Generative Design in Processing
Karaoke Field Trip to Arlene's Grocery
description:
For funsies ITP Camp karaoke-field-trip-outing to the "world-famous" karaoke at Arlene's Grocery on the Lower East Side. Live backing band and cheap drinks, if you're into that.

Meet at ITP at 10p and we'll head out.

title: Fundamental Pop-Up Paper Engineering [rerun]
description: Ever wonder how Pop-up books work? This is your chance to find out. Bring a decent pair of scissors. I'll provide the rest.

title: Simulating Color Blindness in Processing
description:
In this session we will explore color blindness using a new Processing library I have built. My library can do a real-time color transformation on any sketch to simulate what a color blind person would see. Using this library, we will be able to effectively design Processing applications or artwork that color blind people can see and appreciate.

We will cover the science behind color models and color blindness simulation while also exploring design issues using Processing sketches.

No coding is necessary. This library is one of my ITP Camp projects and I would very much appreciate your thoughts and feedback. I also intend to port this library to P5.js after camp, so if you will want to use that later, you should come to this session to learn what it is about.

title: Introduction to the Multimeter
description:
Have you ever see one of these gadgets in the shop and wondered what itâ€™s for and how to use it? This is your class!

The multimeter is a great all-around tool for working with electronics: check the charge on a battery, test a cable, troubleshoot the wiring on your latest Arduino project â€” and much, much more.

This class assumes no prior knowledge of electronics and weâ€™ll also discuss basic electrical safety. Weâ€™ll even measure the voltage of a lemon!

There will be several multimeters on hand, and plenty of time for everyone to ask questions and try everything out!

title: Field Trip: Material Connexion - SECTION CLOSED
description:
IMPORTANT: Please note that the best entrance to use is 111 West 50th Street. The reception desk will be all the way to the back right upon entering. Photo ID will be required.

What\'s Material Connexion? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=swfiZ3Mk204

Material ConneXion maintains the worldâ€™s largest subscription-based materials library with thousands of innovative materials and processes across all disciplines of design.

Join in for a guided tour of Material Connexion, followed by time afterwards to peruse materials in their material library.

title: Intro to the Command Line
description:
Why do programmers still use an interface from the 1970\'s?  And more importantly, how do you use it?  We\'ll cover the most-used commands, explore the file system from a terminal, and play with some useful tools that quickly show you what\'s going on in your computer.  There will be plenty of practice and no one will be left behind.

Do bring your Mac or Linux laptop.  Unfortunately we can\'t cover the terminal in Windows because it\'s a bit different and we\'re not as familiar with it.

title: Sketching plants in the park
description:
Let\'s meet at Washington Square park and sketch plants.
It\'s all very informal.
No prior drawing experience necessary: if you can sign a check -- you can draw!

Bring your sketchbook, and fill it with wonderful mistakes :)
