We will meet next to Garibaldi statue and go from there.
I\'ll circulate phone to text, or use direct slack message.

title: Keyboard Making Workshop (Pt II)
description:
In this two-day workshop (22nd and 23rd), campers will design and build custom keyboards using a person-centered approach. We will invite guests from the community with disabilities to speak about their needs and wants in terms of a keyboard and in teams, design and build for them.

This workshop will be co-led with Ben Light and will help us in the development of a toolkit/refine the process of making custom keyboards.

title: What Is A Scripting Language? â˜… Intro to JavaScript ES6 â˜…
description:
This is an experimental session covering an intro to JS, and what makes JavaScript meaningfully different from Ruby or Python. The session covers some basic FUN THINGS about how to build code. It is for everyone from BEGINNER to INTERMEDIATE: beginners will learn some things that make getting to intermediate easier, like what is a linter, and intermediate programmers will learn about things like fat-arrow functions.

We will go over things like:

â˜…    WHY IS IT CALLED Y-COMBINATOR ANYWAY

â˜…    How to use variables, const, and let

â˜…    Simple program structures

â˜…    Writing a web application server with Express 4

This is a seminar with SOME coding, but which is more about ways to learn meaningful programming if you prefer English class. It is a good intro! You will leave with some specific tools, and an idea of what people are talking about when they talk about Code.

title: From OBJ to IRL. Lets talk about AR and bring our models to life!
description:
A short talk about how AR works in its current implementations, as well as what it is being used for in marketing, academia and art. We will also discuss about its future as the technology develops and the distinction between AR and VR blurs.

Afterwards, we get some models uploaded on an AR platform to show and admire! If you have some models of your own, bring them as .obj

This session is convenient if you arre coming fresh from the photogrammetry session,and want to expand on the things you can do with your newly created 3D models!

title: Sound & Movement Playground
description:
How can we explore our environment with our bodies? How do we interact with our body in technologically enhanced environments? And how does a full-body experience feel for the user, performer or artist?

Well, honestly we do not know the full answer yet. This why we all need to collaborate! 

The plan is to play with yoga-techniques and theatre-games to challenge our perspective and stimulate creativity (first hour), then discuss how we could use these new perspectives on sound & movement in your future tech projects and - if time permits - start to experiment (second hour). 

This is NOT intended to be an expert-lecture on existing software or tools but a collaborative playtime on how to combine different approaches to immersive experiences. You do not need to have any prior knowledge, everybody interested in the combination of body, sounds & movement is invited. The idea is to have a forum dedicated to these topics, have a look at the approaches we have at hand (tech and non-tech) and \\\\\\\"press play\\\\\\\" -  this is why we called it a playground!

title: Intro to 3D Printing & Modeling Techniques
description:
You want to 3D print, but you have NO IDEA where to start. Is this you? Well youâ€™re in luck because this is a session for the uninitiated. We will use a combination of free and proprietary software.

We will get started with some simple 3D scanning techniques with a handheld scanner (Sense scanner), desktop scanner (Makerbor 3D scanner), and the free mobile phone interface 123D Catch. Secondly, we will look into free 3D content libraries such as Thingiverse. Thirdly, we will explore two free and easy-to-use 3D modeling platforms: TinkerCAD and Meshmixer. Lastly, we will look into several ways to get your model to the 3D printer â€“ Makerbot Desktop, Simplify 3D, and Slic3r. 

All skill levels are totally welcome, however, if you have a lot of experience in 3D modeling and printing, this session may prove to be a bit too basic for you. Ideally Iâ€™d like everyone to get hands-on experience, but this is contingent on how many people enroll in the class. 

If youâ€™d like to participate, please do the following ahead of time:
Install Meshmixer on your laptop (http://www.meshmixer.com/download.html), Create a TinkerCAD account (www.tinkercad.com),
Create a Thingiverse account or Makerbot account (www.thingiverse.com),
Install Slic3r on your laptop (optional  http://slic3r.org/download),
Install 123D catch (on your phone)

http://bit.ly/28L5lEQ

title: Are you afraid of the shop?
description: Come get comfortable in the shop, but want to learn about it come ask me questions. This session will be an intro to tools like the drill press, saws, clamping things down, how to use a drill or the sander. Bring questions, or a project you want some advice on, and get familiar with the shop.

title: Sewing with the Serger
description: The serger is a great tool, but a bit of cranky one to set up and get going. If you\'d like to use it and don\'t know how come by for a quick tutorial.

title: Move your body: stretch session
description: Take a break and stretch with me! we have yoga mats!

title: Move your body: stretch session
description: Take a break and stretch with me! We have yoga mats!

title: Intro to web scraping with Python
description:
What is web scraping and how do you do it?

Sometimes, you need to gather large amounts of data or content from a website when there\\\\\\\'s no API available. That\\\\\\\'s where web scraping comes in.

This workshop will be a basic introduction to web scraping using the Python programming language. We\\\\\\\'ll start by looking at some off-the-shelf tools and then go into scraping a website with Python\\\\\\\'s beautiful soup library to extract content from the HTML of a web page.

The following are helpful but not required: Familiarity with HTML; familiarity with programming (any language); basic knowledge of Terminal.

BEFORE FRIDAY, PLEASE MAKE SURE:
------------------------------------------
You have a text editor installed. I use Sublime Text.

That Python is installed on your computer. You can verify this by entering \"python\" (without quotes) in the Terminal. If, for some reason, you find that you do not have Python installed, please follow the instructions for installing version 2.7.11 at python.org. 

You install pip, the Python package manager. On Mac, run the following command in the terminal to do so:
$ sudo easy_install pip

Install Beautiful soup, the library weâ€™ll be using. Use pip install to do so, as follows:
$ sudo pip install beautifulsoup4

title: Sensuous Cities: IOT, Blockchain Smart Contracts & Citizen Science Tools & Strategies
description:
In Sandy Pentlandâ€™s most recent book, [Social Physics: How Social Networks Can Make Us Smarter](http://www.amazon.com/Social-Physics-Networks-Make-Smarter/dp/0143126334?ie=UTF8&keywords=social%20physics&qid=1463171062&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1), he examines and answers big questions like, â€œHow can we design organizations and governments that are cooperative, productive, and creative?â€ 

In this workshop, we will examine several citizen science tools and best-practices for those interested in improving how we manage our shared natural and social capital resources. 

Citizensâ€™ Observatories enable citizens to adopt a key role as Citizen Scientists, in the stewardship and management of their environment. 

**â€œWhat you are trying to do is make a human-machine symbiote, where the humans understand more about the network of interactions because of the computers, and the computers are able to understand more about how humans work, and therefore, work better with them,â€ -Sandy Pentland**

Hardware+ Software:
Arduino & Raspberri Pi, with various other sensors and devices.
Processing, P5js, Temboo, Spacebrew, Meshblu

**Questions for our discussion:**
-How can we include blockchain smart contracts created using The Ethereum [Solidity language](http://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) and [Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO)](https://daohub.org/about.html) governance models to improve the Citizen Science process?
-How can interdisciplinary practitioners in the design, architecture, engineering, and art worlds work better together to solve urgent issues for humanity?

We will look at case studies from [Public Lab](https://publiclab.org/), & [Intelligent River](https://www.intelligentriver.org/data) 

The workshop will conclude with the introduction of a new **citizen science observatory project**  that invites participants to co-create projects that expand on these ideas.

title: Shop Safety! MANDATORY!
description:
Shop safety is MANDATORY for all campers, regardless of whether or not you intend to work in the shop. 

Meet for this short safety session in the Shop with Kat!

title: Shop Safety! MANDATORY!
description:
Shop safety is MANDATORY for all campers, regardless of whether or not you intend to work in the shop. 

Meet for this short safety session in the Shop with Kat!

title: Leather Craft Basics
description:
Learn the basics of working with leather. You will create a small leather accessory - a cord holder, a wristband, a card holder, or a coin purse. We will talk about tips for working on larger projects, what tools you need to get started, and a survey of resources. 
If you have an idea of something else small that you\\\\\\\'d like to make during the class, please email Teresa beforehand.

title: knotty knots: survival knots and rigging basics
description:
Knots are an analog tech that is used heavily in the theater, live performance and the installation world. They can help you scale mountains, hang hammocks, and make artwork. I use knots as a rock climber, rigger, builder, traveler, and aerialist. Ive helped build monumental shade structures all with fabric and ropes, and made climbing structures out of nets. 

This workshop will include:

all the knots I need to survive and build things.

basics of rigging things or people above our heads with rope.

slides of all the knots. 

a brief discussion of the various types of line and when to use what.

I will provide some rope, but if you have some at home feel free to bring it in I can tell you roughly what it is rated for an when it might be applicable.

title: Intro to actuators with the arduino
description:
The workshop will cover how the schematics and code to control actuators of many types: dc motors, servos (180), solenoids (pull and push/pull), holding solenoids, Shape memory alloy. 

You won\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\'t have to know Pcomp, but you can work on more advanced motions if you do.

I will have pre built prototyping boards for each actuator type and parts set aside for you to build your own. We\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\'ll be using a range of tools from variable power supplies to relays, and low power transistors to make the motion. we will combine the motion to make things from the junk shelf wiggle about, or if you took Eric\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\'s kinetic sculptures workshop you can continue to work on your project.

you can see some of my most recent work here thea-rae.tumblr.com/tagged/thesis

title: Wearable Tech Design
description:
What does it mean to place electronics on the body? In this class we will talk about the design challenges of wearable technology - flexibility, size, placement, power, etc. We will look at microcontrollers, sensors, tools, and materials for prototyping, and where to find them. We will explore many examples of wearables projects, and discuss the current state of consumer products and what innovations may disrupt it.

The second half of the class will be devoted to ideation. We will discuss how to turn an idea into a meaningful experience. You will have the chance to develop a concept, build a â€œpaper prototypeâ€, and discuss next steps for bringing a project to life.

title: HTML & CSS - Make a website
description:
If youâ€™ve never touched HTML or CSS, or youâ€™re in need of a refresher, this class will be a chance to get down to basics. Iâ€™ll show you how quick it can be to make something thatâ€™s simple and looks good. During this class you will work on a single page layout. You are encouraged to make a site to show off your work at ITP Camp, but Iâ€™ll also provide some photos of kittens and puppies in case you need content. Topics covered will include custom fonts, responsive design, accessibility, and more.

Please bring a laptop with your favorite text editor. I recommend Sublime Text.

title: Ani-Motion (Workshop)
description:
In this session, we will explore storytelling through stop-motion animation and will bring objects back to life. During the first part of the session, we will learn how animation is created and how the illusion of motion is perceived in our brain. We will learn how to animate still objects, clay, paper cuts and even people. Next, we will go through some basics in DragonFrame which will give the participant the needed tools to create a stop motion animation. 

During the second part of the session, we will be divided into 4 groups, and each group will create a short video using a different stop-motion technique (clay, objects, pixelation and cutouts).

By the end of this session, the participants will acquire the basic knowledge of how to use DragonFrame for stop-motion animation, will be familiarized with different techniques of stop-motion animation and will have a short animation video to show.

Inspiration: https://youtu.be/qBjLW5_dGAM

title: Mermaid Parade
description:
The 34th Annual Mermaid Parade is Saturday, June 18, 2016, 1pm! 

If you want to feature your mermaid tail, [click here to register!](http://www.coneyisland.com/mermaid-parade-registration-page) Or just come over and watch for free.

http://www.coneyisland.com/programs/mermaid-parade
![marmaid](http://www.coneyisland.com/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/580kenny9.jpg?itok=grzCsqMi)

[map](https://www.google.com/maps/d/u/0/viewer?mid=1bWJgSCIA9cyXX6u7Kk9dOaWKMzY&hl=en)

title: Cyborg Nest: Implanting Technology to Create New Senses
description:
Neil Harbisson and Moon Ribas are cyborg artists who each have technology implanted into their bodies. Neil has an antenna implanted in his skull that enables him to sense color via audio vibrations. He uses his new sense to conduct color concerts involving music and painting. Moon has a chip implanted in her arm that vibrates according to the earth\\\\\\\'s seismic activity, which she expresses through dance. 

Neil and Moon, along with a group of collaborators, have recently founded a company called Cyborg Nest, which manufactures implantable senses for sale to the public. Their first sense is the North Sense, which allows one to sense the earths geomagnetic field, like birds and marine animals do. Their philosophy is to use technology to experience nature more deeply, rather than as a conduit for information.

This session will be conducted by Neil and Moon. They\\\\\\\'ll explain how they came to be cyborgs and their work with Cyborg Nest and the North Sense, followed by a Q&A.

title: Realtime & Multiuser Applications with Firebase
description: In this session, you will develop a simple chatroom and a realtime collaborative drawing tool using Google\\\'s Firebase framework. It\\\'s way easier than programming Node.js - so, it\\\'s perfect for people who know just a little bit about programming. And it\\\'s also perfect for people who know a lot about programming. It\\\'s super powerful. With a little practice, you will be able to create social platforms or IoT devices that implement authentication, file storage, analytics, etc. We will be doing some programming together as a group, so please bring a laptop with p5.js installed.

title: Shop Safety! MANDATORY!
description:
Shop safety is MANDATORY for all campers, regardless of whether or not you intend to work in the shop. 

Meet for this short safety session in the Shop with Song!

title: FIELD TRIP TO CONTROL (COME IF U LIKE SYNTHS) ~beep boop
description:
We are going to [Control in Williamsburg](http://www.ctrl-mod.com/)

Come play and make beeps and boops. 

Also! Maybe we can get a group deal on buying a shit ton of kits of some sort, we can come back and solder a bunch of things. Who knows. We will keep our options open.

title: 10x Command-Line Fu (Mac OSX/Unix)
description:
Alternative working title: How to look cooler at Starbucks

The terminal is the main interface for all things coding and sometimes we forget just how powerful it can be. The aim of this session is to give you an idea of that power. Together, we\'ll walk through some advanced commands and examples. We\'ll do some server-side scripting that\'ll make you realize why staying up late to learn Javascript is still a good idea. I\\\'ll demo advanced examples and we\\\'ll work through small assignments together that I hope will help you 10x some of your more mundane tasks.

We\\\'ll cover:

* intermediate commands: history, CTRL-R, grep, alias, curl, say, watch
* writing your first alias
* |, &&, and output redirection
* what does `cat` do anyway? writing your first shell script
* writing your second shell script in javascript
* ~/.bash_profile and understanding the PATH
* cron
* homebrew - a package manager for OSX and why you should\\\\\\\'ve used it yesterday
  - installing tree
  - installing jq (and mixing this with chrome inspector for some real fun)

Beginners are welcome. Exercises will be aimed at those with some familiarity with bash, but all are welcome to follow along and understand why it\\\'s a useful skill.

title: Advanced Time Series Mapping Using Torque
description:
_Interested in making web apps? Check out [React Natural](http://itp.nyu.edu/camp2016/session/78) at **1pm** on the **same day** as this session._

**SESSION REPO: [sighrobot/itpcamp-torque](https://github.com/sighrobot/itpcamp-torque)**

The [Torque](https://cartodb.com/torque/) library, developed by [CartoDB](https://cartodb.com/), lets you map time series data (i.e. any dataset with a date or time field) with ease. At first glance, however, it seems impossible to achieve anything more sophisticated than markers appearing and disappearing over time.

In this one-hour session you will learn the basics of **spatial aggregation**, the technique used by Torque to efficiently render time series data. You will also learn an important trick for using spatial aggregation to display multifaceted data, as well as secrets and caveats of writing [CartoCSS](https://docs.cartodb.com/cartodb-platform/cartocss/).

_An intermediate level of familiarity with CartoDB or data mapping will be assumed. Python will be used to generate CartoCSS._

title: FIRESIDE FRIDAY- "THE POLITICS OF TECH IN REMOTE PLACES"
description: Janvieve Williams Comrie and Edwin Reed-Sanchez talk to us about their experience supporting tech in remote areas of Nicaragua and Colombia. What are the politics of \"remote tech\"? What does community access look like? Can tech influence accountability in marginalized spaces around the world? How can the politics of \"remote tech\" shape how we develop new technology?

title: How do you stop the sea rising?
description:
As the climate system warms the world\'s oceans are rising. There is large uncertainty about how fast our seas will rise, but one things is for sure, they will. The best estimates from the scientific community indicate, that with current pledged climate action, we could witness sea levels rise by up to one meter by 2100. It is estimated that this will displace five hundred million people around the world. Some countries are at greater risk, there is no greater risk than to the people of Bangladesh where thirty million people may be displaced in the next 85 years. 

**Daniel Price** is an environmental scientist who has spent a decade studying the climate system and in particularly investigating Antarctica\'s role in the climate system. After his latest of three fieldwork campaigns to the Antarctic, he started Pole to Paris, a campaign to raise awareness of the importance of COP21 in Paris last December. While his colleague Erlend Moster Knudsen ran from the Arctic Circle to Paris, beginning in the Antarctic he cycled over 10,000 km through 19 countries giving a public speaking tour and reporting the impacts and potential consequences of climate change along the way.

En route, he stopped off in Bangladesh, where he shot a documentary to explore the issue of sea level rise in the country and lift the wider concerns of rising seas into the public domain. After all, Bangladesh isn\'t the only country with a coastline.

**Join us for exclusive viewing of \"Thirty Million\" (duration 34min). This will be followed by an open discussion about how technology and innovation could help society adapt to, or offset predicted rises in sea level and deal with mass migration.**

**Wednesday, June 15, 4-5:30pm
You\\\\\\\'re welcome to join for either part of the session, ideally for both!**

Film can be viewed online: http://thirtymillionfilm.org/

title: VJing 101: Mixing live audio responsive visuals with Resolume
description:
This session will be a crash course on performing live video manipulation aka VJing aka Video Jockeying. I will take you through the workflow of generating some simple content using Resolume Arena (you can download a demo version here:  https://resolume.com/download/) . Im very open to specific requests if anyone has a project in mind, but I plan to cover the basics of getting a performance up and running, including but not limited to: 

- The basics of mixing: composition, layers, and effects 
- Playback and keyboard mapping
- What the hey is a codec and why is it important
- Synching with a DJ and customizing audio reactivity 
- Output and projection mapping

Iâ€™ll compile some demo material for us to play around with. Feel free to come with your own visual/ audio content! 

Google Drive link: https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/0B1YMtA2N-28AMGVySnNWM2RLUG8

title: Trip to Arthur's Tavern, nearby legendary jazz spot (no cover!) for awesome Monday night band
description:
Arthur's Tavern is just a short walk West of Washington Square Park and is where the jazz legend Charlie Parker used to play. True to its history, they've always maintained a no-cover policy.

There is live music 7 days a week here, but Mondays is something special because of their hilarious band. It's not quite jazz, it's not quite soul and its not quite R&B... but it is incredible music and also quite hilarious. 

Join in for a trip to this historic NY night spot!

Meet at the Tables area @ 1030 after photographic thinking

title: Documenting Your Projects
description:
Learn how to create killer documentation for your projects! Whether you want to archive your artwork, beef up your design portfolio, write your own cookbook, or create better open source code, this session has something for everyone.

We will start by discussing some inspirational examples, then set up some basic lighting and camera equipment for shooting tabletop and human subjects, and go over photo/video editing workflow and online publishing strategies.

Come with a project in mind (or in hand)!

title: Open Source Cinema
description:
Motion pictures are a powerful cultural force but are mostly the work of scribes.  Constructing the reality to put in front of a camera is still an undertaking out of reach to all but a few.  If you want to then change or share something from a film you mostly have to reshoot everything.  Recent developments in 3D rendering, motion capture, depth sensing, scanning are making cinema more mutable by making it out of parts that can be changed and shared.  Gutenberg found reusable parts to free printing from the domain of scribes resulting in an explosion of knowledge in our civilization.  What can we expect from a similar democratization of cinema?  In this session we will discuss the general power of systems where you recombine parts to create a universe of meanings.  Then we discuss how they might apply conceptually to cinema, and talk about specific tools that will help to get started in this area.

Here are two books that are interesting for this discussion.
Flicker â€“ by Zach â€”  recent research on how motion pictures work.
The Art of Immersion  â€“ by Rose â€” contextualizes all the current interest and methods of immersive VR.
The Beginning of Infinity - David Deutch  chapter on Jump to the Universal describes the power of universal systems.

Here are some questions:
Is cinema virtual reality?
What are the elements of cinema (hint: not pixels)?
What can you vary to make a story interactive?
Is the headset the thing that defines VR?  What other physical expression is possible?
Can we crowdsource movie making?
Can we borrow from comics with an aesthetic of juxtaposition?
How do we search for film?
Is 360 Video useful?
How do you use the Kinect for greenscreen?
Which is better Unity or Three.js?
What is a format for sharing â€œunflattenedâ€ video?

title: The Business of Experiences: A Panel Discussion (with Insights from Tough Mudder)
description:
ITP Camp seems focused on using tech to create experiences. But what about the next step, building experiences into a viable business? 

In this session, former Tough Mudder executive and employee #4 Alex Patterson will lead a discussion about how to commercialize experiences. 

He is looking for folks who have worked in businesses that sell experience (however broadly defined). 

Alex can also add (if appropriate):
- the story of how Tough Mudder in 3 years grew from zero to $75M in revenue
- describe how he built the Tough Mudder obstacle innovation process & KPIs
- discuss how to turn customers into crazy loyal tribe using social media

The 1.5 hour session will finish attendees being able to describe their projects, with the rest of the participants opining on their likelihood as viable commercial businesses.

title: Lenticular follow-up practicum
description:
This session will be a follow up to the previously held session: Lenticular Imagesâ€“3D & Animation on the Printed Page

We will be picking up where we left off with continued troubleshooting of printing/mounting lenticulars as well as the creation of scanimations.

This follow up is mainly intended for campers who participated in the previous session, but if you want to try to join mid-stream, please look at this code:

http://www.cosmicharding.com/lenny_suite.zip

See you all soon!

title: Electrochemistry
description:
Dissect common batteries! Explore how acids encourage electrons to flow from one metal to another! Compare the output of carbon and zinc to copper and aluminum! Watch as copper comes off of a penny to plate a quarter!

You may know how electromagnets and permanent magnets generate electrical flow, but if the chemistry of electricity is a mystery, come ground yourself in understanding with this fun exploration!

title: What is Color?
description:
Discover what makes the wonderful sensation of color- Discuss the sensory mechanisms of the eye and brain- Make and use a Spectroscope to analyze light-Understand additive and subtractive primaries by separating and combining wavelengths of light- Play with your perception with simultaneous contrast after-image- and enjoy the kaleidoscopic interaction of bi-refringent cellophane and polarized light!

This fun session will expand your understanding and offer simple ways to demonstrate how we experience the phenomenon of color

title: DIY Speaker
description:
How is sound converted into electricity, stored as levels of voltage, then converted back to sound? 
 
Learn how speakers and microphones work by building a simple speaker, then improving its sound by adding resonating chambers! Whose speaker will be the loudest?

title: Needle Felted Simple Circuits
description:
Come enjoy sculpting with natural wool roving- it\\\\\\\'s easy and wonderful!
 
Embed conductive thread or steel wool to add LED\\\\\\\'s or tech 
 
Create joints for movement and bring them to life with stop-motion or robotics


 Note: I am asking for a $5 contribution to cover the cost of wool roving, etc.

title: Intro to Inflatables
description:
Learn the basics of DIY inflatables with an intro lecture to design constraint basics, material choices, fabrication techniques, leak rates vs flow, etc. Then follow-up by experimenting at making your own heat-sealed or adhesive-sealed mylar balloons.

We can increase class size if people commit to BYOI (bring your own irons)! Flat irons for hair or regular clothing irons both work great with this material.

title: Intro to Archetypes
description:
The new technology we learn here at ITP Camp will continue to alter the ways we interact  with each other as fundamentally as the invention of the camera, the television or the smartphone. 
But what we have to say - will that change as well? 

In this session weâ€™ll talk about \\\'archetypes\\\', a term coined by famed Swiss psychologist Carl Jung. In his lifelong study of the human unconscious, Jung found that below an individualâ€™s personal unconscious was a deeper strata he termed the \\\'collective unconscious\\\'. This is the layer of the psyche that is common to all people. Just as all human beings are born with two arms and two legs, so Jung found that we are all born with inherited psychological tendencies â€” sort of like a psychic blueprint. 

This blueprint being populated by archetypes. You can think of archetypes as images, motifs, instructs and centres of energy and attraction all rolled up into one. When we watch movies, hear stories, we are watching and hearing archetypes. The original Star Wars trilogy, for example, got its cult-like status due to its successful use of archetypal motifs. The cultural and religious myths of all peoples and ages tap into this archetypal reservoir. 

This session will go over the basics of archetypal psychology and give contemporary examples of how archetypes are employed in popular media, as well as in politics.

title: Things I Made At Pier 9
description:
This will be super casual. 

Before coming to ITP Camp I did a [residency at Autodesk\'s Pier 9 facility](http://www.autodesk.com/artist-in-residence/home) .

In this talk I will share the nitty gritty of the work-in-progress stuff that I made there. Subjects include pinky fingers, porcupines, and human-machine romance. It will likely only last 20 minutes unless you interrupt and ask lots of questions (which you should) and then maybe it will be longer!

title: Intro to After Effects and Cinema 4D Lite
description:
This class will introduce the After Effects environment. And we will spend some time obsessing over Saul and Elaine Bass. No experience is necessary, but youâ€™ll get more out of the course if you have After Effects installed on your machine. If you have After Effects CC, youâ€™ll have Cinema 4D Lite too!

In this session, we will do the following:

Take a tour of After Effects

Introduce key frames and transformations

Work with bitmap and vector images, audio assets, and footage

Export your video in the proper format

And if time permits, we can explore a little bit of Cinema 4D Lite and 3D scanning to create a 3D motion graphic. 

To get course materials, go here:

Try this link first:

http://bit.ly/1OzDgmW


No luck? Try this one:

http://bit.ly/1TUCNaY

title: ITP â™¥ Data&Society - Whisky Wednesdays Field Trip
description:
This is a field trip to Data & Society\'s Whisky Wednesdays social time. We\'ve been invited by Audrey, their social coordinator. There are a bunch of researchers at Data & Society dedicated, to, well, everything about data and society. Anil Dash works here, as does Danah Boyd (it\'s her research group)!

Probably the most famous of their papers is \"It\'s Complicated: The Social Lives of Networked Teens\".
http://www.danah.org/books/ItsComplicated.pdf

The research group is always turning out interesting work. Turn up, you don\'t have to drink anything, and leave when you like. We\'ll meet at the lab and walk up. You MUST RSVP for this so we can plan numbers and let them know who to expect.

title: Digital Art Curation in the Real World
description:
ITP has introduced so many of us to amazing ideas that always work so well with the almost unlimited resources of NYU...

But what happens when you get into the real world? How do you implement those ideas and techniques in spaces with limited resources? How do you work with clients who don\'t know what they want, only what they don\'t want?

This will be a forum where we share our experiences, tips, and strategies for implementing all of the great things we\'ve learned in real-world, less-than-optimal situations.

title: Max-Jitter 2 / Kinect project demo
description:
A continuation of the session from June 11. 

Advanced topics in Max-Jitter as needed, including a demonstration of Josh\\\'s Kinect project from FIGMENT (covers usage of the Kinect in Max).

title: Grow your own piezoelectric crystals
description:
From phonographs to sonar - microphones to radios, piezoelectric crystals have been at the heart of many inventions. This course will be half lecture/discussion and half hands-on. We will discuss the basics of crystallography and applications of piezoelectricity. The lab will give you all the instruction and materials needed to start growing your own piezo crystal. Finally, as a class we will examine crystals under a microscope in polarized light.

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1Nk-jnJwkc85Ens9NoNGqXboDd0Zawe9WSwJluRi7V0Q/edit#slide=id.g1141bc4dc3_1_78

title: Traditional stab bookbinding workshop
description:
I will be teaching how to bind books using the traditional method of stab-binding, used extensively throughout East Asia since times far past. It is a very elegant technique, and is excellent for DIY-lovers, for it requires close to nothing to do, and is extremely versatile in terms of both material and aesthetics. It\'s a nice jumping board into the world of bookbinding.

We will start by each making a basic sketchbook. After that we will apply the skills toward crafting a quick personal project, with our eye toward exploring what happens when we merge traditional, pre-industrial era techniques with the staggeringly great digital tools at our disposal. 

No prior knowledge needed!
All materials will be provided!

title: A Brief History of Tech, Sex and Fashion
description:
What does the invention of the vibrator have to do with **hygienic underwear systems**? Who is the Herculin Barbin and why was there a zoologist performing their autopsy? WHY IS THAT LADY STICKING A VIBRATOR IN HER EYE?!

Id like to share with you, fair campers, some of my top 10 fun facts that I discovered while researching the history of technology and sex, sexuality & gender in the US at the turn of the 20th century.

This will be a more detailed [possibly silly] version of a TEDx talk I did back in 2011.

In the broadest strokes weâ€™ll be looking at what **fashion as technology** meant in the late 1800s and early 1900s.  How did sex shape tech and vice versa back then in some weird & hilarious ways?  What lessons can we learn from these logical and hilarious â€œmistakesâ€?

If we have time at the end, Ill facilitate an informal discussion about design && sex toys. 



**A little background:** *I was a camp counselor back in 2013 and taught this workshop in 2014.  Here is a camper review from the 2014 workshop:*

*\'Several folks described this as the best workshop during camp. Fresh, curious, interesting topic that blended philosophy and insight with the effects of technology on culture. The length of the session was well orchestrated to allow for full complete delivery of the topic without breathless clicking of slides, followed by genuine engagement and discussion from everyone in attendance. Sheiva got all talking in deep meaningful ways. Was a little island of sensitive conversation in a hub of uber-technology. Memorable.\'*

Hope to see you this year!

title: Introduction to Cinder - Wild and Wooly Programming in C++
description:
__Cinder__ ([libcinder.org](https://libcinder.org)) is a powerful programming library for C++ that makes it easy to construct fast interactive graphics applications.  This session will cover the basics of C++ and the build process, then dive into some of the features of Cinder itself.

It will be helpful if attendees have some experience with C++ or other programming language.

Please download and unzip the Cinder library from [here](https://libcinder.org/download).

Also, you will need to install a C++ compiler.

For the Mac, you can get Xcode for free from the App Store.

For Windows, you can install the free version of Microsoft Visual Studio (called _Community_) [here](https://www.visualstudio.com/products/free-developer-offers-vs).  Select Custom install and uncheck everything except Programming Languages -> Visual C++ -> Common Tools for Visual C++ 2015.  If you have MSVS C++ Express 2013 already installed, then that should work.

title: A (Sl)hackers ABCs: Zero to Adobe Pro Tips, Tricks, and Shortcuts
description:
**MAXIMIZE YOUR WORKFLOW!**

Iâ€™m leading this session to help you make your visual assets (perhaps for your show & tell projects?) even more stunning!  The content will be totally tailored to the campers who participate.

This session would be great for beginners and advanced users alike.  Campers are welcome to drop in whenever they can.

**Part 1:** Lightning fast Adobe CC keyboard shortcuts and tricks to make your workflow super efficient  
**Part 2:** Camperâ€™s choice, Pro tutorial (see some options below)  
**Part 3:** HANDS-ON HELP, letâ€™s make your work beautiful & fun

Learn how to use keyboard shortcuts in Photoshop, Illustrator & InDesign to:

**(1)** to professionally retouch or alter your photos and artworks, -and-or  
**(2)** design a business card, -and-or  
**(3)** fulfill your fantasy of making Daily Show-type animated gifs at lightning speed!  
**(4)** Finally understand what the hell a mask is and how best to use it!  
Or BONUS (5) Give your project that professional polish it needs, fast!

No matter what we cover, you will definitely walk away with truly pro & lightning fast skills.  Learn all the shortcuts you need to become a better, faster, stronger designer or artist!

_Note: These shortcuts work in ALL versions of the software. So come with whatever version youâ€™ve got._

**A little background:** _I was a camp counselor back in 2012 and taught this workshop in 2014.  Here is a camper review from the 2014 workshop:_

\"5 out of 5
_Truly a great instructor!! Well organized workshop plan, and made sure to keep checking with the participants to keep the flow on track. Kept watch on the time, and adjusted accordingly when the bulk of the class wanted to focus on further tips and tricks of masking rather than make a business card.\"_

Hope to see you this year!

title: Datavisualization with D3.js
description:
__D3__ ([D3js.org](https://d3js.org)) is a super-cool data visualization library for JavaScript.  Together we will explore some of the possibilities of D3 and talk about ways to use it.

Please bring an up-to-date browser (Chrome is probably best) and your favorite data set.

You might also want to get a code editor.  You can use NotePad/TextEdit, but a more full-featured one is [Sublime](http://www.sublimetext.com/2) which is not technically free but has an unlimited evaluation period (so it is free).

title: Intro To Inflatables
description:
DIY inflatables with an intro lecture to design constraint basics, material choices, fabrication techniques, leak rates vs flow, etc. Then follow-up by experimenting at making your own heat-sealed or adhesive-sealed mylar balloons.

We can increase class size if people commit to BYOI (bring your own irons)! Flat irons for hair or regular clothing irons both work great with this material.

title: Prototyping Physical Interactions with Virtual Reality
description:
I\'ll walk you through the implementation of a physical controller for a mobile VR experience, using a wifi Arduino microcontroller, a node server, and the SocketIO plugin for Unity.  Then we\'ll build a simple Unity VR app for Google Cardboard or Gear VR, which you can control using your new controller.

To follow along, have Unity, Arduino and node.js installed, and bring a Yun or ESP8266 with a switch or sensor that you\'d like to use to interact with a VR experience.  A simple button is fine, but feel free to get creative.  

If you\'re going to build for iOS, you\'ll need to have XCode installed and your certificates set up -- I\'m not going to cover any of that in this workshop.  And keep in mind that XCode can take an hour or two to install.  If you want to build for Android, you\'ll need the Android SDK installed.

Here is a github repo with sample code, and the Readme describes the hardware and software you\'ll need to follow along.  I may still make some minor changes, but to get a head start, check it out:

[https://github.com/dagoch/vrixd_examples](https://github.com/dagoch/vrixd_examples)

title: Crit Group
description:
Come see what your fellow campers are working on and give your feedback/advice/ideas/skills!

6:30 - Nils Westerlund  
6:50 - Vanessa Dine  
7:10 - Lalo RM  
7:30 - Carrie Wang

We\'ll meet on the green next to Counselor Island.

title: Data Sonification with Max/MSP
description:
Data sonification is the audio equivalent of data visualization. In my eyes, sonification takes two forms: realtime and non-realtime. I would call realtime data sonification the transduction of a live analog or digital data stream into sound that we can hear. Conversely non-realtime data sonification would be running through a precompiled data set and following compositional rules set in advance in the sonification audio environment. 

An example of realtime data sonification would be an audio environment that was controlled by weather data streaming in to the audio software. An example of a non-realtime data sonification could be the translation of a CSV dataset on migration paths of birds to MIDI controlled audio parameters.

We will meet in the multichannel audio studio that will be set up at ITP this week. We will have 8.2 channels of audio to play with. This will very much be an investigation of space. I invite you to ask with me, \"What does sonification afford that visualization doesn\'t?\" What kinds of projects can be realized during the last bit of camp? Ideally this session will spark some group projects that can result in performances, demonstrations, or listening parties during the end of the camp show Tuesday, June 28.

I will teach introductory Max/MSP stuff but the point of this session is not to be an introduction to Max/MSP. I will send out materials beforehand and I encourage attendants to bring datasets (CSV only for now, sorry!), physical computing setups, or at least ideas that we can work on together. 

Please let me know if you have any requests before the session!

title: Exploring the future of design systems in Sketch & Framer JS
description:
Product design is well beyond the static layout. In this session we\'ll touch upon some easy gains of using code and systematic thinking in your UX design process.

Youâ€™ll learn to:
---------------
* Batch populate Sketch objects with data from the interwebs
* Make your Sketch layers move with minimum effort using Framer Studio
* Create strategies to abstract and automate animations
* Find methods to design large scale individualized systems (w. examples from [Link.NYC](https://www.link.nyc/))
* Blabber about the future of design tools

Hope to round off with a conversation about some exciting initiatives within the design / programming community and plausible futures of the design practice.

Basic familiarity with Sketch and a rudimentary understanding of programming will be useful but not necessary.

Tools:
------
* Web browser with a json data scraper. Like [Advanced Web Scraper](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/advanced-web-scraper/gpolcofcjjiooogejfbaamdgmgfehgff?hl=en-US) for Chrome.
* Sketch ([free trial](http://sketchapp.com/))
* [Sketch data populator](https://github.com/preciousforever/sketch-data-populator)
* [Re-name it](https://github.com/rodi01/RenameIt)
* Framer Studio ([free trial](http://framerjs.com/))
* iPhone: [Frameless app](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/frameless-full-screen-web/id933580264?mt=8) / Android: [Framer app](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.framerjs.android&hl=en)

Reads:
-------
Post-session reads will be emailed to all attendees.

title: Suminagashi
description:
This is open session, a repeat of previous one.
We will play with floating inks on water.

Please feel free to come over to the shop at any point either to try it yourself, or to watch.

title: Sound Poetry Composition, Part I
description:
In this 2-part session, we will create our sound and poetry compositions based off Gothic horror stories.

We will dive into sound composition with found sounds. There will also be a discussion on sound poetry in its original context (phonetic expression) and its repurposed context in the digital realm.

After that we will go on a sound walk to collect sounds for the final composition and start to experiment!

(Part 1 will briefly cover digital audio workstations (DAWs). This is not meant to be a full introduction to DAWs, but just as how we can use it as tool for composition.)

title: Sound Poetry Composition, Part II
description:
In this 2-part session, we will create our sound and poetry compositions based off Gothic horror stories.

In part 2, we will cover techniques of sound composition and design and complete our pieces. Newcomers are always welcome!

--Topics From Part 1--

Sound composition with found sounds.
Sound poetry in its original context (phonetic expression) and its repurposed context in the digital realm.
Sound walk and experimentation.

title: Electronic Greeting Cards: Paper Circuits, Wit, and Magic!
description:
I\'ll supply the paper circuit skills, You supply the wit. 

In this workshop, we\'ll make our own electronic greeting cards from scratch! 

I\'ll show you some techniques for paper circuits: working with copper tape, batteries, and LED\'s, then we\'ll craft up witty sayings and make them interactive!

Get ready to have a fun time and leave with a greeting card ready to give.

title: Engaging People ::offline::
description:
Why connecting people is a challenge in our days? How is the world of engaging people offline? What are the challenges? What are the strategies and tools?

Iâ€™ll share with you my experiences - in my short path - of engaging people in a variety of worlds: youth movement, a brazilian fashion brand, a coworking community and a network of young talents. (All in Brazil).

There are 4 pilars to this method:
::Walk The Talk
::Giving Visibility
::Empathy
::Give Back

In each of the worlds above, they show up in different ways. In this class, Iâ€™ll share real life examples and hopefully create an interesting conversation.

Like everything else at ITP this is completely informal and we can just talk about engagement and its challenges.

title: Creating an Interactive Game Box: prototyping Beat The Bomb
description:
This session is hosted by Alex Patterson and Jonny Dubowsky. 

The introduction of the session will be led by Alex, who will give an overview of his Beat The Bomb project, i.e. creating a gameshow-like team vs. team interactive game box hosted by an evil AI system, where the losing team gets blasted by a paint bomb.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LW7kERsVrEE&feature=em-upload_owner 

Alex will present an early vision of the story arc of the experience, and seek feedback, with a storyboard artist on hand to draw up and visualize the end-to-end customer experience. 

Part 2 will be led by Jonny, who will introduce intended programming framework for experiences, Including the various programming layers, the physical computer interface, hardware sensors, and a discussion of pulling the sub-games themselves from free game code directories and apiâ€™s.    

Arduino and Raspberry Pi will be used to provide the most # of accessible layers for hardware and several arrays of sensors can basically deliver the system dynamics, architecture, framework layers, and the basic flow of code and \"tubes\" of the game itself. 

These game dynamics and the overall storyboard flow which makes up The Bombâ€™s primary design will be recorded through the continuous back and forth which will take place amongst the group.

Free Open Source Software Components to download in-advance of the session:

(Itâ€™s processing.org, The processing application/IDE)

P5js
Max
OBS (if any live broadcasting, live streaming to FB, Snapchat, etc)
Arduino IDE
Raspberry Pi (which has itâ€™s own Linux OS and Javascript libraries)

The main game dynamics will ensure the maximum amount of interoperability amongst the various systems, as many systems as possible, so that games can be deeply dynamic with many layers in both the virtual and physical world.

The result should be that by the end of the session, we have a very rough prototype version of the Beat The Bomb indoor game experience (minus the paint bomb cannon, currently in a special effects warehouse in New Jersey) that can be demo\'d at ITP during the Tuesday Show \'N Tell. 

All participants will get beer (we\'ll bring a cooler) and free tickets to the first true Beat The Bomb beta-test in North Bergen New Jersey during a number of days in July.

title: Video Cueing & Mapping: Intro to Izzy
description:
Isadora is a fast and powerful graphical user interface based video cueing and programming program with widespread use in the theatre, dance, and design communities.
You can see more info here: troikatronix.com

It\'s ideal for creating easily cued and interactive scenes for theater, concerts, window displays, and art galleries, or whatever you can think up!  It is faster and easier than Max, has more features than MadMapper, and is cheaper than WatchOut, and has more effects than QLab.

In this session, we\'ll take a look at the basics of using video in Isadora, including jumping between scenes, mapping, and creating effects. We\'ll also take a look at using live feed, and using features like Syphon & MIDI. 

We\'ll download a free trial in the classroom. It may be helpful to have a couple short videos on your computer that we can use to import into the program.

title: Time Travel Agents: Interaction Design and Social Innovation Planning for the 22nd Century
description:
As we wrap up our time together, in preparation for Tuesdayâ€™s show, I will give a workshop focusing on **Generative Design** and **Social Innovation Planning** as a form of **Future Time Travel & Agency**.
Following the examples of inspiring Sci-Fi writers of the 1950â€™s, how can we envision our future with enough **â€œsocial agencyâ€** and **â€œsocial reflexivityâ€**  in the creative narratives we write and produce (and consume) today, such that we **ensure that we build a future that we actually want.*

>**â€Where are our values?â€** asks Gary Comstock, a philosopher at Ohio State University. â€œNow that atrazine has turned up in the water wells, 2-4d has been linked with non-Hodgkins lymphoma in farmers, and Alachlor, the most heavily used herbicide on corn, is suspected to be a carcinogen, why are land-grant universities doing research to find crops that can be grown in the presence of stronger doses of these chemicals?â€ 

>__If research is a form of social planning__, as Chuck Hasselbrook of the Center For Rural Affairs says, what does this say about where we want to go as a society? Instead of pledging allegiance to a method of farming that we know destroys  land and people, shouldnâ€™t we be tackling the problems of getting crops to grow the way we want them to grow? in polyculture and rotations for instance. Shouldnâ€™t we be taking natures advice and giving farmers the tools they need to farm sustainably, rather then giving chemical companies bigger needles to poison us with?â€ -From Biomimicry, Innovation Inspired By Nature by Janine M. Benyus

In this workshop we will revisit the projects we will present on Tuesday night,  through the lens of **[social innovation design](http://www.sva.edu/graduate/mfa-design-for-social-innovation)** and [generative design thinking](https://designit.com/happening/news/generative-imperative) . __Is there a minor add-on or adjustment we can make to our project which would help to ensure some type of additional future agency?__
__Can you go even further into the future and re-examine your project as an ancient artifact? What does this reveal?__

Participants are invited to bring their projects to the workshop, and everyone will have time to give a brief presentation of their project, with the additional invitation to create an on-the-spot tie-in to some type of social innovation which could naturally develop from the projectâ€™s intended purpose.

Workshop participants do not have to present their projects, but will still be able to participate in the design planning and future-mapping exercises, such as the Bucky Fuller \"**[World Game](https://bfi.org/about-fuller/big-ideas/world-game)**\"
â€œMake the world work, for 100% of humanity, in the shortest possible time, through spontaneous cooperation, without ecological offense or the disadvantage of anyone.â€

We owe a great deal of thanks to creative forward dreaming futurists such as Ray Bradbury and Issac Asimov. The work of renaissance scientist/engineer/technologists such as **Buckminster Fuller**, and **Carl Sagan** provided the framework for seemingly impossible technology to leap forward from creative ideas into actual practice, as best demonstrated by the concentrated 10 year global efforts of the aerospace industry and several international space agencies as humanity converted the ideas of paperback sci-fi novels into actual journeys beyond our atmosphere and into the cosmos.

More recent creative exploration into possible future worlds has included the vivid and expansive philosophy of **[Ray Kurzweils 6 Epochs Of Human Evolution](http://goo.gl/KJEy6X)**. We will use Kurzweils fantastic approach to creative possibility, as well as a number of other  leading futurists and technologists and their theories on where humanity is headed.
Lets get our far-fetched creative future-building muscles tuned up and ready to solve some future-world issues.

title: Synaesthesia Playground: Ins and Outs of a multimedia performance
description:
Synaesthesia Playground was a collaboration between artists, academics and software engineers around the concept of synaesthesia and multimedia, which premiered at stony brook university and then at spectrum nyc.

As a series of piano-based performances, we came together to \'augment it\' with different types of technology, from sound to light, video and audience interaction.

In this session, Takafumi and Pierre will talk about their process in developing and assisting with this performance, what was the design process, the software and hardware implementations as well as some of the stuff we learned from this experience.

Come hang out!

title: Data Analysis using Python part 2
description:
The goal of this talk is to have a followup on the first session on data analysis with Python. 

I will mostly be working with 2-3 datasets including:

311 calls in New York, 1MM MovieLens Data, others...

At least some minimal experience with programming (in any language) is recommended.

The code and slides are in my github: https://github.com/GusSand/itptalk2016
they include instructions on installing the prerequisites,

I will assume that everyone would have installed python and pandas using anaconda. See instructions at: https://www.continuum.io/downloads and https://github.com/GusSand/itptalk2016.  

Please make sure you install this so that we can cover more material !!

see you there !

Gustavo

title: Introduction to Docker
description:
[Docker](https://www.docker.com/) is a relatively new technology that become extremely popular among developers in the three years since it was introduced. It greatly simplifies the creation and management of consistent developer environments and make sure they match in production. Better yet, even if you are on a Mac or Windows, you can run Linux environments right on your laptop!

In this workshop, I\'ll give you a quick introduction to Docker and get it installed on your computer. You\'ll learn to create a very simple application and optionally push it to the Docker \"Hub\" so you can share your image and collaborate with others.

title: Parametric Design for Rhino with Grasshopper
description:
We\'ll be discussing parametric design and covering some basic workflows in Grasshopper (Rhino plugin) to aide in your design process.

If there is enough time we\'ll setup a simple Arduino and/or Leap motion example.

Please note: Grasshopper will only work with full version on mac (full or trial version on PC).  If you plan on following along in class, take a PC laptop out from the ER or borrow someone\'s mac with full version on it!

title: Inversions for inventing: headstands, handstands, and general upsidedowning
description:
Take a break from working on your project and get some extra blood to your brain! 

The class is good for all body types and fitness levels. We will work together to explore the world from a flipped perspective.

title: Make an app with HTML using PhoneGap
description:
You really want to make an app, you really do. You have attended several sessions of xCode, Swift and it just has not sunk in. Maybe the tools seem overly daunting, or you just cannot wrap your head around the coding syntax and functions of the programming languages required to simply build the interface and have it animate and do something.

You say to yourself, there must be a better way...

If any of the above pertains to you, then this is the class for you.

Using Adobe PhoneGap you can take standard HTML and easily convert it to an App that will run on your phone and put up on an app store.

This is a simple tour and demonstration of the process.


Here is a rough outline of the hour.

00:15:00 - Intro to PhoneGap

00:25:00 - Demonstration of converting HTML to app

00:10:00 - Uploading the app to device

00:05:00 - How to load it to the store

00:05:00 - Q&A


**BEFORE CLASS**

1. Install free PhoneGap desktop app @ [http://phonegap.com](http://phonegap.com)

2.  Install free PhoneGap mobile app to your device for testing

- iOS - [https://itunes.apple.com/app/id843536693](https://itunes.apple.com/app/id843536693)

- Android - [https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.adobe.phonegap.app](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.adobe.phonegap.app)

3. Create a free PhoneGap account @ [https://build.phonegap.com](https://build.phonegap.com)

title: Soft Robotics for Space Applications
description: I have a quick lecture about soft robotics, why they are awesome, and how they are being applied to problems in space exploration. Thought this presentation might be a nice 30 min break, and good intro to folks who are unfamiliar with the topic. Some of the talk will be about next generation space suits as wearable soft robots.

title: Opening Party
description:
This will include food, drink, opening announcements & orientation, and our illustrious Show One Thing Show where we all get to know a little bit more about each other.

LOCATION: 721 Broadway, 4th Floor South, New York, NY. Take the left elevators to the 4th Floor

WHAT'S HAPPENING:

6PM - Doors open. Check in. Food, drink, and mingling. 

7PM - Camp Orientation. Everything you need to know about ITP Camp.

7:30PM - Show One Thing Show!

title: Show It All Show & Closing Party
description:
This year, as part of the closing party we will be having the Show It All Show!

This is not a formal presentation or a fancy exhibition. This is an opportunity for you to share any and all projects or works in progress you've generated during your time at ITP Camp 2017. Items to put in the Show It All Show include: materials tests, sketches, rough prototypes, projects-in-process, installations, objects, software, video, sound pieces, immersive experiences, manifestos, demos, or anything else you'd like to share!

Our ideal is to have EVERYONE share something, no matter how small. If you have something you'd like to add to the Show It All Show, please sign up here:
[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VEuX30MR5leJa3KuYKhVA5lrxu-8TNt0XB0zDuaW2vY/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VEuX30MR5leJa3KuYKhVA5lrxu-8TNt0XB0zDuaW2vY/edit?usp=sharing)

A camp counselor will get in touch to help you sort out a location and other details.

If you have any questions or want to talk through ideas, just stop by Counselor HQ!

title: All Camp Social Hour
description:
Please join for our first all-Camp social hour! We will break into small groups for semi-guided, collaborative brainstorm sessions.

We will have drinks and dumplings from Vanessa's - YUM!

See you there!

[Activity Outline](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1brZUGWhyhdusN6MRFhdn8ZdZib9ezhrdV-Ed7w8zcDw/edit?usp=sharing)

title: All Camp Social Hour: Porcupine Workshop & Spiky Cocktail Hour
description:
What happens when everyone at a cocktail party is covered in spikes? 
 
You are cordially invited to participate in a micro workshop + social experiment.

Porcupine Workshop + Spiky Cocktail Hour
+ 6:00-6:30 PM: Workshop - constructing Porcupine wearables
+ 6:30-7:30 PM: Spiky Cocktail Hour -  with spiky food & spiky drinks
 
We will spend the first 30 minutes assembling Porcupine wearables - wearable, spiky body-extensions constructed of cardboard and fasteners that allow you to take up more space. They can be used to expand your footprint and sometimes your personal expression. This design TBD, but check out a previous example here:

 http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Make-a-Porcupine-Vest/
 
Materials will be provided and no previous experience is required.

The remaining time will consist of an elegant and prickly cocktail hour. Adorned in our spikes with an extended sense of embodiment we will eat, drink, and interact. 

Photos and video of the festivities will be collected and shared. Spike and/or cocktail themed attire is strongly encouraged.

Please RSVP by June 11th so we have adequate time to prepare the necessary materials!

title: All Camp Social Hour KICK DROP BALL GRAVITY DEFYING EXTRAVAGANZA
description:
SNACKS, DRINKS, PEOPLE!

Tired? Overwhelmed? Eyeballs on fire? 

Let's take a moment and set aside our projects.

That means pause your eight-hour 3D prints. Unplug your tangled arduinos,
shut down your overheating laptops and let someone else use the damn lasercutter.

Join us for the last camp social activity where we'll bring things back to the basics with tape, string, cardboard and fifth grade physics.

Let's create a moving spectacle that will connect us all forever (Youtube).

title: How to Create a ChatBot with RiveScript
description: This session is a collaboration with [TheWriter](http://www.thewriter.com/).  We'll discuss a brief history of "chatbots" (computer programs designed to have a text-based conversation with a human user) and examine the landscape of tools and frameworks for creating them. We'll then build our own chatbots using [RiveScript](https://www.rivescript.com/), a simple scripting language with a friendly, easy to learn syntax (no programming experience necessary!). After we build some simple chatbots, we'll look at how RiveScript can be integrated in a web application with JavaScript.

title: Make Everything Feel: Really Simple Touch / Proximity Sensors From Natural Objects
description:
Plug 1 wire into your arduino, clip it to something kinda conductive ( a plant, a puddle, or a bike handle). and that's all you need  for interactive projects!
.Capacitive Touch sensing is one of the simplest, and most fun ways to make almost anything in the world into a touch sensitive controller! This is how things like touch lamps work, and the basic sensing in fun kits like the Makey Makey: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfQqh7iCcOU](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfQqh7iCcOU)

However, most folks tend to start their capacitive touch sensing projects using (what I consider) outdated methods. Old-fashioned captouch tends to be noisy, needing constant recalibration, and really only works well when the electronics are grounded. It also tends to give best readings on just a binary "Touched or not" kind of basis. Most importantly old style cap-touch tends to use a minimum of 2 wires and a big resistor to make your interaction work.

Using ADC captouch, instead frees us from so many problems, and gives us the smallest amount of materials necessary to make cool interesting sensors! Places like Hackteria started looking to this method as an improvement over the Makey Makey ([http://www.hackteria.org/projects/cocomake7/](http://www.hackteria.org/projects/cocomake7/)), and we can talk about the basic theory while we make them!

WHAT WILL WE DO

First we will start off building and programming our devices. Then we will move outdoors and test out and explore the touch-sensitive properties of many items in nature and public areas nearby. Debugging with cap-touch is fun and lets you explore the material properties of whatever you connect it to. Toward the end, we will refine our projects into interesting interactive demos for public interaction.

title: [OUTDOORS] Berry Foraging in Brooklyn and discussing Urban Fruit Sensors
description:
NOTE: We will meet at pebble beach in brooklyn, right below the Manhattan Bridge!  [https://goo.gl/maps/zmMucQPmK8m](https://goo.gl/maps/zmMucQPmK8m)

There's free fruit all around our cities! I've been in NYC for 2 days and have already found massive bushes full of service berries and mulberries. I got the "fruit eyes" for seeing awesome fruit from my work with Concrete Jungle in atlanta: [https://www.concrete-jungle.org/](https://www.concrete-jungle.org/)  who pick fruit and give to homeless shelters.

They are working on cool problems with distributed sensors like making low-costs noses for smelling if fruit is ripe, or working with bend sensors on trees. I won't have any of this tech with me when we forage, but we can get some hands-on experience with the foraging, and talk about designing tech for the many interesting problems that come up!
(Their research: [https://www.concrete-jungle.org/concrete-jungles-fruit-tree-sensors-part-2-building-an-electronic-nose/](https://www.concrete-jungle.org/concrete-jungles-fruit-tree-sensors-part-2-building-an-electronic-nose/) )

I will have tarps, maybe bring a container to hold lots of berries in (think like a strawberry container!)

If we finish early (which we probably won't) there's more berries near Gowanus Whole Foods

title: Outdoor Hacking: Practice Doing Programming and Electronics Outdoors!
description:
Are you working on an electronics project? Programming project? Sick of being cooped up inside? Well come on out, rain or shine, and build in the wild with us! Ill set up a "wild lab," with modular worksurfaces, tarps, and portable workshop tools all set for you to solder, debug, program, and whatever you need. Feel free to treat it as an open lab, and stop by for a bit or longer and work on your projects, and we can talk about infrastructure that frees you from the lab!

I'll give tips on how to handle common challenges when wild-hacking! Come early and you can help set up the lab!

Update: we will work in some ant collecting and other random hacks and connection, maybe make a EMP? who knows!

title: (Talk) Hacking the Wild and Weird: Physical Computing Meets Reality TV
description:
I ended up starring in an international television show called "Hacking the Wild" release on Discovery's multiple networks. They saw me building electronics in the wild with scientists, and ended up with a quirky show where I am forced to survive by constantly pulling apart laptops.

I'll give a fun talk that pulls back the curtain and goes over the history of this weird TV show, and all the strangenesses that occur during a high-stakes, intense film production that basically relies on interaction design. I'll share clips (many never before seen) from my experience, and do a Q and A about some really strange experiences. 

This talk is a must see for anyone wanting survival tricks and tips when being kidnapped by hollywood producers to work on a survival show.

title: (Talk) Digital Naturalism: Design Framework for Working with Computers and Creatures in the Wild
description:
I'll be giving a talk about my research into "Digital Naturalism." (Introduction with examples here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Q-HbBKC2i4 )

Digital Naturalism investigates the role that Digital Media can play for Biological Field Work. It looks to uphold the naturalistic values of wilderness exploration, while investigating the new abilities offered by digital technology.

In particular, Digital Naturalism looks at how digital media can be used to explore animal behaviors situated in their natural context. Most recently, this research has been carried out directly in the field in the form of Hiking Hackathons. 

I'll share my past and recent experiences hacking in the wilderness and future plans. Then we'll have a quick question and answer session!

title: Near-Perfect Web Design Transfers Using Grids and Sass
description:
In the design-comp-to-website translation, in which a designerâ€™s comprehensive design is converted into a working website, the final result is oftentimes far from the original design. Using Sass with grids heightens the chances that the designerâ€™s intention is translated faithfully into a website.

Weâ€™ll discuss how to use [The Modular Grid](https://github.com/code-warrior/the-modular-grid), an extension in beta for Chrome, to achieve near-pixel perfect translations of design comps to web pages.

The slides and demo for todayâ€™s session are available on [GitHub](https://github.com/code-warrior/the-modular-grid-presentation).

title: Game Design Lab 101
description: What makes a game fun? Can it also be thought-provoking or educational? This workshop will involve a crash course in game design theory, a little discussion on weird games, an exercise in designing your own, non-digital games, and lots of play!

title: Show-One-Thing-Show
description:
A hybrid talent show / open-mic / show-and-tell extravaganza! Each person will have **ONE MINUTE + ONE SLIDE to present ONE THING**

For example, you might want to share:

A project you made  
A place you traveled  
A hobby you have  
A dance you know  
A song you wrote  
A thing you ate  

There are only 2 rules for the slide: it must include your NAME, and it cannot include any video content.

It will be a fun opportunity to get to know each other better, we hope everyone will sign up to share :)

title: See Yourself Sensing: Weird Human Futures, Expanded Bodies, Transformed Heads
description: Author/artist/curator Madeline Schwartzman presents an image and video-packed journey though the future of the human sensorium (near and far flung) through her books See Yourself Sensing and See Yourself X and her mad forays into the Internet

title: Data Driven Activism
description:
Considering the amount of fake news, alternative facts and lies coming out of the highest office in America, we as artists, designers, journalists and decent human beings should do all we can to make the fact-based truths speak louder than the falsehoods. To do this we look to the data. 

In this workshop we will cover how to find appropriate data using publicly available datasets, web scrapping and APIs, briefly cover data scrubbing and analysis, and focus on the best way to present and visualize the data. We will be covering the basics of JavaScript, jQuery, D3js, Python, Kimono, Open Refine, Datavisual, Excel and Sublime Text. This workshop is designed for anyone, but a basic understanding of the web and web languages would be helpful. Please make sure to bring a laptop for this workshop.

title: Drawing in the Terminal
description: Take a trip down memory lane to investigate the creative computing output of days gone by - the 1980s. In these early days, printing one character at a time on a monochrome screen was the only medium available. In this workshop we will learn how to use Python and external libraries to draw and animate graphics patterns in our computer console!

title: Build your own API
description: Everything is on the Internet, but usually not all in the same place. This workshop will be an introduction to NodeJS, a popular JavaScript environment, in order to figure out how we can grab data from a website, save it on our server, and give access to it to anyone who wants it, which will end up being our own API.

title: Lets Make an ITP Cryptocurrency
description:
What would we do with an ITP currency? Trade it for Ron Bobs? I don't know but lets brainstorm together. 

Don't know a bitcoin from a dollar bill - No Problem! We'll cover that too.  Lets put ITP on the blockchain!  

In the course of this workshop cum skill share cum facilitated discussion we will create our own open source Ethereum token for  the ITP community.  We will build the initial  the rules of the currency and discuss use cases.  Do we want to create a token that can invest in or provide access to  ITP projects? Do we want a  DAO? Do we want a token that students  and alums can use in their own projects? 

We will look at some tokens created by companies such as Consensys, and at alternative currencies online and offline.  In thinking about these topics I have been influenced by David Graeber, Silvia Federici, Bernard Lietaer, and Charles  Eisenstein - and essentially the back catalogue of Verso. 

At Print All Over Me, the company that I run, we are implementing our loyalty/royalty program with Ethereum tokens. This is something we have been investigating for 3 years and only now feel that the technology has arrived to let us do what we want. I would love to experiment with the ITP community to make a fantastic open source cryptocurrency that we all can use in new and unexpected ways.

title: Talk Bot to Me: Roadmapping your first conversational UI
description:
You want to talk to the systems. We want to provide you with a framework and best practices to develop your bot conversation before you start development. 

In this session we will workshop and provide suggested guides for character and story development and review testing methods.

##Pre-work:
Come with a chat bot idea!

title: emoji-Bot Army Training
description:
Learn to build a Twitter Bot in JavaScript, using the Twit node package and your emojis. We will learn how to make "paintings" with emoji data and share them with the world. â¤ï¸ðŸŠðŸ’›ðŸ’šðŸ’™ðŸ’œ Participants are encouraged to devise their design idea before the workshop so we have plenty of time to execute it. 

repo: https://github.com/rebleo/emojiBotArmyTraining

title: Computer-Generated Stories, Jokes, Poems and Bots: No Programming Required!
description: Mainstream attention on computer-generated text focuses on its supposed ability to supplant the professional writer. In this workshop, we'll learn the truth: computer-generated text can be useful, but it's far more interesting as a creative and poetic tool, to create and thereby investigate absurd juxtapositions, poised on the brink of the infinite void of nonsense. We'll learn a tool called Tracery (created by Kate Compton), a freely available tool that makes it easy to create expressive text generatorsâ€”with no prior knowledge of computer programming. (If you do know how to program, good news: there are open source libraries for incorporating Tracery grammars into your own programs.)

title: Don't Tweet, Toot: Understanding Mastodon and the Federated Social Network
description: Originally released in October 2016, Mastodonâ€”an implementation of GNU socialâ€”has recently attracted attention as a potential alternative for centralized social networks like Twitter and Facebook. With hundreds of thousands of new users in the past few months, Mastodon (and other software like it) has the potential to shift the landscape of online community. Mastodon is open source and federated: anyone can run their own instance. In this session, we'll talk about what "open source," "federated," and "instance" mean, and talk about why users are eager to use this software instead of its proprietary alternatives. In particular, we'll focus on the creative potential of a customizable social networking platform (e.g., oulipo.social, botsin.space) and take the first steps toward starting our very own Mastodon instance.

title: Scan-ya-Body & Bust-A-Move
description:
Learn how to create a 3d scan of your body and rig it so that it can be animated and brought into a game engine such as Unity. 

For reference check out on Instagram @itpsxsw or gabebc.com

Material covered in this session applies to content covered in Gabe BC's Intro to Virtual Reality

title: A-RRRRRR
description:
This is an introduction to how to create your first Augmented Reality project. We will go over available tools and create an AR project that detects an object or surface and displays a 3D object or image on top of it. If we have time we will work on adding videos to the textures.

Our AR development will be done using Vuforia and Unity.

title: 3D Printed Data - Make Your Own Data Sculpture in Processing
description:
Create 3D forms from raw data using Processing and turn them into tangible objects using a 3D printer. We will cover how to work with data in Processing, how to 3D model based on data, and the process of turning sketch into an actual object. At the end of the class, you will get a ready-to-3d-print model of your own data. 

We will look at the topic of 3D printing outside the confines of 3D modeling software, enabling you to work with 3D printers in new ways.

* An example set of data will be provided at the class, but feel free to bring data which is meaningful to you.
* We will code together at the workshop so you don't need to necessarily know about Processing, but general understanding in programming language would help you to enjoy the workshop.
* You will be able to use 3D printers at ITP to print your model from the class.

title: Practical resources for machine learning for artists
description:
This tutorial will introduce practical resources, applications, and code for getting started with machine learning for creative and artistic use.
