It will include an overview of the materials available with [ml4a.github.io](http://ml4a.github.io), as well as a survey of helpful classes, writings, and code made by others in the field.

Most of the session will consist of tutorials for using the [Python notebooks](https://github.com/ml4a/ml4a-guides/) and [openFrameworks applications](https://github.com/ml4a/ml4a-ofx/) bundled with ml4a, including several demonstrations of Wekinator applications. It will also cover the [web-based demos](https://ml4a.github.io/demos) of ml4a, including javascript deep learning libraries of interest to web developers. It will end with a broad (but not detailed) survey of various open-source repositories for running deep learning routines to produce images and text (and maybe sound, TBD).

The tutorial is loosely a practical follow-up on the more theoretical lecture "[From principal components to puppyslugs](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2017/session/34)" on Tuesday, but attendance to that is not required to take this session.


## Tentative list of topics to cover

#### Data science tasks
 - extracting features from images, sounds, text
 - search query by feature vectors
 - t-SNE and visualization
 - training a neural network for image classification
 - transfer learning for fine-tuning a neural net to custom image classes
 - "neural net painter"

#### Real-time (mostly using openFrameworks)
 - live image classification and object detection
 - fast image search and substitution
 - train classifier for images and sounds 
 - controlling music and visual art programs with Wekinator

#### Web-side demos
 - survey of tools used in making ml4a.github.io/demos
 - convnet.js, keras.js
 - resources for computer vision in the browser

title: A Reasonable Introduction to Natural Language Processing & the Vectorized Word
From principal components to puppyslugs: the mathematics of deep learning for art
description:
This lecture-based session is an accessible primer on the theory and mathematics of machine learning for artistic and creative purposes. If you have ever looked at neural creations like [Deepdream](https://research.googleblog.com/2015/06/inceptionism-going-deeper-into-neural.html), [DCGAN](https://github.com/Newmu/dcgan_code#arithmetic-on-faces), pix2pix [[1]](https://phillipi.github.io/pix2pix/)[[2]](https://affinelayer.com/pixsrv/index.html), or [AlphaGo](https://storage.googleapis.com/deepmind-media/alphago/AlphaGoNaturePaper.pdf), and wondered "how does that actually work?" then this lecture will put you on a path towards understanding it beyond the magic tricks and cliches.

This lecture assumes no advanced knowledge of math or computer science and will start from basics, relying on figures and visual aides to communicate difficult concepts wherever possible. Topics will begin with principal component analysis and probability/statistics, and progress towards neural networks, generative models, and adversarial training. Although this lecture cannot fully demystify what years of mathematical training bring, it will put you on a path towards a deeper understanding of the subject, and academic resources for pursuing the content more thoroughly will be provided for further exploration.

This lecture will be tightly coupled with a [follow-up tutorial/workshop on June 22](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2017/session/32) which will cover practical applications for machine learning for art, mostly using code and resources from [ml4a.github.io](http://ml4a.github.io). The two sessions are complimentary, but it is not necessary to attend both.

title: Intro to Game Development with Unity
description: Unity is becoming the go-to engine for real-time interactive applications. In order to fully grasp all that it can do, this workshop will focus on its roots as a game engine. We will look at the basics of game design principles, as well as the basics of game development principles in order to develop our own game over the course of the workshop.

title: p5js: adding advanced interaction with smartphones!
description:
# About the workshop

Take the accessibility of p5js and smash it with the versatility of smartphone sensing technology, using the cross-platform framework Apache Cordova. 

This workshop will run through the basics of getting real world data from your phone, doing something funky with it in p5, and then outputting that funkiness back into the world.

# Before you come

To get the most out of this workshop please bring:
1. A laptop
2. A smartphone + usb connector cable

Please read though the **"To Prepare In Advance"** section of the [workshop github page](https://github.com/jameshosken/itpcamp2017/tree/master/p5-on-the-phone). Some of the installations take a while and need to be done in advance.

title: Unitweet: Getting real time data into unity using nodejs
description:
Feed a twitter stream right into your Unity game! Use tweet data to generate characters, enhance your world, interact with the outside, anything!

This workshop will run through the basics of getting real time data into Unity using a nodejs server. Though the example we'll use is twitter, the concepts can be ported to any open API.

If you intend to participate in the workshop, **please install the latest Unity**. You can find it [here](https://unity3d.com/get-unity/download).

**Be aware that the download and install can take up to an hour.**

title: Storytelling is Queen
description:
A scene is the basic unit of storytelling. And for short projects, a single scene might even be the entire story, but without understanding how one is constructed, a traditional narrative will never succeed. 

Spend a fun hour learning how to construct a scene. We will talk about character motivation, build, climax and resolution. And then weâ€™ll do an exercise where you choose a fun scenario and spin a yarn with a beginning, middle and an end.

title: Designing for Health -Human Centered Design and UX
description: Human-centered design is a creative approach to problem solving that starts with the people you are designing for and ends with new solutions that are designed to fit the end userâ€™s needs.  We will introduce you to the concepts of human-centered design and how this approach can be used to create innovative, effective solutions for health.  We will cover user research, empathic design, constructing a user journey, personas and prototyping through an iterative process.  By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of human-centered design, prototyping tools, interface evaluation techniques and designing for health tech.

title: JavaScript 101 with p5.js
description: Learn the basics of programming interactivity in the browser utilizing JavaScript with p5.js (a library for creating graphic and interactive experiences).   This workshop will introduce basic programming concepts (variables, conditionals, loops) and give participants a starting point for creating in-browser applications. The focus will be on interacting with the canvas (for animation or drawing), and user interface elements such as buttons, and text input.

title: Bodies in the Browser
description:
In this hands-on workshop, participants will learn how to access to data from the Microsoft Kinect 2 Game Controller with Kinectron in a browser and share the data over the internet..
The Kinect/Kinectron has a slew of interesting capabilities that we'll try out such as:

* Skeleton tracking which allows users to do things like live puppeteer 3D avatars or interact with a webpage using their body instead of a mouse

* Depth images which allow software to determine how far a user is from the camera and can be used in combination with a regular RGB image key a user out from the background to do things like go on virtual tours.

and more!

title: Building/Remixing Server-side Applications using Glitch.com
description: Glitch bills itself as "the friendly community where you'll build the app of your dreams".  In this quick introduction to server-side programming, we'll use the Glitch platform (JavaScript and Node.js) to create basic web applications to serve web pages and interact with databases (put that user or sensor data somewhere and visualize it).  Along the way, we'll have some fun playing with cookies.

title: Intro to Virtual Reality!
description:
An intro to Virtual Reality and world building in Unity. Learn how to create an immersive environment in Unity, program a simple character and put your scene into Virtual Reality. 

Taught by Gabe BC [http://www.gabebc.com](http://www.gabebc.com)

Unity Package
[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-TvojXbnyxOYW5lUWNDYWJMUk0/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-TvojXbnyxOYW5lUWNDYWJMUk0/view?usp=sharing)

Video File
[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-TvojXbnyxOOFhuMDhsSkpaM0k/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-TvojXbnyxOOFhuMDhsSkpaM0k/view?usp=sharing)

title: Video Mapping
description: Learn how to create video mapping artworks using sculptures and projection mapping. The session will cover an overview as to what is currently being done in the world of video mapping and then include a hands on tutorial videomapping with mad mapper.

title: Weaving Conductive Fabric
description: This hands-on workshop will explore methods of weaving yarn into fabric with the goal of making handmade textiles that conduct electricity in order to further create sensors, conductive traces or grounding shields for electronics meant on soft surfaces.

title: "Noticing" Workshop
description: This workshop teaches techniques and tools for noticingâ€”seeing, hearing and comprehending something new. In a short series of exercises weâ€™ll explore the observation process in an array of domains, from cognitive psychology to ethnography and drawing to data collection, with techniques for reaching that moment we all crave: when something unexpected and terrific bursts forward into consciousness.Â Participants should leave with their eyes opened to the inspirations and complexity that surround us, plus an individual "Noticing Plan" of observation techniques for making their next project shine.

title: Another Dimension: An Intro to Photogrammetry
description: Learn about best practices and techniques for photogrammetry so that you can take every day objects, places, and people and make them 3D!

title: Body Based Sculpture Workshop: Session 1
description: This is a sculpture workshop dedicated to the creation of hand crafted forms which may be worn on the body. This is a great opportunity to prototype ideas with soft materials. Participants with combine textile and mixed media components to create fantastic wearable pieces using basic skills in small garment construction, felting techniques, simple sewing and wire armature building. We will have polymer clay, basic jewellery making supplies, and access to sewing machines, so if you have any cool ideas there is lots of wiggle room to think big and small in wearable art! We are planning to hold 2 meetings for the Body Based Sculpture Workshop. By the end of the workshop, we will have a quick photo session featuring role-play with the artwork if you so desire!

title: Body Based Sculpture Workshop: Session 2
description: This is a sculpture workshop dedicated to the creation of hand crafted forms which may be worn on the body. This is a great opportunity to prototype ideas with soft materials. Participants with combine textile and mixed media components to create fantastic wearable pieces using basic skills in small garment construction, felting techniques, simple sewing and wire armature building. We will have polymer clay, basic jewellery making supplies, and access to sewing machines, so if you have any cool ideas there is lots of wiggle room to think big and small in wearable art! No need to attend the first Body Based Sculpture Workshop for this one. By the end of the workshop, we will have a quick photo session featuring role-play with the artwork if you so desire!

title: Soft Robotics and Bioinspiration
description:
Roboticists frequently find inspiration from the incredible evolved forms of nature, and translate them into fresh thinking and solutions. This workshop invites you to explore this fast-growing domain where biology and robotics collide.

This 4hr workshop will take participants from any skill level through what it takes to be a researcher on the forefront of soft robotics. Workshop activities include:

* Learning from actual robot designers about the state of the art of soft robotics
* Building your own inflatable robotic actuators
* Mixing and matching different fields to come up with bioinspired designs
* Learning tools to go from idea to prototype to product faster than ever before

title: The Rise of Zombie Motors
description:
Motors are in tons of consumer electronics and serve a range of functions, from the vibration motors common in mobile devices, to the DC motors in RC cars and drones, to the super precise stepper motors in 3-D printers. 

In this session, we will go over various methods for controlling different motors, from the simplest button-based circuit, to more complex motor-control circuits and microcontroller based methods, you can choose the level of complexity that suits your motor-based idea. 

Bring along your old electronics and we can pull the motors out of them. For example, old Walkmen or CD players, the fans within PC computer towers, dead mechanical childrenâ€™s toys such as the dreaded Furby or even an old electric toothbrush. Also bring an Arduino or the microcontroller of your choice if possible.

Link to powerpoint from this session: https://tinyurl.com/yaq58zk8 
And my site: http://kthartic.com/
Feel free to contact me with motor related questions!

title: Video Editing: Timing, Montage and Collage
description:
Editing video documentation of your work is an art in and of itself. From the plethora of video mash-ups of news footage and current events on YouTube, to the montage-based video works of artists Christian Marclay and Natalie Bookchin, it is clear that the meaning of the video lies not just in what you film, but how you cut it together.

In this session we will go over the basics of editing for meaning in Adobe Premiere Pro. Some video clips will be provided for practice, but feel free to also bring your own, be they family home videos, your old collection of Buffy clips, or clips ripped from YouTube, this will be a fun and hands-on learning session. 

Download a free trial of Adobe Premiere Pro prior to attending. *

*(Note, other video editing software is also acceptable! Basic principals are transferable, but the layout and tool icons may be slightly different)

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1ljjUAkEZk4Iac1jlzabMH8qvfJ6XxBXZGe4DtyOZUtE/edit?usp=sharing   
Note: I'll add some screenshots from the tech demo to this presentation when I have time. Check back in  about a week! -Kat

title: Speculative Design and Science Fiction: The blurry boundaries between fact, fiction, and tech design.
description:
Speculative design is an alternative design process that has gained momentum in the last decade as a tool for approaching difficult and abstract problems pertaining to humankindâ€™s future and its relationship to technology and sustainability (Bleecker, 2009; Candy, 2010; Dunne and Raby, 2013). While design fields such as product design and industrial design tend to address immediate problems with literal, design-based solutions, speculative design looks further into the future and produces design propositions that are not beholden to literal questions of marketability or scalability, allowing for the production of imaginative, provocative and critical ideas.

This one-hour lecture will give a brief overview of contemporary speculative design, as well as the many instances of overlaps between speculative design, science fiction, and consumer tech development.

title: Design Systems: How to solve problems in complex multi-system spaces like the IOT, interactive experiences, and multi-platform apps
description:
This workshop will take you through simple methods for getting a handle on complex design challenges that step between disciplines. Building a tremendous experience on everything from IOT devices to theme park rides hinges on the ability to understand and control aspects that affect the user experience even if the problem falls outside of your own domain expertise.

In this workshop, we will practice tools and techniques for mapping, evaluating, and understand designs for complex systems. The workshop features participatory exercises, sketching lessons, and improv games.

title: EZ VR: Basics of 360Ã‚Â° Video
description: Learn the ABCs of a versatile new storytelling medium known as Cinematic VR, aka 360Â° Video.  We will explore best practices and experiment with tools that have emerged in recent months which make VR EZ to produce and distribute. Our class will culminate in a live 360Â° Video broadcast!

title: Needle Felting Workshop
description: Learn the basics of sculpting with felting wool using basic needle felting techniques. We will make super cute felted ITP camp badges and small sculptural (and possibly wearable) sculptural pieces. A great opportunity to integrate felted wool into your own design and wearable tech ideas too!

title: Launch Weekend: Intro to Physical Computing
description:
An introductory session about physical computing! Come learn about using Arduino with simple sensors, buttons, LEDs, and motors!

The format of this session will be a short lecture (30 mins) followed by a hands-on group activity / workshop (60-90 mins). 

__Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels__, _although the emphasis will be on fundamental concepts._

Once we go over the basics of working with a microcontroller, you'll have a few different circuits to build on your own and code. At the end, everyone will pair up and (hopefully) complete a giant Rube Goldberg machine, connecting all the devices sequentially! 

While some supplies will be available to use, campers are encouraged to bring their own Arduino, breadboard, USB cable, and laptop with the [Arduino IDE installed from arduino.cc](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software). If you have a sensor or actuator you want to try out, bring that along too!

Link to google drive resources - [https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B5HFDPTSNkLxZ2FRRzY2VFI0Y2c](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B5HFDPTSNkLxZ2FRRzY2VFI0Y2c)

title: Launch Weekend: Intro to 3D Modeling
description:
An introductory session about 3D modeling for design, fabrication, and VR.

We'll be working with a trial version of Rhinoceros, but many of these concepts translate into other modeling platforms, such as SketchUp, Maya, Cinema4D, Blender.

Please download a 90 day trial of Rhino here:
[http://www.rhino3d.com/download](http://www.rhino3d.com/download)

We'll go over the basics of 3D modeling, common considerations for VR and game engines, and interfacing with other applications and outputting information for Laser Cutters, Mills, and 3D printers.

If you're interested in Game Engines and VR, please download and install Unity Engine:
[https://unity3d.com/get-unity/download](https://unity3d.com/get-unity/download)

If you're interested in 3D printing on the MakerBots at ITP, please download and install Makerbot Print:
[https://www.makerbot.com/download-print/](https://www.makerbot.com/download-print/)

The format of this session will be a short lecture (30 mins) followed by a hands-on workshop (60-90 mins).

Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels, although the emphasis will be on fundamental concepts.

Please download this file:
[Into to Rhino Work File](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B0gTX-HwGr4XUmhJVkFJNGk2eGs)

Link to a previously recorded session covering many of the same tools:
[Recording of Session](https://vimeo.com/106006433)

title: Launch Weekend: Intro to Computation with p5.js
description:
Introduction to Creative Coding with p5.js

In this workshop you will learn the fundamentals of programming while creating visual compositions. In learning about variables, conditionals, and loops, you will use lines and shapes to create drawings and animations.

The format of this session will be a short lecture followed by a hands-on group activity.

Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels, although the emphasis of this workshop will be on fundamental programming concepts.

Class Notes: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NdSvzGMktnlUT7s4wA9PCWsR_BtGPx8ASBddb9mvH3k/edit?usp=sharing

title: Launch Weekend: Video & Sound
description:
An introduction to photo + video + sound for documentation

The format of this session will be a short lecture followed by a hands-on group activity.

Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels, although the emphasis of this workshop will to introduce fundamental concepts and skills including shooting with a 5D DSLR camera, recording audio with the Zoom recorder and best practices for documentation of your camp projects.

Taught by Gabe BC

title: Diagramming Through Our Uncertainty
description:
Uncertainty is one of the only certainties of working with emerging technology. Examinations of approaches to this paradox left me captivated by diagrams for pathways through innovation. These diagrams span from Russian TRIZ in the 1940s, OODA loop, joke diagrams of every known Agile cultural practice, Stanford d.school process, and iterations for simulation approaches in soft robotics development.

This talk surveys diagrams of processes across time, domains, and goals. It serves as a starting point about whether these models can inspire your own practices or, if not, maybe you'll want to roll your own.

title: Making Things Talk, new edition! More Talking! Now with JavaScript!
description: If youâ€™re interested in connecting physical devices to networks, youâ€™ll probably find Making Things Talk to be a useful book. I just finished a third edition of it, adding new programming tools like p5.js and node.js,  and updating the microcontrollers used to include Raspberry Pi, newer Arduino boards like the Arduino 101 and MKR1000, and the ESP8266 microcontroller. In this talk, Iâ€™ll give an overview of the book, and highlight sections that might be useful to campers working on connected hardware.

title: Programming Devices that Talk to the Web
description: Connecting devices to networks can be a confusing subject, because there are  many approaches. Even if youâ€™re using the Arduino IDE, learning the software can be a challenge because different developers roll their own libraries, and not always in a style thatâ€™s friendly to beginners.  In this workshop, Iâ€™ll show you how to use Arduino MKR1000 and ESP8266 simply and effectively, using libraries that were designed in the spirit of the Arduino API.

title: Really Bright Lights: DMX Lighting with node.js
description:
So maybe you've controlled some LEDs to light things up, but what about brighter lights?  

DMX-512 is an international standard for control of stage and live entertainment lighting. In this session, youâ€™ll learn to control stage lighting using node.js. After that, you can use any of the stage lights we have on the floor at ITP.

title: Home Lights: Programming Philips Hue with JavaScript
description: Philips Hue is a network-connected lighting system designed for the home. If you can program interactive elements of a web page in JavaScript, you can control the Hue. In this session youâ€™ll learn how to use p5.js and node.js to program the Philips Hue hubs that we have on the floor at ITP.

title: Artist Talk: Body Sculptures and Role-Play
description: Interdisciplinary artist Valerie Carew will present her body based, performative sculptural work. Carew will discuss body sculptures as an evocative way to extend body language and communicate ideas by using the human form as a substrate for art making. Part of her presentation will show her MFA thesis work from OCAD University, which features biomimetic role-play of species in southern Ontario farmland ecosystems.

title: Get Started With Neural Networks & Machine Learning!
description:
In this beginners workshop we will go over a variety of open-source machine learning projects, explore and discuss how we can use them for our art/design/etc. endeavours - and train a small neural network.  

To get you started quickly, we skip most of the maths & theory and dive right into this fascinating world in two parts:

### Discovery
We have a quick look at existing neural networks and machine learning implementations that can serve as *artistic tools* for  
â€¢ sound generation  
â€¢ text/handwriting generation  
â€¢ image recognition/generation  
â€¢ interaction  
and talk about *basic workflows*.

### Hands-on Fun
We then train and run *interactive sound/visual experiments* with [wekinator](http://www.wekinator.org/) open source software. 

Highly recommended as a great follow up on this topic:
[Gene Kogan's sessions later in June](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2017/session/34)


###Get Ready
Please download the [wekinator-software](http://www.wekinator.org/downloads/) and the [quick-start-pack](http://www.wekinator.org/examples/) prior to the session.

##Resources
Pretty much all info (and much more than we can cover) will stay on the [git-page](https://rollasoul.github.io/mlstarter/).

title: MEET THE ULTIMAKER 3: Ultimaker Basic Use & Safety Class
description:
Last October, Ultimaker launched the Ultimaker 3, our latest accessible, hackable professional desktop 3D printer. The Ultimaker 3 offers accurate, consistent results, and allows you to produce highly complex 3D prints with a new approach to dual extrusion with our dissolvable PVA support material.

The response among product designers, artists, makers, engineers, educators, students and industrial/manufacturing communities has been overwhelmingly positive, with machines finding homes all over the place, even in fields we never imagined.

The Ultimaker Community Team wants to introduce you to the newest member of our family, and show you how to use the Ultimaker 3. With this new 3D printer comes a lot more than what you would expect at first sight, including new features and tweaks to our Cura Software, an iOS App, and a line-up of easy to use engineering materials that can help you accomplish more with your printing.

In this session, youâ€™ll learn everything you need to print on an Ultimaker 3D printer, including:
- Calibration and operation
- Selecting materials suitable to your project
- Troubleshooting common problems
- Design suggestions to set your jobs up for success
- ITPcamp Ultimaker printer shop policies.
- How to complete training to gain permission for testing engineering materials during this camp year.
- Access to the best resources to quickly level up with intermediate and advanced usage topics

title: MEET THE ULTIMAKER 3: Ultimaker Basic Use & Safety Class
description:
Last October, Ultimaker launched the Ultimaker 3, our latest accessible, hackable professional desktop 3D printer. The Ultimaker 3 offers accurate, consistent results, and allows you to produce highly complex 3D prints with a new approach to dual extrusion with our dissolvable PVA support material.

The response among product designers, artists, makers, engineers, educators, students and industrial/manufacturing communities has been overwhelmingly positive, with machines finding homes all over the place, even in fields we never imagined.

The Ultimaker Community Team wants to introduce you to the newest member of our family, and show you how to use the Ultimaker 3. With this new 3D printer comes a lot more than what you would expect at first sight, including new features and tweaks to our Cura Software, an iOS App, and a line-up of easy to use engineering materials that can help you accomplish more with your printing.

In this session, youâ€™ll learn everything you need to print on an Ultimaker 3D printer, including:
- Calibration and operation
- Selecting materials suitable to your project
- Troubleshooting common problems
- Design suggestions to set your jobs up for success
- ITPcamp Ultimaker printer shop policies.
- How to complete training to gain permission for testing engineering materials during this camp year.
- Access to the best resources to quickly level up with intermediate and advanced usage topics

title: CURA Software - Pro Tips, Tricks, and What's Happening Under the Hood
description:
Open source Cura software [cura software](https://ultimaker.com/en/products/cura-software), actively developed by the Ultimaker software team in collaboration with the community, continues to be the widest adopted 3D printer control software across the desktop 3D printing landscape. Ultimaker uses it, top competitors to Ultimaker use it, and machine builders use it develop, tweak, and test brand new printers and other fabrication robots.

While novices love how easy Cura makes it to prepare your model for 3D printing, there is considerable power under the hood for expert users. Over 200 settings to adjust to your needs, and a newly updated structure for managing profiles for machines, toolheads, platforms, materials, and models, as well as some great new resources for developing your own Cura plugins.

In this session, we will explore basic and advance use of the software, including going under the hood to better understand how the parts of Cura fit together, and how you can draw on these resources to better understand your CuraEngine slicing options, new features related to printer/job management, and other unexpected purposes you can put to Cura. Attendees will master a handful of the most critical settings and options, and become familiar with the best resources to explore these many complex, interdependent options in greater detail for futher study.

Because Cura is open source, our community (including Ultimaker competitors!) helps to enrich it even more with each new version launched. Session will include details how you can participate in the development of this software via Github, Ultimaker Community, your own hosted profiles and solutions, creating your own plugins, and more.

title: The 3D Stuff Your Dreams Are Made Of: Engineering Grade Materials for FFF/FDM Desktop 3D Printers
description:
There are many materials you can process through a desktop 3D printer these days, and a number of 3D printer models engineered specifically to better handle a broad range of material types, properties, and temperatures ranges. Whether you are looking to 3D print a prototype, a part for fit and function testing or an end-use part, a variety of materials are available to you, especially if you are working with an open-source 3D printer.

For all of the opportunities desktop 3D printers offer artists, innovators, designers, and engineers, the ITPcamp community spends far too little time deeply exploring the nature of the eccentric polymers that are themselves â€œthe 3D stuff your dreams are made of.â€ This session draws from recent filament manufacturer insights into how thermoplastics, thermoelastomers, composite materials, etc, are produced, strategies for how to make better use of standards as well as â€œexotics,â€ and why 2017 will be the most exciting year for desktop 3D printing materials to date.

This session aims to address key topics for materials that can be applied to all FFF-style desktop 3D printers -- and help you apply this knowledge with the use of the Ultimaker desktop 3D printers and materials available for your use at ITPCamp this June.

A few of the topics we aim to cover:
- What materials work best for which application? 
- Have you ever wondered what the advantages and disadvantages are of using Nylon versus PLA?
- What can you do to prevent ABS from warping? 
- When to use PC as a print material?
- What adhesion methods work best for each material and why?
- What post processing options are available?
- How can we best leverage the range of dissolveable, breakaway, and otherwise sacrificial materials to print complex parts more easily on a dual extruder machine?

We will discuss technical specifications, tips and tricks, and the best material for a variety of applications, and also look into how to take advantage of open filament systems to print with materials such as Carbon Fiber.

title: Sonic Spectrum Lab: Interactive Visuals
description:
Learn and explore creative coding that interacts with your movements and sounds.

The course will be broken up into 3 sections: [I.] The possibilities of interactive visuals - will show a few projects that use coding to create interactive experiences. [II.] A quick intro to softwares that are great for writing code and manipulating visuals: p5.js, processing and Isadora. [III.] A class exhibition on what we all have created.

title: The Components of Interactive Application Design
description:
Have an idea for an app or product, but don't know where to start?  We will dive into the known unknowns of digital production  Databases, interfaces, APIs, front-end, back-end, design, frameworks, platforms, user experience design.... what are all these things and how do they fit together to actually make something useful and interesting?

This session is meant to teach you the parts that make up a contemporary application.  And we will review the architecture of how these parts fit together, the roles of people involved in such projects, and recommendations on future sessions to attend to learn the nuts and bolts necessary to bring your idea to fruition.

This session will be entirely lecture, conversation, and drawing on an artificial chalk board.  No coding or actual engineering will take place, so breathe easy.

A [preliminary outline of proposed discussion points](http://knowledge.kitchen/The_components_of_interactive_application_design "THIS IS GOING TO BE FANTASTIC!")

title: Laser Cut Stencils
description:
Learn how to use a laser cutter to paint anything you want with the stencil technique! From Street Art and art installations projects to customizing t-shirts and much more, laser cut stencils offer beautiful and complex designs with little effort.

30 min 
*Talk about art projects that use complicated stencils or laser cut as their main technique. Plus, other possibilities of DIY projects with stencils..
10 min - 
*How to prepare a file for the laser cutter - accepted formats, softwares that can be used (open source and adobe softwares)
*Basic explanations about the laser - materials, types of machines, different prices
60 min - 
* Each student will make an exercise of how to transform a picture into a stencil, several stencils and files examples will be presented. They will follow the transformation of a photograph into a stencil file and then do the same with a similar picture of their choice.
50 min - 
* The pieces developed by the students will be cut. They have to be small pieces from 2 to 4 min cutting time (depends on how many lasers the space offers)
* Basic explanation of how to use the laser in the process: turning on the smoke exhaust and the laser, downloading files to the laser, speed/intensity according to choosen materials, putting the material on the laser board, verifying laser calibration, origin point, cutting area box, firing the laserrrr.
* Basic explanation of how to use a spray can for a stencil and other possible painting techniques. In this moment it's necessary to go to an open space or a painting booth.

title: How to make advanced generative artworks
description:
A workshop and contemplation on how to turn your visuals from "sketches" into evolving generative pieces. Too often our visuals are one-dimensional eye-candy. We'll explore ways we can make our generative sound reactive more fluid and evolving. 

Prior knowledge of making visuals in Javascript or p5.js would be a major advantage. As would having attended my "how to make a VJ engine in Javascript" and "Javascript sound and motion reactive systems" be extremely helpful. 

Upfront, I must say I do not have the answers. I'll show how I built my VJ engine, and some of the problems and solutions, and we'll then collaboratively explore new ways to evolve our art.

title: Javascript Audio Visual Art - creating sound and motion reactive systems
description:
How to use particle systems to create audio visual graphics in the browser. 
Using pure Javascript I'll' show you how to create sound reactive and motion reactive artworks.
Previous Javascript knowledge would be an advantage. 


=====================================

Workshop Requirements:
 
1. Laptop with webcam and working microphone input
 
2. Chrome Browser
Youâ€™ll need to have the latest version of Chrome installed [https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/index.html](https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/index.html)
 
3. Development Text Editor
You need to install a text editor. I recommend Atom: [https://atom.io/](https://atom.io/) 
A good alternative to Atom is Sublime: [https://www.sublimetext.com/](https://www.sublimetext.com/)
(but really, Atom is great)
 
4. Live Server:
This is going to make your life so much easier and coding so much faster and fun. For Atom, simply go Preferences->Packages and search and install Live Server
[https://atom.io/packages/atom-live-server](https://atom.io/packages/atom-live-server)
For maximum happiness make sure your default browser is Chrome.
 
5. A basic understanding of the web and HTML:
Again, not really needed, but will go a long way in helping you get more out of the course and make better art.  
 
Hereâ€™s two helpful guides:
[http://htmldog.com/guides/html/beginner/](http://htmldog.com/guides/html/beginner/)
[https://websitesetup.org/html-beginners-guide/](https://websitesetup.org/html-beginners-guide/)
 
Also a basic primer in colours:
[http://htmlcolorcodes.com/](http://htmlcolorcodes.com/)
[http://www.computerhope.com/htmcolor.htm](http://www.computerhope.com/htmcolor.htm)

This is a very very helpful Javascript creative coding primer:
[http://www.crunchzilla.com/code-monster](http://www.crunchzilla.com/code-monster)

title: Arduino To Go: Digital and Analog Read/Write
description:
If you missed the introductory physical computing/Arduino session, or want a refresher on the basics behind digital and analog sensing this is the session for you! Jody Culkin and Eric Hagan will be conducting a short lecture and hands-on workshop to make you feel more comfortable with small scale electronics and brainstorming personal projects.

What to bring:

* Laptop (with Arduino IDE installed if possible)
* Arduino Uno
* USB cable
* Breadboard

Download Arduino IDE [here](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software). Download the IDE for Mac, Windows or Linux, don't use the online editor.

**Where to get an Arduino Uno, a breadboard and a USB A-B cable?**

**Online vendors:**

[Adafruit](https://www.adafruit.com/) is in Brooklyn, short turn-around time for shipping

[Sparkfun](https://www.sparkfun.com/) Electronics

[Maker Shed](http://www.makershed.com/) online store

[Arduino site](https://store.arduino.cc/usa/) You can buy an Uno directly from the Arduino site.

**Local stores:**

[Tinkersphere](http://tinkersphere.com/) is located at 304 East 5th Street, within walking distance. They have a pretty extensive stock available at the store. 

[Microcenter](http://www.microcenter.com/) is located in Sunset Park, and has a number of components (including inexpensive off-brand Arduino Unos).

Other parts will be available to borrow for the purpose of the session. 

We will be referencing both our in-process book project [Arduino To Go](http://arduinotogo.com/), as well as Jody's [breadboard](http://www.jodyculkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/breadboard.pdf) and [Arduino](http://www.jodyculkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/arduino-comic-2014.pdf) comics.

Another very useful link: [Arduino Software Reference](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Reference/HomePage)

And a [link to the slides for the session:](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1H95A3H-kOsxA-KVq6ZEYAB4EOkkDTPat4B7bqRAIVcU/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Arduino to Go: Servo Motors and Project development
description:
This is a follow up to the first Arduino To Go Session, but you did not need to attend the first session to come to this one. 

We will cover the basics of using servo motors with the Arduino, including how to synchronize servo motion utilizing more advanced Arduino programming (custom functions and mapped sensor values). We will also use this session to build motion-based small scale kinetic projects and help with developing the projects you want to build during camp. If you have a servo motor bring it, but we will have some motors to borrow. We will provide a variety of materials to help make your session projects happen. 

We will also spend the latter part of this session discussing techniques for project management. How can you breakdown your physical computing ideas into manageable parts in order to tackle more complicated projects?

What to bring: Laptop (with Arduino IDE installed if possible), Arduino Uno, USB cord, Breadboard. We will have some Arduino Unos, cables and breadboards to loan for the session.

Other parts will be available to borrow for the purpose of the session.

We will be referencing our in process book project [Arduino To Go](http://arduinotogo.com/), as well as Jody's breadboard and Arduino comics.

**Where to get get parts?**

**Online vendors:**

[Adafruit](https://www.adafruit.com/) is in Brooklyn, short turn-around time for shipping

[Sparkfun](https://www.sparkfun.com/) Electronics

[Maker Shed](http://www.makershed.com/) online store

[Arduino site](https://store.arduino.cc/usa/) You can buy an Uno directly from the Arduino site.

[Servo City](https://www.servocity.com/)

**Local stores:**

[Tinkersphere](http://tinkersphere.com/) is located at 304 East 5th Street, within walking distance. They have a pretty extensive stock available at the store. 

[Microcenter](http://www.microcenter.com/) is located in Sunset Park, and has a number of components (including inexpensive off-brand Arduino Unos).

We will be referencing both our in-process book project [Arduino To Go](http://arduinotogo.com/), as well as Jody's [breadboard](http://www.jodyculkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/breadboard.pdf) and [Arduino](http://www.jodyculkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/arduino-comic-2014.pdf) comics.

Another very useful link: [Arduino Software Reference](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Reference/HomePage)

[Slides for this session are available here](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/10X1aYDxYkh7XWqD45gYwRaD3Oq8m2-rK0uw1nQk-CSU/edit?usp=sharing) There are a few more resources listed on the slides.

title: Intro to Programming Languages 101, for Future Presidents
description:
Working links:

- www.repl.it
- https://hackmd.io/JwFgHGwKYgRgtAJgGwEZj3AY1fWWAGDEZMVc1EAVkVlSA===
- github.com/epylinkn/itp-programming-languages

aka the "Language" in "Programming Languages"

The goal: Get better at the one programming language you care about most (and this might be different for everyone). Similar to how studying a foreign language in high school gave you a different context with which to evaluate your native tongue, we'll aim to expose you to other programming languages with the hopes that you'll understand all of them better.

In other words, learn to be more effective in **ANY** programming language! Together we'll compare language concepts between two or three different programming languages. In doing so, we'll learn about what composes a programming language. We'll touch upon:

0. History
1. Syntax
2. Semantics
3. Idioms
4. Libraries
5. Tools
6. Community

Regardless of what language you're looking to master, this session aims to take a step back to see how other languages work. We'll primarily dive into a language you're likely not familiar with: Ruby! For the most part, we'll compare with Javascript, but I promise to also sprinkle in some examples from other languages along the way.

It's a short session, so we'll keep the examples simple with the option to dive into more complexity at the end depending on interest.

Prerequisites:

- Aimed at the intermediate-level programmer with some experience in one or two programming languages
- But also valuable to any novice with some programming experience and an interest for more!

Tools:

- Laptop
- We'll use a few different tools to test our code in: terminal and a couple browser interpreters. Everything is built in so you won't need extra software.

title: Saturday Sessions: playing with touchscreens
description:
Saturday Sessions are a chance for campers to not only learn but to apply their skills and make something, with opportunities to work individually or collaboratively. Think of them like hackathons but a lot more chill. There will be an introduction to the tools and concepts for those unfamiliar at the beginning of the sessions, and counselors to assist everyone throughout. 

For the first session we will look at p5.js and its capabilities with touch screens. You can make a drawing app, a game, procedural art that responds to a touch input, whatever comes to your mind. Projects have the opportunity to be featured on the screens in the hallway which take up to 8 touch inputs.

title: Hands-on Genome Editing with CRISPR
description: CRISPR has been described as a word processor for genomes. Learn how it works, and try it yourself in a fun hands-on lab where you'll use CRISPR to delete a gene in bakers's yeast, resulting in a pink color. How far has this technology gone, and what are its implications for human identity and the planet? What are the ramifications of plug-and-play genome editing? We will speculate even as we become part of the do-it-yourself biology revolution.

title: Painting with Fluorescent Bacteria - Group 2
description: Have you ever made art with living pigments? Discover how to partner with micro organisms to create pieces that are alive. In this workshop we will create collaborative works using non-harmful bacteria that produce colored and vivid fluorescent pigments. You will learn how to culture the organisms and also how to display the works, including the UV lights needed to properly visualize the fluorescence.

title: HCI or HHI in Live Events and Public Spaces
description:
Share various artists' public installation or artistic designs that encourage Human to Human interaction (HHI) in public events or spaces via technologies, thinking about how HCI or tech influence people's impression and actions at different events or spaces. 

Edited)
We are going to go through the interactive public installation examples and what devices or languages were used in those. Then, we will try out basic examples of LEAP motion hand motion controller, Kinect 2 - which would help you to develop the ideas about human interactions.

If you want to use LEAP, download LEAP SDK ( [Windows](https://developer.leapmotion.com/get-started), [Mac](https://developer.leapmotion.com/sdk/v2) ) and [Unity gaming engine](https://store.unity.com/products/unity-personal). Also, download this [github repo](https://github.com/leapmotion/LeapMotionCoreAssets) which has good LEAP motion X Unity examples you can play around with. 

For Kinect 2, download [Processing](https://processing.org/download/) (not P5). Windows people might want to download this [Kinect2 SDK](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=44561) as well..

title: Roll Your Own MFA
description:
In this session we will discuss pursuing education in the arts & technology space through workshops, small programs, tiny schools, summer camps, conferences, incubators, and other part time & short-term opportunities.

For many people professional degrees are out of reach for time, financial, or other practical/personal reasons. However there are many different ways to pursue learning in the arts & technology space outside of degree programs.

In this session I will give a short introduction to the idea of Ã  la carte education and building a school for yourself. I will talk a bit about my own attempts at achieving a self-education comparable to an MFA including some tips & tricks.

Later in the session we will build a course catalog together for a virtual school starting from a base list of educational opportunities and experiences. Participants can add other programs, opportunities, books, movies, and ideas to the list. We will then discuss some of these options and consider how you can put pieces from the catalog together to make your own educational program.

This session is for people who are interested in pursuing further education at the intersection of the arts & technology. Many of the lessons are generally applicable to other areas of self-teaching. 

Class Materials: 
[http://bit.ly/unschoolcatalog](http://bit.ly/unschoolcatalog)

title: Roll Your Own Studio
description:
New York is home to some of the best known and most acclaimed creative technology studios at all scales. From smaller studios like Fake Love, Office for Creative Research, and Data & Society to larger brand-name conglomerates - you can find pretty much everything here.

At some point most of these studios were just a couple of people and a contract trying to get started. How did they go from that to world recognition?

In this workshop we will discuss the process of starting your own studio. We will start by discussing the practicalities of independent practice (one-person studio) and tiny studios (a few people). From there we will explore how these businesses can grow and change over time.

Through the discussion we will explore career opportunities in the creative technology space in studios of all scales. Starting your own studio is extremely challenging and for most people the best option is to join an existing studio.

This session is for anyone who has any interest in working independently, starting their own studio or business, or joining an existing studio in the creative technology space. Many of the lessons are more generally applicable outside of creative technology.

title: Coloring with Basquiat (Field Trip)
description:
Field Trip - Off Campus - Weather Permitting

Visit the grave of Jean-Michel Basquiat, hang out, and color with crayons. Located in the historic and expansive [Green-Wood Cemetery](http://www.green-wood.com) in Brooklyn, Basquiat's grave is a mecca for artists who appreciate his work and story. Actually I have no idea who or how many people go there, but this is the third year I've organized this and it is consistently inspiring and enjoyable.'

**DIRECTIONS**

Thank you for signing up to participate in the Coloring with Basquiat field trip. This field trip is weather dependent. Bring your crayons.

(1) Check your e-mail before heading out to make sure I haven't announced any changes.

(2) The meeting point is Basquiat's grave in the historic Green-Wood cemetery in Brooklyn. I will arrive there on Saturday around 1PM and will stay until around 2:30PM. You are welcome to arrive any time, but I encourage you to arrive earlier than later.

(3) There are several entrances to Green-Wood and depending on which entrance you take the route to get to the grave is different. I recommend taking the F or G to Church Avenue Station. From there it is a short walk to the Eastern Entrance off Ft. Hamilton. The following directions are from that entrance.

Enter the grounds on Ft. Hamilton Parkway near McDonald Ave. Make a left when you enter the cemetery (the road is called Border Avenue) and take it to â€œGrape Avenue.â€  When you reach the intersection of â€œFir Avenue,â€ start cutting through diagonally until you reach a row of small headstones.  

The full map is available here (ask for one at the entrance):

**[Map of Green-Wood](http://www.green-wood.com/html/wp-content/uploads/apdf/green_wood_map.pdf)**

If you get lost you can call me here: +1 (206) 683-4962

(4) I recommend watching at least one of the following two films in advance. 

The Radiant Child - A comprehensive documentary on Basquiat's life. This will probably leave you a little down, but it contains critical lessons about the art world especially in regard to race.

[Watch The Radiant Child](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jvrwT3Nrb3s)

Downtown 81 - If Radiant Child got you down, this will lift you up. Imagine you're making a film about the art scene in New York in the early 80s and then you find this kid Jean-Michel who is just getting started to be the lead actor. Only you don't finish the film till after he is gone and famous, and you lost much of the sound along the way.

[Watch Downtown 81](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/6862661/Downtown%2081.m4v?dl=1)

See you out there,

-josh

title: This is Your Brain on AI
description:
This is an experimental session for exploring the existential implications of Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning. The goal of the session is to explore how study and use of AI may influence human thought processes.

This session is for people into AI, neurology, psychology, brain science, and psychedelics. It helps to have an appreciation for the writings of Robert Anton Wilson, Timothy Leary, and Aldous Huxley.

**Talk - 30 Minutes** - The session will start with a short talk on the current state of AI and its implications for the future. I will then share stories from artists & scientists working with AI on the changes they have observed in their thinking that seem related to their study. Finally I will wrap up the stories with some wild speculation to set the stage for open discussion.

**Discussion - 60 Minutes** - After the talk we will open the floor for participants to share their AI related stories. We will discuss and explore the rationality and implication of the stories and see what conclusions if any we can collectively reach.

**Background**

A little over a year ago I began to come up to speed with the latest in AI. Having taken workshops at SFPC and ITP Camp on the subject I began studying the technology and experimenting with all sorts of applications. My ITP Camp project last year was a series of interactive paintings made using AI.

After several months of intense study I began noticing changes in certain aspects of my own thinking. It seemed as if what I had learned from studying AI was influencing how my own mind functioned.

A year later, AI has become a central topic of global discussion as it transforms the landscapes of countless businesses. 

A year later, I continue to observe significant changes in my thinking as I study the technology, and I'm increasingly hearing similar stories from other people.

In general I prefer to spend a significant amount of time synthesizing ideas around a subject before giving a talk on it. However this is an area moving so quickly that it feels necessary to begin discussion sooner than later.

title: Revealing Migraine through Art & Science
description:
**In this session we will explore the relationship between Art & Science through the lens of Migraine.** The session is extremely relevant for anyone who suffers from Migraine, but the lessons are applicable to any discipline.

Migraine is degenerative neurological condition experienced by 18% of women and 6% of men on average. While commonly discussed as a headache, Migraine is actually a very complex condition that can disrupt the brain and body in countless ways.

The past 10 years has been amazing for research on Migraine. Scientists have a comprehensive understanding of the condition and new treatments are actively in development that could significantly improve the situation for many sufferers.

That said what the scientists have found could have been discovered sooner had they considered the work of artists suffering from the condition. Artworks depicting the condition going back over a hundred years contained much of what was needed to reach the answers we have today. Yet artwork was dismissed as an input to the scientific process due to its subjective nature. 

Migraine is a perfect example of where the failure of Art & Science to collaborate for cultural reasons resulted directly in human suffering. My hope is that in the future it can also be an example of where Art & Science work together to quickly aid the hundreds of millions of people suffering world wide from this condition.

60 minute talk followed by 30 minutes of discussion.

title: Math in Code 4 Noobs
description: Learn how to use basic trigonometry to make your p5 sketch awesome! In this workshop, we're going to explain the basic theory behind trig functions (sine, cosine and tangent) and harness their powers in code. The first half of the workshop will be a trig review, and the second half will walk you through a few examples that use trig in p5.js. The point of this workshop is to help you understand what's actually going on when trig functions are used in code, and help you feel confident enough to use them yourself! This session assumes no prior knowledge of javascript or trigonometry.

title: Shader Shakedown: Embracing the Modern Computer Graphics Pipeline
description:
Shaders offer a gateway to harnessing the massive computational power of the GPU. This power brings the possibility for transforming your programmed graphics without hindering the performance. In this session we will walk through the modern graphics pipeline and look at the different applications that shaders can be used for. We will talk through the jargon and look at the boiler plate associated with using shaders in in Processing using GLSL. 

Participants can expect to leave with enough  overview of the modern graphics pipeline and shaders to be able to dive deeper and learn more about this fascinating subject. This workshop also aims to be practical and I hope that everyone will walk out feeling like they have another new tool in their toolkit and can begin learning how to better use it.

title: Creative Coding in pure javascript
description:
Learn to create generative and sound reactive art in pure Javascript. 

We'll look at using canvas to create audio visual art. I'll show you my process, and then we'll get down to building our own particle system.

Some knowledge in JS and HTML would be a serious advantage.

=====================================

Creative Coding Workshop Requirements:
 
1. Laptop
 
2. Chrome Browser
Youâ€™ll need to have the latest version of Chrome installed [https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/index.html](https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/index.html)
 
3. Development Text Editor
You need to install a text editor. I recommend Atom: [https://atom.io/](https://atom.io/) 
A good alternative to Atom is Sublime: [https://www.sublimetext.com/](https://www.sublimetext.com/)
(but really, Atom is great)
 
4. Live Server:
This is going to make your life so much easier and coding so much faster and fun. For Atom, simply go Preferences->Packages and search and install Live Server
[https://atom.io/packages/atom-live-server](https://atom.io/packages/atom-live-server)
For maximum happiness make sure your default browser is Chrome.
 
5. A basic understanding of the web and HTML:
Again, not really needed, but will go a long way in helping you get more out of the course and make better art.  
 
Hereâ€™s two helpful guides:
[http://htmldog.com/guides/html/beginner/](http://htmldog.com/guides/html/beginner/)
[https://websitesetup.org/html-beginners-guide/](https://websitesetup.org/html-beginners-guide/)
 
Also a basic primer in colours:
[http://htmlcolorcodes.com/](http://htmlcolorcodes.com/)
[http://www.computerhope.com/htmcolor.htm](http://www.computerhope.com/htmcolor.htm)

This is a very very helpful Javascript creative coding primer:
[http://www.crunchzilla.com/code-monster](http://www.crunchzilla.com/code-monster)

title: Intro to User Experience Design
description:
This workshop will serve as a basic introduction and overview of the broad field and problem-solving framework of user experience design.

Campers will learn elements of a UX design toolkit, tactics, and activities to better understand people, their needs, and their contexts with the goal of improving or developing new products and services.

We'll be doing some rapid, collaborative design exercises and you'll be introduced to: user research, persona development, user journey mapping, information architecture, pen and paper wireframing, and creating clickable prototypes.

title: Hacking The Browser: Chrome Extensions Workshop
description: Hands-on workshop focused around developing Chrome extensions. You'll learn the basic structure of Chrome extensions, build one or two in-class, and leave with a taste of the more exotic extension capabilities as well as a healthy respect for (and possibly a fear of) the manifold security concerns that extensions represent.

title: Walking tour over Brooklyn Bridge and through the DUMBO neighborhood of Brooklyn.
description: We will walk over the Brooklyn Bridge to the historic section of DUMBO (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass). Visit  3 contemporary art spaces, tour the area and see unusual historic and industrial architecture. We will also walk through the new and vast Brooklyn Bridge Park. Will end at a local bar and/or restaurant. Dinner with the group possible. Group will decide if they want to walk from NYU to the bridge thru Soho/Chinatown, or take subway to Bridge entrance.

title: Intro to Unity 3D : beyond Game Design
description:
Unity 3D is a game design engine that is used for a wide array of things beyond games (web,  Mobile and VR). It's a great way to think of storytelling and information design and also a great interface to learn how to code (C# & Javascript) 

I plan on doing few Unity 3D Sessions
This will cover the basics of Unity 3D what it does, where to start and how to proceed developing larger projects

title: From Web to World: 3D Printing Web Generated Forms
description:
Complex forms could emerge from simple mathematical rules. In this class, Iâ€™ll walk you through the logic of seashell growth and how to generate your own 3D model with javascript. 

You will receive an airplant, and spend part of the class designing a shell for it ([http://www.instructables.com/id/Generating-Airshells-on-a-Web-Browser/](http://www.instructables.com/id/Generating-Airshells-on-a-Web-Browser/)
). Print the â€˜airshellsâ€™ after class and bring them in for the final show. 
 
Link the the deck
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1ehuoZ4bs9R-2a5H4iMRv2h11tr58dnvyzlRyONwnuqQ/edit#slide=id.g22d49cb0ad_0_57

title: Git it Together Parts 1 and 2
description:
So maybe you've never heard of Git, maybe you've heard about Git and want to know more, or maybe you've heard about it a lot and you've even fibbed a little about knowing what it is and now you live a life of lies. Fear no more! Kat will go over Git from the very beginning. 

Don't have a Git account? Don't know how to use the terminal? Do you think ssh stands for simply sitting at home? No problem! We'll go over everything you've wanted to know and then some. 

At the end of the class you will:

Have a project in Github
Alter that project in Github
Alter your friend's project in Github
Know how to deal with merge errors
Create branches
And so much more!!

**It is HIGHLY recommend that you install git BEFORE the workshop. Go here: http://git-scm.com/download/mac.**

title: Machines Learning Movements
description:
What do machine learning, visual art, and motion capture have in common?

Come find out at this workshop! We will first write some code to record skeleton movement with a Kinect or perceptron neuron suit. Then we will record multiple people doing the same gestures. We will then use a python machine learning library to "learn" these gestures, and finally write simple sketches that are triggered by the gestures we taught to the machine.

title: Screen Printing for Curious Makers and Visual Adventurers
description:
Silkscreen printing is arguably the most versatile print medium in the world, with a huge range of applications from fine art to fashion to technology, and countless combinations of all three. It's simple to learn, and allows the practitioner to transfer nearly any substance to any surface in any design. 

This workshop will teach campers how to go from a physical or digital image to a usable screen to a finished print, using a setup and materials that can be purchased for less than 100.00 and employed in even the most cramped apartment.

And we'll make a t-shirt and/or poster for ITP Camp, incorporating images from all participants, so bring a picture you'd like to contribute.

If you want a shirt (and really, why wouldn't you?), copy this address into your browser:

[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1BtOAjMyjWAeZDqLEW1z-61uKV_cDPw3C2GDXM09v3ck/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1BtOAjMyjWAeZDqLEW1z-61uKV_cDPw3C2GDXM09v3ck/edit?usp=sharing)

go there and add your name and your t-shirt size.

title: Autonomous Vehicles... (0_o)/...LOOK OUT!
description: Don't look now, but autonomous vehicles ("AV's", a.k.a, "driverless cars") and drones are on the road and in the sky delivering gluten-free catering to various VC meetings in Mountain View, and death from above in various locations globally. So, what will happen to our fair New York City? Who needs AV's? What will happen to drunk drivers? Parking lots? Vehicle ownership? Transportation for the sightless? Will I finally get my flying car? Join Towhee Co & JC Fab Lab founder Eric Nadler for a hand's on session of building simple scale-model autonomous vehicles using the Towhee Co. Model A car and some off-the shelf control components from Sam Labs. We'll then spend some time looking at what's on the horizon at the mainstream car manufacturers and at the businesses who are currently thinking about how to create the future with this fear-inducing technology.

title: Joy of Laser Cutting Guided Workshop
description:
The Joy of Laser Cutting workshop will introduce you to the basics of working with laser cutters by walking you through the development of 5 beginner recipes. Through the design and assembly of biscuits, wafers, cookies and crackers, participants will develop a rounded understanding of the techniques that are possible in working with a laser cutter and will have the opportunity to design their own wood or plastic baked goods.

Ideally, participants are artists or creative makers who have not previously worked with laser cutters but are interested in learning. Participants should have some familiarity of Adobe Illustrator and general comfort working with computers. 

This workshop is part of the research work for Alda EscareÃ±oâ€™s masterâ€™s thesis. Participants will be asked to fill out a short questionnaire after the workshop, and will additionally also receive a couple of questions through email a month after the fact. Participation in the research component of the workshop is voluntary. Participants that RSVP for this session will receive an email with additional information.

Due to equipment and material constraints this session will beÂ limitedÂ to 5 people. Please only RSVP to this session if you are definitely able to attend and stay for the entire 3.5 hour session. If anyone RSVP-ed is not present by 5 minutes before the start time, their spot will be given to the next person on the waitlist who is physically present.

We are asking that participants bring their own laptops with a copy of Adobe Illustrator. Please inform the session leader if you do not have access to either.

We are asking that participants bring their own laptops with a copy of Adobe Illustrator. Please inform the session leader if you do not have access to either.

title: Joy of Laser Cutting Self-Guided Workshop
description:
The Joy of Laser Cutting self-guided workshop will introduce you to an online tool that covers the basics of how a laser cutter works, what techniques it is capable of, how you can set up files and how you can combine techniques to create finished projects. A facilitator will be on hand to assist you and to help run files on the laser cutter. 

Through the design and assembly of biscuits and crackers, participants will develop a rounded understanding of some of the techniques that are possible in working with a laser cutter and will have the opportunity to design their own wood or plastic baked goods.

Ideally, participants are artists or creative makers who have not previously worked with laser cutters but are interested in learning. Participants should have some familiarity of Adobe Illustrator and general comfort working with computers. 

This workshop is part of the research work for Alda EscareÃ±oâ€™s masterâ€™s thesis. Participants will be asked to fill out a short questionnaire after the workshop, and will additionally also receive a couple of questions through email a month after the fact. Participation in the research component of the workshop is voluntary. Participants will receive additional information through email once they RSVP.

Due to equipment and material constraints this session will beÂ limitedÂ to 5 people. Please only RSVP to this session if you are definitely able to attend and stay for the entire 2 hour session. If anyone RSVP-ed is not present by 5 minutes before the start time, their spot will be given to the next person on the waitlist who is physically present.

We are asking that participants bring their own laptops with a copy of Adobe Illustrator. Please inform the session leader if you do not have access to either.
