If anyone RSVP-ed is not present by 5 minutes before the start time, their spot will be given to the next person on the waitlist who is physically present.

We are asking that participants bring their own laptops with a copy of Adobe Illustrator. Please inform the session leader if you do not have access to either.

title: How will the content creation generation connect with the virtual world?
description: Exciting technologies such as digital fabrication, virtual/augmented/mixed reality, and 3D scanning and 360 video are becoming more affordable and accessible than ever. This presentation will discuss various examples of educational programming developed around these technologies, demo a 360 video from an anti-trafficking organization in Thailand, explore the symbiotic relationship of 3D printing and virtual technologies and discuss the implications of content creation on the future of VR. Attendees will also have the opportunity to be 3D scanned and receive a free file of the scan following the presentation.

title: How to make your own original content using 360 video to educate and entertain
description:
Join me (and mango and sticky rice) for a a discussion of:

* spatial sound in 360 and why it matters to a user's experience
* a "hands on" demoing the three 360 cameras and equipment I've used 
* tips and tricks about using the different cameras for various purposes
* some original footage from Thailand that I shot last year, which is both educational (about human trafficking) and entertaining (some fun short clips of traveling there.)
* the process of establishing shot lists, scripting the story you want to tell/the experience you want the user to have
* the equipment needed for a successful shoot, and the costs, work arounds, etc. 
information about how to avoid common mistakes in shooting to make your editing process easier
* how to edit your footage (on some phones, with some computer software, etc)
* compatible headsets
* Q&A 

Basically, I'll be teaching what I've learned over the past year using the Gear 360 camera when it was only available from Korea, and the instructions were in Korean. Haha! I learned what I know by jumping in and using the cameras, and creating new content from scratch while working in Thailand. I promise it will be fun and you will learn something, and will definitely want to travel to/or go back to Thailand! It's such a wonderful country and was the perfect first place to shoot!

title: Leave your computer at home. Come to Governors Island! Pet goats, feed chickens and volunteer at Earth Matter's Compost Learning Center!
description:
Get outside! See where your food waste goes! Come to Earth Matter (www.earthmatter.org) on Governors Island and help around the compost learning center! Then you can play with the baby goats and chickens that live there (their poop is key to making amazing compost). 

You would arrive on the 9 am ferry and return to Manhattan on the 1:00 pm ferry.

RSVP mandatory since I need to give names to the ferry. We will be going over there before the general public. If you do not plan on coming PLEASE UN-RSVP! Thank you. It will be fun!

Governors Island is a 172 acre island in the heart of New York Harbor. Itâ€™s only 800 yards from Lower Manhattan, and even closer to Brooklyn. It is a world unto itself, From 1783 to 1966, the island was a United States Army post, and from 1966 to 1996 the island served as a major United States Coast Guard installation. Now, it's a huge park where you can climb the Hills (hill-y landscapes offering unreal 360-degree views of New York Harbor), chill in hammocks, walk. bike (the island is car-free), see art or attend one of the many cool events that happen there.

title: Mappathon: Origami Projection Mapping
description:
Mappathonâ„¢ is inspired by events called hackathons where computer programmers, graphic designers, interface designers and project managers collaborate intensively on software projects in limited time. 

This 3 hours session goes over the latest projection mapping technology and techniques to students, enabling them to create a site-specific interactive or static projection mapping installation. 

The course has three learning stages: Making animation from static images and mixing video contents, How to create a projection mapping on 3-dimensional Origami pyramid surfaces, and making an installation. 

During all stages, there is a strong emphasis on experiential learning, presentation and sharing, and teamwork. The students will experience the process of an art installation from concept to public presentation, enhancing the studentsâ€™ artistic development a great deal.

When you sign up this session, the students get 30-day full access to Modul8, MadMapper, and Vezer.

modul8.ch

madmapper.com

http://imimot.com/vezer/

Go to previous Mappathonâ„¢ photos here, www.mappathon.com

title: ITPower & Enertive API: Visualizing Real-time Energy Usage on ITP Floor
description:
[ITPower](https://itp.nyu.edu/classes/itpower) is an research group that aims to make the ITP community aware of, and reflect on the energy usage on the ITP floor. In this workshop, we are going to build a simple web application that can visualize the real-time power usage on the ITP floor!

We will use [node.js](https://nodejs.org/en), [express.js](https://expressjs.com), [p5.js](https://p5js.org) and [Enertive API](http://www.enertiv.com) to build the application. So if you would like to know more about how to build a web server, or how to use an API, this workshop is perfect for you. We will explain the basics from the beginning! Check this [repository](https://github.com/ITPNYU/ITPower/tree/master/simpleEnertiv) to know more about this workshop.

title: Document Your Project: How to Shoot and Edit Video for Your Art Project
description:
A workshop discussing how to document your coding/hacking/art project using documentary filmmaking techniques. For instance, you may want to document your project for explanatory, archival, or fundraising purposes.

Topics include how to plan and film broadcast-quality video interviews, ways to cover an event or performance, working with the equipment that you've got, and utilizing social media to build support and interest in a project, with a focus on Twitter and Snapchat.

I'll propose some best practices as far as workflow as well.

Examples of well-documented coding, hacking, and other art projects will be shown and there will be some hands on bits as well.

title: 3D Scan and Print Yourself(And Others!)
description:
In this session, we'll learn how to use Skanect, a free 3D-scanning software, to scan ourselves, and then process the mesh through Rhino so that we can make a 3D print.

A ridiculously simple process, and lots of fun!

title: Wearable Design and Prototyping
description: Want to create some wearable projects? Come to the workshop to learn basic wearable design concepts and prototyping methods. This workshop will cover: an introduction to wearable design, basic electronic knowledge for soft circuitry, wearable lo-fi-prototyping and physical computing prototyping methods, and some case studies. Feel free to bring any wearable ideas, WIP wearable projects, and circuits that you want to turn into wearable ones to this workshop to discuss.

title: Getting Started With Soft Circuitry
description: This is an introductory workshop for students to learn the basics of soft circuitry. In this workshop, students will learn electronic basics and soft circuitry basics. Students will get a hands-on experience of building LED circuits, DIY sensors, and sewing with conductive materials.

title: Arduino x Web
description:
This is a hands-on workshop to get started with Web Bluetooth LE. The in-class example will use the onboard accelerometer on Arduino 101 to control a p5.js web app wirelessly.

Please bring an Arduino 101 to this workshop. You could check it out from pcomp closet in the shop.

Link to the slides [here](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1PH2ZsQd4jHbGtYmh1h5KBbh1m-G_GWLSwNvu0cFHyO8/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Create 360 Videos in Processing!
description:
Learn how to create 360 Videos and pictures using the popular Processing animation library!

I am the author of Camera3D, a Processing library that extends the functionality of Processing to create all kinds of 3D effects. One of them is for "equirectangular projections" for the creation of 360 video. I will walk you through all of the steps needed to change an ordinary Processing sketch to a 360 Video. Works with Facebook, Youtube, Vimeo, and more!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tZLm1290W5U

title: Orientation
description: Learn how Camp works, updates about what's new this year, and all the secrets for to make the most of it.

title: How can we make AI an integral part of the creative process?
description:
This hands-on collaborative workshop will explore how to make AI part of your creative process without being an expert in coding or data science. We will start by breaking down the most common myths and misconceptions about AI, followed by test-driving a new ideation process to help you create radically innovative products and customer experiences powered by AI and data.

Co-taught by Marc Blanchard, Global Head of Experience Design at Havas, and Marc Maleh, Global Director of Havas Cognitive (ITP Grad from 2005).

title: The Conservation of Software-based Art
description:
THE CONSERVATION OF SOFTWARE-BASED ART
Presentation by  Deena Engel (prof at NYU comp/sci dept.)

Can you still read a Word document that you wrote 10 or 15 years ago? Likely not! The storage media, the operating system, the software, and/or your hardware have all changed in the interim. What about a work of art? Museums and archival collections are expected to exhibit their holdings in perpetuity: think of the Greek and Roman galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, filled with works of art from so long ago. What about software-based art? How can it be best conserved and re-exhibited? What do conservators and other art professionals need to know and what can they do to protect these fragile works of software-based art for future generations?

title: Pure Noise Raspi
description:
http://moolab.net/raspi/
https://github.com/moomonkey/raspi

This is a crash-course session running sound on Raspberry Pi using Pure Data for Sonic Interaction. A mash-up session for noise, covering different ways of getting sound from Raspi, and a simple Pure Data patch to do wicked stuff. We make a wireless instrument to send data (XBee) to Raspi/Pure data.

Bring:
Raspi 2, (There are Raspberry Pi in the Shop you can check out)
headphones, 
a USB sound card, (most generic ones work like, adafruit 1475 $4.95) with 3.5mm output
Arduino Nano, Mini Pro or any Arduino + 
2 analog sensors, I use light (adafruit product/1384 ,$3.95) for the demo and a push button, and jumper wires, and a breadboard.

XBee Series 1 pair and a 1 x XBee Explorer USB (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11812) and 1 x SparkFun XBee Explorer Regulated (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11373) or 2 x XBee adapter (adafruit) (maybe the shop has some?) and a power source such as a 9V battery + batterysnap  to power the wireless sensor. If you want to use Adfruit's XBee explorer an FTDI cable is good to have, (https://www.adafruit.com/product/70)

For the Raspi (I use Raspi 2) and Jessie, you will need to power it with USB micro cable, To enter Raspi terminal/OS you will need a small HDMI display (adafruit), (there will be some displays in the room, ER has some). USB keyboard/mouse or run it headless USB-Wifi adapter (adafruit)
You will also need to prepare a small sound file in .wav (to make your own sound) in Pure data. Preferably, bring a couple of .wav files to play around with.

I will provide code to download to get you started, both for Arduino and Raspi and some XBee adaptors along. I'm thinking of making a Raspi OS downloadable, alt. copy the OS to some sd cards. I will give you the slides which will provide you with info on how to set it up. 

(You can skip the XBee wireless part and go straight into Raspi from Arduino if you like)

title: The Beauty of Stupid Shit: A Brainstorming Session
description:
Join this session where we will embrace the ridiculous, imagine the unnecessary, and discover ways to innovate things that don't need to be innovated. We'll ponder on the use of mining bitcoin as a way of punishing children while encouraging them to learn complex math, experiencing reality virtually, and a password checker that reads out your password among many more! Discover all the useless uses of technology and have fun doing it. 

This session is for everyone, but especially is encouraged for those who need help figuring out an idea to work on this ITP camp.

title: Kids Day Planning Session
description:
This will be our first planning session to see who wants to work on a kids day event and look at the schedule to find a date. Let me know if you can't join but are interested in participating. In past years, it has been from 5-8 on a weekday, but the group can decide what's best. 

In past years, campers have created their own activities or worked in small groups to create activities that take 15-30 minutes to do. We've had people demo VR, motion capture, 3D cards (they made great gifts!) and many other things. If your camp project is designed for children, this is a great time to do user testing. 

Please us this form to add your plans for Kids Day - https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1IfpmutmRqfTDMabvT_HyH9XERra0zznb1GVDm3bv28Q/edit?usp=sharing

Pictures from the 2015 Kids Day - https://goo.gl/photos/DN4C9PA4FHZeF29E9

More information to follow!

title: Physigital - Combining the Physical Space with Digital
description:
In this session, I'll review a variety of projects that have combined the physical and the digital to create interesting experiments in the future of space. Everyone is welcomed to bring their projects to review as well. In addition, we can talk about the ethics of overlaying digital information onto the real world, including who controls the information flow and updating "content."

Some links to review as a starting point:

http://thephygital.com/

http://www.pattenstudio.com/

http://blog.polinchock.com/socialization-of-place/

http://experiencemanifesto.blogs.com/experience_manifesto/socialization_of_place/

https://vimeo.com/89712955

https://vimeo.com/39611704

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ihPsvgnagEI&t=1s

title: Animating in Maya for Beginners
description:
Introduction to Animating with Maya. First we will get an introduction to the program and then we will animate the bouncing ball in Maya. Please download a free trial of Maya before the class- https://www.autodesk.com/products/maya/free-trial-dts

powerpoint: https://www.dropbox.com/s/hkyxwgl5hhgmic4/FORCLASS.pdf?dl=0

Ball Bounce: https://www.dropbox.com/s/c1hc91610lcrmad/Ultimate_Ball_v1.0.1.ma?dl=0

Ball with Tail: https://www.dropbox.com/s/6qp8c1x2e8ms4h8/Ultimate_Tailed_v1.0.1.mb?dl=0

Frames:

Frame 1 Translate Y value = 38
Frame 9 Translate Y value = 0
Frame 17 Translate Y value = 17
Frame 25 Translate Y value = 0
Frame 32 Translate Y value = 25
Frame 39 Translate Y value = 0
Frame 45 Translate Y value = 19
Frame 51 Translate Y value = 0
Frame 56 Translate Y value = 13
Frame 61 Translate Y value = 0
Frame 65 Translate Y value = 9

Frame 83 Translate Y value = 0

Frame 87 Translate Y value = 0
Frame 88 Translate Y value = 0.5
Frame 89 Translate Y value = 0

title: Kinect Brainstorming Session
description:
Let's brainstorm projects we can do using the Microsoft Kinect!

 To start working with it, download the SDK here (https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/kinect).

Here are things to read about 
general page for info (https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/kinect/develop)
Some forums (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn782037.aspx)
extra tools (https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/kinect/tools)

Disclaimer, I know basically nothing about the Kinect but maybe by the end of this session we will know many things together. Bring your big ideas and let's have fun~

title: Helping you make sense of personal security.
description:
It has become incredibly challenging to make sense of digital security. Often it appears so overwhelming that we end up ignoring the issue altogether. Alternatively we rely on quick fixes or on paid products to handle pieces of it for us.

The goal of this session is to set aside time to identify practical aspects of current digital security for each participant. By the end you should be able to narrow down the scope of what you need to focus on.

This session is not intended for security professionals, there will simply be nothing new or cutting edge. It is intended to help anyone who is anxious about the issue but haven't had the opportunity to make decision about it.

***

# Post Session Things

#### Super useful read:

* [https://ssd.eff.org/en/module/seven-steps-digital-security](https://ssd.eff.org/en/module/seven-steps-digital-security)

#### Password managers:

* [https://1password.com/](https://1password.com/)
* [https://www.dashlane.com/](https://www.dashlane.com/)

#### Slides:

* [https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_bQj19l7F3_cEFhWkRndmVJTEU/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_bQj19l7F3_cEFhWkRndmVJTEU/view?usp=sharing)

#### Ad/Tracking Blockers:

* Privacy Badger: [https://www.eff.org/privacybadger](https://www.eff.org/privacybadger)
* HTTPS Everywhere: [https://www.eff.org/https-everywhere](https://www.eff.org/https-everywhere)
* uBlock Origin (Unrelated to "uBlock" !): [https://github.com/gorhill/uBlock](https://github.com/gorhill/uBlock)
* NoScript: [https://noscript.net/](https://noscript.net/) (the nuclear option)

#### Tor:

* Tor Browser Bundle: [https://www.torproject.org/projects/torbrowser.html.en](https://www.torproject.org/projects/torbrowser.html.en)
* What is Tor: [https://www.torproject.org/about/overview.html.en](https://www.torproject.org/about/overview.html.en)

Please tell me if I forgot anything.

title: Creative Programming with Clojure
description:
[Clojure](https://clojure.org/) is a programming language that is designed to be a practical dialect of [lisp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisp_(programming_language)).

Many of Clojure's core aspects make it a wonderful fit for creative programming. I will go into what these are, and provide practical examples of their use. 

We will also look at certain programming techniques that can help you maintain sanity while creating complex dynamic systems.

The material will focus on people new to Clojure. If you already know the language, please do attend as well, your feedback would be most helpful.  

If you haven't considered the impact of the programming language on your practice, this might also give you a new perspective.

title: Drawing with the Right Side of the Brain
description:
Drawing concepts to improve your ability to see things. This is based on the Betty Edwards book Drawing on the Right Side the Brain. 

The pdf for today's session can be found here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4vBnv6dlkLZTERNNTNUSzU1aVU/view?usp=sharing

title: What does everything collect on you and how can you use it?
description:
Here we'll be going through the popular apps and services that people use and highlighting surveillance and data-collection tools and how you can use them to make interesting things (with examples).

Bring your laptops so you can see exactly what your devices have collected about you and sold to advertisers, and what APIs you can use to pretend you're an advertiser and use this data for Artâ„¢!

Also will give a quick guide to the Freedom of Information Act and what other date collection tools are being used by your local, state, and federal governments, and some good projects that use them for public good.

title: Intro to making music with Ableton Live
description:
We'll talk a little bit about what makes Ableton different than other Digital Audio Workstations, and dive right in to making a mashup. If we have time, we'll get into some other concepts, like using our phone as a controller.

This class is geared towards Ableton beginners, at any level of musical ability - though hopefully anyone will find it interesting.

You should:

Download and run the Ableton trial version [here](https://www.ableton.com/en/trial). Do it before class... it's big-ish.

Download the files I've prepared [here](https://we.tl/0fJDXgVPC1)

If you have an iPhone and you'd like to try using it to control Ableton remotely, download [this free app](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/faders-us/id444262646?mt=8)

Bring headphones/earbuds

title: O No Robots: Kinetic Sculpture 101
description:
HEY LOOK AT THIS: 
[Slides and SOME notes from the class!](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1ja6bg7tBiNGktiz0XjOWqrEDzD873Z7SSbvfkrUB59o/edit?usp=sharing)

^^^^^^ LOOK UP ^^^^^^

Robots are pretty cool, but learning to make them can be a challenge. So many moving parts! So little time! Why make a robot? Are they even engaging if a phone is also present at the same time? Are video games a better bet?

Let's talk about popular parts and where to find them, design techniques and tools available, and how to think about making machines that do nothing.

The first fifteen minutes to forty-five is talking, and after that is prototyping. This will work best if you keep your head up and bring a dead printer or a busted scanner or a dead Swiffer wet-jet, etc.

We will cover:

- trash diving for motors
- choosing robot movements and defying physics
- impractical considerations of installation
- SolveSpace, a free CAD software available Mac, PC, and Linux

There will absolutely be killer robots jokes.

title: (Really) Basic Analog Circuits
description:
We'll discuss some basic fundamentals of analog circuits, learn more about components and chips that allow you build some circuits without ever touching an arduino! Campers will also learn how to build a simple circuit using analog components-- essentially blinking an LED in two different ways. 

While this is meant for beginners to physical computing, anyone is free to sit in! 

If you can, BYOB-- bring your own breadboard! The components are all readily available here at ITP.

Slides are here:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1YYbA00HjDDDSeMXDUBhjik6O5hweGBXQB2XfG6Gw1yY

title: Make a laser cut folding book from one sheet of paper!
description:
Using Adobe Illustrator (no expertise necessary), make a simple folding book out of plain or 'fancy' paper. Cut out interesting shapes,  then draw ,paint or collage backgrounds. Learn how to use the laser cutters with this simple paper project.

[Link 1](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0BxZgGrkmMO6QTmRDa1BEVHMyR0E)

[Link 2](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0BxZgGrkmMO6QYnRaODU1QVdoVzQ)

title: DIY Circuit Design Part 1
description:
Learn all the tools to build your own circuits from scratch. We'll start by learning how to use Eagle to draw our schematic and design our boards. We'll follow that by etching and populating our boards using tools and materials that you can use at home.

In part 1 we'll create a simple circuit on a breadboard, and then create that schematic in Eagle

In part 2 we'll learn all the processes to etch and populate our boards

P.S Ideally I want to split this into 2 sessions as there is a lot of stuff to get through. Also since we're going to be acid etching the boards, I would like to place a limit on part 2 of the session. I can do groups of people back to back if needed but ideally would want to restrict it to 10 people each session due to safety. I can do part 2 on Sunday june 18, but haven't proposed it yet incase we need to figure things out before.

title: Data Visualization & Inforgrapics Using D3.js
description: This is a session for those wanting to enter the world of big data through design!

title: VR to 3D | Printing in the Real World What you paint in a Virtual One
description: Learning how to sculpt and paint in VR and preparing the files in 3D Printing.

title: Laser Cutting 101
description:
Learn the ins and outs of laser cutting at ITP!

This session is intended for anyone who intends to use the laser cutter while at Camp - we will cover materials, settings, and the overall workflow for producing laser cut forms. The emphasis will be on actually using the laser cutters, we will not focus as much on generating designs. 

Sessions are limited to 8 participants.

title: Laser Cutting 101
description:
Learn the ins and outs of laser cutting at ITP!

This session is intended for anyone who intends to use the laser cutter while at Camp - we will cover materials, settings, and the overall workflow for producing laser cut forms. The emphasis will be on actually using the laser cutters, we will not focus as much on generating designs.

Sessions are limited to 8 participants.

title: Laser Cutting 101
description:
Learn the ins and outs of laser cutting at ITP!

This session is intended for anyone who intends to use the laser cutter while at Camp - we will cover materials, settings, and the overall workflow for producing laser cut forms. The emphasis will be on actually using the laser cutters, we will not focus as much on generating designs.

Sessions are limited to 8 participants.

title: Laser Cutting 101
description:
Learn the ins and outs of laser cutting at ITP!

This session is intended for anyone who intends to use the laser cutter while at Camp - we will cover materials, settings, and the overall workflow for producing laser cut forms. The emphasis will be on actually using the laser cutters, we will not focus as much on generating designs.

Sessions are limited to 8 participants.

title: 3D forms from 2D planes:  Digital Fabrication with Lasercutters
description:
In this fabrication session we will investigate digital fabrication with the lasercutter.  Weâ€™ll be working with Adobe Illustrator and a bit with Rhino3D to discuss how to construct forms from planar materials.  We will also cover, file preparation, types of construction methods, and materials.

Please come with Illustrator and Rhino (trial version) installed.

title: Made to Measure: Digital Fabrication for Customizable Parts
description:
In this computer modeling course we will be looking into at how to make custom parts for digital fabrication.  Weâ€™ll be working with Rhino to figure out how to digitally model physical real-world objects and incorporate them with digitally fabricated devices.  

Have a motor?  Letâ€™s model a mechanism that works with it!

Have a lighting idea?  Letâ€™s model an armature to hold that bulb!

Need to hide a mess of wires, sensors, and micro controllers?  Letâ€™s make a vessel that holds all your parts in place, looks good, and doesnâ€™t have excessive volume!!!

title: A Trip to the Whitney
description: Let us explore this amazing city. First up: The Whitney!

title: Rules of Play / Code of Conduct
description:
Camp is beautiful and Camp is hard. Our constantly shifting structure means that we need to be extra careful to be good to each other in our learning and making. We are committed to building a safe, respectful, and positive community for all of our campers, camp counselors, session leaders, staff, and administrators. It is our mission to treat everyone both as fairly and equally as possible. 

For this reason we are looking to implement a Rules of Play / Code of Conduct for ITP Camp. 

We have a draft here:
[https://goo.gl/0j63TU](https://goo.gl/0j63TU)

But we are eager to have this document to reflect the collective voice of ITP Camp.

Please join us to review and revise this document and to share your thoughts and perspectives. We will also share the feedback that we've gotten to date. Hope to see you there!

title: LaGuardia Studio Tour
description:
Come to a tour of NYU's LaGuardia Studios! NYU has state-of-the-art 3D printers available for the NYU community.

This guided tour will show you the 3D printers and discuss their capabilities and how they work.

https://www.nyu.edu/life/information-technology/locations-and-facilities/laguardia-studio.html

Tour limited to 15 people due to size constraints.

title: Getting started with React
description:
[React](https://facebook.github.io/react) is a javascript library for building user interfaces from Facebook. 

It focuses on the "View" in your MVC(model, view, controller) applications and touts a blazing-fast virtual DOM diff implementation. According to JavaScript analytics service Libscore, React is currently being used on the websites of Netflix, Imgur, Buffer, Bleacher Report, Feedly, Airbnb, SeatGeek, HelloSign, Walmart, and others.

React allows developers to create large web applications that use data which can change over time, without reloading the page. Its main goal is to be fast, simple and scalable.

This workshop will explore the basic fundamentals of React to get you started. Check out this web application that I built in React: [ITP Thesis Archive Site](https://itp.nyu.edu/thesis2017/), [code](https://github.com/yining1023/thesisBook).

title: Getting started with React
description:
[React](https://facebook.github.io/react) is a javascript library for building user interfaces from Facebook. 

It focuses on the "View" in your MVC(model, view, controller) applications and touts a blazing-fast virtual DOM diff implementation. According to JavaScript analytics service Libscore, React is currently being used on the websites of Netflix, Imgur, Buffer, Bleacher Report, Feedly, Airbnb, SeatGeek, HelloSign, Walmart, and others.

React allows developers to create large web applications that use data which can change over time, without reloading the page. Its main goal is to be fast, simple and scalable.

This workshop will explore the basic fundamentals of React to get you started. Check out this web application that I built in React: [ITP Thesis Archive Site](https://itp.nyu.edu/thesis2017/), [code](https://github.com/yining1023/thesisBook).

title: Paint with Processing and Touch OSC
description:
In this workshop we will be learning how to connect your Processing sketches to TouchOSC iPad app, create custom TouchOSC interfaces, so that you can control multiple parameters in your Processing sketches. Familiarity with processing will definitely help, but isn't necessary.

We will spend 2 hours reviewing setup, and the 3rd hour will be dedicated to working on your sketches and answering questions.

https://processing.org
https://hexler.net/software/touchosc

You should have TouchOSC installed on your device iPad or iPhone before the class. Unfortunately, it costs $4.99, boo. But definitely worth it!

title: Volumetric capture with DepthKit: Kinect + DSLR
description:
Add a depth sensor to your video camera to film compelling performances in immersive 3D.

DepthKit is a suite of tools that allows anyone to capture, edit, and publish volumetric experiences in VR/AR with Unity, three.js, Max/MSP and more.

Check out this page: http://www.aaronkoblin.com/Aaronetrope/

IMPORTANT: for those that didn't receive the RSVP email from the leaders, please go ahead and sign up with Unity and download the software before the session. It's an easy and free process https://unity3d.com/

title: Practical Knot Tying
description: Knowing knots can be amazingly helpful and fun. Nothing is more satisfying than being able to solve multiple problem with the same basic piece of equipment that can be found most anywhere. In this session we'll go over some really helpful knots, how to tie them, when to use them and how to hang a swing without leaving the ground.

title: Handstands!
description: Get off your computer and into your body. Learn to stand on your hands. Beginners and advanced balancers welcome, everyone will work at their own pace. I have been teaching handstands for 5 years and I guarantee that by the end of the session your handstand will be improved. And it's really fun.

title: Create your own 'Google Home' using a Raspberry Pi, AI and Google's Assistant SDK
description:
We'll be making use of Google's AIY project voice kit to get a natural language recognizer up and running and connect it to the Google Assistant. Along with everything the Google Assistant already does, you can add your own question and answer pairs. All in a handy little cardboard cube, powered by a Raspberry Pi.  In under 3hrs you'll build your very own version of a 'Google Home' and search the internet with nothing but your voice!

We'll spend most of the session setting up Google's AIY voice kit project, but will leave some time at the end to experiment and hack away to create some custom features of our own. All you need is your laptop, ITP will lend you the Pi and Google Voice Kit for the session!

title: Cybersecurity in the Age of Trump: A Digital Security Workshop
description: Digital Safe Space is designed to help you create a safe space for your digital world. We are focused on helping activists, advocates, organizations and allies in the social justice movement, to configure their technology â€” desktops, laptops, tablets, mobile phones, the cloud and other web-based services â€” in a safe and balanced way. We will help you to protect yourself from hacks, attacks and loss of access to your own accounts. We will give you the tools to build your confidence in the privacy of your devices and the data they contain.

title: How to Exponentially Increase Your Online Security with Two-Factor Authentication
description:
One of the easiest ways to  exponentially increase your digital security is by enabling Two-Factor Authentication, or 2FA. With 2-factor authentication, you need to have two different keys to unlock your account. Enabling 2FA gives you peace of mind knowing that your password is not enough to gain access to your account. Digital Safe Space will teach you how to enable Two-Factor Authentication in a individualized clinic. We will cover the use of 2FA on most major online services (list in formation). If you havenâ€™t yet enabled 2FA on your online services, we urge you to attend this session.

We recommend that all attendees bring a laptop and their primary mobile device.

title: Papercrafting: a cheap, accessible start to low-poly 3D fabrication
description:
This is a low-tech, accessible start towards low-poly 3D fabrication with paper, cardboard, and other flat materials. This is aimed at people who have little to no experience with 3D modeling, who might not have access to makerspace equipment like laser cutters and 3D printers after camp ends but who still want to make things! The most expensive part of this process will either be the full version of the program (optional but nice! $38) or the printer ink (??), and you can get very very far with just some cardstock (stiff paper), a blade/knife/razor, a metal straight edge, and glue. 

Note: This session requires Windows to use one of the programs. There exists ways to unfold 3D models for Macs, but I don't know how to and will not be covering it. If you do know how, you're more than welcome to demonstrate for us!
Please bring a Windows laptop with Sketchup and Pepakura Designer installed on it. I use sketchup 2016, linked below, but other versions definitely work as well. 
https://forums.sketchup.com/t/sketchup-make-2016-download-links/37503
http://www.tamasoft.co.jp/pepakura-en/download/index.html

We will be using Sketchup and Pepakura Designer to first create a low-poly shape, and then convert it to a template from which you can print or laser-cut and assemble! I will also cover using Meshmixer to simplify found models, and show some examples of cool things you can make.

title: Deploy your own API
description:
As a follow-up to "Build your own API", come learn:

* how you can give a beautiful front-end to your website

* deploy back-end code on a remote server.

* connect IP addresses and DNS.

* make it available to everyone in the world!

(aka 'how do i make a real website with just a text editor and five dollars'.)

This session will be a refresher in back-end javascript, front-end javascript, html and css (and even an intro to vim!)

title: Painting with Fluorescent Bacteria - Group 1
description: Have you ever made art with living pigments? Discover how to partner with micro organisms to create pieces that are alive. In this workshop we will create collaborative works using non-harmful bacteria that produce colored and vivid fluorescent pigments. You will learn how to culture the organisms and also how to display the works, including the UV lights needed to properly visualize the fluorescence.

title: Painting with Fluorescent Bacteria - Group 3
description: Have you ever made art with living pigments? Discover how to partner with micro organisms to create pieces that are alive. In this workshop we will create collaborative works using non-harmful bacteria that produce colored and vivid fluorescent pigments. You will learn how to culture the organisms and also how to display the works, including the UV lights needed to properly visualize the fluorescence.

title: Laser Cutting 101
description:
Learn the ins and outs of laser cutting at ITP!

This session is intended for anyone who intends to use the laser cutter while at Camp - we will cover materials, settings, and the overall workflow for producing laser cut forms. The emphasis will be on actually using the laser cutters, we will not focus as much on generating designs.

Sessions are limited to 8 participants.

title: Laser Cutting 101
description:
Learn the ins and outs of laser cutting at ITP!

This session is intended for anyone who intends to use the laser cutter while at Camp - we will cover materials, settings, and the overall workflow for producing laser cut forms. The emphasis will be on actually using the laser cutters, we will not focus as much on generating designs.

Sessions are limited to 8 participants.

title: Day of Making & Documentation
description: The last day of Camp will be dedicated to a day of making and documentation. This time will be dedicated to finishing up projects and creating a record of all the crazy, weird, amazing things you've made this month at Camp!

title: Crypto Party!
description:
Introduction to and practical hands-on usage of the basic tools of cryptography (privacy enhancing software) and how you can proactively protect yourself digitally.

We'll go over threat models and then move on to the basic tools everyone should be using (2FA, Password managers, full disk encryption etc) followed up by round table discussions focused on Email/Messaging/Anonymous Browsing.

New and experienced people very welcome. I will spend no more than 20 minutes talking, the focus is on dispelling the myth of protecting yourself being impossible by actually starting to use and understand the software.

title: Digital Fabrication: CNC 101
description: Up your digi fab game and learn how to use the CNC. In this session we'll go over mastercam (the software that interfaces with the CNC) and learn how to use the CNC. This will be a very hands on session, oriented towards everyone getting hands on experience. We'll finish with some tips on how to avoid issues and save time.

title: Augmenting the World with Light - Projection Mapping
description:
Learn how to take control of light in a whole new way, and augment the world around you with animations, color, simulated lighting, & more. 
 
Weâ€™ll start with a quick conceptual overview, analyze various opportunities/limitations of the medium, then dive into a few live demos of whatâ€™s possible with projection mapping, using MadMapper.
 
Once you know the basics of mapping, itâ€™s all about content! This workshop will be content-driven, sharing how to optimize your workflow by organizing a video template, tips Iâ€™ve learned to map rapidly during different â€œprojection-a-dayâ€ road trips, live-video mixing, and using MIDI to make that job a lot smoother. 
 
Weâ€™ll also touch on the fun logistics behind organizing a mapping installation, deciding what projectors youâ€™ll need, how to mount them in difficult spots, and how to put together a mobile mapping setup.
 
_Craig Winslow is an Adobe Creative Resident 2016/2017. Over the past year heâ€™s been focusing on a project called Light Capsules, utilizing projection mapping to bring ghostsigns back to life. These worn ads are digitally recreated following much research, then projection mapped back onto themselves, literally shining a light on history._

title: Outing - Visit to Microsoft's NYC Technology Space
description:
Outing to Microsoft's Technology Space in NYC (Times Square). 

The outing will be a no more than 2-hour long visit with a tour of the space and short demo of MS tech and offerings (still working this part out). There is tech all around ++ a gorgeous space with awesome views of Time Square.

We will meet in the lobby @ 11 Times Square (8th Avenue between 41st & 42nd St) - Enter under the Microsoft Logo. **Will send out final confirmation a few days before.

Interested? RSVP asap

title: Open Source Cinema
description: This will be a discussion of the future of movies.  We will look first at the historical patterns and psychological underpinnings of innovations for human communication like decimals, literacy and the printing press, to help us speculate about how new virtual reality technologies might follow in remaking the production and consumption of cinema.  The true promise may be more about an ease of creation, comparing and sharing of virtual scenes than the immersion of a head mounted display that has become emblematic of virtual reality.  Technologies for generating and handling data will be as important as tools for realistic rendering.  We will talk about how to get started with specific technologies like the kinect, three.js and mongoDB for democratizing cinema.  Finally we will look at the power of movies to provide fake experience that changes minds, to create the fictions that hold our society together and how the application of that power might change in a more democratized future.

title: Drawing Night!
description:
Come hang out and draw or paint! Some art supplies will be provided, but it's a good idea to bring your own as well ðŸ¤¹ðŸŽ¨ðŸŒˆ

Feel free to just come for part of the event!

title: They had bluetooth fidget spinners at the Foodtown. I bought 2! What should we do with them?
description:
What the...? Why...? How does it even?

These questions and more will be answered.

Should we make something cool? Or smash them and see what's inside?

I also bought a bag of Twix, pictured [here](http://i.imgur.com/0M7TmnW.jpg). If things get dull we can just eat the Twix. I've already eaten some, but there are totally enough left.

title: Fashion design for your alter ego
description:
Dear Campers, 

People loooooove all kinds of festivals - from Burning Man and Coachella to Robot Heart and Halloween parties therefore during this class I will: 

Give a little overview on spectacular fashion design pieces in the sea of ready-to-wear shows (to inspire you and share the vision on what is interesting around and what is #soyesterday) 

We would go through the process on how to approach "making a garment" - > 
how to sketch - what to consider - how to come with a pattern - how to sew - where to find the needed parts and what potentially you might want to look for. 

Where this all could be found in NYC 

Answer your questions! 


See you on Monday - let me know if most of those who are interested are fine with the time scheduled!

title: The Basics of Design and Design Process
description:
I'll go over the basics of 2-Design and what makes art aesthetically pleasing (although this is subjective at times). We'll also take a look at color theory, meaning studying the effects of color in design and articulating our emotional response to various colors. We'll also take a look at the creative process, looking at questions such as how to come up with ideas and how to visually express them.

This is an interactive session that's part lecture, part Q&A, and part workshop time. You will be encouraged to observe and analyze art. 

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1QCdCgLY2lCNTPJDGWXov6P8lN_COV5ephkCxATciP2c/edit?usp=sharing

title: Offsite - Jump Rope!
description:
Come jump rope!

Punk Rope is a "mash-up of rope jumping and recess". I've been doing it for years & it's really fun. It has an inclusive and enthusiastic vibe that feels similar to ITP.

The folks who run Punk Rope have invited us to join Monday's class for free. It's outdoors, on the East River, so you can watch the boats and enjoy the summer evening as you jump.

It works for any level of fitness and jump rope skill. Ropes are provided.

[Here's](https://goo.gl/maps/5Bp8tkayQpu) the location, see you there!

The class is about a 30-minute walk from ITP - if you'd like to walk over together, Sophia will be leaving from the 4th floor elevators at 6:20pm.

title: Monday Morning Meditation
description: Start the week right with a quick guided meditation.  There will be an introduction and a brief overview of the basic concepts of meditation as a practice, but mostly this will be a quiet moment to get your brain ready and focused for the rest of the day.

title: Education Meetup
description: This session is an opportunity for campers to discuss their past/current/future work in education. Suggested format is a brief talk/presentation (~3-5min) followed by Q&A/discussion. Aiming to be inclusive of diverse experiences campers may have to share (formal education, informal, K-12, higher ed, US, international, etc.).  If you don't have anything to present but want to listen in or join the discussion that's cool too.

title: Video Sculpture
description:
An intro to video art and creating interactive video installations. I will show you some awesome examples and then teach you some basic Max MSP coding that will get you going on making an interactive video installation. Taught by me. GabeBC.

Class Filez
[https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/0B-TvojXbnyxOekpwNVUwdWJuc0E](https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/0B-TvojXbnyxOekpwNVUwdWJuc0E)

title: Morning Meditation
description: A quick bit of quiet to start your day.  There will be an introduction and a brief overview of the basic concepts of meditation as a practice, but mostly this will be a quiet moment to get your brain ready and focused for the rest of the day.

title: Morning Meditation
description: A quick bit of quiet to start your day.  There will be an introduction and a brief overview of the basic concepts of meditation as a practice, but mostly this will be a quiet moment to get your brain ready and focused for the rest of the day.

description: A quick bit of quiet to start your day.  There will be an introduction and a brief overview of the basic concepts of meditation as a practice, but mostly this will be a quiet moment to get your brain ready and focused for the rest of the day.

title: DON'T BE AFRAID OF PROGRAMMING
description:
Everything you will want to know about object oriented programming. 

Brush up on your coding skills. 
Give yourself a bit more of a foundation in CS Theory.

title: Brainstorm! - Ok. Ok? Ok! Abstract Elements in Communication
description:
Ok. Ok? Ok!  The magical word with a million meanings.  But how can that word accomplish so much and yet fall so flat when you read it from a screen?  

In this session we'll break down the translation from in-person spoken communication to written forms and back to see what's surviving that game of telephone.  

Finally, we'll try to brainstorm strategies to capture and represent some abstract elements in the digital sphere, allowing for greater depth, clarity, and empathy.  Ok? Ok!

title: A History of Women in Computing
description:
According to the Census Bureau's 2009 American Community Survey, women comprise 48 percent of the U.S. workforce but just 24 percent of workers in STEM fields. Half as many women work in STEM jobs as would be expected if gender representation in STEM professions mirrored the overall workforce.

Historically, women have contributed significantly to the evolution of technology and computing. We will discuss reasons why Women are under represented and possible solutions moving forward. Does media play a part? Does society and culture contribute as well? This will be a seminar style discussion,

title: BYOB (Build Your Own Board)
description: Do you buy multiple arduinos for different projects and spend a lot on sensors and breakout boards? Do you want to take your prototypes past the breadboard? In this workshop weâ€™ll show you how to build your own boards. Weâ€™ll spend the first 10-15 minutes talking about PCBâ€™s and the different ways we can make them. The next hour and a half will be a cooking demonstration. We will walk through all of the steps of making a pcb for a 555 timer. This will just be a brief overview, but if there is sufficient interest, this workshop can be followed by more thorough tutorials in smaller groups. The method used in this demonstration will be acid etching and we will use through hole parts.

title: Here's Looking at You Kid
description:
We will be designing and building simple puppet/animatronic eye rigs. We will preform and add personality to our lifeless devices.

Session lead by Kate Hartman and Ben Light.

Image c/o http://www.pyroelectro.com/tutorials/animatronic_eyes/index.html

Slides: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1DN3cFO7j_Q5LwnsizvVdPwFAgBoCPJD-X_KnYKuPvDY/edit?usp=sharing

title: Intro to Software Concepts
description:
What is front end vs back end code? What's the stack? What does it mean if it's full, can it be empty?! What are databases and how do they work? What are data structures and algorithms and should I care???

This class aims to be a general overview of terminology and concepts used in software, programming and computer science, meant for a beginner. The course will mostly be based around the questions that you have and be structured as a discussion, so come with questions. I will also try to find some resources for independent study.

title: One Pixel at a time: Image processing for Programming newbies
description:
In this introductory session we will cover the basic components of computation: conditional statements (if - else) and loops (while, for), and we will use them to manipulate the pixels of an image. 

We will uncover the power of repetitive structures, and we will discover how easy it is to create filters like grayscale conversion, inversion, posterization, brightness/saturation/dynamic range adjustment, distortions, and some creations of our own. Let's unleash the potential of custom-made software, and forget for a while about closed image editing tools.

Our tool will be Processing, and we'll be able to apply our procedures to static images, pre-recorded videos, and live cam feed. We'll also see how to save the output of our sketches as new images.

Download Processing from: [http://processing.org/download](http://processing.org/download)

Session notes: [https://escenaconsejo.github.io/OnePixelAtATime/](https://escenaconsejo.github.io/OnePixelAtATime/)

title: Coding Democracy | Can Tech Save Democracy?
description:
AI congress, AR avatars for natural systems, liquid democracy, smart contracts, e-voting, participatory budgeting, global democracy, blockchain - there are visions out there that could transform democracy to be more accountable, effective and inclusive...but theyâ€™re stuck in an echo chamber. In this talk, we'll break them free and discuss their merits. 

Andrew James Benson is currently producing a web series that shares the visions of those working to realize more accountable, efficient, and inclusive democracies. Learn more about the project at: [http://codingdemocracy.tv/](http://codingdemocracy.tv/)

title: Low-Tech VR Starter Kit
description:
This workshop aims to reduce the learning curve and required technology to create virtual reality projects.
 
Weâ€™ll cover building for VR in the browser using an easy to learn framework called A-Frame, and discuss other libraries in development.

Weâ€™ll also cover tangible VR such as drawing and modifying photos to create 360 images with perspective grid paper, and look at examples of how artists are using physical objects to create VR experiences. 
 
The first hour of the workshop will be spent showing examples of projects that have been created in these ways and short tutorials on these different methods. The last hour will be spent working on your own projects. We'll have VR headsets available, but please bring your own Google Cardboard headsets, or something similar, if you have them.

title: Digi Fab: CNC 101
description: Up your digi fab game and learn how to use the CNC. In this session we'll go over mastercam (the software that interfaces with the CNC) and learn how to use the CNC. This will be a very hands on session, oriented towards everyone getting hands on experience. We'll finish with some tips on how to avoid issues and save time.

title: 3D Scan and Print Yourself(And Others!)
description:
In this session, we'll learn how to use Skanect, a free 3D-scanning software, to scan ourselves, and then process the mesh through Rhino so that we can make a 3D print.

A ridiculously simple process, and lots of fun!

Before coming to class, please download:

- [Rhino](https://www.rhino3d.com/download)
- [Skanect](http://skanect.occipital.com/download/)
- [Cura](https://ultimaker.com/en/products/cura-software/download-request/133)

Also, on the off chance that you own or have access to a V1 Kinect, Model 1414, please bring it to class!

Thanks and see you guys there!!

Alex

title: The Annual Camp Kids' Day
description:
Our annual ITP Camp Kids' Day!

Bring your family, bring your friends, and enjoy an afternoon of activities devoted to the little ones. 

There will be activities for kids of a wide range of ages. If you plan on attending with your loved ones, please leave a comment, and include in it the age/s of kid/s you'll be bringing, so we can best prepare.

If you have a great idea for an activity you'd like to lead, please let us know!

title: Awareness Game -- Find Your Inner Happiness
description:
Joy. It's your default setting. Find out how to uncover it by playing Awareness Games.
  
What are Awareness Games? Awareness Games are:
 
* Enjoyable but surprisingly deep games you can play with your own mind.  Kind of like meditating only more fun and less work.  And not so serious.
* Ways to play with your mind to point it towards the infinite well of happiness and joy that lies within each of us.
* Fun things to do with your mind that trigger spontaneous joy and happiness.
* A fresh approach to meditation and self-help, focusing on play instead of on work or effort.
* Ways of playing with your mind; of stumbling into the infinite well of happiness and joy that lies within us.
* Self-enjoyment, not self-improvement.
 
Play with pure awareness and discover the background of all experience, where happiness is hiding in plain sight.

This class, led by Brian Tom O'Connor, author of "Awareness Games: Playing with Your Mind to Create Joy," will be a combination of light talk and guided exercises to bring your focus to pure awareness.

https://www.playawarenessgames.com/

Podcast, http://www.oneyoufeed.net/brian-tom-oconnor

title: Python basics (quick intro, especially for those attending "machine learning for artists" later)
description:
The "Practical resources for machine learning for artists" workshop in the afternoon will refer to some python code so I thought I would give a brief introduction to python to make it easier for people who are new to this language to follow along.

Please have anaconda python 3.6 installed on your machine before the session starts (https://www.continuum.io/downloads).  

Please download this python notebook, we'll review it in class: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B4pHBC0JSg-4MzBIeGlvZGNXOEk?usp=sharing

title: Super-Human in the making | Game plan
description:
Dear Campers, this session is my investment into camp-wellfare this year. 

We will go through:

- Key ideas and insights on how to design your own identity to achieve a look of a superhuman :)  

- In case you want to become somewhat "a personal brand" - this class should be more than helpful 

The class aims to rock your style-sences. 

The first part will be a presentation on how-to's and know-how's of a life in style.
The second part will be a screening of a documentary about the famous fashion visionary Diana Vreeland who lived in New York. 

 â€œThe future holds a golden world. It will be for beauty; it will be for intelligent productiveness.â€ D.V. 

See you soon! 

PS: Visibility: a measure of the ability of radiant energy to evoke visual sensation
PPS: Don't be a personal brand, be a person ;)

title: Generative & Dynamic Sound for Your Projects
description:
Sound is often an important part of installations, visuals, and other types of projects. In this session, we will learn how to develop a sonic awareness, capture field recordings, and use them with app called Field Scraper to created generative compositions. You do not need to be a musician or familiar with sound.

To follow along with the class I recommend getting the Field Scraper app, or you can always take notes and follow along afterward.

https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/fieldscaper-sound-warp-field-recorder/id1006624104?mt=8

Github Repo
https://github.com/matt0rtega/Generative-and-Dynamic-Sound

title: Futurama: emerging trends in technology and life
description:
During the session we would go through the trend-forecasting agencies and how they work. 

During 2010 the Telegraph reported: 
Trend-spotting is the new Â£36bn growth business. With fortunes to be made in fickle businesses like fashion, trend forecasting is becoming increasingly important for creative industries. 

Trend forecasting is a good example of big-data driven services. 

I would summarize and give an overview of the latest trends (from tech and innovation to science and leisure), moods, movements, predictions on what people would want/need/buy and what would be "hot" in 2018-2019 years based on the reports from WGSN / Percels / Fashion Snoops. 

The session would be of a great value for everyone and designed to give you a rare insight where to apply your creativity and business ideas before everybody else. 

We would finish by discussing personal vision of what would be there in the future for us and hopefully new business ideas will be born this day :) 

Stay tuned!

title: Soft Robotics and Bioinspiration **2nd Session by Popular Request - Capped at 25 People**
description:
Roboticists frequently find inspiration from the incredible evolved forms of nature, and translate them into fresh thinking and solutions. This workshop invites you to explore this fast-growing domain where biology and robotics collide.

This 4hr workshop will take participants from any skill level through what it takes to be a researcher on the forefront of soft robotics. Workshop activities include:

* Learning from actual robot designers about the state of the art of soft robotics
* Building your own inflatable robotic actuators
* Mixing and matching different fields to come up with bioinspired designs
* Learning tools to go from idea to prototype to product faster than ever before

title: Rapid cardboard prototyping: A quick-n-dirty workshop
description:
This session will be an intro/refresher on quickly creating 3d objects out of 2d materials.

We will focus on cardboard, but many of the strategies are useful for other materials as well (wood, plastics, sheet metal etc). 

This is a work session! You are welcome to bring ideas you want to try out. We will take ideas we have for 3d shapes, plot them out into 2d planes, cut those pieces out using knifes, rulers and laser cutters, and assemble them using hot glue.

Special consideration will be made to structural strength, good practice with tools, and taking advantage of the malleable qualities cardboard/paper offers for hands-on-thinking flow.

Light cardboard will be provided. Step on in anytime.

title: FILL THE ROOM - Projection ArtHack
description:
Now that we know the basics of projection mapping, letâ€™s augment ITP with light!
 
After a quick 15 min refresher/overview on projection mapping, this will be a hands-on session as we projection map video, animations, code, live video, data & more... to walls, pipes, ceiling vents, windows, pillarsâ€” if you can see it, you can map it!
 
Come prepared with pre-made content if you have a specific idea, or show up and make something on the fly. Still donâ€™t feel comfortable with mapping? The best way to learn is by doing! 
 
By the end of the session, weâ€™ll have a finished collaborative project: 
_an immersive light collage!_

Everyone who contributes will be credited with their involvement in our ITP Camp project â€” **FILL THE ROOM**
 
_If you missed the previous mapping workshop, you can read my growing slew of notes here: [Augmenting the World With Light â€“ Projection Mapping Notes](http://bit.ly/promapworkshop)._

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - 
 
_Name inspired by the old riddle â€œThe Wisest Sonâ€ :_
 
An old man wanted to leave all of his money to one of his three sons. 
He gave each of them a few coins and told them to buy something that would be able to fill their living room. 
The first son bought as much hay as he could afford, but there was not enough to fill the room. 
The second bought a ton of feathers, but they still did not fill the room. 
The third son pulled two things out of his pocket, filled the room, and obtained his father's fortune. 
 
What were the two things that the man bought and what was able to fill the room?

title: Serverless Programming Using AWS Lambda
description:
"Serverless" is a new programming paradigm that minimizes the amount of infrastructure a developer needs to own in order to deploy code. In this session, we'll spend some time learning about programming using AWS Lambda and the Serverless framework by building a chat bot you can interact with over SMS

Among other use cases, it is the backbone for voice chat interfaces using Amazon Alexa or Google Home. If you've ever been curious about how to get started making your own custom Alexa Skills, this is the workshop for you!

Please come to the workshop with a laptop on which you have installed:

* Node.JS
* The Serverless framework ("npm install -g serverless")
* A text editor that you like to use (e.g. Sublime Text, Visual Studio Code, etc.)

title: Open planning session: Be a part of Kids Day!
description:
This session devoted to planning of kids day. This year it will be on Wednesday the 21st, 4-7pm.

Kids day is held every year at camp. Campers bring their children (of all ages) and their friends, and a section of the floor is dedicated to small open drop-in drop-out sessions geared especially for the little ones. 

Do you have a session you'd like to propose/lead? Or a work of your own you'd like to present to a younger public?

Come to this session to tell us about it. We have materials and some budget for this. 

And if you cant make it, shoot either me, counselor Kar or Jaycee and email!

title: Leveraging Podcasting for Purpose
description:
This session will walk through the steps of leveraging podcasting as â€œcritical eventâ€, lending purpose to in house recording sessions, research, and video conferencing.  Weâ€™ll cover techniques in audio ethnography, facilitating discussion with slide decks, and building from your learning network to reach out to professionals beyond.

My ongoing project, Journeys in Podcasting, will be recording a session this Thursday, and Iâ€™ll demonstrate how readings and inquiry are organized beforehand.

Editing/publishing logistics and tools will be covered.

title: DON'T BE AFRAID OF PROGRAMMING PART 2
description: A continuation of a previous session. This time focusing on Functions, Objects, and Classes

title: PHYSICS IN CODE | Simulating a Physics Engine in Processing
description:
No physics experience expected. 
Learn how to simulate physics or generate animations through code! 
Create your own laws of physics!

title: Indigo Dye Workshop
description:
Try your hand at this beautiful dye technique, offering an infinite variety of results! Make simple summer clothing from your own unique fabrics- all materials supplied, including cotton- but if you have a cotton or wool garment you'd like to experiment with, bring it along!

We will look at the history and technique of indigo dye and its implication in global human interaction, including the beginning of the USA slave trade. We will dicuss the chemical transformation that oxidizes this dye to make the beautiful and distinctive blue. And we will experiment with a variety of easy and fun techniques for creating patterns, variations, and effects.

Binding wood pieces onto folded cotton is one technique to create dynamic resist patterns. You might prepare some laser-cut shapes to use as blocks for resist patterns- use the comments for questions or to set up a prep session.

title: 3D modelling knowledge: Precise modelling with Fusion 360 and Engineering problem solving
description:
Introducing different 3D modelling program. There will be a introductory demonstration focusing on Autodesk Fusion 360.
This is good for people who wants to make precise fitting parts with digital fabrication.

If you have any trouble figuring out mechanical / engineering part of your project, we will have time for working/ question toward the end of the session

Please have fusion 360 installed, mouse is recommended.
Bring your project to the session!

notes:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_E-36h80S7Pda4Olu800eItfOkUoHJ1-7S1CwgppXdU/edit

title: Tour of New Reality Co
description:
Come take a field trip to New Reality Co and see how they're combining VR with physical experiences, as well as adding additional senses to their programs. There is a limit to 10 attendees, so that everyone has a chance to experience everything first hand. If there's enough of a wait list, a 2nd session can be added on Monday from 2 - 4.

[http://newreality.co/](http://newreality.co/)

[http://giantofficial.com/](
http://giantofficial.com/) - Trapped in an active war-zone, two parents struggle to distract their young daughter by inventing a fantastical tale. Inspired by real events, this immersive virtual-reality experience transports the viewer into the family's makeshift basement shelter. The parents' fairytale intensifies as bomb-blasts draw closer and closer...

[https://www.treeofficial.com/](https://www.treeofficial.com/) - This virtual-reality project transforms you into a rainforest tree. With your arms as branches and your body as the trunk, youâ€™ll experience the treeâ€™s growth from a seedling into its fullest form and witness its fate firsthand.

title: Blockchains & Smart Contracts For Creative Coders, Makers, Interaction & Game Designers
description:
This is the first of 3 workshops on Blockchain, Smart Contracts, Deep Identity, and the emerging decentralized Internet Of Agreements. Check out [The Sense Collective's Project page](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2017/project/19) for more details. 

[Download The Sense Collectiveâ€™s Brochure](https://www.dropbox.com/s/nb9jpqoirip0lso/Sense%20Collective%20Brochure%20Final.pdf?dl=0).

EcoBlockchain is a blockchain-based framework that connects databases and analysis engines, creates context, and delivers sense intelligence. It is a framework for registering, identifying, and tracking sensor data and public works activities which rely on real-world measurements and scientific analysis.

 The Sense Collective introduces the hardware (Perceptagon) and Software (LumenOS/EcoBlockchain) to transition our cooperative management of social and natural capital to the decentralized web. Perceptagon is a device that plugs into our natural world and the forces that change it.
It is a hardware and software system specializing in the collection, analysis and distribution of biometric, atmospheric, environmental, geospatial and temporal data. Additionally it is a node in the network.

We will examine the distinct aspects of the "old" internet, and database infrastructure which is currently crumbling under the sheer volume of "Big Data" which floods corporate "Cloud" servers every day.

Using *Raspberry Pi* nodes, hosting *Bitcoin* and *Ethereum* Light Clients, a *Lykke Wallet and Global Exchange portal*, and several innovative blockchain alternatives and plug-ins *(Nexus Earth, PIVX, BOSCoin, Expanse, DASH, SONM, GOLEM)* The LumenOS Operating System hosts over 100 Geospatial database frameworks, Simulation Modeling tools, AI Decision Support, alongside an amazing combination of Creative Coding frameworks, Generative Display, Sonification, Projection Mapping, and other creative tools, 

This first workshop will focus on:
**1) Creating your first Deep Identity account.**
We will check out Uport, OneName, Truffle/Metamask, Token, and a few other emerging standard-bearers who are addressing the requirements of a decentralized identity. 

**2.) Organizing your specification interface** to begin training your own personal AI Chatbot, and Decision Support framework, 

__Blockchain & Smart Contracts 101__
We will spend the first 1/2 of the session going through the various components of blockchain technologies and I will provide enough detail for you to spend the 2nd portion of the workshop developing your own mini-project, smart contract, cooperative fund, Public Art Intervention, or Citizen Science experiment with one of several available physical computers and sensor kits. I will have examples from MaxMSP, Arduino, and P5js as to how creative coding can be used to make sense of the various blockchain transactions in a way that helps to expand these concepts into broader use within our society.

title: Physical Sensors in Virtual Reality: Connecting Arduino to Unity
description:
This session will introduce the tools needed to connect Arduino to your Unity virtual reality experience/game/360 video/whatever else you make in the program. The first half of this session will be a brief overview of the different methods and boards you can use and the second half will be walking you through setting up an Arduino Uno and coding a simple script in Unity to get a potentiometer to rotate a cube with serial data. If people would like to stay a bit longer and work on trying different sensors or different interactions in Unity we can make that happen as well. 

Slides to follow along [here](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1pW6ynoino0gTy9-9q4digZarzsa_fZ7xFl2VmenRqZA/edit?usp=sharing). We will fill in the missing steps in the session.

title: Plot(ting) Devices - Controlling Machines that Can Cut and Draw
description:
Plotting machines allow computer numeric control of a blade to cut thin materials in very precise shapes and depths. The blade could also be replaced with pens, including conductive ink-filled ones, to draw very intricate patterns. ITP is in possession of three: the Silhouette Cameo, the Silhouette Curio, and the Craft Robo Pro. This workshop will cover the basics of using these machines.

Go from vectors to cut outs. Make your own stickers. Cut out a ransom note. Create vinyl resists for PCBs. Cut things that are not laser cuttable, such as metals and materials that release toxins. This will be a hands-on workshop.

If you'd like, come prepared with a vector file to cut your own vinyl laptop sticker.

Link to the Google Slides here:
https://goo.gl/bK5pqb

title: Making Clocks & Expanding Notions of Time
description:
Two years ago I built a Daylight Clock as part of my thesis project at ITP - since then I have been living with this clock reflecting extensively on the experience of time...expanding my own understanding of time. 

I will be giving a TEDx talk in a few weeks about this work, and will start the session by giving my talk. I will follow up with more details about my clock making endeavors and would love to receive any feedback on the talk. Lastly we will open the room for a larger discussion about clocks, time, and experience. 

If you want to check out my Daylight Clock in advance, you can download the Google chrome extension at [chrome.ariellehein.com](http://chrome.ariellehein.com)

title: Hacking the physical in 360 video: Mask-driven storytelling workshop
description:
VR headsets are horrible.
As tools to tell stories through, they are clearly problematic. It is clear that these functional commercial objects are not designed by the storytellers - who are left grappling with the task of delivering emotionally compelling content through the undignified things.

This session asks: What possibilities will emerge if storytellers tap into the power of the mask itself, and take ownership of its design and construction - as part of the process of the story they seek to tell?

Because masks, we should remember, are powerful. All over the world, masks have a huge role in human cultures. Their ability to impact both those inside them and those outside them is used in countless ways - from the sacred to the profane.

This quick-n-dirty workshop will have three parts:

1) A brainstorming session for rapid prototyping of a project. One can work alone or in teams.
2) Creating a fully functional 360 headset-mask using cardboard templates, by hacking a Google Cardboard.
3) Shooting a quick one-shot 360 video to go especially with that mask. I will show how to get a 360 video up on Youtube within minutes of its shooting, using the Samsung gear cameras and their handy software.

Once this session is done, we will have a little exhibition of head-mounted projects.

title: Rapid 360 video: Film, edit, put on Youtube in 15 minutes, with Samsung cameras
description:
This is a short session on how to use the Samsung Gear 360 cameras, which are superior to the Ricohs in both quality and, in my opinion, ease of use.

Using the Samsung software, we will look at how easy it is to film, edit, and throw a 360 video on Youtube, to be viewed with a google cardboard.

If you are at all intimidated by 360 video, this is for you!!
Also useful if you simply have not used these cameras, of which we have plenty in the ER.

title: Field Trip:  Design Do Discover at Marymount
description: ITP graduate and former camper James Dec is hosting the Design Do Discover workshop for educators at Marymount School of New York.  Anyone interested in visiting and meeting their counselors and viewing their projects, seeing their learning spaces, Iâ€™ll take a field trip up there this Friday morning, leaving from 4th Ave and 14th at 8 AM.  Or, meet in front of Marymount at 8:30 am.

title: Interactive Space: Designing Learning/Working Environments
description: ITP is featured in the book Make Space for its reprogrammable architecture.  Join a round table discussion on experiences in interactive space and bring your ideas for blending physical and digital interaction within learning and working spaces.  I'll bring slides from designing active learning spaces within schools and share strategies for human interaction in dispersed teaching and learning design, work with Thornburg's "Campfires in Cyberspace" and how this plays out in high tech and low tech environments.

title: EcoBlockchain Session #2: Meta-Data As Cognitive Love Letter To Future Knowledge Workers: Sentiment Analysis, Semantic Parsing,
description:
Cybernetic AI/Human partnerships require humans to **learn new techniques to realize the full capabilities of Human/Machine knowledge partnership.** Join us for as long as you like as you complete your project for the show, and **we can see where a chatbot, AI Knowledge Repository or Blockchain Identity could fit in your project.** You will gain increased abilities to spot the many AI frameworks in your life, while learning how to improve your relationships and agency with AI. You will also learn how to create your first triple-authenticated Blockchain Identity which we will authenticate via your Twitter, Facebook and Github accounts so you have your first attributable blockchain identity with it's own digital wallet, so you can embed your payment details and other information in every digital artifact you create. 


Meta-tagging of data is like leaving a love note for future knowledge workers.Â It's kind of like those amazing notes my wife leaves in my briefcase, attached to some magazine article she has clipped for me, because she knows me so well, and knows the article will give me inspiration & other socio-cognitive benefits. 
Meta-tagging data **with your authenticated and attributable blockchain identity** ensures that anyone using your valuable data, made ever more valuable by your specification activities, can compensate you for your work.

**Alexa, I feel like you barely understand me** 
But what if our relationship with AI and chatbot decision support systems is in a rocky patch? **Chatbot and AIÂ Couples Therapy** is needed to establish more conscious and deliberate systems to actively work on our relationships with the AI and Cognitive Intelligence frameworksÂ we have come to rely on, and more importantly, Â a method for identifying the many hidden AI systems which weÂ have given great power.  

**How many AI and Automation Services that you use give you the ability to adjust the underlying Persona Sentiment, the general picture the application has of who you really are, and what you really want?**

If an application or service collects data on you, develops a dynamic impression of who you are, and what you want, Shouldn't there be a Persona & Identity Specification Interface for users to adjust the AI's impression of our persona and identity. How do we get what we want from the world, and more specifically from our digital systems, applications and services, if we don't have ultimate control over our Digital Personas and Identity?

This workshop will examine Identity within the blockchain space, and examine several novel approaches to **semantic specification** and **Data Mining of Social Network Identities** as a primary force in **predictive insight generation**, **election influence**, product promotion, and overall **cognitive mapping of human interactions**. 


**Systems Of Systems** & **Complex Adaptive Systems Dynamics** are easily identifiable once you learn the right signals and methods for **Exposition** and **Discovery** of these systems. 

With the right frameworks and interface modules, we can establish our own **Cybernetic Governance Models** & Regulations which set the stage for our initiating **Corporate Use Agreements** which we can assign to our personal or business data by way of Semantic Specification activities that we can quickly and intensively apply across an entire organization, or personal knowledge management framework.
