AI Relationship Management is not just for data scientists & the occasional looping in of the creative strategists & agencies. **Semantic Reasoning Boot** camp will quickly shift your businesses orientation, and your creative design process to the powerful tools currently available for organizing knowledge systems so they keep up with the rapidly advancing abilities of our technology frameworks.

The Sense Collective has spent 2 years developing our own tools and plug-ins, as well as several physical computer and sensor frameworks which give regular citizens and businesses access to cooperative knowledge frameworks. These powerful computational collective intelligence systems have mainly been used by hedge funds, and recently political campaigns for the 2-way leverage they provide for:
-**Analyzing natural language expression**
-**Extracting useful predictive insights**
-**Finding just the right language to use in outgoing communications meant to influence someone's opinion or action**. (this is currently used as more of a dark art, we will discuss defense against the dark arts type work as well as methods to use this force for human benefit).

Watson, Alexa, and the as-yet nameless automation systems AI of the near future provide decision support and governance for automation of driverless cars, robot factory workers, etc. This will surely put some people out of work, but the most powerful performance to be realized from these systems comes **when domain experts partner with AI in active coordinated strategies which continuously feed back human-specifications for realtime refinement as the AI continuously learns and optimizes what us human operators specify as the ideal result of the system.**

title: Computerized Embroidery
description: ITP has two CNC sewing machines that can embroider for you! We will review using the computerized embroidery machine and discuss how to use conductive materials with the embroidery machine.

title: Audience Engagement Strategies for your Interactive Project
description:
Engaging audiences for interactive projects can take many forms, ranging in scope from a quick swipe to fully immersive AR/VR projects.  Community engagement campaigns can look very different and yield a variety of outcomes  including; user comments, exhibition touch screens,  and live event that bring people together for a group experience. All of these different types of audience engagement can connect communities of interest and deepen the impact of the project that you have created and plan to share with the world.

Workshop presenter Erika Howard is the Director of Audience Engagement and Special Projects at POV, television's longest-running showcase for independent non-fiction films. Since 1988, the Emmy Award winning POV series has been sharing the boldest and most innovative documentaries with American audiences on PBS and through its online presence with POV Digital.  Erika is joined by documentary filmmaker and multimedia producer, Ann Bennett, whose PBS credits include, â€œThrough A Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a Peopleâ€, â€œCitizen Kingâ€, â€œFisk Jubilee Singersâ€ and â€œAfricans in Americaâ€.

During this informal, hour long workshop, Erika and Ann will share their experiences with creating outreach campaigns for community engagement and audience participation. The discussion topics will include; identifying target audiences, creating a strategic outreach campaign, content development, and online presence as well as the importance of both quantitative and qualitative analytics and reporting.

ERIKA HOWARD - http://www.pbs.org/pov

ANN BENNETT - http://www.pbs.org/independentlens/films/through-a-lens-darkly, http://www.pbs.org/wgbh//amex/mlk, https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aia/home.html

title: Blockchain 101- Basic Use, Wallet + Exchange Security, Identity, Smart Contracts, Investing in ICO's, Hacking The Planet
description: This will be a general overview of Bitcoin, Ethereum, and other Blockchains, Basic Use, Wallet + Exchange Security, Identity, Smart Contracts, Investing in ICO's, Hacking The Planet. In comments you can request topics or ask questions directly to be covered in the workshop

title: Learn how to document ITP Innovators on Wikipedia presented by AfroCROWD
Camp Cleanup
description:
This is a time to clean up and pack up. We will be breaking down the counselor stand. You will be clearing out your blue bins and lockers, cleaning up from the night before, and claiming all your personal belongings. 

Hours: The Floor will be open regular hours.

Sessions: Please do not post any sessions on Clean Up Day. If you would like to request an exception to this, please ask Kate.

Working on Projects: You can work on projects on this day so long as it doesn't interfere with any clean up activities and you clean up after yourselves.

Counselor Availability: Counselors will be on shift all day EXCEPT 12-1:30 when Counselor HQ will be closed for our end-of-camp counselor celebration. Counselors will be primarily be focused on Camp Cleanup but can answer other questions pending availability.

Lockers: Please empty your locker and return the lock to a counselor by 4PM on Thursday. At 4:00 we will begin inspecting and emptying lockers. You are welcome (and encouraged) to return your lock sooner than that. To return a lock, please hand it directly to a counselor and tell them your name. DO NOT leave your lock on your empty locker or leave it sitting on the counselor desk. You must return it to a counselor who will mark it as returned in our system.

Blue Bins: Blue Bins (in the shop) as well as ALL other personal belongings must be cleared out by 11PM on Thursday, June 29th.

title: Show Setup
description:
Install your project!

Classrooms will be available all day. If furniture needs to be moved please check in with a Camp Counselor.

Equipment is on a first come, first served basis.

Please don't check out any VR equipment until after 9PM on Tuesday. It is needed for a VR class.

title: Registration & Opening Party
description:
This will include food, drink, opening announcements & orientation, and other festivities!

LOCATION: 721 Broadway, 4th Floor South, New York, NY. Take the left elevators to the 4th Floor

title: ES6: The JavaScript We've Waited Decades For
description:
This hands-on workshop is aimed at JavaScript programmers who have yet to delve into ES6, the next generation of JavaScript weâ€™ve waited decades for. Weâ€™ll discuss *many* of the major aspects of ES6 and make comparisons between ES6 code and its equivalent â€” when possible â€” in ES5. Weâ€™ll cover arrow functions, the const and let operators, deconstructing, default function parameter values, the spread operator, string templates, and promises.

## Intended Audience
This workshop is intended for JavaScript programmers experienced in versions of JavaScript before ES6, such as ES5, etc.

## Slides and Code
A GitHub repository containing the slides and code for this workshop is available at [https://github.com/code-warrior/es6--the-javascript-weve-been-waiting-decades-for](https://github.com/code-warrior/es6--the-javascript-weve-been-waiting-decades-for).

title: Launch Weekend: Intro to p5.js
description:
p5.js is a JavaScript library that enables you to easily add animation, sound, and  interactivity to your web pages.  p5.js shares the same goal as Processing: to allow artists, designers, and beginner coders a way to quickly and easily sketch and prototype their ideas in code. This workshop will cover the basics of p5.js. 

The format of this session will be a short lecture followed by a hands-on group activity. Participants are encouraged to bring their own laptop. 

Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels, although the emphasis of this workshop will be on fundamental programming concepts. 

[Link to Resources and Code Samples](http://goo.gl/PF49Vq)

title: Launch Weekend: High Five Gloves
description:
A switch is something that enables or prevents the flow of electricity. It creates or breaks the physical connection of two conductors in a circuit. Switches can come in familiar forms: the toggle switch that controls the light in a room; the slide switch on the barrel of a classic flashlight; the blinking red â€œDO NOT TOUCHâ€ button on the control panel of a failing intergalactic vessel. But switches can also be designed for less common scenarios: the twirl of a moustache; the meeting of eyes; the act of two bodies embracing. Regardless of form or application, the nature of a switch is to connect.

In this workshop we will build social switches - body-based switches that respond to a physical social interaction between to people. Using electronic components and conductive materials we will light up your high fives!

What you will learn:

* circuit building
* methods for working with unconventional conductive materials
* design considerations for wearable technology
* how to bring your high fives to the next level

You can [download the slides here](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1sxGnq26hJR3J10ejDD4WOAGqngXwLFVv)

title: Launch Weekend: Making Time
description:
In this session, you'll learn how to build a custom clock from an off-the-shelf clock mechanism. We'll supply the mechanisms, clock hands, and various materials.  

Clockmaking  is a great excuse to learn various fabrication tools: the laser cutter, CNC mill, vinyl cutter, pen plotter robots, drills, and various hand tools.  We foresee a lot of creative variations from this workshop. When we're done, we'll hang them all for display.

Note: It is strongly recommended that you complete Shop Safety training before this session. There will be some fabrication options for those who haven't completed it, but many that do require it.

[Clock Club Github Repo](https://github.com/ITPNYU/clock-club)

title: Launch Weekend: Making Time Electronics Edition
description:
In this session, we will open up the off-the-shelf clock mechanisms we used in the [first Making Time session](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2018/session/7).  We'll explore how these devices work and make modifications so we can control them with an Arduino.

What you should know beforehand:

* What an  [Arduino](http://www,arduino.cc) microcontroller is.  
* How to program an  [Arduino](http://www,arduino.cc) or Arduino-compatible board (if you've managed to make an LED blink with it, you're ready)

What you should bring:

* Your own [Arduino](http://www,arduino.cc) or Arduino-compatible board
* Your own laptop, with the [Arduino IDE](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software) already installed on it.

There will be some soldering, some programming, and a little electronics.

title: Metal 3d printing to get to space
description:
This session is an introduction to metal 3d printing. 

But we will do so from a design and application point of view (the useful way).

We will discuss different printing materials, technologies and what are the differences between more commonly available 3d printers.

We will see some samples and how to approach designing parts.

Finally will talk about an example on how 3d metal printed parts are used to reduce cost and lead time for space applications.

Most important you will get to touch and feel printed parts!

title: Solar Power Hour (and a half)
description:
Photovoltaic (PV) material directly converts light into usable electricity. We'll do exactly that in this hands-on workshop. We'll look at a few different types of PV material like thin-film and monocrystalline silicon; learn what PV is realistically capable of; see the additional electronics necessary to interface them to batteries or our own projects; and weather permitting, take PV outside.

Supplies - we'll use solar equipment available at ITP, but bring your own if you have any!

This is based on the solar section of this class: 
 [fddrsn.net/teaching/energy](http://www.fddrsn.net/teaching/energy/)

title: Kinetic Energy
description:
In this hands-on session we'll learn more about electricity by making our own. Any electric motor is also an electric generator, and we can hack them to turn kinetic energy into electricity. Almost all electricity we use comes via kinetic energy (except solar power - see Solar Power Hour-and-a-half). Power plants, regardless of fuel, make heat to make steam to turn turbines to move magnets past conductors and generate electricity. Wind turbines too - except the sun powers the the weather converting heat to moving air. 

This session is based on the kinetic section of this class:  [fddrsn.net/teaching/energy](http://www.fddrsn.net/teaching/energy/)

title: Physical Computing: Off the Grid and Into the Wild.
description: Find out what it takes to untether your physical computing prototype from your laptop and release it into the wild.  Learn the basics of batteries, solar, Wi-Fi / cellular / satellite communication and sleep modes.  Get the download on batteries â€“ what kinds are out there and all the factors that determine how long one will last.  Try out different solar panels, and learn about charge controllers.  Check out cellular communication with the Particle Electron, and satellite communication via the Rock Block.  Find out why sleep modes are so important, and see a range of hardware approaches to reducing power consumption such as using a bare microprocessor and power switching for auxiliary devices.  Bring all this info together using both data sheet and empirical approaches to building a current budget, to predict how long your untethered device will last.  Info and strategies can be applied to a range of projects and products including wearables, IOT devices, and environmental monitoring.  This session will be a mix of info, hardware show and tell, and some hands-on activities with a range of current measurement tools.

title: Hacking Sensors for Climate Change
description: What opportunities has the Arduino ecosystem opened up for changing the way we monitor and understand the environment?  How do scientific sensor companies get away with charging 10x to 50x the cost of electronic parts?   Can we still depend on NOAA and the NSF to lead the way on climate change data collection?  We will explore these questions through discussion and by looking at case studies of low cost open source hardware alternatives to commercial sensors.  Topics include DIY CO2 monitoring, ocean temperature and current tracking, radar based river flow gages, and measuring drinking water turbidity.  We will look at sensor applications and calibration issues for science, citizen science and data based environmental design. Strategies for transitioning hardware from a single prototype to a small production run will be shared.  We will also discuss the different business and production models for bringing hardware to a larger community via peer reviewed journal publication, open source licensing and for profit ventures.   The focus here is on environmental sensors, but most of the issues discussed apply to hardware development in general.   The workshop will include the presentation of case studies through documentation and hands on experimentation with circuits.  We will conclude with a small group exercise to workshop ideas and gather interest in future collaborations.

title: Telling Stories Through Games: Procedural and Shared Narratives
description:
Games (and similar interactive experiences) are a unique storytelling medium in that they can a) leverage process and embodiment to allow players to experience stories for themselves; b) permit reciprocal narrative exchange, where players can add to existing stories or create wholly new ones. 

In this session, we'll  1) play some weird games, 2) discuss how narratives functions within games, and 3) create, test,  & critique concepts for interactive storytelling experiences.

The session will include a lecture component, a play component and a design component. Experience with game design is not necessary. The design component will focus on analogue games, unless participants bring in their own software skills and an ability to code at breakneck speed.

title: Creating Player Pianos with MaxMSPJitter
description:
Learn how to build your own self-playing piano using the coding platform MaxMSPJitter.  In this introductory workshop we will go over the basics of Max in order to construct a unique digital player piano, each with their own logic system, controls, and behaviors.

Please bring a laptop with MaxMSPJitter installed. 30 day trial licenses are available at the cycling74.com website and ER laptops also have copies of MaxMSPJitter installed.

title: 3D Scanning Your Own Digital Avatar
description:
We will get our (digital) hands dirty creating 3D scans of each other that will then be  rigged using digital tools. By the end of this workshop you will learn the workflow for transforming your 3D scan into a walking and dancing avatar fully compatible with gaming engines such as Unity and Unreal Engine.

3D scanning tools will be provided in class but students with an Adobe Creative Cloud license are encouraged to bring a laptop for the rigging portion of the class. 3D scans cost $7 to download. If you wish to use your own scan for the remainder of the class create an account at ItSeez3D (https://accounts.itseez3d.com/accounts/register/). If you don't wish to spend money then you can use the scan that instructor will provide on a hard drive.

title: PoseNet in Tensorflow.js: real-time human pose estimation in the browser.
description:
In May of this year, in collaboration with Google Creative Lab, I released a [TensorFlow.js version of PoseNet](https://medium.com/tensorflow/real-time-human-pose-estimation-in-the-browser-with-tensorflow-js-7dd0bc881cd5), a machine learning model which allows for real-time human pose estimation in the browser. 

**Try a live demo [here](https://storage.googleapis.com/tfjs-models/demos/posenet/camera.html)**

![demo](https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1200/1*BKZqEPtvM-6xwarhABZQnA.gif)

Pose estimation has many uses, from [interactive](https://vimeo.com/128375543) [installations](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I5__9hq-yas) that [react](https://vimeo.com/34824490) to the [body](https://vimeo.com/2892576) to [augmented reality](https://www.instagram.com/p/BbkKLiegrTR/), [animation](https://www.instagram.com/p/Bg1EgOihgyh/?taken-by=millchannel), [fitness uses](https://www.runnersneed.com/expert-advice/gear-guides/gait-analysis.html), and more. While many alternate pose detection systems have been open-sourced, all require specialized hardware and/or cameras, as well as quite a bit of system setup. With PoseNet running on TensorFlow.js anyone with a decent webcam-equipped desktop or phone can experience this technology right from within a web browser.  

Underneath the hood, PoseNet uses a convolutional neural network and algorithms to estimate single or multiple poses.  The complexity of this has been extracted away into easy to an easy to use API;  Amateur developers can tinker with and use this technology with just a few lines of code, without needing to understand anything about machine learning.

## This session will go through

* Demos of PoseNet, and a high-level explanation of the algorithms, and the effects that changing the parameters have on speed and accuracy.
* An explanation of what Tensorflow.js is and why as a creative you would want to do machine learning in javascript in the browser.
* An overview of other way pose estimation has been done (Kinect, OpenPose), and how PoseNet does things differently.
* Workshop on how to get PoseNet up and running with a few lines of code in p5.

## Audience

Up until the part about getting PoseNet up and running, this is for anyone that is interested in emerging technology and artificial intelligence.  The workshop section will be geared towards those with basic understanding of Javascript and p5.

title: Live Video Processing with Max/MSP/Jitter
description:
This workshop is an introduction to building video performance systems in Max/MSP/Jitter, a node-based multimedia programming environment. If you're interested in audiovisual performance, VJ-ing, or experimental cinema, this workshop is for you!

In the workshop, we'll cover:

- basic Max concepts like objects, messages, bangs, and toggles
- how Jitter represents images and video as matrices of pixel data
- bringing webcam video into Max
- playing video files and managing video playlists
- chroma keying and video feedback
- building user interfaces and saving presets

You should bring a computer that has Max 7 installed so that you can patch along with me and try out code examples. I'd also recommend bringing a set of videos that you're interested in working with.

Max can be downloaded with a 30-day trial license at [cycling47.com](https://cycling74.com/downloads), and there are also ER laptops with copies of Max installed.

All of the Max patches that we'll make in this workshop can be found on GitHub, along with more resources for diving deeper into Jitter:
[https://github.com/oshoham/itp-camp-2018-jitter-workshop](https://github.com/oshoham/itp-camp-2018-jitter-workshop)

title: Making Art With Your Graphics Card: Intro to Shaders
description:
Fragment shaders are programs that generate images on your computer's graphics card by computing the color of each pixel on the screen simultaneously. Because they run in parallel, fragment shaders are really fast, which makes them a powerful tool for creative coding, game development, and live video performance.

In this workshop, we'll discuss how to think about computation in parallel and go over the basics of the GLSL shader programming language. For the sake of simplicity and time, we'll focus on 2D animation and image processing, but we'll touch briefly on how the same techniques could be applied to 3D graphics. We'll also talk about how to use shaders in creative coding frameworks like Processing, openFrameworks, and Max/MSP/Jitter. By the end of the workshop, you'll hopefully be able to read and understand other people's GLSL shader code, and maybe even feel comfortable writing your own shaders!

This workshop is aimed at people with a basic understanding of programming and an interest in computer graphics. You should already be familiar with concepts like variables, if statements, and functions. You should bring a computer, but we'll be using a browser-based editor for GLSL examples, so you won't need to set anything up beforehand.

All of the slides and code examples can be found on GitHub at [https://github.com/oshoham/making-art-with-your-graphics-card](https://github.com/oshoham/making-art-with-your-graphics-card).

title: Light It Up
description:
In this lecture and demonstration, I'll cover the basics of addressable LEDs: what you can make, where to buy them, some materials you can use to diffuse them, how to properly power them off of batteries or wall power, and how to program them with an Arduino. From there, I'll demonstrate how you can use inexpensive hardware to drive larger installations of addressable LEDs using computer based lighting software. 

BYO Arduino; we'll have some supplies for you to follow along.

title: Making Data Tangible: Part I
description:
Our data forms an intangible version of us, whether it is the facebook profile, spotify stream history, or credit card transactions. Yet it has tangible consequences on our life.  

In this two part workshop, we spend the first lecture on data visualization design. We will talk about ethical data visualization design and how to spot it in various examples. We will review concepts such as "visual trumpery", "data-to-ink ratios", and â€œdata physicalizationâ€. We then turn to geographic data and demonstrate how to visualize it and turn it into a physical object. 

The instructions are at 
https://beta.observablehq.com/@pstuffa/why-visualize-data
https://beta.observablehq.com/@pstuffa/hey-d3
https://beta.observablehq.com/@pstuffa/lets-make-a-line-chart


You'd be ready to make your own in Session 2 https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2018/session/25

title: Making Data Tangible: Part II
description:
Our data forms an intangible version of us, whether it is the facebook profile, spotify stream history, or credit card transactions. Yet it has tangible consequences on our life.  

This is the second part of https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2018/session/24 

Bring your computer and we will have a hands-on coding and making session. We will code together using New York City Open Data (https://opendata.cityofnewyork.us/) to create a physical object, which will then be laser cut or 3D printed at ITP.

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1ddVm2Qe-bYMf-u81TvRnOmUr3aUyWVdmvwslLfzPs8o/edit?usp=sharing

https://beta.observablehq.com/@pstuffa/making-maps-with-nyc-open-data

title: Big Picture : Tiny Screens
description:
This session will function as an exploration in distributed, human/hardware multithreading.  All participants will work in parallel to develop a portion of an emergent animation built out of a single row of 1 color, 128px X 64px OLED screens.

We will look at methods in Arduino to draw and animate for this piece of hardware and find a way to embrace its constraints.  Each camper will be in charge of a single screen's animation, but must collaborate and negotiate with their neighbours to design the overall animation in real-time.

https://github.com/DigitalFuturesOCADU/hardwareResources

title: Step Right Up! Re-imagining carnival games
description:
In this hands-on workshop we'll create physical/digital games rooted in the tradition of classic Carny fare. What could you make using well known, and possibly deceptively-difficult, games with updated technology? What other contexts or messages could be told or supported using skill-based physical games? We'll start with a short introduction to the history and examples of games and then open it up for brainstorming and team-forming. The bulk of the time will be spent creating prototypes of games, finishing with a walk down the midway of our participants' creations. 

It's gonna be quick! So bring ideas and materials (cardboard, microcontrollers, sensors) if you have them!

title: Walk on the Wild Side - American Museum of Natural History outing
description: Come explore the American Museum of Natural History! We'll check out the new Unseen Oceans exhibit and other highlights from the permanent halls. Limit 20 people.

title: Everything is a screen!
description:
In this hands-on projection mapping workshop we'll learn how to use simple projectors to turn any 2d or 3d surface around us intro a screen!

Working with both videos and interactive visuals as source materials, we'll use MadMapper to map projected planes onto real surfaces and create anything from optical illusions to video sculptures.

The workshop will cover the basics of projection plane mapping as well as creation and composition for 2d and 3d surfaces. Finally, we'll hot-swap HDMIs in an audiovisual projection party!

title: Zaha Hadid 101: 3D Modeling in Rhino and Grasshopper
description:
This hands-on workshop will introduce simple and complex ways of 3D-modeling in Rhino and Grasshopper. The goal of this workshop is to understand Rhino as a tool to do many things. I will go over how to prepare 3D models for fabrication purposes such as 3D printing and CNC-ing, and how to export objects for your VR environment or ThreeJS sketches.  

Students will learn how to translate their sketches to 3D geometry using essential Rhino tools and techniques such as curves, surfaces, and solids. Then we will transition into making more complex geometry using different plug-ins for the Rhino environment such as Paneling Tools and Grasshopper. 

Grasshopper is an interface to make parametric, algorithm-based and generative designs. Its GUI (Graphical User Interface) makes scripting, programming and generation of crazy looking geometries possible without any knowledge of writing code! 

For this workshop, I prefer everyone to bring in a Windows computer as Rhino works best on that. You can simply check one out from the ER OR you can install bootcamp on your Mac and partition it to have Windows (this is what I do). If you cannot get your hands on one, then you can take notes and follow along! :) 

### **Rhino Download** 
Rhino is free to download and try for 90 days. Please download the latest version (Rhino 6) as it includes Grasshopper!  

[https://www.rhino3d.com/download](https://www.rhino3d.com/download) 

### **Grasshopper Download**
If you already have Rhino installed on Windows, then make sure Grasshopper is installed by typing Grasshopper in the Rhino command bar. If it does not pop up, then you may download it from this link. 

[http://www.grasshopper3d.com/page/download-1](http://www.grasshopper3d.com/page/download-1) 

### **Paneling Tools Download**
Lastly, after everything is installed. Please download this very cool plug-in called Paneling Tools!

[https://wiki.mcneel.com/labs/panelingtools](https://wiki.mcneel.com/labs/panelingtools)

title: Intro to Adobe Illustrator (so useful for the laser cutter)
description:
And intro session for anyone with no illustrator experience or rudimentary experience. We will cover:

Setting up and navigating the artboard
Basic tools
Making shapes
Layers/organizing
Selections
Hot keys
Pathfinder tools
Masks and compound paths
Basic laser cutter set up

This is for anyone who wants to laser cut and has no illustrator experience or anyone who just wants to pick up more illustrator experience. :)

This wonâ€™t go into the laser cutter itself, there are other sessions and walkthroughs that will take you through the machine! 

Please come with illustrator installed or check out a computer from ITP.

title: Working with Plastic (when a 3D printer can't hack it)
description:
Get acquainted with basic techniques for cutting, bending and joining blocks and sheets of plastic. This encompasses a family of materials from the commonplace to the exotic, with a diverse range of capabilities. When you need sizes, strength or other material properties that 3D printers can't offer, working with solid plastic sheet may be the answer.

We will experiment with several powerful and versatile techniques for bending and joining plastic sheet. Tentatively including:

-Hot bending acrylic and Starboard.

-Using fasteners: drilling and tapping 

-Solvent bonding acrylic, ABS, PVC

-Plastic welding various sheets

title: Programming audio with blocks: Pure Data 101
description:
A first glance of the world of audio programming, using the open source programming language Pure Data, we are going to immerse into noise making algorithms, DIY musical instruments, custom mobile sound apps and weird synth sounds.
Bring a computer and headphones

title: 3D Print the World!
description:
The 3D printing hype is over and all that's left is a powerful tool to bring ideas and solutions into being, if used properly. Knowing how to use a 3D printer is a valuable skill, both for your time at the Camp and in life! 

Most of the confusion around 3D printing can be cleared up by knowing how it works and how should you approach a 3D model with 3D Printing in mind. In this course we will learn about various 3D printers and how they are made and function. Then we will focus on the very common "Fused Filament Fabrication" or FFF 3D Printers (Ultimaker, Lulzbot, etc), the different materials you can use to print your models, and common practices and pitfalls of the FFF method. 

We will teach you how to prepare your models for printing in a Slicer program and important settings you have to adjust for each print. We won't go into the 3D modeling world, but we go in details of what makes a model "printable", and how to modify models in Autodesk Meshmixer to ensure a successful print.

title: Algorave: Livecoding Musical Systems
description:
We will be learning how to make and perform algorithmically-defined music/sound using Sonic Pi. We will start by going over some of the history of generative music, investigating examples like the works of Steve Reich or Brian Eno.

 We'll then dive into the basics of making synths, loops, and playing samples in Sonic Pi. We will also cover how to have Sonic Pi send or receive instructions to other devices over midi.

This session will not get into the finer points of music theory, but will instead focus on how to craft and explore systems to generate sounds which we find compelling.

Headphones recommended. If you have a midi controller or instrument that you'd like to try hooking up to Sonic Pi, you are more than welcome to bring it and test it out.

title: You don't know your face yet 1 : Drawing your self-portrait workshop
description:
This workshop focuses on the creation of oneâ€™s portraits, beginning with a hand drawing on paper and then transforming the style using Adobe Photoshop to obtain a unique artistic profile. It is for everyone who wants to create a different profile image other than a normal smiling profile picture. This workshop is divided into two parts - drawing and Photoshop. Enrolling in both classes is recommended, but students can also take either one individually. 


Part 1 Drawing 
We take selfies with our phones, but we donâ€™t actually know what our faces look like. By observing yourself for a while, you are forced to focus on your appearance. The drawing workshop consists of both lecture and drawing practice so that students can understand how artists have depicted their self-portraits, and then they will learn to express their portrait with their own style. References such as Albrecht Durer, Egon Schiele, and David Hockney will be provided in the class to expose students to diverse styles of self-portrait drawing. Some utensils will be provided, but students are free to bring their own tools like pencils, crayons, and anything that functions as a writing utensil. Also, bring a printed copy of your best profile photo. Letâ€™s enjoy selfie-drawing!

Due to the nature of the conversational style of class, it is highly recommended that you RSVP to keep the class size small.

title: You don't know your face yet 2 : Basic Photoshop workshop
description:
This workshop focuses on the creation of oneâ€™s portraits, beginning with a hand drawing on paper and then transforming the style using Adobe Photoshop to obtain a unique artistic profile. It is for everyone who wants to create a different profile image other than a normal smiling profile picture. This workshop is divided into two parts - drawing and Photoshop. Enrolling in both classes is recommended, but students can also take either one individually.

Part 2
This is at a beginner level so someone who doesnâ€™t have Photoshop experience can easily follow the directional tools while others who already have knowledge of Photoshop can expand their skills further. 
This workshop will provide examples of how we can modify our selfie drawing and add digital brush tools using Photoshop. So, students can use their selfie drawings or their photo selfie to recreate their profile. Before the class, students are required to download a free trial of the Adobe Photoshop program. They will learn how to adjust style, alter color and draw new lines to create their digitalized portrait.

title: Doing Well and Doing Good:  Opportunities in Social Innovation
description:
More and more, talented people are deciding that a good job means more than just a good salary.

More and more, people are recognizing that believing in the work you do...is priceless.

They want to find work that has meaning, and still be able to pay off their student loans...but don't know where to look.  

Over the last few years, there has been an explosion of opportunities in a number of exciting fields -Social Entrepreneurship, Impact Investing, Micro-finance, Education Reform - that offer the chance to create positive change and make a decent living -  delivering the promise of both doing well, and doing good.  

This class will:

  â€¢ Offer an overview of some of the leading players and activities working in the social innovation space. 

 â€¢ Help folks who want to find a job in this space understand where to look for opportunities, and offer insights into how to take advantage of them.

If you are a mid-career professional looking to transition, a college student trying to find your path, or simply someone interested in some of the extraordinary and innovative work being done to try to make our world a better place, this class is for you.

title: Resist!  Intro to Tech and Political Activism
description: Learn about an explosion of companies, products, and tools that are helping to promote democratic and peaceful societies, empower human rights activists, create more efficient government services, and more.

title: Show Don't Tell: Project Photography
description:
Documenting your projects is important! Good documentation can elevate your efforts and a bad one can undermine it all. 

In this photography crash course we will first learn about basics of photography and what lenses to choose for our subjects. We will then build a standard product shoot setup and i will teach you how to light different objects to make them stand out and emphasize the details we care about. 

After that i will show you how to import and retouch your _RAW_ photos inside _Adobe Photoshop Lightroom_ and remove any imperfections and quickly export for various formats.

title: Eco & Budget-friendly, Free-form Enclosures from Paper Mush
description:
Resin and silicone casting can be expensive and toxic. If you're interested in an eco-friendly, organic shape as an enclosure for your physical computing project consider paper enclosures. They are lightweight and sturdy. 

Iâ€™ll demonstrate how to make clay and balloons molds and show you how to concoct a good texture paper machÃ© mush out of bills (preferably unpaid), receipts, egg cartons and other discarded paper.

title: One Minute Cinema: Project Videography
description:
Sometime words and images don't do your ideas justice. Sometimes just a short, well-made video can better show the functionality and the features you've worked hard to implement in your work.

In this class we first learn about basic coverage principles in cinematography and editing, then we move on to use them in practice when we shoot an example setup. While shooting i will talk about how we approach framing and camera movement to tell a better story about our subject.

We will then import our footage into Adobe Premiere Pro and in there we discuss how to go through them, select our best shots, and put them all together to make a short, engaging, and flowing documentation to showcase our work professionally.

title: Playing the Internet: Web Audio Basics
description: The web browser can be a rich and powerful tool for music production, creating experiences that would not be possible by any other means. This class explores Tone and P5 Sound, two Javascript libraries that serve as wrappers for the Web Audio API. We will cover audio playback, user input (from the mouse, keyboard, mic and camera), and web synthesis (creating sounds from scratch within the browser environment with Javascript programming) to create interactive web-based musical environments. While no musical knowledge is assumed, some basic programming skills will be helpful.

title: Blockchain Programming for Beginners
description:
Blockchain technology has the power to change the world and solve many of the problems that people are facing today.

In this workshop we'll cover how blockchain works from start to finish and use Node.js to create our very own functional blockchain from scratch. We'll cover topics such as mining, hashing, Proof of Work, and other ideas that make blockchain technology special. 

No knowledge of blockchain is needed, but a basic understanding of Node.js and javascript is nice to have. 

**Please come prepared with a laptop with the latest version of Node.js and your favorite text editor installed on it**

title: Launch Weekend: Mini Golf
description:
In this camp-wide session we will combine our many creative forces to create a collaborative, sprawling, ITP-style mini golf course.

*******If you have TOOLS - please bring them! Most useful will be xacto-type knifes, glue-guns, rulers, and scissors.********

It's going to be quick, dirty, whimsical and improvised. Cardboard and other materials (including pre-prepared templates for easy connection to buttons) will be distributed, and we will use the J Space to install the finished sections. 

The golf course will be left intact so people can improve their minigolf skills. 

Hope to see you there!!!

title: Accessibility and Net Art
description:
People with widely varying abilities and perspectives use the Internet on a daily basis. 

For web professionals, there's an increasing ethical and legal imperative to build digital products that are accessible to all people - not just those with specific disabilities. But what are the implications for creative coding / net art projects that operate outside of the e-commerce continuum?

In this session, we'll review basic concepts of web accessibility and then apply them to web-based art projects. What does it mean to create something that only works in Chrome on a laptop, or with a text and background color combination that renders its content invisible to many people?

What could radically inclusive digital art look like? Let's discuss together!

title: Multiple Perspectives: Performance with projections
description:
-Performance with projections
Participants are invited to work solo or in a group and create a 5 minute performance that interacts with projections. 
(performance, working cyclically with the camera and projectors, theme of performance, materials for projections).  with perspective and scale to allow the viewer to experience from different points of view, and plays with ambiguity to invite audiences to become active authors of their experience.

title: My, oh, Maya: Adventures in Topological Modeling
description:
Looking to design game assets? Want to 3D print your own sculpture? Never understood Maya's interface? Come one, come all to a session where you will get a crash course in topological modeling in Autodesk Maya. We'll cover the basics of Maya; a core set of tools needed to model successfully; how to imagine new sculptural worlds; and some basic things to look out for before delivering to the graphics or fabrication pipeline. 

Just a warning: We won't be designing tables and chairs, fam. Bring your imagination and get ready to roll.

title: Designing Play for the Gamer in All of Us
description: How do you intentionally design, fun, unpredictable play? This is a hard question that game & experience designers constantly struggle with.  During this session we will explore different ways to design playful experiences, from recognizing the potential for extended play in fun activities to crafting the right mechanics to support an aesthetic goal. Along the way we'll play a series of simple physical games based around the same mechanic and discuss the different feeling their play evokes.

title: Terrible T - teach people something you are really TERRIBLE at.
description:
This is a hands on learning workshop. Where only 15 % of our time will be used with instructions ;)

Come join us in a fun workshop where you will teach others something that you not only are not familiar, but also have absolutely no skills! 

=

title: (Super)natural Structures: Adventures in Topological Modeling II
description:
From Ernst Haeckel to Iris Van Herpen, artist-scientists have often looked to nature for inspiration. And for good reason. We will deep-dive through the elegant, entangled, and extraordinary structures found across the natural world. Using the tools of 3D CAD modeling, we will play with different ways of recreating these structural forms and imagine opportunities for sculptural experimentation. 

Bring images for inspiration!
Not sure where to look?
Try: 

1) https://www.theguardian.com/books/gallery/2017/nov/01/ernst-haeckel-the-art-of-evolution-in-pictures

2) http://www.atlasgallery.com/artists/karl-blossfeldt

3) https://www.ted.com/talks/louie_schwartzberg_hidden_miracles_of_the_natural_world/up-next

title: PhysComp Gets Real! What happens when your art project has to be manufactured.
description:
Artist and designer Eric Forman will give a behind the scenes look at how his project [TreeShell](http://www.ericforman.com/treeshell) got into the MoMA Design Store collection, and what he learned along the way. The presentation will show:

* How to take a low-fidelity prototype to the next level
* How to shrink circuit boards and deal with battery issues
* How to elegantly hide technology
* How to combine disparate materials that manufacturers don't like combining (like trees and circuits)
* And most importantly when to save money and DIY, and when to suck it up and pay someone

This presentation will be aimed at a general audience, no specific experience is necessary. There will be an extended Q&A at the end so you can ask questions about your own ideas and how to make them.

title: Fashion Pollution Solutions Part 1 of 2 - A Design Charette
description:
It's just terrible. Terrible how much so many of us depend on  and desire the availability of vast amounts of inexpensive clothing. I don't think I need to go into the severity of the pollution and waste:
"Fashion Is the 8th Most Polluting Industry?" (May 2017)
https://ecocult.com/now-know-fashion-5th-polluting-industry-equal-livestock/

"An Update on Microfiber Pollution" Feb 2017)
https://www.patagonia.com/blog/2017/02/an-update-on-microfiber-pollution/

"Love Your Clothes" (a resource for consumers)
https://www.loveyourclothes.org.uk/

Aside from the ecological, socio-political/financial impact that this business has on our earth, there may be a business opportunity here. What is it? How might it work? What are the critical roles & skillsets such a company/effort might require?

We are in NYC, a fashion mecca, with a population that is generally full of urgency to look amazing, and to see fashion that is amazing.

What to do?... Let's have a chat about it... a charette (this session), and a follow-up session. 

!! You must come to both sessions if this is going to have meaning and/or impact !!

We'll form design teams and challenge each other to come up with gold, chestnuts, or at least, a refined set of questions that we can pursue after leaving this session.

Your assignment:
- Do some industry research ahead of time. Who is creating clothing for retail with an approach that addresses these pressing issues.
- Talk to your friends in the industry (indies, majors, boutiques, vintage-ish/recyclers, etc.
- Bring your personal stories and knowledge to the table... make sure you have a point to convey... there are many fashion world horror stories... bring one that has a purpose and a specific point.
- Come prepared with some solid ideas, ones that you've perhaps had an opportunity to ask some knowledgable people about, not guesses.
- What are the fundamentals of how clothes are designed, produced, shipped to stores and/or consumers? What does the fashion supply chain look like?
- Ask yourself... is this an impossible/intractable problem? (ps.. don't be a nay-sayer)

Holy moly this is big... Please bite off a chunk that you can focus on... 

We will start a focused discussion group where we can share info, research findings, etc... I think there's a Camp discussion board / google group... I hope :-)
Look for this if you want to really be involved and if you want to be a team lead.

Ready, steady, go -->

title: Fashion Pollution Solutions Part 2 of 2 - Follow-up & then what?
description:
This is the follow-up session to:
Fashion Pollution Solutions Part 1 of 2 - A Design Charette
https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2018/session/56

What have you thought about and done in the last 12 days, since the end of the first session?

Who, which team, will take up the reins and establish a means to accomplish something in this extremely challenging realm?

What is our responsibility as technology ideators & implementers? 

Are you serious about putting work in on this and *really* doing something about it? What's your plan? Do you have a sense of how a company can get built that has a chance of success in the marketplace? Who will buy your company once it has reached some measure of success?

Teams will present proposals for a panel of experts, and we'll have a follow-up discussion.

title: Design for Speculative Worlds
description:
A story is an open space for possibility, it doesn't have to follow the cultural, social and physical constraints of what is. Instead, a story asks what if? 

This session will be a playful introduction to the process of designing for a story. For the first hour of this session, I'll share the speculative world I've been designing for the past few years.

For the rest of the session, we will create a collective narrative, sketch, prototype, and test objects and systems from our story. 

Speculative design uses storytelling to explore ideas outside of physical constraints. It can be useful for exploring design solutions and reframing socio-economic issues through narrative and story. This kind of storytelling is evident in almost all forms of science fiction and has historically driven how we view the future and the role of technology in our lives. However, media and film have also constrained our expectations of the future and who is valued there.

title: Camp Clean Up Day! (Camp closes at 7PM!)
description:
This is the day when we clean all the things and bring all the things home.

All materials must be removed from Shop Bins by 7PM.

All equipment must be returned to the ER by 7PM.

Everything must be removed from lockers by 7PM. 

All campers must leave the floor by 7PM.

We close early on this day to complete admin tasks and then have a much needed staff dinner with the well-deserving counselors.  Also there is another conference starting at ITP on Thursday morning that we need to ready the floor for.

We will miss you very, very much but please help us to close on time!

title: Camp Orientation
description: Learn everything you need to know about ITP Camp! This is recommended for everyone!

title: Show One Thing Show!
description:
A hybrid talent show / open-mic / show-and-tell extravaganza! Each person will have **ONE MINUTE** + **ONE SLIDE** to present **ONE THING**

For example, you might want to share:

* A project you made
* A place you traveled
* A hobby you have
* A dance you know
* A song you wrote
* A thing you ate

There are only 2 rules for the slide: it must include your NAME, and it cannot include any video content.

It will be a fun opportunity to get to know each other better, we hope everyone will sign up to share :)

### [Add your slide here](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1olh7ezaJc2xAP7ceaADHArKBtYI2YiQUQFA7bTqPs-E/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Show All Things Show And Closing Party!
description:
This year, as part of the closing party we will be having the Show All Things Show!

This is not a formal presentation or a fancy exhibition. This is an opportunity for you to share any and all projects or works in progress you've generated during your time at ITP Camp 2018. Items to put in the Show All Things Show include: materials tests, sketches, rough prototypes, projects-in-process, installations, objects, software, video, sound pieces, immersive experiences, manifestos, demos, or anything else you'd like to share!

Our ideal is to have EVERYONE share something, no matter how small. More details will follow, but if you have any questions or want to talk through ideas, just stop by Counselor HQ!

Note: Sessions leaders are all invited to attend!

Submit your project [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U0-95G3s4tLsBbbFJV2knaTo6vw92Eeuguw0A_KwRY0/edit#gid=0) and also in the [camp website](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2018/project/add)!

title: Friday Fireside - Art jam!!!
description:
All are invited to an amorphic, free-form, noisy, inclusive art jam! What is that? Let's find out! We will have-

-A PA system for people who want to make sound

-Multiple projectors for people who want to make visuals

-Space for movement/dancing

-Room for YOU!

Whatever art you'd like to make, bring it! If you need some specific equipment, let us know in the comments!

title: Friday Fireside | Tejuino Blues
description:
Tejuino Blues

Drinks with Prehispanic roots and a New Yorker bite.  

Join us to taste the flavors of Mexico and explore the roots of a popular Mexican drink, prepared specially in NYC for ITP Camp. Tejuino is a fermented blue corn drink hailing from the western Mexican state of Jalisco, tracing its origins to the WixÃ¡rika community.  The drink is served best cold with green lime juice, a scoop of lime sorbet topped with a rim of salt and ash of corn.  (spiked versions optional)

As a side dish, bite into a crunchy blue corn tostada with a base of guacamole, and a roof of purslane greens and blueberry sauce topped with dry Mexican cheese.

title: Friday Fireside: Papelitos (aka Little Papers) with the Instigators
description:
Let's play the game Papelitos! It's a fun, fast-paced version of charades. Teams compete to guess words written on little papers.

Take a break from your projects to come party with your fellow campers for the last time before the final show! Food and drinks will be provided.

title: Python for beginners
description: Python is a clear and powerful programming language used in domains from digital humanities to artificial intelligence to video games. In this up-and-running-style workshop, you'll get a quick introduction to how the language works while learning how to perform simple text-analysis tasks (like counting words in a text file). No previous programming experience is required, but the workshop is designed to also be appropriate and informative for experienced programmers who just want to get an idea of what Python is like. Bring your laptop and install Anaconda beforehand: https://www.anaconda.com/download/

title: Roll Your Own MFA (Introduction to Self-education)
description:
In this session we will discuss pursuing education in arts & technology through workshops, small programs, tiny schools, conferences, incubators, and other part time & short-term opportunities. For many people professional degrees are out of reach for time, financial, or other practical/personal reasons. However there are many different ways to pursue learning in the arts & technology space outside of degree programs.

In this session I will give a short introduction to self-education and building a school for yourself. I will talk a bit about my own attempts at achieving a self-education comparable to an MFA including some tips & tricks.

After the introduction we will build a course catalog together for a virtual school starting from a base list of educational opportunities and experiences. Participants can add other programs, opportunities, books, movies, and ideas to the list. We will then discuss some of these options and consider how you can put pieces from the catalog together to make your own educational program.

A previous workshop from ITP can be viewed here:
https://vimeo.com/172792458

Session documentation is available here:
http://bit.ly/unschoolcatalog

title: Sunday Tarot: Collaborative storytelling with oracle decks
description: Tarot reading is a kind of collaborative storytelling in which two individuals help one another build a narrative from set of symbols and tropes, randomly drawn from the Tarot deck. A Tarot reading is very similar to talk therapy or collaborative storytelling games. In this session, I'll show you a bit about the symbolism, semiotics and structure that surround the Tarot and similar divination techniques, and introduce the basic mechanics of being both the querent and the reader in a Tarot reading, skills which you'll immediately practice in the workshop with your fellow participants. Arrive with an ~open mind~ and a Tarot deck. (I'll have a handful of decks to loan out, but probably best if you buy/borrow your own.)

title: Shooting 360 Video: Cinematic VR 101
description:
We'll go through an overview of 360 video, talk through the **different 360 cameras** (and ways of capturing __spatial audio__), discuss pre-production considerations, cover best practices for shooting 360 video (e.g., be aware of your _seam lines_, don't place the camera too close to your subject), and then we'd do some **hands-on practice with 360 cameras** available from the equipment room.   
  
360 Video is like being in the middle of a globe where you can pan, tilt, and roll:   
![360 Video is like being in the middle of a globe](http://payload505.cargocollective.com/1/21/682130/12402090/prt_200x200_1488934162.gif)

title: Intro to 3D Modeling with Cinema 4D
description:
Did you know that After Effects comes with a version of Cinema 4D? Let's use it to make 3D models and landscapes! You can export the things you make into Unity to +1 your games or VR projects, or into the real world with a 3d printer.

(please come with after effects or cinema 4d installed on your computer)

title: QUITTING NEWS (& social media)
description:
In this session we will discuss the value of spending your personal time reading news and to a larger extent social media. Consuming news, especially in large quantities, can have toxic effects on the mind. In this session we will explore the mental health effects of news and social media. We will then discuss specific approaches to quitting some or all of this media.

I left Facebook 4 years ago, left Twitter 3 years ago, and quit all news and social media 2 years ago. The benefits to my quality of life and mental health have been countless. I will be sharing both my tactics to quit news and what some of the consequences and risks of doing it are.

Part 1/3 of the â€œMindful Intelligenceâ€ series. The other sessions are recommended, but not required. 

Check out "Machine Learning Without Computers" (2/3) and "The Human Uprising" (3/3)

title: Scrapyard Challenge - Build DIY MIDI Controllers
description:
The Scrapyard Challenge Workshops are hands on hardware hacking workshops where participants dismantle old, junked electronics, appliances, toys, games, furniture, and other objects to create musical controllers. No knowledge of programming is needed, just an inquisitive mind and basic soldering skills. The Scrapyard Challenge workshops were founded in 2003 by Jonah Brucker-Cohen and Katherine Moriwaki (both ITP alums) and have been held in 15 countries on 5 continents since 2003.

For this session you will need to bring a piece of junk: old appliance, video game controller, kids toy, old computer, CD player, etc... 

Documentation of This Session is here: [http://bit.ly/scrapchallitpcamp](http://bit.ly/scrapchallitpcamp)

[http://www.scrapyardchallenge.com](http://www.scrapyardchallenge.com)

title: The Human Uprising: Overpopulation, overconsumption, and similar topics that are uncomfortable to discuss
description:
Class Notes and References:
[http://bit.ly/humanuprising](http://bit.ly/humanuprising)

The human population at the time this description was written was 7.62 billion. A meta-analysis of 69 studies into the potential maximum capacity for humans on Earth produced a point estimate of 7.7 billion. While the range of possible capacities is dramatic, itâ€™s entirely reasonable to consider that we are either approaching or have already exceeded the Earthâ€™s capacity to support us as a species.

Discussing this topic is far more difficult than discussing topics like the environment or CO2 emissions. Considering that we as humans may need to figure out how to limit our growth to protect the planet and ourselves is fraught with challenging and difficult to consider topics that are easier avoided than considered.

In this session we will review a range of studies and referenced information on topics including overpopulation, overconsumption, and disaster capitalism. We will then broadly discuss and consider the potential options, outcomes, and perils that may arise for us as humans in this situation.

Part 3/3 of the â€œMindful Intelligenceâ€ series. The other sessions are recommended, but not required.

Check out "QUITTING NEWS" (1/3) and "Machine Learning Without Computers" (2/3).

title: Machine Learning Without Computers
description:
In this workshop we will explore topics in Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence without using computers. We will learn about dimensionality reduction, classification, machine hallucination, training bias, and more, all without using a computer or writing an equation. No background in math or theory is required - applicable to all disciplines.

In teaching Machine Learning it can be difficult to bridge the gap between "WOW COOL!" and the actual theory and mathematics behind it. It's possible to teach people how to quickly do cool stuff without learning the theory. Or you can teach math and theory but won't get to hands on.

This workshop attempts to bridge this gap by using an amazing intelligent learning machine we already possess to explore the subject: the human brain.

An experimental version of this workshop was given as "This is your brain on AI" at ITP Camp 2017, and under the new title at SFPC Learning to Teach 2018.

Part 2/3 of the â€œMindful Intelligenceâ€ series. The other sessions are recommended, but not required.

Check out "QUITTING NEWS" (1/3) and "The Human Uprising" (3/3)

title: Secret Basquiat Field Trip
description:
For fans of Jean-Michel Basquiat, this field trip will explore his life, death, and related topics.

BOOM FOR REAL!

[DETAILS OF THE FIELD TRIP ARE NOW AVAILABLE HERE: http://bit.ly/secretbasquiat](http://bit.ly/secretbasquiat)

** includes self-tour, videos, and more! **

Depart from Tisch lobby (1st floor) at 3:00PM.
OR meet at Green-Wood Cemetery Fort Hamilton Entrance at 4:00PM.

Weather dependent.

Previously given at ITP Camp in 2016 and 2017 as "Coloring with Basquiat."

title: 3D + VR in your phone
description:
Want to create interactive immersive content available for anyone with a smartphone (so, almost everyone)? Have you used a Google Cardboard and were wondering how to make something like that yourself? It's very simple thanks to three.js + WebVR API!

We will start with an easy introduction to three.js: how it works, how to create things and make them move. Then, the magic tricks will be revealed as you learn how to make your VR sketch work in the browser.

We will use Google Chrome to take advantage of the [WebVR API Emulation extension](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/webvr-api-emulation/gbdnpaebafagioggnhkacnaaahpiefil). Please, download it before the workshop!

All the material is in the [following GitHub repository](https://github.com/nicolaspe/unconference_threevr).

title: Arduino + P5
description:
**Waitlist Update** - Anyone is welcome to join the session to listen and observe. The RSVP limit is set to 30 because I only have that many setups (arduino + sensors) for participants to follow along with. If you have your own Arduino + breadboard + sensors PLEASE BRING THEM!

********

Learn how to connect your Arduino microcontroller to P5.js to create creative visualizations and simple interfaces controlled by sensors. We'll also use p5 to control hardware actuators (leds, motors). We will discuss the basics of serial communication, and build an interactive Arduino circuit that talks back and forth with the P5 web editor.  

We'll move somewhat quickly through the basics of Arduino and P5, so some experience with one or both is recommended but certainly not required. 

Participants are encouraged to bring a laptop and their own Arduino Uno and breadboard. I will have some available for checkout during the session. Bring any sensors or actuators that you're interested in playing with, I'll also have options for folks to use. 

[Workshop Notes](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1k_6utVRMlwhQaa1Ibt7D8wlYsyVUIGuKAsTgOOTFvHw/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Making Music with Social Data
description: The goal of this workshop is to expose participants of all levels to the ability to utilize web APIs and online datasets to build data-driven experiences for creative purposes. We will introduce a plethora of available web APIs and together we will code a web-based interactive music experience based on tweets from the Twitter API.

title: The Artist Interview and Video Profiles
description:
If you're an artist and/or videomaker, this casual presentation/conversation session will likely be of interest. I'm an ITP grad from '11 and during my five years working on a Global Art Initiative at the Guggenheim Museum, I conducted interviews with over 50 artists from around the world. I'll be sharing what I've learned about what questions artists at this level love to answer, what they cringe at, how to allow for an organic flow during the interview while also ensuring that they say what's needed for the storyline. For examples, check out videos starting with "Artist Profile" within this [playlist](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL4B158972C6000678).

On the production side, I'll also be talking about filming in museums, galleries, artist studios, what equipment works and what doesn't, what kind of crew is best, and all kinds of editing strategies.

title: Intro to making music with Ableton Live
description:
I did this class last summer... people seemed to enjoy it, so here's another one for anyone who wasn't there (or wants a refresher)!

After a brief intro into what makes Ableton unique among Digital Audio Workstations, we'll dive right into making some music. Towards the end of class, we'll explore using iPhones to remotely control parameters in Ableton.

This class is geared towards Ableton beginners, at any level of musical ability.

Before class, please:

-Download and run the [Ableton free trial version](https://www.ableton.com/en/trial/). It's big-ish, so don't wait until class to download.

-Download [these files I've prepared](https://we.tl/spbLvQuPho)

-iPhone users, please [download this free app](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/faders-us/id444262646?mt=8)

Bring headphones/earbuds

title: One Word: Plastics
description:
Sometimes it's brittle, sometimes it's rubbery, sometimes it's clear and sometimes it's unexpectedly melting into a puddle of green goo.

A little discussion about how plastics work, from the molecules up. It's great to have a basic knowledge of their structure, what they do well, how they fail, and how to select one that's right for your project.

We'll also be trying some fun and unexpected techniques for identifying mystery plastics in the wild. 

Slides from the presentation: http://bit.ly/2HuM9eU

or

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1sHunSClzXKbj03jBgpF4Pw8jeZuzd8jv2dqMZyy_4jQ/edit?usp=sharing

title: Peer-to-Peer Websites
description:
An introductory workshop to the p2p distributed web.

Learn how to create your own self-hosted website. Participants will learn basic concepts of p2p protocols, most specifically DAT, Beaker browser,  how to share and fork websites from the network, existing p2p publishing projects and how to host permanently a website when the original computer is off the network.  

Bring your own computer.
No coding skills required.

title: ACCESS + ABILITY @ The Cooper Hewitt
description:
A trip to the Cooper Hewitt Design Museum! Campers will get to learn about and see asstive technologies on display in hopes of inspiring projects or just gain a new appreciation or awareness with accessibility design. The discussion will be open, sketching and note taking is encoraged!

It is a small museum, so I don't expect more than an hour or two, and campers are free to stay after and see the rest of the museum if they wish. I'm doing it in the morning so you can do the other events at ITP should you wish to. 

I will be leaving from ITP if you want to go as a group, or meet up with us at the front door of the Museum. We will start promptly at 11:30, so if you're late just come and join us.

Admission: 
$18 for Adults
$9 for Students 
 Free for CH Members and anyone under 18 years old.

title: What's the Deal With The Spotlights? An Introduction to Stage Lighting Control
description:
Wandering around ITP, you've probably noticed a few spotlights on the ceiling. In this session, you'll learn how to control them from an Arduino, or using node.js. [DMX-512](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DMX512) is a serial protocol used for stage lighting worldwide. In recent years, it's been supplemented with another protocol, [Architecture for Control Networks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_for_Control_Networks), or [ACN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_for_Control_Networks), which can run over Ethernet. 

DMX-512 and ACN can be used in many different lighting applications, from stage to installations, using both large lights like the ones we have, and programmable LEDs. 

You should know how to program an Arduino, and/or know a little something about node.js in order to get the most out of this workshop. 

Resources:

* ITP Light & Interactivity class [DMX-512 page](https://itp.nyu.edu/classes/light/resources/dmx-resources/)
* [sACN Source library](https://github.com/tigoe/sACNSource) for Arduino
* [DMXSimple library](https://code.google.com/archive/p/tinkerit/wikis/DmxSimple.wiki) for Arduino
* [node-dmx library](https://github.com/wiedi/node-dmx) for node.js
* [Presentation Slides](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1v5_xoVgS9_Ca4CZtl7slAypD7WOzldZXWcB1wp40x8w/edit?usp=sharing)

title: BioHack Your Heart with Pulse Sensor
description: This workshop is hands on introduction to biosensing and biofeedback featuring the [Pulse Sensor](www.pulsesensor.com). See and hear your heartbeat! Control motors and make beats with your beats! We will explore signal processing and data visualization, as well as electronics circuitry and the particulars of Arduino analog inputs. If you have your own electronics gear, bring it along to play with! We will have a pile of stuff checked out from the lab.

title: Storytelling with plastics
description: Ever wish you could tell your story in an unconventional form? Have you always been itching to create your narratives through creative play using handcraft and materials you never knew could be useful to tell a story? In this workshop, we will break the common boundaries of storytelling by using plastics as our medium! You will learn how you can manipulate plastics in different forms and shapes to craft your narrative. This fun filled workshop doesn't require any arts background or technical skills, all you need is an open mind and your imagination.

title: LocalNet Adventure!!
description:
## LocalNet Adventure!!
### Or, How I Learned To Stop Worrying And Hate The Internet

Inspired by Druv Mehrota's [Othernet](http://othernet.xyz/), Dan Phiffer's [Occupy.here](http://occupyhere.org/), and the wifi art of the [Third Space Collective](http://www.th1rdspac3.com/), this workshop/alternate reality game will have participants engage with and explore a simulated infrastructure of local networks as a means to imagine internet alternatives in a post-internet reality. After we finish playing we will have a group discussion on the internet's place in our lives and steps we can take to improve it. Along the way participants will learn some useful command line skills and the basics of network infrastructures. This workshop is appropriate for all audiences and skill levels, but will involve some walking around (no leaving the building though).

title: Strategies for Post-Digital Subversion
description:
## What happened to the technoutopian dream of the 90s?

According to technologists and cyberfeminists of the time, the internet was supposed to make everything better. The removal of barriers, of identities, of physicalities, was supposed to bring us to a grander civilization, to a communal humanity on the integrated circuit. Now it has become corporatized, Web 2.0'd, driven by the extraction of wealth from categorization and commoditization of its users and the data they generate. The practice of "having an identity on the internet" now seems more for the benefit of state and corporate actors who want to surveil and data mine than it does is for the user.

This talk will review a variety of contemporary media artist strategies for subverting the current working order of the internet and the digital systems of oppression that underly it, and then open into a group discussion of ways of incorporating those strategies into our own work. Many art critics label works incorporating these strategies as "post-digital art" and we will also address the appropriateness of this term. This session is appropriate for anyone making creative work who feels that the network technologies of the internet empower oppressive power structures as much as they empower the users of those technologies.

title: Intro to ZBrush: Make any Enclosure You Want
description:
Why this is great: It's like working with clay but on the screen. You can make the objects any shape, add texture, and 3-D print them. Then you can stuff these enclosures with electronics and sensors!

The workshop will cover Zbrush's layout, navigation, hot keys, and popular tools/brushes. For the demo I  will sculpt an organic shape, render it hollow, cut out an opening for a lid attachment, and export for 3D printing.

title: RunwayML: Machine learning for everyone
description:
This session will be focused on using RunwayML, a desktop application to run and use state of the art machine learning models and connect them to other software. Runway allows people to use machine learning models easily by managing all the configurations through a graphical user interface.

No machine learning experience is required.

The session will end with students creating custom creative projects in Unity, Javascript, Max/MSP or openFrameworks

You can learn more about Runway here: https://runwayml.com/

title: ML5.js: A Friendly Introduction to Machine Learning
description:
This workshop will introduce basic principles behind machine learning by building creative projects in the browser. We will be using ml5.js(https://ml5js.org/), which is a friendly JavaScript web framework for machine learning.

Together with examples, tutorials, and datasets, the ml5 libraryâ€™s goal is to make machine learning accessible to a broad audience of artists, creative coders, and students. The ml5 library provides access to machine learning algorithms and models in the browser with no other external dependencies.

During the workshop, we will demo examples built with ml5.js, and we will build a Classifier with Feature Extractor (https://ml5js.org/docs/custom-classifier) together.

**Please bring your laptop with a Code Editor(Visual Studio, Atom, or Sublime) installed. Or create an account in p5 web editor: http://alpha.editor.p5js.org/**

title: How to bake a Raspberry Pi
description:
#A deep dive into a Raspberry Pi 

* Preheat it with Raspbian, 
* Mix it with up with Python 
* Serve it as an Internet of Things project!

##You will learn:
* Concepts about Embedded systems,
* Just enough Linux to get the job done,
* ~Python~
* Using the MTA and Twilio API


#TLDR
Attend this session if you are interested in making IoT projects with a 20 dollar computer.

[github link](https://github.com/adarshmammen/nyc-mta-arrival-notify)

[Link to the slides](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1xpskpqNSmO9Ax6vUvqv9-sakOrNP8VsFAKrptU-7eNc/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Unity3D for non Gamers
description: This is an intro class to Unity3D game engine. No prior knowledge is necessary... this is to show you the range of what you can do - including bringing assets in, manipulating them, applying behaviors and spitting projects out to a variety of platforms... This is about understanding the basic of how Unity thinks and how you can use it beyond making "games"...  I will probably do a few of this building progressively to VR / AR. please download and install http://unity3d.com (free).

title: Making VR in VR
description:
Making VR in VR is AMAZING. We'll be showing you different Tools :
(Google TiltBrush / Blocks / Poly & Oculus Quill & Medium) 
and how to bring them into Unity3D's EditorXR to continue to build in VR inside of Unity... and all the various permutations...

title: How to Build Outstanding Work That Makes an Impact
description:
What makes a great project? How great projects catch the eye of their target audience? Which one of my ideas could become an impactful project?

These questions, and more, are essential guidelines in mind of the creative individual. Asking the right questions is as important to projects' success as the code or to motors that run it.

This lecture will introduce us to a creative project development framework. The goal of this framework is to help individuals turn their ideas into deliverable and impactful work, that can be seen and influence other people.

We will ask tough questions, discuss to find the right answers, and find inspiration in the development process of acclaimed artists and creators.

It's gonna be a lot of fun ðŸŽ‰

title: Music for Non-Musicians
description:
Music is the secret ingredient that shapes the way we feel about our experiences, from film scores and immersive game soundtracks to the background music in the grocery store. Original music can turn good projects (videos, games, web experiences, live installations, etc.) into great projects, and creating your own music gives you control over the emotional tenor of your work. It can also just be a nice way to unwind after a long day at work. 

This class demystifies digital music production, covering basics and best practices with a combination of freeware and web audio tools to create professional-grade work on no budget. Beyond basic computer literacy (web-browsing, downloading files, installing software, etc), no prior knowledge is assumed; and while the class is specifically geared toward students with no musical background, trained musicians and seasoned producers will also walk away with a few new tricks and resources.

title: Concrete: a maker's material
description:
Concrete is the single most widely used material in the world. And yet there are very few examples of DIY projects utilizing it. This course will teach you to make everything from electronics enclosures and stands; to light and magnetic sculptures out of concrete. 

I will demonstrate making magnetic sculptures, embed lights and touch sensors in concrete and even make concrete foam! All the while discussing real-world experience, problems, and solutions.

No prior experience needed!

title: Hello MicroPython
description:
