MicroPython is an implementation of Python 3 which runs on micro-controllers. For the longest time programming embedded electronics meant programming in C or assembly. MicroPython promises to make embedded programming much easier!

We will compare the different boards that support MicroPython, compare MicroPython to Arduino, and code some example projects. You will also finally understand the difference between 'micro-controllers' and 'micro-processors' and which suits your needs better.

No prior coding experience is needed!

title: Use a Leap Motion to control LEDs
description:
I will cover how to use the Leap Motion to control LEDs with different hand gestures. The content will include serial communication between processing and the Arduino. No skill prerequisites. Come and learn how to magically turn on lights without physically touching a switch, like the Harry Potter way! Related project documentation: https://wp.me/p4Nv2h-7c. 


https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1ZQNRdWo-1MEEsDSqWVsd1cjhX5RDTuqQ?usp=sharing

title: Physical Computing Project Strategies
description:
Got an idea for a project involving physical computing, electronics, networks, or wireless, and not sure where to begin?  Bring your ideas along to this session and we'll discuss. In this session I'll outline some strategies for planning and executing projects that are a mix of hardware, software, communications, and human interaction.

In teaching and managing the physical computing area at ITP, I've seen hundreds of projects go by, and the most successful ones are the ones which planned well in advance, considered the user's behavior before they started building, and chose their tools carefully. We'll talk a little about the strengths and limitations of some tools for electronics projects as well. 

Prerequisites: this session is going to be mostly an improv/Q&A session, so it'll work best if you come with project ideas and questions.  I'm hoping that others who teach in this area will join the session so we can trade tips and tricks as well.

title: The Drawing+ Club Presents...
description: Join the Drawing+ Club for a ***live nude sketching session***. No previous drawing skills are required and all materials will be provided to you. Just bring yourself and a can-do attitude! We ask that anyone interested RSVPs by the week before (7 days), and be seated before our model takes his/her position, in order to be able to shut the door and respect the model. We want to refrain from having many people come into the room once the session starts, but participants may leave at any time. The cap for this session is 12 persons, in addition to the lead and model. The entire session runs for a total of 90 minutes.

title: Controlling Real Lightbulbs with Arduino
description:
Have you wanted to program to control â€œrealâ€ light bulbs, not tiny LEDs? Have you been wondering how to control AC (Alternating Current) devices such as fan, coffee maker and any home appliances using Arduino? If so, this workshop is for you! The workshop will teach how to automatically turn on/off and dim AC devices using Arduino. You will learn the easiest way to program AC devices including incandescent light bulbs and how it works so you can use for your projects right away. Imagine you control light bulbs with music, movement, temperature, time, force, or your voiceâ€”any input you want!

We will go over the basic electronics and Arduino programming for this project together. I will also briefly talk about different solutions you can adopt, including how to build a custom circuit board for controlling any AC devices.

title: Failures of Media & Undocumentable Art
description:
This session will go over examples of digital and analog media's failure to accurately document aspects of the world that are readily perceived by the naked eye. Additionally, we will look at examples of how these effects can be harnessed creatively.

If there is interest following this course, there will be an additional session in which we will create a device that will visually distort an object in real time.

title: Introduction to Python using Google Colab
description:
This lesson will cover an introduction of the Python programming language using Google's free Colabratory service. Python is the greatest and bestest programming language ever created, and you'll learn why this Monday night. I'll start by showing you how to use Google's tools and teach the basic language syntax and data structures. I'll also give you an idea of where you can go using Python tools to analyze and visualize data.

Google's Colab service is a free online tool for programming in Python. There is nothing to install but you'll need a laptop with a browser (preferably Chrome).

title: Introduction to Python Data Analysis Tools using Google Colab
description:
This lesson will provide an introduction to Python data analysis tools using Google's free Colabratory service. I'll cover the basics of Numpy and Pandas and show you why these libraries are a basic staple of Python data analysis. I'll also provide resources for further learning.

I'll be using Google's free Colabratory service so there is nothing to install in advance. You'll need a laptop with a browser. No prior knowledge of Python is necessary but it would be helpful if you attend my Intro to Python lesson on June 4th or Allison's on June 5th.

title: Fabricating the Future: Makers in the Shared Economy
description:
â€œFabricating the Future: Makers in the Shared Economyâ€

Physical fabrication forms a core discipline of contemporary design education. The mandate to â€˜makeâ€™ crosses almost every path a student can take through school. And just as often as designers, creatives, technologists, policymakers, faculty, and students are asked to substantiate their design research with physical products, they find opportunities to turn made objects into launching points for truly creative research. Meanwhile in the city, practicing makers increasingly blur the distinctions between digital and â€˜conventionalâ€™ fabrication, as well as the meanings of â€˜researchâ€™ and â€˜product.â€™ This selection of designers does exactly that, with work that is as creative and conscientious as it is accomplished and entrepreneurial. This facilitated discussion (workshop) will offer the opportunity to further extend the domain of innovative methods and technologies within digital fabrication in the field of design and built environment, through an active presentation of three to four presenters, and a moderated panel discussion. 

Meanwhile, the facilitated discussions will include participation and extend partnerships between New York and learning further from a) Autodesk (in San Francisco and Boston), b) from the various actors within the NYCEDC Futureworks partnerships in New York, such as NEW Inc, NEW lab, A/D/O, and c) bring the foundations of these relationships from NYC institutions such as Parsons and the Future Factory (http://futurefactory.cc) lab, Columbia GSAPP, and CUNY, and d) to foster a critical discussion on the future of urban living. Future Factory (FF) with the intention of it is an educational and student-led â€œresearch group and laboratory investigating the access and ownership of technological information that is distributed amongst the various private and public players within New York Cityâ€, the mentorship through the various mentioned players, especially through discussion with the Futureworks network, could better structure the future discussions of: 1) the future of work, 2) the future of urban living, and 3) the future of cities. These research interests of the above three categories, with the assistant of the research assistants already part of the research lab, will then be documented through case-studies broadcasted on the website and shared within the larger community.

Participants within this workshop will be generating new case studies, and discussions towards a digital publication after the 4-hour workshop. Published case-studies will be found at the Future Factory digital platform.

title: Get Leddy?
description:
This workshop will teach everyone how to map mono-color LED light strips using MadMapper with hardware.

The participants will be teamed up in groups to explore together how to make an analog LED light on a geometric shaped structure made of bubble tea straws. 

Limited to first 10 students. sign up. They will get 30-day full access to madmapper, modul8, and Vezer.

title: Map on Mask
description:
This workshop will teach everyone how to make a projection mapping onto a mask using madMapper, modul8, and Vezer.

Limited to 15 students. 
They will get 30-day full access to madmapper, modul8, and Vezer.

title: Easily create explosive abstract art using Blender (3D) (1/2)
description:
We'll be creating explosive abstract art using Blender's displacement modifier. Blender is a free, open source and surprisingly powerful 3D modeling tool available to designers, artists and hobbyists alike. We will have a quick lay of the land regarding 3D software, examine Blender's interface and then we'll get right into it.  

A few things to note:

1. Please make sure to download the software prior to the session:

https://www.blender.org/download/

2. Secondly try to watch this tutorial for how to navigate Blender as it can be a little counter intuitive:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xT2mtoDnSzM

3. It is CONSIDERABLY easier to navigate Blender's interface if you have a three button mouse (aka any mouse with the wheely bit in the middle). I will be teaching the session as if you have one of these so please try to bring one or potentially see if the help desk have any available :)

title: NIME Day One: Intro to New Interfaces for Musical Expression
description:
A crash course in the invention of new kinds of musical instruments and the creative
potentials for using them in live performance

We'll cover an overview of the ideas around New Interfaces for Musical Expression and watch some videos of performances from past ITP NIME shows. 

There will be an optional homework assignment: Build a musical instrument and prepare a one minute performance!  Performances will be held during [NIME Day Two: Perform Some Music! Play Your One Minute Compositions!](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2018/session/119)  on Tuesday, June 19, 7-9pm

NIME is a course that's been running at ITP for almost 20 years. This session will mirror the course's first class session where we introduce the concepts and set everyone out to build a musical instrument in one week with (almost) no constraints!  

Quick Introductions to: 
 * how sound works 
 * how music works  
 * how performance works 

Google Doc with notes and links from the session: [NIME: ITP Camp Notes](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1kJUxhKLrC-H-wrp-plZnw3uJtgomKUo3_Sz5N4eHs14)

title: Perform Some Music!  Play Your One Minute Compositions!
description:
Bring a musical instrument that you've built and play a one minute composition - live!

Whether or not you attended the [NIME Day One session](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2018/session/118), here's a chance to present an instrument you've built

New Interfaces for Musical Expression (NIME) is a course that's been running at ITP for almost 20 years. This session will mirror the course's second class session in which students perform on instruments they've built. in one week with (almost) no constraints!  

__Here's the mission:__

- Create a musical instrument using any material or technique you like 

- - It can be very simple, but it should be something that youâ€™ve created/modified - not something straight off the shelf

- - Software instruments are fine!  Acoustic instruments (without electronics) are fine!  Electronic instruments are fine!  

- Prepare a __one minute__ performance to be played during the session. Don't just talk about your instrument â€“ play a piece of music with it

- Suggestion: Think about what gestures youâ€™re using to play your instrument and how they might help convey your artistic intentions to the audience  

- This is meant to be a fun project that gets us started thinking about composition and performance with novel instruments

title: Art in the Age of Instagram: Experiential 101
description:
In the era of selfie-factories, the experiential industry is becoming more and more saturated with events that prioritize the coveted photo moment above all else, diluting the guest experience and powering the trend of doing everything "for the 'gram". In this session, we'll discuss some guiding principles to approaching experiential that cultivate a rich guest experience through a robust consumer journey, creative engagement strategies, and design hacks for creating beautiful spaces without jeopardizing the integrity of the experience. 

The format of this session will be a short presentation followed by an open Q&A.

title: Mastering the Pen Tool
description:
The Pen tool is used in many different programs to create vector logos, graphics, icons, custom type, illustrations, masks for animations, and much much more. Itâ€™s tricky to get the hang of, but over the course of this workshop, weâ€™re going to focus in on mastering this powerful tool. 

How do I vectorize a raster image? Where do I put beziers for clean curves? How in the heck do I make a letter S from scratch? These questions and more will be answered. This course will focus on the pen tool in Illustrator, but weâ€™ll also touch on unexpected use cases in Photoshop and After Effects. 

_Weâ€™ll also explore overall best-practices, hotkeys, and ways to speed up your workflow!_

For this workshop, bring a laptop with Adobe Illustrator CC installed.

During the workshop we will:
â€” Overview the pen tool & capabilities
â€” Vectorize a low-res logo
â€” Make a vector mask to crop an image
â€” Utilize Masking / Compound & Clipping Paths
â€” Selection tool/grouping tricks
â€” Pathfinder Tips
â€” Live corners

What can I do next?
â€” Laser-cut or engrave your design onto things!
â€” Animate your designs in After Effects!
â€” Export SVGs to animate/modify in code!

title: Kundalini Yoga Brain Break
description:
This practice is perfect for starting and finishing your projects. 

Kundalini Yoga is a technology that harnesses the power of human consciousness, awareness and potential. It powerfully combines the full spectrum of yogic tools: sound, postures, hand positions, body locks, meditation and breath â€” to help you experience immediate benefits -- more energy, mental clarity, ability to focus, increased intuition, brighter mood, calmer mind, better sleep.

It balances both hemispheres of the brain, clears the cobwebs and takes out the garbage -- the subconscious clutter that gets in the way of creativity and productivity. It helps us to operate from a more neutral, centered, zen state of being.

Classes 2 to 3 days a week with the option to add classes.

Each 30 minute class will include exercise sets and a meditation.

Sets: 
1)"Becoming Crystal Clear"  2)"To Withstand the Pressure of Time"  3)"Removing Body Blocks"  4)"To Relax & Release Fear"  5)"Outward Bound"

Meditations: 
1)"For Beaming and Creating the Future"  2)"For Absolutely Powerful Energy"  3)"To Fight Brain Fatigue"  4)"For Guidance by Intuition"  5)"To Prevent Freaking Out"

title: Room-Scale Interactive and Context-Aware Sensing
description:
Using the basic ideas developed by WDW Research, we will create an interactive wall experience that will be displayed here at the ITP during camp and then potentially moved to my new lab experience space later this summer. Some things to cover:

* What are the best activities for this kind of ambient experience?
* How do you get people to start engaging?
* Are there limitations to the number of people who can engage at any given time.

We'll provide the materials, you bring the ideas! 

https://www.disneyresearch.com/publication/wall-room-scale-interactive-and-context-aware-sensing/

title: When the Physical Meets the Digital, and the Ethics of an Overlayed World
description:
In this session, I'll review a variety of projects that have combined the physical and the digital to create interesting experiments in the future of space. Everyone is welcomed to bring their projects to review as well. 

We will also talk about the ethics of overlaying digital information onto the real world, including who controls the information flow and updating "content."

Some links to review as a starting point:

http://craigwinslow.com/

http://thephygital.com/

http://www.pattenstudio.com/

http://blog.polinchock.com/socialization-of-place/

http://experiencemanifesto.blogs.com/experiencemanifesto/socializationof_place/

https://vimeo.com/89712955

https://vimeo.com/39611704

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ihPsvgnagEI&t=1s

title: Servo Party #1 - Make Something Move
description:
Would you like to make something move?

Would you like to make something move by moving yourself?

This is a short workshop to learn about how servos, small motors with a 180-180 range of motion, work in robotics. They're tiny! They're powerful! They make a noise like power armour. 

In this workshop we'll:
- Load up an arduino
- Share some software to make an arduino run
- Plug some wires into other wires
- Wave our arms like goofs
- Add some dance mechanics
- Deeply consider how motion can be a fun or less-fun thing!

Come on out! Servos will be provided. Bring your own arduino, or check out one from Camp!

title: Critical Networked Experience: Connected Projects Focused on Disruption
description: Jonah will discuss several of his projects and work in the theme of â€œCritical Networked Experienceâ€ that challenge and subvert accepted notions of network interaction and socialization. Some projects he will discuss include â€œBumpListâ€, an email community for the determined, â€œKiller Routeâ€ a GPS navigation system that integrates live crime data, â€œWSSIDâ€ a hacked wireless router that broadcasts the weather, â€œAlerting Infrastructure!â€, a website hit counter that destroys a building,â€œPoliceStateâ€ a fleet of radio controlled police cars whoâ€™s movements are dictated by terrorist keywords sniffed on a local network, â€œWifi-Hogâ€ a portable system for regaining control of public wireless networks and he will also discuss his "Scrapyard Challenge" hardware hacking workshops that he has been running since 2003. the Talk will conclude with a live demo and explanation of â€œLivelyâ€, a web and mobile based project that allows for collaborative interaction from mobile devices on a shared public screen.

title: Scraping the Web with Python Beautiful Soup
description:
Wanna collect large amount of data but don't want to deal with silly APIs? Come and learn a very useful skill using python. During this session I will teach how to scrape the web with the Python Beautiful Soup library. We will select a couple fun websites with the campers attending the session and scrape the contents including text and images with some simple lines of code. 

All levels are welcomed but we encourage you to attend Allison Parrish's Python for Beginners session on Tuesday June 5th ( https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2018/session/69) Please bring your laptop and install Chrome and Anaconda beforehand: https://www.anaconda.com/download/

Slideshow: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1YcTx3UXQ3LPGwLrmQbp0_Uop5IT1SYUe_b5GpUwRD8c

https://github.com/effyfan/Eletronic_Text/blob/master/ITP_Camp%20BeautifulSoup.ipynb

title: Augmented Reality 101 with Weather API
description:
This is a hands-on tutorial of Augmented Reality with Unity + Vuforia. I will demonstrate how to use your own target image and augment it with the current temperature using a weather API. No pre-requirements. We will write a little bit of C#. 

https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1hqkXD7eZnPFQ2DzxGF84OqSngkdtYhV_?usp=sharing

title: Learn how to kick ass and take down bad guys! An INTRO to Systema.
description:
Learn ways to literally kick ass though the practice of a Russian martial art called Systema, which I have trained for 5 years with the Masters credited for its creation. The CAP is 20 people, because of the space required to effectively learn and have enough room to practice drills. 

Systema (Ð¡Ð¸ÑÑ‚ÐµÐ¼Ð°, literally meaning The System) is a Russian martial art. Training includes, but is not limited to: hand-to-hand combat, grappling, knife fighting, and firearms training. (NOTE: we will be focused on the basics, and this will NOT include grappling, knife fighting or firearms, though it is really fun! ;)
This is an INTRO class to the basics of Systema to give you skills to be more safe in the world. 

Typical training involves drills and sparring without set kata (that most traditional martial arts have). In Systema, the goal is to free the body of tension, fill it with breath and enhance endurance, flexibility, and effortless movement. It is a very practical martial art. 

Key to the philosophy of Systema, the  "spirit" or psychological state aims to be calm, free of anger, irritation, fear, self-pity, delusion, ego and pride.

Systema has four pillars - Breathing, Relaxation, Body Position, and Movement, as well as utilizing an attacker's momentum against him and controlling the six body levers (elbows, neck, knees, waist, ankles, and shoulders) through pressure point application, striking, and weapon applications (this last part will NOT be demonstrated in this class). 

As a discipline, it is becoming more and more popular among police and security forces and it is taught by several practitioners inside and outside Russia. There are multiple schools of Systema - Systema Kadochnikova, Systema Ryabko, Systema Vasiliev. I have been lucky to train with these Masters and in other schools, and would love to share the best of what I've learned! 

We will go over the basics, pair up, and do group demonstrations while having a lot of fun without actually hurting anyone. (But please take this class at your own risk!) Hopefully, you will leave with a basic knowledge of Systema and some skills to use when needed.

title: LaGuardia Studio Tour
description:
This is a tour of NYU's LaGuardia Studio offering museum quality 2D and 3D printing services. The tour will show you examples of other people's work and showcase the printing and scanning capabilities.

You can learn more about LaGuardia Studio here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cv8vQUZR9DU

As ITP Campers you have access to these services for the duration of camp. When camp is over you will no longer have access, even if you are an alumni. I am running this tour early in the month so you have more time to make use of this opportunity.

This tour is limited to 15 people so if you RSVP please please please make sure you actually attend. If there is high demand I will schedule a second tour.

We will meet by the elevators on the 4th floor of our building and leave promptly at 11:15 for the 11:30 tour. Don't be late! We can walk over together and return after the tour.

The address of LaGuardia Studio is 545 LaGuardia Place, one block south of Washington Square Park.

title: Wireless & Tangible Interactive Media in the era of the Internet Of Shit!? (1st edition)
description:
You will hopefully recognize the reference to the very serious tech watch organization, "[Internet Of Shit](http://InternetOfShit.net)", otherwise, pardon my french.

### TL;DR:
Tutorial link: [github.com/honnet/ITP](https://github.com/honnet/ITP)

Content:

- Hardware (1): ESP8266 microcontroller ([wemos](http://wemos.cc)) + MPU6050 (accelerometer + gyroscope)

- Firmware: Arduino (optional [intro](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1d3UTxDgPXPSCQaPC38jFeznyrmNE9uLW6D7fg5fEFEY))

- Communication: OSC (+more more possible)

- Software: processing.org (or p5.js) for interactive visualization (2) (+ optional: sonification, gesture recognition with wekinator or even re-physicalization with motors...)

### Why?
Are you a [new] creative coder, music techie, physical computerist, or any kind of curious tinkerer in this area !?

Ever wanted to use wireless motion sensors for real time visualization, sonification? (or re-physicalization!?)

For Wireless & Tangible Interactive Media, motion sensors are probably the simplest and most expressive, but we can look at other sensors for those who are interested (luminosity, noise, etc).

This workshop will be interactive, the idea is to adapt to your need, so the following is an adaptable proposition:

### Program idea:
To connect electronic shit on the internet, it makes sense to understand the electronic part a bit, so this session could start with a quick introduction for artists, using the intuitive analogy of water-electrons.

We could then briefly see how arduino works for those who don't know, play with the accelerometer data and dive in the wireless communication.

A nice conclusion could be to tinker with processing sketches for visualizations and sound generations...


### Notes

(1) The hardware is provided so you only need a computer,

(2) An example of motion visualization is available [here](https://github.com/sojamo/Movement-of-Things/#exploring-inertial-motion-sensing-when-autonomous-tiny-and-wireless)

title: Soft Sensing: Materials As Sensors
description:
When working with electronics we most often think about sensors as parts or components with clearly defined size, shape, and tactile properties. But what happens when we as designers start to consider sensors as materials rather than objects? How do we design with sensors that can be squishy, sticky, or slippery? And how do our designs change when we can sprinkle a sensor like fairly dust, spread it like paint, or knit it like yarn? This session will explore the softness of sensors both in physical form as well as in concept. Leveraging practices and research from the world of electronic textiles and material science, we'll discuss ways to identify and utilize the conductive and resistive properties of materials that can be used for sensing.

Worksheet and resources can be found here: 
https://drive.google.com/open?id=1pCPHpkyGrKH3V_OoZd0mBZ8QPHjMqXRy

title: Interactive Spaces PART 1 (Ideation)
description:
Interactive Spaces will be a series of sessions that culminates in a final work displayed as part of the *Show All Things Show*. It starts with an ideation session to find a set of common directions and co-working groups.

We will go through a couple of methods to come up with some interesting  possibilities for interactive environments.  In particular we are interested in the intersections of:

* Projection Mapping
* Movement
* Light (Objects)
* Site Specific Contexts
* Environmental Storytelling
* Wearables & Costuming
* Incorporating Tangible Structures and Components
* Spaces within spaces

We will also discuss the affordances/possibilities of interactive artwork in relation to public and private spaces. 

This session will be followed by two more that will focus on making the things we decide on/imagine.

title: Intro to Ethereum Smart Contracts with Solidity
description: Learn about the fundamentals of the Ethereum blockchain and how to program smart contracts. We'll discuss what a smart contract is, and introduce the programming language Solidity. By the end of the workshop, youâ€™ll have written your first smart contract, and will have resources to continue building on your new skills.

title: Engaging Mobile Audiences with SMS: Creating Interactive Displays in Public Space
description:
This session will show you how to build custom public SMS input sessions using "Lively", a web-based texting platform that uses WEBGL that I worked on that allows for multiple participants to send messages to a shared public display. Lively has been shown at conferences, festivals, meetings, universities, classrooms, and more around the world. Visualizations include 3D blocs, custom background videos and audio, dynamic images, and more...

In this session you will build your own Lively sessions, customize their look/feel, and deploy them to the public or for whatever experience you want to have audience input. All participants in this workshop will have access to "Premium" accounts which will allow for full control of the system.

No Programming Skills Needed


Everyone should bring a laptop to this session as we will be using Google Chrome to author sessions.

title: BioDesign Challenge Exhibition
description:
NATURE/POSTNATURE

Student Projects from the Biodesign Challenge

Opening Reception: June 21st from 7:00pm - 9:00pm


Parsons School of Design
The Sheila C. Johnson Design Center
66 Fifth Avenue (Entrance on 5th & 13th Street), 2nd Floor
New York, NY 10011


Join us for the opening of NATURE/POSTNATURE, an exhibition of student projects from the 2018 Biodesign Challenge. The 26 chosen projects portray futures where the lines between the natural and designed worlds have blurred, and where products and provocations are made from organisms that have been engineered on the cellular level.


Chosen from 100+ BDC projects developed throughout 2018 by collaborations between students, biologists, artists, and designers, the exhibited pieces explore the possible ways biotechnology may reshape our lives, environment, and very understanding of the natural world.

Light snacks and drinks will be provided.

RSVP here as well: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/naturepostnature-student-projects-from-the-biodesign-challenge-tickets-44769423551

title: Wireless & Tangible Interactive Media in the era of the Internet Of Shit!? (2nd edition)
description:

title: Talk Bot to Me Workshop: Service Design a Chatbot Experience
description:
You want to talk to the systems. We want to provide you with a framework and best practices to develop your bot conversation before you start development. This hands on service design workshop will provide you with suggested guides to create characters and story development. 


**** Pre-work *****
Come with a chat bot idea!

title: Playlist
description:
What better way to get to know someone than to listen to their music?

I'm going to use this session to shuffle the music on my iPhone. It'll be like taking a road trip, blasting the music except we not gonna be in a car.

title: ITP Social Chairs present: SCTNO - Summer Camp Thursday Night Out!
description:
Come for a Thursday Night Out for Summer-Campers at a local bar near ITP! Take a break from the soldering irons and keyboards to meet fellow campers over drinks in a social atmosphere.

This is a weekly tradition we do at ITP.

Location - right around the corner at:

[West 3rd Common, 1 W 3rd St](https://goo.gl/maps/Mbunt4AaYMs)

title: The Dark Arts: Brainwashing, Cults, and What Separates Healthy from Unhealthy Communities
description:
How does brainwashing work? What makes one susceptible? How can we spot cults early and make sure to avoid them? We'll explore all these questions and more in this hour-long session,

Additionally, we'll look at the difference between cults and other organizations, and see what it means to create a strong institutional or community culture without becoming a cult.

This session will be lecture format with some activities and Q&A.

title: Mindful in Nature - Field Trip to Central Park
description:
You've been spending all your time in front of a screen or using power tools in a dusty room.... now it's time to get outside!

Inspired by the Japanese trend of shinrin-yoku, directly translated as forest bathing, this mindful walk will be an intentional way of getting back in touch with nature. As we walk through the park, we will open all of our senses to the world, stopping to smell the flowers or sitting and listening to the birds chirping.

We will meet at Central Park North, 110th street station at 10am, and then head to the North Woods, one of the quieter, more secluded parts of the park. I'll provide some guidance for the practice, and then we'll have some free time to explore the park alone or in pairs. We'll come together again at 11:30am to talk about the experience.

More about forest bathing from the New Yorker:
https://www.newyorker.com/culture/photo-booth/japanese-photographer-captures-the-mysterious-power-of-forest-bathing

More about the North Woods:
https://foursquare.com/v/north-woods/4ba3931df964a520964838e3

title: Learn to Play Go / Baduk / Weiqi
description:
Go is an abstract strategy board game for two players, in which the aim is to surround more territory than the opponent. The game was invented in China more than 2,500 years ago and is believed to be the oldest board game continuously played to the present day. 

For years, Go was one of the few remaining games where humans could beat computers. Then, in 2016, DeepMind released AlphaGo, which won 4 out of 5 matches with former world champion Lee Sedol.

In this session, aimed at beginners, you'll learn to play Go, as well as some of the basic strategies. Please bring a laptop / tablet, as we will be playing using some of the online game engines since we don't have boards for everyone.

If you're a more experienced player and would like to help run the workshop, please reach out!

title: Make your UX interface interactive! Intro to Sketch + Principle
description:
Still showing your client screenshots for your web/mobile interface designs? 

Want to make your product interactive and test it with users, but don't have the time/ability to code?

Drooling for the GIF shots on Dribbble but think After Effects it's a bit too much for you?

Then Sketch + Principle are exactly up your alley! In this 2-hour workshop, we'll learn to make a basic interactive interface with Sketch and Principle. It's the best if you got some previous experience with graphic and interaction design, but also welcome if it's the first time you hearing it! 

Sketch: Sketch App in a light, fast yet powerful prototyping and design tool for Mac (sorry, no official release for windows yet;( ). Like Adobe Illustrator, it can be used to design vector arts, interface designs, produce UI kits, also has a lot of powerful plug-ins! And it's easy to learn for even non-designers. Now it has been widely used in many corporations.

Download for trial: https://www.sketchapp.com/

Principle: Principle is also an App for Mac system. It's an off-line prototyping tool with a great power in creating Animations! Though there are plenty prototyping software and online platforms, Principle is still my favorite and can make some animation really easy!

Download for 14-day trial: http://principleformac.com/






**Workshop assets and Slides will be posted and able to download around 3 days before the workshop starts

**Please bring your Macbook during the workshop;)

**This session is an intermediate one (which means might be a few learning gaps for first-time designers! But I'll try my best to prepare helpful assets for beginners;)


** https://goo.gl/y8p6TC  download exercise files and workshop slides

title: Intro to Maya
description:
Maya is an industry standard software for creating 3D animation and visual effects. While it's extremely versatile, getting started can be a little daunting due to the many menus and interfaces. 

We'll be going over the core Maya functions and exploring the possibilities of simulation, generative design, rendering, character animation and more. Since the scope is only one session, the goal will be to prepare you to know what questions to ask and where to direct your learning for the future.

title: Self Sovereign Identity &  Web 3.0 First Principles: Create your own Meta-Identity w/ uPort, Keybase, Blockstack & Magic Words!
description:
Web3.0 development nears a tipping point, as civil society finally gets the bill for all our "free" social media accounts, email, search and other basic web platforms. We are giving away the single most valuable asset remaining on Earth, our personal data, and we recieve little to none of the transformative AI insights and business process recommendations that are generated by carefully analyzing each user's every word, using sentiment analysis and other semantic web tools. In giving away free and total access to our online behaviors and every word we type, we have helped power a juggernaut AI training framework for Google, Fb, Amazon, etc. who continuously fail to protect this precious resource, as evidenced by the Cambridge Analytica/FB scandal, and associated social engineering, meant to disrupt the very fabric of our political process. 
Had enough? 
Want to understand alternative options and learn how to build the future? The future web will be decentralized, and likely see the decoupling of data from the application layer. Self-sovereign identity is an essential aspect of designing a better data model. So how can we rebuild "The Web of Trust" using Self-Soverign Identity? 

As a very basic starting point, identity is the human capacity â€“ rooted in language â€“ to know â€˜whoâ€™s whoâ€™ (and hence â€˜whatâ€™s whatâ€™)
Identity is hard to pin down...
A Concept

A physical card

A range of alternatives

Always Evolving

Self-Sovereign Identity

Every individual human being is the original source of their own identity

Identity is not an administrative mechanism for others to control

No one may charge rent or be able revoke another's identity

Each individual is the root of their own identity, and central to its
administration

The role of names, citizenship, licenses & other credentials should be distinct as "verified claims" offered by their issuers, not as identifiers
of a human being

We need Self-Soverign Identity

IN ORDER TO FORM ACCESSIBLE PATHWAYS BETWEEN:

LOCAL COMMUNITIES

LEADING RESEARCH INSTITUTES

DOMAIN EXPERTS, SCIENTISTS, POLICY MAKERS

ARTISTS AND INFLUENCERS

ECOÂ­FEEDBACK SYSTEMS AND SENSE INTERFACES

& COLLECTIVE INTELLIGENCE, AI & GOVERNANCE Frameworks.

This workshop and talk will provide an opportunity to dive right in and create your self-sovereign identity using a number of free and open source software (Keybase.io, UPort, Civic, Blockstack) 

We will create a working Self Sovereign Identity dApp (decentralized application) that allows users to generate their identity, and to prove ownership of other social profiles using social proofs and linked hashes. You will end the workshop with the ability to say to someone, hey- send a pile of btc to myname.id
We will utilize blockchain protocols such as Bitcoin and Ethereum, but no prior technical knowledge is necessary. 

We will touch on distributed file systems such as Keybase which use this identity model to coordinate content addressable namespaces to facilitate content rich communication networks that include customizable permissions for social interactions with extended privacy, security and portability across multiple platforms. .

Reclaim your data, as the entry point into Web3.0 Interaction Design, Incentive Management for Crowd Sourcing and P2P business models, and Blockchain applications where the user controls their data, which stands apart from the application layer. Coordination of complex networks requires a user-centric data and identity model and the addition of cryptoeconomics and other cryptographic primitives, such as homomorphic encryption and zero knowledge proofs, and other trustless coordination and consensus mechanisms introduce new superpowers for building increased user agency online. 
The workshop will focus on generic use-cases, and high-level abstractions of the self sovereign identity concept, and then we will dive into specific use cases that utilize specific products and protocols. The focus will be on conveying a general understanding of how powerful this concept will be in future web technologies, and within the context of current cloud.

This workshop outline is a living draft and additional links and info is forthcoming.

title: Kundalini Yoga Brain Break
description:
This practice is perfect for starting and finishing your projects.

Kundalini Yoga is a technology that harnesses the power of human consciousness, awareness and potential. It powerfully combines the full spectrum of yogic tools: sound, postures, hand positions, body locks, meditation and breath â€” to help you experience immediate benefits -- more energy, mental clarity, ability to focus, increased intuition, brighter mood, calmer mind, better sleep.

It balances both hemispheres of the brain, clears the cobwebs and takes out the garbage -- the subconscious clutter that gets in the way of creativity and productivity. It helps us to operate from a more neutral, centered, zen state of being.

Each 30 minute class will include exercise sets and a meditation.

Sets: 1)"Becoming Crystal Clear" 2)"To Withstand the Pressure of Time" 3)"Removing Body Blocks" 4)"To Relax & Release Fear" 5)"Outward Bound"

Meditations: 1)"For Beaming and Creating the Future" 2)"For Absolutely Powerful Energy" 3)"To Fight Brain Fatigue" 4)"For Guidance by Intuition" 5)"To Prevent Freaking Out

title: Box Design for Laser Cutting
description:
If youâ€™ve never designed a box or created a 3D object using the laser cutter before, this session will offer an introduction to creating simple boxes or enclosures. You can go on to apply these techniques to design a custom case for an electronics or lighting project, art piece, game piece storage, etc. 

Fortunately, there are some online generators that simplify the design process, which we will review in this workshop. We will also go over considerations such as measuring and accommodating for kerf, various joint types, hinges, materials, etc.

We will be using Illustrator in this class, but our focus will be on walking through these box generators:

http://www.makercase.com 

https://www.festi.info/boxes.py

Even if you don't have Illustrator, you can export your files suitable for use on other vector graphics editors such as the free and open source Inkscape.

title: Play! Improv Games for Everyone
description:
Improv games are designed to cultivate things like team chemistry, creativity, embracing mistakes, listening, present-moment awareness, and *fun* -- all qualities that are useful while here at camp!

On top of that, they're super fun! Many of the people I know in improv in NYC say it's the most fun they've had since they were a kid.

We'll play an hour of low-pressure improv games, with some time in between to talk about what the experience is like as a participant, the mechanics of the game, and why they work. 

This is a great way to unwind after a long day of camp, giving your brain a break before reengaging with your projects. It'll also be a great way to bond with some of your fellow campers.

No experience necessary. Come have some fun!

title: Augmenting the World with Light - Projection Mapping
description:
Crash course in projection mapping! Learn how to take control of light in a whole new way, and augment the world around you with video, animations, color, code, simulated lighting, data visualizations & more.

Weâ€™ll start with a quick conceptual overview of the medium, analyze various opportunities/limitations of projection, then dive into a crash course with a few live demos, using the room around us as a canvas, using MadMapper.

From there, we can add simple MIDI input for interactivity, sound analysis for audio reactive installations, or use Syphon to pull in other sources.

We'll also dive into structured light scanning to show how this method enables more precise work. 
 
This workshop will also include a bunch of tips Iâ€™ve learned & discovered over the past several years setting up light installations. Feel free to bring specific questions or just general curiosities. Let's get lit!

title: Time Series Data Workshop
description:
Time Series data is ubiquitousâ€”it appears everywhere we measure change. New technologies enable us to collect vastly more data than we could before, from IoT sensors which gather weather data, to software that monitors server performance or business systems that collect sales data.

This workshop will provide an introduction to the applications of time series as well as the techniques used in its analysis, followed by some hands-on experience collecting and visualizing data using Arduino and an open source heartbeat sensor.

Laptop required.

title: Beep, Boop Hello World | Python + APIs  | Twitter Bot Go
description:
Ever wonder how the Slack and Twitter bots of the world (err, internet) work? APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) are everywhere. From accessing structured data to listening for real time changes most services offer a way to interact with them in an automated fashion.

We'll talk about the various ways web APIs are structured and how to interact with them using Python. Since the best way to learn programming is hands-on we'll then move on to creating our very own Twitter Bots!

Very basic knowledge of Python is expected. I'd recommend Learn Python The Hard Way since that is what I used way back in 2011 but it appears to have become non-free since then.

title: Bleeps and Bloops - An Intro to (Modular) Synthesis
description:
# Beeps!  Squeaks!  Drones!

In this session, we'll be diving into the exciting world of synthesized sound, with the focus on modular synthesizers.

## What is Synthesized sound?  
It's electronically-produced sound.  Think of the Stranger Things soundtrack...or pretty much any song from the 80's.

Because my personal area of "expertise" is NOT in the comparison of classic synthesizers (there's a whole lot of that online) we won't get deep into model numbers, but we'll pull up some YouTube videos of the main contenders so you can get a feel for the range of sounds and tonalities.

## The Main Focus
The main focus of this class will be to help everyone get their head around what synthesis is - oscillators, filters, sequencers, effects, etc.  I'll also talk about some basic non-boring-physics principles of sound and audio while we're at it.

## Hope you'll join me!

title: Basics of Acoustics, Psychoacoustics, and Multi-channel Audio
description:
This is a repeat/update of a session I led back in 2015 that I had a lot of fun with!

I want to expand for everyone the possibilities of audio in their projects - beyond the notion of "Stereo".
### What can be done with more speakers?  

### How many is too many?  
(trick question - no such thing as too many speakers)

### This session will cover...

Acoustics - how sound reacts with our physical world, and how we perceive that.  How can speaker placement help you, and how can it hurt you?  Not physically...usually.

I'll talk a little about sound system design for large-scale events, such as an arena concert or a Broadway theater, but mostly I'll be talking about how our brain interprets sound and how we can use that to our advantage.

Psycho-acoustics - how our brains interpret the sound waves coming into our ears.  It's a fabulous, nebulous, and bizarre world and I'm so excited to talk to you all about it!

title: Workshop on Heightening Emotional AI
description:
It is said that eyes are the windows to the soul. The human eye and the surrounding nerves and muscles are capable of silently expressing dozens of complex emotions to the observer. This emotional communication occurs regardless of whether the participants are aware of it consciously or not. It is also a well know fact that smiling, even forcing a fake one, can trick your brain into a state of happiness and also be beneficial to ones health! From a technological perspective the application of these two very well studied phenomenon has barely begun to be realized. 

This workshop will showcase the concept behind a patent pending invention aimed at marrying together the current state-of-the-art of Emotional AI, which is 100% focused on automatically "reading" human emotions, and "writing" emotional via noninvasive light energy signatures. The eventual goal is the first full emotionally aware feedback loop. You're invited to come experience a taste of the future of emotional AI.

title: Get Deep: Using 3D Depth and Skeletal Data in Three.js (via Kinectron / Kinect 2)
description: You're so three dimensional in real life, why do you settle for just two dimensions in your internet life? In this session, we'll explore using real-time, three-dimensional (volumetric) images and skeletons in Three.js. We'll use [Kinectron](https://kinectron.github.io/), an open-source tool to bring Kinect 2 data into the web and across networks to explore real-time 3D interactivity in the browser and across the world.

title: Livecoding with Kinect and Processing - Turning Human Motion into Graphics
description:
I have some Processing code that reads skeleton input from a Kinect 2 sensor, and generates particle systems displayed through a projector, along with some utilities for saving and playing back capture sessions, etc.  I'm thinking to set up the Kinect and a projector (or two) and we can see how far we can go by live coding and hacking on my code base.

This session will be flexible and we can do what people want to do.  I can go over my existing code and describe how it works.  Or we can just dive in and start making changes.

I will clean up the code a bit and post it ahead of the session, so everyone can join in.  Please have Processing 3 installed on your computer ahead of time.

Code can be found here:
https://github.com/claybudin/Kinect\_Processing\_Livecoding

title: Coffee 101 - What makes good coffee, good + Tasting
description:
Coffee is so damn expensive averaging at $4 a cup and upwards of $6! Worst part is, you might even get a bad cup of coffee. You also have probably encountered 'coffee snobs' who could possibly give you false information as well as disrespect your taste in coffee. This session aims to clarify any misconception, as well as expose you to the basics of coffee and hopefully train your tastebuds to identify good coffee. The session will begin with a presentation on coffee basics and end with a tasting session of drip coffee (letting you try 'bad' and 'good' coffee) made by me. 

Credentials: I run a coffee house (Brewhouse: A Coffee Project - https://www.facebook.com/yncbrewhouse/) in my school that aims to provide affordable espresso-based coffee ($1.50) and training students in the barista process.

P.S. Unfortunately I have a limited budget and resources and might be unable to provide coffee tasting for everyone (I'll try my best!) so do bring your own bag of drip coffee (and cups if you're saliva conscious) if you would like to share your beans with the class!

title: The MP3 Experiment Outing
description:
My favorite thing that happens every summer in New York (aside from Shakespeare in the Park) is the MP3 Experiment put on by Improv Everywhere. It is magic writ real, a powerful form of interactive theater, a temporary madness of a collective delusion and a hell of a lot of fun. I invite you all to join me!

Make sure to follow the directions with respect to what to bring and how to dress at the event page: 

https://improveverywhere.com/2018/05/08/the-mp3-experiment-fifteen-save-the-date-2018/

We'll meet at the elevators. We need to be in Brooklyn Bridge Park promptly at 7 which means we should be fine so long as we leave by 6:15 but I'd rather not chance it. Pray for no rain!

title: Haptic Feedback
description:
From the crass rattle of early pager motors to the more sophisticated purr of the iPhone taptic engine the ability to buzz has slowly worked its way into our devices. This session start a discussion around interaction design for non-visual feedback. Traditional tools such as eccentric rotating mass (ERM) motors, linear resonance actuators (LRAs), and haptic motor drivers will be introduced and demonstrated. We will also discuss less conventional methods such as gentle poking, prodding, warming, cooling, squeezing, and tickling. Overall we will consider how haptic feedback can be better utilized and integrated into handhelds, wearables, objects, and environments. 

Resources:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vJyNfXmqHiRkefknGVqIx9yU6xaIxp_qQ0sXjJzYNUs/edit

title: Mini Weapon of Mass Destruction: Design and Build a Catapult
description:
In this workshop, we will examine the catapult as an example of design innovation that gets to the root of what design actually is. What is design and when did we as humans start â€œdesigningâ€? Our starting point for this discussion revolves around the concept of â€œMan the Makerâ€, of human beings able to control their fate and their environment through design.

We will start with a brief history of design, leading to the development of the technology behind catapults. Primitive catapults were essentially "the product of relatively straightforward attempts to increase the range and penetrating power of missiles.

With that in mind, we will work in small teams to build and innovate small catapults. This is where the fun really starts because we will conclude the class by firing salvos from our creations at an unwitting target or targets. Materials will be provided so just bring your creativity and your siege mentality

Slides for the workshop:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1ANRuYTwNwCMRG-xPJ-yJT4DXDTEH9q20wqwz8BrEN7w/edit?usp=sharing

Catapult instructions:
http://322ides.com/work/reading/ITP_Camp_catapult.pdf

title: Fast as Flock: Compute shaders in Unity
description:
Unleash the power of your GPU. Compute shaders allow artists and coders to control huge amounts of arbitrary data for use with particle systems, physics simulations, or GPGPU tasks. 

This class will provide an introduction to the graphics pipeline, how to use shaders to manipulate geometry, and how to use compute shaders to massively accelerate computation of large amounts of data to simulate things like fireworks, galaxies, flocks of birds, swirling smoke, etc.

If you'd like to participate bring a computer with the latest version of Unity installed and a Github login, a Unity project will be provided via Github .

title: 3D Scan Yourself
description: In this session participants will learn the basics of 3D scanning. We will go over the current technology that is available for 3D scanning. Participants will also learn how to use a structure sensor to capture 3D scans of themselves. We will then go over ways to use their scans. I will also instruct a later session called â€œAugment Yourselfâ€ where participants will get to augment themselves using their scan.

title: Augment Yourself
description:
In this session participants will learn the foundations of Unity and augmented reality. In doing so, they will be able to use animate 3D scans of themselves and see them in the real world.  It is highly encouraged that participants attend the previous session so that they will be able to have a scan of themselves. However, it is not mandatory. This session will also cover Vuforia, Mixamo and image tracking. 

If you do not have a 3D scan, you can still attend and learn the basics of augmented reality.

title: 3D Animation with C4d
description:
Build puzzles and animate everything using Cinema 4D. You don't need c4d to participate - After Effects has a version of c4d lite with everything you need! We'll cover: 3d modeling, lighting, cameras and animation

This is a follow up to Intro to 3D Modeling with Cinema 4D, but we'll be reviewing the basics quickly, so feel free to come even if you didn't attend the first workshop!

title: Copyright | Know Your Creative Rights | Own Your Sh*t |
description:
This session is a discussion of copyright, and online copyright registration from my point of view as a photographer.

**What you create is YOUR sh*t and it's YOUR EXCLUSIVE RIGHT to decide what to do with it**

**Rights Granted Under Copyright**
Copyright law grants you several EXCLUSIVE RIGHTS to control the use and distribution of your copyrighted work. The rights include the exclusive power to:

1. **ONLY YOU** have the right to reproduce (i.e., make copies of) the work;

2. **ONLY YOU** have the right to create derivative works based on the work (i.e., to alter, remix, or build upon the work);

3. **ONLY YOU** have the right to distribute copies of the work;

4. **ONLY YOU** have the right to publicly display the work;

5. **ONLY YOU** have the right to perform the work; and

6. In the case of sound recordings, **ONLY YOU** have the right to perform the work publicly by means of a digital audio transmission.

As a copyright owner, you can transfer each of these rights to others, either individually (e.g., just the reproduction right or just the display right) or as a group (all of the rights listed above). Additionally, although the exclusive rights are broad, copyright law does not give you an attribution right (i.e., the right to require that your name be associated with the work). Thus, if you decide to transfer or license any or all six of the rights listed above and wish to have your name be associated with the work, make sure to provide for attribution through the contract or license. For information on how to transfer or license rights under copyright, visit the **Copyright Licenses and Transfers** section (http://www.dmlp.org/legal-guide/deciding-whether-and-how-license-your-content) of the website of the **Digital Media Law Project** (http://www.dmlp.org/legal-guide/rights-granted-under-copyright)

If someone else performs an action that violates one of these exclusive rights without your permission, you can sue that person or entity in federal court for copyright infringement. Bear in mind that certain prerequisites apply before you can file suit.

The Copyright Act protects a wide variety of works that are used with computers, tablets, smartphones, videogame platforms, and other electronic devices. It also protects works that are used or distributed on the internet, such as websites, blogs, and other online content.  

**Online Copyright Registration** http://eco.copyright.gov/
 
**Works Commonly Registered In This Category**
* Apps
* Blogs
* Computer Programs
* Databases
* Mask Works
* Screen Displays
* Spreadsheets
* Video Games
* Virtual Reality Environments
* Websites

And, let's talk about **The Open Movement**: Github, Creative Commons, Arduino, and sharing on social media such as Instagram, Twitter, Facebook.

**Notes** here: https://goo.gl/GsqKmn

title: Who Am We? | Genetic Genealogy in the 21st Century
description:
My concept of family was very limited until I took that DNA test! I have cousins everywhere. As a matter of fact, if you are reading this, YOU are my cousin unless you can prove otherwise.

In my session, I'll show you how I'm learning via ancestry dot com, 23 and me, and Gedmatch tools.

Ancestry dot com is selling DNA kits for $69 if anyone is interested. 

Once processed, you can download your DNA raw data and do stuff with it. The only thing I've done is to upload it to gedmatch.com which has some cool tools for analysis. I'm positive you'll think of some other ways to use your data.

I'll try to answer any questions you may have about DNA testing and genetic genealogy.

title: Electronics bases and PCB intro
description:
Are you interested in learning [electronics bases](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1wAiOwGdXLhd2jfT-Y60z3puwZVjwAUnTICC-0ZTqKcQ/) with intuitive analogies? (course made for artists and autodidacts)

Have you ever wanted to learn how to design your own PCB (Printed Circuit Board)? 

It doesn't need any software installation, online tools are really getting usable!

Here are examples:

[HiveTracker.Github.io](https://hiveTracker.Github.io)

[instructables.com/id/Collaborative-PCB-Intro](https://www.instructables.com/id/Collaborative-PCB-Intro)

Bonus: if the ITP milling machine is available, we might even get to actually build a few boards...

title: Second LaGuardia Studio Tour
description:
By popular demand I have organized a second tour of NYU's LaGuardia Studio. This facility offers museum quality 2D and 3D printing services. The tour will show you examples of other people's work and showcase the printing and scanning capabilities.

You can learn more about LaGuardia Studio here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cv8vQUZR9DU

As ITP Campers you have access to these services for the duration of camp. This tour is limited to 15 people so if you RSVP please please please make sure you actually attend. The first tour had high demand so I arranged a second.

We will meet by the elevators on the 4th floor of our building and leave promptly at 1:15 for the 1:30 tour. Don't be late! We can walk over together and return after the tour at around 3 PM.

The address of LaGuardia Studio is 545 LaGuardia Place, one block south of Washington Square Park.

title: WTF is sudo: Command line basics
description:
Are you intimidated by the terminal?
Have you ever wondered what cd does, or what ls or sudo mean?
Join us for a quick introduction into the world of the UNIX console and the most used commands.

Just bring your computer!

title: Succulent Planter -Fusion 360 intro and 3D printing.
description:
This session will cover the basics of Autodesk Fusion 360 while designing a suculent planter ready for 3D printing. 

Outline for the workshop can be found [here](https://gist.github.com/sebmorales/7ff2d2fb921d5826fa7539e2023b3975).

title: Experimental "Comics" and Comics-Making as a Way of Thinking
description:
Abstract comics, hypercomics, comics poetry, comics-making in pedagogy, and more! If youâ€™re curious about â€œcomicsâ€ that integrate aesthetic principles from conceptual art, interactive fiction, computational media, poetry, experimental music and graphic scores, please join me!

Iâ€™ll be sharing some patterns Iâ€™ve found in my own research on innovations in comics that acknowledge the traditional framework of comics (panel-based composition/sequential art, space-as-time, juxtaposition, word-image hybrid) but warp, tilt, and twist it into other things.

We'll be looking at work from the following collections:

Abstract Formalist Comics: https://www.are.na/shea-fitzpatrick/abstract-formalist-comics

Comics Poetry: https://www.are.na/shea-fitzpatrick/comics-poetry

Panel-based animation: https://www.are.na/shea-fitzpatrick/panel-based-animation

Digital and Game Comics: https://www.are.na/shea-fitzpatrick/digital-and-hypercomics

Generative Art in Print: https://www.are.na/shea-fitzpatrick/generative-art-in-print

Comics and Pedagogy: Scores, scripts, and designed constraints: https://www.are.na/shea-fitzpatrick/comics-pedagogy-scores-scripts-designed-constraints

title: Kundalini Yoga Brain Break
description:
This practice is perfect for starting and finishing your projects.

Kundalini Yoga is a technology that harnesses the power of human consciousness, awareness and potential. It powerfully combines the full spectrum of yogic tools: sound, postures, hand positions, body locks, meditation and breath â€” to help you experience immediate benefits -- more energy, mental clarity, ability to focus, increased intuition, brighter mood, calmer mind, better sleep.

Each 30 minute class will feature an exercise set and a meditation.

Your experience will be unique each time, because each class contains a different set and meditation.

title: Unity3D for non Gamers : Part 2
description:
Last session was a basic intro to Unity and where we are now...
This session will cover a bit more on bringing various assets (3D models / Pictures/ Video) into Unity and the relationship of Textures, Materials and Shaders. 
But we will focus more on player actions like Movement/gaze and interactions as well as behaviors coming from the story world.

title: The Disrupting Sketchbook
description:
When I was in my late thirties, after a devastating subway accident, I started to draw.
This simple habit ended up dramatically changing my creativity, my career, and my life.
Iâ€™d like to tell you the story of what happened and where it led. And what lessons I learned that might be relevant to your creativity, career, and life. 

Some of the subjects Iâ€™ll cover:

â€¢  The dangers of certainty
â€¢  The power of side projects
â€¢  How to draw without talent
â€¢  How to pick a pen
â€¢  How to write a dozen books while in the C-Suite and raising a family
â€¢  Recovering from 30 years in advertising
â€¢  Starting a successful online business
â€¢  Creating a robust virtual community

All this in an hour and 150 slides. 
With time left over for questions.

No coding, soldering, or drawing experience required.

title: Jewelry 101: All that glitters isnt always gold
description:
Jewelry is adornment, but it doesnâ€™t have to be make out of metal. Pull up a chair and make a piece of jewelry out of objects you have brought from home or materials supplied in class. Or, bring a project you are working on. Traditional and nontraditional materials will be provided. 
No experience necessary.

title: DIY Speakers & Headphones
description:
Make your own headphones! 
Discussion of coils & magnets and how they relate to recorded audio
With plenty of materials to build your own pair!
fun & easy!

title: Marbleizing on Fabric
description:
Textile inks can be floated on thickened water and manipulated into amazing patterns. Introduction to marbling traditions from Japan, Turkey, & Italy to inform the design process

Bleached muslin will be provided. Designs will be permanent and washable.

title: Marbleizing on Fabric
description:
Textile inks can be floated on thickened water and manipulated into amazing patterns. Introduction to marbling traditions from Japan, Turkey, & Italy to inform the design process

Bleached muslin will be provided. Designs will be permanent and washable.
