title: Video Workflow with Adobe Premiere Pro 101
description:
We will go over the basics of video editing workflow using Adobe Premiere Pro! Please download Adobe Premiere Pro before class:

https://creative.adobe.com/products/download/premiere

Alternatively, you can also borrow one of the computers from the ER. 

We will provide some materials to work with! 

Each of attendees will be making a 15 sec commercial in the second half of the session.

title: How to ride your bicycle across America
description:
Have you ever thought of crossing the country by bicycle? It can be as simple as jumping on your bike and pedaling into the sunset, but if youâ€™re serious about checking off this bucket list item, thereâ€™s a lot to think about in terms of logistics, timing, and safety. The physical part is the easiest part! 

Iâ€™ll do a 15-minute presentation on everything you need to execute such a trip, and then q&a.

title: 360Ã‚Â° without Anderson Cooper: Immersive Journalism, Production & Practice
description: 360Â° Video, aka Cinematic VR, is powerful new documentary tool expanding the boundaries of cinÃ©ma vÃ©ritÃ©. We'll go over everything you need to know to get started from affordable equipment (we'll demo the ER's cameras) through best practices for shooting and post production, including where and how to publish 360Â° Video.

title: Git and GitHub — A Thorough Introduction
description:
Git is the distributed version control system (DVCS) that is taking over distributed version control systems, and is becoming the standard DVCS for all varieties of software and design projects.

In this workshop **for beginners**, you will learn to use Git (with and without GitHub) in solo- and team-based projects. You will learn to revise, compare, and reset files, and, at the project level, you will understand how to branch, merge, and issue pull requests.

**Digital designers, developers, and engineers who have never used Git are the intended audience for this workshop.**

**Before the first class,** please do the following:

1. **Open a GitHub account** at [https://github.com/](https://github.com/)
2. **Download the GitHub client** at [https://desktop.github.com/](https://desktop.github.com/)

Slides for the workshop are available at [https://github.com/code-warrior/git-workshop](https://github.com/code-warrior/git-workshop).

title: Ok Robot Reboot! - Intro to Voice User Interfaces (Part 1)
description:
Today we no longer solely communicate with computers through a graphical user interface. As a consequence of the internet leaving the flat screen, alternative forms of interaction are increasingly becoming more ubiquitous. Designing for these new connected devices requires a different approach. From HAL 9000 to Amazon Alexa, this class presents an overview of methods, technologies and design challenges that are required to build Voice User Interfaces - VUI. Over the course of the weekend (2 days), campers will appropriate existing technologies, analyze examples of Voice Interfaces (in sci-fi, popular culture, art installations, connected devices).

- Part 1: Intro to Voice Interfaces
- Part 2: Google AIY kit (build voice interfaces using raspberry pi)

title: Ok Robot Reboot! - Intro to Voice User Interfaces (Part 2)
description:
Today we no longer solely communicate with computers through a graphical user interface. As a consequence of the internet leaving the flat screen, alternative forms of interaction are increasingly becoming more ubiquitous. Designing for these new connected devices requires a different approach. From HAL 9000 to Amazon Alexa, this class presents an overview of methods, technologies and design challenges that are required to build Voice User Interfaces - VUI. Over the course of the weekend (2 days), campers will appropriate existing technologies, analyze examples of Voice Interfaces (in sci-fi, popular culture, art installations, connected devices).

- Part 1: Intro to Voice Interfaces
- Part 2: Google AIY kit (build voice interfaces using raspberry pi)

title: Ritual Design Lab
description:
We'll look at the role rituals play in society, and then explore how different cultures around the world handle life events like births, deaths, weddings, and coming of age. 

Finally, we'll explore a design-thinking approach for coming up with some new rituals for ITP Camp!

This workshop is based on ideas from the Ritual Design Lab at Stanford:
https://www.ritualdesignlab.org/

title: Workshop: Make your own metallic tattoo that can be used as a touch-capacitive sensor!
description:
Make your own metallic tattoo or capacitive-touch sensor with your own design! Derived from a graduate paper from MIT Media Lab, we will be generating a temporary tattoo in imitation gold or silver leaf from your own vector file. There will be several interactive samples on-site to see the possibilities! 

To create a few designs during the session, please bring your Illustrator file converted to a DXF file format. If you'd like to design on-site, I can help tweak your Illustrator file or we can convert to DXF (file format preferred by the Silhouette Cameo vinyl cutter).  This is not an Illustrator class, however. You can also use the Silhouette software to create your design. 

If you'd like to make a sensor, please bring a touch capacitive board (Adafruit 12-Key Capacitive Touch Sensor Breakout - MPR121 + Adafruit Feather 32u4 Bluefruit)  and your computer with Ableton or GarageBand to connect to your arm. I can show you how to connect your sensor to bluetooth, but the coding is up to you! 

Let's decorate our bodies with METAL!

title: Intro to Processing: Designing Brushes
description: Processing is a flexible software sketchbook and a language for learning how to code within the context of the visual arts. For anyone who was here for the p5.js intro at the beginning of camp, this will go over similar topics but reviewing the differences between p5.js and Processing, advantages and disadvantages. The goal of the class will be to learn how to create custom brushes, designing first on paper, and thinking about  the set of rules that can help us achieve our design.

title: Size Doesn't Matter- Urban Farming Microgreens
description: This is a community building project based around a discussion on microgreens, food systems, urban gardens, and sustainable practices. Come get your hands dirty as we plant in ITP's vertical gardening shelves.  Expect to harvest your crops within the week.

title: Groove 101 - Learn about Groove and improve your Projects
description:
"There's a certain groove you pick that makes the music flow, and when you have it it's in your pocket. It's the feeling behind the rhythm... to me, the hardest thing to strive for is that feeling, behind the groove."
Max Weinberg


I like to introduce you to the Concept of Groove and show how this can help to improve your visual/timebased Projects. 

The core of music is tension and release. Its like breathing. Music starts to breath and resonate when it finds this captivating balance between tension and release. 

We will look at Concepts used in Arranging and Composition that help to build up tension and release like:
- Motive Development
- Layering
- Foreshadowing
- Rhytmic Displacement

We will also groove by doing some fun exercises. 

At the end we will have an open discussion and share some experiences, and see if you can transfer these concepts into your Projects. 

I might show some concepts applied in photoshop, that relates to my artistic work using some of the concepts back in the year 1999. Later on I discovered that this looks a lot like generative design.
https://rrenoir.myportfolio.com/digitale-collagen-ausstellung-1999

title: Let's Talk About Documentation
description:
***Documentation*** can serve a lot of different purposes - as a tool for reflection, as proof of work or archive, as a DIY or open source manual for others. From sketching to field notes to publication, there are many different methods for comprehensively documenting a project. And this conversation becomes much more complex when we consider the vast number of tools at our disposal, when we're required to document a variety of sources (hardware, software, design files...), or when we need to collaborate with others in this process. 

This session is less of a documentation how-to and more of a high-level discussion about the role of documentation within a creative practice. How do you document your work? Who is it for? What tools do you use? What barriers have you encountered? What will happen to the records in 5 or 10 years?

I hope that we can gather a diverse group of creators in an open conversation about their experience with documentation from diverse perspectives and disciplines.

title: Arduino+PD
description:
Looking for adding some sensors to the Arduino and making sound? On this session we will cover some methods for connecting them and have physical inputs to Pure Data and make some noise.

Please bring your Arduino, some sensors you want to use (buttons or potentiometers work just fine), breadboard and your computer with Pure Data installed.

title: "Functional Programming" with Scala
description: An introduction to functional programming concepts. We'll probably be using Scala with the Ammonite REPL (http://ammonite.io/). I'm still working on figuring out what to cover and how to cover it (this is my first time leading a session...ah!), but this will be low key, and we'll try things out together. I'll also go over conceptually what "functional programming" is and a little bit about Scala. Let me know if you have anything in particular you'd like to go over!

title: Optimizing The Workflow with Google Script
description:
Have you ever felt like you are repeating the same tasks over and over at work? It's time to automate those tasks. In this session, we are going to build a system that routes data across google tools such as google form and google spreadsheets using  google script. 


gitHub: https://github.com/Yoshie026/gs-integration/

gs: https://developers.google.com/apps-script/

title: The Digital Public Space
description:
â€˜Whatsappâ€™Â­ based participatory walk/performance that encourages the individual to uses the senses in a creative journey  that encourages selfÂ­ guided wandering through call and response prompts and allows participants to reÂ­experience familiar or unfamiliar sites.

Download whatssap on your cell phone. 

When signing up please provide your cell phone number to arantxa.araujo@gmail.com

title: SCNO - Summer Camp Night Out
description:
Come for a Thursday Night Out for Summer-Campers at a local bar near ITP! Take a break from the soldering irons and keyboards to meet fellow campers over drinks in a social atmosphere.

This is a weekly tradition we do at ITP.

Location - right around the corner at:

West 3rd Common, 1 W 3rd St

We'll leave from ITP at 9pm and head over for anyone who is interested.

title: The Drawing+ Club Presents...
description:
Join the Drawing+ Club for a super fun, super chill sketch sesh where we will go through a few lightly guided drawing exercises before a live model sketching period. Campers who don't mind getting up and posing and being drawn by peers are appreciated!

NO EXPERIENCE NEEDED. NO MATERIALS NEEDED. JUST BRING YOU!

title: Tactile pixel art
description:
This is an informal session where we will be creating pixel art and then learning how to translate the image onto a more physical form, cross stitching.  No previous skills required and materials will be provided.

https://www.piskelapp.com/p/agxzfnBpc2tlbC1hcHByEwsSBlBpc2tlbBiAgMCvq_b6Cgw/edit

https://learn.adafruit.com/cross-stitch/instructions

title: Sustainable Crafting, Production and Consumption
description:
In this session, I hope to shed light on what it means to be a sustainable consumer and maker.  

We will discuss the following:
What does it really mean to be sustainable in life and in craft?
How to focus your passion to heal the world into your daily life choices.  
Who is doing what and how do we really know it isn't all BS?.  
New sustainable materials (Biotech!)


My hope is that you will come out of this session with:
-a better understanding of what sustainability means to you
-resources for sustainable consumption
-resources for sustainable production
-list of organizations who are working to give consumers better options 
-tools to help you make informed decisions 

Lastly, I would like to hear your thoughts on what sustainable technology can look like in the future!

title: Arduino Crash Course
description:
You may have been using Arduino in other sessions, but are there Arduino concepts or techniques that your'e still confused about? 

This hands-on session will be a comprehensive crash course in physical computing. We'll talk about the difference between analog and digital inputs and outputs, and build a circuit that integrates multiple sensors and actuators. The goal of this workshop is to provide context and techniques for combining sensors and actuators to build interactive physical systems. 

Bring your questions - we'll start with a brief discussion about what's confusing (and what you already know), what projects you're working on, and anything else that would be useful in finishing projects. 

Participants are encouraged to bring their own Arduino and laptops. Also please download the [Arduino IDE](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software) prior to the workshop. 

[Class notes](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lQ7gMIC96dGWCdr-LXtkV-r389Z5MAVrMAl36ojbZJs/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Size Doesn't Matter -  Urban Farming Microgreens
description: This is a community building project based around a discussion on microgreens, food systems, urban gardens, and sustainable practices. Come get your hands dirty as we plant in ITP's vertical gardening shelves. Expect to harvest your crops within the week.

title: Programable Room Workshop w/ Recurse Alumni Jonathan Dahan
description:
Living Room:  https://github.com/living-room/Lovelace) a system designed by Recurse alumni Jonathan Dahan, which makes a room within Recurseâ€™s HQ, physically programmable. Living Room is made up of a projector, some cameras, and a database. It can recognize physical objects and can project onto the wall in response to what it sees. Living Room is inspired by Realtalk (a computing system being built at Dynamicland, a genuinely different and exciting community center in Oakland), Natural Language Datalog, and Linda.

Living Room has the potential to make collaborative working spaces into richer experiences. A physically programmable space at ITP will make it easier to see what projects other ITP'rs are working on, and will make it more likely that projects persist from one batch of ITP camp to the next.

Katherine Ye (Sâ€™13) started a research blog where she, Jonathan, and other Recursers working on the project are keeping their notes.

Jonny Dubowskyâ€™s research into Knowledge Representation, Knowledge Sharing and the coordination of shared resources will serve as a thread to connect this workshop to several ongoing research grants which are geared toward nurturing the development of a knowledge commons. Participants of this workshop will have the opportunity to explore this project beyond the scope of ITP camp.

This workshop will be co-hosted by Josh Schneier and Jonny Dubowsky. Josh has been in contact with Jonathan Dahan, but we want to make sure there are at least 15 people interested in attending.

title: Code For A Cause: A Multi-Session Hackathon For Social Impact Grants Featuring Decentralized Web Technology
description:
Part 1 of a 3 session series that will introduce several opportunities to align your ITP Camp project to a number of grants that are currently ongoing within the blockchain sector.

I will provide a quick demo on using ColonyJS: e bridge between the user facing and the infrastructure-facing layers of Colony. The colonyJS library allows developers to leverage the power of Colonyâ€™s smart contracts in their own applications.
Bring your ITP Camp project, and I will show you how to patch in a rich pipeline to grants and a microVC network where you can apply for various sources of funding. 
We will primarily look at activating the social impact benefits of creative coding projects, which can include adding in educational components, student-driven documentation, and other artifacts that will release the most value from your work, within your community. 

Blockchain Madness

We've seen hundreds of millions of dollars stream into the blockchain sector in the last year. While this initially brought with it a fair amount of fraudulent projects, and just poorly planned ventures, a few dozen projects have really created transformative technology that will undoubtedly change the future of software and the internet as we know it. Decentralized, distributed ledger technology, and self soverign identity provide the essential layers for reclaiming our digital identity and building a future web that is more in line with the original philosophy of Sir Tim Berners Lee, Alan Kay, Englebardt and others.

The standout blockchain projects that are doing the best work each have several million dollars to invest in developers and projects that demonstrate the powerful benefits of their specific protocols.
In this multi part workshop, I will introduce 10-15 different blockchain protocols and projects that are currently looking for innovative projects to fund with developer grants and incubator funds. There is over $400 million dollars currently set aside to fund innovative projects that prove the viability of decentralized web technologies. Let's put our heads together and come up with some benefits projects for humanity that utilize the creative energy which flows through itp camp.
As my primary interest in this space deals with social impact projects, I will use two projects as examples and will also feature a project of fellow itp campers developing an affordable maker space
We will use the Colony.io grant as the first example and this example grant can serve as a meta layer for any other grants as the colony Grant focuses on introducing project management and governance tools that make ad hoc collaboration possible without the risk of being left high and dry. Through the use of smart contracts and multi signature wallets, stakeholders can outline the financial terms of each grant and be sure that they will be met.
These sessions will serve as an opportunity to take a deep dive into several amazing decentralized web technology and features, and I will tailor the workshops to meet the interests of the participants as best I can.

The Colony Hackathon
June 5 â€“ June 24

Build real applications on the Colony Protocol with the colonyJS library, K
Build with the Colony Stack
Extensions and Integrations

Projects that connect external tools, data, and platforms we use everyday to Colony-ready dApps.

dApps

The user-facing applications that enable people to interact with the Colony Network, built by developers from all around to suit the needs of their organization.

colonyJS

The bridge between the user facing and the infrastructure-facing layers of Colony. The colonyJS library allows developers to leverage the power of Colonyâ€™s smart contracts in their own applications.

Colony Network

A set of smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain, the Colony Network handles incentivization, division of labour, decision making, and dispute resolution to make decentralized organizations work. 

Let's put these interesting new opportunities into our creative portfolio to unlock additional social benefits of our work.

title: Build a pair of VR Glasses - DIY tech for all
description:
No experience needed!

In this workshop, we will be building VR Glasses out from scratch.
From lenses to the body of the VR glasses.

Materials will be provided + Adult Drinks

You are welcome to BYOD as well :-)

Please make sure you download your favorite VR app to your phone before coming to this workshop so we can test our glasses. 

(Or, if you have a VR app that you build, just send us  so that we can share the link with the class!)

Some VR apps recommendations:

â€¢ Within { Story-based } â€” www.with.in 

â€¢ Water Slide { Game- based } â€” play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.water.slide.adventure.vr&hl=en_US 

â€¢ Abbey Road Studios, where The Beatles, Oasis, Adele and Muse have recorded their hits. â€” insideabbeyroad.withgoogle.com

See you there,

title: AdobePremiere-101
description:
You will learn how to video edit ( post production) your own work or work for others that you may do in your future. 
In my class you will learn how to do a three-camera edit from video clips from my personal stage performances held at New York University Tisch-School of Art Department.

If you do not know Adobe Premiere already, you will learn how to put your video's on a timeline, how to do a fade in-and- a fade out, layer (opacity), cutting, adding music, and how to implement titles.
I will also guide on how and when to make a good cut that makes since to the viewers's eye's and not have your edits not be abrupt.

Lastly, I welcome all levels of campers that understand Adobe Premiere... We all can collaborate.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1pPg4zthicDszzuFshDW24GIS69grTtMI/view?usp=sharing

title: Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain
description: Exploring principles to enhance your drawing skills and see in different way.  We will be discussing key notes from Betty Edwards Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain and other methods of perception from different artists and educators.

title: handstands and inversions
description:
Shift your perspective (literally) by learning to invert using handstands and headstands to bring blood to your brain. 

open to all body types and physical ability levels

suggested that you wear clothing you are comfortable been seen going upside down in.

title: Movement play: playful patterns for mobility
description:
I've been taking movements from capoeira, dance, gymnastics and yoga to combine them into mobility (strength and flexibility combined) oriented patterns that help us physically play while maintaining a healthy body. 

This session will work for all body types and physical abilities, but please wear movement friendly clothing.

title: Paper Programs: Run Javascript on Pieces of Paper!
description:
[Paper Programs](https://paperprograms.org/) is a browser-based platform for running javascript programs on physical pieces of paper, using a camera and a projector. Programs are printed on pieces of paper, recognized by the system, and then executed on your projection surface. In this session, we'll be setting up a paper programs environment, and collaboratively writing our very own paper program. Basic javascript knowledge will be helpful, but not required. Participants will have the opportunity to write their own programs as well.

Link to code editor: https://paperprograms.org/editor.html?080bc3b2

CODE EXAMPLES: https://github.com/pyxel-lab/pyxel-lab/tree/master/experiments and https://github.com/codeparkhouston/paperprograms-notes/tree/master/programs

title: Shaders and OpenGL in Max/MSP/Jitter
description:
Max/MSP/Jitter is a great tool for manipulating video in live performances and installations, but most of the Jitter objects run on the CPU, and as you start to build more complex patches, you may run into issues with low frame rates.

In this workshop, I'll show you how to use GLSL shaders in Jitter to process video on your computer's GPU, which will allow you to use more technically ambitious video effects in real-time.

I'll also demonstrate how to incorporate OpenGL-based 3D graphics into your Jitter patches, including primitive shapes, lighting, and 3D models.

You should bring a computer that has Max 7 installed so that you can patch along with me and try out code examples. Max can be downloaded with a 30-day trial license at [cycling47.com](https://cycling74.com/downloads), and there are also ER laptops with copies of Max installed.

All of the Max patches that we'll make in this workshop can be found on GitHub: [https://github.com/oshoham/itp-camp-2018-shaders-opengl-jitter-workshop](https://github.com/oshoham/itp-camp-2018-shaders-opengl-jitter-workshop)

title: FAT CAT outing to PLAY all the thingz!!
description:
Hey, everyone! So, it's almost criminal to keep one of THE fave ITP spots from those of you who might not have been to Fat Cat! It might be because I have 11 brothers (b/c the cult, remember?? lol) that I I love this place so much. There are so many things to play: ping pong, pool, shuffle board, etc. It's also not too pricey, and it's divey so you can wear anything... (yeah, I think that is one of few rules they have ... it's not a clothing optional place!) haha! 

ANYWAY, here's the link to get ALL the info: http://www.fatcatmusic.org
I'll be walking over after Friday's all camp social hour, and I invite you to join me at 7:30 by the elevators so we can walk over together to PLAY and hang out! Camp is almost over!! Alternatively, you can walk over when you feel like it, or you could try another game, called hide and seek (and try and find me... it gets packed, and I'm 4"10, so take your chances! ;)
Check out their link for specifics like cover charge, etc. (it's minimal!) COME PLAY!! http://www.fatcatmusic.org

title: My, oh, Maya: Adventures in Topological Modeling ENCORE EDITION
description:
NEW SESSION SCHEDULED. Lots of folks reached out and asked me to do this same session again. Please attend if any of this material interests you! 
----
Looking to design game assets? Want to 3D print your own sculpture? Never understood Maya's interface? Come one, come all to a session where you will get a crash course in topological modeling in Autodesk Maya. We'll cover the basics of Maya; a core set of tools needed to model successfully; how to imagine new sculptural worlds; and some basic things to look out for before delivering to the graphics or fabrication pipeline.

Just a warning: We won't be designing tables and chairs, fam. Bring your imagination and get ready to roll.

title: Machine learning + images: what's possible
description:
This workshop will introduce students to the basics of manipulating and generating images with neural networks.  

There will be a short presentation at the beginning showing work of artists currently working with ML, and a discussion about our ethical obligations as artists+technologists working with images.  *If you plan to attend, please come for this part of the class!*

The second half of the class will be a hands on workshop.

We'll use [style transfer](https://github.com/cysmith/neural-style-tf) as an introduction to ML models, and discuss how to use pre-trained models, tweak parameters on models, and how to train your own models.

Finally, we'll take a look at libraries such as [pix2pix](https://github.com/junyanz/pytorch-CycleGAN-and-pix2pix) and [openpose](https://github.com/CMU-Perceptual-Computing-Lab/openpose) which offer beginner-friendly tools for working with ML and images.

I'll be using Spell (spell.run) to show the demos (but you're welcome to use another platform).  I'll  also give a quick intro to remote training and the difference between GPU/CPU.

title: Glass Blowing Demonstration
description: I will be performing a 1 hour demonstration and informative talk about the process of glassblowing and sculpting at UrbanGlass located in 647 Fulton St. Brooklyn. 3rd Floor. This will go over how fiber optics are made, a number of quick demonstrations, and a larger piece to end the hour. 45 people are allowed in the studio at one time so ONLY RSVP if you're actually going to be there. Seriously. Molten glass is always a fun time to watch. It'll be warm in there so be prepared for that. Looking forward to it!

title: After ITP Camp
description:
Oh no! ITP Camp is ending... now what do I do?

If you're like me, you'll quickly find yourself restless in July. You'll rifle through the Arduino starter kit and buy a mini-projector to play with some in-home projection mapping. You might even look up how much an Ultimaker or Epilog Laser costs (hint: A LOT). You'll even try to calculate how many lunches you can reasonably skip to afford such awesome maker tools. Luckily, we're here to try and help you navigate life beyond camp.

This session is open to everyone, but some special cases we'd love to cover are:

1. I'm an incoming ITP student starting in Fall 2018.
2. I'm exploring applying to ITP or an ITP-like program.
3. I just want to know whats available in NYC to continue making!

Come with questions or just come and contribute!

title: So now what? How to communicate and sell your big idea
description:
At this point in camp you've probably got some killer ideas or a product you think could change the world, right? Right. So it's time to make a logo and watch that cash roll in right? Not so fast...

We're going to talk about how to use identity design to help clearly communicate your idea, craft a coherent story and ensure you stand out amongst your peers when trying to pitch that big idea both to investors and to the public.

I've been fortunate enough to help out on a lot of big identity projects and am excited to share whatever knowledge I can so we can see more ITP passion projects hitting the big-leagues and changing the world on a larger scale.

title: openFrameworks!!!
description:
openFrameworks is an amazingly powerful open source C++ toolkit for creative coding. However, C++ can be a difficult barrier to entry for those unfamiliar making openFrameworks harder to get into than other platforms! But, I don't think it needs to be that way. Let's flip the script and look at an understandable process for getting started and then diving in!

This workshop will present openFrameworks as something approachable. We'll get up and running quickly and I will walk the group through my understanding and process of how to best learn and use openFrameworks.

This workshop assumes no prior familiarity with openFrameworks and will leave participants with the knowledge and path for getting started and continuing. Some prior programming experience will be extremely helpful since we won't have time to cover all things in details but, even without, this session will really help give people an understanding of what openFrameworks is and isn't and how it might be useful to them in the future. 

The format of the workshop will be a combination of lecture and hands-on examples that we will dive into together as we build up the basic skeleton of sketch.

title: FIELD TRIP to COOPER HEWITT - The Senses: Design Beyond Vision
description:
Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum will present â€œThe Senses: Design Beyond Visionâ€ exhibition, on view April 13 through Oct. 28, which examines how multisensory design amplifies everyoneâ€™s ability to receive information, explore the world, satisfy essential needs and experience joy and wonder. 

â€œThe Sensesâ€ features direct sensory experiences and displays practical, innovative and exploratory products to touch, hear, see and smell. The exhibition invites visitors to encounter design with all their senses through several interactive installations, created in collaboration with contemporary designers, from a furry wall with digital sensors that play music to a scent commission by Christopher Brosius inspired by winter.

https://www.cooperhewitt.org/2018/02/27/cooper-hewitt-smithsonian-design-museum-to-present-the-senses-design-beyond-vision/

$16 for adults
$7 for students

title: 3D from 2D: Intro to Pressfitting and Laser-Cutting Fabrication Tips
description:
UPDATE 10:24AM: 4th floor is closed right now. Moving this to 10:30 for now, but may start even later depending on when floor opens. Feel free to join when you get in!

Went to the laser-cutting training but don't know quite what to do next? Need some additional guidance through your first laser-cut? Don't know what pressfitting is?

This session will give you the tips and tricks you need to start designing parts for the lasercutter and rapidly prototype with this amazing tool. We'll go through some online tools to help you design your parts and talk about when it is best to use the lasercutter (as opposed to other fabrication methods).

The first hour will be a slideshow and lecture style. Second hour (onwards) we'll start designing parts and head to the lasercutters!

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1nPmWZJEvKROcK-RFUo7R8p_FtasvVi2lmnWtQSQ43Ig/edit?usp=sharing

title: Registration & Opening Party
description:
This will include food, drink, opening announcements & orientation, and other festivities!

LOCATION: 721 Broadway, 4th Floor South, New York, NY. Take the left elevators to the 4th Floor

title: Launch Weekend: Aelectrosonics: Listening in on air and electricity
description:
*Launch Weekend Workshops are single track workshops that give everyone an opportunity to gather and make together in one large space.*

Participants will create an electromagnetic transducer, a circuit that turns the energy emitted by electronic devices into sound. This will be followed by a walk around the neighbourhood, putting these devices into action while exploring the sonic characteristics of the built environment.

Circuit parts and materials will be provided. Just bring some wired headphones!

[Slides used for this session are available here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1sbgfyyJOlciIBmj3neQ7dI0_HpTYihOL/view)

title: Launch Weekend: Multitouch Paper Recognising Gestures (with vvvv)
description:
*Launch Weekend Workshops are single track workshops that give everyone an opportunity to gather and make together in one large space.*

Our fingers are constantly swiping across touchpads, to enter passwords, navigate maps, play games, type messages. But how does this work? How are our physical interactions with materials sensed and translated into electronic signals that our computers can understand?

In this workshop we will build our own muti-touch pressure-sensitive touchpads from paper, copper tape and Velostat - a carbon impreganted plastic film with piezoresistive properties. 
Then we will use the visual programming environment vvvv to read our touchpadâ€™s raw data, apply a blob detection algorithm to detect multiple touch points and do gesture recognition on this input. 

[>>Download presentation slides here](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1qHQdwfUu0VxNMObMrYzhY8tWm--GaEQY)

![pressure matrix with vvvv](https://live.staticflickr.com/65535/47839729021_7483643f06_z.jpg)

# Schedule

## INTRO (15min)
- workshop overview
- Arduino & vvvv install check
- touchpad demos

## PART 1 (2h 15min)
- intro to electricity, resistance
- Velostat pressure sensor
- translate resistance to voltage (voltage divider)
- translate analog to digital (ADC)
- Velostat matrix
- internal pull-up resistors
- i/o pin reconfiguration
- matrix parsing code (Arduino)

## 30min break

## PART 2 (2h 30min)

- intro to patching with vvvv
- drawing a line with a mouse
- reading serial communication
- gray-scale translation of matrix data
- blob detection
- multi-tracking
- gesture recognition
- gesture training


# PLEASE bring:
 - if you have a Windows PC (or MAC with Windows install) please bring it (if you donâ€™t have Windows we will pair you up with somebody who does)
 - 3 button mouse
 - Multimeter
 - Scissors


# Download & Install:

- [Arduino](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software)
- vvvv (which only runs on Windows) - link coming soon
- [code examples](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1qHQdwfUu0VxNMObMrYzhY8tWm--GaEQY)


# We will provide:
  - Matrix kit (paper stencil, copper tape, Velostat, jumper wires)
  - Some multimeters
  - Arduino
  - Aligator clips
  - Scissors/cutter knives and mats
  - Regular tape

# Links
[pressure sensor matrix](https://www.kobakant.at/DIY/?p=7443)

title: Camp Cleanup Day! (Camp closes at 7PM)
description:
This is the day when we clean all the things and bring all the things home.

All materials must be removed from Shop Bins by 7PM.

All equipment must be returned to the ER by 7PM.

Everything must be removed from lockers by 7PM.

All campers must leave the floor by 7PM.

We close early on this day to complete admin tasks and then have a much needed staff dinner with the well-deserving counselors. 

We will miss you very, very much but please help us to close on time!

title: Friday Fireside: Paper Folding
description:
Simple to make, dazzling to look at, fun to pinch and touch!

Join us for a paper folding session, get a drink and eat good food from [Sage Kitchen](https://www.sagekitchen.com/)! Pleat paper to create a modular curtain for projection and illumination, experiment with folds to make paper structures, springs and patterns.

Easy and FUN!

title: Friday Fireside: Livecoding Music Performance by Koala Tokki
description:
Friday Fireside is our weekly all-camp event where we gather for food, drink, and an exciting event to bring us all together.

This week, we're excited to host a livecoding music performance by Koala Tokki, a media artist duo consisting of Michael Simpson and Yeseul Song. They will be programming music live on the stage while exposing the code on the screen. The algorithms they write with code will compose music in real-time. 

Hope you can join us!

* Koala Tokki (Yeseul Song, Michael Simpson) is a New York based media artist duo whose work exposes computational systems and processes to elucidate and magnify the inherent beauty within them. The duo create installations, audio-visual performances, and software. Both are alumni of NYU's Interactive Telecommunications Program (ITP) and the School For Poetic Computation. Currently, both Yeseul and Michael are Research Residents at ITP as well as Resident Artists in Mana Contemporary's New Media Program. Yeseul and Michael have collaborated for several years and their work has been shown at a number of places including New York Live Arts, IAC Building, Fort Mason Art and Culture Center, and SÃ³nar+D. The duo won the Communication Arts Interactive Annual Award in 2019.
https://koalatokki.com Instagram @yeseulsong_ @mgs.nyc

title: Friday Fireside - Art jam!!!
description:
All are invited to an amorphic, free-form, noisy, inclusive art jam! What is that? Let's find out! We will have-

-A PA system for people who want to make sound

-Multiple projectors for people who want to make visuals

-Space for movement/dancing

-Room for YOU!

Whatever art you'd like to make, bring it! If you need some specific equipment, let us know in the comments!

title: coloring computing
description:
the coloring computers are non-electronic digital computers that work when you color them according to a simple set of rules. some of these computers compare, others count, and some others allow you to play. 

in this workshop we'll have several printed copies of these computers. we'll introduce them and do a walkthrough of the rules of play. then we'll have time for coloring them. 

at the end we'll be able to share and compare our results, to talk about how computers perform complex functions with a combination of simple components, and to discuss the possible roles of computers that are neither efficient nor productive.

title: Liches and Kobolds and Owlbears, Oh My!: How to Play Dungeons and Dragons
description:
Hail and well met, adventurers! Have you secretly always wanted to partake in the holy grail of nerd-dom, but had no idea where to start? Look no further, this is the only side quest you'll need! In this workshop we will go over all the basics of how to be a player in the world of D&D (5th edition), including how to make a character, what all those weird dice are for, and some tips for different types of roleplaying. Then, weâ€™ll jump right into a game and actually play for the last hour and a half or so!

*No need to bring dice or character sheets, though you're welcome to use your own if you have them!*

title: Electronics bases part 1/2 - theory: simple components
description:
Are you interested in learning electronics bases with intuitive analogies?

[This course](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1wAiOwGdXLhd2jfT-Y60z3puwZVjwAUnTICC-0ZTqKcQ/) was made for artists, hackerspace tourists and autodidacts.

This is the 1st part of a double class, [the 2nd session](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2019/session/21) will be about designing your own PCB.

title: Magnificent Maya: A Beginner's Guide to 3D Modeling
description:
Are you tired of relying on Google Poly? Or using the same Unity/Unreal tree asset as everyone else? This session will do a deep dive into 3D modeling in Maya and show you how to make the assets you always dreamed of! We will go over the essential tools and techniques for making imaginative and natural forms. 

Weâ€™ll start by making our own sketches on paper in response to prompts and then bringing them to life in 3D by editing polygonal models/meshes and applying materials and textures. Youâ€™ll get to take home your very own unique 3D asset creation rendered with dramatic lighting (or whatever kind of lighting you choose).

If you are someone who has never done any 3D modeling or worked in Maya but are interested, this session is for you! If you are an expert 3D modeler in another program but never worked in Maya, you are welcome as well, but please be aware that the concepts and techniques may be a bit basic for you.

Please bring a laptop with Maya installed on it and a 3 button mouse. You can download a 30 day free trial of Maya here: https://www.autodesk.com/products/maya/free-trial

title: Feminist History of the Internet Walking Tour
description:
Weâ€™ll use 721 Broadway as a launching pad to learn about the history of the internet and NY tech - from Red Burns, the â€œGodmother of Silicon Alleyâ€, to Echo, one of the internetâ€™s first chatrooms (created by an ITP alum!) that boasted, â€œthe highest percentage of women in cyberspace. And none of them will give you the time of day." 

Weâ€™ll learn about this history and more while we travel to little-known historical sites such as Silicon Alley in the Flatiron District and the offices of Word.com, one of the earliest e-zines whose creative director was an ITP grad and got her start by making a digital magazine distributed on floppy discs! Weâ€™ll discuss how these pioneers have influenced the technologies we use today and the huge impact they have had on digital culture. And finally, we'll look into what modern day cyberfeminist groups such as Deep Lab up to! 

Wear good walking shoes!

title: Laser Cut Your Personality: Design and make your own acrylic earrings
description:
This will be a hands-on workshop on how to design and make your own acrylic earrings using laser cutting technology. 
The first half of the session will be a short introduction of laser cutting and designing adobe illustrator files ready to cut.  I will also show some acrylic earring products including some that I created. 
In the second half of the workshop, we will cut the earrings and share them with everyone. Everyone is welcomed but a laptop with adobe illustrator is highly recommended.
Participants can take the earrings the create and will also get some small giveaways.
tag_list: laser cut; design; illustrator; wearable; earrings;

title: Make a Fabric Touchpad
description:
This workshop builds off the workshop: [Multitouch Paper Recognizing Gestures PART 1&2](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2019/session/3). 
I will show you techniques for building textile pressure sensor matrices using a variety of techniques from:
- fusing
- machine sewing
- hand sewing

### Types of fabric touchpads (pressure sensor matrix) covered in the workshop:

#### [Stretchy Touchpad](http://www.kobakant.at/DIY/?p=7639)
[![stretchy touchpad](https://live.staticflickr.com/65535/33965032968_d0a7f9ded8.jpg)]
[![video](https://www.youtube.com/embed/Piey6b-PxJU)]

#### [Soft Touchpad](https://www.kobakant.at/DIY/?p=7651)
[![soft touchpad](https://live.staticflickr.com/65535/47820368281_e0593cb704.jpg)]

## prerequisites: 
Ideally youâ€™ve attended the previous workshop, but if you are knowledgeable on electronics and sensing, you are welcome to join.

# MATERIALS and TOOLS
Please bring any of the bellow materials and tools that you already have to this workshop!
ITP has some that we can use, but it is always good to have more.

## materials:
- conductive fabrics
- conductive threads
- velostat or eeonyx fabrics
- regular fabrics (stretch, non-stretch)
- regular sewing thread
- fusible interfacing (iron-on hot-melt adhesive)
- protoboard (with copper strips)
- ribbon cable or wires

## tools:
- sewing machines
- sewing needles
- scissors
- iron
- laptop/computer
- arduino/breadboard
- crocodile clips
- jumper wires
- soldering irons

title: Wear your tools!
description:
*â€œWith my tools at hand I pay attention to things I've never seen before."*

Bring a selection of your favourite tools and materials with you, and design and build a transformable [alwaysON apronPouch](http://wsp.plusea.at/alwayson-tool-apron/) that allow you to carry them with you at all times. 

We will go through a process of analyzing the form-factors, access-frequencies and use-combinations of your tool selection, consider where these could be placed in the apron-pouch and how they could be mounted.

Since there are only 2-4 sewing machines at ITP, please bring your own or borrow one and bring if possible. Realistically it will be possible for 6-8 people to productively work on sewing together a project in this workshop. But many more people can join to follow the process of thinking through and creating this design.

Never used a sewing machine before? Consider taking this class first:
https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2019/session/64

This workshop is part of [A Wearable Studio Practice](http://wsp.plusea.at/a-wearable-studio-practice/) - a collection of wearable and portable items that make it easier to become nomadic in your practice of making and manipulating the world.

Video: [alwaysOn apronPouch](https://youtu.be/AiUA03ap9MI)

[![alwaysON: apron](https://live.staticflickr.com/65535/33920069978_72b6d31964.jpg)]

[![alwaysON: pouch](https://live.staticflickr.com/65535/46880768835_e75a8753a0.jpg)]

[![pattern](https://live.staticflickr.com/65535/46939297705_575c72a210.jpg)]





# MATERIALS and TOOLS



## materials:
In order to build the [alwaysON apronPouch](http://wsp.plusea.at/alwayson-tool-apron/) you will need to bring following materials with you to this workshop:


### FABRIC
roughly 100x50cm piece of non-stretch fabric (canvas or tarp work well, but it can also be a thinner fabric)

[![patter pieces to cut out](https://live.staticflickr.com/65535/47953325418_ed16eb3e9b.jpg)]


### ZIPPER
40-60cm long open-able zipper (can be nylon-spiral, plastic or metal teeth)

[![open-end zipper](https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/0225/9227/products/5n557.png?v=1553550333)]


### ELASTIC
30-60cm of flat elastic (1-2cm wide)

[![flat elastic](http://ukhaberdashery.com/wp-content/uploads/imported/5/05/QUALITY-8-COLOUR-10mm-Satin-Soft-Feel-Strong-Lingerie-Flat-Elastic-Bra-Anti-Roll-302311986005.JPG)]


### WEBBING + BUCKLE
150cm of webbing strap and matching buckle (or an old belt!)
I like to use 2.5cm wide strap and buckle.

[![webbing](https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/0923/3012/products/flat-webbing.jpg?v=1481224967)]

[![buckle](https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/81cvs%2BFiuWL._SX425_.jpg)]


### SNAPS
one set of snaps (hand sewable, machine-press or magnetic)

[![hand-sew snaps](https://safetypinswholesale.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/metal-snaps.jpg)]

[![machine snap](https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/71YQrvwAemL._SX425_.jpg)]

[![magnetic snap](https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/51i30KD-ZSL._SX425_.jpg)]




## tools:
- scissors
- sewing machine
- snap press
- hole punch
- iron

title: Afraid of coding? Try patching with vvvv!
description:
[vvvv](https://vvvv.org) is a visualprogramming environment with a focus on creative coding type of scenarios. Think [processing](http://processing.org) only without writing code, but instead connecting boxes to create a program.

vvvv has been around since 2002 and has [recently been re-launched](https://vvvv.org/blog/vvvv-gamma-2019.1-preview) with many new features. So even if you've used vvvv before, this may be new to you!

![Example of face detection with vvvv and OpenCV](https://6-28.mastodon.xyz/media_attachments/files/006/741/695/original/37f7ca107bf5c566.png)
_Example of face detection with vvvv and OpenCV_

## What you will learn
In this hands-on workshop I'm going to introduce you to the ideas of visualprogramming with vvvv. We're going to realize a couple of examples step-by-step. You'll learn how to:

- create and export generative drawings as .svg or .pdf for further manipulation in a 2d vector software like e.g. [Inkscape](http://inkscape.org)
- use the [OpenCV](http://opencv.org) computervision library for tasks like face-detection 
- create an interactive 2d particle system

## Prerequisites
- vvvv only runs on windows 
- vvvv is best operated with a 3-button mouse. 

If you don't have a windows laptop you can still come to join and we'll see if we can pair you up with someone how brought one.
