title: Joints and Structures in Mylar (Dura-lar)
description: Mylar is easily cut by plotter or laser and manipulated into a large rang of sturdy structures that can be used as sculptural and structural components. Learn basic methods for designing and cutting strong, easy to assemble joints and folds.

title: Strength Training for Gym Avoiders
description:
Take a break from your desk chair and learn some simple, low- or no-equipment-necessary exercises to improve your strength and stability. Drawn from my experience as a weightlifting coach with diverse abilities in mind, this is a careful and patient introduction to safe and effective strength exercises.

Wear whatever is comfortable for you and bring a yoga mat if you have one.

Molly

title: Get Your Project Funded
description:
Now that you have been exposed to many technologies, in this session we will explore the key funding opportunities for your projects of different types. We will look at key private and public funding including investment, grants, commissions, and more. 

Presentation Notes here:
http://bit.ly/ITP-funds

title: Field Trip - Interactive Arts District: ON CANAL
description:
> 

Field trip to the interactive arts district ON CANAL, a collection of 20+ popup galleries and brand activations featuring works from digital and screen based artists and technologists. The tour will be a gallery hop. Wear comfy shoes. To learn more, visit: https://www.oncanal.nyc/

title: Movement As Medium: Intro to Stepper Motors and Kinetic Sculpture
description: This is an intro class to controlling stepper motors with a basic driver and arduino. This class will introduce you to different programming options for motors as well as different driver and microcontroller options. This class is about thinking about motor movement and honing different elements of stepper motors as a medium for making kinetic sculpture. This is also about how a little tech can add intense meaning. We will go over different resources for motors, basic simple machines, and end with a hands-on exercise using motors to drive sculptural form. It helps to have an interest in sculpture and fine art, but no requisites necessary.

title: 3D Text: Creative text in WEBGL + P5js
description:
This is an intro session that uses WEBGL in p5.js as a medium for creative writing! We will go over some interactive mouse and keyboard possibilities and how text can be applied to shapes in 3D digital environments. We can cover how different, simple computational strategies, functions, and formats (like for loops, noise, strings, arrays) can create different affects.  We will also talk about narrative control, creative hypertext formats, and how poetry and prose fit into the architecture of the internet. An interest in creative writing is suggested but not necessary. 
This is a beginner level course but I will send some videos and basic exercises before class so that p5.js isn't totally unfamiliar to students in the workshop!

title: Make Cards Pop! Paper engineering and pop-up card techniques
description:
Paper Engineering and pop ups are based on just a few main types of folds, unlocking unlimited possibilities. Come learn how to create these folds, and to manipulate them into storybooks, cards, or art.

This workshop will begin with instruction, and include time for you to work on your own card and ask questions as you work. This is a great workshop for you if you have a friend, or family member with a birthday or celebration coming up!

Join us!

**If you can, please bring:**  
- Scissors  
- Colored paper  
- Markers/Colored Pencils  
- Glue Sticks  
- Your favorite pop-up book or a pop-up card so we can talk about the techniques used to make it

title: Movement as Research: Creativity Warm-Up
description:
* spatial thinking; systems thinking
* dance as code; gesture as function
* IRL UX
* no movement experience required!

this workshop will get you ready for full-body listening, for multisensory and interactive creativity.  techniques drawn from contemporary dance-theatre mashed up with a coding modality. dress comfortably in clothes you can move in!

title: Slime Mold as Capacitive Storytelling - Session 1
description:
Slime mold is a beautiful living monoculture. Due to its tendency to grow in the pattern of nodes and branches, new media bio-artists have been using it as a medium to represent everything from the functionality of the Internet to diaspora migration patterns of the human race.

This workshop happens over the course of two sessions, separated by a week. In this workshop, youâ€™ll learn how to cultivate and care for your slime mold, creating a hospitable ecosystem for it to flourish. Weâ€™ll also mount low fi switches to our habitat that will act as switches, safely triggering sound samples that will play when the slime mold makes contact. Weâ€™ll discuss the kinds of audio both narrative and non-linear that may be meaningful to program. In session two weâ€™ll discuss the experience of witnessing this collaborative performance piece and look at creating more elaborate bio-ecosystems.

title: Become a Rhino-it-all! 3-D Modeling in Rhino 6
description:
Come learn the foundations of 3-D modeling through Rhino 6. We will start by covering the basic operations and move towards strategies for ideation: formal investigations, modular prototyping with existing materials (PVC pipes etc.), and work-flow approaches to 3-D printing, laser cutting, and routing on the OtherMill.  

Please download the 90-day free trail : https://www.rhino3d.com/download 

Come with rhino installed on your computer. Leave a Rhino-it-all.

title: Intro to Making Wonders
description:
Introduction to the art of performing magic focusing on the exploration of magic as a prompt to create real world solutions to real world challenges. You will get a sense on what is it like to be a magician as well as we will learn how to develop curiosity towards your passion. By the end of the workshop you will learn basic storytelling and acting techniques to perform a magic trick. And, finally, I will tell you why you should never play playing cards with strangers. 

Prerequisites:
1 deck of playing cards

title: Soft Circuits Skillshare: Machine Sewing 1 of 4
description:
Never used a machine to sew? Need a refresher in order to begin a new project?
Come learn to use the sewing machine.  

Due to the limited number of machines, this session is being capped at 10 attendees.  Please look for one of the 3 other sessions if this is full.  Feel free to reach out/find me if you unable to make one of those sessions and we will work out an impromptu sewing workshop.  

Please also bring any projects/ideas which you might have in mind or are currently working on.  If you are working with material other than a standard woven/knitted textile, please also bring that with you.  I will have multiple machine accessories (presser feet, needles, etc.) to accommodate varying materials and stitches.

title: Hands On Blender 2.8: Let's Make a Spaceship!
description:
[Link to workshop](https://generallyplayful.com/hints/intro-to-blender/)

[Download Blender 2.8](https://www.blender.org/2-8/)

This workshop will be a hands-on introduction to making things in 3D using the free and open source Blender 2.8. During this workshop we will design, model, and light a 3D spaceship, then prepare it for export to images, movies, and/or games!

We'll go over navigating the sometimes-confusing interface, creating and positioning things in 3D, and manipulating geometries to make your very own 3D models!

Once we have our model created, we'll briefly cover how to light the scene and then export it as an image, 3D printable object, or game-ready asset.

This workshop will be best experienced with a laptop, a 3-button mouse, and a copy of Blender 2.8 (it's completely free! https://www.blender.org/2-8/)

This workshop is beginner friendly. Blender is a great way to test the waters of 3D creation since it is and always will be free to use.

title: Machines Are Poets Too: Fun With Generative Text
description: We'll go through the basics of generative text software, focusing on preparing text and training models, then making generative texts with JS: markov chains in Rita.js, CharRNN and word2vec() in ml5, sentiment analysis with npm's sentiment module, and a brief introduction to some of the text-based models available in Runway (im2txt and txt2img). Pretrained models and code samples will be provided, but attendees are encouraged to bring text files that they'd like to play around with. By the end of the session, everyone will have generated texts on their own computer and taken home skills to apply to future text-based projects. Basic javascript and command line skills encouraged.

title: Asteroids! In Your Browser!
description:
In this beginner's workshop we will leverage ITP's favourite JavaScript library, p5.js, to create a fully fledged browser-based game of Asteroids from scratch. In doing so we will cover all sorts of programming fun, including randomness, Object Oriented Programming, physics, and human input. 

First we'll set up our scene, using random noise to create a beautiful starfield.

Next we'll build our ship, and make sure that we can control it using arrow keys. This section will cover human interaction, as well as setting up simple physics. Of course we'll include the asteroid defense laser here too, pew pew.

Finally, we'll add some asteroids! We'll revisit the concept of randomness here, and throw in some collision detection to make things fun. 

This workshop will be best experienced with a laptop and Chrome, though other browsers will work too.

title: What is User Centered Design?
description:
Taken from the IDEO/IBM playbook,  I'll take you through how we can use user-centered design to create products, services, and experiences by keeping peopleâ€™s lives and desires at the core. 

With this Field Guide, youâ€™ll be armed with the tools needed to bring that belief to life! In this session, we'll go through the philosophy of design and the
seven mindsets that set us apart: Empathy, Optimism, Iteration, Creative Confidence, Making, Embracing Ambiguity, and Learning from Failure. We'll also go through interactive 'methods' to bring the theory to practice!

title: Intro to Unity: Designing A One Button Game for Mobile
description:
Unity is a multi-purpose game engine that makes it easy to quickly prototype games, systems, and applications using its extensive builtin features. 

Game design isn't all about flashy graphics and giant studio teams. You can make a game just as good as any other using just one button! In this introductory workshop you'll learn how to use Unity to express creative ideas by implementing fundamental gaming mechanics. Then you'll design your own One Button Game to test and run on your mobile device. 

We'll be going over the Unity engine, interface, and different components while also discussing what constitutes good game design. We'll go over programming fundamentals while building a game together. Towards the end, you'll think of what type of game you want to make and harness the one button restriction to get creative. 

For anyone interested in Unity and dipping their feet in game design! 


### **Before Attending**
- Please bring your mobile device and connecting USB cord
- Download the app "Unity Remote 5" 
- Download and setup the free community edition of Unity


http://bit.ly/itp-rise : lesson

password: ITP2019


http://bit.ly/itp-unity :gist code

title: Introduction to Python
description:
This session will cover an introduction of the Python programming language using Google's free Colabratory service. Python is the GREATEST and BESTEST programming language ever created, and you'll learn why this Monday night. I'll start by showing you how to use Google's tools and teach basic language syntax and data structures. I'll also give you an idea of where you can go using Python tools to analyze and visualize data.

This session will be suitable for beginners. All are welcome!

title: Github for Artists : Experiment and Collaborate Faster
description:
Join us for a session in how to incorporate Github into your creative and professional practice.  The first half of the sessions we will go over the basics of using Github with the command line (plus a command line refresher) and the second will lead you through practical examples on collaboration and artistic iteration.  Brent Bailey and myself will lead you through a series of fun and engaging real life use cases and you will come out this session with the skills to incorporate Github into your projects.  

Intended Audience : People with basic coding and command line experience, basic knowledge of P5.

title: Interactive Product Design: "Designing for People" Workshop
description:
The course leads participants in the creation of interactive product and/or experience for human users to communicate the value of iterative human-focused design methodology. The course will answer questions such as: 

âŒ¾ How to insert user's motivations and expectations into the design process? 
âŒ¾ How to go about product design process that includes elements such as: conducting research, defining problem, collecting data, mapping user experience journey, sketching ideas, storytelling, rapid prototyping, and user evaluation/validation.

Students will be active participants in class during:
âŒ¾ ideation/brainstorming exercise
âŒ¾ group discussion/collaborative sessions 
âŒ¾ sketching exercise/listening exercise 

Students will work in groups to implement concepts learned as well as in-class exercises to develop a quick physical product or interactive experience prototype and sharing final concept, design, and prototype to the class for feedback.

title: Getting Started With "LiVELY": Create Your Own SMS Inputs For Public Displays
description:
This session will show you how to build custom public SMS input sessions using "Lively", a creative web-based texting platform that uses WEBGL that I worked on that allows for multiple participants to send messages to a shared public display. Lively has been shown at conferences, festivals, meetings, universities, classrooms, and more around the world. Visualizations include 3D blocs, custom background videos and audio, dynamic images, and more...

In this session you will build your own Lively sessions, customize their look/feel, and deploy them to the public or for whatever experience you want to have audience input. All participants in this workshop will have access to "Premium" accounts which will allow for full control of the system.

No Programming Skills Needed

Everyone should bring a laptop to this session as we will be using Google Chrome to author sessions.

More info on Lively](http://www.livelyevent.com)

title: Visual Sarcasm: Intro to Urban Projections & Data Juxtapositions
description:
## *note*: **Bring your laptop, no specific software necessary.**

Have a message you want to shout from the rooftops? We will look at how dynamic data can be projected into public space to encourage discourse around the sociopolitical issues of our day â€“ and how juxtaposing diverse data sets can be used as a strategy to get your message across.

In this workshop, you will create an initial concept for your own urban data visualization projection. You will select a dataset (we will provide options, or you can come with your own); develop your angle or story around the data; juxtapose the data with another data set and create an initial sketch.

This workshop can be used as a starting point to our next workshop, which will allow you to create and project a data juxtaposition into public space.

![Killing Time](https://datainpublic.space/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/DSC07589-761x1024.jpg)

This workshop comes out of our most recent project, DOUBLESPACE. 
Find us on instagram: [@datainpublic](https://instagram.com/datainpublic/)
and at our work-in-progress website: [datainpublic.space](https://datainpublic.space/)

Workshop Resources:

[**datasets**](https://datainpublic.space/map/resources/data/text-20/)

title: Evening Projection Session: Make and Display Your Own Public Projection
description:
## *note:* **Bring a laptop, no particular software required**

[**resource link**](https://datainpublic.space/map/resources/data/text-40/)

Digital media is encroaching on public space. How can we use projection to carve our space for digital media â€“ for â€“ citizens?

We will introduce the method of Web-Based Urban Projections as a low threshold way to participate in the public digital media landscape. With Web-Based Urban Projections, anyone can create content to be shared in public, host it online, and then project it into pubic space.

In this workshop, you will choose your own story and datapoint, create your own web-based data visualization, get a URL to share with your friends, and end the session with a public projection of everyoneâ€™s work.

![doublespace project graphic](https://datainpublic.space/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/peojectgraphic-80-976x1024.jpg "icon")

This workshop comes out of our most recent project, DOUBLESPACE. Find us on instagram: @datainpublic and at our work-in-progress website: datainpublic.space

title: How Are We Talking About AI? A Data Viz Exploration
description:
## *note:* **Please Bring Your Laptop, or sign one out from IT.** No special software needed.

## [> `API Link`](https://groupchat.datainpublic.space/index.html#!/entries/get_entries_latest_search)

How are we collectively talking about AI? How do reddit comments compare to discussions in the UK parliament? We have created a custom dataset that collects coverage on AI across 4 different sectors: news media, academic scholarship, government, and public comments online.

What kinds of stories can we tell from this data? In this workshop, you will â€œsmell the dataâ€, determine what kind of story you would like to tell, and create and share a sketch of your own data visualization.

This workshop comes out of our most recent project, DOUBLESPACE. Find us on instagram: @datainpublic and at our work-in-progress website: datainpublic.space

title: ml5.js: A Friendly Introduction to Machine Learning
description:
ml5.js(https://ml5js.org) aims to make machine learning approachable for a broad audience of artists, creative coders, and students. The library provides access to machine learning algorithms and models in the browser, building on top of TensorFlow.js with no other external dependencies.

The library is supported by code examples, tutorials, and sample datasets with an emphasis on ethical computing. Bias in data, stereotypical harms, and responsible crowdsourcing are part of the documentation around data collection and usage.

During the workshop, we will talk about some basic concepts in machine learning and build an image/sound classifier!

title: Getting stuff done: going from Idea to ACTION
description:
Makers & doers are frequently face 3 types of resistance: a) personal resistance or fear, b) social resistance or pressure, c) creative resistance or the best/worst feeling of having too many ideas. 

Join this workshop to think about how to identify + overcome whatever resistance is holding you back. We will explore different ways to manage our time, our energy, and how to channel it into projects. 

In the end, everybody will leave with a sort of plan/design of how they will go about executing any idea. 

Less talking/thinking/wishing ... more doing! POW!


Session Slides --> http://bit.ly/idea2actionitp

title: Field Trip: Material Connexion Materials Library
description:
Material ConneXion maintains the worldâ€™s largest subscription-based materials library with thousands of innovative materials and processes across all disciplines of design. They maintain a showroom with recently added samples for you to see and touch, With new materials added each month, materials in its collection are  are curated to showcase the newest and most exciting innovations beginning to be available for manufacture. It is a great place to visit to find inspiration and/or learn what is coming in the near future.

https://www.materialconnexion.com/
This video is from their old location, but is still a good overview.
What's Material Connexion? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=swfiZ3Mk204

We will meet at ITP to travel together up to their midtown location for a 5pm appointment. The session is capped at 18 people to accommodate the need for us to send the RSVP list in advance, and be relatively quiet in their open office. It is necessary for every attendee to bring a government issued photo ID that matches the First/Last name they reserved under.

title: Concept to Object - Designing for Fabrication in Fusion 360
description:
Learn the basics of Autodesk's Fusion 360 modeling program to bring your concepts into the real world. Planning to cover basics of modeling, design parameters for fabrication and prepping a design for CNC milling around a real world object. We may not actually get to shop stuff this session but would plan on actually cutting an object on the CNC router. 

Very open to suggestions on stuff people want to make!

title: Singing with Motors!
description:
Did you know that any motor can sing? In fact, almost every motor is essentially a speaker! Basically anything that vibrates, can be programmed to sing. Attaching a motor to different materials can provide an array of wonderfully weird noises.

In this workshop we will be using motors to create our own instruments. We will explore what it means to create digital sound for an analog purposes. Additionally, we can learn how to transform songs into MIDI, and how to program music with Arduino.

PS. Some of the best motors come from recycled electronics. Old printers, drills, CD drives, RC carsâ€¦ Bonus points if you come with a motor with a past who is ready for a revival.

title: Wearable Pulse Sensor Workshop
description:
# Pulse Sensor + LilyTwinkle

[Pulse Sensor](https://pulsesensor.com/) is a plug-and-play heart rate monitor for Arduino. You can plug it in to just about any programmable micro-controller platform and get heart beats and BPM. But what if you want to really slim it down? Make a light-weight and truly wearable project? This workshop will do just that! We'll start with the basics of how Pulse Sensor works, and what kinds of data you can get from it. Then, we'll go through connecting Pulse Sensor to the [LilyTwinkle ProtoSnap](https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11590) to create a heart beat project that you can wear to your next geeky nerd party or cosplay convention! The first 20 participants will get a free Pulse Sensor and a LilyTwinkle!

title: Roll Your Own MFA (Introduction to Self-education)
description:
In this session we will discuss pursuing education in arts & technology through workshops, small programs, tiny schools, conferences, incubators, and other part time & short-term opportunities.

For many people professional degrees are out of reach for time, financial, or other practical/personal reasons. However there are many different ways to pursue learning in the arts & technology space outside of degree programs.

The session will start with a short introduction to self-education and building a school for yourself. I will talk a bit about my own attempts at achieving a self-education comparable to an MFA including some tips & tricks.

From there we will review and expand upon the "[Unschool Catalog](https://bit.ly/unschoolcatalog)" - a living document created and maintained for this class that contains links to other relevant schools, programs, opportunities, books, films, and materials.

You can view the unschool catalog here: [https://bit.ly/unschoolcatalog](https://bit.ly/unschoolcatalog)

This is the fourth year this workshop has been offered. Every year we continue to expand the unschool catalog with new information. I greatly appreciate participants coming with previous experience to share and new opportunities to reveal. 

If you're a bit overwhelmed by the self-directed nature of ITP camp this is a great place to help get you centered. If you're already a self-educating autodidact we greatly appreciate you participating and sharing your experiences.

A previous workshop from ITP can be viewed here: [https://vimeo.com/172792458](https://vimeo.com/172792458)

title: Sunday Evening Tech Poetry Reading & Writing
description: Reading poetry about technology together, we'll examine what poetry can teach us about our work and what it means to be a technologist and an artist. This is *not* a machine generated poetry workshop, but rather a very chill reading of poems written by humans about machines. I'll bring selections from Franny Choi, Sasha Stiles, Terrance Hayes, and more to lead a discussion. We can also do a little poetry writing exercise.

title: Learn the Command Line with LocalNet Adventure!!
description:
> ![](https://s26913.pcdn.co/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/business-hackers.jpg)
> A network island... full of mystery... you must find your way and win!

The internet of today appears to us as a monolithic, totalizing force. In this workshop/alternate reality game we will do work to demystify it, imagine alternatives, and show how the internet doesn't have to be the only network around. To do so we will engage with and explore a simulated infrastructure of a pocket local networks, on something like a digital scavenger hunt. Our goal is to be playful with our network technologies while still being critical of their uses and impacts on our lives. 

If you've never used the command line before this is a great way to learn, but if you're  a pro you'll still find it challenging.

Here is the game's reference sheet: 
[http://blog.alden.website/post/localnet-adventure-LA/](http://blog.alden.website/post/localnet-adventure-LA/)

title: Machine Learning Without Computers
description:
##Machine Learning Without Computers##

In this workshop we will explore core concepts in Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence without using computers. We will learn about dimensionality reduction, classification, machine hallucination, training bias, and more, all without using a computer or writing an equation. No background in math or theory is required - applicable to all disciplines.

In teaching Machine Learning it can be difficult to bridge the gap between "WOW COOL!" and the actual theory and mathematics behind it. It's possible to teach people how to quickly do cool stuff without learning the theory. Or you can teach math and theory but won't get to hands on.

This workshop attempts to bridge this gap by using an amazing intelligent learning machine we already possess to explore the subject: the human brain.

A follow-up session, "Technology and Society", will continue and build on the discussion from this session. While not required, the second session is highly recommended.

Register for "Technology and Society" here: [https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2019/session/130](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2019/session/130)

title: Build moving machines (automata) out of cardboard!
description:
Delightful Hand Crank Automata have been around for hundreds of years (or longer), and range from the simple to [extremely elaborate](https://www.thisiscolossal.com/2016/06/elaborate-hand-cranked-automata-by-dave-hall/). Learn about basic machines (mechanisms) and how to construct them out of cardboard, craft materials, and recycled items. Optionally, add an Arduino, motor, sensors, and LEDs for high-tech excitement. Materials will be provided, but for added variety bring bottle caps, broken toys, unused trinkets, and items from your recycling bin.

Courses I teach that utilize these skills include "Performing Robots" and "Machine Lab". Students often seem to rush to the laser cutter without a clear idea of how a mechanism will behave. Prototyping mechanisms in cardboard allows us to quickly modify the design when confronted by differences between how we thought it would work and how it really works (or doesn't).

No prior experience necessary. If you've ever thought "I can't make anything" this class is for you.

title: Targeted Response Emotion Vectors (try the REAL prototype after last year's camp Emotional AI session/s)
description:
Did you attend the Emotional AI workshop last year?? Curious to try out the ACTUAL working prototype and be part of making history? You are welcome to join a select group of awesome campers who are interested in participating in biometric testing of this state of the art invention that just might make it possible for people to achieve a level of emotional enhancement with this novel invention. 

Completely safe and voluntary! The area will be set up and interested and intrepid techies can try it out for 20 mins and help advance science and AI and so much more! Note: Sign up by slapping the link below in a new tab (not sure why this platform doesn't make it clickable!) B/C you'll then be able to get a text from me when it's your turn to play: https://forms.gle/xDncxQYSBTkhbFpu7

title: Idea vs Self: encountering and using foreign ideas
description:
The world is an infinite source of ideas and inspiration. One man's trash is another man's treasure. There is nothing new under the sun, only new combinations. 

This discussion session explores the ways in which we create new juxtapositions and find innovative solutions through connecting disparate ideas in the process of interdisciplinary learning about the world and ourselves.

Weâ€™ll go over the relevance of engaging with foreign ideas, conditioning that prevents growth and learning, tools to increase our exposure to what we don't know we don't know and how to become more resourceful and capable.

Before the session, it would be helpful to think about your own experiences with encountering unexpected ideas that became useful.

title: Drawing Characters
description:
Drawings are like potato chips â€“ itâ€™s hard to stop at just one.  

Drawing skills are becoming increasingly important for animators, designers, storyboard artists, and anyone who wants to communicate ideas simply and effectively. Perhaps you want some time drawing from a model to work on developing a character. This course will let you work on your drawing, whether you are beginning, intermediate, or advanced. 

There will be a clothed live model and you will need to bring something to draw with and something to draw on.

title: Tech Talk: Bring Your Own Lunch
description: This is a low-key social meet up for anyone who might be at ITP Camp during daytime hours. Bring your own lunch, come by, and say hello! Talk with other campers about what you're working on, or anything else that's on your mind.

title: Introduction to Augmented Reality
description:
Let's make some augmented reality. GabeBC will teach you how to use Unity to create some simple AR and will also provide a brief overview of what's going on in the field. 

Before Attending
Download the free version of Unity and be sure to install with Vuforia

title: Intro to video mapping
description:
The session will cover basic video mapping using mad mapper as well as a bit of a history of video mapping and art. Taught by GabeBC

Please bring a white object to the class to use for mapping!

title: Visualizing New York City in Data
description:
This workshop introduces students to a variety of code-based methods for visualizing urban data. The first portion of the workshop will cover the fundamentals of obtaining, analyzing, and visualizing data, as well as how to avoid common mistakes that occur when working on a data-related project. The second portion of the workshop will be a hands-on tutorial where students will learn how to visualize geospatial data using Python's geopandas library. Some experience working with Python is recommended but by no means necessary.

Students should install a copy of [Anaconda 3 ](https://www.anaconda.com/distribution/) prior to attending the session.

title: Masks & Mysteries: Live Action Interactive Stories
description:
Immersive Theatre, Interactive Performance, Participatory Art, LARP, Pop-Up Experiences, Big Games...audiences are interacting with stories and characters in increasingly inventive ways, from grand theatrical works such as "Sleep No More", to Nordic â€œkitchen sinkâ€ LARPs. In this workshop, weâ€™ll try out a few of this kind of embodied, narrative experience, discuss principles employed in their design, and then make and perform our own unique experiences!

NOTE: This workshop does not teach new tech skills and requires no prerequisite skills, apart from a willingness to get a little weird and performative! Of course, participants should feel free to bring in their own digital chops!

title: Creating VR in VR
description:
Perhaps more than anything else VR is an amazing creation (& co-creation) tool.

Explore the tools for making Art, building Stories & creating Assets inside of VR & get to understand what each one is and does.

- TiltBrush
- Blocks
- Quill
- Medium
- MasterpieceVR & Motion.

We will talk about new workflows to bringing assets into VR and exporting them out as models, games and stories for other platforms.

We will also be speaking about the VR Editors of platforms like Unity & Unreal as well as Collaboration tools

title: Jewelry making basics, with LEDs
description: Learn the basics of jewelry making, from components, to loops, to wire wrapping. Then we embed LED sequins on a piece of your choice, be it earrings, on a pendant or even in a bracelet. Hands on soft circuitry.

title: Coding Cultural Interfaces
description: How do we conceptualize mapping a cultural artifact from our minds to the cavnas? We will look at some readings, and as a class draw an African mask in p5.js.

title: Make your audio great with EQ and compression!
description:
Working on a project that uses audio?

Need that audio to be heard in a noisy environment?

Need a sound to blend with other sounds, but still be heard clearly?

Want to learn tools for music production, film audio mixing or podcast recording?  

WE CAN HELP YOU!

EQ and compression are the salt and pepper of audio processing. They've both been around for many years and are relatively simple to understand. But they're often misunderstood or used ineffectively.

We'll learn how best to use these tools, with a focus on learning the underlying concepts and training our ears. We'll look at how they apply to real-world situations, like music production and dialog mixing. I'll use Logic Pro X to demonstrate the concepts, but they're applicable to any Digital Audio Workstation or software that utilizes audio processing.

This workshop is geared to anyone that works with audio, with a beginner to intermediate knowledge of these tools.

Note: this is not a code-based workshop. We'll be working with easy-to-use audio plugins.

title: Tape casting
description: Learn how to make easy casts with saran wrap and tape and then combine different forms for abstract creations.

title: Camp Orientation
description: Learn everything you need to know about ITP Camp! This is recommended for everyone!

title: Show One Thing Show
description:
A hybrid talent show / open-mic / show-and-tell extravaganza! Each person will have ONE MINUTE + ONE SLIDE to present ONE THING

For example, you might want to share:

* A project you made
* A place you traveled
* A hobby you have
* A dance you know
* A song you wrote
* A thing you ate
* There are only 2 rules for the slide: it must include your NAME, and it cannot include any video content.

It will be a fun opportunity to get to know each other better, we hope everyone will sign up to share :)

### [Add your slide here](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1y1nbjYlQ4xoYr-X7lEZICbmGeoKUpQZ7sgZuOsTUw_Q/edit?usp=sharing)

title: Circuitboard Art
description:
A circuit board is a canvas, if looked at with the right eye. It is basically a fibre glass board, with a copper layer, and two layers of paint on each side of board. With this, an artist can get shades of colors and surface textures. Each board is milled with a CNC, so you can get it in any shape and size. And best of all, it is ridiculously cheap and fast to manufacture. 

We will learn basics of Eagle- a PCB design software. Everyone will design a small PCB badge for the camp which will then be manufactured in China and given back to you before end of camp.

No prior experience needed. Please bring a laptop with the latest version of Eagle installed. https://www.autodesk.com/products/eagle/free-download

title: PCB Milling
description:
Small CNC mills are the fastest way to produce two sided circuit boards at home. But the same techniques can be used to mill metal, wood and plastics. 

In this session we will learn the basics of CNC milling. We will demo using the OtherMill software to cut aluminium and acrylic, and see how illustrator files can be milled easily. Working in groups, everyone will mill a small circuit board badge to take home.

No prior experience needed. Please bring a laptop with Bantham tools software installed. https://resources.bantamtools.com/software-download

** If you can't make it to this session, or if there aren't enough spots, please look at the repeat session from 2-4pm on the same day **

title: Show All Things Show And Closing Party!
description:
This year, as part of the closing party we will be having the Show All Things Show!

This is not a formal presentation or a fancy exhibition. This is an opportunity for you to share any and all projects or works in progress you've generated during your time at ITP Camp 2019. Items to put in the Show All Things Show include: materials tests, sketches, rough prototypes, projects-in-process, installations, objects, software, video, sound pieces, immersive experiences, manifestos, demos, or anything else you'd like to share!

Our ideal is to have EVERYONE share something, no matter how small. More details will follow, but if you have any questions or want to talk through ideas, just stop by Counselor HQ!

Note: Sessions leaders are all invited to attend!

title: Archaeology of the Ancient Internets
description:
what does the ancient internet have to teach us? 
what do your own old projects look like? 
what did the sites that you visit everyday today look like in 1998?

what do we miss? what sucked?
how does the design of the internet relate to the aesthetics of public space? of power? 

we will use the wayback machine to find examples and discuss/critique nostalgia, centralization, standardization, aesthetics, and the past + future of the web.  

we will also have some good laughs about what AltaVista + GeoCities looked like.

-

slides from session: http://45.55.202.222/itp2019/archaeologyInternets.pdf

Olia Lialina Tumblr (GeoCities archive project w/bot crawler): 
https://oneterabyteofkilobyteage.tumblr.com/

sources I listed for critical theory/aesthetics/power/public space:

Guy Debord, Society of the Spectacle - full text online: https://bit.ly/2Wrb27v


Jean Baudrillard, Simulations and Simulacra 

Michel de Certeau, The Practice of Everyday Life

Walter Benjamin, Illuminations

Pierre Bourdieu, Firing Back Against the Tyranny of the Market 

Invisible Cities, Italo Calvino

*above = the tip of the iceberg! if you want more readings on this subject, i can give more recommendations.

-

also if anyone is interested, the Internet Archive also archives old software...a lot of old games are on there: https://archive.org/details/OregonTrailMacintosh  !!

title: reFrame: a primer on transparent displays
description:
## Welcome to the world of Alternative Displays!

Learn the potential of transparent displays as an artistic medium! Transparent displays have been around for long time, mostly used practically in Military in Heads Up Displays (HUD) and Holographic Weapon Sights to augment important information over the physical world. In the civilian world however these displays lose their augmentation capabilities. In the commercial scene they are mostly used as eye-candy for product display, and in the art scene you see them used from time to time in installations or performances.

reFrame is for the most part a methodology to turn transparent displays into AR windows that tailor information to each user. It was developed as part of my thesis here at ITP, and i'm very excited to teach you all about it. By the end of the class you will have a new interactive medium on your hands with a lot of potential to discover. The last part of the class would be dedicated to discussion of how it might be applied to various industries.

This class will use Touchdesigner and Kinect as its core technologies, but the principles are applicable to any 3D rendering environment, or any 3D people tracking system.

1. Welcome to the world of alternative displays
2. Relevant development history of transparent and head's up displays
3. So why aren't transparent displays everywhere?
4. Optics, perspective, lighting, parallax
5. Building a cheap transparent display from scratch
6. Q&A on the state of the technology
7. Setting up Touchdesigner
8. understanding Kinect development strategies
9. Correcting for Parallax
10. Adding elements augmented to the reality through the window
11. Further discussions.

#### suggested duration: 2:00 hrs

title: PCB Milling - Encore
description:
** This is a repeat session of the one from 11-1pm. **

Small CNC mills are the fastest way to produce two sided circuit boards at home. But the same techniques can be used to mill metal, wood and plastics.

In this session we will learn the basics of CNC milling. We will demo using the OtherMill software to cut aluminium and acrylic, and see how illustrator files can be milled easily. Working in groups, everyone will mill a small circuit board badge to take home.

No prior experience needed. Please bring a laptop with Bantham tools software installed. https://resources.bantamtools.com/software-download

title: jQuery Nuts and Bolts: IMMERSION in the browser
description:
treating the browser like a stage, using the javascript library jQuery to affect a user's experience of light, sound, movement, video - a great base for creative coding and interactive storytelling of all kinds.

you can get deeply, dynamically interactive without AR/VR!

some experience with HTML, CSS or Javascript would be helpful for this workshop, but we will work with the experience in the room and help each other out.  this could work for beginners.  if you're super-advanced, come help others code!

-

JSFiddle:

https://jsfiddle.net/mab253/t5xh7zq6/

video asset: 
http://45.55.202.222/frigata.mp4

background sounds assets:

http://www.greenestreet.nyc/assets/audio/intro1.mp3

http://migration.nyudri.org/intro/intro1.mp3

title: Introduction to Arduino Through Sound
description:
This is a session for people who want to get an introduction to the Arduino microcontroller and are interested in sound and music. You're also welcome if you already know Arduino, or if you teach Arduino,  and want to see a different approach to introducing microcontrollers than blinking an LED.  I'll use the Arduino MKR Zero for this session instead of the venerable Arduino Uno. This is a more modern Arduino that can do a few things the Uno can't. 

In this session, I'll talk about how microcontrollers generate sound, and how sounds are organized into a musical scale. Then we'll make some music. From there, we'll talk about generating a melody. 

The session is based on a [series of tutorials](https://tigoe.github.io/SoundExamples/) I wrote this past winter and spring. I've taught introductions to Arduino countless times, but never this way before. So it should be an adventure for me and you both. 

I'll follow this up with a second session on [advanced music things](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2019/session/182) you can do with the MKR Zero.

title: Neat Music Things You Probably Didn't Know You Could Do With An Arduino
description:
In this session, I'll show how to generate music using MIDI over USB and over Bluetooth LE  from an Arduino MKR Zero and a MKR 1010 or a Nano 33 IoT. I'll also show how to play sound files from an SD card using the I2S sound protocol. 

This is the second session of two I'm running on making music with Arduino. The material comes from a  [series of tutorials](https://tigoe.github.io/SoundExamples/) I wrote the past few months highlighting some of the features of the Arduino MKR series of boards. If you're familiar with Arduino, you don't need to come to [the first session](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2019/session/180) to make sense of this one.

title: Intro to Neopixels!
description:
Ever want to incorporate LEDs into your work but thought LEDs were hard? Fret no more -- LEDs are simple and easy to use! This workshop will enable you to know the fundamentals of using the addressable WS2812B LED (aka. neopixel) strip in conjunction with the Adafruit Neopixel library. I will also cover topics like power considerations, power consumption and LED colors, as well as pose simple programming puzzles so that you really leave the workshop knowing how to use LED strips. 

Please bring: 
-an arduino (any one will do)
-laptop
-cord to connect the arduino to laptop

I will supply the rest!

title: Many Ways to Fade an LED
description:
If you've worked with a microcontroller before, you've probably faded an LED. Sure you have. But was it a really *satisfying* fade? Did it end too quickly?  Was it a problem when you wanted to interrupt it from a button or a knob? Did you give up in frustration and use NeoPixels and the auto-fading examples for them instead, resulting in a project that had softly scrolling rainbow colors that made your project look like something out of a Burning Man Instagram feed? 

Your first LED project with a microcontroller is a bit like your first autobiographical story in a creative writing class, Everyone has to do it. And it should probably be put in a drawer after you do, and never be seen again. You can get better  by doing it again and again and again. 

I've faded LEDs with microcontrollers a lot. I'm getting better at it. In this session I'll introduce some microcontroller techniques from a class I teach at ITP called [Light and Interactivity](https://itp.nyu.edu/classes/light/), and talk about some of the things I've learned to make my projects look and feel better.

title: Metal Etching with just a 9-volt battery and a Q-tip? Yes!
description:
Electric Etching is the process of using electricity and an electrolyte to etch a pattern onto a metal surface. A non-conductive pattern is placed over the material to be etched. The metal to be worked on is then grounded. The live wire is then connected to the applicator. When the applicator is applied to metal surface, wherever is not masked will be etched. The advantage of using electricity to etch metal is that it is a very predictable process. If it is desirable to have a deep etch, a higher current or longer exposure time increases the prominence of the edge. While this all can sound complicated, it can be done with just a 9-volt battery, a q-tip, alligator clips and some salty water!

During this session we will hand-cut stencils from vinyl (you can upgrade your project by using a vinyl cutter available on the floor ahead of time for making a stencil), and practice electric etching on a scrap piece of metal I provide.  Another upgrade you can do is to bring your own metal object from home! (Any conductive metal is great including copper, aluminum, stainless steel, brass, etc)

If we have a lot of sign ups, people will be sharing equipment, so if you happen to have a 9-volt battery and alligator clips of your own, it would be helpful if you bring it.

title: Intro to making music with Ableton Live
description:
I did this class last summer... people seemed to enjoy it, so here's another one for anyone who wasn't there (or wants a refresher)!

After a brief intro into what makes Ableton unique among Digital Audio Workstations, we'll dive right into making some music. Towards the end of class, we'll explore using iPhones to remotely control parameters in Ableton.

This class is geared towards Ableton beginners, at any level of musical ability.

Before class, please:

-Download and run the [Ableton free trial version](https://www.ableton.com/en/trial/). It's big-ish, so please download and install before the workshop starts.

-Download [these files](https://we.tl/t-BvcLTRvWrG) I've prepared.

-iPhone users, please download [this free app](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/faders-us/id444262646).

Bring headphones/earbuds (or check them out from the equipment room)

title: Thursday Night Out: Vol De Nuit
description: During the year ITP students traditionally go out to a nearby bar on Thursday Nights to blow off steam and complain about circuits/javascript/CNCs/whatever else may be bothering them. We're taking this tradition to camp this year, starting at Vol De Nuit: an open-air beer bar and fry spot near NYU. Come by!

title: Soft Circuits Skill share: Machine Sewing 2 of 4
description:
Never used a machine to sew? Need a refresher in order to begin a new project?
Come learn to use the sewing machine.  

Due to the limited number of machines, this session is being capped at 10 attendees.  Please look for one of the 3 other sessions if this is full.  Feel free to reach out/find me if you unable to make one of those sessions and we will work out an impromptu sewing workshop.  

Please also bring any projects which you might have in mind or are currently working on.  If you are working with material other than a standard woven/knitted textile, please also bring that with you.  I will have multiple machine accessories (presser feet, needles, etc.) to accommodate varying materials and stitches.    

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1uQ8iwRy3LyT4crxVV_rtfN24DEDlR9UJJjLopXI5XTw/edit?usp=sharing

title: Plotter/Cutter Skill Share
description:
Interested in using the vinyl cutter for cutting thin sheet material or drawing pictures from vectors? This is a quick walk-through of set-up for the graphtec vinyl cutter. I'll demo cutting mylar (for stencils or structures) and drawing with a pen/marker/paintbrush.

I'll bring materials for this quick demo. To make you're own work you'll need a vector program (Illustrator) and the Cutting Master plug-in for the plotter.

If you're interested but the time doesn't work for you, please let me know and we can add another session.

Molly

title: Machines Learning Movement
description:
In the past several years, Machine Learning has been the buzzword, from the new algorithms Netflix and Amazon use to recommend you products to the latest technical intervention/disruption to the art world.

Here's are some awesome artists using Machine Learning in their practice:

Ross Goodwin
Kyle McDonald
Gene Kogan

These artists feed their algorithms images and words to create pieces completely unique. But as a movement practitioner, I wondered what the role of movement had in this new exciting world.

Can machines learn movement? 
If so, what can we do?

Agenda
Today we will accomplish the following:

1. Record and label our movements using the Kinect and Processing
2. Use a classifier to teach our computers how to identify our movements
3. Trigger something fun with our movements!

Already feel a little lost? It's ok, just roll with it. Today is a day to try something new, make mistakes (or completely mess up), and get out of your comfort zone! This will be very technical (which is why I included all the code), but don't forget to have fun and don't be afraid to get a little creative with the instructions!

title: Un-Gym Class: Week 1 B
description:
Start your camp day with a little fun, low-pressure strength development exercise in the park. We will cover proper posture and technique and ways of adjusting the difficulty of each movement to fit your needs. I'll introduce new moves each class, and the A and B classes each week will address different areas.

Everyone is welcome, no special skills or equipment required. Wear comfortable shoes and bring a yoga mat if you have one. We will meet by the elevator and walk to the park (weather permitting).

Note: I will happily add sessions at different times if there is demand. Just let me know.

title: Machine Learning for Creative Technologists
description:
**Are you a creative person interested in making new things with technology? Curious about machine learning (ML) but don't know where to start?**

In this workshop, I will give you the primer you need to begin creating rich and innovative new ML-based interactions for music, art, and other creative work.

At the end of the session, you will come away with an intuition about how ML works, and receive ideas plus working examples on how to apply ML as part of your creative toolkit.

We will begin with the absolute basics about ML, so *no* prior knowledge or rigorous math background is necessary. Programming experience in any form will be helpful but is not compulsory. Please bring a laptop!

Note: this session is an experiment - it arose from my conversations with campers. I hope to share what I know about ML, to introduce its potential, and to explore the world of creative applications of ML together. Any suggestions are welcome as I continue to plan the session!

title: Building a Catapult with Arduino
description:
Last summer, I ran a workshop where campers built small catapults out of craft materials and spare parts from the junk pile. We personalized them a bit and then had fun firing them at each other. 

After the session, I asked the participants for feedback and the response was, "add Arduino".  So, welcome to v. 2.0 of the catapult workshop where we will design and build small catapults that utilize Arduinos in some capacity. 

Bring your design chops, creativity, and get ready for the next level of miniature siege warfare at ITP Camp. No experience needed. Please bring an Arduino, 

Slide deck for the class can be found here:

https://bit.ly/2MGvay2

Please bring along an Arduino and breadboard!

Thanks.

title: Intro to Photogrammetry: Turning yourself into a 3D model and twerking in a virtual environment
description:
Still using Maya, Blender, or other 3d modeling software to make 3d avatars of yourself or your friends? With the software like Metashape (Photoscan Pro), we only need an iPhone, or tbh any kinds of phone or camera to turn 2d photos into a wholesome 3d model! 

In this workshop, we will explore the idea of photogrammetry by seeing different sample works and introducing photogrammetry software. Then, we will pair up at the workshop and take photos of each other in groups. This workshop will focus on Metashape (former PhotoScan) to build the 3D model of our own. We will also cover Mixamo in this workshop, a powerful tool to animate your model and make you twerk or do any other weird things in the virtual environment.

title: Educator's Meetup
description: Meet, greet, brainstorm, share project or documentation ideas.  There are many project oriented, Maker Ed teachers at the camp, it would be great to share ideas and perhaps collaborate on projects.

title: ðŸŒˆ Inclusive Grid System Design
description:
# Grid system is the crucial foundation of outstanding visual design works

Learning to design a well-structured grid system helps the designer creating a more inclusive and user-friendly layout, which is especially crucial in this international world. At the same time, the invisible grid definitely makes designing balanced and elegant layout easier. 

- No prerequisite knowledge is required!

- Good-to-have but not required materials: 
1. Pencil, eraser and ruler
2. Laptop with Adobe Illustrator, Sketch or other vector graphic drawing softwares you're comfortable with

title: A brief history of (alternative) bicycle design
description:
I'm a huge bike nerd and would like to share what I've learned over the years about bicycle designs and the fascinating people and politics that influenced it. 

You can check out the presentation I'll be going through here (link below) and I'll be focusing on how each design innovation and technological advance impacted the experience of riding bikes and the bike world as a whole. 


https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1cH37CJi8yr080XE_dkaCphhe2ltrCQbOQS4_5eB0q40/edit?usp=sharing

title: LASER CUTTING A PHONOGRAPH RECORD: dropping your single on acrylic
description:
This session will culminate with each participant laser engraving their own custom acrylic phonograph record. Before we get to the actual lasering, we will go over the way that digital and analog audio works, the physics of sound & sound recording, the constraints of using a laser cutter for this off-label purpose, and the code that makes it all happen (which will be made available online for future use).

We will cut one camper's record as a class so we can go over the process with the laser cutter, but then everyone can cut their own records after the session has taken place.

Programming experience will make this session easier, but if you have none, you'll still be able to get a record made! :)

There will be a cap on enrollment for this session, but we may run another later if there is interest, so let us know!

Before you come to this session, it would be ideal to take care of the following:

1. Remember to bring your computer and a USB drive.
2. You have already taken the laser cutter training (not mandatory, but encouraged)
3. You have downloaded Processing [https://processing.org/download/](https://processing.org/download/)
4. You have downloaded and installed the sound, minim, and svg libraries [https://processing.org/reference/libraries/](https://processing.org/reference/libraries/)
5. Download [audacity](https://sourceforge.net/projects/audacity/) or another audio editing application
6. Download the processing [repo](https://github.com/jesse-harding/phonography_tools) for this session

I'll bring materials for this quick demo. To make you're own work you'll need a vector program (Illustrator) and the Cutting Master plug-in for the plotter.

If you're interested but the time doesn't work for you, please let me know and we can add another session.

Molly

title: Come kick my ass in ping pong TONIGHT at Fat Cat!! (after social hour...)
description:
Hey, hey, hey, ITP camp fam! It's finally FRIDAY!! Woo hoo! :)  
FatCat is one of my fave haunts near ITP and I want to share this gem with new campers!! Some of you from last year's camp might remember our EPIC 5 hrs there of ping pong, drinking and bonding! LET'S DO IT AGAIN and make new memories!! 

I'll be there around 7:30pm to get a ping pong table so you don't have to wait when you come! I'll get 4 paddles and everyone can take turns playing and hanging. We'll also have a play off... Chris and Chris (Davis, aka, "the other Chris") haha! 

You won't want to miss this!! I hope people just come whenever because I won't be able to hang with everyone b/c  I have to go to DC from Thurs - Mon for work, etc. I want to get to know more of you, and hang after our long week! 

It's less than a 10 min walk from ITP. The address is 75 Christopher at 7th Ave. 
Here's the link for anyone who is new (there's something for everyone to enjoy!)    http://fatcatmusic.org/gaming.html

title: Field Trip: NYC Resistor
description:
NYC Resistor is a hacker collective with a shared space located in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. It's a great place to plug into if you're local to NYC, and are looking for a hybrid technology/art space and public access to to digital tools (3D printers, laser cutter, vinyl cutter, embroidery machine, etc).  It's also a fun place for out-of-town visitors to check out if you're generally interested in hackerspaces. 

Our community is inclusive of a variety of different professions and personal backgrounds, including crafters, creative technologists, engineers of every kind, designers and both part-time and full-time artists. We also foster a mix of skill levels, ranging from beginners to seasoned experts.

The Code of Conduct, as well as accessibility information, can be found at www.nycresistor.com/participate/

This field trip will be lead by NYC Resistor Member Kari Love, and will leave from ITP just after 7. For folks wanting to meet us at the space, the tour will be during Craft Night (one of the twice weekly free public nights) which starts at 7:30pm. So feel free to meet us there at:
87 3rd Avenue, 
4th Floor 
Brooklyn, NY 11217

If you'd like to bring a project along to hang out, Craft Night runs until the last member is tired and needs to go home (officially 10:30, but often later)!

title: Visualizing Audio with p5.js
description:
Did you come to the camp's first [Friday Fireside](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2019/session/7)? Did you like the audio visualization projection?

Come by to learn how to create audio triggered visualization with [p5.js](https://p5js.org/) and [p5.sound.js](https://p5js.org/reference/#/libraries/p5.sound). We will learn how to connect an audio input (such as microphone and music playing from your computer) to use its amplitude and frequency spectrum to create real-time visualization! This session will provide fundamental concepts of using audio input in p5.js and also cover some tricks that will enhance your p5.js visualizations (if you didn't know them already).
